alphabetical letter $ *
The thirteenth letter of the alphabet: called $iynN. It is one of the letters termed mahomuwsap [or non-vocal, i. e. pronounced with the breath only, without the voice]; and of the letters termed $ajoriy~ap, (TA,) from Al$~ajoru, which means “ the place of the opening of the mouth. ” (TA on the letter j. See also $iyonN in art. $yn.) It is sometimes substituted for the affixed pronoun of the second pers. fem., ki; as in raA^ayotu$i for raA^ayotuki, and as in the following verse,
faEayonaA$i EayonaAhaA wajiydu$i jiyduhaA
wal`kin~a Als~aAqi mino$i raqiyqu
[And thy two eyes are her two eyes, and thy neck is her neck; but the bone of thy shank is slender]; i. e. EayonaAka and jiyoduki and minoki: this substitution for the affixed pronoun of the second pers. fem. is of dial. of Benoo-'Amr and Temeem; and is not restricted to cases of pausation, as is shown by the verse above cited, though some assert it to be so: it is also substituted for the k of diyk, when with kesr, so that they said diy$K: also for jK, as in mudam~a$N[or mudoma$N], for mudam~ajN [or mudomajN]: and for s, as in jaEo$uw$N, for jaEosuwsN. (MF. [See also De Sacy's Chrest, Arabe, sec. ed., iii. 530-31.]) -A2- [As a numeral, it denotes Three hundred.]

$uw^obuwbN *
A shower, or fall, or what pours forth at once or without intermission, of rain (S, A, O, K) &c.: (S, O:) or of rain with hail; for otherwise this term is not applied to rain: (ISd, TA:) pl. $aA=biybu: (S, A, O, K: *) this is the pl. of $uw^obuwbN (K, TA) in all its senses: (TA:) or rain that falls upon one place and misses another; like najowN and najaA='N. (AZ, TA.) ― -b2- [A thin, not wide, cloud, of which the rain falls with vehemence. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)] ― -b3- A heat, or an unintermitted act, of running. (TA.) ― -b4- Sharpness, vehemence, force, or strength, of anything: (K:) violence, or vehemence, of impetus or pushing or driving, (S, A, O, K,) of rain, (A,) or of anything. (K.) Kaab Ibn-Zuheyr says, speaking of a he-ass and she-asses,
A_i*aA maA A@notaHaAhun~a $uw^obuwbuhu
raA^ayota lijaAEiratayohi guDuwnaA
i. e. When he runs vehemently [towards them, or rather when his vehemence of running is directed towards them], thou seest a wrinkling [or wrinkles] in his jaAEirataAni [dual of jaAEirapN, q. v.]. (S, O.) ― -b5- The first appearance [or bloom] of beauty. (K.) One says of a girl, or young woman, A_in~ahaA laHasanahu $aA=biybi Alwajohi Verily she is goodly in respect of the first appearances [or bloomings] of beauty of countenance in the eye of the beholder. (O.) ― -b6- The vehemence of the heat of the sun. (K.) ― -b7- And The Tariyqap of the sun: (K:) $aA=biybu Al$~amosi signifies the lines, or streaks, (TaraAy^iq,) of the sun when it rises. (O.) ― -b8- $aA=biybu AlS~amogi What flows, of the [manna, or gum, called] migofar [q. v.], and remains like strings, or threads, between the trees and the ground. (T, L.) [See also maEaAbiybu.]

$ay^iytN * A horse that has a habit of stumbling; or that stumbles often: (S, K:) it has no corresponding verb: and accord. to As, it signifies (S) a horse whose hind hoofs fall short of reaching [the spots that have been trodden by] his fore hoofs: (S, K:) [but see $abuwbN:] pl. $uw^uwtN. (TA.) [See also A^aHaq~u.]

1 $ay^ifato rijoluhu * , (S, O, K,) aor.
$aAa^a , (K,) inf. n. $aA^afN; (S, O;) and $uy^ifato rjlh; (O, K;) His foot became affected with an ulcer, or imposthume, such as is termed $aA^ofapN, breaking out in it. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- Accord. to some, (O,) $aA^fu AljuroHi (O, K, [in my MS. copy of the K $aA^ofu, and so accord. to the TK, and in the CK without ', but I think that the right reading is $aA^afu, and that its verb is $ay^ifa, or it may be $aA^ofu, and inf. n. of $uy^ifa,]) signifies The wound's becoming in a corrupt state, so that it will hardly, or not at all, be cured. (O, K.) ― -b3- $ay^ifa Sadoruhu EalaY~a His bosom bore concealed enmity and violent hatred, or rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, against me. (TA.) ― -b4- $ay^ifato A^aSaAbiEuhu, (Az, O, K,) or yaduhu, (M, TA,) His fingers, or his hand, became cracked, or disintegrated, in the parts around the nails; (Az, M, O, K;) as also say^ifato, (O, TA,) and saEifato: so say AZ and IAar, and in like manner says Th. (TA.) -A2- $ay^ifotuhu, (S, O, K,) and $ay^ifotu lahu, (AZ, O, K,) aor.
$aAa^a , (K,) inf. n. $aA^ofN, (S, O, K,) in the Bári' $aA^afN, with fet-h to the ', (TA,) and $aA=fapN; (O, K;) and $ay^ifotu minohu, inf. n. $aA^ofN, omitted in the K [and S, and O], but correct, as Sgh has indicated in the Tekmileh; (TA;) I hated him; (S, O, K;) like $anifotu lahu; (S and O in art. $nf;) namely, a man: (S, O:) or the first and second signify, (K,) or the first also signifies accord. to IAar, (O,) I feared, when I saw him, namely, a man, that I should smite him with an evil eye, or should guide against him one whom he disliked, or hated; (O;) or I feared that he would smite me with an evil eye, or I guided against him one whom he disliked, or hated. (K.) ― -b2- And $uy^ifa He (a man, A'Obeyd, O) was frightened, or afraid. (A'Obeyd, O, K.)

10 Aisota$oA^afato * , said of a quroSap, [so in the TA, an evident mistranscription, app. for qaroHap, and so in the next paragraph, i. e. an ulcer, or imposthume,] means SaAra lahaA A^aSolN [It had, or acquired, root, or rootedness, or permanence; as though it became a $aA^ofap]. (TA.)

$ay^ifN * [part. n. of $ay^ifa, and properly meaning Having an ulcer, or imposthume, such as is termed $aA^ofap,] is applied as an epithet to a heart, in the following verse, cited by IKtt,
yaA A^ay~uhaA AljaAhilu A^al~aA tanoSarifo
walamo tudaAwi quroSapa Alqalobi Al$~ay^ifo
[in which quroSapa is doubtless a mistranscription (like that in the next preceding paragraph) for qaroHapa; the obvious meaning of the verse being, (assumed tropical:) O thou ignorant one, wherefore wilt not thou revert, when thou hast not cured the sore of an ulcerated heart?]. (TA.)

$o'ANfp *
Original text has hamza and sukun above sheen. An ulcer, or imposthume, (qaroHapN,) that breaks out in the bottom of the foot, and is cauterized, (S, IAth, O, K,) or is cut, (Yaakoob, IAth, O,) and goes away; (Yaakoob, S, IAth, O, K;) and the word is also pronounced without ' [i. e. $aAfapN]: (IAth, TA:) or an ulcer, or imposthume, in the foot of a person, who dies if it is cut: (O, K:) and it is also said to be a tumour in the hand, and foot, from the entering of a piece of wood, or stick, into the flesh of the foot, or the palm of the hand, and its remaining therein, so
that the place swells, and becomes large. (TA.) AisotaA^oSala A@ll~`hu $aA^ofatahu (S, O, K) is a prov. (S, O) meaning (assumed tropical:) May God cause him to go away like as the $A^fp above mentioned goes away: (S, O, K:) or this means may God extirpate him: for ― -b2- $aA^ofapN is also syn. with A^aSolN [i. e. Root, &c.]: (O, K:) so says Sh. (O.) [See also 10 in art. ASl: and see what here follows.] ― -b3- It is also said to signify The family and household of a man: and hence the form of imprecation, AisotaA^oSala A@ll~`hu $aA^ofatahumo [May God extirpate their family and household]. (TA.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) Enmity. (TA.)
$aA^afapN * , thus with fet-h to the ', is an epithet applied to a man, meaning Mighty, potent, powerful, or strong; inaccessible, or difficult of access. (TA.)

rijolN ma$ow^uwfapN *
A foot affected with an ulcer, or imposthume, such as is termed saA^ofapN, breaking out in it: (O, K:) from $uy^ifato rijoluhu. (O, * K, * TA.) ― -b2- And ma$ow^uwfN, from $uy^ifa, Frightened, or afraid; (A'Obeyd, O, K;) applied to a man. (A'Obeyd, O.)

1 $uy^ima Ealayohimo * (S; MA, K,) inf. n. $uw^omN, (MA,) He (a man, S) was, or became, unlucky, or inauspicious, (SaAra $uw^omFA, S, K, in the MA $wm $d,) to them: (S, MA, K;) as also $aA^amahumo, and $aA^ama Elyhm, and $aw^uma Elyhm: (K:) or $aA^amahumo, (AZ, Ham p. 224,) or $aA^ama Ealayohimo, (S,) or both of these, (TA,) aor.
$aAa^a , (S, TA,) inf. n. $aA^omN, (TA,) he drew upon them ill luck, or evil fortune; (S, TA;) or caused ill luck, or evil fortune, to befall them from him: (AZ, Ham ubi suprà, TA:) or $uw^umN as an inf. n. signifies the being unlucky: and the rendering unlucky: and so $uwmN [as it is commonly pronounced: see $uw^umN below]. (KL.) -A2- And $aA^amahumo, inf. n. $aA^omN, so in the L; in the K, ↓ $aA^~amahumo, inf. n. ta$oy^iymN; but the former is the right; (TA;) He made them to go, or journey, to Al$~aA^om [i. e. Syria]. (K, TA.)
2 $aA~a^a see what next precedes.

3 $aAy^imo biA^aSoHaAbika *
Take thou the direction of the left hand with thy companions: (S, K, TA:) yaAmino signifies “ take thou the direction of the right hand. ” (TA.) ― -b2- And $aA=ma He (a man) came to Al$~aA^om [i. e. Syria]: like yaAmana signifying “ he came to El-Yemen. ” (TA. [See also 4.])

4 A$A^m *
He desired the left: like as A^ayomana signifies “ he desired the right. ” (TA in art. ymn.) ― -b2- And He (a man, S) came to Al$~aA^om [i. e. Syria]: (S, K, TA: [see also 3:]) or he went thither: and A^ayomana signifies “ he came to El-Yemen. ” (TA.) -A2- maA A^a$oA^amahu (S, K, TA) How unlucky, or inauspicious, is he! (TA:) the vulgar say, maA A^ayo$amahu. (S, TA.)

5 t$A^~m bihi * , (MA, TA,) from Al$~uw^omu, (TA,) He found him, or it, unlucky, or inauspicious: and he became unlucky by means of him, or it: (MA:) or t$A^~m signifies he had ill luck, or evil fortune. (KL.) See also 6. ― -b2- And t$A^~m He took the direction of his left hand: (K, TA:) and in like manner tayaAmana, [whence it seems that t$A^~m in the sense expl. above may be a mistake for ↓ t$A='m,] “ he took the direction of his right hand. ” (TA.) ― -b3- And He asserted his relationship to [the people of] Al$~aA^om [i. e. Syria]: (S, K:) a verb similar to tkw~f and tqy~S. (S.)

6 t$A='mwA bihi * , (S, Msb, K, TA, &c.,) in some of the copies of the K ↓ t$A^~mwA, (TA,) [and in like manner t$A^~m bihi, which is often opposed to tayam~ana bihi, (see an instance in Bd xvii. 14,) is used in the K in art. ETs, and t$A^~m minohu in the TA in the same art. as on the authority of IKh, whence it seems that both these verbs are correct in the sense here following, though the former is probably preferable, and bihi ↓ Ast$A^m is used in the same manner in “ Les Oiseaux et les Fleurs, ” p. 83, as mentioned by Freytag, so that t$A^~m bh and Ast$A^m are the contr. of tym~n bh and Astymn,] They augured evil from him, or it; regarded him, or it, as an evil omen; (Msb, KL; *) like taTay~aruwA bihi: (Msb:) deemed him, or it, unlucky, or inauspicious. (KL.) ― -b2- t$A='m, thus, with medd, also signifies He took the direction of Al$~aA^om[i. e. Syria]. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 5.
10 A_isota$oAa^a see the next preceding paragraph.

Al$~aA^omu * , the name of a certain country [i. e. Syria], is masc. and fem.; (S;) sometimes masc.: (K:) and may also be pronounced Al$~aAmu [as it commonly is in the present day]. (Msb.) ― -b2- [And as this country lies on the north of Arabia, Al$~aA^omu also signifies The northern region; opposed to Alyamanu.]

$uw^omN * , (S, Msb, K, &c.,) thus, with ', but always pronounced $uwmN, without ', (TA,) is an inf. n.: (MA, KL: [see 1, first sentence, in two places:]) and signifies [as a simple subst.] Unluckiness, inauspiciousness, unfortunateness, unprosperousness, evil fortune, or ill luck; contr. of yumonN; (S, K;) [i. e.] i. q. aHosN: (Har p. 158:) evil [of any kind]; syn. $ar~N: (Msb:) [and particularly] an evil omen: (PS:) and ↓ ma$oA^amapN signifies the same as $uw^omN: (TA:) [or, like manoHasapN, a cause of unluckiness, &c.:] ma$aAy^imu is a pl. of $uw^omN, [or of ↓ ma$oA^amapN: if of the former,] irreg., like as its syn. manaAHisu is [said to be] of naHosN. (TA in art. nHs.) It is said in a trad., A_ino kaAna Al$~uwomu fafiY valaAv K AlmaroA^api waAld~aAri waAlfarasi, meaning If there be that whereof the consequence is disliked, or hated, and feared, [or if there be unluckiness,] it is in three things, the wife, and the house, and the horse: i. e., if any of you have a wife whose companionship he dislikes, or a house in which he dislikes dwelling, or a horse that he dislikes taking for the purpose of keeping post on the enemies' frontier, let him separate himself therefrom, by divorcing the wife, and removing from the house, and selling the horse: or, as some say, the $w^m of the wife is her not producing children; and that of the house, its straitness, and the badness of its neighbour; and that of the horse, one's not going to war upon it. (JM.) ― -b2- See also ma$ow^uwmN. -A2- Also Black camels: and HiDaArN signifies “ white ” camels, (K, TA,) and is also written and pronounced HaDaArN: (TA:) neither of these has a sing.: (K:) both occur in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb: but accord. to one reading thereof it is $iym; pl. of A^a$oyamu: so says AA: and IJ says that $uwmN, [without ',] being originally $uyomN, of the measure fuEolN, may also be pl. of A^a$oyamu. (TA.)

$aA^omapN * and ↓ ma$oA^amapN The left, meaning the left side or direction or relative location or place; (S, K;) i. q. [yasorapN and] mayosarapN; (S;) contr. of yamonapN and mayomanapN. (K.) One says of a man, qaEada $A^omapN [He sat on the left]. (S.) And one says, xu*o bihimo $aA^omapF i. e. [Take thou with them] the direction of the left hand. (S.) And naZarotu yamonapF wa$aA^omapF [I looked in a right direction and in a left direction]. (TA.) And hence ↓ A^aSoHaAbu Alma$oA^amapi, in the Kur [lvi. 9 and xc. 19], (TA,) meaning [The occupants of the left: or] those who shall have their records given to them in their left hands: or the occupants of the low, or ignoble, place, or station: or the havers of unfortunateness (Al$~uw^om): and A^aSoHaAbu Almayomanapi is expl. as having the contr. senses. (Ksh and Bd in lvi. 9.) -A2- Also, the former, A mole (xaAlN) upon the person: thus, with ', as mentioned by IAth: also mentioned without ' in art. $ym. (TA.) ― -b2- See also $aAmapN as meaning “ a black she-camel, ” in art. $ym.

$iy^omapN *
Nature; natural, native, or innate, disposition, temper, or other quality or property: (K, TA:) mentioned thus, as with ', by AZ and Lh, and said by IJ to be sometimes thus pronounced; but the pronunciation thereof with ' is held by ISd to be extraordinary. (TA.) [See art. $ym.]

$aAmiY~N * , (S, Msb, K, TA,) without ', (TA,) and ↓ $aA=mK, (S, Msb, K,) of the measure faEaAlK, (S,) an allowable form, without Y, (Msb,) like tahaAmK and yamaAnK, (TA,) and ↓ $aA=miY~N, (Sb, S, K,) [Syrian;] of, or relating to, Al$~aA^om: (S, Msb, K:) one should not say $aA^omK; any instance [of this] occurring by poetic license being accounted for as a case of the use of the name of the country for the rel. n.: (S:) the fem., applied to a woman, is $aAmiy~apN and ↓ $aA=miyapN, the latter without teshdeed: (S, TA;) the pl. of $aAmiY~N is $uwaAmN, like guraAbN [in measure]. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence, Northern.]
$aA=mK * , and $aA=miyapN the fem. of the former; and
$aA=miY~N * : see the next preceding paragraph.
$aAy^imN * : see ma$ow^uwmN.

A^a$oA^amu * [More, and most, unlucky, inauspicious, unfortunate, or unprosperous]. The Arabs say,
A^a$oA^amu kul~i A@moriy^ K bayona laHoyayohi, (Meyd, TA,) as some relate it, or, as others relate it, fak~ayohi, which means the same, (Meyd,) [app. meaning accord. to the TA, The most unlucky thing of every man is between his two jaws, or the two lateral portions of his lower jaw; but it is said that] A^a$oA^amu is here used in the sense of $uw^omN [i. e. the unluckiness, &c.]; and in a similar manner [the contr.] A^ayomanu is used [in the sense of yumon]: so says AHeyth: (Meyd:) the prov. meaning the tongue. (AHeyth, TA.) The fem. is $uw^omaY. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) Alyadu Al$~uw^omaY The left hand or arm; contr. of AlyumonaY; (K, TA;) i. q. Al$~imaAlu. (TA.) It is said in a trad., respecting camels, laA yaA^otiY xayoruhaA A_il~aA mino jaAnibihaA AlA^a$oA^ami [Their goodness comes not save from their left side]: i. e. they are milked and mounted only from the left side. (TA.) ― -b3- See also ma$ow^uwmN, in three places. ― -b4- Zuheyr, in the following saying,
fatunotajo lakumo gilomaAna A^a$oA^ama kul~uhumo
kaA^aHomari EaAd K vum~a turoDiEo fatafoTimo
uses it in the sense of the inf. n. $uw^om; (S;) meaning gilomaAna $uw^omK: (S, and EM p. 124:) he says, And it, i. e. war, will bring forth for you boys of ill luck, or evil omen; all of them like Ahmar of' Ád: then it will suckle these boys, and wean them: by Ahmar of ' Ád, he means Ahmar of Thamood, for Ahmar was the surname of him who hamstrung the she-camel of Sálih, and his name was Kudár: he says thus for the sake of the measure: or, as some say, Thamood were called 'Ád-el-Ákhireh. (EM.)
ma$oA^amapN * : see $uw^omN, in two places: ― -b2- and see also $aA^omapN, likewise in two places.

ma$ow^uwmN * , (S, MA, K, KL,) and ma$uwmN, (S, K,) the latter like maquwlN, (TA,) [a contraction of the former,] Unlucky, or inauspicious, (S, MA, K, KL,) EaY qawomihi [to his people, or party], (S, MA, K,) and EalaY nafosihi [to himself]: (Ksh and Bd in lvi. 9:) [and so ↓ $uw^omN; (as in an ex. in the first sentence of this art.;) this being an epithet as well as a subst., like its syn. naHosN; syn. with ma$ow^uwmN, like as naHosN is syn. with manoHuwsN; and app., like naHosN, used alike as sing. and pl., for it seems to be originally an inf. n.:] and so ↓ $aAy^imN; (K;) or this signifies drawing ill luck, or evil fortune, upon his people [and upon himself]: (S, TA:) and A^a$aAy^imu, a pl., likewise signifies unlucky, or inauspicious; (KL;) contr. of A^ayaAminu; (S, K, TA;) these being pls. of ↓ A^a$oA^amu and A^ayomanu: (TA:) the pl. of ma$ow^uwmN is ma$aAy^iymu, (S, KL, TA,) which is extr., for by rule it should be ma$ow^uwmuwna. (TA.) One says also ↓ TaAy^irN A^a$oA^amu meaning [An omen] happening, or occurring, (jaArK,) with unluckiness, or inauspiciousness; [i. e. an unlucky, or inauspicious, omen;] (K, TA;) and [in like manner] ↓ TayorN A^a$oA^amu: and the pl. is A^a$aAy^imu [as above]. (TA.)

1 $aA^anotu $aA^onahu *
i. q. qaSadotu qaSodahu [meaning I pursued his (another's) way, or course, doing as he did]; (S, L, K: * in the K, $aA^ana $aA^onahu and qaSada qaSodahu;) and in like manner one says, $aA^onahu ↓ A$tA^n. (K.) ― -b2- And Ai$oA^ano $aA^onaka Do thou what thou dost well. (S, L, K. *) And Keep thou to thy affair. (IAar, L.) ― -b3- And maA $aA^ana $aA^onahu He did not know, or had not knowledge of, him, or his affair or case or state: (Lh, IAar, L, K:) [from a passage in the L, imperfectly written, it seems, accord. to Lh, to be said of one who does what another likes or dislikes, app. without regard to his liking it or disliking it, agreeably with what here follows:] or (K) this means, (S, K,) or means also, (L,) he did not care for, mind, heed, or regard, him. (S, L, K. [In the S and L, the verb in the sense thus expl. is in the first pers.: and in one place in the L it is expl. by A^araAda, which often has this meaning.]) One says also, laA^a$oA^ann~a $aA^onahumo, meaning I will assuredly know, or try, prove, or test, (laA^axoburan~a,) their affair or case or state: (L:) or this means I will assuredly corrupt, or pervert, or mar, their affair or case or state: (S, L, K: *) and laA^a$oA^anan~a xabarahu, (L,) or xabarahumo, (K,) means I will assuredly know, or try, prove, or test, [his, or their, state, or] him, or them. (L, K. [In the CK and in my MS. copy of the K, laAuxobiran~ahumo, is erroneously put for laA^axoburan~ahumo.]) -A2- $aA^ana baEodaka means SaAra lahu $aA^onN [i. e., app., He became a person to whom importance attached (accord. to the general meaning of lahu $aA^onN) after thou knewest, or sawest, or mettest, him; baEodaka being for baEoda Eahodika bihi, agreeably with common usage]. (K.)

4 A$A^n $aA^onahumo * is mentioned by Golius as meaning “ Corrupit ac pervertit rem eorum, ” as on the authority of the S, (the right reading in which has been given above,) and on that of the KL, in my copy of which I find nothing of the sort.]
8 A_i$otaAa^a see 1, first sentence.

$aA^onN *
A thing, an affair, or a business; syn. A^amorN; (S, L, K;) and xaTobN [in the same sense, or in that next following]: (L, K:) a great thing or affair: (Har p. 274:) state, condition, case, quality, or manner of being; syn. HaAlN: (S, L:) [also property, or nature: and importance attaching to a person or thing:] pl. $uw^uwnN and $iy^aAnN, (L, K,) the latter mentioned by IJ on the authority of AAF, and $uwnN occurs in poetry for the former of these, or as another pl. originally $uw^onN, of the measure fuEolN. (L.) It is said in the Kur [lv. 29], kul~a yam K huwa fiY $aA^onK [Every day He is employing Himself in an affair of some kind]: expl. as meaning that, of his business (mino $aA^onihi [which may also be rendered “ of his property ”]) it is to render mighty one who is brought low, and to bring low one who is mighty, and to enrich one who is poor, and to impoverish one who is rich; and no affair occupies him so as to divert him from an affair (laA ya$oEaluhu $aA^onN Eano $aA^onK). (L.) [And one says, maA $aA^onuka What is thy affair? or what is thy case? And $aA^onaka, for Ai$oA^ano $aA^onaka i. e. Pursue thy way or course, or thy affair; or do what thou dost well; or keep to thy affair: or the like: and to this is often added, wamaA turiydu i. e. and what thou wilt, or wishest, or desirest. And mino $aA^onihi A^ano yafoEala ka*aA It is of his business, or of his property, or nature, to do, or that he should do, such a thing. And rajulN saholu Al$~aA^oni (a phrase occurring in the S and K in art. h$) A man of easy nature. And lahu $aA^onN, sometimes meaning There is for him, or he has, a great thing or affair to perform or transact: but more commonly, great importance attaches to him, or to it: see 1, last sentence. And a grandee, or a prince, is said to be EaZiymu Al$~aA^oni i. e. Of great importance or rank or dignity.] -A2- Also [A suture of the skull; i. e.] the place of junction of the qabaAy^il [or principal bones, namely, the frontal, occipital, and two parietal, bones,] of the head: (K:) sing. of $uw^uwnN, (Mgh,) which signifies the places of junction, (As, S, Mgh, L,) and of meeting, (S, L,) of the qabaAy^il (As, S, Mgh, L) of the head; (S, L;) between every two of which qbAy^l is a $aA^on: (As, L:) [it is fancifully said that] from them come the tears: (As, S, L:) the pl. is also expl. as meaning the salaAsil [i. e. sutures as being likened to the slAsl (or lines) of writing] that unite the qbAy^l: by Lth, as the namaAnim [likewise meaning sutures resembling lines of writing] of the skull; between the qbAy^l: by AHát, as the $uEab [meaning serrated edges] that unite the qbAy^l of the head. (L.) ― -b2- And The channel by which the tears flow, or run, to the eye: pl. [of pauc.] A^a$ow^unN and [of mult.] $uw^uwnN: (L, K:) [perhaps thus called because supposed to come from the sutures of the skull: but they may have been supposed to come thence because tears are called maA='u Al$~uw^uwni (as in a verse cited voce rasama); for this phrase may have been misunderstood as signifying “ the water of the sutures of the skull, ” whereas it seems to be properly rendered “ the water of the channels of the tears: ”] it is said that the $uw^uwn connect the qbAy^l of the head [expl. above] to the eye: Lth says that they are the ducts (Euruwq) of the tears from [the interior of] the head to the eye: and Th, that they are certain ducts (Erwq) above the qbAy^l, which become strong by degrees as the man advances in age: (L: [but it seems that Th has confounded explanations of $w^wn in two different senses:]) accord. to ISk, (S,) or AA and others, (L,) the $aA^onaAni are two ducts (EiroqaAni) descending from [the upper part of] the head to the eyebrows and then to the eyes. (S, L.) ― -b3- [The pl. $uw^uwnN is also expl. as though meaning Tears themselves, in a phrase mentioned voce *ay^irN (q. v.), on the authority of the K.] ― -b4- And $uw^uwnN Alxamori means (assumed tropical:) The effluvia of wine that creep (maA dab~a mina Alxamori) in the veins of the body. (L.) ― -b5- $aA^onN also signifies A vein of earth in a mountain, (L, K,) i. e. a cleft therein, (L,) in which palm-trees are
planted; (L, K;) or in which trees of the kind called naboE grow; or that produces plants, or herbage: (L:) pl. $uw^uwnN: (L, K:) which is said by ISd to mean lines, or streaks, in a mountain: or, as some say, cracks, or clefts: and to these cracks, or clefts, the poet Keys Ibn-Kuráa likens [imaginary] clefts in the liver, occasioned by love. (L.)

A_in~ahu lami$oA^anu $aA^on K A^ano nufosidaka * is a saying mentioned by Lh, expl. [only] by the words AY An nEml fY fsAdk [i. e. A^ano naEomala fiY fasaAdika, app. meaning Verily he is busying himself in the doing of a thing in order that we may labour in causing thee to be in a bad, or corrupt, state]. (L.)
$aAhobal~uwT * [a Pers. word, and also used by the Arabs in the present day, applied to The chestnut]: also written $aAho bal~uwT. (TA voce bal~uwTN and voce jamalN.)

$aAhiynN *
A certain well-known bird, (K, TA,) of those that prey; (Msb, * TA;) it is of the birds called Suquwr [pl. of SaqorN], as are also the baA$aq and the baAziY and the zur~aq and the yuw^oyuw^; (AHát in “ the Book of Birds, ” TA in art. b$q;) [said by Golius, on the authority of Dmr, to be the white falcon; and to this bird it is perhaps applied by some of the Arabs; but some of them, I believe most of them, and I believe also that they do so most properly, apply this appellation in the present day to the gerfalcon, which is not wholly white; and some, to the falcon gentle:] the word is [of Pers. origin,] not genuine Arabio; (TA;) it is an arabicized word: the pl. is $awaAhiynu, and sometimes $ayaAhiynu is used in its stead, formed by substituion [of Y for w] for facilitating the pronunciation. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) The Eamuwd [meaning beam] of the balance. (K.) ― -b3- And i. q. SanojapN [which signifies A balance, and a steelyard, and a weight of a balance]: so in the Expos. of the “ Muwatta. ” (MF, TA.)

1 $aA^awotu Alqawoma * , (AZ, S,) aor.
$aAu^a , (JM, PS,) or
$aAa^a , (Ham p. 786,) inf. n. $aA^owN, (AZ, S, K,) I preceded, or outwent, the people, or party. (AZ, S, K. *) Accord. to [several of] the copies of the K, $aA='ahu i. e. like $aAEahu in measure, which is incorrect, [in other copies ↓ $aA='aAhu, agreeably with what is said in the S,] signifies He strove, or contended, with him to precede him, or outgo him: or he preceded him, or outwent him: but in the S it is said, $aA='aAhu, of the measure faAEalahu, signifies he strove, or contended, with him to precede him, or outgo him: and $aA='ahu like $aA^aAhu, [the former belonging to art. $wA^ and] formed by transposition, signifies he preceded him, or outwent him; and both of these are used by the poet (El-Hárith Ibn-Khálid El-Makhzoomee, TA) in his saying,
mar~a AlHuduwju wamaA $aA^awonaka naqorapF
walaqado A^araAka tu$aA='u biAlA^aZoEaAni
this [passage in the S], however, is taken from what is said by A'Obeyd, in [his work] “ ElGhareeb el-Musannaf, ” which is as follows: $aA='aniY AlA^amoru, like $aAEaniY [in measure], and $aA=niY, like $aEaAniY, mean the affair, or event, grieved me; and thus in the verse of El-Hárith Ibn-Khálid, which he cites; and the same is said in the T on the authority of IAar, who says that the poet has used two dial. vars.: [accordingly the verse may be rendered, The camels with their saddles upon them passed along and they grieved thee not at all; but I see thee that thou art grieved by the women borne in the camel-vehicles:] it is said in the M, $aA='aniY Al$~aYo'u means the thing preceded me, or outwent me: and also the thing grieved me: formed by transposition from $aA=niY, as is proved by its having no inf. n.: IAar says that they are two dial. vars. because of his not being a grammarian. (TA.) [See also 8.] -A2- And $aA^awotu Albiy^ora, (Lh, TA,) or $A^wt mina Albiy^ori, (S,) inf. n. $aA^owN, (K, TA,) I drew forth the earth from the well: (S, K: *) or I drew forth a basketful of earth ($aA^owFA) or two basketfuls of earth ($aA^owayoni) from the well. (Lh, TA.)

3 $aA='aAhu * : see 1. yu$aAwiY occurs in a verse of Milhah El-Jarmee, meaning yusaAbiqu, from $aA^owN meaning TalaqN: one says $aA^aAhu, aor. ya$oA^aAhu, meaning sabaqahu: but the verb of the measure regularly formed from Al$~aA^owu is $aA='Y; so that y$AwY is formed by transposition and by the change of the ' into Y. (Ham p. 786.)

6 ta$aA='aY maA bayonahumaA * , (S, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, ta$AwaY,]) like ta$aAEaY [in measure], (S,) The space between them two became farextending. (S, K.) ― -b2- And t$A='Y Alqawomu The people, or party, became scattered, or dispersed. (S, K.)

8 Ai$otaA^aY *
He preceded, or outwent: (S, K:) so says El-Mufaddal. (S.) ― -b2- And He gave ear, hearkened, or listened. (S, K.)

$aA^owN * The utmost extent, term, limit, point, reach, or goal. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And A heat, or single run to a goal or limit: so in the saying, EadaA $aA^owFA (S) or jaraY $aA^owFA (Msb) [He (a horse, TA) ran a heat]. ― -b3- And i. q. him~apN: thus in the saying, A_in~ahu labaEiydu Al$~aA^owi (assumed tropical:) [Verily he is far-aiming, or far-aspiring, in purpose, desire, or ambition]: (Lh, TA:) and saA^owN is a dial. var. thereof. (TA.) -A2- Also A [basket such as is termed] zabiyl; and so ↓ mi$oA=pN: (K:) or ↓ zabiyl in which the earth of a well is taken forth; of the measure of mi$oEaApN; and the pl. is ma$aA='K: (S:) and $aA^owN signifies, (S,) or signifies also, (K,) the earth that is taken forth from a well (S, K) with the like of the mi$oA=p, (as in a copy of the S,) or such as fills the m$oA=p: (so in another copy of the S [agreeably with what next follows]:) a zabiyl of the earth of a well. (As, T, TA.) ― -b2- And hence, i. e. as being likened to a zbyl of the earth of a well, (assumed tropical:) The dung that the he-ass and the she-ass casts forth: (As, T, TA:) or the dung of the she-camel; (M, K;) but the more approved word is [saA^owN,] with s. (M, TA.) -A3- Also The nose-rein (zimaAm) of a she-camel. (Lth, K.)
mi$oA=pN * ; see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
mu$otaA^K * [part. n. of 8, q. v.: ― -b2- and] i. q. muxotalifN [app. as meaning Disagreeing, differing, or discordant]. (TA.)

1 $ab~a * , aor.
$abi3a , (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. $abaAbN (S, Mgh, Msb, K *) and $abiybapN (S, Msb, K *) and $ubuwbN and $abiybN, (TA,) He became a youth, or young man; i. e. he attained to the state termed $abaAbN meaning as expl. below; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) said of a boy. (S, Msb.) [And in like manner $ab~ato is said of a girl, i. e. She became a young woman.] ― -b2- $ub~a used as a noun: see below. ― -b3- [Perhaps as an inf. n. of which the verb is $ab~a, (as Freytag has assumed,) but more probably of $ub~a, which will be found mentioned in this paragraph, for I do not find the former verb in the requisite sense,] $ab~N signifies Anything's being, or becoming, raised, or elevated. (K.) ― -b4- $ab~a said of a horse, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
$abi3a , and
$abu3a , (S, K,) inf. n. $ibaAbN and $abiybN (S, Msb, K) and $ubuwbN, (K,) He was brisk, lively, or sprightly, (S, Msb, K, *) and raised his fore legs (S, Msb, K) together, (S, Msb,) as though in leaping, (TA,) and played. (S. [See also $ab~at in art. $bw, said of a mare.]) And likewise He was or became, restive, or refractory: one says, briy^otu A_ilayoka mino $ibaAbihi and $abiybihi and EiDaADihi and EaDiyDihi [I am irresponsible to thee for his being restive, or refractory, and for his biting]. (S.) ― -b5- $ab~ati Aln~aAru, [aor., accord. to rule,
$abi3a ,] (Msb, K,) and $ub~at [pass. of the trans. verb $ab~a, q. v. infrà], inf. n. $ubuwbN (which is of the intrans., TA) and $ab~N (which is of the trans. verb, TA), The fire burned, burned up, burned brightly or fiercely, blazed, or flamed. (Msb, K. [See also 5.]) [And hence,] $ab~ati AlHarobu bayonahumo (tropical:) [War, or the war, burned, or burned fiercely, between them]. (A, TA.) -A2- $ub~a It was raised, or elevated. (O, TA.) ― -b2- $ab~a Aln~aAru, aor.
$abu3a , (S, O, Msb,) inf. n. $ab~N (S, O, K) and $ubuwbN, (S, K,) or the latter is the inf. n. of the intrans. verb mentioned above, (TA,) He kindled the fire; or made it to burn, burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame; (S, O, Msb, K; *) as also ↓ $b~bhA, inf. n. ta$obiybN; (L;) and ↓ A$b~hA: (A and TA in art. H$:) and so $abaAhaA. (TA in art. $bw.) And in like manner, $ab~a AlHaroba (assumed tropical:) He kindled war, or the war; or made it to burn, or burn fiercely. (S.) ― -b3- [Hence,] $ab~a, aor.
$abu3a , said of the blackness of a garment, (Sh, A, TA,) (tropical:) It heightened and increased, (A,) or made to appear bright and beautiful, and [as it were] burning, or glowing, (Sh, TA,) the whiteness of the wearer. (Sh, A, TA.) And $ab~a lawonahaA (aor. as above, S) (assumed tropical:) It
(a woman's hair) showed, [or set off,] and rendered beautiful, her colour, or complexion: (S:) it (a woman's head-covering, and her hair,) increased, and showed, [or heightened, and set off,] her beauty: (K:) it (a woman's black headcovering) increased her fairness, and rendered her beautiful. (TA.) And ya$ub~u Alwajoha, said of patience, (assumed tropical:) It gives beauty and colour to the countenance. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b4- See also 4, in two places.

2 $b~b Aln~aAra * , inf. n. ta$obiybN: see the preceding paragraph. ― -b2- Hence, ta$obiybu Al$~iEori (tropical:) The making the commencement of poetry elegant, or ornate, by the mention of women: (L, TA:) or the primary meaning of Alt~a$obiybu is the mention of the days of youth and of play or sport, and amatory language; and it is in the commencing of odes; and the commencement thereof is so called, absolutely, though there be not in it any mention of youth: (TA:) it means Aln~asiybu, (S, O,) or Aln~asiybu biAln~isaA='i, (K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, Alt~a$ab~ubu bAlnisA'i,]) i. e. bi*ikorihin~a: (TA:) one says, yu$ab~ibu biqulaAnapa, (S, O,) and bihaA ↓ yt$b~b [if this be not a mistranscription for yu$ab~ibu], (TA,) meaning yanosibu bihaA: (S, O, TA:) [see this fully expl. in art. nsb: i. e.] $b~b bifulaAnapa, inf. n. ta$obiybN, means, (tropical:) He spoke of such a female in amatory language [in the commencement of his ode], (Msb, TA,) and alluded to the love of her: (Msb:) and $b~b qaSiydatahu (assumed tropical:) He embellished [the commencement of] his ode by the mention of women: (Mgh, Msb:) and $b~b qaSiydatahu bifulaAnapa (tropical:) [He embellished the commencement of his ode by mentioning, in amatory language, such a female]: (A, TA:) and ↓ $abaAbN is used in the sense of ta$obiybN; thus a qaSiydap is said to be HasanapN Al$~abaAbi (tropical:) [Beautiful in the mention of women &c.]; and Jereer is said to have been A^araq~u Aln~aAsi $abaAbFA (tropical:) [The most elegant of men in the mention of women &c.]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- Hence, i. e. from ta$obiybN AlqaSiydapi, may be derived Alt~a$obiybu as a conventional term in the science of the division of inheritances; meaning (assumed tropical:) The mention of daughters according to the different degrees [of descent]: (Mgh:) it is as when one says, “ he died, and left three daughters of a son, subordinate one to another, and three daughters of a son's son, in like manner, and three daughters of a son's son's son, in like manner, and the sons died and the daughters remained. ” (O.) ― -b4- ta$obiybu Alkutubi signifies (assumed tropical:) The commencing of books, or writings: and hence $ab~aba yujaAwibuhu, occurring in a trad., meaning (assumed tropical:) He commenced answering him: not from the ta$obiyb of women in poetry. (TA.)

4 A$b~hu A@ll~`hu *
God made him, or may God make him, to become a youth, or young man; i. e., to attain to the state termed $abaAbN meaning as expl. below: and A$b~ A@ll~`hu qaronahu means the same: (S, A, TA:) the latter [lit. means God made, or may God make, his equal in age to become a youth, &c., (see Har p. 572,) and therefore] is tropical. (A, TA.) ― -b2- A^a$obayotu Alfarasa I excited the horse to be brisk, lively, or sprightly, and to raise his fore legs together, as though in leaping, and to play. (S, * K, * TA.) ― -b3- A$b~ Aln~aAra: see 1. ― -b4- A^u$ib~a liYa Alr~ajulu, inf. n. A_i$obaAbN; as also ↓ $ub~a; (tropical:) The man appeared before my upraised eyes when not hoped for. (AZ, TA.) ― -b5- And A^u$ib~a liY ka*aA, and ↓ $ub~a, (tropical:) Such a thing was prepared, or appointed, or ordained, for me. (S, K, * TA.) -A2- A^a$ab~u (tropical:) He became one whose child, or children, had attained to the state of $abaAb [i. e. youth, or young manhood, &c.]: (K:) [or] A^a$ab~a Alr~ajulu baniyna (tropical:) the man became one whose children had attained to that state: (S, TA:) and in like manner, A^a$ab~ato A^awolaAdFA is said of a woman. (TA.) ― -b2- And A^a$ab~a said of [the species of bovine antelope called] the wild bull, (S, K,) He became such as is termed $ababN [q. v.], i. e., (S,) he became advanced in age, or full-grown; (musin~, S, K;) one whose state termed A_isonaAn [q. v.] had ended. (S.)

5 ta$ab~a3a [ta$ab~ati Aln~aAru The fire became kindled; or made to burn, burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame: see also 1.] One says on the occasion of kindling fire,
ta$ab~abiY ta$ab~uba Aln~amiymaho
jaA='ato bihaA tamorN A_ilaY tamiymaho
[Be thou kindled like the state of kindling of the calumny that Temr brought to Temeemeh: but to what this alludes I know not]: it is like the saying, A^awoqada biAln~amiymapi naArFA [He kindled a fire with calumny]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- See also 2.

10 A_isota$oba3a It is said in a trad., yajuwzu $ahaAdapu AlS~iboyaAni EalaY AlkibaAri yusotavab~uwna [The boy's giving testimony against those that are full grown is allowable, when they (the former) are deemed to have attained to the state of youths, or young men]: it is as though it were said that if they take upon themselves the bearing witness in boyhood, and give their testimony when full grown, it is allowable: (TA:) or yusota$ab~uwna means they shall be sought youths, such as have attained to puberty, or maturity, in the case of giving testimony: or they shall be waited for, in the case of giving testimony, until the period of becoming youths, or young men. (Mgh.) ― -b2- And it is said in another trad., Aisota$ib~uwA EalaY A^asowuqikumo fiY Albawoli, i. e. Sit upon your shanks as one does when preparing to rise, not stooping with the whole body near to the ground; [having your feet only upon the ground; in the voiding of urine:] from $ab~a Alfarasu meaning “ the horse raised his fore-legs together from the ground. ” (TA.)

R. Q. 1 $abo$aba *
He completed [a thing]; (AA, O, K;) said of a man. (AA, TA.)

$ab~N * , and its fem. $ab~apN: see $aAb~N. -A2- Also The stones of zaAj [or vitriol]: (K:) or the stones from which zAj and the like thereof are obtained; the best whereof is that which is brought from El-Yemen, which is white $b~, and is very glistening: (TA:) [but $ab~N yamaAniY~N, as also $ab~N alone, is a name now commonly given to alum:] or it is a certain thing resembling zAj: (S, Msb:) or a species thereof: accord. to El-Fárábee, the stones from which come zAj and the like: Az says, it is one of the minerals produced by God in the earth, with which one tans, and resembling zAj, and the name [correctly] heard is thus, with b, but is by some mistranscribed with the three-dotted v, [i. e. $av~N,] which is a kind of tree of bitter taste, and I know not whether one tans with it or not: accord. to Mtr, in the saying that one tans with $b~, this word is a mistranscription; for $b~ is a dye, and one does not tan with a dye; it is mistranscribed for $av~, which is a kind of tree like the dwarf apple-tree, whereof the leaves are like those of the xilaAf [q. v.], and with them one tans: El-Fárábee also says, in the section of v, that the $av~ is a species of mountain-tree, with which one tans: from all which it appears that one tans with both of them; for an affirmation is to be preferred to a negation: (Msb:) and it is a well-known medicine; (K, TA;) as some say: so accord. to the correct copies of the K, in some of which, daA='N is put for dawaA='N. (TA.)

$ub~ * and dub~, though originally verbs, are used as nouns, by the introduction of mino before them: one says, A^aEoyayotaniY mino $ub~a A_ilaY dub~a and mino $ub~K A_ilaY dub~K [expl. in art. dba]: (S:) and in like manner they are used in another saying expl. in art. db [q. v.]: (S in that art.:) or, without tenween, they may be regarded as verbs used in the way of HikaAyap [or imitation]. (MF.)
$ab~apN * The burning, burning up, burning brightly or fiercely, blazing, or flaming, of fire. (TA.)

$ababN * and ↓ $abuwbN, applied to a [bovine antelope of the species called the] wild bull, (As, S, K,) and to a sheep or goat, (K,) and ↓ mu$ib~N, applied to the former, and ↓ mi$ab~N, (As, S, K,) sometimes, applied to the former, (As, S,) or to both, (K,) Advanced in age, or full-grown, (musin~N, S, K,) whose state termed A_isonaAn [q. v.] has ended; (As, S;) and ↓ mu$ib~apN is in like manner applied to a she-camel as meaning musin~apN: (TA:) or ↓ $buwbN, (AA, K,) applied to both, (K,) as also ↓ mu$ib~N, (TA,) or to a bull, (AA,) is syn. with ↓ $Ab~N [meaning youthful, or in the prime of life]: (AA, K, TA:) and accord. to AO, $ababN, applied to a bull, means that has attained to the end of $abaAb [i. e. youthfulness, or the prime of life]: (S, TA:) or, as some say, that has attained to the end of his full growth and strength; as also ↓ $abuwbN, which is likewise applied to the female; or, accord. to AHát and ISh, when he is a year old, and weaned, he is called dababN; and then, $ababN [meaning more than a year old]; and the female, $ababpN. (TA.)

$abaAbN * and ↓ $abiybapN [both mentioned above as inf. ns.] (S, Msb, K) [and ↓ $abaAbiy~apN which is a simple subst.] Youth, youthfulness, the prime of man-
hood, or young manhood; syn. fataA='N; (K;) or HadaAvapN; contr. of $ayobN: (S:) or the state from puberty to the completion of thirty years; or from sixteen years to thirty-two; after which a man is called kaholN; (TA;) the age before Alkuhuwlap: (Msb:) or the state between thirty and forty: (Mgh:) or, accord. to Mohammad Ibn-Habeeb, the state from the seventeenth year to the completion of fifty-one years is termed ↓ $abaAbiy~apN; the period before, from birth, being termed guluwmiy~apN; and in the period after, a man being called $ayoxN, until he dies. (TA.) One says, saqaY A@ll~`hu EaSora ↓ Al$abiybapi [May God freshen as with rain the times, or mornings, or afternoons, of youth, &c.], and EuSuwra Al$~abaAy^ibi [the times, &c., of the states of youth, &c.]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- [$abaAbN often signifies (assumed tropical:) The sap, or vigour, of youth or young manhood.] One says, AisotaHaAra $abaAbuhaA, as in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb, (assumed tropical:) The sap [or vigour] of youth (maA='N Al$~abaAbi) flowed in her. (IB, TA in art. Hyr.) And AimotalaA^a $abaAbFA (assumed tropical:) [He became full of the sap, or vigour, of youth or young manhood]. (The lexicons, &c., passim.) [But] maA='N Al$~abaAbi signifies [also] (tropical:) The freshness, or brightness, and beauty, of youth. (Har p. 340.) [And ↓ $abiybapN app. signifies also (assumed tropical:) Youthful folly, or the like; (see an ex. voce gamorapN;) and so, probably, does $abaAbN.] ― -b3- [Hence,] $abaAbN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The first, or beginning, or the new, or recent, state, of a thing; (K, TA;) and so ↓ $abiybapN. (TA.) One says, qadima fiY $abaAbi Al$~ahori (A, TA) (tropical:) He came, or arrived, in the beginning of the month. (TA.) And laqiytuhu fiY $abaAbi Aln~ahaAri (A, TA) (tropical:) I met him in the beginning of the day: (TA:) and jiy^otuka fiY $abaAbi Aln~ahaAri and bi$abaAbi Aln~ahaAri (assumed tropical:) I came to thee in the beginning of the day: (Lh, TA:) or $abaAbu Aln~ahaAri means the period when the sun has risen high, when one fifth of the day has passed. (A in art. rA^d.) And one says also ↓ faEala *`lika fiY $abiybatihi He did that at the commencement thereof. (TA.) -A2- See also $aAb~N -A3- And see 2.
$ibaAbN * an inf. n. of $ab~a said of a horse. (S, Msb, K.) -A2- See also the next paragraph, in two places.

$ibaAbN * : see $ab~a, in three places. ― -b2- Also A horse whose hind feet pass beyond his fore feet; (K;) which is a fault: accord. to Th, such is termed ↓ $abiybN: IM says that the correct word is $ay^iytN: [but] see this in its proper place. (TA.) -A2- Also A thing with which a fire is kindled, or made to burn, burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame; (S, K;) and so ↓ $ibaAbN. (K.) ― -b2- And [hence, as also ↓ $ibaAbN,] (tropical:) A thing that serves [as a foil] for beautifying, or setting off, (K,) [or making to appear bright and beautiful,] or for increasing, or enhancing, and strengthening, [or heightening, in beauty,] (S, TA,) to another thing. (S, K, TA.) So in the saying, h`*aA $abuwbN lika*aA (tropical:) This is a thing that serves for increasing, or enhancing, [or heightening, in beauty,] to such a thing. (S, TA.) One says of a woman's headcovering, huwa $abuwbN liwajohihaA (tropical:) [It is a thing that serves for giving an appearance of additional brightness and beauty to her face]. (A.)
$abiybN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
$abiybapN * : see $abaAbN, in five places.

EasalN $abaAbiY~N *
Honey of Shebábeh ($abaAbap); (A, TA;) or, of Benoo-Shebábeh, (Mgh,) a people of Et-Táïf, (A, Mgh, TA,) of [the tribe of] Khath'am, who possessed bees, and hence it was thus called. (Mgh.)
$abaAbiy~apN * : see $abaAbN, in two places.

$ab~a*aA zayodN *
i. q. Hab~a*aA [q. v. in art. Hb]. (Th, TA.)

$aAb~N * part. n. of $ab~a said of a boy; (Msb;) [Youthful, or in the prime of manhood; a youth, or a young man;] in the state from puberty to the completion of thirty years; or from sixteen years to thirty-two; after which a man is called kaholN; (TA;) in the age before Alkuhuwlap: (Msb:) or in the state between thirty and forty: (Mgh:) [or in the state from the seventeenth year to the completion of fifty-one years: (see $abaAbN:)] and IAar mentions ↓ $ab~N as an epithet applied to a man [in the same sense as $aAb~N]: (TA:) a female is termed $aAb~apN (S, Msb, K) and ↓ $ab~apN; both signifying the same: (S, K:) the pl. of $aAb~N is $ub~aAnN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and $ababapN (S, A, K) and ↓ $abaAbN, (S, A, * K,) or the last is an inf. n. used as an epithet applied to a pl. number, (Mgh, and Ham p. 50,) or it is a quasi-pl. n.: (TA:) females, (Msb,) or women, (K,) are termed $awaAb~N (Msb, K) and $abaAy^ibu, (K,) the latter said by AZ to be allowable in the sense of the former, (TA,) which is pl. of $aAb~apN, (Msb,) $abaAy^ibu, accord. to Az, being pl. (not of $aAb~apN but) of $ab~apN, like as DaraAy^iru is of Dar~apN: (TA:) the dim. of $aAb~apN is ↓ $uwayob~apN, and some of the Arabs say ↓ $uwaAb~apN, changing the Y into A before a double letter [as in duwaAb~apN for duwayob~apN]. (ISd, L in art. hd.) One says, mararotu birijaAl K $ababapK meaning $ub~aAnK [i. e. I passed by men that were youths, or persons in the prime of manhood]. (S.) ― -b2- See also $ababN.
$uwaAb~apN * : dims. of $aAb~apN fem. of $aAb~N, q. v.
$uwayob~apN * : dims. of $aAb~apN fem. of $aAb~N, q. v.
$awo$abN * The scorpion. (IAar, K.) ― -b2- And The louse; syn. qamolN: (K in this art.:) or the ant; syn. namolN: (K in art. $$b:) fem. [or perhaps n. un.] with p. (TA.)
mu$ib~N * , and its fem., with p: see $ababN, in three places. ― -b2- Also the former, A lion: (K:) or a full-grown lion: syn. A^asadN kabiyrN. (TA.)
mi$ab~N * : see $ababN.

mu$ab~abN AlA^aZaAfiri * [or rather AlA^aZaAfiyri, pl. of the pl. A^aZofaArN or of A^uZofuwrN,] (tropical:) Having sharp-pointed nails or talons or claws; as though they flamed, by reason of their sharpness. (A, TA.)

ma$obuwbN * [pass. part. n. of 1]. You say naArN ma$obuwbapN A fire kindled, or made to burn, burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame: $aAb~apN in this sense is not allowable. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] applied to a man, (A, TA,) (tropical:) Comely, (S, TA,) of goodly countenance; (A, TA;) as though lighted up: bright, or fair, in complexion, and of goodly countenance; as though his countenance were lighted up with fire: pl. ma$aAbiybu. (TA.) And (tropical:) A man of acute mind. (TA.) And TalaEati Alma$obuwbataAni Alz~uharataAni [or Alz~ahoraAwaAni?] (tropical:) Venus and Jupiter, so called on account of their beauty and splendour, rose. (A, TA.)

$ibit~N * [Anethum graveolens, or dill, of the common garden-species;] a certain herb, or leguminous plant, well known: (K:) it is said that sibit~N is an arabicized word from $ibit~N; but it has been stated before [in art. sbt, q. v.,] that both these are arabicized words from $iwi*o [or $iwido]; and that sbT [i. e. siT~N] is a dial. var. (TA.) [See also $ibiv~N.]
1 $abVva see the next paragraph, in two places.

5 t$~bv bihi *
He, or it, clung, caught, clave, or adhered, to it, (S, A, L, Msb, K, * TA,) namely, a thing; (S, L, TA;) as also ↓ $abiva bihi, aor.
$abava , inf. n. $abavN: (L, TA:) or, accord. to Esh-Shiháb, in the Expos. of the Shifè, to a thing in which was weakness: or, accord. to the 'Ináyeh, he, or it, clung, &c., to it with weakness; and therefore ↓ muta$ab~ivN is used as an epithet applied to a spider; and tamas~uka signifies a stronger action; and t$b~v bh is also expl. as meaning he, or it, took fast, or firm, hold upon it: (L, TA:) and he stuck, or fixed, or struck, the claw, or talons, or nails, into it: (MA, PS:) and Al$~aYo'a ↓ $abiva he laid hold upon the thing, and took it: IAar was asked respecting some verses, and he said, maA A^adoriY mino A^ayona $abivotuhaA I know not whence I laid hold upon them [and took them]. (L, TA.)

Q. Q. 1
accord. to the S and L, $anobava: see art. $nbv.

$abavN * The spider: (K:) or a large spider, with many legs. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (K) A certain small creeping thing, (S, A, Msb, K,) having many legs, (S, A, K,) of the A^aHonaA$ [or creeping things &c.] of the earth: (S, Msb:) it should not be called $ibovN: (S:) or a certain small creeping thing, having six long legs, yellow in the back, and in the outer sides of the legs, black in the head, and blue in the eye: or a certain small creeping thing, having many legs, large in the head, of the AHnA$ of the earth: or a certain small creeping thing, wide in the mouth, high in the hinder part, that perforates the ground, is found where there is moisture, and eats scorpions; and it is what is called $aHomapu AlA^aroDi: (TA:) pl. $ibovaAnN. (S, A, Msb, K.) The [marks termed] A^avor of the blade of a sword are likened by
a poet, (S, TA,) namely, Sá'ideh Ibn-Ju-eiyeh, (TA,) to the tracks of $ibovaAn. (S, TA.)

rajulN $abivN *
A man whose nature it is to cling, catch, cleave, or adhere, to a thing. (S, K.) And DirosN DabivN $abivN [A tooth, or molar tooth,] that catches, or fastens, to a thing. (TA.)
$ubavapN * , (K,) or $ubavapN DubavapN, (TA,) A man (TA) who cleaves to his qiron [i. e. opponent, or adversary], not quitting him. (K, TA.)

$ibiv~N * [erroneously written in some copies of the K $ibovN, and in the L $ibivN,] A certain wellknown plant; (AHn, L, Msb;) a certain herb, or leguminous plant; (K;) [i. q. $ibit~N and sibit~N, q. v.; i. e. anethum graveolens, or dill, of the common garden-species:] Sgh says that $bv is a foreign word of which sibit~N is an arabicized form; and it is made of the measure fiEil~N because this measure has many examples; whereas the measure fiEil~N, of which A_ibilN is an instance, is extraordinary. (Msb.)
$ab~aAvN * : see what next follows.

$ab~uwvN * and ↓ $ab~aAvN [so in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K, but the latter is strangely said in the TA to be with kesr,] sings. of $abaAbiyvu, which signifies The flesh-hooks (kalaAliyb) of the fire. (K.)
Al$~anobavu * : see art. $nbv.
Al$~unaAbivu * : see art. $nbv.
mita$ab~ivN * an epithet applied to a spider: see 5.

1 $abuHa * , (S, K,) inf. n. $abaAHapN, (TK,) said of a man, (S,) He was, or became, broad in the fore arms: (S, K, TA:) or long therein. (TA.) -A2- $abaHahu, (A, O, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) aor.
$abaHa , (K,) inf. n. $aboHN, (TK,) He extended, stretched, or stretched out, it, or him; (A, O, Mgh, L, Msb, K;) namely, a thing; (IF, L, Msb;) a hide, or skin, (A, L, K,) or some other thing, (L,) between pegs, or stakes; (K;) and a man, (Mgh, L, Msb,) between two things, to be flogged, (L,) [i. e.,] between two stakes inserted and fixed in the ground, (Mgh, Msb,) which are called EuqaAbaAni, (Mgh,) when he was beaten, or crucified, (Mgh, Msb,) or like him who is crucified; and ↓ $b~Hhu is used, accord. to some, in the same manner. (L.) And $abaHa yadayohi He extended, or stretched forth, his arms, or hands: (L:) or $abaHa [alone] he extended his arm, or hand, to offer a prayer, or supplication; (K;) or he extended and raised his arms, or hands, in his prayer, or supplication. (A.) And AlHirobaA='u ya$obaHu EalaY AlEuwdi (tropical:) The chameleon extends (S, A, O) itself (S, O) or its fore legs (A) upon the branch. (S, A, O.) ― -b2- Also, inf. n. as above, He cut, hewed, or pared, it, namely, a stick, or piece of wood, so as to make it wide. (O, L. [See also 2.]) ― -b3- And He clave it, or split it, (K, * TA,) namely, another's head, or anything whatever. (TA.) ― -b4- $abaHa lanaA He (a man, K) stood erect [as though drawing himself up] to us. (O, K.) ― -b5- And $abaHa laka It (a thing) appeared, or became apparent, to thee. (L.) -A3- $ubiHa biA^amorK He was, or became, attached, or addicted, to an affair; or fond of it. (O.)

2 $b~Hhu * : see 1. ― -b2- Also, (K,) inf. n. ta$obiyHN, (S,) He made it (a thing) wide. (S, K.) ― -b3- And ta$obiyHN signifies also The act of paring, or peeling, or the like. (O. [See also 1.]) ― -b4- And The act of pulling, or plucking, out, or up. (O.) -A2- And $b~H, (O, K,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He (a man, TA) became aged, and saw a [thing such as is termed] $abaH appearing as though it were two. (O, K.)
$aboHN * : see $abaHN, in two places: -A2- and see also ma$obuwHN.

$abaHN * (S, A, O, Msb, K) and ↓ $aboHN (S, O, K) i. q. $axoSN [i. e. The body, or bodily or corporeal form or figure or substance, of a man or some other thing or object, which one sees from a distance]: (S, A, O, Msb, K:) a man, or some other creature, of which the $axoS [or body, &c.,] appears to one: (L:) and a thing that is perceived by sense (A, O, L) and by sight: (O, L:) pl. A^a$obaAHN, (A, O, Msb, K,) which is of the former, (A, Msb,) and [of the latter] $ubuwHN. (K.) One says, laAHa liY $abaHN, meaning $axoSN [i. e. A body, or bodily form, appeared, loomed, or gleamed, to me]. (A.) And humo A^a$obaAHN bilaA A^arowaAHK [They are bodies without souls]. (A.) And A^a*aq~u mino $abaHK baATilK, (A, O,) and mino xayoTi baATilK, a prov., (O,) meaning [More minute, or inconsiderable, than] the atoms that are seen in the rays of the sun entering from a mural aperture in a chamber: (A, * O:) or, as some say, than the thread that comes forth from the mouth of the spider; [meaning gossamer;] called by the children muxaATN Al$~ayoTaAni. (O.) And AlA^asomaA='u DarobaAni A^asomaA='u A^a$obaAHK waA^asomaA='u A^aEomaAlK, meaning [Nouns are of two sorts,] the names of things perceived by sense, and the names [of actions, or rather of accidents or attributes, i. e.] of other things; like as they say A^asomaA='u AlA^aEoyaAni and A^asomaA='u AlmaEaAniY. (A.) And halaka A^a$obaAHu maAlihi The known ones of his camels, and sheep or goats, and other cattle, perished. (O, K. *) -A2- $abaHN also signifies A door or gate, of high structure; (O, K;) and so ↓ $aboHN: (K:) [but the latter may have originated from a mistranscription; for Sgh says,] and so $abajN. (O.) -A3- See also $abaHapN.

$aboHapN *
A rafter, or timber, (Euwd,) of the ceiling, or roof, of a house: so in a trad. where it is said, fanazaEa saqofa baytiY $aboHapF $aboHapF [And he pulled off the roof of my house, rafter by rafter, or timber by timber]. (JM, * TA.)
$iboHapN * of horses: what is thus called is well known [as being A rope which is extended from a horse's fore leg to his hind leg: so in the present day]. (TA.)

$abaHapN * a word occurring in the K and TA voce mu$oTN and in the TA voce miHar~N &c. [app. as meaning A broad piece of wood]. ― -b2- Al$~abaHataAni signifies The two pieces of wood of the minoqalap, (O, K,) which is the thing upon which bricks are carried from place to place: the pl. is Al$~abaHaAtu and [the coll. gen. n., of which $abaHapN is the n. un., is] ↓ Al$~abaHu. (O.)
$aboHaAn * [whether with or without tenween is not apparent, as the fem. is not mentioned,] Tall; (AA, S, O, K;) an epithet applied to a man. (TA.)

$abiyHapN * sing. of $abaAy^iHu, (O,) which signifies Pieces of wood, (O, K,) broad, (O,) placed transversly, (O, K,) contrariwise, or on contrary sides, (O,) in the [camel's saddle called] qatab (O, K) that is of wood: so expl. by Shujáa. (O.)

mu$~abaHN * , applied to a [garment of the kind called] kisaA=', Strong, or stout: (O, K: *) or, as some say, wide. (O.) ― -b2- And [applied to a stick, or piece of wood,] Pared, (K, TA,) and cut, or hewed [app. so as to be made wide: see 1]. (TA.) -A2- And A species of fish.. (TA.)

ma$obuwHN *
Wide between the shoulders. (L.) ― -b2- ma$obuwHu Al*~iraAEayoni and Al*~iraAEayoni ↓ $aboHu A man broad in the fore arms: (S, K:) or long therein: but AAF and Ibn-El-Jowzee prefer the former explanation. (TA.) -A2- ma$obuwHN biA^amorK Attached, or addicted, to an affair; or fond of it. (O.)

1 $abara * , aor.
$abura (S, A, Msb) and
$abira , (S,) inf. n. $aborN; (IAar, S, Msb, K;) and ↓ $b~r, inf. n. ta$obiyrN; (IAar, K;) He measured by the $ibor [or span] (IAar, S, A, Msb, K) a garment, or piece of cloth, (S, K,) or a thing: (A, Msb:) from Al$~iboru; like as one says buEotuhu from AlbaAEu. (S.) mano laka A^ano ta$obura AlbasiyTapa (tropical:) [Who will be guarantee for thee that thou wilt measure the earth with thy span?] is a prov. applied to him who imposes upon himself that which he is unable to accomplish. (A, TA.) ― -b2- $abara AlmaroA^apa, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) He compressed the woman. (TA.) ― -b3- $abarahu, (ISk, S, A,) aor.
$abura and
$abira , (TA,) inf. n. as above; (S, K;) and ↓ A$brhu, (S, A,) inf. n. A_i$obaArN; (K;) and ↓ $b~rhu, inf. n. ta$obiyrN; (TS, TA;) He gave him (ISk, S, A, TS, K *) wealth, or property, (ISk, S, A,) or a sword, (ISk, S,) or a coat of mail. (S, IB.) -A2- $abira, aor.
$abara , He exulted; or exulted greatly, or excessively; and behaved insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully. (TS, K, TA.)

2 $ab~ara see 1, in two places. ― -b2- Also $b~rhu, (AHeyth, K,) inf. n. ta$obiyrN, (AHeyth, TA,) He magnified him, or honoured him; namely, a man: (AHeyth, K, TA:) and made him a near companion, a familiar, or a favourite. (AHeyth, TA.)

4 A$br *
He (a man) begat children tall in the A^a$obaAr, i. e. statures: and he begat children short therein. (IAar, TA.) -A2- A$brhu: see 1.

5 t$b~r *
He was, or became, magnified, or honoured: and made a near companion, a familiar, or a favourite. (AHeyth, TA.)

6 t$AbrA *
They (two bodies of men, S) drew near, each to the other: (S, K:) as though they became a span ($ibor) distant, one from the other; or as though each extended the span to the other. (S.)

$aborN * The measure [of the width (see *iraAEN)], by the span, of a garment, or piece of cloth: so in the saying, kamo $aboru vawobika [How much is the measure of the width, by the span, of thy garment, or piece of cloth?]. (Msb.) ― -b2- Stature; (Fr, K;) and so ↓ $iborapN; whether short or tall: (TA:) pl. [app. of the latter] A^a$obaArN. (IAar, TA.) You say, maA A^aTowala $aborahu How tall is his stature! (TA.) ― -b3- Life, or age; as also ↓ $iborN. (TS, K.) Thus in the saying, qaS~ara A@ll~`hu $aborahu and ↓ $iborahu [May God shorten, or God shortened, his life]. (TS, TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) The act of giving: (A, IAth:) like as baAEN and yadN are said for “generosity.” (A.) ― -b5- See also $abarN, in two places. ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) The due for marriage, and for concubitus; (Sh, S, * K; *) such as what are termed mahorN and EuqorN. (Sh, TA.) You say, A^aEoTayotu AlaroA^apa $aborahaA I gave the woman her due for marriage, or for concubitus. (S.) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) The hire that is given for the stallion-camel's covering of the female. (IAar, T, S, Msb, K. *) The taking of this is forbidden. (T, S, Msb.) ― -b8- (tropical:) Marriage: (IAth, K:) because it is accompanied by a gift. (IAth, TA.) baAraka A@ll~`hu fiY $aborikumaA May God bless your marriage is a saying mentioned in a trad. (IAth, TA.)

$iborN *
A span; the space between the extremity of the thumb and that of the little finger (Msb, K) when extended apart in the usual manner: (Msb:) of the masc. gender: (K:) pl. A^a$obaArN, (S, Msb, K,) the only pl. form. (Sb.) [See also buSomN, and *iraAEN.] [Hence,] qaSiyru Al$~ibori (applied to a man, S) (tropical:) Contracted, or short, in make: (S, A, K:) or, accord. to some of the lexicons, in step. (TA.) ― -b2- [As a measure in astronomy, it is said in several of the law-books to be The twelfth part of the rumoH; and therefore twentytwo minutes and a half, accord. to modern usage: but there is reason to believe that ancient usage differed from the modern with respect to both of these measures, and was not precise nor uniform. See rumoHN.] ― -b3- qibaAlu Al$~ibori (assumed tropical:) The serpent: (IAar, K:) and so qibaAlu Al$~isoEi. (IAar, TA.) ― -b4- See also $aborN, in two places.

$abarN * (tropical:) A gift; (S Mgh, K, TA;) as also ↓ $aborN (Mgh, TA) and ↓ $iborapN: (IAar, TA:) and wealth, or the like; syn. xayorN: (K:) the first is a word similar to xabaTN and nafaDN; and he who says that it is used by poetic license for $aborN [as it is said to be in the S] is in error: ↓ $aborN and $abarN are said to be two dial. vars., like qadorN and qadarN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A certain thing which the Christians give, one to another, (yataEaATaAhu Aln~aSaAraY, K, TA, abEoDuhumo libaEoDK, TA,) like the qurobaAn [or Eucharist], (K, TA,) seeking to ingratiate themselves thereby: (TA:) or the Eucharist (qurobaAn) itself: (K:) or a thing which the Christians give (tuEoTiyhi), one to another, as though seeking to ingratiate themselves thereby: (Kh, Sgh, TA:) or (TA, in the K “and”) bodies: and powers, or faculties: (K, TA:) or (TA, in the K “and”) the Gospel. (K, TA.)
$iborapN * : see $aborN: ― -b2- and see also $abarN.

$ab~uwrN *
A trumpet; syn. buwqN; (S, K;) a certain thing in which one blows: (Mgh:) said to be an arabicized word; (S;) not genuine Arabic: (Mgh, TA:) accord. to IAth, it is Hebrew: (TA:) [app. from the Hebr. שׁוֹפָּר, as observed by Golius.] ― -b2- See also A^u$obuwrN.
rajulN $aAbiru AlmiyzaAni * (assumed tropical:) A man that is a thief. (Sgh, K.)

A^a$obaru *
Wider in span; syn. A^awosaEu $iborFA. (A, TA.) So in the saying, huwa A^a$obaru mino SaAHibihi [He is wider in span than his companion]. (A.)

A^u$obuwrN *
A certain fish; (K;) called by the vulgar ↓ $ab~uwr. (TA.)

ma$obarN * sing. of ma$aAbiru, (TA,) which signifies Certain notches (HuzuwzN [pl. of Haz~N, in the CK erroneously written xuwuwozN,]) in the cubit, by means of which buying and selling are transacted: (K, TA:) of them is the notch (Haz~) of the span, and the notch of the half of the span, and of the quarter thereof: every notch of these, small or great, is termed ma$obarN: mentioned by Sgh, from Aboo-Sa'eed. (TA.) -A2- ma$aAbiru also signifies Rivers, or rivulets, (A^anohaAr,) that are depressed, so that the water comes to them from several places, (K, TA,) of such as overflows from the lands: (TA:) pl. of ma$obarN and ↓ ma$obarapN. (K, TA.)
ma$obarapN * : see what next precedes.

ma$obuwrapN *
A liberal, bountiful, or generous, woman. (IAar, K.)
$ubaATN * (AA, K) and $ubaATu, being perfectly and imperfectly decl., (AA, TA,) The name of a month in Greek; (AA, K;) i. q. subaAT, q. v. (AA, TA.)

$ab~uwTN * (S, K) and $ub~uwTN, (K,) the latter mentioned in the O on the authority of Lth, but in the L on the authority of Lh, and said by him to be a Greek word, (TA,) [a coll. gen. n.,] n. un. with p, and sometimes that with fet-h is without teshdeed, (K,) i. e. $abuwTapN, mentioned by ISd, but with the expression of a doubt as to its correctness, (TA,) [now applied to A species of cyprinus, or carp: or, accord. to Golius, a fish resembling the alosa, or shad, but three times larger; wont to be brought from the Euphrates to Aleppo:] a species of fish, (Lth, S, K,) slender in the tail, wide in the middle part, soft to the feel, small in the head, resembling a barobaT [or Persian lute]: (Lth, K:) the brbT when long, not broad, is likened to this fish; and this fish, to the brbT: the pl. is $abaAbiyTu. (TA.) [See sub~uwHN.]

1 $abiEa * , [aor.
$abaEa ,] inf. n. $ibaEN (IDrd, S, Msb, K) and $iboEN, (IDrd, Msb, TA,) which is a contraction of the former, or accord. to some it is a subst., having the signification assigned to it below, (Msb,) or it is both, (TA,) and $aboEN, (Ibn- 'Abbád, K,) He was, or became, satiated, sated, or satisfied in stomach; $ibaEN being the contr. of juwEN, (S, K,) and one of those inf. ns. [which are of a measure often] denoting natural affections or qualities [such as riwFY and simanN &c.]. (S.) You say baladN qado $abiEato ganamuhu A country of which the sheep, or goats, have become completely satiated, or satisfied, by abundance of herbage. (TA.) And $abiEotu xubozFA, and laHomFA, (S, Msb, K,) and mino xubozK, and mn laHomK, (S, K,) I was, or became, satiated, sated, or satisfied, with bread, and with flesh-meat. (S, K.) ― -b2- Hence, metaphorically, $abiEotu mino h`*aA AlA^amoi warawiytu (tropical:) I have become, or I became, disgusted [or satiated to loathing] with this thing, or affair. (S, * TA.) ― -b3- [See also another metaphorical usage of this verb voce HuzaAnapN.] -A2- $abuEa Eaqoluhu (assumed tropical:) His intellect was, or became, full, perfect, (K,) strong, or solid. (TA.)

2 $ab~aEato ganamuhu * , (S, K, [in some copies of the former, erroneously, $abiEato,]) inf. n. ta$obiyEN; (K;) and $ub~iEato; (as in one place in the TA;) (tropical:) His sheep, or goats, were, or became, nearly, but not quite, satiated, or satisfied. (S, K, TA.)

4 A$bEhu * [signifying It satiated him, sated him, or satisfied his stomach,] is said of food and of abundance of drink. (TA.) ― -b2- A^a$obaEotuhu [I satiated him, sated him, or satisfied his stomach; or] I fed him so that he became satiated, sated, or satisfied. (Msb.) And A^a$obaEotuhu mina AljuwEi [I fed him so as fully to relieve him from hunger]. (S, K.) [Hence,] A^a$obaEotu Alv~awoba (S, TA) mina AlS~ibogi (S) (tropical:) I saturated the garment, or piece of cloth, with the dye. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] A$bEhu (tropical:) He made it (namely anything, TA) full, without lack or defect, or abundant, or copious. (K, * TA.) It is said of other things beside substances; as, for instance, of blowing, and of reading or reciting, and of any expression. (TA.) You say also, saAqa fiY h`*aA AlmaEonaY faSolFA mu$obaEFA [He carried on, respecting this idea, a full section]. (TA.) [And A$bE HarakapF He rendered a vowel full in sound, by inserting after it its analogous letter of prolongation. And such a letter of prolongation is said to be inserted, or added, liloA_i$obaAEi to render the sound full; as in nukaAtN for nukatN, and A^anoZuwru for A^anoZuru, and maraADiyEu for maraADiEu. And A_i$obaAEFA is also used as signifying For the sake of, or by way of, pleonasm, or giving fulness of expression.] -A2- A$bE Alr~ajulu The man's beasts were, or became, completely satiated, or satisfied, by abundance of herbage. (TA.)

5 t$b~E *
He ate immediately after eating. (K.) ― -b2- He feigned himself satiated, sated, or satisfied in stomach, not being so. (K, TA.) ― -b3- [And hence,] (tropical:) He made a boast of abundance or riches, (Msb, K, * TA,) or of more than he possessed; and invested himself with that which did not belong to him. (TA.) [See muta$ab~iEN.]

$iboEN * a subst., signifying A thing that satiates one, sates one, or satisfies one's stomach; (S, Msb, K;) consisting of bread, and of flesh-meat, &c.; (Msb;) as also ↓ $ibaEN: (K:) accord. to some, the former is an inf. n.: (Msb:) or it is an inf. n. and also a subst. signifying as above. (TA.) You say, Alr~agiyfu $iboEiY The cake of bread [is that which] satiates me, &c. (Msb.)
$ibaEN * inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Thickness in the shanks. (TA.) -A2- See also $iboEN. You say, A^aroDN *aAtu $ibaEK A land having abundance of herbage, and plenty. (Mgh.)

$uboEapN mino TaEaAmK *
The quantity with which one is satiated, sated, or satisfied, once, of food. (S, K.)

A^aroDN $abiEapN *
i. q. *aAtu $ibaEK [q. v.]. (Mgh.)

$aboEaAnu *
Satiated, sated, or satisfied in stomach; (S, Msb, * K;) as also ↓ $aAbiEN, but this is allowable only in poetry: (K:) fem. of the former $aboEaY, (S, Msb, K,) and $aboEaAnapN (Sgh, K) is sometimes used: (Sgh:) the pl. of $bEAn and of $bEY is $ibaAEN and $abaAEaY. (TA.) [Hence the saying,] qawomN A_i*aA jaAEuwA kaAEuwA wataraAhumo sibaAEFA A_i*aA kaAnuwA $ibaAEFA [A people who, when they are hungry, are fearful and cowardly, and thou seest them to be beasts of prey when they are satiated]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- [And hence,] $aboEaY AlxaloxaAli (tropical:) A woman who fills up the anklet by reason of her fatness. (S, K, TA.) And $aboEaY Als~iwaAri (tropical:) Who fills up the bracelet by reason of fatness. (K, TA.) And $aboEaY Alwi$aAHi (tropical:) A woman large in the belly. (TA.) And $aboEaY Ald~iroEi (tropical:) A woman bulky in make: (A, O, L, TA:) in the K erroneously written $aboEaY Al*~iraAEi, and expl. as meaning bulky in the forearm. (TA.)

$abiyEN * Food that satiates, sates, or satisfies the stomach. (Fr.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) An arrow that kills much or many or often. (Ibn-'Abbád.) ― -b3- vawobN $abiyEu Algazoli (tropical:) A garment, or piece of cloth, [of full texture, or] of many threads: (S, K, TA:) pl. viyaAbN $uboEN. (TA.) And HabolN $abiyEN, (K,) or $abiyEu Alv~al~api, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) A rope abundant, (K, TA,) and firm, or strong, in the wool, (TA,) or in the hair, or fur, [of which it is composed:] (K, TA:) pl. $uboEN. (TA.) ― -b4- rajulN $abiyEu AlEaqoli (assumed tropical:) A man full, or perfect, (K, TA,) and strong, or solid, (TA,) in intellect; (K, TA;) from IAar; (TA;) as also ↓ mu$obaEuhu. (K.) And Alqalobi ↓ rajulN mu$ab~aEN [or perhaps Alqalobi ↓ mu$obaEu] (assumed tropical:) A man strong, or firm, in heart. (TA.)

$ubaAEapN *
A portion of food that remains, or is redundant, after one is satiated, or satisfied. (Ibn-Abbád, K. *)
$aAbiEN * : see $uboEaAnN. ― -b2- bahiymapN $aAbiEN A beast that has attained to eating; an epithet applied to such a beast until it is nearly weaned. (TA.)
fulaAnN fiY riY~i wama$obaEK * [Such a one is in a state in which he is satiated, or satisfied, with drink and food]. (T, A, TA, in art. nZr.) [See manoZarN.]
mu$obaEN * pass. part. n. of 4 [q. v.]. See also $abiyEN, in two places.
mu$ab~aEN * : see $abiyEN. ― -b2- AlbaA='u Almu$ab~aEu [or Almu$ab~aEapu] The letter P. (TA in art. bls.)

muta$ab~iEN * (tropical:) One who invests himself with, and makes a boast of, more than he possesses; who invests himself with that which he does not possess; (S, TA;) who affects goodly qualities more than he possesses; like him who feigns himself satiated, or satisfied in stomach, not being so: (TA:) or he who feigns himself satiated, or satisfied in stomach, not being so: and hence, (assumed tropical:) a lying person, who affects to be commended or praised for, or boasts of, or glories in, that which he does not possess. (Mgh.) Thus in a trad., (S, Mgh,) in which it is said, Almuta$ab~iEu bimaA laA yamoliku kalaA bisi vawobaYo zuwrK, (S, TA,) or bimaA layosa Einodahu, (Mgh,) (tropical:) [He who invests himself with, and makes a boast of, more than he possesses, &c., is like the wearer of two garments of falsity: or] accord. to A'Obeyd, it means [that such is like] the hypocrite who wears the garments of the devotees in order that he may be thought to be a devotee, not being so: or, as some say, the person who wears a shirt to the sleeves of which he attaches two other sleeves in order to make it appear that he is wearing two shirts: or [the wearer of the garments of the false witness; for] it is said that there used to be in the tribe the man of goodly exterior, and when false witness was needed, he bore [such] witness, and was not rejected, because of the goodliness of his apparel. (Mgh.) [See also art. zwr, in which this trad, is cited with a small variation.]

1 $abiqa * , (S, M, O, Msb, K,) aor.
$abaqa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. $abaqN, (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb,) He was, or became, affected with vehement lust, or carnal desire: (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K:) said of a man; (M, Msb;) and in like manner one says of a woman; and also, sometimes, of other than human beings. (M, TA.) ― -b2- And $abiqa mina All~aHomi He suffered indigestion, or turned away with disgust, from flesh-meat. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

$abiqN *
Affected with vehement lust or carnal desire; (Msb, TA;) applied to a man; and sometimes to other than man: (Msb:) fem. with p. (Msb, TA.)

$uwbaqN *
A certain wooden implement of the baker, or maker of bread; (K;) a baker's rolling-pin; (MA;) [thus called, and also $uwbak, in the present day;] an arabicized word, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) from [the Pers.] juwbah [or Juwbaho, or from the Pers. $uwbajo]. (TA.) [See also kariybo.]

1 $abakahu * , aor.
$abika , (K, TA,) inf. n. $abokN; (TA;) and ↓ $b~khu, inf. n. ta$obiykN; He infixed, (K, TA,) and inserted, (TA,) one part thereof into another, or parts thereof into others: (K, TA:) so in the M: (TA:) [but the latter more usually signifies he infixed, and inserted, many parts thereof into others: (see 8, first sentence, respecting its quasipass.:) and hence, he made it reticulated, retiform, like a net; and like a lattice, or trellis, or grating, or cage: and both signify also he made it commingled in its several parts, intricate, complicated, perplexed, or confused; either properly, as when the object is a fabric, or anything made by art, or created; or tropically, as when the object is ideal:] primarily, (TA,) Al$~aboku signifies AlxaloTu [i. e. the mixing together a thing or things]; and [implies] Alt~adaAxulu [i. e. the entering of one part of a thing into another part, or of parts of a thing or things into other parts; or the being intermixed, or intermingled]. (S, TA.) Hence, AlA^aSaAbiEi ↓ ta$obiyku, (S, TA,) meaning The inserting of some of the fingers [i. e. those of one hand] amid the other fingers; (Msb, TA;) which it is forbidden to do in prayer: (TA:) one says, [$b~k A^aSaAbiEahu, or] $b~k bayona A^aSaAbiEihi, He inserted, or interserted, his fingers together [so as to conjoin his two hands]: (MA:) or, as some interpret it, ta$obiyku AlA^aSaAbiEi which is forbidden in prayer is (assumed tropical:) the mixing, and entering, into contentions, or altercations. (TA.) [Hence also,] ↓ kaAnati Alr~iyHu $ab~akatohumo, a saying of Mohammad Ibn-Zekereeyà, meaning (assumed tropical:) The wind had made them like the $abakap [or net], in the interkniting and contraction of the limbs. (Mgh.) ― -b2- $abakahu Eanohu, inf. n. as above, means (assumed tropical:) He, or it, diverted him, or occupied him so as to divert him, from him, or it. (TA.)
2 $ab~aka see above, in three places: -A2- and see also 8, in two places.
3 $Abk bayonahumaA * , inf. n. mu$aAbakapN, [app. (assumed tropical:) He caused an embroilment between them two,] occurring in a tradition, (TA.)

4 A$bkwA *
They dug wells (O, K) such as are called $ibaAkN (O) or such as are called $abakapN. (K.) ― -b2- And A^a$obaka It (a place) had [such] wells dug in it by many persons. (TA.)
5 ta$ab~aka see 8, in four places.

6 ta$aAobaka see 8, in three places, ― -b2- t$Abkt Als~ibaAEu The beasts of prey leaped [the females]; syn. nazato: (K:) or desired to do so (A^araAdati Aln~izaA='i). (IAar, TA.) ― -b3- ta$aAbakaA [app. (assumed tropical:) They became embroiled, each with the other;] quasi-pass. of $aAbaka bayonahumaA. (TA.)

8 A$tbk * , quasi-pass. of $abakahu, It had one part thereof infixed, (K, TA,) and inserted, (TA,) into another, or parts thereof into others; as also ↓ t$b~k, quasi-pass. of $b~khu: (K, TA:) so in the M: but ↓ the latter imports muchness, or multiplicity: (TA:) [i. e. it signifies it had many parts thereof infixed, and inserted, into others: and hence, it was reticulated, retiform,
like a net; and like a lattice, or trellis, or grating, or cage: and both signify also it was, or became, commingled in its several parts, intricate, complicated, perplexed, or confused; either properly, as when said of a fabric, or anything made by art, or created; or tropically, as when said of what is ideal.] One says, A$tbkt Aln~ujuwmu, and ↓ t$Abkt, and ↓ $ab~akat, [or the last may be a mistranscription for ↓ t$b~kt,] The stars were intermixed among themselves, and confused: (TA:) [or were clustered together:] or Ai$otibaAku Aln~ujuwmi signifies the stars' being numerous, and being intermixed among themselves; from $abakapu AlS~aAy^idi [“the net of the fisherman” or “sportsman”]: (Mgh:) or their being numerous, and [as though] gathered [or clustered] together: (Msb:) or, as some say, the appearing of all the stars [which causes them to appear confused]. (TA.) And A$tbkt AlEuruwqu The veins were knit together, commingled, or intricately intermixed or intermingled; syn. Ai$otajarat. (O, TA.) And A$tbk Als~araAbu The mirage became intermixed, or confused. (TA.) And A$tbk AlZ~alaAmu (tropical:) The darkness became confused. (S, O, TA.) And A$tkbt AlA^umuwru, and ↓ t$Abkt, and ↓ $b~kt, (K, TA,) and ↓ t$b~kt, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The affairs became intricate, complicated, perplexed, or confused. (K, TA.) And A$tkbt AlHarobu bayonahumo (assumed tropical:) The war, or fight, became intricate, and entangled between them; syn. na$ibat. (TA in art. n$b.) And A$tbkt A^anoyaAbuhu waA@xotalafato [His canine teeth locked together, and were dissimilar]; referring to a lion. (O. [See also $aAbikN.]) Ai$otibaAku Alr~aHimi means (tropical:) The close [or intimate] connexion of relationship by birth: (TA:) [and in like manner, AlA^aroHaAmi ↓ ta$aAbuku such connexion of relationships by birth: see an ex. of its part. n., voce mu$otabikN.]
$abakN * : see $abakapN. ― -b2- Also The teeth of a comb; (O, K;) because of their nearness together. (TA.)

bayonahumaA $ubokapN * , (K,) or $ubokapN nasabK, (S, Msb,) (tropical:) Between them two is [a close or an intimate connexion of] relationship by birth: (S, K, TA:) and bayona Alqawomi $ubokapu nasabK (tropical:) Between the people, or party, is an intermingling [of relationship]. (O, TA.)

$abakapN * The $arakap [meaning net] of the Say~aAd [i. e. fisherman, and fowler or sportsman]; (K;) the miSoyadap, (Lth, O, TA,) or instrument of AlS~ayod, (S,) that is used in the water [i. e. for catching fish] and on the land [i. e. for catching fowls or wild animals]; (Lth, O, * TA;) applied by some peculiarly to the miSoyadap of the water; (TA;) and ↓ $ub~aAkN signifies the same: (K:) pl. of the former $ibaAkN (S, Msb, K) and $abakaAtN (Msb) and [coll. gen. n.] ↓ $abakN: (Msb, K:) and the pl. of ↓ $ub~aAkN is $abaAbiyku (K.) ― -b2- And A certain thing for the head; (Lth, O;) [a small net, for the head, a veil of net-work, in order that the face may not be known.
