(Golius, on the authority of Meyd.)] -A2- Also Wells near together, (K, TA,) of which the water is near [to the mouths], communicating [app. by filtration] one with another: so accord. to El-Kutabee: (TA:) or wells separate, one from another: (M and L in art. mA^d:) and, (K,) or as some say, (TA,) wells (O, K, TA) that are open to view, (K, TA,) dug in a rugged place, of the depth of the stature of a man, and twice and thrice that measure, in which the rain-water becomes retained: so called because of their mutual proximity, and confusedness: a single one of them is not called $abakapN; for this is only a name for a plural number; but the pl. $ibaAkN is applied to aggregates thereof in sundry places: (O, TA:) or $ibaAkN, (S,) or $abakapN, (Msb,) signifies wells that are numerous and near together in a [tract of] land; (S, Msb;) form Ai$otibaAku Aln~ujuwmi: (Msb:) or, accord. to As, $abakapN signifies wells, or other pits or hollows dug in the ground, that are numerous; and the pl. is $ibaAkN. (IDrd, O.) ― -b2- And A [tract of] land in which are many wells, (K, TA,) not tracts that exude water and produce salt, nor such as give growth to plants, or herbage: (TA:) or [the pl.] $ibaAkN signifies places, of the earth, that are not such as exude water and produce salt, nor such as give growth to plants, or herbage; such as the $ibaAk of El-Basrah. (Lth, O.) ― -b3- And The burrow of the [field-rat called] jura*: (K, TA:) or the burrows thereof, which are near together: pl. $ibaAkN. (TA.)

$ibaAkN * , (thus in the 'Eyn and O and L and TA,) or ↓ $ub~aAkN, (thus in the K, there said to be like zun~aArN,) but [SM says that] the latter is a manifest mistake, (TA,) A thing, (K, TA,) or anything, (Lth, O,) composed of canes, or reeds, (K, TA,) or such as canes, or reeds, (Lth, O,) firmly bound together, (Lth, O, TA,) in the manner of the manufacture of mats: (Lth, O, K, TA:) a single piece whereof is termed ↓ $ibaAkapN, (Lth, O, TA,) or ↓ $ub~aAkapN. (So in the K.) ― -b2- And likewise, (i. e. $ibaAkN, as in the 'Eyn and O and L, but in the K ↓ $ub~aAkN, TA,) What is between the curved pieces of wood of the [vehicles called] maHaAmil, [pl. of maHomil, q. v., composed] of net-work of thongs (mino ta$obiyki Alqid~i [Alqid~ being here used as a coll. gen. n.: see art. qd]). (K, TA.)
$ibaAkapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
$abaAy^iku * [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned,] Contentions, or altercations. (TA.)

$ab~aAkN * means mano yaEomalu Al$~ibaAka AlwaTiy~aAti [app. A maker of soft netted fabrics of thongs for maHaAmil; (see $ibaAkN, latter sentence;) supposing AlwaTiy~aAti to be for AlwaTiyoy^aAti, agreeably with a well-known license]. (TA.)

$ub~aAkN * : see $abakapN, in two places: ― -b2- and $ibaAkN, likewise in two places: ― -b3- and $ub~aAkapN, also in two places. ― -b4- Applied to a diroE i. q. maHobuwkapN [app. as signifying Woven well, or well and compactly; in which sense this epithet seems to be more properly applicable to a woman's “shift” than to “a coat of mail;” but diroEN in the former of these senses is seldom, if ever, fem.; and in the latter sense, seldom, if ever, masc.]. (TA.) -A2- [It is also a pl., of which the sing., if used, is probably ↓ $aAbikN, accord. to analogy; as a possessive epithet, meaning *uw $abakapK, like laAbinN meaning *uw labanK, &c.:] one says, raA^ayotu EalaY AlmaA='i Al$~ub~aAka I saw, upon the water, the fishermen with the nets. (Az, Z, TA.)

$ub~aAkapN * , (S, O, KL,) or ↓ $ub~aAkN, (Msb, TA,) A thing formed of grating, or lattice-work, (↓ ma$obakapN, S, O, or mu$ab~akN, KL, TA,) or iron, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) and of other material [i. e. of wood &c.]: (TA:) and [particularly] a window so formed: (KL:) pl. $abaAbiyku. (S, O, TA.) One says, raA^ayotuhu ↓ yanoZuru mina Al$~ub~aAki [I saw him looking from the grated, or latticed, window]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also $ibaAkN.

$aAbikN * [app. a possessive epithet, meaning *uw $abakapK]: see $ub~aAkN. ― -b2- [Also meaning *uw A@$otibaAkK.] One says TariyqN $aAbikN A road, or way, that is confused and intricate. (O, K.) ― -b3- [Hence,] A^um~u Aln~ujuwmi Al$~awaAbiki may mean The sun; as being the chief of the [confused] stars: or the milky way; [as being composed of confused stars;] Al$~awaAbik [pl. of Al$~aAbikap] meaning ↓ Almu$otabikap. (Ham pp. 43 and 44.) ― -b4- And luHomapN $aAbikapN: see mu$otabikN. ― -b5- And $aAbikN applied to a lion, Having the canine teeth locking together, (AlA^anoyaAbi ↓ mu$otabiku, K, TA, [see 8, near the end, in the CK muta$ab~iku AlAanoyaAbi,]) dissimilar: (TA:) and $Abiku AlA^anoyaAbi is applied to a camel, (O, TA,) in like manner. (TA.) [Hence,] Al$~aAbiku is one of the names for The lion. (TA.) ― -b6- And one says rajulN $aAbiku Alr~umoHi, meaning A man whom one sees, by reason of his skill, thrusting with the spear [indiscriminately] in all the faces. (O, TA.)
mu$ab~akN * : see $ub~aAkapN. ― -b2- Almu$ab~aku is A certain sort of food. (TA.)

mu$otabikN * : see $aAbikN, in two places. ― -b2- raHimN mu$otabikapN (A'Obeyd, S, TA) means (tropical:) [Relationship by birth] closely, or intimately, connected. (A'Obeyd, TA.) And one says also, ↓ bayonahumaA A^aroHaAmN muta$aAbikapN (tropical:) [Between them two are relationships by birth closely, or intimately, connected]: and ↓ luHomapN $aAbikapN [which means the like]. (TA.)
A^aroHaAmN muta$aAbikapN * : see what next precedes.

1 $abala * , (K,) aor.
$abula , (TK,) inf. n. $ubuwlN, He (a boy, TA) became a youth, or young man, (K,) or grew up, and became a youth, or young man, (TA,) in a state of ease and plenty. (K, TA. [In the CK, fY niEomapK is erroneously put for fY naEomapK.]) Accord. to Ks, one says, $abalotu fiY baniY fulaAnK, meaning I grew up, or became a youth, or young man, among the sons of such a one: (S, TA:) and qado $abala AlgulaAmu A^aHosana $ubuwlK The boy has grown up, or become a youth, or young man, in the best manner: (S:) but accord. to others,
it is not said except in the case of being in a state of ease and plenty. (TA.)

4 A^a$obalati AlmaroA^apu baEoda baEolihaA * (assumed tropical:) The woman bore with her children, [tending them patiently, after the loss of her husband,] without marrying: (S, O:) [and] A$blt EalaY waladihaA (tropical:) She (a woman) applied herself constantly to the care of her children, after [the loss of] her husband, (K, TA,) and bore with them, (TA,) not marrying: (K, TA:) and the epithet applied to her is ↓ mu$obilN [without p]. (TA.) One says, hiYa fiY A_i$obaAlihaA kaAll~abuwapi EalaY A^a$obaAlihaA (tropical:) [She is, in her constant application of herself to the care of her children, &c., like the lioness over her whelps]. (TA.) ― -b2- And A$bl Ealayohi (tropical:) He inclined to him; affected him; or was, or became, favourably inclined towards him: (S, O, K, TA:) and he aided, helped, or assisted, him. (K, TA.)

7 An$bl * is expl. by Golius as signifying “Leviter e loco exivit, effluxit;” as on the authority of the KL; but I do not find it in my copy of that work; and think that it is some other word to which this meaning is there assigned.]

$ibolN * The whelp, or young one, of the lion: (S, Mgh, O, Msb:) or the young one of the lion when it has attained to the seeking, or taking, of prey: (K, TA:) [and Freytag says, on the authority of Meyd, of any wild beast:] pl. A^a$obaAlN (S, O, Msb, K) and A^a$obulN (S, O, K) [both properly pls. of pauc.] and [pl. of mult.] $ubuwlN and $ibaAlN. (K.)

$aAbilN * A lion whose canine teeth have become such as lock together, dissimilar; expl. by the words Aal~a*iY A@$otabakato A^anoyaAbuhu. (K. [Perhaps, in this sense, a mistranscription for $aAbikN, q. v.]) ― -b2- And (K) (assumed tropical:) A boy, or young man, full [or plump] in body, by reason of ease and plenty and of youthfulness: (IAar, O, K: *) and so $aAbinN, and HiDajorN. (IAar, O.) ― -b3- [$aAbilapN, expl. by Golius as signifying “Diminuta lacte camela, pulli septimestris mater,” as on the authority of the KL, is a mistake for $aAy^ilapN.]

[
A^a$obalu * , expl. by Golius as signifying “Magno veretri præputio camelus,” as on the authority of the KL, is a mistake for A^avoyalu.]

mu$obilN * A lioness whose whelps, or young ones, accompany her, (S, O, Msb,) going with her. (S, O.) And A she-camel whose young one has become strong, and goes with her. (AZ, S, O.) ― -b2- See also 4.
ma$obuwlN * A place in which are lions' whelps or young ones. (Ham p. 416.)

1 $abima * , (S, K,) aor.
$abama , (K,) inf. n. $abamN, (TA,) It was, or became, cold; (S, K;) said of water. (S.) -A2- $abama AljadoYa, (K,) aor.
$abuma , inf. n. $abomN, (TK,) He put the $ibaAm [q. v.] in the mouth of the kid; as also ↓ $b~mhu, (K,) inf. n. ta$obiymN. (TA.)
2 $ab~ama see what next precedes.

$abamN *
Cold, or coldness; (S, Msb, K;) accord. to the M, of water: (TA:) but one says gadaApN *aAtu $abamK [A morning having coldness]: (S:) and yawomN *uw $abamK A day having coldness. (Msb.) ― -b2- Jureybeh Ibn-El-Ashyam El-Fak'asee says,
waqado $ab~ahuwA AlEiyra A^aforaAsanaA
faqado wajaduwA mayorahaA *aA $abamo
[And they likened our horses to the camels carrying provision of corn; but they found their provision to be something having coldness]; meaning, accord. to Aboo-Riyásh, that they found death; for death is cold; and poison also is cold: but there is another reading, accord. to which the last word is ba$amo, meaning “heaviness,” such as results from food. (Ham p. 363.) See also the next paragraph.

$abimN *
Cold, as an epithet, (S, Msb, TA,) applied to water, (S, TA,) and to rain; and one says gadaApN $abimapN, meaning A cold morning. (TA.) [And] Feeling cold: (K:) or feeling cold together with hunger. (AA, S, K.) ― -b2- Also A weapon, or weapons; as being cold: and such has been said to be the meaning [of ↓ *aA $abamo] in the verse cited above. (TA.) ― -b3- And Death; because of its coldness: ― -b4- and Poison; for the same reason. (K. [But see the verse cited above, and the explanation of it.]) -A2- And baqarapN $abimapN A fat ox or cow, or beast of the bovine kind: (K, TA:) but the epithet commonly known is sanimapN, [meaning “having a large hump,”] with s and n. (TA.)
$ibam~N * : see $ibaAmN.

$abaAmN *
A certain plant, (AHn, K,) resembling in colour the Hin~aA=' [q. v.]. (AHn, TA.)

$ibaAmN *
A piece of wood which is put crosswise in the mouth of a kid, (S, K, TA,) or, as in the M, in the two sides of the mouth of a kid or lamb, and tied behind its head, (TA,) in order that it may not suck its mother; (S, K;) as also ↓ $ibma: (K:) and so Hi$aAkN. (IDrd and S in art. H$k.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) or the dual, $ibaAmaAni, (S, TA,) Two threads, or strings, attached to the [kind of face-veil called] buroquE, by which the woman [draws and] binds [the two upper corners of] it to the back of her head: (S, K:) [also called vibaAtN:] pl. $ubumN. (O in art. snbk.)

mu$ab~amN * : see the following paragraph. Applied to a lion, it means Having his mouth tied, or bound; from $ibaAmN in the former of the senses expl. above: (Meyd, TA:) thus in the following prov.:
taforaqu mino Sati AlguraA
bi wataforisu AlA^asada Almu$ab~amo
[She is frightened at the cry of the crow, or raven, and breaks the neck of the lion whose mouth is tied]: (Meyd, K, TA:) or, accord. to another relation, Almu$at~am, [meaning “ the grimfaced, ”] from $ataAmapu Alwajohi: (Meyd:) a saying originating from the fact of a woman's breaking the neck of a lion, and then hearing the cry of a crow, or raven, and being frightened: applied to him who advances boldly to undertake that which is of high account, [or attended with peril,] and fears that which is contemptible. (Meyd, K.)
ma$obuwmN * [and ↓ mu$ab~amN] A kid, or lamb, having the piece of wood called $ibaAm put into its mouth and tied behind its head, in order that it may not suck its mother. (TA.)

2 $ab~ahahu A_iy~aAhu * and bihi , (MA, K,) inf. n. ta$obiyhN, (S, K, KL,) He made it to be like it, or to resemble it; he assimilated it to it; (MA, KL;) i. q. mav~alahu [meaning thus: and also meaning he likened it to it, or compared it with it; agreeably with the explanation here next following]: (S, * K:) $ab~ahatu Al$~aYo'a biAl$~aYo'i I put the thing in the place, or predicament, of the [other] thing, by reason of an attribute connecting them [or common to them]; which attribute may be real and ideal; real as when one says, “ this dirhem is like this dirhem, ” and “ this blackness is like this blackness; ” and ideal as when one says, “ Zeyd is like the lion ” or “ like the ass ” i. e. in his strength or his stupidity, and “ Zeyd is like 'Amr ” i. e. in his power and his generosity and similar qualities; and sometimes it is tropical, as when one says, “ the absent is like the non-existent, ” and “ the garment is like the dirhem ” i. e. the value of the garment is equivalent to the dirhem. (Msb.) $ab~ahu, [app. for $b~h $ayoy^FA bi$aYo'K,] accord. to IAar, means He made a thing equal to a thing, or like a thing. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] $b~hhu Ealayohi, inf. n. as above, He rendered it confused to him [by making it to appear like some other thing]; (JK, * TA;) he rendered it ambiguous, dubious, or obscure, to him. (MA.) See also 8, [with which it is, in its pass. form, and in its act. form likewise, nearly or exactly syn. in one of the senses,] in two places. ― -b3- [And $ab~ahatohu A_ilayohi Aln~afosu, or AlHaAlu, The mind, or the case, imaged it to him; like xay~alatohu: see art. xyl.] See also 5, [with which, in its pass. form, this verb is nearly or exactly syn. in one sense.] ― -b4- [ta$obiyhN used as a simple subst. means A comparison, simile, similitude, or parable: and has for its pl. ta$obiyhaAtN. Hence, EalaY Alt~a$obiyhi By way of comparison.]
3 $aAobaha see the next paragraph, in four places.

4 A$bhhu * , [inf. n. A_i$obaAhN;] and ↓ $Abhhu, [inf. n. mu$aAbahapN;] (S, K;) He was, or became, like him; he resembled him; syn. maAvalahu. (K.) One says A^a$obaha Alwaladu A^abaAhu, and ↓ $Abhhu, The child [resembled his father, or] shared with his father in some one of his qualities, or attributes. (Msb.) And mano A^a$obaha A^abaAhu famaA Zalama, (Meyd, TA,) or ↓ mano yu$aAbihu A^bahu famaA Zalama, as some relate it, (TA,) [Whoso resembles his father, he has not done that which is wrong:] a prov., meaning, he has not put the likeness in the wrong place; for there is not any one more fit, or proper, for him to resemble than he: or it may mean that the father has not done
that which is wrong. (Meyd. [See also Har pp. 667-8.]) And A$bh Alr~ajulu A^um~ahu, (IAar, K,) and ↓ $aAbahahaA, (K,) [The man resembled his mother,] meaning (assumed tropical:) the man became impotent, and weak. (IAar, K.) And it is said in a trad. of 'Omar, A_in~a All~abana yu$obahu Ealayohi [Verily one becomes like by feeding upon milk]: i. e. the infant that is suckled often becomes like the woman who suckles it, because of the milk: (JK:) or Allbn y$bh [app. for All~abanu yu$obahu Ealayohi]: i. e. one acquires a likeness to the natural dispositions of the woman who suckles [him]: or, as it is also related, ↓ yt$b~h [app. for yuta$ab~ahu Ealayohi]. (TA.) -A2- [A$bh is also a verb of wonder: hence the saying,
maA A^a$obaha All~ayolapa biAlbaAriHaho
How like is this night to yesternight! expl. in art. brH.]

5 t$b~h bihi * [He became assimilated to him, or it: and he assumed, or affected, a likeness, or resemblance, to him, or it; he imitated him, or it;] he made himself to be like, or to resemble, him, or it; (MA, KL; *) i. q. tmv~l: (S, * TA: [in the former, this meaning is indicated, but not expressed:]) said of a man. (S.) See also 4, last sentence but one. ― -b2- [Hence,] t$b~h lahu A^an~ahu ka*aA It became imaged to him [in the mind, i. e. it seemed to him,] that it was so; syn. taxay~ala, (S and K * in art. xyl,) and taxaAyala: (S in that art.:) and A_ilayohi A^an~ahu ka*aA ↓ $ub~iha [signifies the same; or] it was imaged to him [in the mind] that it was so; syn. xuy~ila. (PS in that art.)

6 ta$aAbuhN * signifies The being equal, or uniform; syn. AisotiwaA='N: (TA:) [or rather the being consimilar.] You say, ta$aAbahaA They were like, or they resembled, each other. (MA.) And AlxuTuwTu tata$aAbahu The lines are like one another; the lines resemble one another. (Mgh.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph, in two places.

8 Ai$otabahaA * and ↓ ta$aAbahaA They resembled each other so that they became confounded, or confused, or dubious. (K.) And A$tbh (S, MA) and ↓ t$Abh (MA) It (a thing, S, MA, or an affair, MA) was, or became, ambiguous, dubious, or obscure, (MA,) EalaY~a [to me], (S,) or Ealayohi [to him]: (MA:) and Ealayohi AlA^amoru ↓ $ub~iha the thing, or affair, was rendered confused, or dubious, to him: (K, * TA:) and Al$~aYo'u ↓ $abahN, also, [see mu$otabihN,] the thing was, or became, confused, or dubious. (IAar, TA.)

$ibohN * and ↓ $abahN are syn., (S, Msb, K,) like mivolN and mavalN, and bidolN and badalN, and nikolN and nakalN, the only other instances of the kind, i. e. of words of both these measures, that have been heard, having the same meaning, (S and TA in art. bdl,) i. q. ↓ $abiyhN, (S, Msb, K,) syn. mivolN, (K,) [i. e.] A like; a similar person or thing; (MA; Msb;) [an analogue; a match;] a fellow: (MA:) pl. (of all, TA) A^a$obaAhN. (K, TA.) One says, h`*aA $ibohuhu [and ↓ $abahuhu], i. e. ↓ $abiyhuhu [meaning This is the like, &c., of him, or it]. (S.) And fulaAnN $ibohuka and ↓ $abahuka and ↓ $abiyhuka [Such a one is the like, &c., of thee]. (JK.) [And ↓ bihi This is like him, or it. And hence, in lexicology, AlA^a$obaAhu waAln~aZaAy^iru The words that are alike in form: generally applied to rare instances.] ― -b2- See also the next paragraph, in two places.

$abahN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in three places. ― -b2- [Hence,] syn. with $akolN [signifying A likeness, resemblance, or semblance, as meaning something resembling]; (AA, K and TA in art. $kl;) and ↓ $ubohapN is syn. with mivolN [in the same sense]: (K in the present art.: [see exs. of the latter voce EuqorN:]) pl. of the former [in this sense, as is indicated in the S,] ↓ ma$aAbihu, contr. to rule, like maHaAsinu and ma*aAkiyru; (S, TA;) or this is a pl. having no proper sing. (TA.) One says, bayonahumaA $abahN [Between them two is a likeness, &c.]. (S,) And nazaEa A_ilaY A^abiyhi fiY Al$~abahi [He inclined to his father in likeness]. (S, in art. nzE.) And a poet cited by IAar says,
A^aSobaHa fiyhi $abahN mino A^um~ihi
mino EiZami Alr~aA^osi wamino xuroTum~ihi
[He became so that there was in him a resemblance of his mother, in respect of bigness of the head, and of his nose]. (TA.) And one says also, lahu ↓ bihi $ubohapN i. e. mivolN [In him is a likeness, or something having a likeness, to him, or it]. (TK.) ― -b3- Also, (JK, S, Msb, K, &c.,) and ↓ $ibohN, (JK, S, K,) and ↓ $abahaAnN, (K, TA, but not in the CK,) [A sort of fine brass;] a metal resembling gold in its colour, the highest in quality of Sufor [or brass]; (Msb;) yellow nuHaAs; (K;) a sort of nuHaAs (JK, T, S, M *) rendered yellow by the addition of an alloy (lit. a medicament): (T, M, * TA:) so called because resembling gold in its colour: (M, TA:) pl. A^a$obaAhu. (K.) One says kuwzu $abahK and ↓ $ibohK [A mug of $bh]. (S.) -A2- See also $abahaAnN.

$ubohapN * : see $abahN, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence,] Confusedness, or dubiousness: (S, K:) pl. $ubahN (TA) [and $ubohaAtN and $ubahaAtN and $ubuhaAtN: whence the phrase A^aSoHaAbu Al$~ubuhaAti Those persons who are of dubious characters; those who are objects of suspicion]. One says, layosa fiyhi $ubohapN [There is not any confusedness, or dubiousness, in respect of it]: referring to property. (Msb voce $aAy^ibapN, in art. $wb.)

$abahaAnN * and ↓ $abahN, (K accord. to the TA,) the latter on the authority of IB, (TA, [and mentioned also in the M voce sayaAlN on the authority of AA,]) A certain thorny plant, (K accord. to the TA,) resembling the samur [or gum-acacia-tree], (TA,) having an elegant red blossom, and grains like the $ahodaAnaj [or hemp-seed], an antidote for the bite, or sting, of venomous reptiles, beneficial for the cough, lithotriptic, and binding to the bowels. (K accord. to the TA: but see what here follows.) And ↓ $ubuhaAnN, (K accord. to the TA,) or $abahaAnN, (so in a copy of the S,) or both, (so in copies of the K,) or ↓ $abuhaAnN, or ↓ $ubahaAnN, (so in different copies of the S, [the latter of these two I find in one copy only,]) A kind of trees, of the [kind called] EiDAah: (S, K:) or the vumaAm [i. e. panic grass]: (K, TA, but not in the CK:) or the nam~aAm [now commonly applied to wild thyme, thymus serpyllum], (S, K), one of the sweetsmelling plants, (S,) having an elegant red flower, &c., as in the next preceding sentence. (So in copies of the K. [See $ahabaAnN.]) -A2- See also $abahN.
$abuhaAnN * , or $ubuhaAnN, or $ubahaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph.

$abaAhN * (Lth, JK, K) and $ubaAhN (CK [but not in my MS. copy of the K nor in the TA]) A certain grain, like that called Hurof (Lth, JK, K) in colour, [see HurofN and ra$aAdN,] which is taken, i. e. swallowed, as a medicine. (Lth, JK.)
$abiyhN * : see $ibohN, in four places.

A^a$obahu * [More, and most, like]. A^a$obahu mina Alt~amorapi biAlt~amorapi [More like than the date to the date] is a prov.: and so A^a$obahu mina AlmaA='i biAlmaA='i [More like than water to water]. (Meyd.) ― -b2- [And More, or most, suitable. One says, h`*aA A^a$obahu bika This is more suitable to thee. And h`*aA AlA^a$obahu This is the most suitable.]
mu$ab~ahN * : [see its verb: ― -b2- and] see mu$otabihN. ― -b3- Also, applied to the plant called naSiY~, Becoming yellow. (TA.)
mu$ab~ihN * : [see its verb: ― -b2- and] see ma$otabihN.
ma$aAbihu * : see $abahN, of which it is said to be an anomalous pl.

mu$otabihN * [part. n. of 8, q. v.]. mu$otabihaAtN, (S,) and ↓ mu$ab~ihaAtN, [thus agreeably with an explanation of its verb by IAar, (see 8, last sentence,)] (JK,) or A^umuwrN mu$otabihapN, and ↓ mu$ab~ahapN like muEaZ~amapN, (K,) Things, or affairs, that are confused or dubious [by reason of their resembling one another or from any other cause]: (JK, S, K:) [and uncertain: (see an ex. of mu$ab~ah in this sense in a verse cited voce sanafa:)] ↓ mu$otabihFA wagayora muta$aAbihK, in the Kur [vi. 99], means resembling one another so that they become confounded, or confused, or dubious, and not resembling one another &c. (TA.)

muta$aAbihN *
Consimilar, or conformable, in its several parts: thus muta$aAbihFA means in the Kur xxxix. 24. (Jel.) And muta$aAbihaAtN Things like, or resembling, one another. (JK, S.) ― -b2- See also mu$otabihN. ― -b3- muta$aAbihaAtN in the Kur iii. 5 means Verses that are equivocal, or ambiguous; i. e. susceptible of different interpretations: (Ksh:) or verses unintelligible; such as the commencements [of many] of the chapters: (Jel:) or the muta$aAbih in the Kur is that of which the meaning is not to be learned from its words; and this is of two sorts; one is that of which the meaning is known by referring it to what is termed muHokam [q. v.]; and the other is that of which the knowledge of its real meaning is not attainable in any way: (TA:) or it means what is not understood without repeated con-
sideration: (TA in art. fsr:) Ed-Dahhák is related to have explained AlmuHokamaAtu as meaning “ what have not been abrogated; ” and Almuta$aAbihaAtu as meaning what have been abrogated. (TA in the present art.)

1 $abaA * , (K,) [aor.
$abuwa ,] inf. n. $abowN, (TA,) It was or became, high, elevated, or lofty. (K. [See also 4, first sentence.]) ― -b2- $abati Alfarasu, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) The mare stood upon her hind legs. (K.) [It is added in the TA that the vulgar say $b~t: but see art. $b, where a similar meaning is assigned to $ab~a said of a horse.] ― -b3- $abaA wajohuhu His face shone after having become altered. (K.) -A2- $abaA Aln~aAra, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He kindled the fire; or made it to burn, burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame; (K;) as also $ab~ahaA. (TA.)

4 A^a$obati Al$~ajarapu * , (S,) or A$bY Al$~ajaru, (K,) inf. n. A_i$obaA='N, (TA,) The tree, (S,) or the trees, (K,) became tall, (S, K, TA,) and tangled and dense, by reason of luxuriance (K, TA) and sappiness. (TA.) ― -b2- A$bY said of a man, He begat a boy [sharp] like the point of iron (ka$abaA AlHadiydi): (Yz, TA:) or he had a son born to him sharp in intellect: (S, K, TA:) or he begat generous, or noble, children, by whom he had sharp means of attack and defence, like the points of spear-heads. (Ham p. 384.) -A2- A^a$obayotu Alr~ajula i. q. wajadotu lahu ↓ $abaApF [app. meaning I found the man to have sharpness]. (Ham p. 385.) ― -b2- And A$bAhu He exalted him, syn. rafaEahu, (S,) and honoured him; namely, a man. (S, K.) ― -b3- And He cast him into a well, or into an evil, or a hateful, plight: thus having two contr. meanings. (K.) -A3- A$bY is also syn. with dafaEa [He impelled, pushed, thrust, &c.]. (K. [But perhaps this is a mistake for rafaEa, a syn. of A$bY mentioned before: if not, it may be from $abaApF signifying the “ point ” of anything.]) -A4- And i. q. A^aEoTaY [He gave]. (K. [In this sense, accord. to the TK, trans. without a prep.; which I think doubtful.]) ― -b2- And i. q. A^a$obala, (K,) meaning A^a$ofaqa [i. e. He was, or became, favourably inclined; &c.]. (TA. [In this sense, also, both A$bY and A$bl, accord. to the TK, are trans. without a prep.; but this I think a mistake with respect to both of these verbs, the latter of which is well known to be trans. only by means of EalaY.]) -A5- [And i. q. A^a$obaha.] One says, A$bY fulaAnFA waladuhu, (S,) or A$bY zayodFA A^awolaAduhu, (K,) His children resembled such a one, or, Zeyd; syn. A^a$obahuwhu. (S, K.)
$abFA * : see $abaApN, in two places. -A2- Also The green substance that overspreads stagnant water; syn. TuHolubN. (K.)
$ubowN * [written in my original $ubw] i. q. A*Y [i. e., app., A^a*FY, A state of annoyance or molestation: or annoyance, molestation, harm, or hurt: or a thing that annoys, &c.]. (TA.)

$abaApN * The point (S, K) of the extremity (S) of anything: (S, K:) pl. ↓ $abFA [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.] and [the pl. properly so termed is] $abawaAtN. (S, K. *) ― -b2- And The sting of the scorpion; (K;) [and] so ↓ $abFA [mentioned above as having a pl. meaning]. (Sh, TA in art. $wl; and Ham p. 385.) ― -b3- And The portion with which one cuts, of a sword. (Har p. 17.) ― -b4- And The two sides of the A^asalap [i. e. toe, or tapering head or foremost part,] of a sandal: pl. as above [app. in all of the senses of the sing.]. (K.) ― -b5- [And app. (assumed tropical:) Sharpness, as a quality of a man:] see 4. ― -b6- Also The scorpion: (Fr, TA:) or the scorpion when just born: or a yellow scorpion: (K:) so in the M. (TA.) [See also the next paragraph.] ― -b7- And A mare raising her head (EaATiyapN) in the bridle. (K.) And [A mare] standing upon her hind legs. (K.)

$abowapu *
The scorpion; (A'Obeyd, S, K, TA; [in the CK, $abowapu AlEaqorabi is erroneously put for $abowapu AlEaqorabu;]) a proper name thereof; it may be from Al$~abaA signifying its sting; (Ham p. 385;) determinate; (TA;) imperfectly decl.: (A'Obeyd, S, TA:) it is said in the K, “ and [the article] Al is prefixed to it; ” but this is a mistake: it should be, “ and Al is not prefixed to it: (TA:) [but, although a proper name, it has a pl.;] the pl. is $abawaAtN. (S.) [See also $abaApN, which signifies “ a scorpion, ” and of which $abawaAtN is a pl.] ― -b2- jaAriyapN $abowapN A girl, or young woman, that is bold, much in motion, foul in speech or actions. (TA.)
mu$obFY * [pass. part. n. of 4,] Honoured [&c.]. (TA.) -A2- See also what next follows.

mu$obK * [act. part. n. of 4,] A man having a son born to him sharp in intellect; (Th, K, TA;) and so ↓ mu$obFY, (K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, ma$obiY~N,]) accord. to IAar, but disallowed by Th. (TA.) And the former, accord. to IAar, A man who begets generous offspring. (TA.) ― -b2- And mu$obiyapN A woman affectionate, kind, or favourably inclined, to her children. (TA.)

1 $at~a * , (S, A, Mgh, K,) aor.
$ati3a , (Msb,) inf. n. $at~N (S, Msb, K *) and $ataAtN, (S, A, K, *) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) and $atyitN (K, by implication,) and $utuwtN; (MA;) and ↓ An$t~, (K,) and ↓ Ast$t~, and ↓ t$t~t; (S, K; [but the last, app., has an intensive signification;]) It (the state of affairs, S, or the state of union of a people or party, A, TA) became dissolved, broken up, discomposed, deranged, disorganized, disordered, or unsettled; syn. tafar~aqa, (S, A, Msb, K, TA,) or Ainofaraqa; (CK;) and of the third and fourth verbs, [or rather of all,] Ainota$ara. (TA.) And ↓ t$t~twA They became separated, disunited, dispersed, or scattered. (A.) -A2- See also 2, in two places.

2 $t~t * , (S, K,) inf. n. ta$otiytN; (S;) and ↓ A$t~; and ↓ $at~a, aor.
$ati3a , [which is anomalous in the case of a trans. verb of this class,] inf. n. $at~N and $ataAtN and $atiytN; (K;) [the first and second mentioned in the K only with reference to God as the agent;] He dissolved, broke up, discomposed, deranged, disorganized, disordered, or unsettled, syn. far~aqa, (S, K,) the state of affairs [&c.], (S,) and the state of union of a people or party. (TA.) And one says also, biY qawomiY ↓ A$t~ My people, or party, dissolved, broke up, &c., my state of affairs. (S, TA.) And biqalobiY ↓ $at~a ka*aA waka*aA Such and such things discomposed, or disorganized, (far~aqa, [which may also be rendered frightened,]) my mind, or heart. (As, TA.) And $at~atahumu A@ll~`hu God separated, disunited, dispersed, or scattered, them. (A.)
4 A^a$ota3a see 2, in two places. -A2- [A^a$at~a Ealayoka It (a thing) was, or became, distinct, or clear, to thee. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)]
5 ta$at~a3a see 1, in two places.
7 A_ino$ata3a and 10: see 1.

$at~N * an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.] (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And signifying Separation, disunion, or dispersion: so in the saying, AlHamodu lil~`hi Al~a*iY jamaEanaA mino $at~K [Praise be to God who has brought us together from a state of separation, disunion, or dispersion]: (TA:) a saying mentioned by AA, as heard by him from an Arab of the desert: (S, TA:) and ↓ $ataAtN is [similar in meaning, being] likewise an inf. n. of 1; (S, A, K;) or it is a subst. from the intrans. verb $at~a, (Msb,) and signifies a state of separation or disunion; as in the saying, A^axaAfu Ealayokumu Al$~ataAta [I fear for you separation, or disunion]. (TA.) -A2- Also i. q. mutafar~iqN [meaning Dissolved, broken up, discomposed, deranged, disorganized, disordered, or unsettled; and separated, disunited, dispersed, or scattered]; as also ↓ $atiytN, (S, A, Msb,) [and ↓ $ataAtN, as will be shown in what follows;] or ↓ $atiytN is syn. with mufar~aqN, [which is virtually the same as mutafar~iqN,] and mu$at~atN: (K:) the pl. of $at~N is A^a$otaAtN (S) [and $utuwtN also, as will be shown by an ex. in what follows]: and ↓ $at~aY is pl. of ↓ $atiytN, like as maroDaY is of mariyDN; (Jel in xx. 55, and MF;) or, accord. to some, it is a sing. noun. (MF.) One says A^amorN $at~N i. e. mutafar~iqN [A state of affairs dissolved, broken up, &c.]; (S;) and [so] ↓ A^amorN $ataAtN, the latter word being an inf. n. used as an epithet. (Ham p. 176.) And ↓ SaAra jamoEuhumo $atiytFA i. e. mutafar~iqFA [Their company, or congregated body, became separated, disunited, dispersed, or scattered]. (A.) And jaAw^uwA A^a$otaAtFA They came separated, disunited, dispersed, or scattered; syn. mutafar~iqiyna: (S, Msb, K:) and so ↓ jAw^wA $ataAta $ataAta, (K,) in one copy of the K $ataAta wa$ataAta; and MF allows ↓ $utaAta, like vulaAva and rubaAEa; but there is no apparent reason for the repetition; and accord. to the L, the phrase as transmitted from the authorities worthy of confidence is ↓ jaA='a Alqawomu $ataAtFA and $ataAta i. e. The people, or party, came separated, &c. (TA.) And ↓ qawomN $at~aY (S, Msb, K, TA) A people, or party, separated, &c.; syn. mutafar~iquwna: (Msb, TA:) or consisting of sundry, or distinct, bodies; not of one
tribe. (K.) And A_in~a Almajolisa layajomaEu $utuwtFA mina Aln~aAsi, (S, TA,) and mina Aln~aAsi ↓ $at~aY, Verily the assembly comprises sundry, or distinct, bodies of men; (TA;) or men not of one tribe. (S TA.) And ↓ A^a$oyaA='u $at~aY [Things of sundry, or different, or distinct, kinds or sorts]. (S.) A^azowaAjFA mino nabaAtK ↓ $at~aY, in the Kur xx. 55, means Sorts, of plants, various, or different, in colours, tastes, &c. (Jel.) ↓ A^um~ahaAtuhumo $at~aY see expl. voce A^um~N. And taw^uwbu ↓ $at~aY AlHalabaho, a prov., see expl. voce HaAlibN.
$ataAtN * and $ataAta and $ataAtFA: see $at~N, in five places.
$utaAta * : see $at~N.

$atiytN * : see $at~N, in four places. vagorN $atiytN means [Fore teeth] separate, or wide-apart, one from another. (S, A, K.) Tarafeh says,
mino $atiytK kaA^aqaAHi Alr~amoli guro
[meaning From separate fore teeth like white chamomiles of the sands: vagorK being understood, and guro being for gur~K]. (TA.)
$at~aY * : see $at~N, in seven places: ― -b2- and see also the last sentence of the following paragraph.

$at~aAna bayonuhumaA * , (K, TA, but omitted in the CK,) with damm to the n of byn, (TA,) [Different, or distinct, are they two: or widely different or distinct are they two: or how very, or widely, different or distinct, are they two! lit., the union of them two is severed: or the interval between them two is far-extending, or wide: or how greatly is the union of them two severed! as will be shown below.] AZ quotes, in his “ Nawádir, ” with byn in the nom. case, the following verse:
$at~aAna bayonuhumaA fiY kul~i manozilapK
h`*aA yaxaAfu wah`*aA yarotajiY A^abadaA
[Different, or widely different, &c., are they two in every predicament: this fears, and this hopes, ever]. (TA.) The mansoob form, however, is also employed (K, TA, but omitted in the CK) by some of the Arabs in the above-mentioned phrase, so that one says, $at~aAna bayonahumaA, maA being understood, as though one said, $at~a Al~a*iY bayonahumaA [meaning, as above explained, Different, or widely different, &c., are they two: lit., separated, or disunited, or severed, is that which is between them two: or far-extending, or wide, is the interval between them two: or how greatly separated, or severed, is the union between them two!]: Hassán Ibn-Thábit says,
wa$at~aAna bayonakumaA fiY Aln~adaY
wafiY AlbaA^osi waAlxubori waAlmanoZari
[And different, or widely different, &c., are ye two in munificence and in valour and internal state and external appearance]. (TA.) In like manner also, [but with mA,] one says, $at~aAna maA bayonahumaA, (A, Msb, K,) accord. to Th. (TA.) This [as also, consequently, the same phrase without mA] is disallowed by As and IKt: IB, however, says that this phrase occurs in the verses of chaste Arabs: for instance, Abu-l-Aswad EdDuälee says,
wa$at~aAna maA bayoniY wabayonaka A_in~aniY
EalaY kul~i HaAlK A^asotaqiymu wataZolaEu
[And different, or widely different, &c., are I and thou: for I, in every case, go erect, and thou haltest]: and similar is the saying of El-Ba'eeth,
wa$at~aAna maA bayoniY wabayona A@boni xaAlidK
A^umay~apa fiY Alr~izoqi Al~a*iY yataqas~amu
[And different, or widely different, &c., are I and Ibn-Khálid Umeiyeh, with respect to the supplies for the wants of life that are divided among mankind]. (TA.) One says also, $at~aAna maA humaA; (S, A, K;) and $at~aAna maA EamorNw waA^axuwhu; (S, K;) Different, or distinct, or widely different, &c., are they two; and 'Amr and his brother: [lit., separate, or distinct, are they two; &c.: or remote are they two, one from the other; &c.:] or how greatly, or widely, are they two separated; &c.! (S, A, K:) here mA is redundant; and in the former phrase, hmA is the agent of $t~An; as is the former of the two nouns, to which the latter noun is conjoined, in the latter phrase. (TA.) ElAashà says,
$at~aAna maA yawomiY EalaY kuwrihaA
wayawomu Hay~aAna A^axiYjaAbiri
[Different, or widely different, &c., are (or were) my day upon her (the camel's) saddle, and the day of Heiyán the brother of Jábir: in which, for yawomiY and yawomu, some read nawomiY and nawomu]. (S, TA.) And in like manner, [but without mA,] one says, $at~aAna A^axuwhu waA^abuwhu [Different, or widely different, &c., are his brother and his father]. (TA.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited voce daAy^imN, in art. dwm.] ― -b2- $at~aAna, is a preterite verbal noun, signifying Aifotaraqa, [and so expl. above,] accord. to many authorities, [including most of the grammarians,] and therefore they have made it a condition that its agent must be what denotes more than one: [for A$trTwA fY fElh Altrd~d, I read A$trTwA fY fAElhu AltEd~d, which agrees with what is afterwards said in the TA and here; though the former phrase may be so rendered as to convey essentially the same meaning: but this condition is not necessary if we render $t~An by baEuda:] (TA:) or it signifies tabaAEada and Aifotaraqa; (Ibn-Umm-Kásim;) or baEuda; [and so expl. above;] (S, A, Msb, K;) and is inflected from $atuta; (S, K;) [which is a verb not used; in the CK, incorrectly, $atata;] the fet-hah of the n being the fet-hah originally pertaining to the [final] t [of the verb]; and this fet-hah shows the word to be inflected from the preterite verb, like as saroEaAna is from saruEa, and wa$okaAna from wa$uka: (S:) or, accord. to Er-Radee, it implies wonder, [like several verbs of the measure faEula, as shown in remarks on hayuw^a &c.,] and means how greatly separated, disunited, or severed, &c.! (TA:) or, accord. to El-Marzookee and Hr and Zj and some others, it is an inf. n.: El-Marzookee says, in his Expos. of the Fs, that it is an inf. n. of a verb not used, [namely $atuta,] and is indecl., with fet-hah for its termination, because it is put in the place of a pret. verb, being equivalent to $at~a, [for $atuta,] i. e., ta$at~ata A^awo tafar~aqa jid~FA [as expl. above]: and Zj says that it is an inf. n. occupying the place of a verb, of the measure faEolaAn, and therefore indecl., because differing thus from others of its class: Aboo-'Othmán El-Mázinee says that $at~aAn and suboHaAn may receive tenween, whether they be substs, or occupying the place of substs.: upon which AAF observes that if $t~An be in its proper place, it is a verbal noun, meaning $at~a: if with tenween, it is indeterminate; if without tenween, determinate; and if translated from its office of a verbal noun, and made a subst. answering to Alt~a$otiytu, and determinate, it is similar to sbHAn in the phrase suboHaAna mino Ealoqamapa AlfaAxiri, which is a subst. answering to Alt~anoziyhu. (TA.) The n in $at~aAn (sometimes, TA) receives kesreh; (K;) though this is contr. to what is said by AZ and by IDrst: its being sometimes with kesreh is mentioned by Th, on the authority of Fr: and Er-Radee seems to infer that its being so was an opinion of As; and gives two reasons for his disallowal of the expression $t~An mA byn; first, because $t~An occurs with kesr to the n; and second, because its agent cannot be otherwise than what denotes more than one: [but see what has been observed above on this point:] IAmb says that one must not say $at~aAni maA bayona A^axiyka waA^abiyka, because, in this case, $t~An [virtually] governs only one noun in the nom. case: but that one may say, $at~aAni A^axuwka waA^abuwka, and $at~aAni maA A^axuwka waA^abuwka, using $at~aAni as the dual of $at~N; though correctly $t~An is a verbal noun: MF, however, observes that the Expositors of the Fs seem to say that Fr makes $at~aAni to be the dual of $at~N; but that he only mentions it as a dial. var. of $at~aAna: the following is adduced as an ex.
la$at~aAna maA A^anowiY wayanowiY banuw A^abiY
[Different, or widely different, &c., are that which I intend and that which the sons of my father intend]: in which $t~An is read with both fet-hah and kesreh: and it is said in the O that $at~aAni is a dial. var. of $at~aAna. (TA.) ― -b3- IJ mentions ↓ $at~aY as an accidental syn. of $t~An; and says that it is not the fem. of the latter: therefore the assertion of some, that it is used by poetical license in the following verse of Jemeel requires consideration:
A^uriydu SilaAHahaA waturiydu qatoliY
wa$at~aY bayona qatoliY waAlS~ilaAHi
[I desire to make peace with her, but she desires to slay me: and different, or widely different, &c., are slaying me and making peace]. (TA.)

1 $atira * , aor.
$atara , (S, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. $atarN; (T, S, A, Msb, K, &c.;) and $utira; (S, K;) He (a
man) had an inversion in the eyelid; (T, S;) seldom natural: (T:) or an inversion of, (A,) or in, (Msb,) the lower eyelid: (A, Mgh, Msb:) or an inversion of the eyelid above and below, (M, K,) or above or below, (Mgh,) and a contraction thereof: (M:) or a cracking thereof, (K,) so that the edge [for AlxitaAr, in the TA, I read AlHitaAr,] became separate: (Mgh, TA:) or a flaccidity of its lower part. (K.) ― -b2- And $atirati AlEayonu, and $utirat, (K,) and ↓ An$trt, (S, K,) The eye had an inversion in the lid: (S:) [or in, or of, the lower lid:] or an inversion of the lid above and below, (K,) and a contraction thereof: (TA:) or a cracking thereof, (K,) so that the edge became separate: (TA:) or a flaccidity of its lower part. (K.) ― -b3- And $atira, (TK,) inf. n. $atarN, (K,) He (a man) had his lower lip cracked. (K, * TA.) -A2- $atarahu, and ↓ A$trhu, (S,) or the latter but not the former, (Sh, TA,) He caused him to have an inversion in the eyelid. (S.) ― -b2- And $atara AlEayona, (K,) aor.
$atira , inf. n. $atorN; (TA;) and ↓ A$trhA; and ↓ $t~rhA; (K;) He caused the eye to have an inversion of the lid above and below, (K,) and a contraction thereof: (TA:) or a cracking thereof, (K,) so that the edge became separate: (TA:) or a flaccidity of its lower part. (K.) ― -b3- $atorN also signifies The cutting off of the lower eyelid: for which a quarter of the whole price of blood must be paid. (TA.) -A3- $atira bihi He reviled him; (K;) found fault with him; blamed him; or censured him; in verse or in prose: (TA:) and bihi ↓ $t~r, inf. n. ta$otiyrN, he detracted from his reputation; found fault with him; blamed him; or censured him; (S, TA;) made him to hear what was bad, evil, abominable, or foul: (TA:) Sh says that it is $n~r, and he disallows ↓ $t~r: but IAar and AA say $t~r; and AM holds this to be correct. (TA.) [See also $*~r bh.]
2 $at~ara see 1, in three places.
4 A^a$otara see 1, in two places.
7 A_ino$atara see 1, second sentence.

A^a$otaru * A man having the affection of the eyelid described above, voce $atira: (S, A, Mgh, Msb:) or having the eyelid slit: (IAar, TA in art. $rm:) fem. $atoraA='u. (Msb.) ― -b2- A man having his lower lip cracked: and $afapN $atoraA='u a cracked lip. (TA.)

1 $atamahu * , (MA, Msb, K,) aor.
$atima (Msb, K) and
$atuma , (K,) inf. n. $atomN (S, MA, Msb, K) and ma$otamapN and ma$otumapN, (K, TA,) the last of these [written ma$otimap in the CK] with damm to the t, or this and the next before it, though said to be inf. ns., may be simple substantives, as A'Obeyd inclines to think them, (TA,) He reviled him, vilified him, upbraided him, reproached him, defamed him, or gave a bad name to him; (S, * MA, K, TA;) syn. sab~ahu: (K, TA:) or, as some say, $atomN signifies [the addressing with] foul speech, without qa*of [here meaning the casting an accusation, though commonly used and expl. as syn. with $atomN]: (TA:) and ↓ $Atmhu signifies the same as $atamahu, (MA, Msb,) being a rare instance of a verb of the measure faAEala denoting an act of a single agent when it has an unaugmented verb of the same radical letters [and the same signification], as SaAdamahu AlHimaAru meaning Sadamahu, and zaAHimahu meaning zaHamahu. (Msb.) Hence the saying, faA_ino $utima faloyaEulo A_in~iY SaAy^imN [And if he be reviled, let him say, Verily I am fasting], which may mean that he should say this with his tongue, which is the more proper meaning, or mentally: or ↓ faA_ino $uwtima, which is allowable, though the former is the more proper. (Msb.) ― -b2- $Atmhu fa$atamahu: see 3. -A2- $atuma, aor.
$atuma , (S, K,) inf. n. $ataAmapN (S, IB) and $atamN, (IB, TA,) (assumed tropical:) He (a man, S) was, or became, displeasing, or hateful, in countenance. (S, K.) -A3- [$atima, trans. by means of b, expl. by Golius as meaning He rejoiced at evils, or misfortunes, of an enemy, is, I doubt not, a mistake for $amita; though it might be supposed to be formed by transposition, like jaba*a from ja*aba.]

2 $t~m * , accord. to Reiske, said of a camel when haltered, and of a lion, as mentioned by Freytag, signifies (assumed tropical:) He was harsh, and surly, in countenance, and uttered a grumbling sound: if used, it must be $ut~ima, agreeably with the part. n., expl. below.]

3 mu$aAtamapN * is syn. with musaAb~apN, (S,) signifying The reviling, vilifying, upbraiding, reproaching, defaming, or giving a bad name to, each other: (KL:) and [in like manner] ↓ ta$aAtumN is syn. with tasaAb~N, (S,) signifying as above [but used in relation to two persons and more than two]: (KL:) you say, $aAtamaA and ↓ ta$aAtamaA meaning tasaAb~aA [They reviled, vilified, &c., each other]: (K:) and ↓ t$AtmwA They reviled, &c., one another; like tasaAb~uwA. (MA.) [$Atmhu may therefore be rendered He reviled him, &c., being reviled, &c., by him: but sometimes it is syn. with $atamahu:] see 1, in two places. ― -b2- One says also, ↓ $aAtamahu fa$atamahu, aor.
$atuma , meaning [He vied, or contended, with him in reviling, vilifying, &c.,] and he overcame him [therein, i. e.] in reviling, &c. (TA.)

5 t$t~m * is said by Freytag to signify He exposed himself to contumelies; on the authority of the Ham p. 310: but I there find only the part. n., muta$at~imN, signifying as expl. below: so that the verb, if used, means he became exasperated by reviling, vilifying, &c., and addressed, or applied, himself thereto. ― -b2- He also explains it as signifying (assumed tropical:) He contracted the face very austerely; on the authority of the Deewán of the Hudhalees.]
6 ta$aAotama see 3, in three places.
$itaAmN * : see the next paragraph.

$atiymN * : see ma$otuwmN. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Displeasing, or hateful, in countenance; (S, K;) applied to a man, and to a lion; (S;) and to an ass, as meaning thus, and foul, or ugly: (TA:) or to a lion as meaning (tropical:) grim-faced; or stern, austere, or morose, in countenance; as also ↓ mu$at~amN; and ↓ $at~aAmapN; (K, TA;) the last like jab~aAnapN [in measure, but in the CK written $atAmap]. (TA.) One says, fulaAnN $atiymu AlmuHay~aA (assumed tropical:) Such a one is displeasing, or hateful, in countenance. (S.) -A2- Also, and ↓ $itaAmN, An obstruction (sud~ap) of the fauces, combined with foulness, or ugliness, of face. (TA.)

$atiymapN * a subst., (S, Msb, K, and Ksh in lxxiv. 41, [by Bd, in explaining the same passage of the Kur, improperly said to be an inf. n.,]) from $atamahu, (Msb, K,) in the sense of $atomN [meaning The act of reviling, vilifying, or upbraiding; reproach, obloquy, or contumely]; (S, * and Ksh ubi suprà;) as also ↓ ma$otamapN, and ↓ ma$otumapN, or, as mentioned above, [see 1, first sentence,] these two are inf. ns. (TA.)
$at~aAmN * [One who reviles, &c., much]. (Ham p. 310.)
$at~aAmapN * One who reviles, &c., [very] much. (TA.) ― -b2- See also $atiymN.

[
$aAtimN * act. part. n. of 1, Reviling, &c. ― -b2- It is also said by Golius, on the authority of the Mirkát el-Loghah, to signify Rejoicing at another's evils, or misfortunes: but this I believe to be a mistake for $aAmitN: see 1, last sentence.]

AlA$tyAm * , with kesr, [which seems to indicate that it is AlA_i$otiyaAmu,] is expl. by IB as meaning ry^ys AlrkAb [app. ray^iysu Alr~uk~aAbi The headman, or master, of the riders: but whence this is derived I know not, unless it be arabicized, from the Pers. A^usotaA yaAm (if there be such an appellation), meaning “ the master of the post-horse ”]. (TA.)
ma$otamapN * and ma$otumapN: see $atiymapN.
mu$at~amN * : see $atiymN; and see also mu$ab~amN.

ma$otuwmN *
Reviled, vilified, upbraided, reproached, defamed, or called by a bad name: and so with p applied to a female, as also ↓ $atiymN; (K, TA;) this last, without p, mentioned on the authority of Lh. (TA.)

muta$at~imN *
Exasperated by reviling, &c., and addressing, or applying, himself thereto. (Ham p. 310: there expl. by the words mtHkk bAl$tm wmEtrD lh [i. e. mutaHak~ikN biAl$~atomi wamuEotariDN lahu: see 5].)

1 $ataA Al$~itaA='u * , aor. ya$otuw, inf. n. $tw [app. $utuw~N, The winter commenced: like as one says, rabaEa Alr~abiyEu, inf. n. rubuwEN]. (TA.) ― -b2- And $ataA Alyawomu, aor. as above, The day was, or became, intensely cold. (Msb.) ― -b3- And $ataA bihi, (K,) and $atawotu bihi, (S,) and $atawonaA bihi, aor. as above, inf. n. $atowN, (Msb,) He, and I, and we, remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, (S, Msb, K,) during the $itaA=' [or winter, &c.], (S,) or during a $itaA=', (Msb, K,) in it, (S, Msb, K,) namely, a place, (S, Msb,) or a country or town; (K;) as also ↓ $t~Y, (K,) inf. n. ta$otiyapN; (TA;) and ↓ t$t~Y, (S, K,) said by AZ to be from Al$~itaA='u, like taSay~afa from AlS~ayofu: (TA:) [and all are also app. trans. in this sense without a prep.:] or, as some say, $ataA AlS~ay~aAna means he re-
mained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, in the Sam~aAn [q. v., meaning a particular place and also a particular sort of place,] in the $itaA='; and ↓ ta$at~aAhaA, he pastured [his cattle] therein in the $itaA='. (TA.) ― -b4- And $ataA Alqawomu, (K,) aor. as above, (TA,) The people, or party, experienced drought, or barrenness, or dearth, in the $itaA='; as also ↓ A^a$otawoA. (K.) ― -b5- See also 4. -A2- $atiYa, like raDiYa [in measure], He was smitten by the $itaA='. (IKtt, TA.)
2 $t~Y * , inf. n. ta$otiyapN: see 1. ― -b2- One says also, h`*aA Al$~aYo'u yu$at~iyniY This thing will suffice me for my $itaA=' [or winter, &c.]. (S.)

3 EaAmalahu mu$aAtaApF * (S, K) and $itaA='F (K) [He bargained with him for work by, or for, the season called $itaA=']; and in like manner, AisotaA^ojarahu [He hired him, or took him as a hireling]: (TA:) from Al$~itaA='u [i. e. the subst.]; (S;) like muraAbaEapF from Alr~abiyEu, &c.: (TA in art. rbE:) $itaA='F being here in the accus. case as an inf. n., not as an adv. n. [of time]. (TA.)

4 A^a$otawoA * , (S, K,) and A^a$otayonaA, (Msb,) They, and we, entered the [season called] $itaA='; (S, Msb, K;) and ↓ $atawonaA signifies the same as A$tynA in this sense. (Ham p. 117.) ― -b2- See also 1, near the end.
5 ta$at~awa see the first paragraph, in two places.

$atFA *
A rough, or rugged, place. (K.) ― -b2- And The Sador [i. e. higher, or upper, part, or front, or fore part,] of a valley. (Az, K.)
$atowapN * : see $itaA='N, in three places.

$atowiY~N * and $atawiY~N, (S, Msb, K,) like xarofiY~N and xarafiY~N, (S,) [signifying Of, or relating to, the season called $itaA=',] are rel. ns. of $itaA='N (S, Msb, K) regarded as pl. of $atowapN: (Msb:) or it may be that they formed the rel. n. from $atowapN, and discarded that of $itaA='N; as is said in the M: (TA:) or those who regard $itaA='N as a sing. make its rel. n. to be ↓ $itaAy^iY~N and ↓ $itaAwiY~N. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- Al$~atawiY~u, (S, K,) thus with fet-h to the $ and t, (K,) signifies also The rain of the [season called] $itaA='; and so ↓ Al$~atiY~u; (S, K;) the latter occurring in a verse (S, TA) of En-Nemir Ibn-Towlab. (TA.) [See the latter of the tables inserted voce zamanN; and see also nawo'N.] ― -b3- Also The increase, or offspring, (nitaAj,) of sheep and goats in the [season called] rabiyE [by which is here meant the season called Alr~abiyEu AlA^aw~alu and rabiyEu AlkalaA^i, commencing in January and ending in March: see the former of the two tables mentioned above]: (Aboo-Nasr, TA voce SafariY~N [q. v.]:) [and in like manner, of camels; for] $atowiY~N and $atawiY~N and ↓ $atiY~N are applied to the young camel brought forth by her that is termed ↓ mu$otK, meaning murobiEN [i. e. that brings forth in the (season called) rabiyE]. (TA.)

$itaA='N * a word of well-known meaning [in the sense in which it is most commonly used, i. e. Winter]; (S;) one of the quarters [of the circle] of the seasons; (K;) and ↓ $aAtaApN signifies the same; (Sgh, K;) [and so does ↓ $atiy~apN; (see an ex. voce riboEiY~N;)] and so does ↓ ma$otaApN: (Msb, TA:) [also the half-year commencing at the autumnal equinox:] ISk says, Als~anapu is with the Arabs a name for twelve months: then they divided it into two halves, and commenced the sanap [or year] at the commencement of the $itaA=' because this word is masc. and the word Sayof [meaning in this case the “ half-year commencing at the vernal equinox ”] is fem.: then they divided the $itaA=' into two halves; the $twY being the former; and the rbyE, the latter; [but this is a manifest mistake, probably attributable to a copyist; for, as is well known, the former half is called the rabiyE; and the latter, the $itaA=' or ↓ $atowap;] each consisting of three months; and in like manner the Sayof and the qayoZ consist, each, of three months: (TA:) also one of the six seasons into which the year is divided, each whereof consists of two months; namely, the season [commencing in November and ending in January,] next after that called Alxariyfu: (S and K voce rabiyEN: [see this word; and see, again, the former of the two tables mentioned above:]) accord. to Mbr, (S,) $itaA='N is pl. of ↓ $atowapN; (S, Msb, K;) it is said to be so by IF on the authority of Kh, and by some on the authority of Fr or some other: or $itaA='N and ↓ $atowapN signify the same, (K,) as is said in the M; (TA;) [i. e.] some say that Al$~itaA='u is a proper name for the quarter [&c.]: (Msb:) the pl. is A^a$otiyapN, (S, Msb, K,) i. e. pl. of $itaA='N, (S, Msb,) because A^afoEilapN, as pl. of fiEaAlN, is peculiar to a masc. [noun]; (Msb;) and $utiY~N also, (K, TA,) originally A^u$otuwYN [a mistake for $utuwYN], written in the Tekmileh $itiY~N, as on the authority of Fr.: (TA:) the pl. of its syn. ↓ ma$otaApN is ma$aAtK. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also, i. e. $itaA='N, Hail, syn. baradN, (K, TA, [in the CK barodN,]) that falls from the sky. (TA.) ― -b3- And Drought, or dearth: (K, and Ham pp. 117 and 150:) this meaning being assigned to the $tA=' exclusively of the Sayof because in it the people keep to the tents, not going forth to seek after herbage. (TA.)
$atiY~N * : see $atowiY~N, in two places.
$atiy~apN * : see $itaA='N [with which it is syn.].
$itaAy^iY~N * and $itaAwiY~N: see $atowiY~N.

$aAtK *
Entering the $itaA=', which, with them, [i. e. the Arabs, and app. in this case,] means [a season of] drought, or dearth. (Ham pp. 149-50.) ― -b2- yawomN $aAtK A day intensely cold: (Msb:) or a day in which is barad [i. e. hail (accord. to the CK barod)]; and in like manner gadaApN $aAtiyapN [a morning in which is hail]. (K, TA.)
$aAtaApN * : see its syn. $itaA='N.
ma$otFY * The place [in which one resides, stays, dwells, or abides, during the season] of the $itaA=' [or winter, &c.]; as also ↓ ma$otaApN: (K:) pl. ma$aAtK. (TA.)

mu$otK * : see $atowiY~N, last sentence. ― -b2- It is said in a trad., as some relate it, waAln~aAsu muromiluwna mu$otuwna, meaning The people being in a state of straitness, or dearth, and hunger, and paucity of milk: but IAth says that the reading commonly known is musonituwna. (TA.)
ma$otaApN * : see $itaA='N, in two places: ― -b2- and ma$otFY.

$av~N *
A species of tree, (As, IDrd, ISd, Msb,) of those that grow upon the mountains, (As,) or a certain plant, (S, K,) of sweet odour, (S, Msb, K,) but bitter to the taste, (S, Msb,) with which one tans, (S, K,) growing in the mountains of El-Ghowr (ADk, Msb) and Tihámeh and Nejd; (ADk;) a kind of tree like the dwarf-apple-tree, (AHn, Mgh,) in size, (AHn,) the leaves of which are like those of the xilaAf [q. v.], (AHn, Mgh,) and are used for tanning therewith, (Mgh,) without thorns, and having a small rose-coloured [fruit of the kind called] baramap, in which are three or four black grains, resembling the $iyniyz [q. v.], which, when scattered, are eaten by the pigeons: n. un. with p. (AHn:) the word occurs in a trad. as the name of a tan: Az says that it is a mistake for $ab~, though he knew not whether the $av~ were used for tanning, or not: (TA:) [Mtr, however, says that] $ib~ is a mistake in this case, for it is a species of zaAj, and is a dye, not a tan: (Mgh:) accord. to some, (TA,) the $av~ is the wild nut (jawozu Albar~i). (K [in which this last is mentioned as a distinct signification] and TA.) [See also $ab~N.] -A2- The honey-bee. (AA, K.) -A3- A broken portion of the head of a mountain, remaining in a form like the [kind of acroterial ornament of a wall called] $urofap: pl. $ivaAvN. (K.) -A4- Also Many, or much, of anything. (TA.)

1 $aj~ahu * , aor.
$aju3a and
$aji3a , (S, Msb, K,) the former reg., (Msb,) [the latter irreg.,] inf. n. $aj~N, (S, Msb,) He broke it, [so as to cleave its skin or its flesh,] namely, another's head: (S, * K, TA:) or he clave his skin of the face or of the head; or he clave its skin, i. e. the skin of the face or of the head: (Msb:) originally he struck it, namely, the head, so as to wound it and cleave it [in the skin or flesh thereof]; and then used in relation to other members: (TA:) or $aj~ahu fiY raA^osihi and fiY wajohihi [he wounded him so as to cleave the skin or the flesh in his head and in his face]. (A.) Accord. to some, [contr. to the authority of the A,] it is from $aj~ati Als~afiynapu Alb~Hora [expl. below]. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] it is said in a prov., fulaAnN ya$uj~u biyadK wayaA^osuw biA^uxoraY [Such a one breaks a head with one hand and cures with another]; meaning (assumed tropical:) such a one corrupts, or mars, one time, and
rectifies, or repairs, another time. (TA.) And zayodN ya$uj~u mar~apF wayaA^osuw mar~apF (tropical:) Zeyd does, or says, wrong one time, and right one time. (A, TA.) ― -b3- And $aj~ati Als~afiynapu AlbaHora (tropical:) The ship clave the sea: (S, A, L, Msb:) and [in like manner] $aj~a AlbaHora (tropical:) he clave the sea; (K, TA;) said of a swimmer. (TA.) And $aj~a AlmafaAzapa (tropical:) He traversed the desert. (S, A, K.) And $aj~a AlA^aroDa biraAHilatihi (assumed tropical:) He traversed the land, with his camel that he rode, at a vehement rate. (TA.) ― -b4- And $aj~a Al$~araAba, (K, TA,) or $aj~a Alxamora biAlmaA=', aor.
$aju3a and
$aji3a , inf. n. $aj~N, [as above,] (TA,) (tropical:) He mixed the beverage, or the wine, (K, TA,) with water. (TA.) Hence, fakaAna ya$uij~u EalaY~a misokFA, occurring in a trad., means (tropical:) And it was as though it mixed with her odour of musk the breath of wind that reached my organ of smell. (TA.)

2 ta$ojiyjN * [The breaking of another's head much, so as to cleave the skin or the flesh: or the breaking of heads so as to cleave the skin or the flesh. ― -b2- And hence, perhaps,] (assumed tropical:) The acting with penetrative energy, vigour, or effectiveness; syn. taSomiymN. (O, K.)
3 bayonahumo $ijaAjN * (A, O, K) and ↓ ta$aAj~N (A, TA) Between them is a mutual breaking of heads. (A, O, K, TA. [In the CK, $ajaAjN is erroneously put for $ijaAjN.])
6 ta$aAoja3a see what next precedes.

$aj~apN *
A single act of breaking of one's head [so as to cleave its skin or its flesh]. (TA.) ― -b2- And A wound by which the head is broken (S, * A, * L, Msb) so as to cleave its skin or its flesh: (L:) and [such] a wound in the face: (A, * Msb:) pl. $ijaAjN (S, A, L, Msb) and $aj~aAtN. (Msb.) What are termed $ijaAj are of ten different kinds, (A, L,) distinguished by the following epithets: [1] HaAriSapN, which peels off the [external] skin, but does not bring blood: [2] daAmiyapN, which brings blood: [3] baADiEapN, [which cleaves the flesh slightly, and brings blood, but does not make it to flow: (but in art. dmg, voce daAmigapN, q. v., what are here mentioned as the second and third are transposed:) 4, mutalaAHimapN,] which cleaves the flesh much: [5] simoHaAqN, which leaves between it and the bone only a thin skin: these are five $jAj for which there is no retaliation nor any determinate mulct, but respecting which a judge must give his sentence: [6] muwDiHapN, which reaches to the bone, and for which the mulct is five camels: [7] haA$imapN, which breaks the bone, and for which the mulct is ten camels: [8] munaq~ilapN, from which bone is removed, from one place to another, and for which the mulct is fifteen camels: [9] maA^omuwmapN, also called A=m~apN, which leaves between it and the brain only a thin skin, and for which the mulct is one third of the whole price of blood: [10] daAmigapN, which reaches the brain, and for which the mulct is also one third of the whole price of blood. (L.) The $aj~ap of 'Abd-El-Hameed, [who was the goodliest man of his age,] the son of 'Abd-Allah the son of 'Omar the son of El-Khattáb, was the subject of a prov. on account of its beauty [and is said to have increased his goodliness]. (MF.)
$ajajN * The mark, or scar, of a wound by which the forehead has been broken. (S, * A, K, * TA.)

$ajajaY *
The EaqoEaq [or magpie]; (K, TA; omitted in the CK;) [and] so ↓ $ajawojFY. (K and TA in art. $jw.)

$ajiyjN * and ↓ ma$ojuwjN A head broken [so that its skin or its flesh is cloven]: or a man having his head [so] broken: (S, TA:) pl. [of the former] $aj~aY: you say qawomN $aj~aY. (AZ, TA.) ― -b2- Each is also applied as an epithet to a wooden peg or stake [as meaning (assumed tropical:) Having its head broken, or mangled, by blows]: and so is ↓ mu$aj~ajN, but in an intensive sense. (S, L.) ― -b3- And both the first and ↓ last signify (tropical:) A wooden peg or stake; (A, TA;) each as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates: because its head is separated, or uncompacted, in its component parts [or fibres by its being battered]. (TA.) One says, maA biAld~aAri $ajiyjN and ↓ mu$aj~ajN (tropical:) There is not in the house [even] a wooden peg or stake. (A, TA.)
$ajawojFY * : see $ajajaY.
saAbiHN $aj~aAjN * (tropical:) A swimmer that cleaves the water vehemently. (TA.)
A^a$aj~u * A man having a mark, or scar, of a wound by which his forehead has been broken. (S, A, K.)
mu$aj~ajN * : see $ajiyjN, in three places.
ma$ojuwjN * : see $ajiyjN.

1 $ajiba * , aor.
$ajaba , (S, A, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. $ajabN; (S, O, Msb, K;) and $ajaba, aor.
$ajuba , (S, A, O, K,) inf. n. $ujuwbN; (S, O, K;) He perished: (S, A, O, Msb, K:) or, accord. to AO, he perished in relation to religion or the present worldly state: the former verb said by Ks to be the better: (TA:) or the former, (S,) or each, (O,) signifies he grieved, or mourned; or was sorrowful, sad, or unhappy. (S, O.) [See also $ajabN, below.] ― -b2- And $ajaba, aor.
$ajuba , inf. n. $ajobN and $ujuwbN, It (a thing) went, went away, or passed away. (TA.) ― -b3- And $ajaba, aor.
$ajuba , inf. n. $ajobN, said of a raven (guraAb), It uttered the croak that is ominous of separation: (TA:) [or it croaked vehemently: or it (a raven of separation) bemoaned, by its croak, a misfortune: see $aAjibN.] ― -b4- See also 6. -A2- $ajabahu, (S, K,) aor.
$ajuba , inf. n. $ajobN, (S,) He (God, S) destroyed him: (S, K:) one says maA lahu $ajabahu A@ll~`hu [What aileth him? May God destroy him!]: thus the verb is trans. as well as intrans. (S.) ― -b2- And He grieved him; or caused him to mourn or lament, or to be sorrowful, sad, or unhappy: (S, K, TA:) [and so, app., ↓ A^a$ojabahu; for] one says, A^a$ojabahu AlA^amoru fa$ajiba lahu, inf. n. $ajabN, i.e. Hazina, [which seems to mean The affair grieved him and he grieved at it,] and [in like manner] A^a$ojabaka AlA^amoru fa$ajibota. (TA,) ― -b3- And He cast, or shot, at him, namely, a gazelle, (O, K, TA,) with a spear, (O,) or with an arrow, or some other thing, (TA,) and severed one of his legs, so that he could not move from his place. (O, K, TA.) ― -b4- Also He drew, or pulled, him, or it. (O, K.) One says of a horseman, and of a horse, $ajaba All~ijaAma and ya$ojubuhu, He pulled the bit and bridle, and he pulls it. (O.) And A_in~aka lata$ojubuniY Eano HaAjatiY Verily thou drawest me from the thing that I want. (As O.) ― -b5- And He occupied him, or busied him, or occupied him so as to divert his attention [from a thing]. (ISk, S, O, K.) ― -b6- And $ajabahu bi$ijaAbK He stopped it with a stopper; syn. sad~ahu bisidaAdK. (S, O, TA.)
4 A^a$ojaba see the preceding paragraph.

5 t$j~b *
i. q. taHaz~ana [app. as meaning He expressed pain, grief, or sorrow, or he lamented, or moaned]. (O, K.)

6 t$Ajb *
It (an affair, Nh, Msb, TA) became confused: (Nh, Msb, K, TA:) and (Msb, K, TA) it (a thing, IDrd, TA) became intermixed, or intermingled, one part of it entering into, or within, another; (IDrd, Msb, K, TA;) as also $jb [app. ↓ $ajaba], inf. n. $jb [app. $ajobN]. (IDrd, TA.)

$ajobN *
Want, or a want, syn. HaAjapN: and anxiety: (A, O, K:) pl. $ujuwbN. (TA.) -A2- Also, as an epithet, applied to a skin for water or milk, as though a contraction of $ajibN meaning “ perishing, ” Old, and worn out; (O, TA; *) as also ↓ $aAjibN: (O:) or the latter, so applied, signifies dry. (TA.) ― -b2- And [as a subst., or an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] A skin for water or milk of which half is cut off and the lower part made into a bucket: (O, K:) pl. $ujubN. (TA.) And A dry skin for water or milk into which pebbles are put and then shaken for the purpose of frightening camels. (L, K. *) Az says, on the authority of an Arab of the desert, that it signifies An old, worn-out, skin for water or milk, of which, sometimes, the mouth is cut off, and fresh ripe dates are put in it. (TA.) Suh says, in the R, that A water-skin was thus called [app. meaning absolutely]. (MF, TA.) And it is said in a trad. that a man of the Ansár used to cool water for the Prophet fY A$jAbp [app. a mistranscription for fiY A^a$ojaAbihi, meaning in his water-skins, or worn-out water-skins; and cited to show that A^a$ojaAbN is a pl. of $ajobN, like as A^anohaArN is pl. of nahorN]. (TA.) -A3- Also One of the poles of a tent: (A, K:) pl. $ujuwbN [agreeably with an explanation in the S]. (TA.) -A4- And [as an epithet,] Long, or tall. (K.)

$ajabN *
Grief, or sorrow; and anxiety: (K, TA:) but the word more commonly known is with n [i.e. $ajanN]. (TA.) [The pl. is A^a$ojaAbN (like A^a$ojaAnN) occurring in the O, See also $ajiba, of which it is the inf. n.: and see $ajobN, first
sentence.] ― -b2- And Distress that befalls a man by reason of disease or of fight. (K, * TA.)

$ajibN * and ↓ $aAjibN Perishing: (S, O, K:) [accord. to an explanation of their verbs by AO, in relation to religion or to the present worldly state:] or the former, (S,) or each, (O,) signifies, grieving, or mourning; or sorrowful, sad, or unhappy. (S, O.)

$ujubN *
Three pieces of wood [set up as a tripod] upon which the pastor hangs his bucket (K, TA) and his skin for water or milk. (TA.) [See also $ijaAbN (voce mi$ojabN), of which it is said in the TA to be pl.]
$ijaAbN * : see mi$ojabN. ― -b2- Also A stopper; syn. sidaAdN. (S, O, TA.)
$ajuwbN * A woman affected with anxiety, whose heart is given up thereto. (O, K.)

$aAjibN * : see $ajobN: ― -b2- and $ajibN. ― -b3- Also A raven (guraAbN) croaking vehemently, or that croaks vehemently: (S, O, K:) a raven uttering the croak that is ominous of separation: a raven of separation that bemoans, by its croak, a misfortune. (TA.) ― -b4- Also Irrational in talk, and loquacious. (K.) It is said in a trad., Aln~aAsu valaAvapN $aAjibN wagaAnimN wasaAlimN, i. e. Men are [of] three [sorts;] a speaker of what is bad, or an utterer of foul, or obscene, language, aiding in wrongdoing; and a speaker of what is good, and an enjoiner thereof, and a forbidder of what is disapproved, so that he obtains good fortune; and one who is silent: or, accord. to A'Obeyd, $aAjibN signifies perishing, or in a state of perdition, and sinning. (TA.) [Or] the Prophet said, AlmajaAlisu valaAvapN fasaAlimN wagaAnimN wa$aAjibN, meaning [Assemblies are of three sorts;] secure from sin; and acquiring recompense; and perishing, or in a state of perdition, and sinning. (O.)

mi$ojabN *
Pieces of wood, (T, Msb, K,) bound together [at the top], upon which clothes are spread, (T, Msb,) or upon which clothes are put; as also ↓ $ijaAbN; (K;) of which latter the pl. is $ujubN: (TA: [see this last word above:]) pieces of wood, or sticks, of which the heads are joined together, and the feet parted asunder, upon which clothes are put, and sometimes the water-skins are hung thereon for the purpose of cooling the water: (Nh, TA:) or a piece of wood upon which clothes are put: (S:) Suh says, in the R, that they used to call the water-skin $ajobN, and they used not to hold it otherwise than suspended, so that mi$ojabN properly signifies the piece of wood, or stick, to which the water-skin is suspended: then they amplified the application of this word so as to call thereby the thing upon which clothes are suspended: (MF, TA:) the pl. is ma$aAjibu. (A.)

1 $ajorN * is an inf. n. of $ajara, and signifies The being, or becoming, intricate, complicated, perplexed, confused, or intricately intermixed; as also ↓ Ai$otijaArN. (TA.) You say, $ajara AlA^amoru bayonahumo, (Msb, K,) aor.
$ajura , inf. n. $ajorN (Msb, TA) and $ujuwrN, (K, TA,) The affair, or case, was, or became, complicated, intricate, or confused, so as to be a subject of disagreement, or difference, between them; syn. AiDoTaraba; (Msb;) and so $ajara bayonahumo [in which AlA^amoru is understood]; syn. Aixotalafa: (S:) it was, or became, an occasion of contention, or dispute, or of disagreement, or difference, between them. (K, TA.) fiymaA $ajara bayonahumo, in the Kur iv. 68, means Respecting that which hath become complicated, or intricate, or confused, [so as to be a subject of disagreement, or difference,] between them: and hence the word $ajarN, [“ trees, ” and “ shrubs, ”] because of the intermixing, or confusion, of the branches: (Bd:) or respecting the disagreement, or difference, that has happened between them. (Zj, Mgh.) And it is said in a trad., A_iy~aAkumo wamaA $ajara bayona A^aSoHaAbiY Avoid ye the disagreement, or difference, that hath occurred among my companions. (TA.) -A2- $ajarahu, (K,) aor.
$ajura , (TA,) inf. n. $ajorN, He tied it; namely, a thing. (K.) ― -b2- $ajarahu biAlr~umoHi He thrust, or pierced, him with the spear, (S, A, K, TA,) so that it stuck fast in him. (TA.) ― -b3- $ajarahu Eanohu, (S, A, K,) aor.
$ajura , (TA,) inf. n. $ajorN, (S,) He, or it, averted, or diverted, him, from it; (S, A, K;) namely, an affair: (K:) he removed, or put away, (TS, K,) him, (K,) or it, (TS,) from it: (TS, K:) he withheld, or debarred, and repelled, him from it. (K.) You say, maA $ajaraka Eanohu What has averted thee, or diverted thee, from it? (S, A.) ― -b4- $ajara Albayota, (S, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He propped up the byt [or tent] with a pole. (S, K, TA. [In some copies of the K, biEuwdK is erroneously put for biEamuwdK.]) In like manner $ajarotuhu is said of anything as meaning I propped it up with a pole or the like. (TA.) And $ajara Al$~ajarapa, (T, K, TA,) and Aln~abaAta, (T, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He raised the hanging branches of the tree, or shrub, (T, K, TA,) and of the plant. (T, TA.) And $ajara Alv~awoba He raised the garment, it having gone down. (T, TA.) And $ujira, inf. n. as above, is said of anything as meaning It was raised, upraised, uplifted, or elevated. (TA.) ― -b5- $ajara faAhu He opened his mouth (A, K, * TA) with a stick, or a piece of wood, (A, TA,) by inserting this into the part of the mouth called its $ajor, (TA,) faA^awojarahu [and then put, or poured, medicine, or water, &c., into his mouth]. (A, TA.) And $ajara Ald~aAb~apa, (TS, K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above; or, accord. to one relation of a trad. in which it occurs, ↓ Ai$otajarahaA bilijaAmihaA; (TA;) He made the beast to open its mouth by jerking its bridle to curb it. (TS, K, TA.) ― -b6- And $ajara Al$~aYo'a He threw the thing upon the mi$ojar [q. v.], (S, K,) i. e. the mi$ojab. (S.) -A3- $ajira, aor.
$ajara , i. q. kavura jamoEuhu [app. meaning Its aggregate became large in quantity; or it became much in the aggregate]: (TS, K, TA:) but accord. to As, [it seems to signify it became collected together, and then scattered, or dispersed, by something: for he says that] ↓ $ajirN [its reg. part. n.] is applied to anything collected together, and then scattered, or dispersed, by something (TA.)

2 ta$ojiyru Aln~axoli *
i. q. ta$oxiyruhu, (K,) The laying of the racemes of the palm-trees upon the branches, lest they should break: (K in art. $xr:) this is done when the fruit is much in quantity, and the racemes are large, and one fears for the heart of the tree, and for the base, or lower part, of the raceme. (TA in the present art.)

3 $Ajr AlmaAlu *
The cattle pastured upon $ajar [i. e. trees, or shrubs], (ISk, S, A, K,) having consumed the herbs and leguminous plants. (ISk, S, A. *) ― -b2- $Ajr fulaAnN fulaAnFA, (K,) inf. n. mu$aAjarapN (S,) Such a one contended, disputed, or litigated, with such a one. (S, * K, TA.)

4 A$jrt AlA^aroDu *
The land produced $ajar [i. e. trees, or shrubs]. (K.)
6 ta$aAojara see 8, in three places.
7 A_ino$ajara see 8, in two places, and see 7 in art. sjr.

8 A$tjr *
It was, or became, knit, or connected, together, one part with another; as also Ai$otabaka: it was, or became, commingled, one part amid, or within, another; (TA;) and so ↓ t$Ajr: (Ham p. 161:) it was, or became, intricate, complicated, perplexed, confused, or intricately intermixed. (TA: see 1, first sentence.) It is said in a trad., relating to conflict and faction (fitonap), ya$otajiruwna fiyhaA A@$otijaAra A^aTobaAqi Alr~aA^osi They become knit together therein, like the knitting together of the bones of the head that interjoin, one with another, one entering into another: or the meaning is, they disagree, or differ, one with another. (TA.) You say, A$tjrwA birimaAHihimo (TA) and bihaA ↓ t$AjrwA (S, A, Msb, TA) They became knit together, or commingled, one with another, [in conflict,] with their spears: (TA:) or they thrust, or pierced, one another with their spears. (S, A, Mgh, Msb, TA.) And A$tjrwA (Zj, S, A, Msb, K) and ↓ t$AjrwA (Zj, S, A, Mgh, K) They became commingled, or confused, or embroiled, disagreeing, or differing: (Zj, TA:) they contended, or disputed, together; (S, A, Mgh, Msb;) or disagreed, or differed. (S, * A, * Mgh, Msb, * K.) ― -b2- Also He preceded, outwent, or outstripped; (K, * TA;) and so ↓ An$jr. (K.) ― -b3- And, said of sleep, It withdrew, or kept aloof, from one; (K, * TA;) as also ↓ An$jr. (K.) -A2- Also (S, K) said of a man, (S,) He put his hand beneath his $ajor, against the part beneath his chin: (S:) or he put his hand beneath his chin and leaned upon his elbow, (K, TA,) not laying his side upon the bed. (TA.) ― -b2- [And, said of a horse, He was bridled, reined, or curbed: (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees:) or perhaps the verb in this sense is in the passive form:] -A3- see 1, last sentence but two.

$ajorN *
A discordant, or complicated, or confused, affair, or case. (O, K.) -A2- Also The part, of a raHol [or camel's saddle], that is between the kar~aAni, (K, TA, [this word erroneously written in the CK with z,]) which are the qaAdimap and the A=xirap, (TA in art. $xr,) [i. e. the $aroxaAni,] the kar~
being what conjoins the ZalifataAni [in the fore part of the saddle and in like manner in the hinder part]: the part between the kar~aAni is also called the $axor. (TA in the present art. [It is there said that this part is also called the $arox as well as the $axor: but this is a mistake.]) ― -b2- And The chin: (As, O, K:) or (TA, in the K “ and, ”) the place of opening (maforaj, [as in the K voce $iynN,] in the K here erroneously written maxoraj, the meaning being mafotaH,) of the mouth: (K, * TA:) or the part between the two lower jaws: (AA, S, K:) or the hinder part of the mouth: or the side of the mouth, where the upper and lower lips unite: or what has opened of the part where the mouth closes [when medicine or the like is put into it]; expl. by maA A@nofataHa mino munoTabaqi Alfami: or the place of meeting of the lihozimataAni [q. v., a word variously explained]: (K:) or the part where the two sides of the lower jaw unite, beneath the hair that grows between the lower lip and the chin: and, in a horse, the part between the upper, main, portions of the two sides of the lower jaw: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^a$ojaArN and [of mult.] $ujuwrN and $ijaArN. (K.)

$ajarN * (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) and ↓ $ijarN and $iyarN, (K,) in which last the j is changed into Y, like as the Y is changed into j, as in ganij~N, originally ganiY~N, or, accord. to IJ, the Y in $iyarN is not changed from j because it remains Y in the dim., in which, where it so changed, it should be changed back into j, whereas the dim. of $iyarapN is said to be $uyayorapN and $iyayorapN, and because it has kesr instead of fet-h to the $, [whence it appears that IJ knew not $ijarN,] (TA,) [as coll. gen. ns., Trees; and shrubs, or bushes; which latter are also called, for distinction, diq~u Al$~ajari; and sometimes applied to plants in general; and, as a gen. n., sometimes meaning the tree, &c.;] the kind of plant that has a trunk, or stem: (S, A, K:) or the kind that has a hard trunk, or stem, (Mgh, Msb,) like the naxol &c.: (Msb:) or such as produces seed, and does not come to an end in its year: (Mgh:) or such as rises, or rises high, of itself, whether slender or large, and whether it withstand the winter or lack strength to do so: (K:) called $ajarN from $ajara, because of the intermixing, or confusion, of the branches: (Bd in iv. 68, and TA: *) n. un. with p, (Msb, K,) i. e. $ajarapN (S, Mgh, Msb, TA) and ↓ $ijarapN and $iyarapN: (TA:) the pl. [of $ajarN] is A^a$ojaArN (S, Msb) and [of $ajarapN] $ajaraAtN (Msb, TA) and [of $iyarapN] $iyaraAtN: (TA:) ↓ $ajoraA='u also signifies the same as $ajarN: (K:) or it is a pl. [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] of $ajarapN; a pl. [or quasi-pl. n.] of which there are few other instances; qaSobaA='u of qaSabapN, and TarofaA='u of TarafapN, and HalofaA='u of HalafapN; or, accord. to As, the sing. [or n. un.] of HlfA='u is HalifapN: and accord. to Sb, $ajoraA='u is sing. and pl., and so are qaSobaA='u and TarofaA='u and HalofaA='u: (S:) or $ajoraA='u signifies tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, $ajar: (A:) or a collection of $ajar. (TA.) ― -b2- $ajarapu Albaq~i &c.: see in arts. bq &c. ― -b3- In the saying in a trad., that the $ajarap and the Saxorap are of, or from, Paradise, by the former is said to be meant The grape-vine: or the tree beneath which allegiance was sworn to the Prophet; and which, it is said, was a $amurap [or gum-acacia-tree]: (TA:) and by the latter, the Sxrp [or rock] of Jerusalem. (TA in art. Sxr, q. v.) ― -b4- By Al$~ajarapu AlT~ay~ibapu, mentioned in the Kur in xiv. 29, is said to be meant The palm-tree: or a certain tree in Paradise: and by Al$~ajarapu Alxabiyvapu, in the next verse but one, the colocynth, and the ka$uwv: [see art. xbv:] or each may have a more general application. (Bd in xiv. 31.) And Al$~ajarapu AlmaloEuwnapu, mentioned in the Kur xvii. 62, means The tree called Alz~aq~uwm: and some explain it as meaning the Devil: and Aboo-Jahl: and El-Hakam Ibn-Abi-l-'As. (Bd.) ― -b5- $ajarapN also signifies (tropical:) The stock, or origin, of a man: (O, TA:) [hence,] one says, huwa mino $ajarapK Tay~ibapK (tropical:) [He is of a good stock or origin]; and mino $ajarapi Aln~ubuw~api (tropical:) [of the prophetic stock, meaning of the stock of the Prophet]. (A.) [And (assumed tropical:) A genealogical tree; a pedigree.] ― -b6- Also, (CK,) or ↓ $ajorapN, (O, and K accord. to the TA, [but probably thus in the TA only because found to be so in the O,]) (assumed tropical:) A small speck, or speckle, on the chin of a boy: (O, K:) on the authority of IAar.
