(TA.) ― -b7- And one says, maA A^aHosana $ajarapa DaroEihaA, (so in my copy of the A, and accord. to the CK,) or DrEhA ↓ $ajorapa, (O, and so accord. to the text of the K as given in the TA, [but Z has, in the A, distinguished the phrase as tropical, and hence it seems that he held the former reading to be the right,]) (tropical:) How goodly are the shape, (A,) or the size, (O, K,) and the appearance, of her udder! (A, O, K:) or the veins and skin and flesh thereof! referring to a she-camel. (O, K.)
$ajirN * : see 1, last sentence: -A2- and its fem., with p, see voce $ajiyrN.
$ijarN * ; and its n. un., with p: see $ajarN.
$ajorapN * : see $ajarN, last two sentences.
$ajoraA='u * , as a quasi-pl. n.: see $ajarN. -A2- Also fem. of A^a$ojaru as syn. with $ajiyrN.
AlHuruwfu Al$~ajoriy~apu * [The letters of which the $ajor is the place of utterance; (in the CK, Al$~ajariy~apu;)] the letters j and $ and D. (K.)
$ajaArN * : see mi$ojarN, in two places.

$ijaArN * : see mi$ojarN, in four places. ― -b2- Also The wood of a well, (S, K, KL,) by means of which the bucket is drawn out therefrom: (KL:) pl. $ujurN: (S:) this pl. occurs in a verse, accord. to J; but the right reading in that instance is sujul, as is shown by the rhyme of the poem. (Sgh, TA.) ― -b3- Also [A wooden bar of a door;] a piece of wood which is put behind a door; called in Pers. mataros, (S, K, TA,) written by Az mat~aros. (TA.) ― -b4- And A piece of wood with which a couch-frame (sariyr) is repaired, by its being affixed as a Dab~ap [q. v.], (S, K,) beneath it. (S.) ― -b5- And A piece of wood which is put in the mouth of a kid, to prevent its sucking. (TS, K.) ― -b6- And A certain brand, or mark made with a hot iron, upon camels. (S, K.)

waAdK $ajiyrN * , and ↓ A^a$ojaru, (K,) or the former, (S, A,) but not the latter, (S,) and ↓ mu$ojirN; (K;) and A^aroDN $ajiyrapN, (S, TA,) and ↓ $ajirapN, (A, K,) and ↓ $ajoraA='u, (S, Msb, K,) and ↓ ma$ojarapN; (AHn, S, * K;) A valley, and a land, abounding with $ajar or A^a$ojaAr [i. e. trees, or shrubs]. (S, A, Msb, K.) ― -b2- $ajiyrN also signifies Strange, or a stranger; applied to a man, (S, A, K,) and to a camel. (S, K.) ― -b3- And An arrow that is used in the game called Almayosir, thrown among arrows not from its kind of tree: (S, K:) or one that is borrowed, and from the winning of which [on former occasions] one augurs good. (TA.) ― -b4- Also Bad, corrupt, or disapproved. (Kr, K.) ― -b5- And A companion: (M, K:) or a friend: (A:) pl. $ujaraA='u. (M, TA.) ― -b6- And A sword. (K.)
$ajaArapN * : see mi$ojarN.

$awaAjiru * [pl. of $aAjirapN fem. of $aAjirN]: see mu$otajirN. ― -b2- Also Withholding, or debarring, and diverting, things. (TA.) You say, $ajaratoniY Eanohu $awaAjiru [Withholding, or debarring, or diverting, things withheld, or debarred, or diverted, me from it]. (S.)

A^a$ojaru * ; and its fem., $ajoraA='u: see $ajiyrN. ― -b2- Also (K) Containing more $ajar [i. e. trees, or shrubs]: (S, K:) so in the saying, h`*ihi AlA^aroDu A^a$ojaru mino h`*ihi [This land is one containing more trees than this]. (S, K. *) It has no known verb. (TA.)

ma$ojarN * (S, K, TA) [and] ↓ ma$ojarapN (Mgh, Msb) A place (S, Mgh, Msb, K) of growth (Mgh, K) of $ajar or A^a$ojaAr [i. e. trees, or shrubs]: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) or, as some say, the former signifies many $ajar. (TA.) ― -b2- The former also signifies A place of mu$aAjarap [i. e. contending, disputing, or litigating]: pl. ma$aAjiru: and, some say, it is an inf. n. (Har p. 473.) ― -b3- See also mi$ojarN, in two places.
mu$ojirN * : see $ajiyrN. ― -b2- You say also A^aroDN mu$ojirapN meaning A land giving growth to $ajar [i. e. trees, or shrubs]. (TA. [See also ma$ojarN.])

mi$ojarN *
i. q. mi$ojabN [i. e. A thing composed of pieces of wood, or sticks, the heads of which are bound together, and the feet parted asunder, upon which clothes &c. are put]: (S:) or pieces of wood, or sticks, tied together, like the mi$ojab, upon which articles of furniture, or utensils, are put: (M, Msb:) pl. ma$aAjiru. (M, TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (M,) The wood, (K,) or pieces of wood, (M,) of the [kind of camel-vehicle for women called] hawodaj; (M, K;) as also ↓ ma$ojarN and ↓ $ijaArN and ↓ $ajaArN: (L, K:) n. un. ma$ojarapN and ↓ $ajaArapN: (TA:) or a vehicle used by women, smaller than the hawodaj, having the head uncovered; (AA, K, * TA;) as also ↓ ma$ojarN and ↓ $ijaArN and ↓ $ajaArN: (K:) accord. to Lth, ↓ $ijaArN signifies the wood [or frame-work] of the hwdj, which when covered becomes a hwdj: (TA:) As
says that ma$aAjiru signifies the pieces of wood of a hwdj: AA, that it signifies vehicles smaller than hawaAdij, having the heads uncovered; also called sujurN, of which the sing. is ↓ $ijaArN. (S.)
ma$ojarapN * : see $ajiyrN: ― -b2- and see also ma$ojarN.
mu$aj~arN * Figured work (TA) having the form of $ajar [i. e. trees, or shrubs]: (K, * TA:) and silk brocade (diybaAj) figured with the forms of $ajar. (S, K.)
mu$otajaru Alr~imaAHi * [The place of the commingling of spears; or of the thrusting, or piercing, therewith]. (Ham p. 161.)
mu$otajirN * and ↓ muta$aAjirN Commingled [and confused]: you say rimaAHN mu$otaji`rapN and ↓ muta$aAjirapN and ↓ $awaAjiru Spears commingled and confused. (TA.)
muta$aAjirN * : see what next precedes, in two places.

1 $ajuEa * , aor.
$ajuEa , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. $ajaAEapN, (S, Msb,) He (a man, S) was, or became, courageous, brave, valiant, bold, daring, or stronghearted (S, Msb, K) on the occasion of war, or fight, (S, K,) making light of wars, by reason of his boldness. (Msb.) AZ says that sajaAEapN sometimes denotes a comparative quality in relation to him who is weaker than the person to whom it is ascribed. (Msb.) -A2- $ajaEahu, aor.
$ajaEa , [which in this case is contr. to the general rule, notwithstanding the guttural letter, for by rule it should be
$ajuEa ,] He overcame him, or surpassed him, in $ajaAEap [or courage, &c.]. (K.) [See 3.] -A3- $ajiEa, aor.
$ajaEa , (Msb,) inf. n. $ajaEN, (IDrd, Msb, K,) He was, or became, tall. (IDrd, Msb, K.)
2 $j~Ehu * , (S, K,) inf. n. ta$ojiyEN, (K,) He encouraged him; or strengthened his heart; (S, K;) and emboldened him: (K:) or he said to him, Thou art $ujaAE [or courageous, &c.]. (Sb, S, K.)
3 $aAjaEotuhu fa$ajaEotuhu * [I strove to overcome or surpass him, or contended with him for superiority, in $ajaAEap (or courage, &c.), and] I overcame him, or surpassed him, therein. (TA.)
4 maA A^a$ojaEahu * [How courageous, brave, valiant, bold, daring, or strong-hearted, is he, on the occasion of war, or fight!]. (TA in art bsl.)

5 t$j~E *
He affected (takal~afa) courage, bravery, valour, boldness, daringness, or strength of heart on the occasion of war, or fight; (S, K;) [he encouraged himself; made himself, or constrained himself to be, courageous:] and he feigned, or pretended to have, courage, &c., on the occasion of war, or fight, not having it in him. (TA.)

$ajaEN *
Penetrating energy; boldness. (As.) ― -b2- Quickness of the shifting of the legs, in camels, (S, K,) or, accord. to IB, in horses. (TA.)

$ajiEN * ; fem. with p: see $ujaAEN, in three places. ― -b2- $ajiEu AlqawaAy^imi Quick in the shifting of the legs, applied to a he-camel; and so $ajiEapN and ↓ $ajoEaA='u, applied to a she-camel. (S, K.) And qawaAy^imu $ajiEaAtN Quick, and light, active, or nimble, legs. (TA.) ― -b3- Mad, applied to a camel. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)
$ijaEN * : see $ujaAEN.

$ajoEapN * : see $ujaAEN: -A2- see also $ujoEapN: ― -b2- also Tall, and uncompact in frame: ― -b3- and crippled by disease; or having a protracted disease: [whence] it is said in a prov., A^aEomaY yaquwdu $ajoEapF [A blind man leading one crippled by disease, or having a protracted disease: but in Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 119, the last word is written $ajaEap, and said to be pl. of ↓ $aAjiEN, and to signify, app., suffering paralysis]. (TA.)

$ujoEapN * : see $ujaAEN. -A2- Also Cowardly, weak, (Ibn-'Abbád,) lacking strength or power or ability, lean, or emaciated, and small in body, having no heart; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) as also ↓ $ajoEapN: (Lh, K:) the former seems to have the meaning of a pass. part. n., [i. e. of ma$ojuwEN, q. v.,] like suxorapN and other words. (Ibn-'Abbád.)
$ijaEapN * : see $ujaAEN.
$ajaEaA='u * [or $ijaEaA='u or $ajoEaA='u]: see $ujaAEN.

$ajoEamN *
A bulky serpent: or a malignant and audacious serpent: regarded by Sb as a quadriliteral-radical word. (TA.) [See also $ujaAEN.]
$ajaAEN * : see what next follows.

$ujaAEN * and ↓ $ijaAEN (Lh, ISk, S, Msb, K) and ↓ $ajaAEN, (Msb, K,) which is of the dial, of Benoo- 'Okeyl, being made by them to accord with its contr., which is jabaAnN, (Msb,) and ↓ $ajiyEN (Lh, S, Msb, K) and ↓ A^a$ojaEu (S, K) and ↓ $ajiEN (K) and ↓ $ijaEN, (as in some copies of the K,) or ↓ $ijaEapN, (as in other copies of the K and in the TA,) [of all which forms the first is the most common,] Courageous, brave, valiant, bold, daring, or strong-hearted (S, Msb, K) on the occasion of war, or fight, (S, K,) making light of wars, by reason of boldness: (Msb:) fem. [of the 1st and 2nd and 3rd respectively] $ujaAEapN and $ijaAEapN (S, * Msb, * K) and $ajaAEapN (Msb, * K) and $jAE also [without p] (Msb) and [of the 4th] ↓ $ajiyEapN (Msb, K) and [of the 5th] ↓ $ajoEaA='u and [of the 6th] ↓ $ajiEapN: (K:) pl. masc. (of the 1st, S, Msb) $ijoEapN [a pl. of pauc.] (AO, S, Msb, K) and [of the first three, and perhaps of the 4th also,] $ajaEapN (S, K) and (of the 1st, S) $ijoEaAnN (Lh, S, K) and (of the 4th, S) $ujoEaAnN (Lh, ISk, S, K) [or, accord. to IDrd, $jEAn is a mistake, as is said in the TA, but the word is there written without any syll. signs,] and (of the 4th, S, Msb) ↓ $ujaEaA='u (S, Msb, K) and [of the 4th, and perhaps of others also,] $ijaAEN, (K,) and also, (but these are quasi-pl. ns., TA,) ↓ $ajoEapN (AO, S, K) and ↓ $ujoEapN (K) and ↓ $ajaEaA='u [app. a mistake for $ijaEaA='u or $ajoEaA='u]: (TA:) pl. fem. [all of $ajiyEapN, or the last of $ajoEaA='u or of $ajiEapN,] $ajaAy^iEu and $ijaAEN and $ujuEN: (Lh, K:) or $ujaAEN is [an epithet] peculiar to men: (K, * TA:) AZ says, “ I have heard the Kilábees say, rajulN $ujaAEN, but they do not apply this epithet to a woman: ” (S:) ↓ $ajiEapN and ↓ $ajiyEapN, however, are applied to a woman, and signify bold, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) longtongued, and vehemently clamorous, towards men; (Ibn-'Abbád, TA;) audacious in her speech, (Ibn- 'Abbád, K, [but these two epithets as applied to a woman and signifying “ bold ” &c. are omitted in the CK,]) and in her length of tongue, and vehement clamorousness. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) ― -b2- $ujaAEN (S, Msb, K) and ↓ $ijaAEN (K) also signify (assumed tropical:) The serpent; (K;) and so does ↓ A^a$ojaEu: (TA:) or (tropical:) the male serpent: (Mgh, K:) or a certain species of serpent, (Sh, S, Msb, K,) as also ↓ A^a$ojaEu, (S,) small, (K,) or slender, and asserted to be the boldest of the serpent-kind: (Sh:) pl. $ijoEaAnN (Lh, IDrd, K) and $ujoEaAnN, (IDrd, K,) the former of which is the more common: (IDrd:) the pl. of A^a$ojaEu is A^a$aAjiEu; or, as some say, this is pl. of A^a$ojiEapN, which is pl. [of pauc.] of $jAE, signifying the serpent. (TA.) [See also $ajoEamN, above.] ― -b3- Also (tropical:) The serpent called SafarN, that presents itself in the belly (S, K, * TA) of a man, as the Arabs assert, when he has been long hungry: (S, TA:) but As says that $ujaAEu AlbaToni signifies (assumed tropical:) vehemence of hunger. (Az, TA.)
$ijaAEN * : see $ujaAEN, in two places.
$ajiyEN * ; fem. with p: see $ujaAEN, in three places.
$aAjiEN * : see $ajoEapN.

A^a$ojaEu * ; fem. $ajoEaA='u: see $ujaAEN, in four places. You say also, labuw^apN $ajoEaA='u A bold lioness. (TA.) ― -b2- Applied to a man, accord. to some, it signifies, (S,) or it signifies also, (K,) In whom is lightness, or unsteadiness, like what is termed hawajN, (S, K,) by reason of his strength. (S.) See also $ajiEN. ― -b3- Mad; or possessed by a devil: (TA:) Lth says that, applied to a man, it signifies one who is as though there were in him madness, or diabolical possession; but Az says that this is a mistake; for, were this its meaning, the poets would not have used it in praise. (TA, in another part of the art.) ― -b4- Tall: (IDrd, Msb, K:) and so the fem. applied to a woman. (IDrd, Msb.) ― -b5- Bulky; big-bodied; or stout: or, as some say, youthful; or in a state of youthful vigour. (TA.) ― -b6- The lion. (Lth, S, K.) ― -b7- It is said in the K that AlA^a$ojaEu also signifies Ald~ahoru [i. e. Time; or fortune; &c.]; and J says that this is what the poet means by the expression, A^a$ojaEu A^ax~aA*N: but this cannot be the correct meaning, for the poet, namely El-Aashà, says,
biA^a$ojaEa A^ax~aA*K EalaY Ald~ahori Hukomuhu
by AlA$jE meaning himself, or some other thing. (TA.) -A2- Also, (S, K,) and A_i$ojaEN, (K,) or the latter accord. to some, but this was not known to Abu-l-Ghowth, (S,) sing. of A^a$aAjiEu, [in some copies of the S written A^a$aAjiyEu, but the former, which, as is mentioned in the TA, is found in the
handwriting of J, is that which is commonly known,] which signifies [The knuckles nearest to the wrist; this being what is meant by] the bases (A^uSuwl) of the fingers, which are connected with the tendons of the outer side of the hand: (S, K:) in the T, we find the heads (ruw^uws) of the fingers, instead of ASwl: (TA:) or A$jE in the hand and foot [but see what follows] signifies the tendons extended above the sulaAmaY [here meaning the metacarpal and metatarsal bones] from the wrist to the bases (A^uSuwl) of the fingers or toes, which are called A^aTonaAbu AlA^aSaAbiEi, above the outer side of the hand: or the bone which connects the finger with the wrist; [i. e. the metacarpal bone;] every finger having to it a bone thus called: he who says that the A^a$aAjiE [so here instead of A$jE as above] are the tendons calls those bones the A^usonaAE. (TA.) Aboo-Bekr is described as EaAriY AlA^a$aAjiEi Eano mafaASili AlA^aSaAbiEi, meaning Having little flesh upon what are thus termed: or having their tendons apparent. (TA.) [See also raAjibapN and burojumapN.] -A3- A^a$ojaEu mino diykK [More courageous than a cock] is one of the proverbs of the Arabs. (Mgh.)

mu$ojaEN * , like mujomalN, (K, TA,) i. e. having the form of a pass. part. n., (TA,) [in the CK ma$ojaE, like maHomal,] In the utmost state of madness, or diabolical possession: (K:) so says Ibn-Abbád; and hence, accord. to him, $ujaAEN [but in what sense he does not say]. (TA.)

ma$ojuwEN *
Overcome, or surpassed, in $ajaAEap [or courage, &c.]. (K, TA.)

1 $ajina * , (S, L, K,) aor.
$ajana ; (K;) and $ajuna, aor.
$ajuna ; inf. n. [of the former] $ajanN [in some copies of the K $ajonN] and [of the latter, or of both,] $ajuwnN; (L, K;) He grieved, mourned, or lamented; or was sorrowful, sad, or unhappy; (S, L, K;) and was anxious: and ↓ t$j~n signifies the same: (L:) or this last signifies, (K,) or, as Lth says, it seems to signify, (L,) he remembered; syn. ta*ak~ara. (L, K.) And $jnt AlHamaAmapu, [app. both $ajinat and $ajunat,] inf. n. $ujuwnN, The pigeon cooed in a wailing and plaintive manner. (L.) [See also $ajanN below.] -A2- $ajanahu, (S, L, K,) [aor.
$ajuna , accord. to the usual rule of the K,] inf. n. $ajonN and $ujuwnN, (L, K,) signifies the same as ↓ A$jnhu, (S, L, K,) i. e. He, (another person, S,) or it, (an affair, or an event, or a case, L, K,) caused him to grieve or mourn or lament, or to be sorrowful or sad or unhappy. (S, L, K.) -A3- $ajanatoniY AlHaAjapu, (S, L,) and $ajanatohu, (L, K,) aor.
$ajuna , inf. n. $ajonN, (S, L,) Want, or the want, detained, or withheld, (S, L, K,) me, (S, L,) or him. (L, K.) And maA $ajanaka Ean~aA What detained, or withheld, thee from us? (L.)
4 A$jnhu * : see the preceding paragraph. -A2- A$jn Alkaromu The grape-vine had a branchlet of a bunch of which all the grapes came to maturity. (L, K. [See $ijonapN.])
5 ta$aj~ana see 1, first sentence. -A2- t$j~n Al$~ajaru The trees were, or became, tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense. (L, K.)

$ajonN * (S, L, K [in the CK $ajanN, but expressly said in the S to be biAlt~asokiyni]) A road of a valley; (S, L;) or a road in a valley: or in the upper, or uppermost, part thereof: as also ↓ $aAjinapN: (K:) pl. of the former $ujuwnN: (S, L, K:) and of ↓ $awaAjinu: (K:) or ↓ $aAjinapN signifies a valley in which are many trees; (S, L;) or a place in which are $ujuwn, which means tangled trees; (Ham pp. 761-2;) and $awaAjinu is its pl.: (S, L, and Ham p. 762:) or ↓ $aAjinapN signifies a sort of valley producing good herbage: or, as some say, $awaAjinu signifies the upper, or uppermost, parts of a valley; and its sing. is ↓ $ajanN [thus written in the L in this instance], as ISd mentions on the authority of A'Obeyd, but adding that, as such, it is irregular, and that it is more properly to be regarded as pl. of ↓ $aAjinapN. (L.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, AlHadiyvu *uw $ujuwnK, (S, Meyd, L, K,) $ujuwn being pl. of $ajonN, with the j quiescent; (Meyd;) a prov., (Meyd, L,) meaning (assumed tropical:) The story is involved, or intricate; (S, Meyd, L;) or has several ways [in which it may be understood]; (Meyd;) or has several modes, or manners; and objects of aim: (L, K:) applied to a story by which one calls to mind another: (A'Obeyd, Meyd, L:) the first who said it was Dabbeh Ibn-Udd Ibn-Tábikhah: he had two sons, named Saad and So'eyd: and some camels belonging to him ran away by night, so he sent his two sons to seek them; and they separated; and Saad found them and restored them; but So'eyd went on seeking them; and El-Hárith Ibn-Kaab met him; and there were upon the young man two [garments such as are called] burds (burodaAni), which El-Hárith asked him to give to him, but he refused to comply with his desire; whereupon he slew him, and took his two burds: and Dabbeh, when he saw a dark object in the night, used to say, A^asaEodN A^amo suEayodN [“ Is it Saad or So'eyd? ” (see saEodN)]; and this saying of his became current as a prov.: some time after this, having gone on pilgrimage, he met El- Hárith Ibn-Kaab at 'Okádh, and saw upon him the two burds of his son So'eyd, and asked him respecting them; and he answered that he had met a young man wearing them, and slain him, and taken them: Dabbeh said, “ With this thy sword? ” and he answered, “ Yes: ” and he said, “ Give it me that I may look at it, for I think it to be sharp: ” and El-Hárith gave it him: and he took it, and shook it, and said, A_in~a AlHadiyva *uw $ujuwnK; and slew him with it: whereupon it was said to him, “ O Dabbeh, in the sacred month? ” and he said, sabaqa Als~ayofu AlEa*ola [“ The sword preceded the censure ”): these three provs. he originated. (Meyd.)
$ujonN * and $ijonN: see the next paragraph.

$ajanN *
Grief, mourning, lamentation, sorrow, sadness, or unhappiness; (S, L, K;) and anxiety: (L, K:) pl. A^a$ojaAnN (S, L, K) and $ujuwnN; (L, K; [in the latter of which these pls. are mentioned after all the explanations of the sing.;]) the former a pl. of pauc., and the latter of mult. (Ham p. 404.) [See a verse cited voce EaraDN, in which it means A cause of anxiety.] ― -b2- And The soul's love, or its inclination, or its blamable inclination: (L:) [or] love that is followed by anxiety and grief. (Kull p. 165.) ― -b3- And A want, (S, L, Msb, K,) as also ↓ $ajiynN, (L,) wherever it be: (S, L, K:) pl. $ujuwnN (S, L, Msb, K) and A^a$ojaAnN; (L, Msb, K;) the latter being pl. of $ajiynN also. (L.) A rájiz says,
liY $ajanaAni $ajanN binajodi
wa$ajanN liY bibilaAdi Als~inodi
[I have two wants; a want in Nejd, and I have a want in the country of Es-Sind]. (S.) -A2- Also An intricately-intermingling branch of a tree; (L, K;) and a $uEobap [i. e. branch, or branchlet, or the like,] of anything; (K;) like ↓ $ijonapN and ↓ $ujonapN and ↓ $ajonapN (L, K) in the former sense: (L: [accord. to the K, app., in the latter sense:]) or, accord. to IAar, one says ↓ $ujonapN and ↓ $ujonN meaning a branch of a tree, [or the latter app. means branches, for it seems to be a coll. gen. n.,] and ↓ $ijonapN and ↓ $ijonN, and [the pl. of ↓ $ujonapN is] $ujonaAtN and $ujunaAtN: (L:) or, accord. to J, (L,) ↓ $ijonapN and ↓ $ujonapN signify roots of trees intricately intermingling: (S, L:) [but] the primary signification of ↓ $ijonapN and ↓ $ujonapN is a branchlet (a $uEobap of a guSon) of a tree: (L:) or ↓ $ijonapN signifies tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, trees. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also $ijonapN. ― -b3- And see $ajonN. ― -b4- Also, (K,) or $jnp, (L, [thus written without any syll. signs, perhaps fem. of $ajanN, i. e. $ajanapN, but it seems to be indicated by the context in the L that it is ↓ $ujonapN,]) A she-camel compact in make, of which the several parts are interknit, one with another, (L, K, *) like the parts of a tree. (L.)
$ajonapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
$ujonapN * : see $ajanN, in six places: and $ijonapN. -A2- Also, as some say, Leanness; or slenderness, and leanness; or leanness, and lankness in the belly. (L.)

$ijonapN * : see $ajanN, in five places. ― -b2- Also, i. e. with kesr, (K,) or ↓ $ajanN and ↓ $ajanapN, (L,) A branchlet of a bunch of a grape-vine of which all the grapes come to maturity. (L, K.) ― -b3- $ijonapN signifies also (assumed tropical:) Relationship closely, or intimately, connected. (L.) One says, bayoniY wabayonahu $ijonapu raHimK, and raHimK ↓ $ujonapu, (assumed tropical:) Between me and him is a relationship closely, or intimately, connected. (S.) And it is said in a trad., Alr~aHimu $ijonapN mina A@ll~`hi i. e. (tropical:) Alr~aHimu is derived from Alr~aHom`n: (S, L: [see raHimN:]) or, accord. to AO, (L,) the meaning is, [Alr~aHim is] relationship, from God, closely, or intimately, connected, like the roots of trees. (S, L.) ― -b4- Also A crack, or cleft, in a mountain. (Lh, L, K.)
$ajanapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

$ajuwnu * ↓ $aAjinatiY is a saying of the Arabs like their saying EaAbilatiY Eabuwlu [i. e., app., My withholder is death, or shall be death alone; for $ajanatohu $ajuwnu may be rendered Death withheld him, like as Eabalatohu Eabuwlu is rendered “ death separated him ”]. (L.)
$ajiynN * : see $ajanN.

$aAjinN *
Grieving, mourning, or lamenting; or sorrowful, sad, or unhappy; (S, L;) and anxious. (L.) -A2- See also an ex. of its fem., with p, voce $ajuwnu.
$aAjinapN * [as a subst.]; pl. $awaAjinu: see $ajonN, in five places.

1 $ajiYa * , aor.
$ajawa , inf. n. $ajFA, He was choked; or his throat, or fauces, became obstructed; (S, K;) bihi by it; i. e. a bone or the like. (K.) One says, Ealayoka biAlkaZomi walawo $ajiyta biAlEaZomi [Keep thou to self-restraint though thou be choked by the bone]. (TA.) ― -b2- And, [hence, by a metaphor, (see Har p. 33,)] aor. and inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) He grieved, mourned, or lamented; or was sorrowful, sad, or unhappy: (S, Msb:) and he was, or became, anxious, or disquieted in mind. (S.) ― -b3- Also, aor. and inf. n. as above, said of a creditor (gariym), He went away, Eanohu [from him]. (K. [See 4.]) -A2- $ajaA bayonahumo It was, or became, an occasion of contention, or dispute, or of disagreement, or difference, between them. (K.) -A3- $ajaAhu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
$ajuwa , inf. n. $ajowN, (S, Msb,) [app. originally syn. with A^a$ojaAhu in the first of the senses assigned to the latter in the next paragraph: ― -b2- and hence,] (assumed tropical:) It (anxiety, Msb) grieved him; or caused him to mourn or lament, or to be sorrowful or sad or unhappy; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ A$jAhu. (K.) And, said of wealth (AlginaY), inf. n. $ajowN, It excited his griefs, mournings, &c., and his desire. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, and ↓ A$jAhu, (assumed tropical:) It caused him to be mirthful, (Ks, K, TA,) and excited him. (Ks, TA.) Thus each of these verbs has two contr. significations. (K.) But MF observes that Tar~abahu, the explanation here given in the K, is said by the author of the K [in art. Trb] to denote a lightness arising from joy or grief. (TA.) [Generally, however, it means as rendered above.]

4 A$jAhu * , inf. n. A_i$ojaA='N, It choked him; or caused his throat, or fauces, to be obstructed; syn. A^agaS~ahu; (S, TA;) said of a bone lying across in the throat, or fauces. (TA.) [This is clearly shown to be the meaning in the S, as well as in the TA, intended by A^agaS~ahu; with which it is also syn. in another sense; for] ― -b2- It signifies [also] (assumed tropical:) It, or he, caused him to fall into grief, mourning, lamentation, sorrow, sadness, or unhappiness. (K.) See also 1, in two places. ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) He subdued, overpowered, or overcame, him, (K, TA,) so that he grieved, or was sorrowful. (TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) He angered him. (Ks, TA.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) He made him to go away. (Az, TA.) And A^a$ojayotuhu Ean~iY (assumed tropical:) I gave him (i. e. a creditor or petitioner) what contented him, so that he went away. (TA.)

6 ta$aAjato Ealayohi * , (As, T, K, * TA,) said of a woman of the desert with reference to a young man who had been dallying, and holding amorous converse, with her, (As, T, TA,) (assumed tropical:) She resisted him, and expressed grief, or unhappiness, to him, or on account of him, [i. e. on account of his advances,] saying, Alas, my grief, or my unhappiness! (As, T, K, * TA.) And said of a woman with reference to her husband, meaning (assumed tropical:) She expressed grief, &c., as above. (A, TA.)

$ajFA *
A bone, or some other thing (S, K) of the like sort, (K,) sticking fast, (S,) or lying across, or forming an obstruction, (K,) in the throat, or fauces, (S, K,) of a human being, and of a beast; (TA;) a thing in the throat, or fauces, that [chokes one, or] prevents from swallowing: (Har p. 69:) an inf. n. used as a subst. [properly thus termed]. (Har p. 33.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

$ajowN * (assumed tropical:) Anxiety, or disquietude of mind; and grief, mourning, lamentation, sorrow, sadness, or unhappiness; (S;) [and] so ↓ $ajFA: thus termed because a man is choked thereby. (Har p. 33.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A want; an object of want. (Az, K, TA.) One says, bakaY fulaAnN $ajowahu [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) Such a one wept for his object of want]: and daEati AlHamaAmapu $ajowahaA [app. (assumed tropical:) The pigeon called for its object of want]. (TA.)

$ajK * (assumed tropical:) Grieving, mourning, or lamenting; or sorrowing, sad, or unhappy; applied to a man; (S, Msb;) and $ajiyapN, of the measure faEilapN, applied to a woman: one says, wayolN lil$~ajiY mina AlxaliY~i [mentioned and expl. voce xaAlK, in art. xlw, where each of these epithets is written with teshdeed to the Y; and likewise in another saying there mentioned]: (S:) or, in this saying, (TA,) it signifies occupied [by anxiety or grief]; (K, TA; [in the CK, Al$~ajA is erroneously put for Al$~ajiY;]) and xaliY~ means “ free [therefrom]: ” so says AZ: and in this instance Al$~ajiY may mean occupied by a bone choking, or obstructing, his throat, or fauces, or by anxiety, and not having found a way of escape therefrom; or by his opponent, or adversary, whom he has been unable to withstand: (TA:) and sometimes one says ↓ $ajiY~N, like as one says HazinN and HaziynN; though this is rare; (Msb;) it is mentioned in the 'Eyn; but $ajK is more known; and is said by Az to be the chaste form: (TA:) Mbr says, the Y of AlxlY is with teshdeed, and the Y of Al$~ajiY is without teshdeed, (S,) and sometimes this Y is with teshdeed in poetry; (S, K;) but if you make it to be from $ajaAhu, it is ↓ $ajiY~N only, syn. with ma$ojuw~N. [i. e. grieved, &c.]; (S;) and so it is said to be by Az and Z: and Az adds, the second way of accounting for it is, that they often lengthen faEilN with a Y, saying, fulaAnN qaminN lika*aA and qamiynN, and samijN and samiyjN, and karK and kariY~N: and the third way is, that they assimilated one word in measure to another, as in AlgadaAyaA waAlEa$aAyaA, the [proper] pl. of gadaApN being only gadawaAtN. (TA.)
$ajiY~N * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
mafaAzapN $ajowaA='u * [A desert, or waterless desert,] difficult to travel. (S, K. *)
$ajawiY~N * , with fet-h to the j; rel. n. of $ajK. (S.)

$ajawojFY * , (S, K,) of the measure faEawoEalN [and therefore with tenween], (Mz 40th nwE, and MF and TA,) like xajawojFY &c., (S, * and Mz ibid.,) and ↓ $ajawojaA='N, (K,) applied to a man, (S,) Long in the legs: (S, K:) or very tall: or very tall, with bigness (Dixam, in the CK Daxom,) of the bones: or long in the back, short in the leg; (K;) thus in the M; but Az says the reverse, i. e. long in the legs, short in the back. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) or the former, (TA,) A bulky horse. (K.) ― -b3- And The EaqoEaq [or magpie]; (K;) [and] so $ajajaY; (K and TA in art. $j;) fem. with p [i. e. $ajawojaApN]. (K.) ― -b4- And A wind continually blowing; as also $ajawojaApN. (K.) All this is in the M. (TA.)
$ajawojaA='N * : see the next preceding paragraph.

A^amorN $aAjK *
An affair, or event, grieving; or causing to mourn or lament, or to be sorrowful or sad or unhappy. (TA.)

1 $aH~a * , (Msb,) sec. pers. $aHaHota, aor. ya$uH~u and ya$iH~u, (S, O, Msb, K,) the latter of these aors. agreeable with analogy as the verb is intrans., and the former deviating therefrom; (MF;) and sec. pers. $aHiHota, aor. ya$aH~u; (S, O, Msb, K;) [the first of which, having for its aor. ya$uH~u, is the most common;] inf. n. $uH~N (S, A, O, Msb, K) and $iH~N and $aH~N, (ISk, O, K,) of which three inf. ns. the first is the most approved; (TA;) He was, or became, niggardly, tenacious, stingy, penurious, or avaricious; syn. yaxila: (Msb:) or bxl relates to single things, or particulars; and $H~, to things in general: or bxl relates to wealth, or property; and $H~, to wealth, or property, and to kindness, or beneficence: or $H~, signifies he was, or became, niggardly, &c., as above, in the utmost degree: (TA:) or he was, or became, niggardly, &c., as above, (S, A, O, K,) and covetous, or vehemently or greedily or excessively or culpably desirous, (K,) or with covetousness, or vehement or greedy or excessive or culpable desire. (S, A, O.) You say, $aH~a bihi and $aH~a Ealayohi; (T, M, K;) by the former meaning He was, or became, niggardly, &c., of it, i. e., of his property, or the like; and by the latter, he was, or became, niggardly, &c., to him, i. e., to an asker, or a beggar, or a seeker, or the like: (MF:) or [in some cases, as will be seen from phrases mentioned below, (see $aHiyHN,)] meaning by the latter the same as by the former. (L.) [Thus] one says, huwa ya$uH~u bimaAlihi [He is niggardly, &c., of his property; and sometimes, in the same sense, ya$uH~u EalaY maAlihi]. (A.) And $aH~a baEoDuhumo
EalaY baEoDK [Some of them were niggardly, &c., to some; meaning they were niggardly, &c., one to another]. (Msb, K.)

3 huwa yu$aAH~uniY bika*aA * [He is niggardly, tenacious, &c., as above, with me, of such a thing]. (A.) [The inf. n.] mu$aAH~apN [in the CK erroneously written ma$AH~ap] is syn. with Din~apN: (K, TA:) hence the saying, laA mu$aAH~apa fiY AlAiSoTilaAHi [There shall be no acting in a niggardly manner, of one with another, in the making of peace, one with another]. (TA.) And one says, fulaAnN yu$aAH~u EalaY fulaAnK Such a one is tenacious of such a one; syn. yaDan~u bihi. (S, L.)

6 t$AH~ Alqawomu *
The people, or party, were niggardly, tenacious, &c., as above, [see 1,] one to another, (Msb, K, TA,) fiY AlA^amori [in the affair], (K, TA,) and Ealayohi [for it], (TA,) and vied in hastening to it, (TA,) fearing lest it should become unattainable. (K, TA.) And ta$aAH~aA EalaY AlA^amori laA yuriydaAni A^ano yafuwtahumaA (S, O, K, TA) They two (i. e. two men, S, O) contended together for the thing, or affair, each of them being unwilling that it should become beyond his reach, or attainment. (TA.) And ta$aAHaHaA AlmaA='a [or ta$aAH~aAhu] i. q. tajaA$aEaAhu [i. e. They straitened each other in pressing to the water, and vied, each with the other, in endeavouring to satisfy their thirst]. (TA in art. j$E.)

R. Q. 1
$aHo$aHapN [inf. n. of $aHo$aHa] The being cautious, wary, or vigilant; or fearing. (O, K.) ― -b2- The crying of the [bird called] Surad. (K.) You say, $aHo$aHa AlS~uradu The Srd uttered its cry. (O, TA.) ― -b3- The camel's reiterating of his voice, [or his being not clear, or his being sparing,] in his braying. (K.) You say of the camel, $aHo$aHa fiY hadiyrihi [He reiterated his voice, or ] he was not clear, (S,) or he was sparing, (L,) in his braying. (S, L.) ― -b4- And The flying swiftly. (S, K.)
nafosN $aH~apN * : see $aHiyHN.

A^awoSaY fiY SiH~atihi wa$iH~atihi * means [He made his will during his state of soundness, or health, and] in his state of which he is tenacious [or the state which he is reluctant to quit] (fiY HaAlihi Al~atiY ya$uH~u EalayohaA). (O, K.)
$aHaAHN * : see the next paragraph in four places.

$aHiyHN * (S, A, Msb, K) and ↓ $aHaAHN (S, A, K) and ↓ $aHo$aHN and ↓ $aHo$aAHN and ↓ $aHo$aHaAnN, (K,) applied to a man, Niggardly, tenacious, stingy, penurious, or avaricious: (Msb:) or niggardly, &c., as above, in the utmost degree: (TA:) or niggardly, &c., as above, (S, A, K,) and covetous, or vehemently or greedily or excessively or culpably desirous, (K,) or with covetousness, or vehement or greedy or excessive or culpable desire: (S, A:) and ↓ nafosN $aH~apN signifies the same as $aHiyHapN [a soul that is niggardly, &c.]: (IAar, TA:) the pl. (of $aHiyHN, S, Msb) is A^a$iH~apN [a pl. of pauc.] (S, A, Msb, K) and $iHaAHN (S, A, K) and A^a$iH~aA='u. (Msb, K.) You say, [huwa $aHiyHN bi$aYo'K and] $aHiyHN EalaY $aYo'K He is niggardly, &c., of a thing. (L in art. $d.) A^a$iH~apF EalaY Alxayori, in the Kur [xxxiii. 19], means [They being niggardly, or vehemently desirous, of the good things, i. e.] of the wealth and spoils: (TA:) and A^a$iH~apN Ealayokumo, in the same verse, means [They being niggardly] of aid [to you]. (Jel.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A_ibilN $aHaAy^iHu, [in which the latter word is pl. of $aHiyHapN,] (O, K,) or $iHaAHN, (A,) (tropical:) Camels that yield little milk. (A, O, K, TA.) And ↓ zanodN $aHaAHN (tropical:) A piece of stick, or wood, for producing fire, that does not yield fire. (S, A, K.) And maA='N ↓ $aHaAHN (assumed tropical:) Water little in quantity; not copious. (K.) And ↓ A^aroDN $aHaAHN (assumed tropical:) Land that will not flow with water unless in consequence of much rain; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ $aHo$aHN: (O, K:) and also, (ISk, L, TA,) or ↓ the latter word, (so accord. to the K,) (assumed tropical:) Land that flows in consequence of the least rain; (ISk, K, TA;) as though it were niggardly of itself to the water: (TA;) like Ha$aAdN [in this, or in the former, sense]: (ISk, L:) thus having two contr. meanings. (K.) And accord. to AHn, $iHaAHN signifies (assumed tropical:) [Small water-courses such as are termed] $iEaAb any one of which is made to flow if a skinful of water is poured into it. (TA.)

$aHo$aHN * : see $aHiyHN, in three places. ― -b2- Also Evil in disposition; (O, K;) and so ↓ $aHo$aAHN. (TA.) ― -b3- Very jealous; (Fr, S, O, K;) as also ↓ $aHo$aAHN and ↓ $aHo$aHaAnN. (Fr, O, K.) ― -b4- Courageous; (S, K;) and so ↓ $aHo$aAHN. (TA.) ― -b5- Also, (S, O, K, TA,) applied alike to a male and to a female, (TA,) and ↓ $aHo$aAHN, (K, TA,) or ↓ $aHo$aHaAnN, (S, * O,) One who keeps, attends, or applies himself, constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, to a thing: (S, O, K, TA:) who strives, labours, or exerts himself, therein: (TA:) or, as some say, (S, O,) penetrating, sharp, vigorous, or effective, therein: (S, O, TA:) the first, (S, O, K, TA,) and ↓ second, (TA,) applied to an orator, or a preacher, (S, O, K, TA,) in this last sense, (S, O, TA,) or as meaning eloquent (K, TA) and powerful: (TA:) and both, as epithets of general application, penetrating, sharp, vigorous, or effective, in speech, or in going or journeying: the first is also applied to an orator, or a preacher, as meaning skilful: (TA:) and ↓ the last of these three epithets is applied by Dhu-r-Rummeh to a driver of camels, who urges them by singing to them. (S, O, TA.) ― -b6- Also the first, applied to a raven, or crow, (guraAb,) That croaks much. (O, K.) ― -b7- And Light, or agile; applied to an ass; as also ↓ $uHo$uHN, (O, K,) as some say. (O.) ― -b8- And Swift in flight; applied to a qaTaAp. (S, O, K.) ― -b9- Also, and ↓ $aHo$aHaAnN, Tall, or long, (Fr, O, K, TA,) and strong. (TA.) ― -b10- And the former, applied to a [desert such as is termed] falaAp, Wide; (O, K, TA;) in which the places of alighting are far apart, and in which is no herbage. (TA.)
$uHo$uHN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
$aHo$aAHN * : see $aHiyHN: ― -b2- and see also $aHo$aHN, in five places. ― -b3- Also, applied to a woman, Resembling a man in her strength, (O, K,) and her exertion, or energy. (O.)
$aHo$aHaAnN * : see $aHiyHN: ― -b2- and see also $aHo$aHN, in four places.

mu$aHo$aHN *
Niggardly, tenacious, stingy, penurious, or avaricious; [like $aHiyHN;] (TA;) possessing little, or no, good. (O, K, TA.)

1 $aHaba * , aor.
$aHuba (S, A, O, K, &c.) and
$aHaba , (A, O, K, &c.,) but the former more commonly obtains, (TA,) inf. n. $uHuwbN; (S, O, K;) and $aHuba, (Fr, S, A, O, K, &c.,) inf. n. $uHuwbapN, (Fr, S, O, K,) but this form of the verb is disapproved by AZ and 'Iyád; (TA; [in which, however, nine authorities for it are mentioned;]) said of one's body; (Fr, S, O;) or of one's colour, or complexion, (A, K,) and so $uHiba, (A, O, K,) inf. n. $uHuwbN; (A;) [It was, or became, altered [for the worse, wan, or haggard], (Fr, S, A, O, K, &c.,) in consequence of emaciation, (K,) or hunger, (A, K,) or sleeplessness, and the like, (A,) or travel, (K,) or work, or disease, or impatience, or distress or fatigue: or, accord. to the author of the “ Wá'ee, ” $uHuwbN signifies emaciation itself: (TA:) in this sense, it is of the dial. of Benoo-Kiláb. (A, TA.) -A2- $aHaba AlA^aroDa, (IDrd, O, K,) aor.
$aHaba , inf. n. $aHobN, (IDrd, O,) He pared the ground, or scraped off its superficial part, with a shovel, (IDrd, O, K,) or some other thing: of the dial. of El-Yemen. (IDrd, O.)
$aHibN * : see what follows.

$aAHibN * A man having his colour, or complexion, altered [for the worse, wan, or haggard], (TA,) or so $aAHibu All~awoni, (A,) in consequence of disease, or travel, or the like: (TA: [see 1:]) and emaciated, or lean; (TA, KL;) as also ↓ $aHibN. (KL.) It is said in a trad., laA taloqaY Almuw^omina A_il~aA $aAHibFA [Thou wilt not find the believer otherwise than wan, or haggard; or emaciated, or lean]; because $uHuwb is one of the effects of fear, and of paucity of food, and of little enjoying of plentifulness and pleasantness or easiness, and softness or delicacy, of life. (TA.) ― -b2- It is also applied as an epithet to a sword, meaning Altered in its colour by blood that has dried upon it: used in this sense by the poet Taäbbata-sharrà. (TA.)

1 $aHaja * , aor.
$aHaja and
$aHija , inf. n. $aHiyjN (S, O, K) and $uHaAjN (As, S, O, K) and $aHajaAnN (O, K) and ta$oHaAjN; (O, L;) and ↓ t$H~j; and ↓ Ast$Hj; (L, TA;) He uttered his voice or cry; [brayed;
croaked;] said of a mule, (S, O, K, &c.,) and of an ass, (ISd, O,) and of a raven, or crow; (S, O, K, &c.;) and sometimes, (tropical:) of a man: (L:) or $aHiyjN is used in relation to a mule; and $aHajaAnN, in relation to a raven, or crow: (T, TA:) or the former of these two signifies the reiterating of the voice or cry of the raven, or crow; and when it stretches forth its head [and croaks], you say naEaba: and accord. to the L, the first and second inf. ns., used in relation to an ass, signify the uttering certain of his voices or cries: Th is thought by ISd to have mentioned also $aHija; but the latter doubts its correctness: and $uHaAjN is also expl. as signifying the raising of the voice; but as used more especially in relation to the mule and the ass. (TA.) $aHaja is also said of a raven, or crow, meaning He, being advanced in age, had a rough, or harsh, voice or cry: (O, K:) [he croaked roughly, or harshly, by reason of age:] it is said in the M that $aHiyjN and $uHaAjN signify the crying of a raven, or crow, when advanced in age. (TA.)
5 ta$aH~aja see the preceding paragraph.
10 Ast$Hj * [He desired a raven, or crow, to croak]. One says of ravens, or crows, Ausotu$oHijona fa$aHajona [They were desired to croak, and they croaked]. (O, K.) ― -b2- See also 1.

$aH~aAjN * , applied to a mule, an ass, and a raven or crow, that brays, or croaks, or raises its voice, much: and by Er-Rá'ee it is applied to (tropical:) a muw^a*~in. (TA.) ― -b2- banaAtu $aH~aAjK, (S, A, O, K,) and ↓ $aAHijK, (L,) Mules: (S, A, O, K:) and asses. (A, TA.) ― -b3- And $aH~aAjN and ↓ mi$oHajN The wild ass: (S, O, K:) in the L said to be the wild pigeon: [but HmAm is evidently there a mistranscription for HimaAr:] each an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates. (TA.)

banaAtu $aAHijK * : see $aH~aAjN. ― -b2- $awaAHiju [pl. of $aAHijapN] Ravens, or crows: which are also called ↓ musota$oHajaAtN and ↓ musota$oHijaAtN, meaning desired to croak and croaking. (O, K.) Dhu-r-Rummeh uses the phrase biAlfiraAqi ↓ musota$oHijaAtN [Ravens croaking by reason of separation]. (O, TA.)
mi$oHajN * : see $aH~aAjN.
musota$oHajaAtN * : see the next but one of the preceding paragraphs, in three places.

1 $aHa*a * , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
$aHa*a , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. $aHo*N, (S,) He sharpened (S, A, Msb, K) a knife, (S, A, L, K,) and a sword, and the like, (L,) or an iron implement, (Msb), with a whetstone or other similar thing; (TA;) as also ↓ A$H*; (K;) and ↓ $H~*, inf. n. ta$oHiy*N. (KL.) ― -b2- [Hence,] $aHa*ota EalayonaA lisaAnaka (tropical:) [Thou hast sharpened against us thy tongue]. (A and TA in art. rhf.) And Ai$oHa*o lahu garoba *ihonika (tropical:) [Sharpen thou for it the edge of thine intellect]. (A.) And $aHa*ahu biEayonihi, (K,) or bibaSarihi, (A,) (tropical:) He looked sharply at him. (K, * TA.) And $aHa*a AljuwEu maEidatahu (assumed tropical:) Hunger made his stomach keen, and strengthened it, (L,) and inflamed it. (L, K.) ― -b3- Hence also, i. e. from $aHa*a in the sense first expl. above, (Har p. 377,) fulaAnN ya$oHa*u Aln~aAsa, (inf. n. $aHo*N, K,) (tropical:) Such a one begs importunately of men: (A, K, * and Har ubi suprà:) and $aHa*otuhu I begged importunately of him. (Msb.) ― -b4- And $aHa*ahu (assumed tropical:) He drove him away; namely, a man; (K;) as also ↓ t$H~*hu, (CK, and so accord. to the O,) or ↓ $H~*hu, (K accord. to the TA,) inf. n. ta$oHiy*N. (TA.) [See also 5 below.] And $aHa*otuhu, (O, TA,) inf. n. as above, (K,) (assumed tropical:) I drove him vehemently. (O, K, * TA.) ― -b5- $aHo*N also signifies (assumed tropical:) The being angry. (K.) You say, $aHa*a Ealayohi (assumed tropical:) He was angry with him. (TK.) ― -b6- And i. q. qa$orN [The act of paring, or peeling, &c.]. (O, K.) You say, $aHa*ahu, i. e. qa$arahu [He pared it, peeled it, &c.]. (TK.)
2 $aH~a*a see above, in two places.

3 $aAHa*aniY * , inf. n. $iHaA*N, He assisted me, by alternating with me, (raAsalaniY,) and did like as I did, in sharpening a sword and the like. (Ham p. 533.) -A2- $AH*t Aln~aAqapu The she-camel raised her tail, and then twisted it vehemently, when in labour, being near to bringing forth. (O, K.)
4 A^a$oHa*a see 1, first sentence.

5 raA^ayotuhu yata$aH~a*u * (tropical:) [I saw him applying himself to importunate begging]. (A, TA. [In both this meaning is indicated by the context.]) -A2- ta$aH~a*aniY fulaAnN (assumed tropical:) Such a one drove me away, and subjected me to trouble, or difficulty. (TA.) See also 1.

$aHa*aAnN * (assumed tropical:) [Having a keen appetite;] hungry. (S, M, L, K.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A vehement driver. (K TA. [See also mi$oHa*N.]) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) Light, or active, in his work (fiY saEoyihi). (O, K.)
$uHo*uw*N * , applied to a man, i. q. naziqN (assumed tropical:) [Light, and unsteady, or lightwitted; &c.]. (TA.)
$aHiy*N * , applied to a knife [&c.], Sharpened; (Lth, A, TA;) as also ↓ ma$oHuw*N. (Lth, TA.)

$aH~aA*N * (tropical:) An importunate beggar: (A, K: *) one should not say $aH~aAvN: (K:) the latter is said by IB to be a vulgar corruption; but several authors assert it to be correct, because * is changed into v without any error in speech, as is asserted by El-Khafájee and others; and accord. to the A, both these words signify as above: (TA in art. $Hv, and partly repeated in the present art.:) [it is said, however, that] $aH~aA*N meaning a beggar does not occur in the language of the Arabs. (Har p. 377.)

mi$oHa*N *
A whetstone; or thing with which, or upon which, one sharpens. (S, K.) ― -b2- And [hence,] A rough, severe, or violent, driver: (O, K: [see also $aHa*aAnN:] and applied also as an epithet to a driving. (O.)

ma$oHa*apN * [A cause, or means, of sharpening: a word of the class of majobanapN &c.]. One says, h`*aA kalaAmN ma$oHa*apN lilofahomi (tropical:) [This is discourse that is a cause, or means, of sharpening of the understanding]. (A.)

mi$oHaA*N *
An [elevation such as is termed] A^akamap, wide within, (O, K, TA,) not rough in the stones [thereof], but extending long upon the earth, not having in it trees nor soft ground: (O, TA:) or, accord. to ISh, (O, TA,) level ground, (O, K, TA,) in which are pebbles like those [that are strewn in the court] of the mosque, and in which is no mountain: but he says that ADk disapproves the word: (O, TA:) accord. to Fr, (O,) the head of a mountain, (O, K, TA,) when sharp, or pointed: pl. ma$aAHi*u. (O.)
ma$oHuw*N * : see $aHiy*N. ― -b2- fulaAnN ma$oHuw*N Ealayohi (tropical:) Such a one is an object of anger. (O, TA.)

1 $aHaTa * , aor.
$aHaTa , inf. n. $aHoTN (S, K) and $aHaTN (K) and $uHuwTN (S, K) and ma$oHaTN; (K;) and $aHiTa, aor.
$aHaTa , (K,) inf. n. $aHaTN; (TA;) It was, or became, distant, or remote: (S, K:) or $aHoTN and $aHaTN signify the being distant, or remote, in all states or circumstances. (TA.) You say, $aHaTa AlmazaAru The place of visiting was, or became, distant, or remote. (S.) And laA A^anosaAka EalaY $aHoTi Ald~aAri I will not forget thee notwithstanding the distance of the dwelling. (TA.) And El-'Ajjáj says,
waAl$~aHoTu qaT~aAEu rajaA='i mano rajaA
[And distance is the severer of the hope of him who hopeth]. (TA.) ― -b2- $aHaTa fiY Als~awomi He went far, or far from what was right, and exceeded the due limit, in the demanding of a price. (TA.) ― -b3- Hence, (TA,) $aHaTa AlbaEiyra fiY Als~awomi, (K, TA, [in the CK, and in a MS. copy of the K, Alb~Eiyru,]) aor.
$aHaTa , inf. n. $aHoTN, (TA,) He went to the utmost of the value of the camel in the demanding of a price: (K, TA:) or he went far from what was right, and exceeded the due limit: (K:) and $aHiTa signifies the same; (K;) or is thought to do so by ISd. (TA.) Hence, also, what is said in a trad., by Rabee'ah, respecting a man emancipating a portion of a slave: yakuwnu EalaY AlmuEotiqi qiymapu A^anoSibaA='i $urakaA=y^ihi yu$oHaTu Alv~amanu vum~a yuEotiqu kul~ahu [The value of the portions of his copartners shall be imposed upon the emancipater;] the price of the slave shall be carried to the utmost; [then he shall emancipate the whole of him:] or the meaning is, the price of the slave shall be collected; from $aHaTa AlA_inaA='a, which see below. (TA.) ― -b4- $aHaTa fulaAnFA He preceded, outwent, got before, or passed beyond, such a one, and became far from him: (K, TA:) and in like manner, Alxayola [the horses, or horsemen]. (T, TA.) One says also, $aHaTato banuw haA$imK AlEaraba The sons of Háshim surpassed, and outstripped, the Arabs [in general] in excellence. (TA.) -A2- $aHaTa AlA_inaA='a He filled the vessel. (Fr, K.) -A3- See also 5.

2 $H~Thu * , inf. n. ta$oHiyTN, (S, K,) He made him (a slain man) to struggle, or flounder, bidamihi
in his blood: (S:) or he besmeared, bedawbed, befouled, or defiled, him, biAld~ami with blood. (K.)

4 A$HThu *
He made him, or caused him, to be, or become, distant, or remote; he put him, sent him, or removed him, far away. (S, K.)

5 t$H~T *
He (a slain man) struggled, or floundered, bidamihi in his blood: (S:) and ↓ $aHoTN [inf. n. of $aHaTa] also signifies the struggling, or floundering, in blood: (Lth, ISd, K:) or the former signifies he struggled, or floundered, and rolled, or wallowed, fiY damihi in his blood: (TA:) or became besmeared, bedawbed, befouled, or defiled, (Mgh, K,) and he rolled, or wallowed, (Mgh,) or struggled, or floundered, (K,) fiY damihi in his blood. (Mgh, K. *) And It (the fœtus) struggled, or floundered, fiY Als~alaY in the membrane enclosing it. (K.)
$aH~aATN * : see what next follows.

manozilN $aAHiTN *
A distant, or remote, place of abode; as also ↓ $aH~aATN. (TA.) ― -b2- $awaAHiTu AlA^awodiyapi, [the former word being pl. of $aAHiTapN,] The distant, or remote, parts of the valleys. (TA.)

$awoHaTN *
Certain trees, (K,) a species of the trees of the mountains, (S,) meaning of the mountains of the saraAp, [the mountain-range extending from near 'Arafát to Nejrán in El-Yemen,] for there they grow, (TA,) of which bows are made: (S, K:) AHn says, One acquainted with [the kind of trees called] the $wHT has informed me that it grows in the manner of the A^aroz [or pine-tree], many rods growing from one stem; its leaves are thin and long, and it has a fruit like the long grape, [the word here rendered “ grape ” is Enbp, but it has been altered in the MS., and may therefore be incorrect,] except that its extremity is more slender, and it is soft, and is eaten: (TA:) or i. q. naboEN: (IB:) or a species of the naboE, (K,) of which bows are made: (TA:) or the $wHT and nbE and $iroyaAn are one; the name varying according to the excellence of their places of growth; what is upon the summit of the mountain being called nbE; what is upon its base, or foot, or lowest or lower part, $ryAn; and what is in the depressed tract by its base, $wHT: (Mbr, Az, K:) IB says the same with respect to the nbE, but that the $wHT is that which is upon the lowest part of the mountain; and this is confirmed by what is said by AZ and others: El-Ghanawee El-Aarábee says, the nbE and $wHT and saraA=' are one: as to the $ryAn, no one holds it to be of the nbE except Mbr: Aboo-Ziyád says that bows are made of the $ryAn, and they are good, but of a black colour tinged with redness: and AHn says in one place, that the nbE and $wHT are yellow in the wood, heavy in the hand; and when they become old, they become red: (TA:) the n. un. is with p. (K.)

1 $aHuma * , (S, Msb, K,) aor.
$aHuma , (K,) inf. n. $aHaAmapN, (MA, Msb,) He (a man, S, K) was, or became, fat; (S, MA, K;) as also $aHima, aor.
$aHama : (TA:) or he was, or became, abundant in the fat of his person. (Msb.) And $aHumato A_ibiluhu (K) His camels were, or became, fat. (TA.) And $uHimati Aln~aAqapu; and $aHamat, aor.
$aHuma ; of the classes of EuniYa and naSara; inf. n. $aHomN and $uHuwmN; The she-camel became fat after leanness. (TA.) ― -b2- $aHima, (S, K,) aor.
$aHama , (K,) inf. n. $aHamN, (TA,) He was, or became, eagerly desirous of fat. (S, K, TA.) And He ate much fat. (TA.) -A2- $aHamahu, (K,) or $aHama A^aSoHaAbahu, (S,) aor.
$aHama , (K,) inf. n. $aHomN, (TA,) He fed him, or his companions, with fat; or gave him, or them, fat to eat. (S, K.)

4 A$Hm *
He had much fat in his possession: like as AlHm signifies “ he had much flesh in his possession. ” (TA.)

$aHomN * , (S, Msb, K,) of an animal, (Msb,) a word of well known meaning, (S, Msb, K,) Fat; (MA, KL;) the substance of fatness: (ISd, TA:) $aHomapN is a more special term, (S, Msb,) [i. e. a n. un.,] signifying a piece thereof: (K:) the pl. of the former is $uHuwmN. (Msb, TA.) It is said of the Jews, in a trad., Harumato Ealayohimu Al$~uHuwmu fabaAEuwhaA waA^akaluwA A^avomaAnahaA [Fats have been forbidden to them; but they have sold them, and have devoured the prices thereof: see Lev. vii. 23]: the fat that is forbidden to them is that of the kidneys and of the stomach and of the intestines into which the food passes from the stomach; but not that of the A^alayop [meaning the “ rump, ” and also the “ tail of a sheep, ”] nor of the back. (TA.) One says, laqiytuhu bi$aHomi kulaAhu [lit. I met him, or found him, with the fat of his kidneys,] meaning, (tropical:) in his state of briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness. (K, TA.) And of him who is deemed weak, one says, fulaAnN $aHomN lilomubotaliEi (tropical:) [lit. Such a one is fat for the swallower]. (Ham p. 771.) ― -b2- Also The hump of the camel: (TA:) heard by Az from the Arabs in this sense. (TA in art. Hm.) ― -b3- And The whiteness [app. meaning the white part] of the belly. (TA.) ― -b4- $aHomapu AlA^u*uni [The lobe, or lobule, of the ear;] the part, of the ear, to which the quroT [i. e. ear-ring or ear-drop] is suspended; (S, Msb, K;) i. e. the soft portion of the lower part of the ear: or the place of the perforation for the quroT. (TA.) ― -b5- $aHomapu AlEayoni The muqolap of the eye; (TA;) i. e., what comprises the white and the black of the eye: (Zj in his “ Khalk el-Insán; ” and S and Msb and K voce muqolapN:) [this is what is generally meant by it; i. e. the globe of the eye:] in the T it is said to be the Hadaqap [i. e. black, or what is in the middle of the white,] of the eye: and some say that it is the $aHomap [app. meaning the whole substance] that is beneath [or behind] the Hadaqap. (TA.) ― -b6- $aHomapu AlHanoZali [and $aHomuhu, as in the K in art. HnZl,] The inner part [i. e. the pulp] of the colocynth, exclusive of its seeds. (K.) ― -b7- $aHomapu Alr~um~aAni The thin yellow [pulp] that is amid the seeds of the pomegranate; (K;) or, as in the M, the substance that separates the seeds of the pomegranate. (TA.) ― -b8- $aHomu Aln~axoli The heart pith, or cerebrum, (jum~aAr,) of palm-trees: (S in art. j*b:) and $aHomapu Aln~axolapi the heart (jum~aArap) of the palm-tree. (M, TA.) ― -b9- $aHomapu Almaroji The xiTomiY~ [or marsh-mallow]. (K.) ― -b10- $aHomu AlA^aroDi The truffle; as a gen. n.; syn. Alkamo'u: (TA in art. kmA^:) and $aHomapu AlA^aroDi the truffle; as a n. un.; syn. AlkamoA^apu: (K:) or the white truffle; syn. AlkamoA^apu AlbayoDaA='u. (S.) [It should be observed that Alkamo'u is generally held to be a n. un.; and AlkamoA^apu, to be a coll. gen. n.; contr. to analogy: but they are here evidently used in the reverse manner.] ― -b11- $aHomapu AlA^aroDi also signifies A certain white worm: or is of (min [which is omitted in some of the copies of the K]) the [long worms, found in moist earth, and in the mud of rivers, called] xaraATiyn: (K, TA:) or a white EaZaA='ap [n. un. of EaZaA='N, q. v.], not big: or, as some say, it is not of the [species called] EaZaA='; it is more pleasant [to the taste], and better: and [because it dwells in the sand-hills,] they say [i. e. call it] also $aHomapu Aln~aqaA, like as they say banaAtu Aln~aqaA: (TA:) it is the [reptile called] Hulakap, which dives into the sand, and to which the fingers (banaAn) of virgins are likened. (TA in art. ArD. [See HulakapN: and see also $abavN.]) ― -b12- A^abuw $aHomK is an appellation of The small species of what is called HimaAru qab~aAna. (TA in art. qb, q. v.) ― -b13- [See also $aHomapN below.]
$uHomN * , with damm, [as though pl. of A^a$oHamu, which I do not find mentioned,] White; applied to men. (IAar, TA.)

$aHimN *
Eagerly desirous of fat. (S, K.) One says, rajulN $aHimN laHimN A man eagerly desirous of fat and of flesh. (TA.) ― -b2- EinabN $aHimN Grapes having little juice (K, TA) and thick skin. (TA.) ― -b3- And rum~aAnapN $aHimapN A pomegranate having thick $aHomap [or pulp amid the seeds]. (TA.)

$aHomapN * [n. un. of $aHomN, which see throughout. -A2- Also] A certain bird. (K. [For TaAy^irN, which I regard as the right reading, in the CK, I find in other copies of the K AlT~aAy^iru as an explanation of Al$~aHomapu.]) -A3- And A certain game of the children of the Arabs of the desert. (K, * TA.)

$aHiymN *
Fat, as an epithet applied to a man: (ISk, S, K:) or abundant in the fat of his person. (Msb.)

$aH~aAmN *
A seller of fat; (S, K;) as also ↓ $aAHimN. (K.) ― -b2- And One who feeds men much with fat. (TA.)

$aAHimN * One who feeds men with fat. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And A man having, or possessing, fat; like laAHimN signifying “ having, or possessing, flesh: ” possessive epithets like laAbinN and taAmirN. (TA.) ― -b3- See also $aH~aAmN.

mu$oHimN * , (S, [so in my copies, see 4, of which it is the part. n.,]) or ↓ mu$aH~imN, like muHad~ivN [in measure], (K,) [both perhaps correct,] A man having much fat in his house or tent. (S, K.) ― -b2- And the former, A man whose camels are fat. (K.)
mu$aH~amN * : see ma$oHuwmN.
mu$aH~imN * : see mu$oHimN.
ma$oHuwmN * Food, and bread, into which fat has been put; (TA;) [and so ↓ mu$aH~amN, for] one says xubozapN mu$aH~amapN [a cake of bread, &c., into which fat has been put]. (K in art. rbq.)

1 $aHana * , (S, L, Msb, K,) aor.
$aHana , inf. n. $aHonN, (L, Msb,) He filled (S, L, Msb, K) a ship, (S, L, K,) or a house, or chamber, &c.: (Msb:) he filled, [or laded,] and completely equipped or furnished, a ship. (L.) And in like manner, It (i. e. what was in it) filled a ship. (L.) And, (S, L, K,) as also ↓ A$Hn, (K,) He filled a town or city (S, L, K) biAlxayoli [with horsemen or the horsemen]. (S, L.) -A2- Also, (L, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (L,) and so the inf. n., (L, Msb,) He drove away (L, Msb, K) a people, or party, (L,) or him. (Msb.) And (L) one says, mar~a ya$oHanuhumo, (S, L,) inf. n. as above, (S,) He passed along driving them away, and pursuing them. (S, L.) AZ heard an Arab of the desert say, Ai$oHano Eanoka fulaAnFA, meaning Remove thou, and put far away, from thee such a one. (L.) And one says of a thing that is intensely acid, A_in~ahu ya$oHanu Al*~ubaAba i. e. Verily it drives away the flies. (TA.) -A3- $aHonN also signifies The running vehemently. (L.) And $aHana, He went far, or far away. (K.) And one says, $aHanati AlkilaAbu, (L,) [and $aHinat, as appears from what follows,] aor. ta$oHanu and ta$oHunu, (L, K,) like tamonaEu and taEolamu and tanoSuru, (K,) inf. n. $uHuwnN, (L,) The dogs went far in pursuit without catching any prey, or game. (L, K.) -A4- $aHina Ealayohi, aor.
$aHana , (L, Msb, K,) inf. n. $aHanN; (L, Msb;) and $aHana, aor.
$aHana , inf. n. $aHonN; (Msb;) He bore rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, against him; (Msb, K;) and (Msb) bore, (L,) or showed, (Msb,) enmity towards him. (L, Msb.)

2 $H~nhu *
He made him, or appointed him to the office of, a $iHonap, q. v.; occurring in postclassical works.]

3 $AHnhu * , (L, Msb, K,) inf. n. mu$aAHanapN, (L, Msb, KL,) He regarded him, or treated him, with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite; (Msb;) or with enmity; being so regarded, or treated, by him: (L, Msb, K, KL:) or, as some say, mu$aAHanapN is such reviling, and blaming, upbraiding, or reproaching, reciprocally, as does not amount to fighting one another; from $aHonaA='u meaning “ enmity. ” (L.)

4 A$Hn * : see 1. ― -b2- Also, (K,) inf. n. A_i$oHaAnN, (L,) He sheathed the sword: (L, * K:) and he drew the sword: thus having two contr. significations. (K.) -A2- Also, (S, L, K,) inf. n. as above, (S, L,) He (a boy, or child, S, L, and, as some say, a man, L) was ready, or about, to weep: (S, L, K:) or his eyes watered at the approach of weeping (L.) ― -b2- And A$Hn lahu bisahomK He prepared himself to shoot him, or to shoot at him, with an arrow. (K.)
6 ta$aAHunN * The regarding, or treating, one another [with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite; (see 1, last sentence; and 3;) or] with enmity. (L.)
$aHonapN * [thus written, with fet-h to the $, but I incline to think that it is correctly ↓ $iHonapN,] The contents of a ship, that fill it. (L.)

$iHonapN * : see what next precedes. ― -b2- [Also] A body of men sufficing for the guarding, controlling, or firm holding, of a province, or city, on the part of the Sultán. (Az, L, K. *) And (K) A troop of horsemen keeping post (S, L, K) in a country or town. (S, L.) IB says that the vulgar usage of this word as syn. with A^amiyrN [i. e. A commander or commandant, &c., being used app. only in post-classical times, from the Pers. $aHonaho, meaning in Pers., and hence in Arabic also, a viceroy, prefect, chief of the police, or the like,] is a mistake. (L.) ― -b3- And The quantity of fodder appointed to beasts as sufficing them for a day and a night. (Az, L, K.) -A2- See also what next follows.

$aHonaA='u *
Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite: (L:) or vehement hatred: (Msb:) and enmity; (S, L, Msb, K;) as also ↓ $iHonapN. (S, L, K.) Hence the saying, kaAna bayonahu wabayona A^axiyhi $aHonaA='u i. e. [There was between him and his brother] enmity. (L.)

$uHuwn * in the following verse, cited by ISd,
taA^aT~arona fiY AlmiynaA='i vum~a tarakonahu
waqado laj~a mino A^aHomaAlihin~a $uHuwnu
may be, accord. to him, an inf. n. of $aHana, or an extr. pl. of $iHonapN: (L:) [but I rather think that it is a pl. of ↓ $aAHinN, like as $uhuwdN is of $aAhidN; and accordingly I would render the verse (which evidently relates to ships) thus: They kept close in the port, then they left it, and laders had persisted in contention by reason of their burdens, i. e. the burdens of the ships, because of the labour that they occasioned.]

$aAHinN * [act. part. n. of $aHana]: see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- See also ma$oHuwnN. -A2- Also A dog going far in pursuit without catching any prey, or game: pl. $awaAHinu. (L.) -A3- And Bearing enmity [or rancour &c. (see 1, last sentence,)] towards another: one says, huwa $aAHinN laka [He is bearing enmity &c. towards thee]. (L.)

ma$oHuwnN * A ship (fulokN, so in the Kur [xxvi. 119 &c.], S, L, or marokabN, K [in the L, erroneously, rakabN],) Filled [or laded, and completely equipped or furnished: see 1, first sentence]; (S, L, K;) as also ↓ $aAHinN, like kaAtimN in the sense of mukotuwmN, (L, K,) mentioned by Kr. (L.)

mu$oHay^in~N *
Becoming angered; or made angry. (K.)

Eaduw~N mu$aAHinN * [An enemy who regards, or treats, another with rancour, &c., being so regarded, or treated by him: see 3]. (S, L.) Almu$aAHinu as used in a trad. means The schismatic innovator in religion: (L, K:) so says El-Owzá'ee: or the transgressor: (L:) or it means he who has in his heart rancour &c. ($aHonaA=') towards the Companions of the Apostle of God: or he who forsakes the institutes, or rule and usage, of his prophet; who speaks against his people; who sheds their blood. (TA.)

1 $aHaA * , (K,) or $aHaA faAhu, (Ks, S,) aor.
$aHawa , (Ks, TA,) or
$aHuwa , (S,) inf. n. $aHowN, (Ks, S, TA,) said of a man, (TA,) He opened his mouth; (S, K, TA;) as also ↓ A$HY [or app., A$HY faAhu], (K,) and faAhu ↓ $H~Y, inf. n. ta$oHiyapN. (TA.) $aHaA faAhu [meaning as above] is also said of the ass when about to bray. (TA.) And one says of the bit, $aHaA fama Ald~aAb~api [It opened the mouth of the beast]. (TA.) [See also art. $HY.] -A2- And $aHaA fuwhu, (S, K, *) aor.
$aHuwa , (S,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) His mouth opened; (S, K;) as also fwh ↓ $H~Y; (TA;) but one should not say A$HY fwh. (IAar, TA.) ― -b2- And $aHaA, inf. n. as above, He stepped, paced, or walked. (TA.) Hence it is related in a trad. of 'Alee, that, having mentioned sedition, or conflict and faction, or the like, he said to 'Ammár, lata$oHuwan~a fiyhaA $aHowFA laA yudorikuka Alr~ajulu Als~ariyEu, meaning Thou shalt assuredly go [or step or pace] quickly, and advance, therein [so that the swift man shall not overtake thee]. (TA.) And it is said that $aHaA fiyhi signifies He went far; and took a wide, or an ample, range; in it. (TA. [See also 5.])
2 $aH~awa see the preceding paragraph, in two places.
4 A^a$oHawa see 1, first sentence.

5 t$H~Y * , accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, primarily signifies He took a wide, or an ample, range in anything. (TA. [See also 1, last explanation.]) ― -b2- [Hence,] t$H~Y Ealayhi He spread out, or stretched out, his tongue, [or he gave wide range to his tongue,] respecting him [or against him]. (K.)

$aHFA * , (K,) thus with the short A, (TA,) Wide; applied to anything: and ↓ $aHowaA='u, applied to a well, signifies the same: (K:) or the latter, thus applied, wide in the head [or upper part]. (TA.)

$aHowapN *
A step, pace, or single act of stepping or pacing. (S, K.) One says, farasN baEiydu Al$~aHowapi A horse having a far extent of step: (S, TA:) and ragiybu Al$~aHowapi (S in art. rgb) a horse wide of step; that takes a large space of ground with his legs. (TA: but there, Al$~aHowi [which is the inf. n.].) ― -b2- [Hence,] rajulN baEiydu Al$~aHowapi fiY maqaASidihi (tropical:) [A man who strides along in his pursuits]. (TA.) ― -b3- And A_inaA='N waAsiEu Al$~aHowapi i. e. (tropical:) [A vessel wide] in the interior. (TA.)
$HA=' * : see the next paragraph.

$aHowaA='u * : see $aHFA. ― -b2- Also A she-camel wide of step: and it is said in a trad. that the Prophet had a horse named ↓ Al$HA=', thus related, with medd, [app. Al$~aHaA='u, like AlwasaAEu,] expl. as meaning the wide of step: so says IAth. (TA.)

$aAHK * [act. part. n. of 1: fem. $aAHiyapN; pl. of the latter $awaAHK and $aAHiyaAtN]. One says, jaA='ati Alxayolu
$awaAHiYa The horses came opening their mouths: (S, A, K, * TA:) and so A^aqobalati Alxayolu $aAHiyaAtK. (M, TA.) ― -b2- And jaA='anaA $aAHiyFA He came to us stepping along. (TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) He came to us without any want. (TA.) ― -b4- Al$~awaAHiY is applied by the vulgar to The large pieces of wood resembling columns: but [SM says,] I have not seen any mention thereof in the [classical] language. (TA.)

1 $aHiYa * , like raDiYa, inf. n. $aHoYN, is said by ISd and in the K to be a dial. var. of $aHaA, inf. n. $aHowN, i. e., as ISd says, meaning He opened his mouth; but the latter, he says, is the better known: this, however, requires consideration: for it is said in the Tekmileh that $aHaY fulaAnN, aor. ya$oHaY, inf. n. $aHoYN, is a dial. var. of [$aHaA, aor.] ya$oHuw, inf. n. $aHowN, on the authority of Lth. (TA.)

1 $axaba * , (Mgh, TA,) aor.
$axuba [and
$axaba ], inf. n. $axobN, said of milk, (Mgh,) and of anything, It flowed. (Mgh, TA.) And $axabotuhu I made it to flow. (Mgh.) You say, $axaba All~abanu, aor.
$axuba and
$axaba , (S, O, CK,) inf. n. $axobN, (S, O,) The milk flowed in an extended stream from the udder when milked; (S, O, CK;) and (assumed tropical:) in like manner one says of blood: (O:) or $axaba All~abana, aor.
$axuba and
$axaba , he made the milk to flow in a continuous stream from the udder (K accord. to the TA [and accord. to the context in the K, in which it is immediately added faA@no$axaba, showing that ↓ An$xb has the former of these two significations as quasi-pass. of $axaba, and the like is said in the A,]) between the vessel and the teat. (TA.) Hence, i. e. from $axaba All~abanu, the saying of ElKumeyt,
wawaHowaHa fiY HiDoni AlfataApi DajiyEuhaA
walamo yaku fiY Aln~ukodi AlmaqaAliyti ma$oxabu
[And he who lay upon his side with her, or her bedfellow, breathed audibly, by reason of the cold, in the bosom of the young woman, and there was not, among the she-camels that had no young ones living, and that should therefore abound with milk, because not suckling, any flowing of milk in a continuous, or an extended, stream, or any time, or place, thereof, for ma$oxabN may be, agreeably with a general rule, an inf. n. or a n. of time or of place]. (S.) And some expl. $axobN as signifying The sounding, or sound, of milk when it is being drawn from the udder. (TA.) One says also, $axabato A^awodaAju Alqatiyli damFA i. e. (tropical:) [The external jugular veins of the slain person] streamed, or flowed with blood: (Msb, TA: * [and the like is said in the Mgh:]) and $axabotuhu A^anaA (assumed tropical:) [I made it to stream, or flow]: the verb being intrans. and trans. (Msb.) And huwa ya$oxubu damFA (assumed tropical:) He, or it, flows [or streams] with blood; the last word being in the accus. case as a specificative: and be, or it, pours forth, or makes to flow [or stream], blood; the last word, when this is the meaning, being in the accus. case as an objective complement: but the former is that which is commonly known. (Mgh.) And $axabato yadaAhu Hat~aY maAta (assumed tropical:) [His hands flowed, or streamed, with blood, until he died: or poured forth blood, &c.]: said, in a trad., of one whose knuckles, or finger-joints, were cut. (TA.) ↓ An$xb, also, is said of blood [as meaning (assumed tropical:) It flowed, or streamed]. (TA.) And damFA ↓ An$xb, said of a vein, means (assumed tropical:) It flowed, or streamed, with blood. (S, K, TA.) And it is said in a trad. respecting the HawoD [or pool (of the Apostle)], ya$oxuabu fiyhi miyzaAbaAni mina Aljan~api (assumed tropical:) [Two spouts will pour forth into it from Paradise]. (TA.) And one says, $axabotu All~iqaAHa I milked the milch camels. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And mar~a ya$oxabu fiY AlA^aroDi (assumed tropical:) He went, or passed by, (O,) or ran, (El-Fáïk, TA,) swiftly [in the land, or upon the ground]. (El-Fáïk, O, TA.)
7 A_ino$axaba see the preceding paragraph, in three places.
$axobN * : see the next paragraph. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Blood. (K.)

$uxobN *
Milk coming forth, (A,) or milk that has come forth, (K,) from the udder, (A, K,) when drawn therefrom; (TA;) and so ↓ $axobN; (A, K;) which is also an inf. n.; (TA;) or this latter is an inf. n., (S, O,) and the former [is a subst. properly so called, and] signifies an extended stream of milk, (S, A, O,) like a thread, or string, (A,) when it is drawn from the udder; (S, A, O;) of the measure fuEolN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (A:) or the milk that comes forth from beneath the hand of the milker at each squeeze of the udder of the ewe or she-goat. (TA.) It is said in a prov., $uxobN fiY AlA_inaA='i wa$uxobN fiY AlA^aroDi, (S, Meyd, A, O,) i. e. One extended stream of milk from the udder into the vessel, and one &c. upon the ground: (Meyd:) applied to him who hits the mark one time and misses another time (S, Meyd, A, O) in what he says; or says right one time and wrong another time. (Meyd.) And in another prov., $uxobN TamaHa An extended stream of milk from the udder that has fallen upon the ground so as to be unprofitable; for such is the meaning of TamaHa in this case: applied to a man who has made a slip, or mistake: or it means a good hap that has escaped one's opportunity to avail himself of it. (Meyd.) See also the next paragraph.

$uxobapN *
A single stream of milk from the udder; (A, K;) pl. $ixaAbN [q. v.]: (K;) or it signifies, (K,) or so ↓ $uxobN, (TA,) an extended stream of milk (K, TA) when it is drawn (TA) from the udder, streaming continuously (K, TA) between the vessel and the teat. (TA.)

$ixaAbN *
Milk when it is drawn from the udder: (A, K: [in which latter it is also said to be pl. of $uxobapN:]) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)
wadajN $axiybN * (assumed tropical:) [An external jugular vein] cut so that its blood has flowed, or streamed, forth. (TA.)

A^u$oxuwbN * The sound of the streaming of milk. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- [And it seems to be used as an epithet; for it is added that] one says, A_in~ahaA laA^u$oxuwbu AlA^aHaAliyli [app. meaning Verily she is one whereof the orifices of the teats produce a sound by the streaming of the milk]. (S, O.)
ma$oxabN * : see the verse in the first paragraph.

1 $axuta * , (S, K,) aor.
$axuta , inf. n. $uxuwtapN, (K,) said of a man, (S,) [and app., in like manner, of anything,] He [or it] was, or became, thin, or slender, (S, L, K,) lean, and lank in the belly, not in consequence of emaciation. (L, K.)
2 ta$oxiytN * The bringing, conveying, or causing to come; syn. A_ibolaAgN. (K.) One says, $x~thu A_ilayohi He brought it, &c., to him. (TK.)

$axotN * and ↓ $axiytN, (S, A, K,) the former also pronounced ↓ $axatN, (K, TA,) by some, (TA,) applied to a man, (S,) Thin, or slender, (S, A, L, K,) lean, and lank in the belly, not in consequence of emaciation: (A, L, K:) slender in the body: fem. of the first with p: (TA:) pl. $ixaAtN: (S, A, K:) or $axotN signifies thin, or slender, as applied to anything: thus it is applied to him who is thin, or slender, in the neck, and in the legs: one says, [of a beast,] A_in~ah la$axotu AljuzaArapi Verily he is thin, or slender, in the legs: (TA:) and qawaAy^imuhu $ixaAtN His legs are thin, or slender: (A:) and HaTabN $axotN Slender firewood. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A_in~ahu la$axotu AlEaTaA='i (assumed tropical:) Verily he is one who gives little. (TA.) And zayodN $axotu Alxuluqi (tropical:) Zeyd is low, ignoble, or mean, in natural disposition. (A, TA.) ― -b3- Some say that it is arabicized, from the Pers. saxot. (TA.)
$axatN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
$axiytN * : see $axotN: ― -b2- and also what here follows.
$ix~iytN * and ↓ $axytN and $ixotiytN Dust (gubaArN) rising, or spreading, or diffusing itself. (K.)
$ixotiytN * : see what next precedes.

1 $axara * , aor.
$axira , inf. n. $axiyrN (S, K) and $axorN, (K,) He raised his voice, with snorting; said of an ass: (S:) he uttered a sound from the fauces: or from the nose: (K:) or from the mouth, without the nose: (TA:) he (a horse) neighed: (K:) or uttered a sound after neighing: (TA:) or uttered a sound from his mouth, (K, TA,) without the nose: (TA:) As says that among the sounds made by horses are those termed $axiyrN and naxiyrN and kariyrN; the first of which is from the mouth; the second, from the nostrils; and the third, from the chest: some say that $axara is like naxara [he snorted]. (TA.)

$axorN * The first period or stage of youth; (K, TA;) and the sharpness thereof; like $aroxN. (TA.)
― -b2- The part, of a raHol [or camel's saddle], that is between the qaAdimap and the A=xirap, (O, K, TA,) which are the kar~aAni: (TA:) [said to be] also called the $arox, [which is an evident mistake, perhaps originating from its having been said that $axorN and $aroxN are syn., meaning in another sense, mentioned above,] (O, TA,) and the $ajor [q. v.]: (TA:) or the space between the upper part of the two extremities [at the fore part and hind part] of the [saddle called] qatab. (JK.) ― -b3- And The chink of the buttocks. (JK, O. [In the K, for wa$axoru AlAisoti $aq~uhaA, the reading in the JK and O, is put wa$axara AlAisota $aq~ahaA.])

$ix~iyrN *
That utters much, or often, the sound termed naxiyr: (K:) or, as in some copies of the K [and in the O], $axiyr: (TA:) [see naxara and $axara:] applied to an ass in this sense, (O,) or as signifying vociferous. (TA.)

1 $axasa * , aor.
$axasa , (K,) inf. n. $axosN, (S, A, O, K,) It was, or became, conflicting, incongruous, or dissimilar, in its several parts; $axosN being syn. with AiDoTiraAbN and AixotilaAfN [here used in the same, or nearly the same, sense]. (S, A, O, K.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) inf. n. as above; (Lth, O, K;) or ↓ $Axs; (so says Lth, TA; and so in a copy of the A;) and ↓ t$Axs; (O, K;) said of an ass, (Lth, A, O, K,) He opened his mouth on the occasion of gaping (Lth, O, K) and smelling the urine of a she-ass: (Lth, O:) or he opened his mouth, raising his head, after smelling the dung. (A.) It is said that the primary signification of Al$~axosu is The opening of the mouth to gape. (Ham p. 196.)

3 $Axs faAhu * , said of time, It caused his teeth to become incongruous; (ISk, A, O;) some of them being long and some of them being broken: (ISk, O:) this is the case in extreme old age: (A, TA:) $ixaAsN and mu$aAxasapN, [as inf. ns. of the pass. verb,] in relation to the teeth, signify their being in such a condition that some of them incline and some of them have fallen out: (JK, TA: *) one says, [$uwxisa faAhu, or $uwxisato A^asonaAnuhu, and] fuwhu ↓ t$Axs, (A,) or t$Axst A^asonaAnuhu, (S, O, K,) His teeth became incongruous, (S, A, O, K,) and some of them inclined and some of them fell out, (S, O, K,) by reason of extreme old age. (S, A, * O, K.) ― -b2- $Axs AlS~adoEa, said of the repairer of a wooden bowl, He made the crack of the bowl to incline, so that it remained not closed up. (O, K.) -A2- See also 1.

4 A$xs * (assumed tropical:) He showed a sour, a crabbed, or an austere, face, (Aboo-Sa'eed, O, K,) lahu to him, (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA,) fiY AlmanoTiqi in speech; as also A$xS. (Aboo-Sa'eed, O, TA.) ― -b2- And A$xshu, (O, K,) and A$xs bihi, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He spoke evil of him behind his back, or in his absence, or otherwise, with truth, or though it might be with truth; syn. AigotaAbahu; (O, K, TA;) as also A$xS bh. (TA.)

6 t$Axs * : see 1: and 3. ― -b2- It (a crack in a wooden bowl) was made by the repairer to incline, so that it remained not closed up. (TA.) ― -b3- It, said of the upper part of a man's skull, (i. e. said of his qiHof, IDrd, O,) or said of his head, (K,) became severed in twain, in consequence of a blow: (IDrd, O, K:) or said of the two [lateral] bones of his head (qiHofaA raA^osihi), meaning tdAnyA wAxtlfA; [but the former of these two verbs is app. a mistranscription for tabaAyanaA; and the meaning, they became separated, each from the other, and not fitting together:] and it is sometimes said of the thumb; and of a vessel. (TA.) ― -b4- t$Axs Alqawomu (assumed tropical:) The people, or party, became distant, or remote, one from another. (JK.) ― -b5- t$Axs A^amoru Alqawomi (assumed tropical:) The state of affairs of the people, or party, became divided, (O, K, * TA, *) and conflicting, or inconsistent. (TA.) And t$Axs maA bayona Alqawomi (assumed tropical:) The state between the people, or party, became bad, or corrupt. (ISk, S, O, K. *)

$axiysN * (assumed tropical:) An affair, or a state of affairs, (A^amorN,) disorganized, disordered, or unsettled; syn. mutafar~iqN. (K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Speech in which is a sour, a crabbed, or an austere, look: (JK: [like $axiySN:]) or (tropical:) incongruous, or discordant, speech; (O, K, TA;) as also ↓ muta$aAxisN, (A 'Obeyd, TA, in art. $xS,) and muta$aAxiSN. (K ibid.) ― -b3- [A man] adverse to that which he is commanded to do. (TA.)
muta$aAxisN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

1 $axaSa * , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
$axaSa , (A, Msb, K,) inf. n. $uxuwSN, (S, Msb, K,) He, or it, rose; or became raised, or elevated. (S, A, Msb, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] It (a star) rose. (K.) And $axaSa lahu $axoSN [A figure seen from a distance rose to his view]. (TA in art. zwl.) ― -b3- $axaSa baSaruhu (S, Mgh, Msb, K, [in some copies of the K, baSarahu, but this occurs afterwards in that work,]) is said when a man opens his eyes and then does not move his eyelids; [and signifies (tropical:) His eyes, or lit., his eye, became fixedly open:] (S, K: *) or it signifies his eye became raised: (Msb:) or his sight became stretched and raised. (Mgh.) [See the Kur xiv. 43, and xxi. 97.] You say, $axaSa A_ilayoka baSariY (tropical:) [My eye, or eyes, became fixedly open, or raised, or my sight became stretched and raised, towards thee]. (A.) And $axaSa baSaru Almay~iti, (A,) inf. n. as above, (IAth,) (tropical:) [The eye, or eyes, of the dying man became fixedly open: or] the eyelids of the dying man became raised upwards, and he looked intently, and became disquieted, or disturbed. (IAth.) ― -b4- saxaSati Alkalimapu mina Alfami (assumed tropical:) The word, or sentence, rose [from the mouth] towards the palate: this is sometimes natural: i. e., one's raising his voice, and not being able to lower it. (K.) ― -b5- $axaSa Als~ahomu (inf. n. as above, Msb,) (tropical:) The arrow rose [so as to deviate] from the butt, or object of aim: (K:) or the arrow passed beyond the butt, or object of aim, going above it: (A, Msb:) or rose in the sky. (ISh.) ― -b6- $axaSa (aor. as above, Msb, and so the inf. n., S, Msb,) also signifies He went, or went away, from one town or country to another: (S, A, K:) or he went forth from one place to another, (Msb,) or from his place of alighting or abiding: (TA:) or [so accord. to the TA, but in the K “ and ”] he journeyed upwards. (K, TA.) You say also, $axaSa mino qawomihi He went forth from his people: and $axaSa A_ilayohimo he returned to them.
