(TA.) ― -b7- Also, (M, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) It (a thing) rose; or swelled; or became swollen: (M:) it (a wound) rose, and became swollen: (M, K:) [it was, or became, protuberant, or prominent.] -A2- $axaSa baSarahu, (Msb, K, TA,) or $axaSa bibaSarihi, (Mgh,) or both, (TA, [in which it is said to be tropical,]) and $axaSa bibaSarihi A_ilaY Als~amaA='i, (Msb,) or $axaSa [alone], (so in a copy of the A, [in which it is mentioned among proper expressions,]) (assumed tropical:) He raised his eye, or sight, (K, TA,) towards the sky, and did not move his eyelids; said of a dying man: (TA:) or he stretched and raised his sight: (Mgh:) or he opened his eyes, (A, Msb,) and did not move his eyelids, (A,) or [looking fixedly,] not moving his eyelids. (Msb.) ― -b2- ya$oxaSu biSawotihi falaA yaqodiru EalaY xafoDihi (assumed tropical:) [He raises his voice, and is not able to lower it]. (K.) ― -b3- $uxiSa bihi, (S, K,) coordinate to EuniYa, (K,) or $uxiSa [alone], (so in a copy of the A,) or $axiSa bihi A^amorN, coordinate to taEiba, inf. n. $axaSN, (Msb,) (tropical:) [He was disquieted by a thing that happened to him: or] a thing that disquieted him happened to him: (S, A, K:) or a thing happened to him and disquieted him: (Msb:) as though he were raised from the ground by reason of his disquietude. (TA.) [See also 4.] -A3- $axuSa, aor.
$axuSa , (S, K,) inf. n. $axaASapN, or this is a simple subst., [for] ISd says, I have not heard a verb of which it may be the inf. n., (TA,) [if used, signifying] He (a man, S) was, or became, big, bulky, or corpulent. (S, K.)
2 $x~S Al$~aYo'a * , (A,) inf. n. ta$oxiySN. (TA,) (tropical:) He individuated the thing; syn. Eay~anahu. (A, TA.) [From $axoSN, q. v.]

4 A$xShu * [He made him, or it, to rise, or become raised or elevated]. You say, A$xS nafosahu [He raised himself; or drew, or stretched, himself up]. (S and K in art. Elb.) ― -b2- A$xS bisahomihi (tropical:) He made his arrow to pass beyond the butt, or object of aim, going above it. (A.) ― -b3- And A$xShu He made him to go, or go away, from one town or country to another: (S:) or to go forth from one place to another: (A, * Msb:) or to go, or journey: (A in art. syr:) or to journey upwards. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) He disquieted him, (K, TA,) so that he went away from a place. (TA.) [See also 1.] -A2- A$xS (tropical:) His (an archer's) arrow passed beyond the butt, or object of aim, (S, A, Msb, K,) going above it. (S, A, Msb.) -A3- The time of his journeying, going away, or departing, came, or arrived. (S, K, TA.) -A4- A$xS A_ilayohi (tropical:) He showed him a sour, a crabbed, or an austere, face, or countenance; looked at him in a sour, a crabbed, or an austere, manner; (A, TA;) or so A$xS lahu, (TA in art. $xs,) fiY AlmanoTiqi in speech; as also A$xs. (Aboo
Sa'eed, O and TA in art. $xs.) ― -b2- A$xS bifulaAnK (tropical:) He spoke evil of such a one behind his back, or in his absence, or otherwise, with truth, or though it might be with truth; syn. AigotaAbahu; (Yaakoob on the authority of AO, S, A, K;) as also A$xs. (AO, Yaakoob, S.)
5 t$x~S * [quasi-pass. of 2; (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, individuated; it, or he, had, or assumed, the quality of individuality or personality; syn. taEay~ana].

$axoSN * The body, or bodily or corporeal form or figure or substance, (sawaAd,) of a man, (S, A, Msb, K,) or some other object or thing, (S, A, K,) which one sees from a distance: (S, A, Msb, K:) applying in common to what is termed juv~apN and what is termed TalalN, in relation to a man; i. e., in relation to a man sitting or sleeping [or lying down], and in relation to a man standing erect: (Msb, voce juv~apN:) or it is applied only to a body, or material substance, composed, [not simple,] and having height: (El-Khattábee, Msb, TA:) or any body, or material thing or substance, [that is somewhat high, and conspicuous, or] having height and appearance: (IAth, TA:) pl. (of pauc., S) A^a$oxuSN (S, K) and (of mult., S) A^a$oxaASN [which is properly another pl. of pauc.] and $uxuwSN (S, A, K) and $ixaASN. (TA.) ― -b2- Then used as signifying (assumed tropical:) A man himself; a man's self, or person; his *aAt; (Msb;) [i. e.,] a person; a being; an individual; syn. nafosN [also syn. with *aAtN]; (L, TA;) as in the following verse of 'Amr Ibn-Rabee'ah, cited by Sb:
fakaAna mijan~iY duwna mano kunotu A^at~aqiY
valaAvu $uxuwSK kaAEibaAni wamuEoSiru
(assumed tropical:) [And three persons, namely, two girls whose breasts were beginning to swell and one who had attained the age of puberty, were my shield against such as I was fearing]: meaning valaAvapu A^anofusK: (L:) [the poet making the word in question fem. because it relates here to females: but] Rubeh is related to have said valaAvapu A^a$oxuSK, meaning, of women. (M, voce nafosN.) A $axoS [meaning a person] ceases to be a $xS by its being divided; whereas, when a jisom is divided, no part of it ceases to be a jsm. (Er-Rághib, TA in art. jsm.) It is said in a trad., laA $axoSa A^agoyaru mina A@ll~`hi (tropical:) [There is not any being more jealous than God]; $xS being here metaphorically used for *aAt: or the meaning is, a person ($xS) should not be more jealous than God: but accord. to one relation, the words are laA $aYo'a A^agoyaru mina A@ll~`hi [which has the first of the two meanings mentioned above]. (IAth, TA.) [It is also used in a pl. sense: see a verse of Ziyád el-Aajam in art. AlY.]

$axiySN *
Big, bulky, or corpulent: (S, K, TA:) or great in $axoS [or person] and make: (TA:) applied to a man: (S:) fem. with p; (S, A, K;) applied to a woman. (S, A.) ― -b2- A lord, master, chief, man of rank or quality, or a personage. (AZ, K.) ― -b3- manoTiqN $axiySN (tropical:) Sour, crabbed, or austere, speech. (Ibn-'Abbád, A, K. [See also $axiysN.])

$axaASapN *
Bigness, bulkiness, or corpulence: or greatness of $axoS [or person] and make. (TA.) [Said to be a subst.: but see $axuSa.]

$aAxiSN * [part. n. of the intrans. verb $axaSa]. [Hence,] baSarN $aAxiSN (tropical:) [An eye fixedly open: or raised: or sight stretched and raised: see 1]: you say, samiEotu biquduwmika faqalobiY bayona janaAHaY~a raAqiSN wabaSariY taHota HijaAjiY $aAxiSN (tropical:) [I have heard of thy coming, and my heart is throbbing between my two sides, and my eye beneath my bone of the eyebrow fixedly open, &c.]. (A, TA.) With the pl., A^aboSaArN, you say $aAxiSapN, (A, Msb, TA,) and $awaAxiSu, (A, TA,) or $uxuwSN [like $uhuwdN as pl. of $aAhidN; if not an inf. n., as which it may be applied, in the place of an epithet, to a pl. subst.]. (Msb.) ― -b2- sahomN $aAxiSN (tropical:) An arrow passing beyond the butt, or object of aim, going above it. (S, A.) You say, rumiYa biAl$~aAxiSaAti (tropical:) [He was shot at with arrows which passed beyond him, going above him: perhaps doubly tropical, meaning he was assailed with invectives which did not harm him]. (A.) ― -b3- $aAxiSN also signifies A man prosecuting war [during three or more days together,] not on alternate days: and of such it is said in a trad., that he may shorten prayer. (TA.) -A2- $aAxiSN as the act. part. n. of the trans. verb, [for $aAxiSN baSarahu,] (Msb,) (assumed tropical:) [A man raising his eye, or sight, and looking fixedly; as does a dying man: or stretching and raising his sight: (see 1:) or] a man opening his eyes and not moving his eyelids. (S, * Msb.)

[
ma$oxaSN * , as though signifying The place of a $axoS used in the sense of Suwrapi: accord. to modern usage sing. of] ma$aAxiSu deenárs [or pieces of gold] figured [or stamped with effigies]. (TA.)
mu$ax~aSN * (tropical:) A thing individuated. (A, TA.)

muta$aAxiSN *
Discordant; (A'Obeyd, K;) applied to language, or speech; (A'Obeyd, TA;) and to a thing, or an affair; (TA;) and muta$aAxisN signifies the same. (A'Obeyd, TA.)

1 $ad~a * , as an intrans. verb, aor.
$adi3a , inf. n. $id~apN: see 8; and see also $id~apN. ― -b2- [Hence,] la$ad~a maA is an expression used in the same sense as laEaz~a maA (A and K in art. Ez) and laHaq~a maA: (A and TA in that art.:) [and in like manner without the l: thus] one says, $ad~a maA A^an~aka *aAhibN, meaning Haq~a A^an~aka *aAhibN [i. e. It is distressing, or it distresses me, that thou art going away]: and if you please, you may consider $ad~a as similar to niEoma; as when you say, niEoma AlEamalu A^an~aka taquwlu AlHaq~a [Excellent, or most excellent, is the deed, thy saying the truth]. (Sb, TA.) [And it is also used to render intensive a verb following it; as in the saying, la$ad~a maA A^abogaDaniY Much indeed, or greatly indeed, did he hate me.] ― -b3- $ad~a Ealayohi, aor.
$ada3a (S, L) and
$adi3a , (L,) inf. n. $ad~N (S, L) and $uduwdN, (L,) He charged, or made an assault or attack, upon him, in war, or battle. (S, L.) You say, $ad~a EalaY AlEaduw~i $ad~apF waAHidapF, and $ad~aAtK kaviyrapF, He made one charge, or assault, or attack, upon the enemy, and many charges, &c. (L.) And $ad~a EalaY qironihi bisik~iynK, or biEaSFA, He made an assault, or attack, upon his adversary, with a knife, or with a staff; as also Ealayohi ↓ A$td~. (Mgh.) And $ad~a Al*~iy^obu EalaY Alganami The wolf asaulted, or attacked, the sheep or goats. (L.) In the phrase, $ad~uwA AlA_igaArapa, the meaning is $ad~uwA liloA_igaArapi [They made a charge for the purpose of a sudden attack upon an enemy, or a predatory incursion]; and therefore AlAgArp is put in the accus. case, not as an objective complement. (Ham p. 8.) ― -b4- $ad~a, (S,) aor.
$adu3a and
$adi3a , (TK,) inf. n. $ad~N, (S, L, K,) also signifies He ran; (S, L, * K; *) and so ↓ A$td~. (S, L, K.) rub~a $ad~K fiY Alkurozi [Many a run is in the sack] is a prov., originating from the fact that a man riding a pregnant mare was pursued by an enemy, and she cast her foal, which ran with its mother, whereupon the horseman alighted, and carried it off in a sack; and the enemy overtook him, and said to him, “Throw to me the foal;” and he replied in these words, meaning that the foal was of generous race: it is applied to him whose internal, or intrinsic, qualities are commended. (Meyd.) And one says, $ad~a fiY AlEadowi, (A, Mgh, L,) inf. n. $ad~N; (L;) and ↓ A$td~; (A, Mgh, L;) He hastened, or was quick, in running: (Mgh, L:) and $ad~a AlA_iHoDaAra [meaning the same]. (S in art. Afr.) ― -b5- $ad~a Aln~ahaAru, (S, L,) and AlD~uHaY, (L,) inf. n. $ad~N; (L, K; but in the latter, Aln~aAr is erroneously put for Aln~ahaAr; TA;) and ↓ A$td~; (L;) The day, and the morning, became advanced, the sun being high. (S, * L, K. *) [See also $ad~N below.] -A2- $ad~ahu, aor.
$adu3a (S, A, L, Msb) and
$adi3a , the latter anomalous, for the aor. of a trans. verb of this class, of the measure faEala, should be
$adu3a only, and that of an intrans. verb of the same class and measure should be
$adi3a , and this is the only instance, or almost the only one, of its kind, with both of these forms of aor., except Eal~a [and bat~a] and nam~a AlHadiyva, but there is one trans. verb of the same class having the latter form of aor. only, namely, Hab~a, (Fr, S, L,) inf. n. $ad~N, (L, Msb, K,) He made it, or rendered it, hard; used in relation to substances and attributes: (L:) he made, or rendered, it, or him, firm, compact, or sound; and strong, powerful, or forcible; vigorous, robust, or sturdy; syn. A^aHokamahu, (L,) and qaw~aAhu; (S, A, L, K; *) as also ↓ $d~dhu, [inf. n. ta$odiydN,] i. e. as syn. with AHkmhu (L) and qw~Ahu: (S, A, L:) he bound, or tied, him, or it, firmly, fast, or strongly; syn. A^awovaqahu: [which may also be meant to convey the signification immediately preceding this last:] (S, L, Msb, K:) and [simply] he tied, bound, or made fast, him, or it; syn. rabaTahu. (S and Msb and K &c. in art. rbT.) One says, $ad~a EaDudahu i. e. He
strengthened [his fore arm, or perhaps his upper arm, but the former is app. here meant]. (S, L.) And $ad~a EalaY yadihi He strengthened him, [lit. his arm, or hand,] and aided him. (L.) And $ad~a A@ll~`hu mulokahu, and ↓ $ad~adahu, God strengthened, or may God strengthen, his dominion. (S, L. [See also a similar ex. voce A^azorN.]) And $ad~a AlEuqodapa [He tied firmly or fast or strongly, or he pulled tight, or tightened, the knot], (A, Mgh, Msb,) and AlwavaAqa [the bond]. (Kur xlvii. 4.) [And $ad~a Ald~aAb~apa He bound the saddle on the beast: see an ex. voce daliylN.] $ad~u Alr~iHaAli [lit. The binding of the camels' saddles upon their backs] is a metonymical phrase for (tropical:) the going a journey. (Mgh, Msb.) And $ad~u Almiy^ozari, occurring in a trad., [lit. The binding of the waist-wrapper upon the waist] is a metonymical phrase for (tropical:) the avoiding of women: or the exerting oneself, or employing oneself vigorously or laboriously, in work: or for both of these together. (L.) maA A^amoliku $ad~FA walaA A_iroxaA='F [lit. I possess not power to tighten nor to slacken] means I am not able to do anything. (TA.) [And $ad~ahu also signifies He pressed, compressed, or squeezed, it: and he pulled, or strained, it.] waA@$odudo EalaY quluwbihimo, in the Kur [x. 88], means And put Thou a seal upon their hearts, so that they may not heed admonition, nor be disposed, or directed, to that which is good. (L.) -A3- A^a$ad~u laqado kaAna ka*aA, as also A^a$adu without teshdeed, means A^a$ohadu [q. v.]: (K:) a strange saying. (TA.)

2 $ad~a3a see the preceding paragraph, latter half, in two places. ― -b2- $d~dhu, inf. n. ta$odiydN, also signifies He made it, or rendered it, namely, a beating, and anything, hard to be borne, heavy, vehement, violent, intense, severe, strict, rigorous, or excessive; he intensified it, or aggravated it: (L:) ta$odiydN is the contr. of taxofiyfN [in this sense and in other senses here following]. (S.) [Hence, the objective complement being understood,] one says, $d~d Ealayohi, (A, Msb,) which is the contr. of xaf~afa [i. e. of xaf~afa Eanohu; thus meaning He rendered his burden, suffering, distress, uneasiness, or the like, hard to be borne, heavy, vehement, violent, intense, severe, strict, rigorous, or excessive; intensified it, or aggravated it; or he pressed hard upon him; treated him with hardness, strictness, severity, or rigour]: (Msb:) and mano $ad~ada $ad~ada A@ll~`hu Ealayohi [Whoso treateth others hardly, God will treat him hardly]. (A. [See also 8.]) ― -b3- [ta$odiydN, as opposed to taxofiyfN, also signifies The characterizing of a letter by a lengthened pronunciation equivalent in grammatical analysis and in prosody to doubling, denoted in writing by the sign called ↓ $ad~ap, i. e. by the sign ~ over that letter; as also tavoqiylN.] ― -b4- See also sad~adahu.

3 $Ad~hu * , (A, L,) inf. n. mu$aAd~apN and $idaAdN, (L,) He vied with him, contended with him for superiority, or strove to surpass him, in strength, power, or force. (A, L.) [Hence,] mano yu$aAdidi Ald~iyna yagolibohu, (A,) or mano yu$aAd~a h`*aA Ald~iyna bigolibohu, i. e. Whoso contendeth for superiority in strength with this religion, and withstandeth it, or opposeth it, and tasketh himself with religious service beyond his power, it (the religion) will overcome him: a trad. (L.) And lano yu$aAd~a Ald~iyna A^aHadN A_il~aA guliba No one shall contend for superiority in strength with religion, &c. but he will be overcome by the religion. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- See also 5.

4 A$d~ * , (S, A, L, K,) inf. n. A_i$odaAdN, (K,) He, (a man, S, L, K, *) or they, (a company of men, A, L,) had, (A, L,) or had with him, (S, L, K,) [or had with them,] a strong beast, (S, L, K,) or strong beasts. (A, L.) -A2- [maA A^a$ad~a ka*aA How hard, hard to be borne, vehement, violent, intense, or the like, or how great, is such a thing!]

5 t$d~d *
He acted, or behaved, with forced hardness, firmness, strength, vigour, hardiness, courage, vehemence, severity, strictness, or rigour; he exerted his strength, force, or energy; strained, or strained himself, or tasked himself severely; syn. taSal~aba; (A and TA in art. Slb;) and jahada nafosahu; (L;) [fiY Al$~aYo'i in the thing; as also fiyhi ↓ $aAd~a; for] Almu$aAd~apu fiY Al$~aYo'i and Alt~a$ad~udu fiyhi signify the same: (S, L, K: * [see an ex. of t$d~d in the first paragraph of art. jld:]) [and] both of these phrases signify the showing hardness, &c., in the thing. (PS.) You say also t$d~d liloA^amori He applied himself with hardness, firmness, vigour, hardiness, severity, or rigour, to the affair. (MA.) And ta$ad~adati Alqayonapu The slavesongstress strained herself, or tasked herself severely, in raising her voice in singing. (L.) ― -b2- Also He (a man) was, or became, hard, or difficult: you say, saA^alonaA fulaAnFA HaAjapF fata$ad~ada EalayonaA [We asked of such a one a thing wanted, and he was hard, or difficult, to us]. (TA in art. wEr.) ― -b3- And He was, or became, niggardly, tenacious, or avaricious. (MA, KL.)

6 t$Ad~wA * [They vied, contended for superiority, or strove to surpass one another, in strength, power, or force: see 3]. (TA in art. Hms: there coupled with AiqotataluwA.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

8 A$td~ * ; (S, A, L, Msb;) and ↓ $ad~a, aor
$adi3a , (L, Msb,) the only form of its aor., (L,) inf. n. $id~apN, (S, Msb,) whence the former verb; (S;) and ↓ t$Ad~; (L;) It was, or became, hard, (L, and MA and KL and PS in explanation of the first,) said of a substance and of an attribute: (L:) it, or he, was, or became, firm, compact, or sound; (L &c. as above;) strong, powerful, or forcible; vigorous, robust, or sturdy; (L, and A and MA and KL in explanation of the first, and Msb in explanation of the second:) [also it was, or became, bound, or tied, firmly, fast, or strongly:] and the first of these verbs, [and the second also,] it was, or became, hard to be borne, heavy, vehement, violent, intense, pressing, severe, strict, rigorous, tight, strait or difficult, distressing or distressful, afflictive, calamitous, or adverse. (MA, L, KL.) It is said in a trad., laA tabiyEuwA AlHab~a Hat~aY ya$otad~a i. e. [Ye shall not sell grain] until it becomes hard, or firm, or strong. (L.) And you say, A$td~t AlEuqodapu [The knot became tied firmly, fast, or strongly; or became tight]. (A, Mgh, Msb.) And A$td~ Alz~amanu Ealayohimo The time, or fortune, became hard upon them; or severe, rigorous, distressful, afflictive, calamitous, or adverse, to them. (L. [See also 2.]) And A$td~ bihi AlA^amoru [The affair, or event, distressed, or afflicted, him; like A$td~ Ealayohi]. (L in art. jd, &c.) ― -b2- See also 1, former half, in four places.

$ad~N * an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, L, &c.) ― -b2- [Hence,] $ad~u Aln~ahaAri, and $ad~u AlD~uHaY, The time when the day, and the morning, is advanced, the sun being high. (L.) One says, jiy^otuka $ad~a Aln~ahaAri, and $ad~a AlD~uHaY, (L, and the like is said in the A,) and fiY $ad~i Aln~ahaAri, and fiY $ad~i AlD~uHaY, (L,) I came to thee in the time when the day, and the morning, was advanced, the sun being high. (A, * L.)

$ad~apN * [inf. n. of un. of $ad~ahu: as such signifying] A single act [of making, or rendering, hard, firm, compact, or sound; strong, powerful, or forcible: and] of binding, or tying, firmly, fast, or strongly. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 2, last sentence but one. -A2- Also [inf. n. of un. of the intrans. verb $ad~a: as such signifying] A single charge or assault or attack in war or battle. (S, A, * Mgh, L, K. *)

$id~apN * inf. n. of ↓ $ad~a (L, Msb) as syn. with Ai$otad~a: (L:) [and] a subst. from [i. e. syn. with] Ai$otidaAdN: (K:) The attribute denoted by the epithet $adiydN: (S:) hardness, (A, MA, L,) in substances and in attributes; (L;) firmness, compactness, or soundness; strength, power, or force; vigour, robustness, sturdiness, or hardiness; (MA, L; see A^a$ud~N, which, accord. to some, is a pl. of $id~apN;) courage, bravery, firmness of heart: (L:) niggardliness, tenaciousness, or avarice: (A: [see also 5, last sentence:]) vehemence, violence, intenseness, stress, pressure, severity, strictness, rigour, tightness, straitness or difficulty: (MA:) hardship, rigour of fortune: (MA, L:) famine, dearth, want of victuals; hardness, straitness, or difficulty, of subsistence [&c.]: (L:) trouble, distress, affliction, calamity, or adversity; (MA, L;) as also [↓ $ud~aY, in these as well as in some of the preceding senses, and] ↓ $adiydapN, [rather meaning a hard, or distressing, event, an affliction, or a calamity, and rarely used,] of which, (L,) or of $id~apN, (MA, L,) the pl. is $adaAy^idu, (MA, L,) agreeably with analogy if of $adiydapN, but extr. if of $id~apN: and this pl. also signifies seditions, discords, or dissensions, whereby men are put into a state of commotion: (L:) and the rigours, or pangs, (gamaraAt,) of death: (S and Msb in art. gmr:) accord. to Sb, the pl of $id~apN is $idadN, which, he says, preserves its original form [without idghám] because it does not resemble a verb. (L.) One says, qaAsayotu minohu $id~apF [I endured, from him, hardness, &c.; or from it, hardship, &c.]. (A.) And fulaAnK ↓ xfotu $ud~aY meaning $id~atahu
[i. e. I feared the hardness, &c., of such a one]: so says AZ: and he cites this verse:
↓ faA_in~iY laA A^aliynu liqawoli $ud~aY
mina AlHadiydi ↓ walawo kaAnato A^a$ad~a
[And, or for, I will not become gentle for a hard saying, (lit. a saying of hardness,) though it should be harder than iron]. (L.) And A^aSaAbatoniY ↓ $ud~aY meaning $id~apN [i. e. Hardship, &c., befell me]. (AZ, S.) [And $id~apN also signifies A strong, an intense, or a great, degree of any quality &c.]
$ud~aY * : see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.

$adiydN *
Possessing the quality of $id~ap: (S, L:) i. e. hard; applied to a substance and to an attribute: firm, compact, or sound: (L:) strong, powerful, forceful; vigorous, robust, sturdy, or hardy; (A, Mgh, L, Msb;) applied to a thing, (Msb,) and to a man; (A, Mgh, L;) as also $adiydu AlquwaY: (Mgh:) pl., applied to men, A^a$id~aA='u and [applied to things and men] $idaAdN (A, L) and $ududN, (Sb, L,) which last preserves its original form [without idghám] because not resembling a verb: (L:) also courageous, brave, firm of heart: (L, K: *) and niggardly, tenacious, or avaricious; (A, L, Msb, K;) as also ↓ muta$ad~idN: (S, A, L, K:) and [as is implied by the first explanation above, and shown by frequent usage,] vehement, violent, intense, pressing, severe, strict, rigorous, tight, strait or difficult, hard as meaning hard to be borne, troublesome, distressing or distressful, afflictive, calamitous, or adverse. (L, KL, PS, &c.) You say, huwa $adiydN EalaY qawomihi [He is hard, or severe, or rigorous, to his people]. (A.) [And $adiydN EalaY ka*aA Niggardly, tenacious, or avaricious, of such a thing.] Aboo-Dhu-eyb says, using $adiyd in the sense of $aHiyH,
HadaronaAhu biAlA^avowaAbi fiY qaEori huw~apK
$adiydK EalaY maA Dum~a fiY All~aHodi juwluhaA
[We lowered him, with the grave-clothes, into the bottom of a cavity in the ground, the sides whereof were tenacious of what was comprised in the lateral hollow which was the place of the corpse]. (L.) And the words of the Kur [c. 8], waA_in~ahu liHub~i Alxayori la$adiydN, accord. to Zj, mean And verily, on account of the love of wealth, he is niggardly, or tenacious, or avaricious. (L.) $adiydu AlEayoni applied to a man, and $adiyodapu jafoni AlEayoni metaphorically applied by a poet to a she-camel, mean Whom sleep does not overcome. (L.) And Al$~adiydu means The lion; (K;) because of his strength and hardiness. (TA.) [$adiyd with a subst. or an inf. n. following it in the gen. case, the latter having the article Al prefixed to it, or being prefixed to another noun in the gen. case, supplies the place of an intensive epithet; as in $adiydu Als~awaAdi Intensely, or very, black; and $adiydu AlgaDabi Vehemently, or exceedingly, or very, angry; and] misokN $adiydu Alr~aAy^iHapi Strong-smelling musk; (L;) [and rajulN $adiydu bayaADi AlEayoni A man intensely white in the eye.] ― -b2- AlHuruwfu Al$~adiydapu [The strong letters] are those letters which, in a state of quiescence, prevent the current of the voice in their utterance; namely A^, b, t, j, d, T, q, and k; (TA;) the letters comprised in the words A^ajadota Tabaqaka. (K.)
$adiydapN * [as a subst. from $adiydN, rendered such by the affix p]: see $id~apN.

A^a$ad~u * [Possessing the quality of $id~ap, in a greater, and in the greatest, degree; i. e. more, and most, hard, &c.]. See an ex. in a verse cited voce $id~apN. Halabota biAls~aAEidi AlA^a$ad~i, or HalabotuhaA Alx, is a prov., expl. in art. Hlb. And baqiYa A^a$ad~uhu. [The hardest part of it has remained] is another prov., applied to him who attains a part of that which he wants, and is unable to attain the completion thereof. (TA. [See also Freytag's “ Arab. Prov., ” i. 169.]) [With an indeterminate subst. or inf. n. following it in the accus. case, it supplies the place of a simple epithet denoting the comparative and superlative degrees; as in A^a$ad~u sawaAdFA More, and most, black; and A^a$ad~u gaDabFA More, and most, angry.] ― -b2- A^a$ad~u Aln~ahaAri The time when the day is most advanced, the sun being at the highest. (L. [See $ad~u Aln~ahaAri.])

A^a$ud~N * , (S, A, Mgh, L, K, &c.,) also pronounced A^u$ud~N, (Seer, K,) but the latter form is rare, (TA,) is both masc. and fem., (Zj, TA,) and as used in the Kur it has somewhat different meanings: (Az, TA:) in the phrase Hat~aY yaboluga A^a$ud~ahu, (S, K,) and other phrases in the Kur, (TA,) A^a$ud~ is expl. as meaning The state of strength; (S, Mgh, L, K;) which is from eighteen to thirty years: (S, L, K:) or from about seventeen to forty: (Zj:) or from thirty to forty: (Zj in another place:) or puberty: (Az, Mgh, L:) or firmness, or soundness, of judgment, produced by experience: (L:) or puberty together with such maturity as gives evidence of rectitude of conduct or course of life; (Zj, Az, Mgh, L;) which may be at, or before, the age of eighteen years; accord. to most of the men of science, and among them Esh-Sháfi'ee; (Zj, Az, L;) and the extreme term of which is three and thirty years: (Mgh:) or the age of forty years; as in the Kur xlvi. 14: (L:) A^a$ud~N [originally A^a$odudN] is a sing. having a pl. form, like A=nukN; and these two words are [said to be] the only instances of the kind: (S, K: [but see A=nukN:]) or a pl. having no proper sing., (S, Mgh, K,) like A=saAlN and A^abaAbiylu and EabaAdiydu and ma*aAkiyru: (S:) or its sing. is ↓ $id~apN, (AHeyth, S, Mgh, K,) accord. to Sb; and this is good with respect to the meaning, because one says, balaga AlgulaAmu $id~atahu; (S;) but fiEolapN does not form a pl. of the measure A^afoEulN; (S, K;) for as to A^anoEumN, (S,) which is said by AHeyth to be pl. of niEomapN, (TA,) [and respecting which Mtr says that] A^a$ud~N is said to be pl. of $id~apN like as A^anoEumN is of niEomapN, formed by regarding the p as elided, (Mgh, [and AHeyth says the like,]) it is only pl. of nuEomN in the phrase yawomu nuEomK: (S:) or its sing. is $ad~N, like as kalobN is of A^akolubN; or $id~N, like as *iy^obN is of A^a*ow^ubN; (S, K;) accord. to some; (S;) but neither $ad~N nor $id~N has been heard from the Arabs [as sing. of A^a$ud~N]; and they are only deduced from analogy: (S, K:) or it is pl. of A^a$ad~u; and the A^ is not regarded in the formation of this pl. (IJ, from A 'Obeyd.)
ma$ad~u AlEiSaAbapi * [The place, or part, where the fillet, or the like, is bound, or tied]. (A.)

mu$id~N * A man having, (A, Mgh, L,) or having with him, (L,) a strong beast, (A, Mgh, L,) or strong beasts; (L;) contr. of muDoEifN. (Mgh, L.) It is said in a trad., yarud~u mu$id~uhumo EalaY muDoEifihimo [He among them who has a strong beast, or strong beasts, shall give back a portion of the spoil to him of them who has a weak beast, or weak beasts]; meaning that the strong warrior and plunderer shall share with (yusaAhimu) the weak in the plunder that he gains. (L.)
muta$ad~idN * : see $adiydN.

1 $adaxa * , (S, A, Msb, &c.,) aor.
$adaxa , (Msb, K, *) inf. n. $adoxN, (S, A, Msb, K, &c.,) He broke, or crushed, syn. kasara, (S, A, Msb, K,) and faDaxa, (TA, and Ham p. 363,) or ha$~ama, (TA,) a hollow thing, (S, A, L, TA,) or a soft, or tender, or an easily-broken, thing, (A,) or a moist thing, (K,) or a moist and soft thing, such as the Earofaj and the like, (L, TA,) a person's head, (S, A, L, Msb, TA,) and a colocynth, and an unripe date, (A,) and any hollow bone, and a rod, (Msb,) or, as some say, a dry thing, (K,) with the hand, or with a stone &c.: (Ham ubi suprà:) or he pressed, or squeezed, syn. gamaza, [app. so as to crush,] a hollow thing, or a soft, or tender, or an easilybroken, thing, as a head, and a colocynth, and an unripe date. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] $adaxa dimaA='ahumo taHota qadamihi (tropical:) He made their blood (lit. bloods) to go for nothing, or to be of no account. (A, K. *) And [simply] $adaxa Ald~imaA='a (assumed tropical:) He made the blood [of men] (lit. bloods) to go for nothing, unretaliated, or uncompensated by mulcts; or to be of no account. (Ham p. 91.) And $adaxotu Ald~iyaAta taHota qadamaY~a (assumed tropical:) I made the bloodwits to be of no account [so that they should not be exacted]. (Ham ibid.) ― -b3- And $adaxahu He hit, or hurt, his mu$ad~ax, i. e. the part of the neck so called. (K.) -A2- And $adaxa aor.
$adaxa , (TA,) inf. n. $adoxN (K, TA) and $uduwxN, (TA,) He, (a man, TK,) or it, (a thing, or an affair, TA,) deviated, or declined, (K, TA,) from the right course, aim, or scope, (TA,) or from the [proper] way. (AO, TA.) ― -b2- $adaxati Algur~apu, (S, TA,) aor.
$adaxa , (TA,) inf. n. $adoxN (K, TA) and $uduwxN, (TA,) The blaze on the horse's forehead spread widely upon the face (S) [from the forelock to the nose, without reaching to the eyes: see $aAdixapN]: or spread, and extended downwards, (K, TA,) filling the forehead, without reaching
to the eyes: or covered the face from the root of the forelock to the nose. (TA.)

2 $ad~axotu Alr~uw^uwsa *
I broke, or crushed, the heads; or did so much: the verb is with teshdeed to denote muchness, or frequency, or application to many objects. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [And $d~x Albusora He pressed, or squeezed, the unripe dates, so as to crush them: see mu$ad~axN.]
5 ta$ad~axa see what next follows.

7 An$dx *
It was, or became, broken, or crushed; (S, A, Msb, K, TA;) said of a hollow thing, (S, A, TA,) or a soft, or tender, or an easily-broken thing, (A,) or a moist thing, (K,) or a moist and soft thing, (TA,) a person's head, (S, A, Msb, TA,) a colocynth, and an unripe date, (A,) and any hollow bone, and a rod, (Msb,) or, as some say, a dry thing; (K;) and so ↓ t$d~x [but app. implying muchness, or frequency, or relation to many things, as quasi-pass. of 2, q. v., whereas the former verb is quasi-pass. of 1]: (K:) or it was, or became, pressed or squeezed [app. so as to be crushed; or it was, or became, crushed by being pressed or squeezed: see mu$ad~axN]. (A.)

$adaxN *
An abortive fœtus, (L, K, TA,) in a soft, or tender, state, before it has become firm. (L, TA.) ― -b2- See also $aAdixN, in two places.
$adoxapN * A soft, or tender, or succulent, plant: (K:) applied in the M as an epithet to the species of plant called Eijolap. (TA.)

$aAdixN * A child that is soft, or tender; (K;) as also ↓ $adaxN: (IAar, L:) or gulaAmN $aAdixN signifies a youth: (A:) accord. to IAar, a boy is called jaforN; then, yaAfiEN; then, ↓ $adaxN; then, muTab~ixN; and then, kawokabN. (TA. [See also muTab~ixN.]) -A2- Also A thing, or an affair, deviating from the right course, aim, or scope, (K, TA,) or from its [proper] way. (AO, TA.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

$aAdixapN * , [as a subst.,] (S, L, K, TA,) or gur~apN ↓ $aAdixapN, (A,) A blaze on a horse's forehead spreading [widely (see 1)] upon the face, (S,) or covering the face, (A,) from the forelock to the nose, (S, A,) without reaching to the eyes: (S:) or spreading, and extending downwards, (K, TA,) filling the forehead, without reaching to the eyes: or covering the face from the root of the forelock to the nose: (TA:) or such as is long; such as is round being called watiyrapN. (AO, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A notorious, and a bad, or an evil, an abominable, or a foul, deed. (S, TA.) A rájiz says,
laA hum~a A_in~a AlHaAriva bona jabalaho
zan~aY EalaY A^abiyhi vum~a qatalaho
warakiba Al$~aAdixapa AlmuHaj~alaho
i. e. [O God, (laAhum~a being for Aall~`hum~a,) verily El- Hárith Ibn-Jebeleh straitened, or oppressed, his father, (zan~aY being for zan~aA^a,) then slew him,] and committed a bad and notorious deed in slaying him. (S.)
A^a$odaxu * A horse having a blaze such as is termed $aAdixapN: fem. $adoxaA='u. (K, L, TA.) ― -b2- AlA^a$odaxu The lion. (K.)

mu$ad~axN *
Unripe dates pressed, or squeezed, (yugomazu, in some copies of the S and K and in the L and TA yugomaru, [but the former I think to be evidently the right reading,]) until they become broken or crushed (yano$adixu), (S, A, * L, K,) and dried for the winter, (A,) or then dried in the winter. (L.) -A2- Almu$ad~axu i. q. muqaT~aEu AlEunuqi [app. meaning The part of the neck where it is cut up by the butcher]. (K.)
mi$odaAxN * [A post-classical term] A surgical instrument with which the head of the fœtus is crushed [in the womb]. (Albucasis de Chirurgia, p. 342.)
1 $adiqa * , inf. n. $adaqN, said of a man, He was wide in the $idoq [q. v.]. (M, TA. *) ― -b2- And He was eloquent. (TA.)

5 t$d~q *
He twisted his $idoqaAni, [i. e. the two sides of his mouth, or the quivering flesh of his mouth, inside his cheeks,] in order to affect clearness, or distinctness, of speech, or to be more clear, or distinct, in speech. (K.) And t$d~q fiY kalaAmihi He opened his mouth and was diffuse in his speech. (M, TA.)
$adoqN * : see what next follows.

$idoqN * (Lth, S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and ↓ $adoqN (Lth, M, O, Msb, K) The quivering flesh (TafoTafap) of the mouth, inside the two cheeks; (Lth, O, K;) or so the dual of each: (M:) or the side of the mouth; (S, Mgh, Msb;) so says Az: (Msb:) pl. (of the former, S, Msb) A^a$odaAqN (Lth, S, M, O, Msb, K) and (of the latter, Msb, TA) $uduwqN. (M, Msb, TA.) One says, nafaxa fiY $idoqayohi [He blew in the sides of his mouth so as to distend them]. (S.) And A_in~ahu lawaAsiEu AlA^a$odaAqi, meaning [Verily he is wide] in the $idoq; using the pl. as a sing.; a phrase mentioned by Lh. (M, TA.) $idoqaA Alfarasi means The chink of the mouth of the horse, to the extremity thereof at [the place of] the bit [on each side]. (M.) tarokabu $idoqahaA mina Aln~a$aATi [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) She goes at random, (like tarokabu raA^osahaA,) by reason of briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness,] is said of a woman and of a she-camel and of a mare. (K voce miDoraArN.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) The two sides of a valley; as also ↓ $adiyqN: (K:) or the duals, $idoqaAni and $adoqaAni, have this signification; the sings. signify the side of a valley; (O;) or so $idoqN, with kesr; (Msb;) and so ↓ $adiyqN. (O.)

$adaqN * [mentioned above as inf. n. of 1] Wideness of the $idoq: (S, K:) or, as in the T, wideness of the $idoqaAni. (TA.) ― -b2- And Eloquence. (S, * TA.) ― -b3- and (assumed tropical:) A bending, or winding, in a valley. (TA.)

$idaAqN *
A certain brand with which a camel is marked upon the $idoq. (M, TA.)
$adiyqN * : see $idoqN, in two places.
$adoqamN * and $adoqamiY~N: see the next paragraph; the former in three places: and see also art. $dqm.

A^a$odaqu * A man wide in the $idoq: (M:) or a man wide in the $idoqaAni: (Mgh, Msb:) or wide in the $idoq, and inclining therein in any manner: (TA:) fem. $adoqaA='u: (M, K:) and pl. $udoqN: (K:) and ↓ $adoqamN and ↓ $adoqamiY~N signify the same as A^a$odaqu; the m being augmentative, as in fusoHumN and sutohumN; or, accord. to IJ, it is radical: (M, TA:) whence, i. e. from $adoqamN in the sense expl. above, (I 'Ab, TA,) one says also ↓ $idoqN $adoqamN, meaning a wide $dq: (I 'Ab, M, TA:) and $afapN $adoqaA='u means a lip wide in the part where each $idoq is cleft [by the extremity of the mouth]. (M, TA.) ― -b2- It is also applied as an epithet to an orator, (S, M, K, TA,) meaning Eloquent; (M, K, TA;) good and eloquent in speech; (M, * TA;) and so ↓ $adoqamN. (TA.)

muta$ad~iqN * One who twists his $idoqaAni in order to affect clearness, or distinctness, of speech, or to be more clear, or distinct, in speech. (S. [See 5.]) ― -b2- Diffuse in speech, without preparation, or caution, or precaution: or one who ridicules men, twisting his $idoqaAni with them and against them. (TA.) And muta$ad~iqN fiY manoTiqihi Diffuse in his speech. (TA.)

div2.head: Quasi $dqm
div2.entryFree:
$adoqamN *
Wide in the $idoq [or side of the mouth]; (S, K;) applied to a man; as also ↓ $adoqamiY~N; (TA;) and ↓ $udaAqimN: (K, TA:) [mentioned under this head in the S and K, but] the m is augmentative. (Az, S.) It has been erroneously said that it is with the pointed *. (MF.) ― -b2- See also A^a$odaqu. ― -b3- Also The lion; (K;) and so ↓ $udaAqimN. (IB, TA.) ― -b4- And A certain stallion-camel belonging to En-Noamán Ibn-El-Mundhir: whence ↓ $adoqimiy~aAtN Certain camels, so called in relation to that stallion. (S, K.)
$adoqamiY~N * : and $adoqamiy~aAtN: see the preceding paragraph.
$udaAqimN * : see the first paragraph, in two places.

1 $adana * , (S, K,) aor.
$aduna , (S,) inf. n. $uduwnN, (S, K,) said of a gazelle, and of the young of any cloven-hoofed animal, and camel, and solid-hoofed animal, He became strong, and in no need of his mother: (K:) or he became strong, and in a good state of body, and active and grown up, and vied with his mother in his faculties [so I render
maAlaka A^um~ahu of which I do not find any explanation] so that he went along with her; and [in this sense] it is said of a colt also: (TA:) or, said of a young gazelle, he became strong, and his horns came forth, and he became in no need of his mother: and sometimes it is said of a colt [in a similar sense]. (S.) Hence, it is said of a boy, meaning He became strong, and active and grown up. (Har p. 536.)

4 A$dnt *
She (a gazelle) had a young one that had become such as is termed $aAdin. (S, K.)

$adonN *
A kind of tree, (K, TA,) having weak, or soft, and thick stems, (TA,) the flower of which is like the jasmine (K, TA) in form, but tinged with redness, and more pleasant [in odour] than the jasmine; said by IB to be of pleasant odour. (TA.)

$adaniy~aAtN *
Certain she-camels, so called in relation to a place in El-Yemen, (S, K, and EM p. 229,) named $adan: (TA, EM:) or in relation to a certain stallion. (IAar, K, TA. [In the CK, faHolN is erroneously put for faHolK.])

$aAdinN * A young gazelle that has become strong, and whose horns have come forth, and that has become in no need of his mother: (A 'Obeyd, TA: [see $aSarN:]) when used alone, [not as an epithet, in which quality it seems to be applied also to the young of any cloven-hoofed animal, and camel, and solid-hoofed animal, (see 1,)] it means [simply] a young gazelle. (S, TA.)

mu$odinN * [without p] A doe-gazelle whose young one has become such as is termed $aAdin: (S, K, TA:) or who has a $aAdin following her: and in like manner applied to other animals of the clovenhoofed kind, and of the solid-hoofed, and to a camel: (TA:) pl. ma$aAdinu and ma$aAdiynu, (S, K,) like maTaAfilu and maTaAfiylu, (S,) [pls. of muTofilN,] the latter pl. anomalous. (TA.)
ma$oduwnapN * , applied to a girl, i. q. EaAtiqN [i. e. That has newly attained to puberty, and has not been married; or that is between the periods of puberty and middle age; &c.]. (IAar, K.)

1 $udiha * , (JK, S, K,) inf. n. $adohN, (S,) He (a man, JK, S) became confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; or became bereft of his reason or intellect; i. q. duhi$a: (JK, S, K:) and also, (K,) or, accord. to AZ, only, (S,) he was, or became, busied, occupied, or employed; or busied, &c., so as to be diverted from something; or diverted from a thing by being busied; syn. $ugila: (S, K:) and he was caused to become confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; (K;) as also ↓ An$dh, or ↓ A$tdh, (K, accord. to different copies: the former accord. to the TA.) Accord. to Az, $adohN is not from Ald~aha$u, as it is thought to be by some [and as is implied by what here follows]. (TA.) ― -b2- $adahahu He confounded, or perplexed, him, so that he was unable to see his right course; or bereft him of his reason or intellect; syn. A^adoha$ahu; (K;) as also ↓ A$dhhu: (A 'Obeyd, K:) or the former verb, in the act. form, has not been heard: (Har p. 64:) and [it is asserted that] one does not say ↓ A$dhhu. (JK.) -A2- $adaha raA^osahu i. q. $adaxahu [i. e. He broke his head]. (K.)
4 A^a$odaha see the preceding paragraph, in two places.
7 A_ino$adaha and 8: see 1, first sentence.
$adohN * : see what next follows.

$udohN * (S, K) and ↓ $adahN (S, and so in some copies of the K and in the TA) and ↓ $adohN (so in some copies of the K in the place of the second, and in others together with the second, and in the TA) [app. A state of confusion, or perplexity, so that one is unable to see his right course; or a state of alienation of mind;] substs. from $udiha: (S: [but in the K they are mentioned after $adahahu and A^a$odahahu meaning A^adoha$ahu, and ma$aAdihu meaning ma$aAgilu, as being the substs.; so that they may signify as above, and also business, occupation, or employment, &c.; agreeably with renderings in the TK:]) and ↓ $udaAhN is a subst. from $udiha [app. in the former, or in both, of these senses]. $a*i3a and
$a*u3a , inf. n. $u*uw*N and $a*~N, also signifies (tropical:) It (a word, form or measure, construction, or government,) deviated from the common, or constant, course of speech in respect of analogy, or rule; deviated from common, or constant, analogy, or rule; was extraordinary, or exceptional, as to rule; or was anomalous, abnormal, or irregular: and it (the same) deviated from the common, or constant, course of speech in respect of usage; deviated from common, or constant, usage; was extraordinary, or exceptional, as to usage; or was unusual: [the verb is used absolutely to express each of these meanings; the context in general showing clearly which meaning is intended: the former is that which is most frequently intended: and] the former meaning is also expressed by the phrase $a*~a fiY AlqiyaAsi or Eani AlqiyaAsi: and the latter, by the phrase $a*~a fiY AlAisotiEomaAli. (Mz, 12th nwE.) [See also the contr. AiT~arada: and see $aA*~N, below.] -A2- See also 4.

$a*u3a , only; (M, K;) but As disallows this last form of the verb; (IJ, L;) He, or it, caused it to be, or to become, apart, (S, L,) to fall, or go, or come, out, or forth, from the generality of things, or the general assemblage, main body, bulk, or common mass, (S, M, L, K,) to which it pertained: (M, L:) and the first signifies he removed it, and put it far away; namely, a thing: (K:) and he set him, or exposed him, apart from his companions, or alone: (IJ, L:) and he scattered, or dispersed, it. faA^a$a*~aniY limuruwrihimo fakaA^an~aniY

$aA*~N * A thing that is, or becomes, apart, (S, L, Msb,) and that falls, or goes, or comes, out, or forth, from the generality of things, general assemblage, main body, bulk, or common mass, (S, L,) to which it pertains: (L:) anything apart, or alone: and a man apart from his companions, or alone: (Lth, L:) and [app. a beast] taking fright, and running away: (Msb:) $u*~aAnN is a pl. thereof, like as $ub~aAnN is of $aAb~N; [and so is $u*~aA*N, agreeably with analogy;] and ↓ $a*~aAn is used in a similar sense, but is an epithet of the measure fiEolaAn, not a pl. of $aA*~N. (L.) maA yadaEu fulaAnN $aA*~FA walaA naAd~FA A_il~aA qatalahu [Such a one does not leave any one apart from his companions, nor any one taking fright and running away, but he slays him,] is said of a courageous man whom no one encounters without his slaying him. (IAar, L.) And one says $u*~aAnu qawomK Those, of a people, who have become apart, or separate, from their companions. (L, from a trad.) And $u*~aA*u Aln~aAsi Those who are among a people but do not belong to their tribes (S, L) nor to their places of abode: (L:) and those who are scattered, or dispersed, of people; (A, L;) as also Aln~aAsi ↓ $a*~aAnu, (S, L,) and $u*~aAnuhumo. (L.) And qawomN $u*~aA*N A people not among their own tribe nor in their own places of abode: (L, K: *) or a people among another people, not among their own tribes nor in their own places of abode. (M, TA.) And $u*~aA*u AlA=faAqi The strangers. (Har p. 352.) And jaAw^uwA $u*~aA*FA They came few in number. (L, K. *) And AlA_ibili ↓ $a*~aAnu and $u*~aAnuhaA Those that are scattered, or dispersed, of the camels. (L.) And $u*~aAnu AlHaSaY (M, L) and AlHaSaY ↓ $a*~aAnu (S, IJ, M, L, K) What are scatterred, or dispersed, of pebbles; (S, L, K;) what have flown about, and become scattered or dispersed, thereof: (M, L:) and in like manner one says of other things, (L, K,) or of similar things. (M, L.) ― -b2- Applied to a word, form or measure, construction, or government, it signifies (tropical:) Deviating from the common, or constant, course of speech in respect of analogy, or rule; deviating from common, or constant, analogy or rule; extraordinary, or exceptional, as to rule; or anomalous, abnormal, or irregular: such a word, &c., though itself admitted if agreeable with common usage, is not taken as an example to be imitated: also, applied to the same, deviating from the common, or constant, course of speech in respect of usage; deviating from common, or constant, usage; extraordinary, or exceptional, as to usage; unusual: [used absolutely to express each of these significations; the context in general showing clearly which signification is meant: the former is that which is most frequently intended:] a word, &c., may be $A*~ in respect of usage but agreeable with common analogy or rule; as the pret. of ya*aru and yadaEu; and the regular phrase makaAnN muboqilN, the epithet more commonly heard being baAqilN: and $A*~ in respect of analogy, or rule, but agreeable with common usage; as A^axowaSa Alr~imovu, and AisotaSowabotu AlA^amora: and $A*~ in respect of analogy, or rule, and of usage, together; as vawobN maSowuwnN, and misokN madowuwfN: (Mz, 12th nwE: [and the like is said, but less fully, in the Msb:]) the pl. masc. is $u*~aA*N; and pl. fem. $awaA*~u. (Mz, ib.) See 4, last sentence. [See also the contr. muT~aridN: and see $a*~a, latter part.] ― -b3- Applied to a tradition, (assumed tropical:) Having a single ascription, attested by a [single] sheykh, whether he be trustworthy or not: in the latter case, not accepted: in the former case, one hesitates respecting it, and does not adduce it as an argument, or evidence. (KT.)

1 $a*aba * , aor.
$a*iba and
$a*uba , (K,) inf. n. $a*obN, (TA,) He stripped off, or removed, the bark of a tree; as also ↓ $*~b, inf. n. ta$o*iybN: (K:) he cut off portions of a tree, or the bark thereof. (TA.) He cut, or cut off, a thing; (O, K;) aor.
$a*iba , inf. n. $a*obN. (O.) He cut, or lopped, a tree: or he divested it of its bark. (A.) He pruned, or pared, a tree by cutting off its $a*ab, i. e. its straggling branches, or its thorns, or its bark; aor.
$a*iba , inf. n. $a*obN; and ↓ $*~b has the like meaning, but importing muchness, or relation to many objects: and $a*aba also signifies he trimmed, or cleared, anything by removing another thing from it: (Msb:) or he pruned a tree by lopping off its branches so that it became apparent: (K, TA:) and he pruned a palm-tree by cutting off from it its $a*ab, meaning its branches: (TA:) and [in like manner] ↓ $*~b, (S, TA,) inf. n. ta$o*iybN, (S, K, TA,) he pruned a tree by cutting off its $a*ab, meaning its straggling branches not in the choice, or best, part thereof: (S:) or he trimmed a palm-trunk (K, TA) by lopping off the stumps of the branches: (TA:) Alr~ayaAHiyni ↓ ta$o*iybu [likewise] signifies the pruning, or cutting off, the superfluous portions of the straggling extremities of the sprigs of sweet-smelling plants: (Mgh:) and $u*iba Eanohu, said of anything, signifies it was removed from it, namely, another thing. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 2, in two places.

$a*iba , inf. n. $a*obN: (Sh, TA:) and Eanohu ↓ $a*aba he repelled from him, or defended him. Pieces, or cuttings, of trees; (As, A 'Obeyd, K;) n. un. with p: (As, A 'Obeyd:) or bark of trees: (K:) pieces of bark, and pieces of wood, or sticks, or twigs or branches, in a dispersed, or scattered, state; (O, K;) pl. tafar~aquwA $a*ara ma*ara * , and $i*ara mi*ara, They [dispersed, or became dispersed, or] went, or went away, in every direction: (S, L, K:) it is not said of a people coming: (L:) the m in m*r is sometimes changed into b; or, accord. to some, b*r is the original, being from Alt~abo*iyru; but MF thinks that m*r is the original, as it is only an imitative sequent, in which no regard is had to the meaning of “ dispersion. ” (TA.)

A [garment of the kind called] miloHafap: an arabicized word; (S, K;) from the Pers. jaAdaro [or JaAdaro or JaAdiro]. (S.) And i. q. A_itobN; (A, K, TA;) i. e. A [garment of the kind called] burod, which is slit [in the middle], and worn by a woman, who throws it upon her neck, [putting her head through the slit;] having neither sleeves nor an opening at the bosom: (TA:) or [a garment] like the SidaAr, [which is said by some to be the same as the A_itob,] worn by a young woman: (Har p. 55:) a garment which a woman wears beneath her vawob: (Fr:) a certain garment which a woman and a girl wear, extending to the extremity of the upper half of the arm. (Lth.) [The modern JAdr of Persia and El-'Irák seems to be generally what is commonly called in Egypt a “ miláyeh, ” correctly “ muláäh ” (mulaA='ap), figured and described in my work on the Modern Egyptians: or, in some instances, a similar covering of plain white, or dark blue, cotton; the former of which is now called in Egypt an “ izár. ” (See Dozy's “ Dict. des Noms des Vêtements chez les Arabes, ” pp. 216-219.)]

(TA.) ― -b2- Dog-flies; (S, K;) which also sometimes light upon the camel: (S:) or flies in general: (K:) or large blue flies that light upon beasts, and annoy, or molest, or hurt, them: (TA:) n. un. ↓ $a*aApN. (S. [It is said in the Msb that $a*FA, of which the n. un. is $a*aApN, is also with kesr (i. e. ↓ $i*FA); but in what sense is not specified.]) One says of him who is vehemently hungry, Darima $a*aAhu [lit. His flies have become vehemently hungry, or burning with hunger]. (S.) ― -b3- And [app. because of the annoyance that it occasions,] Mange, or scab: (ISd, K:) and so $adFA. (K in art. $dw.) ― -b4- And [app.
because of its pungency,] Salt: (S, K:) said in the M to be pl. [but properly coll. gen. n.] of ↓ $a*aApN, which signifies a piece of salt. (TA.) ― -b5- See also $a*owN. ― -b6- Also Fragments of aloes-wood (S, * K, * TA) with which one perfumes himself. (TA. [The same is also indicated in the S.]) ― -b7- And Sharpness, (S,) or strength, (Fr, T, K,) of pungency of odour; (Fr, T, S, K;) accord. to the M, of sweet odour. (TA.) ― -b8- See also $a*aApN. ― -b9- Also The extremity of anything: (TA:) and so $adFA. (K and TA in art. $dw.) -A2- And A sort of trees, (S, K,) used for masaAwiyk [i. e. sticks with which the teeth are cleansed], (K,) growing in the Saráh (Als~araAp) and having gum. (TA.) -A3- And A sort of ships or boats: (Lth, S, K:) n. un. ↓ $a*aApN: (Lth, S:) [or] ↓ $a*aAwapN signifies one of a sort of small ships, or boats, like those called zabaAzibu [pl. of zabozabN]: and its pl. is $a*aAwaAtN. (Msb.)
$i*FA * : see the next preceding paragraph.

$a*owN * , so accord. to the K, but written in copies of the M with kesr [i. e. ↓ $i*owN], (TA,) Musk; (IAar, K, TA;) as also ↓ $a*FA: (IJ, TA:) or the odour thereof: (As, T, Sgh, K:) or the colour thereof. (K.)
$i*owN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

$a*aApN * : see $a*FA, in three places. ― -b2- Also Sharpness. (TA.) ― -b3- And Strength, and boldness, of a man. (Lth, TA.) ― -b4- [Or] A remnant of strength: (S, K:) pl. $a*awaAtN (TA) and [coll. gen. n.] ↓ $a*FA. (S, * TA. [See also $adFA, in art. $dw.]) -A2- As an epithet applied to a man, (TA,) Evil in disposition, (K, TA,) sharp in temperament, that annoys, or molests, or hurts, by his evil, or mischief: in some of the copies of the K, Al$~aYo'u Alxalaqu is erroneously put for Als~aY~i'u Alxuluqi. (TA.) -A3- See again $a*FA, last sentence.
$a*aAwapN * : see $a*FA, last sentence.

1 $ar~a * , (L, K,) sec. pers. $arirota, (S, Msb, K, MF,) aor. ya$ar~u; (L, Msb, MF;) and sec. pers. $arurota, (S accord. to some copies, L, Msb, K, MF,) aor. ya$ur~u; (L, Msb, K, * MF;) and sec. pers. $ararota, (S accord. to some copies, M, K, MF,) aor. ya$ir~u; (M, K, MF;) of which three vars. the first is the best known; and the last is strange, and disallowed by most authorities; (MF;) inf. n. [of the first or third] $ar~N (S, K) and [of the first] $ararN (S) and [of the second or third] $araArapN, (S, K,) and $ir~apN also is an inf. n. [syn. with $ar~N]; (S;) He (a man) was, or became, evil, a wrongdoer, unjust, bad, corrupt, wicked, mischievous, vitious, or depraved. (S, * L, Msb, K, * &c.) The manner in which the K mentions $ar~a with the two aors. ya$ur~u and ya$ir~u [only, omitting the most common aor., i. e. ya$ar~u,] obviously demands consideration. (MF.) One says, $arirota yaA rajulu [Thou hast been evil, or a wrongdoer, &c., O man], (S, K,) and so $arurota and $ararota. (S accord. to different copies, and K.) ― -b2- $ar~a, aor. ya$ar~u, also signifies He increased in evil, wrongdoing, &c. (L.) It is said in a prov., kul~amaA takobaru ta$ar~u [In proportion as thou growest old, thou increasest in evil, &c.]. (AZ, L.) ― -b3- maA $ar~ahu: see 4, last sentence. -A2- $ar~ahu, (O, K,) aor. ya$ur~u, (O, TA,) inf. n. $ur~N, (O, K,) with damm, (K, [which is said in the TA to indicate that the aor., not the inf. n., is with damm, but this is inconsistent with the common practice of the author of the K, and is evidently wrong,]) He blamed him; found fault with him; attributed or imputed to him, charged him with, or accused him of, a vice, fault, defect, blemish, or something amiss. (O, K, * TA. [See also 4.]) One says, maA qulotu *aAka li$ur~ika waA_in~amaA qulotupu ligayori $ur~ika I said not that to find fault with thee, but I only said it for a different purpose than that of finding fault with thee: (S, TA:) or this has a different meaning, which see below, voce $ur~N. (TA.) One says also, qado qabilotu EaTiy~ataka vum~a radadotuhaA Ealayoka mino gayori $ur~ika walaA Dur~ika, meaning [I have accepted thy gift; then I have given it back to thee] without rejecting it to thee or blaming thee [and without injuring thee]. (IAar, TA.) -A3- Also $ar~ahu, (S,) or $ar~ahu fiY Al$~amosi, (A,) [aor. and inf. n. as in the next sentence;] and ↓ $r~rhu, (A,) inf. n. ta$oriyrN; (S;) and ↓ A$r~hu; and ↓ $aro$arahu; (A;) He spread it (i. e. a garment, or piece of cloth, S, or some other thing, TA) in the sun: (S, A, TA:) this is the primary signification. (TA.) And [hence,] $ar~ahu, (S, K,) aor. ya$ur~u. (S,) inf. n. $ar~N; (S, K;) and ↓ A$r~hu, (K,) inf. n. A_i$oraArN; (TA;) and ↓ $r~rhu, (K,) inf. n. as above; (TA;) and $ar~aAhu [or $araAhu without tesh-deed?]; (K;) He put it (i. e. [the preparation of curd called] A^aqoT, and flesh-meat, S, K, and the like, and salt, S, and a garment, or piece of cloth, and the like, K) upon a xaSafap, (S, K,) i. e. a mat, (TA,) or some other thing, (K,) to dry. (S, K.) And $r~hu He sprinkled it; namely, salt. (R, MF.)
2 $r~rhu * inf. n. ta$oriyrN, He rendered him notorious, or infamous, among men. (Yz, K.) -A2- See also 1, latter part, in two places.

3 $Ar~hu * , (K,) inf. n. mu$aAr~apN, (S,) He acted with him in an evil manner; (K;) he treated him with enmity, or hostility: (L, TA:) he contended, or disputed, with him: (S, L, TA:) he did evil to him, obliging him to do the like in return. (L, TA.) [See also 3 in art. $rY: and see an ex. voce jaAr~a.]

4 A$r~hu *
He attributed, or imputed, to him evil, wrongdoing, injustice, or the like: (S, K:) but some disallow this. (S. [See also 1.]) ― -b2- A^a$ar~uwhu They banished him, or drove him away, and caused him to be alone. (TA.) -A2- See also 1, latter part, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] A$r~hu signifies also (tropical:) He manifested it, revealed it, published it, or made it known. (S, A, K.) Thus in a verse of Imra-el-Keys, where he says, lawo yu$ir~uwna maqotaliY (assumed tropical:) [that they might publish, or make known, my slaughter]; as related by As; but it is better with s. (S.) -A3- maA A^a$ar~ahu, and ↓ maA $ar~ahu, [the latter of which is extr. with respect to form, but more commonly used than the former, meaning How evil, wrongdoing, unjust, bad, corrupt, wicked, mischievous, vitious, or depraved, is he!] phrases similar to maA A^axoyarahu and maA xayorahu [which have the contr. meaning]. (TA in art. xyr.)
8 A$tr~ * , said of a camel, [and of any clovenhoofed animal,] i. q. Ajtr~, i. e. He ruminated, or chewed the cud: j and $ being from one place of utterance. (IAth, TA.)

10 Ast$r~ *
He became possessor of a great herd, such as is termed A_i$oraArap, of camels. (K.)

R. Q. 1 $aro$arahu * , (A 'Obeyd, K,) inf. n. $aro$arapN, (S,) He split it, or clave it: (A 'Obeyd, S:) and cut it much, or in many pieces. (A 'Obeyd, S, K.) ― -b2- He bit it, and then shook it; namely, a thing. (O, K, TA. [In the CK, naqaDahu is erroneously put for nafaDahu.]) ― -b3- $aro$aratohu AlHay~apu The serpent bit him. (L, K. *) ― -b4- $r$rt AlmaA$iyapu Aln~abaAta The cattle ate the herbage. (K.) ― -b5- $r$r Als~ik~iyna He sharpened, (K,) or rubbed, (O,) the knife upon a stone, (O, K, TA,) so that its edge became rough. (O, TA.) ― -b6- See also 1, latter part. -A2- $aro$ara, inf. n. as above, It (a bird) expanded and flapped its wings, without alighting; like raforafa. (TA in art. fr$.)

R. Q. 2 ta$aro$ara *
It became separated, or scattered. (A.)

$ar~N * (S, A, Msb, K, &c.) and ↓ $ur~N, (Kr, K,) the former of which is the more chaste, (TA,) and ↓ $ir~apN (Ham p. 629) Evil, [moral and physical;] (L, Msb;) wrongdoing, injustice, badness, corruptness, wickedness, mischievousness, vitiousness, or depravity: (Msb:) [and evil fortune, misfortune, woe, or unhappiness:] contr. of xayorN: (S, A, K:) pl. $uruwrN. (Msb, K.) It is said in a trad., in a form of prayer, (TA,) used by the Prophet, (Msb,) waAlxayoru kul~uhu biyadayoka waAl$~ar~u layosa A_ilayoka, (Msb, * TA,) meaning [And all good is in thy hands, and evil i. e.] wrongdoing, or injustice, or corruptness, is not imputable to Thee: (Msb, TA:) or evil is not a means of advancement in thy favour, or of obtaining thine approval: or evil speech does not ascend to Thee. (Nh, L.) ― -b2- $ar~N also signifies (assumed tropical:) Poverty. (K.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) Fever. (K.) ― -b4- It is also an epithet, applied to a man, (Yoo, S,) and so is ↓ $ariyrN, (Akh, S, A, Msb, K,) meaning Evil, wrongdoing, unjust, bad, corrupt, wicked, mischievous, vitious, or depraved: (Yoo, * Akh, * S, * A, * Msb, K: *) [fem. of the former $ar~apN, like as xayorapN is fem. of its contr. xayorN; and $ur~aY, fem. of A^a$ar~u, is used in the same sense, as will be shown in what follows:] the pl. of $ar~N, (Yoo, S,) or of ↓ $ariyrN, (Akh, S, Msb, K,) is A^a$oraArN, (Yoo, Akh, S, Msb, K,) and of the former $iraArN; (Ham p. 514;) and you say qawomN A^a$ir~aA='u [pl. of $ar~N or of ↓ $ariyrN]. (S.) A woman of the Arabs, (S, L,) who, accord. to some, was of the Benoo-'Ámir, (L,) is related to have said, ↓ A^uEiy*uki biA@ll~`hi mino nafosK Har~aY waEayonK $ur~aY, meaning [I charm thee by invoking God, against
a thirsty soul, and] an evil, or a malignant, eye: (S, L:) or an eye that looks at one with vehement hatred. (TA.) And Al$~ar~u [The evil one] is an appellation of Iblees. (K.) ― -b5- [It is also used to denote the comparative and superlative degrees; like the contr. xayorN.] You say, huwa $ar~N minoka [He is worse, or more evil or wrongdoing &c., than thou]. (K.) And h`*aA $ar~N mino *aAka [This is worse, &c., than that]. (Msb.) And fulaAnN $ar~u Aln~aAsi [Such a one is the worst, &c., of mankind]; (S;) and ↓ A^a$ar~u; (S, Msb, K;) this latter being the original, (Mgh, Msb,) but rare, (K,) or bad, (S, K,) peculiar to the dial. of the Benoo-'Ámir, (Msb,) or unused. (Mgh.) The fem. [of $ar~N] is $ar~apN, [like as the fem. of its contr., xayorN, is xayorapN,] (K,) and (of A^a$ar~u, S, * or of $ar~N, which is used for A^a$ar~u, Kr) ↓ $ur~aY. (S, Kr, K.) And [using the dim. form of $ar~N,] you say, minoka ↓ huwa $urayorN [He is a little worse, &c., than thou]. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA in art. xyr. [See xayorN.]) -A2- maA $ar~a for maA A^a$ar~a: see 4.

$ur~N *
A vice, fault, defect, blemish, or something amiss: (TA:) a thing disapproved, disliked, or hated. (K, TA.) You say, maA radadotu h`*aA Ealayoka mino $ur~K bihi I did not give this back to thee on account of any fault &c., in it, but I preferred to give it to thee. (TA.) And maA qulotu *aAka li$ur~ika I said not that on account of a thing that thou disapprovest, &c.: (K, TA:) or this has a different meaning, expl. above in the first paragraph. (TA.) ― -b2- See also $ar~N, first sentence.

$ir~apN * : see $ar~N, first sentence. ― -b2- Also The inordinate desire, or eagerness, (S,) and sprightliness, of youth: (S, K:) and in an absolute sense, inordinate desire, or eagerness; and [simply] desire; and sprightliness: (TA:) [and] sharpness, and angriness. (Har p. 35.) It is said in a trad., A_in~a lih`*aA AlquroA=ni $ir~apF vum~a A_in~a liln~aAsi Eanohu fatorapF [Verily there is an eagerness for this Kur-án: then men have a weariness of it]. (L.)
$ararN * ; n. un. with p: see what next follows.

$araArN * , (S, A, O, Msb, TA,) accord. to the K $iraArN, but this is a mistake, (MF,) and ↓ $ararN, (S, A, O, Msb, K,) which is a contraction of $araArN, (Msb,) Sparks of fire: (S, O, Msb, K:) n. un. of each with p. (S, A, O, Msb, * K.) See an ex. voce $ar~aArN.

$ariyrN * : see $ar~N, in three places. -A2- Also The side of the sea, or of a great river; (AHn, K;) the shore thereof: (Kr, TA:) or the part that is near to a sea or great river: pl. A^a$ir~apN: (AA, TA:) which signifies also seas or great rivers [themselves]. (TA.) ― -b2- And (as some say, TA) A kind of tree that grows in the sea, or in a great river. (K, TA.)
$urayorN * dim. of $ar~N: see the latter, last sentence but one.

$ariyrapN *
A [large needle such as is termed] misal~ap (K, TA) of iron. (TA.)
$ir~aArN * [Emitting many sparks]. One says, A^abuwka ↓ naArN $ar~aArapN waA^atota minohaA $araArapN [Thy father is a fire that emits many sparks, and thou art a spark from it]. (A.)

$ar~aAnN *
Certain insects (K) resembling baEuwD [or gnats], (S, K,) which cover the face of a man, but do not bite; sometimes called AlA^a*aY: (S:) of the dial. of the people of Es-Sawád: (T, TA:) [it is with tenween; for] the n. un. is with p. (K.)
$ir~iyrN * (S, A, K) Abounding in $ar~ [or evil or wrongdoing &c.; very evil &c.]; applied to a man: (S, A:) pl. $ir~iyruwna (K) and A^a$oraArN, which latter is anomalous. (Ham. p. 699.)

$aro$arN * , (IAar, S, K,) or (so in the S, but in the K “ and ”) ↓ $iro$irN, (Ibn-Ziyád, S, K,) A certain plant, (S, K,) which extends along the ground like ropes, (Ibn-Ziyád, AHn, K,) in the same manner as the quTob, but having no thorns that hurt any one: (Ibn-Ziyád, AHn:) Az says that it is a well-known plant, seen by him in the desert; that it fattens the camels, and makes their milk plentiful; and that it is mentioned by IAar and others among the plants of the desert: ↓ $iro$irapN is expl. in the K as though it were the name of another plant; but it is not so; for $iro$irN is the pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] thereof: it is a herb smaller than the Earofaj, having a yellow flower, and twigs, or shoots, and large dust-coloured leaves: it grows in plain, or soft, ground; and spreads wide, as though it were ropes, by reason of length, of the measure of a man in a standing posture; and has berries (Hab~), like those of the haraAs. (TA.) -A2- $iwaA='N $aro$arN Roasted flesh-meat, of which the grease, or gravy, drips; (S, K;) like $alo$alN and ra$oraA$N. (TA.)
$iro$irN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

$aro$arapN * , ('Ináyeh, and so in some copies of the K,) or ↓ $uro$urapN, (so in other copies of the K, accord. to the TA,) sing. of $araA$iru, (K,) which signifies The fringe-like extremities of a tail; (S, * K, * A, TA;) and of wings. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, metaphorically, [or synecdochically,] the pl. is used as signifying (tropical:) The whole: and hence the saying, A^aloqaY Ealayohi $araA$irahu (tropical:) He betook himself altogether to it; as though, says As, by reason of his eagerness, he threw himself altogether upon it: accord. to EshShiháb, it means he betook himself [to it], openly or secretly: or $araA$iru signifies (assumed tropical:) the whole body; (K;) and AlqY Elyh $rA$rh and A^ajoraAnahu and A^ajoraAmahu, provs. mentioned by Meyd, all signify the same [app. (assumed tropical:) he threw upon it the weight of his body: see Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 409 and 410: and see art. jrm]: or the first of these means (assumed tropical:) he loved it so that he courted death, or destruction, (Aisotaholaka,) in his love of it: (TA:) or he loved it with a love that he would not give up, because of his necessity: (Lth, TA:) or (tropical:) he desired it inordinately, or eagerly, and loved it. (A.) [See also A^aloqaY Ealayohi A^arowaAqahu, voce rawoqN. Accord. to different authorities,] $araA$iru also signifies (assumed tropical:) Burdens, or weights; (S, K;) sing. $aro$arapN: (S:) and it is so expl. as used in the saying mentioned above: or it there signifies (assumed tropical:) weight, and whole person: or the reduplication implies intensiveness; as though this word originally signified weight of evil: but F, in his comments on the Preface of the Ksh, objects to this, as the word does not imply the contr. of xayorN, but dispersion. (TA.) Also (tropical:) Self: (K, TA:) and the saying mentioned above is expl. as meaning (tropical:) He threw himself upon it, through inordinate, or eager, desire, and love. (S, TA.) And (assumed tropical:) Love: (K:) or (assumed tropical:) love of self. (Kr, TA.)
$uro$urapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

$iro$irapN *
A piece of anything. (K.) -A2- See also $aro$arN.

$uro$uwrN *
A certain bird, (K, TA,) of small size; said by As to be thus called by the people of El- Hijáz; and by the Arabs of the desert, baroqa$ [a mistranscription for biroqi$]: it is said to be dustcoloured; in elegance, like the Hum~arap; and to be a little larger than the EuSofuwr [or sparrow]. (L, TA.) [Freytag, on the authority of Dmr, says that it is the same as is called Abw brAq$: (but see biroqi$N:) and describes it as being of an ashy colour, with some mixture of redness; and of the passerine kind.]
A^a$ar~u * ; and its fem., $ur~aY: see $ar~N, latter half, in three places. ― -b2- $ur~aY is also applied to a woman as meaning A great imputer of vices, faults, or the like, to others. (AA, L.)

A_i$oraArapN *
A xaSafap, (S, K,) i. e. mat, (TA,) upon which [the preparation of curd called] A^aqiT (S, K) and other things (S) are spread (S, K *) to dry; (TA;) [as also ↓ ma$ar~u or ↓ mi$ar~N, as written in different copies of the S voce Eabavat:] or a piece of cloth, of those whereof a tent is composed, used for that purpose: (TA:) or a tablet of stone or wood, upon which flesh-meat is dried: (Lth, IAar:) pl. A^a$aAriyru: or this pl. signifies pieces of flesh-meat cut into strips and dried: (S:) or the sing. signifies also flesh-meat cut into strips and dried. (K, TA.) -A2- Also A great herd of camels: (K:) because scattered. (TA.)
ma$ar~N * or mi$ar~N: see the next preceding paragraph.

Almu$aro$iru *
The lion: (Sgh, K:) from Al$~aro$arapu “ the biting ” a thing “ and then shaking ” it. (Sgh, TA.)

1 $ariba * , (S, A, K, &c.,) aor.
$araba , (A, K,) inf. n. $urobN and $arobN (S, A, Msb, K, &c.) and $irobN, (S, A, K,) agreeably with three different readings of the Kur lvi. 55, (S, TA,) the first of which (with damm) is that generally obtaining, (Fr, TA,) and is the only one admitted by Jaafar Ibn-Mohammad, notwithstanding which the second form (with fet-h) is said by MF to be the most chaste as well as the most agreeable with analogy, (TA,) or the second (with fet-h) is an inf. n., and the first is a simple subst., (AO, S, Msb, K,) and so is the third, (AO, S, K,) and ma$orabN, (S, K,) which is
also a n. of place [and of time], (S,) and ta$oraAbN, (S K, TA,) a form used when muchness of the act is meant, (TA,) and ti$oraAbN, which is anomalous, (TA voce bay~ana, q. v.,) He drank, (KL, PS, TK,) or he swallowed, syn. jariEa, (A, K, [but the former meaning is evidently intended by this explanation, and such I shall assume to be the case in giving the explanations of the derivatives in the A and K. &c.,]) water, &c., (S,) or a liquid, properly by sucking in, or sipping; and otherwise tropically; (Msb;) [generally, gulping it; for] you say, $ariba AlmaA='a fiY kar~apK [He drank the water at once, or at a single draught]; and fiY ↓ t$r~bhu muholapK [He drank it leisurely, or gently, or slowly]: (Mgh:) $urobN signifies the conveying to one's inside, by means of his mouth, that in the case of which chewing is not practicable: (KT:) [but] Es-Sarakustee says, one does not say of a bird $ariba AlmaA='a, but HasaAhu. (Msb.) In the saying of Aboo-Dhu-eyb, describing clouds,
$aribona bimaA='i AlbaHori vum~a taraf~aEato
[which is evidently best rendered They drank of the water of the sea, then rose aloft, agreeably with what has been stated respecting bi in the sense of mino in p. 143, it is said that] the b is redundant, or, as rawiyna is rendered trans. by means of bi, [though I do not think that this is the case unless bi be used as meaning “ by means of, ” and I do not remember to have met with an instance of it,] $aribona is thus rendered trans. (TA.) [See a similar ex. in the 28th verse of the Mo'allakah of 'Antarah, EM p. 232. One says also, $ariba fiY A_inaA='K, meaning He drank out of a vessel; agreeably with an explanation of mi$orabapN, in the S and K, as meaning A_inaA='N yu$orabu fiyhi.] And one says, A_in~iY laA^amokuvu Alyawomayoni maA A^a$orabuhumaA maA='F, meaning maA A^a$orabu fiyhimaA maA='F [i. e. Verily I tarry the two days not drinking in them water]. (O.) ― -b2- [$ariba Ald~awaA='a, in the conventional language of the physicians, as is indicated in the Mgh, voce banojN (q. v.), on the phrase $ariba Albanoja, and as is shown in many instances in the K &c., means He took, i. e. swallowed, the medicine, whether fluid or solid. ― -b3- And in the present day, they say, $ariba Ald~uxaAna, meaning He inhaled, properly imbibed, smoke of tobacco; or he smoked tobacco, or the tobacco.] ― -b4- One says of seed-produce, or corn, when its culms have come forth, qado $ariba Alz~aroEu fiY AlqaSabi (assumed tropical:) [The seed-produce, or corn, has imbibed into the culms]: (O, TA:) and when the sap (AlmaA=') has come into it, $ariba qaSabu Alz~aroEi (assumed tropical:) [The culms of the seed-produce, or corn, have imbibed]. (TA.) And one says, $ariba Als~unobulu Ald~aqiyqa (tropical:) [The ears of corn imbibed the farina; or] became pervaded by the farina; (En-Nadr, A, O;) or had in them the alimentary substance; as though the farina were water which they drank. (TA.) And waqado $ariba Alz~aroEu Ald~aqiyqa, occurring in the story of Ohod, (O, TA,) as some relate it, or ↓ $ur~iba as others relate it, means (tropical:) [And the seed-produce, or corn, had imbibed, or had been made to imbibe, the farina, or] had become hardened in its grain, and near to maturity. (TA.) [And ↓ A^u$oriba means the same: for one says,] A^u$oriba Alz~aroEu (tropical:) [The seed-produce, or corn, was made to imbibe the farina; or] became pervaded by the farina: and in like manner, A^u$oriba Alz~aroEu Ald~aqiyqa, i. e. (tropical:) [The seed-produce, or corn, was made to imbibe the farina, or] its alimentary substance. (TA.) ― -b5- One also says, A^akala ganamiY wa$aribahaA (tropical:) [He ate the flesh of my sheep, or goats, and drank the milk of them]. (TA in art. Akl.) And [in like manner] A^akala fulaAnN maAliY wa$aribahu (tropical:) [Such a one fed upon, devoured, or consumed, my property]. (A.) And A^akala Ealayohi Ald~ahoru wa$ariba (tropical:) [Time wasted him, or wore him away; as though it fed upon him]. (A.) ― -b6- And maA lamo ↓ A^a$orabotaniY A^a$orabo [lit. Thou hast made me to drink what I have not drunk,] meaning (tropical:) thou hast charged against me, or accused me of doing, what I have not done; (S, A, K;) like A^ak~alotaniY maA lamo A=kulo. (S in art. Akl.) ― -b7- $ariba also signifies He was, or became, satisfied with drinking: (TA:) and in like manner $aribat is said of camels. (A 'Obeyd, S, TA.) And He was, or became, thirsty; (K, TA;) thus having two contr. significations; (TA;) as also ↓ A^a$oraba. (K, TA.) ― -b8- Also, and ↓ A^a$oraba, His camels were, or became, satisfied with drinking: and, i. e. both these verbs, his camels were, or became, thirsty: (K, TA:) or the former verb signifies, or signifies also, (accord. to different copies of the K,) his camel was, or became, weak. (K, TA.) -A2- $ariba bihi, and bihi ↓ A^a$oraba, He lied against him. (K.) -A3- $araba, aor.
$aruba , (O, K, TA,) inf. n. $arobN, (O, TA,) He understood: (O, K, TA:) on the authority of AA. (TA.) [In a copy of the A, the verb in this sense is written $ariba; and app. not through the fault of the transcriber, for it is there mentioned as tropical: but in the O, it is said to be like kataba, aor.
$aruba , inf. n. katobN; and in the K, to be like naSara.] One says, $araba maA A^uloqiYa A_ilayohi, i. e. He understood [what was told to him]. (TA.) And one says to a stupid person, AuHolubo vum~a A@$orubo Kneel thou; then understand. (O, TA. See also 1 in art. Hlb.)

2 $ar~aba [$r~bhu, inf. n. ta$oriybN, He made him to drink water &c.; and so, as is indicated in the S and K &c., and as is well known, ↓ A^a$orabahu: and] $ar~abotu AlmaA='a I gave to drink the water; as also ↓ A^a$orabotuhu. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, Zal~a maAliY yuw^ak~alu wayu$ar~abu [lit. My cattle passed the day made to eat and made to drink,] i. e. (assumed tropical:) pasturing as they pleased. (S, TA.) And $ar~aba maAliY waA^ak~alahu [lit. He made people to drink my property, and made them to eat it; or to drink the milk of my cattle, and to eat the flesh thereof;] i. e. (assumed tropical:) he fed people, (S,) or gave people to drink and to eat, (TA,) [of] my property, or cattle. (S, TA.) ― -b3- And $r~b AlA^aroDa waAln~axola (assumed tropical:) He gave drink to the land and the palm-trees. (TA.) ― -b4- And $r~b luqomapF biAld~asami (assumed tropical:) [He imbued, or soaked, a morsel, or mouthful, with grease, or gravy]. (TA in art. rwg.) ― -b5- And $ar~abotu Alqirobapa, (A 'Obeyd, S,) inf. n. ta$oriybN, (A 'Obeyd, K,) (assumed tropical:) I rendered the water-skin sweet; (K;) I put into the water-skin, it being new, clay and water, in order to render its savour sweet. (A 'Obeyd, S.) ― -b6- And $ur~iba Alz~aroEu Ald~aqiyqa: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.

3 $Arbhu * , (S, A, K, TA,) inf. n. mu$aArabapN and $iraAbN, He drank with him; namely, a man. (TA.) ― -b2- [And He watered his camels, &c. with his, i. e. with another's : or he drew water with him for the watering of camels &c.:] see an ex. of the latter inf. n. in a verse cited voce $ariybN.

4 A^a$oraba see 2, in two places. One says, A^a$orabotu AlA_ibila Hat~aY $aribato [I made the camels to drink until they were satisfied with drinking; or I watered the camels, or gave them to drink, &c.]; (S, TA;) [for] A^a$oraba is syn. with saqaY. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Alv~awobu yu$orabu AlS~Kboga: see 5. And A^u$oriba Alv~awobu HumorapF (tropical:) The garment, or piece of cloth, was imbued, or saturated, with redness. (A.) And A^a$oraba All~awona (tropical:) He saturated the colour [with dye]. (K, TA.) And A^u$oriba lawonFA (assumed tropical:) It was intermixed with a colour; as also ↓ Ai$oraAb~a. (TA.) And A^u$oriba AlA^aboyaDu HumorapF (assumed tropical:) The white was suffused, or tinged over, with redness. (S, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence, A^u$oriba is also said of a sound, as meaning (assumed tropical:) It was mixed with another sound; as appears from the words here following:] His~u AlS~awoti fiY Alfami mim~aA laA A_i$oraAba lahu mino Sawoti AlS~adori (assumed tropical:) [The faint, or gentle, sound of the voice in the mouth, of such kind as has no mixture of the voice of the chest]. (K in art. hms.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] A^u$oriba Alz~aroEu: see 1, latter half. ― -b5- And A^u$oriba fiY qalobihi Hub~ahu, (S,) or A^u$oriba Hub~a fulaAnK, (K,) or Hub~a fulaAnapa, (A,) (tropical:) [He was made to imbibe into his heart the love of him, or of such a man, or of such a female;] meaning that the love of him, or of her, pervaded, or commingled with, his heart, (S, A, K, TA,) like beverage. (TA.) Whence, in the Kur [ii. 87], waA^u$oribuwA fiY quluwbihimu A@loEijola, for Hub~a AlEijoli, (S, TA,) i. e. (assumed tropical:) And they were made to imbibe [into their hearts] the love of the calf.. (Zj, TA.) ― -b6- And rafaEa yadahu faA^a$orabahaA AlhawaA='a vum~a qaAla bihaA EalaY qa*aAlihi (tropical:) [He raised his hand, and made the air to swallow it up, (i. e. raised it so high and so quickly that it became hardly seen,) then gave a blow with it upon the back of his head]. (A, TA.) ― -b7- And A^a$orabotaniY maA lamo A^a$orabo: see 1, latter half. ― -b8- And one says to his she-camel, laA^u$oriban~aki AlHibaAla (tropical:) [I will assuredly put upon thee the ropes, or cords], and AlEiqaAla [the cord, or rope, with which the fore shank and the arm are bound together]. (A.) [Or] A$rbhu means (tropical:) He put the rope, or cord, upon his neck; namely, a man's, (K, TA,) and a camel's, and a horse's or the like: (TA:) and A$rb Alxayola he put the ropes, or cords, upon the necks of the horses. (K,) And A$rb A_ibilahu (tropical:) He tied his camels, every one to
another. (K, TA.) -A2- A$rb as an intrans. verb: see 1, last quarter, in two places. ― -b2- Also He (a man, TA) attained to the time for the drinking of his camels. (K, * TA.) -A3- A$rb bihi: see 1, near the end of the paragraph.

5 ta$ar~aba see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Hence one says, (Mgh,) t$r~b Alv~awobu AlEaraqa, (S, Mgh, * K,) and AlS~iboga, (A, Mgh, L,) (tropical:) The garment, or piece of cloth, imbibed, or absorbed, (S, A, Mgh, * L, K,) the sweat, (S, Mgh, K,) and the dye; (A, Mgh, L;) as though it drank it by little and little: (Mgh:) and [in like manner] one says, Alv~awobu y$rb AlS~iboga [app. ↓ yu$orabu, (like as one says yu$orabu HumorapF, as shown in the next preceding paragraph,) meaning (assumed tropical:) The garment, or piece of cloth, is made to imbibe, or absorb, the dye]. (TA.) [It is said that] the verb is not used intransitively in the [proper] language of the Arabs. (Mgh.) [But] one says, t$r~b AlS~ibogu fiY Alv~awobi, meaning (tropical:) The dye pervaded the garment, or piece of cloth: (K, * TA:) and AlS~ibogu yata$ar~abu Alv~awoba (tropical:) [The dye pervades the garment, or piece of cloth]. (TA.) [See also the explanation of a verse cited voce tasaq~aY.]

10 Ast$rb lawonuhu * (assumed tropical:) His, or its, colour became intense. (K.) And Ast$rbt Alqawosu HumorapF (assumed tropical:) The bow became intensely red: such is the case when it is made of the [tree called] $aroyaAn. (AHn, (TA.)
11 Ai$oraAb~a * : see 4, near the beginning.

Q. Q. 4 Ai$oraA^ab~ * , (S, A, O, K,) inf. n.
