Ai$oriy^obaAbN, (S, O,) (tropical:) He raised his head like the camel that has satisfied his thirst on the occasion of drinking: (A:) or he stretched forth his neck to look: (S, A, O, K:) not improbably, from Al$~urobu in its well known sense, as though he did so when preparing to drink: (O:) or, as is said in the L, from ma$orabapN as syn. with gurofapN: (TA:) you say, Ai$oraA^ab~a lahu, (S, A,) or A_ilayohi, (K,) or both; (TA;) [the former of which may be rendered He raised his head at it, or he stretched forth his neck at it to look; or, as also the latter, he stretched forth his neck to look at it;] namely, a thing: (S:) or A$rA^b~ originally means he stretched forth his neck in preparing to drink water: and then, in consequence of frequency of usage, he raised his head, and stretched forth his neck, in looking; and hence is trans. by means of A_ilaY: (Har p. 152:) or he raised, or exalted, himself. (K, * TA.) ya$oray^ib~uwna liSawotihi, occurring in a trad., means (tropical:) They will raise their heads at his voice to look at him. (TA.) And Ai$oraA^ab~a Aln~ifaAqu waA@rotad~ati AlEarabu, in another trad., means (tropical:) Hypocrisy exalted itself [and the Arabs apostatized, or revolted from their religion]. (TA.)

$arobN * an inf. n. of $ariba [q. v.]. (S, A, Msb, K, &c.) -A2- And a pl., (S, Msb,) or [rather] a quasipl. n., (ISd, TA,) of $aAribN, q. v. (S, ISd, Msb, TA.) -A3- [Golius assigns to it also the meaning of “ Linum tenue, ” as on the authority of Meyd.]

$urobN * an inf. n. of $ariba [q. v.]; (S, A, Msb, K, &c.;) like ↓ $irobN: (S, A, K:) or a simple subst. [signifying The act of drinking]; (AO, S Msb, K;) as also ↓ $irobN. (AO, S, K.) -A2- In the phrase A^axuwka $urobN it is used as [an epithet,] meaning *uw $urobK [which may be regarded as virtually syn. with $aAribN or as similar to this latter but intensive in signification]. (Ham p. 194.)

$irobN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places. ― -b2- Also Water, (K, TA,) itself; so some say; (TA;) as also ↓ mi$orabN, (K, accord. to the TA,) with kesr, (TA,) or ↓ ma$orabN, (so in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K,) i. e. water that one drinks; so says AZ: pl. of the former A^a$oraAbN. (TA.) [See also $araAbN.] ― -b3- [And A draught of milk: see an ex. in a verse cited in art. slf, conj. 4.] ― -b4- And A share, or portion that falls to one's lot, of water: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) or so $irobN mino maA='K. (ISk, TA.) It is said in a prov., A=xiruhaA A^aqal~uhaA $irobFA [The last of them is the one of them that has the least share of water]: originating from the watering of camels; because the last of them sometimes comes to the water when the watering-trough has been exhausted. (S. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 61.]) ― -b5- As a law-term, it means The use of water [or the right to use it] for the watering of sown-fields and of beasts. (Mgh.) ― -b6- Also A wateringplace; syn. maworidN: (AZ, K:) pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b7- And (assumed tropical:) A time of drinking: (K:) but they say that it denotes the time only by a sort of tropical application; and they differ respecting the connexion of this meaning with the proper meaning. (MF, TA.)
$arabN * : see $arabapN, in two places.

$arobapN *
A single act of drinking. (S.) ― -b2- And A single draught, or the quantity that is drunk at once, of water. (S.) It is said in a prov., niEoma miEolaqu Al$~arobapi h`*aA [Excellent, or most excellent, is the traveller's drinking-cup, or bowl, that will hold a single draught, namely, this!]: the miEolaq is said by As to be a drinking-cup or bowl which the rider upon a camel suspends [to his saddle]: (Meyd:) it is said in describing a camel: (TA:) and it means that, to the place of alighting to which he desires to go, he is content with a single draught, not wanting another: (Meyd, TA:) the prov. is applied to him who, in his affairs, is content with his own opinion, not wanting that of another person. (Meyd.) $arobapu A^abiY Aljahomi [The draught of Abu-l-Jahm] is said of a thing that is sweet, or pleasant, but in its result unwholesome: (MF, TA:) Abu-l-Jahm was a frequent visiter of the Khaleefeh El-Mansoor El-'Abbásee, who, finding him troublesome, ordered that a poisoned draught should be given to him, in his presence: which having been done, Abu-l-Jahm, pained by the draught, rose to depart; and being asked by the Khaleefeh whither he was going, he answered, Whither thou hast sent me, O Prince of the Faithful. (MF.) ― -b3- In the Mo'allakah of Tarafeh, it is applied to A draught of wine. (EM p. 87.) ― -b4- [In the conventional language of the physicians, it is a term applied to A dose of medicine, such as is drunk and also such as is eaten.] -A2- Also A palm-tree that grows from the date stone: (K:) pl. $arabaAtN. (TA. [It seems to be there added that $araAy^ibu and $araAbiybu are also its pls.: the former may be like DaraAy^iru pl. of Dar~apN: the latter is app. a mistranscription, and should perhaps be $araAy^iybu, for $araAy^ibu; like maHaAmiyru for maHaAmiru, &c.])

$urobapN * , (K,) or $urobapN mino maA='K, (S,) The quantity of water that satisfies thirst. (S, K.) ― -b2- $urobapN is also syn. with ↓ A_i$oraAbN [originally an inf. n.] meaning (assumed tropical:) A colour tinged over with another colour; as in the saying, fiyhi $urobapN mino HumorapK (assumed tropical:) [In him is a colour tinged with redness]: (S, TA:) [and] (tropical:) somewhat of redness; as in the phrase, fiyhi $urobapN (tropical:) [In him is somewhat of redness]: (A:) or (assumed tropical:) a redness in the face: (K:) or (assumed tropical:) whiteness mixed with redness. (IAar, TA voce HusobapN.)

$arabapN * [The act, or habit, of] much drinking. (K.) One says, A_in~ahu la*Fw $arabapK, meaning Verily he is one who drinks much. (AA, AHn, TA.) -A2- It is also allowable as a pl. of $aAribN [q. v.]. (Msb.) -A3- Also A small trough, (S, K, TA,) made, (S,) or dug, (TA,) around a palm-tree, (S, K, TA,) and around any other kind of tree, and filled with water, (TA,) holding enough to irrigate it fully, (K, TA,) so that it is plentifully irrigated thereby: (S, TA:) pl. ↓ $arabN [or rather this is a coll. gen. n., of which the former is the n. un.,] and [the pl. properly so termed is] $arabaAtN. (S.) ― -b2- And i. q. kurodu daborapK, (K, TA,) which is syn. with masoqaApN: (TA:) [from a comparison of the explanations of all of these words, it seems to mean A channel of water for the irrigation of a plot, or tract, of sown land: or, if the explanation msqAp, in the TA, be conjectural, the meaning may be a portion of such land, having a raised border to retain the water admitted upon it:] pl. $arabaAtN and [coll. gen. n.] ↓ $arabN [as above]. (TA.) -A4- Also Thirst. (Lh, T, O, K.) One says, lamo tazalo bihi $arabapN Alyawoma He has not ceased to have thirst to-day. (Lh, TA.) And jaA='ati AlA_ibilu wabihaA $arabapN The camels came thirsty. (T, O.) And TaEaAmN *uw $arabapK Food wherewith one has not sufficient water to satisfy thirst. (O, TA.) Accord. to the L, $arabapN signifies The thirst of cattle after the being satisfied with fresh pasture; because this invites to drink. (TA.) ― -b2- And Vehemence of heat. (K.) One says, yawomN *uw $arabapK A day of vehement heat, in which is drunk more water than at other times. (TA.)
$urabapN * One who drinks much; (ISk, S, K;) as also ↓ $aruwbN and ↓ $ar~aAbN. (S.) One says rajulN A^ukalapN $urabapN A man who eats and drinks much. (ISk, S.)
$urobubN * , applied to herbage, i. q. gamolaY; (O, K;) i. e. Tangled and dense, one part above another. (O.)

$arab~apN * , [said to be] the only word of this form except jarab~apN, (K,) [but to this should be added bagat~apN, inf. n. of bagatahu,] A way, mode, or manner,
of being, or acting &c. (S, O, K.) One says, maA zaAla fulaAnN EalaY $arab~apK waAHidapK Such a one ceased not to be [employed] upon one affair. (S, O.) -A2- And A tract of land, (K, TA,) soft, or plain, (TA,) producing herbs, but having in it no trees. (K, TA.) ― -b2- [And] The side of a valley. (Mgh.)

$araAbN *
A beverage, or drink, (Mgh, L, Msb, K,) of any of the liquids, (Mgh, Msb,) or of anything that is not chewed, (L,) or of whatever kind and in whatever state it be; thus in a copy of the K: (TA:) and syn. with $araAbN are ↓ $ariybN and ↓ $aruwbN, (K,) accord. to a saying attributed to AZ: (TA:) or these two have another meaning, expl. in the next paragraph: (K:) the pl. of $araAbN is A^a$oribapN; (Mgh, TA;) or it has no pl., as is said in the K in art. nhr [accord. to one or more of the copies; but see nahaArN, where it is shown that in copies of the K, as well as in the S, the word to which this statement relates is saraAbN, with the unpointed s]. (TA.) The lawyers [and generally the post-classical writers, and sometimes others,] mean thereby [Win, and] such beverage as is forbidden. (Mgh.) [Also Sirup: pl. $araAbaAtN: so in the language of the present day.]

$aruwbN * and ↓ $ariybN are syn. with $araAbN, q. v.: or both signify Water inferior to the Ea*ob [or sweet]: (K:) or [brackish water; i. e.] water between the salt and the sweet: (AO, S:) or water drinkable, or fit to be drunk, but in which is disagreeableness: (Msb:) or the former signifies water that has some degree of sweetness, and is sometimes drunk by men notwithstanding what is in it; and ↓ the latter, water inferior to what is sweet, and not drunk by men save in cases of necessity, but sometimes drunk by cattle: (IKtt, TA:) or ↓ the latter, the sweet: and the former is said to signify water that is drunk: (TA:) or ↓ the latter, water that has no sweetness in it, but is sometimes drunk by men notwithstanding what is in it; and the former, water inferior to this in sweetness, and not drunk by men save in cases of necessity: (AZ, T, M, TA:) or, accord. to Lth, ↓ $ariybN and ↓ $ir~iybN signify water in which are bitterness and saltness, but not abstained from as drink: and maA='N $aruwbN and TaEiymN are syn.: and ↓ maA='N mi$orabN is syn. with $aruwbN: this last word is used alike as masc. and fem. and sing. and pl. (TA.) It is said in a prov., originally in a trad., juroEapu $aruwbK A^anofaEu mino Ea*obK muwbK [expl. in art. wbA^]. (TA.) -A2- Also, $aruwbN, A man who drinks vehemently. (TA.) See also $urabapN: and $ir~iybN. ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A she-camel desiring the stallion. (K.)

$ariybN * : see $araAbN: and $aruwbN; the latter in five places. -A2- Also One who drinks with another: (S, K:) and one who waters his camels with those of another: of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mufaAEilN: (S:) and one who draws water, or is given to drink, with another. (IAar, K.) You say, huwa $ariyibiY [He is my companion in drinking; or in watering his camels with mine: &c.]. (TA.) And a rájiz says,
rub~a $ariybK laka *iY HusaAsi
kaAlHaz~i biAlmawaAsiY ↓ $iraAbuhu
[Many a one who waters his camels with thine, or who draws water with thee for the watering of camels, having an evil disposition, his watering &c. is like the cutting with razors]: i. e., thy waiting for him at the watering-trough is [a cause of] killing to thee and to thy camels. (TA.)

$ariybapN * is expl. in the S as meaning A sheep, or goat, which one drives back, or brings back, from the water, when the sheep, or goats, are satisfied with drinking, and which they follow: but in some of the copies in a marginal note stating that the correct word is sariybapN, with the unpointed s. (TA.)

$araAbiY~N *
A cup-bearer: or a butler: and a seller of wine or of sirup. (MA.)

$uraA^obiybapN * a subst. (K) from Ai$oraA^ab~a [q. v.; as such signifying (tropical:) A raising of the head like the camel that has satisfied his thirst on the occasion of drinking: &c.]: (S, K, TA:) like TumaA^oniynapN [from AiTomaA^an~a]. (K, TA.)
$ar~aAbN * : see $urabapN: and what here next follows.

$ir~iybN *
Addicted to $araAb [i. e. drink, or wine]; (S, K, TA;) like xim~iyrN; (S;) as also ↓ $ar~aAbN and ↓ $aruwbN and ↓ $aAribN. (TA.) -A2- See also $aruwbN.

[
$ur~aAbapN *
A tassel: so in the language of the present day: probably post-classical: pl. $araAriybu.]

$aAribN *
Drinking, or a drinker: pl. $aAribuwna (Msb) and ↓ $arobN, like as SaHobN is of SaAHibN, (S, Msb,) or, accord. to ISd, (TA,) $arobN, which signifies people drinking, (K, TA,) and assembling for drinking, is a quasi.-pl. n. of $aAribN, being like rakobN and rajolN; and $uruwbN, which is said by IAar [and in the S] to be pl. of $arobN, is pl. of $aAribN, like as $uhuwdN is of $aAhidN; (TA;) $arabapN also is allowable as a pl. of $aAribN, like as kafarapN is pl. of kaAfirN; (Msb;) and A^a$orubN is pl. of $arobN, or it may be an anomalous pl. of $aAribN: (MF:) the pl. $uruwb occurs in the saying of El-Aashà,
huwa AlwaAhibu AlmusomiEaAti Al$~uruw
ba bayona AlHariyri wabayona Alkatano
[He is the giver of female singers to the drinkers, some clad in silk and some in linen]. (S.) ― -b2- See also $ir~iybN. ― -b3- [Hence, The mustache; i. e.] the defluent hair over the mouth; (Msb;) or so $awaAribu, (Lh, A, K,) which is the pl., (Lh, S, Msb,) as though the sing, applied to every distinct part: (Lh:) the two [halves] are called $aAribaAni: (S, TA:) or, as some say, only the sing. is used, and the dual is a mistake: (TA:) accord. to AHát (Msb, TA) and AAF, (TA,) the dual is is scarcely ever, or never, used; but accord. to AO, the Kilábees say $aAribaAni, with regard to the two extremities: (Msb, TA:) and the pl., (A, K,) or, accord. to the T &c., the dual, (TA,) signifies the long portions [of the hair] on the two sides of the sabalap [q. v.]: (T, A, K, TA:) or (K, TA) $aAribN signifies the sabalap altogether, (A, K, TA,) as some say; but this is not correct. (TA.) One says, Tar~a $aAribu AlgulaAmi [The mustache of the boy, or young man, grew forth]. (S.) ― -b4- And hence, as being likened to the two long portions of hair on each side of the sabalap, the $aAribaAni of the sword, (T, TA,) i. e. (tropical:) Two long projections (A^anofaAni TawiylaAni) at the lower part of the hilt, (A, * K, TA,) [extending from the guard,] one on one side and the other on the other side of the blade, (T, * TA,) the gaA$iyap [or leathern covering of the scabbard] being beneath them: so says ISh. (TA.) ― -b5- Al$~awaAribu also signifies (tropical:) The Euruwq [or ducts] of the Huloquwm [or windpipe]: (A:) or certain ducts (Euruwq) in the Haloq [i. e. fauces or throat], (K, TA,) that imbibe the water [or saliva?], being the channels thereof: (TA:) and, (K,) or, as some say, (TA,) the channels of the water [or saliva?] (S, K, TA) in the Haloq [i. e. fauces or throat] (S) or in the neck: (K, TA:) or certain ducts (Euruwq) adhering to the windpipe, and the lower parts thereof to the lungs: so says IDrd: or rather, some say, the hinder part thereof [adhering] to the watiyn [or aorta], having tubes from which the voice issues, and in which choking takes place, and whence the saliva issues: and those of the horse are said to be [certain ducts] by the side of the A^awodaAj [or external jugular veins], where the veterinary surgeon draws blood by cutting the AwdAj: the sing. seems by implication to be $aAribN. (TA.) Hence the phrase HimaArN Saxibu Al$~awaAribi (assumed tropical:) An ass that brays vehemently. (S, TA.) And Saxibu Al$~awaAribi (tropical:) [A man] having a disagreeable voice: thus likened to an ass. (A, TA.) ― -b6- Accord. to IAar, Al$~awaAribu signifies [also] majaAriY AlmaA='i fiY AlEayoni, which AM supposes to mean The channels of water in the spring, or source; not in the eye. (L, TA.) ― -b7- sunobulN $aAribu qamoHK means (tropical:) Ears of corn becoming, or being, pervaded by the farina: (A, TA:) or, in which the grain has hardened, and nearly come to maturity. (TA.) -A2- Also (assumed tropical:) Weakness, or feebleness, in any animal: (K, * TA:) or a strain (Eiroq) thereof; as in the saying, niEoma AlbaEiyru h`*aA lawolaA A^an~a fiyhi $aAriba xawarK (assumed tropical:) [Excellent, or most excellent, were the camel, this one, were there not in him a strain of weakness or feebleness]. (TA.)

$aAribapN * [a subst. from $aAribN, made such by the affix p,] A people, or party, dwelling upon the side (Daf~ap, in some copies of the K Suf~ap,) of a river, (S, * A, K,) and to whom belongs the water thereof. (S.)
A_i$oraAbN * as syn. with $urobapN: see the latter.

ma$orabN * is a noun of place, [and of time,] as well as an inf. n.: [i. e.] it signifies [A place, and a time, of drinking: or] the quarter (wajoh) whence one drinks: (S, TA:) and a place to which one comes to drink at a river or rivulet: (TA:) and ↓ ma$orabapN, (S, Msb, K, TA,) not, as is implied in the K, ma$orubapN also, (TA,) signifies [the same, as
is indicated in the A; or] a place whence people drink; (Msb, TA; *) i. q. ma$oraEapN; (K;) or like a ma$oraEap. (S, TA.) One says, h`*aA ma$orabu Alqawomi and ↓ ma$orabatuhumo [This is the people's, or party's, drinkingplace, or place whence they drink]. (A.) And it is said in a trad., ↓ maloEuwnN mano A^aHaATa EalaY ma$orabapK, (S, TA,) i. e. [Cursed is he] who takes entirely to himself, debarring others from it, a place whence people drink. (TA.) ― -b2- See also $irobN.
mu$orabN HumorapF * (tropical:) A man whose complexion is tinged over [or intermixed] with redness. (TA.) [See 4: and see also mu$ar~abN.]

rajulN mu$oribN *
A man whose camels have drunk [until satisfied with drinking: see A^a$oraba near the end of the first paragraph]. (TA.) And A man whose camels are thirsty, or who is himself thirsty. (TA.) AisoqiniY faA_in~aniY mu$oribN is a saying mentioned by IAar, and expl. by him as meaning EaTo$aAnu: it means [Give thou me to drink, for] I am thirsty or my camels are thirsty. (TA.)
mi$orabN * : see $irobN: and see also $aruwbN.

ma$orabapN * : see ma$orabN, in three places. ― -b2- Hence, (A, TA,) An upper chamber; syn. gurofapN; (S, A, Msb, K, TA;) and Euil~iy~apN; (S, * K;) both of which signify the same; (MF, TA;) because people drink therein; (A, TA;) as also ↓ ma$orubapN: (S, Msb, K, TA:) pl. ma$aAribu, (TA,) syn. with EalaAliY~u, (S,) and ma$orabaAtN. (TA.) ― -b3- And the former, (K, TA,) not, as is implied in the K, the latter also, (TA,) A Suf~ap [i. e. roofed vestibule or the like]: (K, TA:) or the like of a Suf~ap in the front of a gurofap [expl. above]. (TA.) ― -b4- Also the former, (K, TA,) not, as is implied in the K, both words, (TA,) Soft, or plain, land, in which is always herbage, (K, TA,) i. e. green and juicy herbage. (TA.) ― -b5- See also mi$orabapN. -A2- [Also A cause of drinking: a word of the class of maboxalapN &c.] One says TaEaAmN ma$orabapN Food [that is a cause of drinking, or] upon which one drinks much water: (T, TA:) or TaEaAmN *uw ma$orabapK food upon which the eater drinks. (A.)
ma$orubapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

mi$orabapN * , (S, A, K,) and MF says that ↓ ma$orabapN is allowable in the same sense, mentioning it as on the authority of Fei, [in my copy of whose lexicon, the Msb, I do not find it,] (TA,) A drinkingvessel. (S, A, K.)

mu$ar~abN HumorapF * (tropical:) A man whose complexion is much tinged over [or much intermixed] with redness. (TA.) [See also mu$orabN.] ― -b2- mu$ar~abapN is an epithet applied to Certain letters the utterance of which, in pausing, is accompanied with a sort of blowing, but not with the same stress as the [generality of those that are termed] majohuwrap: they are zaAY and ZaA=' and *aAl and DaAd: [and Lumsden (in his Ar. Gr. p. 47) states that raA=' belongs to the same class, likewise: and, as some say, nuwn when movent:] Sb says that some of the Arabs utter with more vehemence of voice than others. (TA.)

1 $araja * : see 4. ― -b2- Also, (S, A, O, TA,) [aor.
$aruja ,] inf. n. $arojN, (S, O, K, TA,) He put, or set, together bricks (labin), in order, side by side, or one upon another, compactly; (S, A, O, K, TA;) and (O) so ↓ $r~j, (O, Mgh, Msb,) with teshdeed, (Msb,) inf. n. ta$oriyjN. (O, Mgh.) ― -b3- And He collected together, (O, K,) or put together, or joined, (L,) any thing or things, one part to another, or one thing to another; (O, L;) as also ↓ $r~j. (L.) ― -b4- [And app. He wove palm-leaves: see $riyjapN, below; and see also $ariyTN.] ― -b5- And He mixed (A, O, K) beverage, or wine: and in like manner ↓ $r~j he mixed honey &c. with water. (O.) ― -b6- And $arajahu fiY AlA^amori, aor.
$aruja , (TK,) inf. n. as above, (K, TK,) He was, or became, a partner, or sharer, (K, TK,) with him in the affair. (TK.) -A2- Also, (O,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He lied; (O, K;) like saraja and sadaja. (O.) -A3- $arija, (O, TA,) with kesr to the r, (O,) He was, or became, beautifully fat. (O, TA.)

2 $r~j * , inf. n. ta$oriyjN: see above, in three places. ― -b2- Also, said of pasture, or herbage, It caused the flesh of an animal to be intermixed with fat. (L.) And $ur~ija, said of the flesh of an animal, It was intermixed with fat: (S, O:) or was made to be of two colours by reason of the fat and the flesh: (TA:) and biAl$~aHomi ↓ t$r~j it (the flesh) became intermixed with fat. (S, O, K.) -A2- And ta$oriyjN also signifies The sewing with stitches far apart. (S, O, K) ― -b2- See also 4.
3 mu$aArajapN * The being like, one to another. (O, K.) One says, $Arjhu He was like to him; or it, to it: and $aArajaA They two were like, each to the other. (TK.)

4 A$rj * , (AZ, S, A, O, Msb,) inf. n. A_i$oraAjN; (K;) and ↓ $r~j, (AZ, O,) inf. n. ta$oriyjN; (K;) and ↓ $araja, (AZ, O,) inf. n. $arojN; (K;) He closed, or made fast, the [leathern receptacle called] xariyTap (AZ, O, K) or Eayobap, (S, A, O, Msb,) by inserting its A^a$oraAj [or loops] one into another. (S, A, * O, Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A$rj Sadorahu Ealayohi (tropical:) [He closed his bosom upon it]. (A, TA.)
5 ta$ar~aja see 2.
7 An$rj * , (K,) or An$rjt, said of a bow, (ISk, S, O,) It split. (ISk, S, O, K.)

$arojN *
A place in which water flows from a [stony tract such as is termed] Har~ap to a soft, or plain, tract; (S, K;) as also ↓ $arojapN: (TA:) or the latter signifies [simply] a place in which water flows; and some elide the p, saying $arojN: (Msb:) pl. $iraAjN (S, Mgh, Msb, K, expl. in the Mgh agreeably with the former explanation above, and said in the Msb to be pl. of $arojapN,) and $uruwjN. (S, K.) -A2- Also A party, or distinct body or class [of men]. (S, K.) One says, A^aSobaHuwA fiY h`*aA AlA^amori $arojayoni i. e. [They became, in this affair,] two parties. (S.) And it is said in a trad., A^aSobaHa Aln~aAsu $arojayoni fiY Als~afari [The people, or men, became two parties in the journey]; meaning, half of them fasting, and half of them breaking the fast. (TA.) ― -b2- And The like of another; (S, K;) as also ↓ $ariyjN: (O, K:) the latter from the same word as meaning “ a piece of wood [or a branch] that is split into two halves; ” each of which is the $ryj of the other. (O.) One says, h`*aA $aroju h`*aA This is the like of this. (S.) ― -b3- And A sort, or species. (S, K.) One says, humaA $arojN waAHidN They two are one sort, or species. (S.) ― -b4- And $arojaAni Any two different colours: (S:) [and] ↓ $ariyjaAni signifies [the same, i. e.] two different colours (K, TA) of anything; or, accord. to IAar, two mixed colours, not black and white: (TA:) and ↓ this latter, also, the two lines of the nayraAni [or two ornamental borders] of a [garment of the kind called] burod, (O, K,) one of which is A^axoDar [here meaning of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour], and the other white or red. (O.) ― -b5- And Al$~aroju, like falos [in measure, not to be confounded with Al$~araju], signifies The [perinæum, or] part between the anus and the testicles. (IKtt, TA.)

$arajN * The loops (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) of the [leathern receptacle called] Eayobap, (S, Mgh, O, Msb,) and of the [tent called] xayomap, (O, TA,) and the like, and of the muSoHaf [or copy of the Kur-án, &c.]: (TA:) [the loops here meant being such as are inserted one into another, to close a bag &c.: see 4:] pl. A^a$oraAjN. (S, Msb.) [And it seems also, from what here follows, to signify A single loop.] ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) The anus: (Msb, TA:) or hence $araju Ald~uburi signifies (assumed tropical:) the anus. (Mgh.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) The vulva of a woman: (O, K:) pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b4- And $araju Ald~araAhimi [The purse for money]. (M and K in art. Sr: in the CK, $aroj.) -A2- Also A place of expanding of a valley: (S, O, K:) pl. as above. (S.) ― -b2- And The Milky Way in the sky: (S:) or so Al$~araju. (K.) -A3- Also A splitting, or cracking, (Aino$iqaAqN, S, and so in some copies of the K, or $uqaAqN, so in other copies of the K and in the O,) in a bow. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- And in a beast, The having one of the two testicles larger than the other. (S, O, K.)
$arojapN * : see $arojN. ― -b2- Also A hollow dug in the ground, in which a piece of skin is spread, and from which camels are watered, (O, K,) water being poured upon the skin. (O.)

$ariyjN *
A branch, or rod, that is split into two halves: and ↓ $ariyjapN, a bow that is made thereof: (S, O, K:) or the former, a branch, or rod, from which are split two bows: and either of the bows thus made: or a split bow: pl. $araAy^iju: accord. to AA, a bow that is split from a branch, or rod, in two halves; also called filoqN: accord. to Lh, a
bow in which is a splitting ($aq~N, used as an inf. n.), and [such as is] a $iq~, by which is meant the subst. [i. e. half of a branch or rod divided lengthwise]; $ryj being used by him as an epithet: and some say that ↓ $ariyjapN signifies a bow that is not [made] from a sound, or whole, branch; like filoqN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also An arrow used in the game called Almayosir belonging to the person who plays with it, not borrowed. (TA in art. $jr.) ― -b3- See also $arojN, in three places. ― -b4- Almaro'u bayona $ariyjaYo gam~K wasuruwrK is a tropical saying [app. meaning (tropical:) Man is between the two different conditions of grief and happiness]. (A, TA.)

$ariyjapN *
A thing (S, Mgh, Msb, K) that is woven (S, Mgh, Msb) of palm-leaves (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and the like, (Msb,) in which are carried melons and other things (S, Mgh, Msb, K) of the like kind: (S, Mgh, K:) pl. $araAy^iju. (Msb.) ― -b2- A door, (Mgh,) or a thing like a door, (Msb,) made of reeds, or canes, for a shop. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b3- A cage, or coop, (jadiylap,) of reeds, or canes, (O, K, TA,) made (TA) for pigeons. (O, K, TA. [The explanation in the K is strangely misunderstood and rendered by Freytag as meaning “ Zona ex arundine facta, qua utuntur in balneo. ”]) ― -b4- And The sinew with which the feathers of an arrow are attached: (O, K:) if it is feathered by means of glue, the glue is called ruwmapN. (O.) ― -b5- [Also, accord. to Golius, as on the authority of Meyd, The tie, or band, (“ ligamentum ”) of a book.] ― -b6- See also $ariyjN, in two places.

$ayorajN * , (Msb, TA,) or $iyrajN, (so in my copy of the Mgh,) or the latter is not allowable, (Msb, TA,) vulgarly pronounced siyraj, [q. v.,] with s and kesr, (TA,) an arabicized word, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) from [the Pers.] $iyraho, (Mgh, Msb,) Oil of sesame, or sesamum: (Msb, TA:) and white oil (Mgh, Msb, TA) is sometimes thus called: (Msb, TA:) and expressed juice (EaSiyr), (Mgh, Msb, TA,) or [beverage of the kind called] nabiy*, (Mgh,) before it alters; (Mgh, Msb, TA;) as being likened to oil of sesame because of its clearness. (Msb, TA.)
A^a$oraju * A beast having one of his testicles larger than the other. (S, Mgh, K.) ― -b2- A man having one testicle. (A, TA.)

[
sahomN mu$ar~ajN *
An arrow having cracks. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)]
fatayaAtN muta$aArijaAtN * [in the CK, erroneously, muta$aArajAt,] Young women equals in age. (O, K.)

1 $araHa * , aor.
$araHa , (K,) inf. n. $aroHN, (S, O,) He uncovered, laid open, displayed, exposed to view, discovered, revealed, or disclosed. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, $araHa A^amorahu (tropical:) He showed, discovered, disclosed, or made apparent, his affair, or case. (A, TA.) And $araHa masoA^alapF (A, TA) (tropical:) He explained a question; (TA;) he explained, or made manifest, the answer to a question. (A.) And $araHa AlgaAmiDa (assumed tropical:) He expounded, explained, or interpreted, what was obscure, recondite, or abstruse. (S, O.) And $araHa AlHadiyva, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) He expounded, explained, or interpreted, the tradition; showed, or made apparent, its meaning. (Msb.) ― -b3- And $araHa, aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., (O, TA,) He opened (O, K, TA) a thing of any kind, of any substance or material. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) He defloured a virgin: (O, K, TA:) or (tropical:) he compressed a woman, (A, L,) or a virgin, (K,) lying on her back; (A, L, K;) or he threw, or laid, upon her back, and then compressed, his female slave, or young woman. (O, L.) ― -b5- He widened, or dilated, a thing. (K.) ― -b6- Hence, (TA,) $araHa A@ll~`hu Sadorahu, (S, A, Mgh, O, Msb, TA,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (Msb, TA,) (assumed tropical:) God dilated his bosom, (Mgh, O, Msb, TA,) liqabuwli Alxayori [for the acceptance, or favourable acceptance, of what was good], (O, TA,) and liloA_isolaAmi (Mgh, Msb, TA) for the acceptance, or favourable acceptance, [of El-Islám, or] of the truth, (Msb, TA,) as in the Kur [xxxix. 23]. (TA. [Said in the TA to be tropical; but not so in the A, being mentioned in the latter as proper.]) [And hence, an objective complement being app. understood,] fulaAnN ya$oraHu A_ilaY Ald~unoyaA (tropical:) Such a one manifests desire for the things of the present world: (A:) or such a one becomes dilated in the bosom at the prospect of the things of the present world, and desirous of acquiring them, with large desire. (O, * L.) And maA liY A^araAka ta$oraHu A_ilaY kul~i riybapK (tropical:) What aileth me that I see thee manifesting desire for everything occasioning doubt, or suspicion, or evil opinion? (A, TA.) ― -b7- Also He cut; and so ↓ $r~H. (K.) You say, $araHa All~aHoma, (A, O, Msb, TA,) inf. n. as above; (O;) and ↓ $r~Hhu, (A, O, Msb, TA,) inf. n. ta$oriyHN; (S, O, TA;) the former meaning He cut the flesh-meat lengthwise [or into an oblong slice or into such slices]: and the latter, he so cut it much or into many [such] pieces [or slices]: (Msb:) or the former, he cut the flesh-meat from the joint or limb: or both signify he cut the flesh-meat upon the bone: (L, TA:) or $aroHu All~aHomi signifies taSofiyfuhu; and so ↓ ta$oriyHuhu: (O:) or Alt~aSofiyfu is a kind of ↓ ta$oriyH; i. e. the cutting a piece of flesh-meat thin, so that it is translucent by reason of its thinness, and then throwing it upon the live coals. (TA.) ― -b8- Also, (K,) inf. n. as above, (O,) He understood (O, K) speech, or language. (TK.) ― -b9- And $aroHN also signifies The act of keeping, preserving, or guarding. (TA.) [And particularly The guarding of seed-produce from the birds; (see $aAriHN;) as also $iraAHapN; (see 1 in art. xfr, fourth sentence;) each an inf. n., of which the verb is $araHa.]

2 $ar~aHa The inf. n. ta$oriyHN signifies The expounding, explaining, or interpreting, well, language, or discourse. (KL.) ― -b2- See also 1, latter half, in four places. ― -b3- [Also The dissecting, or anatomizing, a body.]
7 An$rH Sadoruhu * (S, A, O) His bosom became dilated, (O,) [with joy or the like, or] liloA_isolaAmi [for the acceptance, or favourable acceptance, of El-Islám]. (S.)

10 Ast$rH *
He asked for language to be expounded, explained, or interpreted, to him: or for flesh-meat to be cut for him in the manner termed $aroHN. (O.)

$aroHN * inf. n. of 1. (S, O, &c.) ― -b2- [An exposition, explanation, or interpretation, in the form of a running commentary, comprising the entire text of the work which it expounds; distinguished from a HaA$iyap, which is a commentary only on particular words and passages: pl. $uruwHN.]

$aroHapN * : see $ariyHapN. ― -b2- $aroHapN mina AlZ~ibaA='i Flesh-meat of gazelles cut in the manner termed $aroH [i. e. into oblong slices], (TA,) such as is brought in a dry state, just as it was, not muqad~ad [which means cut into strips and then dried by exposure to the sun]. (ISh, O, K, TA.)

$araAHN * The discovery, disclosure, or explanation, of an affair or a case: so in the prov., Aln~ajaAHu maEa Al$~araAHi [The accomplishment of one's want is with the discovery, or disclosure, or explanation, thereof]; meaning, discover thou, or disclose, or explain, to me my affair, or case, for the doing so is one of the means of accomplishing my want: thus expl. by As. (Meyd. [In the TA, mn is put in the place of mE. See a similar prov. voce saraAHN.])
$ariyHN * , applied to flesh-meat, i. q. ↓ ma$oruwHN [i. e. Cut into oblong slices]. (O.) ― -b2- See also $ariyHapN, in two places.

$urayoHN * The vulva of a woman; (O, K;) and (K) so ↓ ma$oraHN: (A, Mgh, K:) or a proper name for the vulva of a woman; like as rumayoHN is a proper name for “ the penis. ” (TA in art. rmH. [Golius appears to have found in the K AlHar~u in the place of AlHiru.])

$ariyHapN *
A cut piece of flesh-meat, (S, A, O, K,) as also ↓ $ariyHN and ↓ $aroHapN, (K,) such as is ma$oruwH [or cut into oblong slices]; (O;) [i. e. an oblong slice of flesh-meat:] or a thin piece, or slice, of flesh-meat: (L, TA:) and any extended piece of fat flesh-meat; (S, O;) as also ↓ $ariyHN: (S:) pl. of the first $araAy^iHu. (A.)

$aAriHN * [An expositor, explainer, or interpreter, of a book or the like. ― -b2- And] A keeper, or guardian. (TA.) In the dial. of El-Yemen, (O, TA,) A guardian of seed-produce from the birds (O, K, TA) amp;c. (O, TA.)
ma$oraHN * : see $urayoHN. ― -b2- [Also] The saAfilap [i. e. podex, or anus,] of a man. (O.)

ma$oruwHN * : see $ariyHN. -A2- Also The saraAb [or mirage]: (K: [In the CK, Al$~araAbu is put in the place of Als~araAbu:]) mentioned on the authority of Th: and masoruwHN [q. v.] is a dial. var. thereof. (TA.)

1 $araxa * , (S, A, L, K,) aor.
$araxa , (L,) inf. n. $aroxN (S, K) and $uruwxN, (L, K,) said of the naAb [or tush] of a camel, It clave the flesh, (S, A, * L, K,) and came forth. (L.) ― -b2- And $araxa, inf. n. $uruwxN (S, L) and $aroxN, (L,) said of a boy, He became a youth, or young man, such as is termed $aArixN. (S, L.)

$aroxN * The rising, protruding, prominent, or projecting, extremity or edge of a thing. (L, K.) [Hence,] $aroxaA Alfuwqi, (ISh, S, A, TA,) or $aroxaA Als~ahomi, (Msb, TA,) both alike in meaning, (TA,) The zanamataAni, (ISh, A, Msb, TA,) or two edges or extremities [or cusps], (S, TA,) of the arrow, (ISh, TA,) [i. e.] of the notch of the arrow, (S, A, Msb, TA,) between which is the place of the bow-string. (ISh, S, A, Msb, TA.) And in like manner, (S,) $aroxaA Alr~aHoli signifies The A=xirap and waAsiTap of the camel's saddle; (S, L, Msb;) the two extremities of the camel's saddle; or, as some say, [more precisely,] its two [upright] pieces of wood, [corresponding to the qarabuwsaAni of the horse's saddle, rising from it] behind and before [or at the fore and hind parts]: (L, TA:) [whence] one says of him who journeys much, laA yazaAlu fulaAnN bayona $aroxaYo raHolihi [Such a one ceases not to be between the two uprights of his camel's saddle: for between them the rider sits: see A=xirapu Alr~aHoli, voce A=xirN]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- The naAb [or tush] of a camel. (L.) ― -b3- A sword-blade (naSol) that has not yet been tempered (lamo yusoqa baEodu), nor had its hilt affixed to it: (S, K:) pl. $uruwxN. (S.) ― -b4- The origin, source, or root, syn. A^aSolN and EiroqN, (L, K,) of anything; like sinoxN(L.) ― -b5- The beginning, commencement, or first period or state, (S, A, L, Msb, K,) of a thing, or an affair, and also, (S, A,) of youth; (S, A, L, Msb, K;) the prime and best part or period of youth, (A,) and its beauty and brightness, and its strength. (L. [See also $axorN.]) ― -b6- A youth, or young man, such as is termed $aAb~N; and youths, or young men; originally an inf. n., and [therefore, when used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] applied to one and to two and to a pl. number: (L:) or it is a pl. of ↓ $aArixN in the sense of $aAb~N, (S, L, K,) or [rather] a quasi-pl. n., (L,) like as SaHobN is of SaAHibN, (S,) [i. e.] a noun used as a pl. in the sense expl. above: (Sh:) or, accord. to some, it signifies strong young men, profitable for service: and accord. to others, young children: (A'Obeyd, L:) it has also for pls. $uruwxN and $ur~axN: (L:) and $uruwxN $ur~axN is an expression used in an intensive sense. (L, K.) ― -b7- The offspring of a man: (K, TA:) or the sperma by which offspring is produced, (TA.) ― -b8- The increase, or offspring, or brood, syn. nitaAj, (AO, S, L, Msb, K,) of camels, (Msb,) [i. e.] consisting of the young ones of camels, (S, K,) in any year, (S, Msb, K,) or of camels, &c., of one year, while they continue small. (L.) One says, h`*aA mino $aroxi fulaAnK This is of the increase (nitaAj) [of the camels &c.] of such a one. (AO, L.) ― -b9- An equal in age, a contemporary in birth; (S, A, K;) an equal, a match, fellow, peer, or compeer; pl. $uruwxN. (S, K.) You say, huwa $aroxiY He is my equal in age, (A, TA,) or my equal or match. (TA.) And humaA $aroxaAni They two are equals [in age,] or matches. (S, K.) -A2- [The pl.] $uruwxN also signifies [Trees of the kind called] EiDaAh. (K.)
$aArixN * : see the next preceding paragraph. You say SabiY~N $aArixN, meaning A young boy. (A.)

1 $arada * , aor.
$aruda , inf. n. $uruwdN (S, L, Msb, K) and $iraAdN, (S, L, K,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) and $uraAdN (K) and $arodN, (L,) said of a camel, (S, A, L, Msb,) and of a horse or the like, (L,) He took fright, or shied, and fled, or ran away at random; or became refractory, and went away at random, or ran away, or broke loose, and went hither and thither by reason of his sprightliness; syn. nafara, (S, L, Msb, K,) and nad~a: (Msb:) and [simply] he fled, or ran away; said of a camel &c. (Aboo-Bekr, TA.) The saying of the Prophet, A^amaA ya$orudu bika baEiyruka (tropical:) [Does not thy camel take fright and run away with thee?], addressed by him to Khowwát, who answered, A^amaA muno*u qay~adahu AlA_isolaAmu falaA [As to the period since El-Islám shackled him, no], mentioned in the A, points to a story related of Khowwát Ibn-Jubeyr, (TA,) that, being found by the Prophet sitting by some strange women, he endeavoured to excuse himself by saying that he had a camel which took fright and ran away, and he was seeking for something wherewith to shackle him: the Prophet used afterwards to taunt him by inquiring of him respecting the running-away of his camel: what Kr says, and J in the S [in art. nHY], is incorrect. (IAth, L.) You say also, $arada Ean~iY fulaAnN Such a one fled, or went away or aside or apart or to a distance, from me; syn. nafara. (A.) [Or] $arada said of a man, inf. n. $uruwdN, means He departed, driven away. (L.) And you say, $arada EalaY A@ll~`hi, meaning He departed from obedience to God, and seceded, or separated himself from the community [of the faithful]. (L.)

2 $r~dhu * , (L, Msb,) inf. n. ta$oriydN, (S, L, Msb, K,) He made him to take fright, and flee, or run away at random; or to become refractory, and to go away at random, or run away, or break loose, and go hither and thither by reason of his sprightliness; namely, a camel [and a horse or the like: see 1]: (Msb:) or he drove him away, or expelled him; (S, * L, K; *) as also ↓ A$rdhu; (L;) [and so $r~d bihi; for] you say $ar~adotuhu Ean~KY and $ar~adotu bihi [I drove him away from me]. (A.) And ta$oriydN signifies also The act of dispersing, or scattering. (K.) [Hence,] $ar~ido bihimo mano xalofahumo, in the Kur [viii. 59], means Disperse thou, or scatter thou, by them, those [who shall come] after them: (S, L:) or terrify thou, by them, those [who shall come] after them: or make thou them notorious to those [who shall come] after them: (L:) [for] ― -b2- $r~d bihi (inf. n. as above, TA) signifies He rendered him notorious by exposing his vices or faults. (L, K.)

4 A^a$orada
A$rdhu He made him to be driven away, or expelled, (L, K,) and not received into a place of refuge, covert, or lodging. (L.) See also 2.

5 t$r~d Alqawomu *
The people, or party, went away, or departed. (L.)
$aradN * : see $aAridN.

$iraAdN * an inf. n. of $arada [q. v.]: (S, L, K:) or a simple subst. from $arada [and as such signifying A taking fright, or shying, and fleeing, or running away at random; &c.: or a disposition thereto]. (Msb.) You say, of a camel, bihi $iraAdN [He has a disposition to take fright, or shy, &c.]. (A.)
$aruwdN * : see $aAridN, in five places.

$ariydN *
Driven away, or expelled: (S, L, K:) or, accord. to Aboo-Bekr, when following TariydN, it signifies fleeing, or running away: or, as As says, alone, or solitary. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A remainder of anything; as of water in a vessel, and as of property, or camels and the like; pl. $araAy^idu, deviating from rule: or $ariydapN is a syn. [or rather fem.] of $ariydN [and $araAy^idu is its reg. pl.]. (L.)

$aAridN * and ↓ $aruwdN, (S, A, L, K,) applied to a camel, (S, A, L,) and to a horse or the like, (L,) Taking fright, or shying, and fleeing, or running away at random; or refractory, and going away at random, or running away, or breaking loose, and going hither and thither by reason of sprightliness: or that takes fright, or shies, &c.: (S, L, K:) [or] the latter [signifies wont to take fright, or shy, &c.: and] is applied to a male animal and to a female: (L:) [the fem. of the former is with p:] pl. of the former $ur~adN (A, * L) and ↓ $aradN, (S, L, K,) [or rather this is a quasi-pl. n.,] like as xadamN is of xaAdimN; (S, K;) [and the pl. of $aAridapN is $ur~adN and $awaAridu;] and the pl. of ↓ $aruwdN is $urudN, like as zuburN is of zabuwrN. (S, L, K. *) You say ↓ farasN $aruwdN A horse, or mare, refractory towards the rider: and ↓ naAqapN $aruwdN A she-camel that runs away, or breaks loose and goes hither and thither by reason of her sprightliness. (L.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ↓ qaAfiyapN $aruwdN (tropical:) A rhyme, or verse, or poem, current through the countries, lands, or regions, or through the cities, or towns. (S, A, K.) ― -b3- And qawaAfK $awaAridu (S in art. Abd) and qawaAfK $ur~ado (K ibid.) [pls. of qaAfiyapN $aAridapN] (tropical:) Strange, unusual, unfamiliar, or extraordinary, rhymes or verses or poems; syn. A^awaAbidu. (S and K ibid.) And [in like manner] lafoZapN $aAridapN,
in lexicology, signifies (assumed tropical:) A barbarism; or a strange, or an uncouth, unusual, unfamiliar, or extraordinary, word or expression or phrase; as also lfZp gariybapN and waHo$iy~apN and Huw$iy~apN; opposed to lfZp faSiyHapN. (Mz, 13th nwE.)
$irodimapN * : see the art. here following.

$iro*imapN *
A party, or company, (TaAy^ifapN,) of men, or people: (S:) or a small company: (TA:) or a small number of men, or people: (K:) and so $irodimapN, with the unpointed d, on the authority of AA: (IB, TA:) the former occurring in the Kur xxvi. 54. (TA.) ― -b2- A piece, or portion, (S, K,) of a thing, (S,) of a quince &c.: pl. $araA*imu and $araA*iymu. (K.) ― -b3- [Hence,] vawobN $araA*imu, (S,) or viyaAbN $araA*imu, (K,) A garment, or garments, old and worn out, (S, K,) much rent. (K.)

1 $arisa * , aor.
$arasa , (Msb, TA,) inf. n. $arasN (Msb, TA, TK) and $araAsapN and $ariysN, (TK, the first and second also mentioned and explained, but not said to be inf. ns., in the S and O and K, and the third in like manner in the K,) or the second is a simple subst., (Msb,) or an inf. n. of which the verb is with damm [to the medial radical letter, as shown below], (TA,) He was, or became, evil in disposition, or illnatured, (S, * A, * Msb, K, * TA,) and very perverse or cross or repugnant, (S, * A, * K, * TA,) and averse. (TA.) And $arisato nafosuhu, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. $arasN; (TA;) and $arusato, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. $araAsapN; (TA;) [His mind was, or became, evil in disposition, &c.:] ISd and others make this distinction [in respect of the inf. ns.] in the usages of the two verbs. (TA.) ― -b2- And $arisa He showed, or manifested, or he made himself an object of, love, or affection, to men. (IAar, O, K.) [Thus it has two contr. meanings.] -A2- Also, $arisa, He kept continually, or constantly, to the pasturing upon the trees called $iros. (IAar, O, K.) -A3- And $arasati AlmaA$iyapu, (AZ, AHn, O, K, *) aor. - There is no diacritic specified in the text., (AZ, O, K,) or, as written by El-Umawee and AHn,
$arisa , (TA,) inf. n. $araAsapN, The cattle ate vehemently: (AZ, AHn, O, K:) thus expl. without the particularizing of the $iros [as the pasture eaten]. (TA.) -A4- And $arasahu, (Ibn-'Abbád, O,) inf. n. $arosN, (K,) He pained him, or distressed him, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K, *) namely, his companion, (K,) with speech, (Ibn-'Abbád, O,) [i. e.,] with rough speech. (K.)

3 $Arshu * , (A, TA,) inf. n. $iraAsN (A, O, K) and mu$aArasapN, (O, K,) He treated him, or behaved towards him, or dealt with him, with hardness, (A, O, * K, * TA,) or harshness, or illnature. (A, TA.)

6 t$ArswA *
They treated one another [with hardness, or harshness, or illnature, (see 3,) or] with enmity, or hostility, (S, O, K,) and contrariety, or perverseness. (TA.)

makaAnN $arosN * , (S, O, TA,) and ↓ $arisN, (S, [both of these forms I find in my two copies of the S, the former in a poetical ex., and therefore it may perhaps be contraction of the latter by poetic license,]) and ↓ $araAsN, (TA,) A place that is rugged, or rough, (S, O, TA,) and hard: or, as in the M, rough to the fell. (TA.) And A^aroDN ↓ $arosaA='u, and ↓ $araAsK, and ↓ $araAsN, (O, K, TA, [the last written by Freytag $ur~aAsN,]) Land that is rugged, or rough, (O,) or hard, (K,) or hard and rugged or rough. (TA.)

$irosN *
Such as are small, of thorny trees; (Mgh, * K;) as also ↓ $arasN; (K;) the latter word thus expl. by AHn: (O:) or the EiDaAh of the mountain, which are the small kind of thorny trees, (S, O, TA, *) having yellow thorns, or, as some say, such as have slender thorns, growing in depressed tracts, and in the deserts (AlS~aHaAraY), but not in the plain, or soft, tracts of valleys; (TA;) such as the $uborum and HaAj (S, O) and $ukaAEaY and qataAd. (O. [See EiD~N.]) See also A^a$orasu.
$arasN * : see next preceding paragraph.

$arisa * (S, A, O, Msb, K) and ↓ $ariysN (A, O, K) and ↓ A^a$orasu (S, O, K) A man (S, O) evil in disposition, or illnatured, (S, A, O, Msb, K,) and very perverse or cross or repugnant, (S, A, O, K,) and averse: (TA:) and $arisapN and ↓ $ariysapN [both fem.] abounding in evilness of disposition or illnature, and in excessive perverseness &c. (TA.) One says also ↓ nafosN $ariysapN A mind evil in disposition, &c. (A, TA.) And ↓ naAqapN $ariysN, (TA,) or *aAtu $ariysK, (O,) or the latter also, (TA,) i. q. $arisapN[A she-camel evil in disposition, &c.]. (O.) See also A^a$orasu. ― -b2- $arisu AlA^akoli, (O, K,) or, accord. to AHn, AlA^akoli ↓ $ariysu, (TA,) Vehement in respect of eating. (AHn, O, K.) ― -b3- See also $arosN. -A2- $arisapN and ↓ $ariysapN [A land (A^aroDN)] abounding with $aras [or $iros, i. e. the trees thus called]; (TA;) [and] ↓ A^aroDN mu$orisapN a land abounding with $iros. (Yaakoob, S.)
$araAsN * : see $arosN, in two places.
$araAsK * : see $arosN.
$ariysN * : see $arisN, in six places: and A^a$orasu.

A^a$orasu * : see $arisN. Hence, (O,) AlA^a$orasu The lion; (O, K;) as also ↓ Al$~arisu, (O,) or ↓ Al$~ariysu; (K;) because of his evil disposition. (O.) ― -b2- And Bold, or daring, in fight: (O, K:) or this is a mistranscription for A^a$owasu, mentioned in the T as having this meaning. (TA.) ― -b3- Also i. q. A^afaZ~u [More, and most, evil in disposition or illnatured &c.]. (TA in art. fZ.) ― -b4- Eavara biA^a$orasi Ald~ahori, meaning (assumed tropical:) [He stumbled upon, or chanced to meet with,] hardship, calamity, or adversity: a prov. (O, K. [In Meyd (and so in Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 96,) Ald~ahori ↓ EavaronaA bi$irosi, and expl. as lit. meaning the trees called $iros.]) ― -b5- See also $arosN.

mu$orisN *
Whose camels pasture upon the [trees called] $iros. (S.) ― -b2- A^aroDN mu$orisapN: see $arisN.

$arosafapN *
Badness of natural disposition; illnature. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

$urosuwfN * The guDoruwf [or cartilage] attached to each rib; (S, O, K;) like the guDoruwf of the scapula: (S, O:) or the extremity of the rib, projecting over the belly: (S, O, K:) or the head of the rib, next the belly: (IAar, O:) or a rib having a guDoruwf [or cartilage] at its extremity: (ISd, TA:) pl. $araAsiyfu. (S, O.) -A2- A camel shackled. (IAar, O, K.) ― -b2- And A camel hocked, or hamstrung, in one of his legs. (IAar, O, K.) ― -b3- And A captive having his arms bound behind his back. (IAar, O.) -A3- Calamity, or misfortune: and the commencement of hardship. (K.) One says, A^aSaAbati Aln~aAsa Al$~araAsiyfu The commencements of hardships befell the people. (IF, O.)

$aApN mu$arosafapN *
A sheep, or goat, having in its sides a whiteness covering the $araAsiyf [pl. of $urosuwfN, q. v.,] (Lth, O, K) and the $awaAkil [pl. of $aAkilapN, q. v.]. (Lth, O.)

1 $araTa Ealayohi ka*aA * , (S, Msb, K,) aor.
$ariTa and
$aruTa , (S, Msb,) inf. n. $aroTN; (Msb;) and Elyh ↓ A$trT k*A; (S, * Msb, * K, * TA;) both signify the same; (S, Msb, K;) [He imposed such a thing as a condition, or by stipulation, upon him;] he made such a thing a condition against him. (TK.) And $araTa Ealayohi fiY AlbayoEi He imposed a thing as obligatory upon him in the sale, and took it upon himself as such. (TK.) -A2- $araTa, aor.
$ariTa and
$aruTa , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. $aroTN, (Msb, K,) He (a cupper) scarified; syn. bazaga; (S, K;) as also ↓ $r~T, inf. n. ta$oriyTN. (JK in art. bzg, and TA. *) [Hence, and from the verb in the sense first mentioned, the saying,] rub~a $aroTi $aAriTK A^awojaEu mino $aroTi $aAriTK [Many a condition of one making a condition is more painful than the scarifying of a scarifier]. (TA.) ― -b2- He slit the ear of a camel. (TA.) ― -b3- He slit. and then twisted, [or wove together, (see $ariyTN,)] palm-leaves. (TA.) -A3- $ariTa He fell into a momentous, or formidable, case. (O, K.)
2 $ar~aTa see the next preceding paragraph.

3 $ArThu * , (K,) inf. n. mu$aAraTapN, (TA,) He made a condition, or conditions, or he stipulated, with him, mutually; each of them made a condition, or conditions, or each of them stipulated, with the other. (O, L, K.) And Ealayohi ↓ t$ArT is like $aAraTa [app. meaning He made a condition, or conditions, with another, or others; or they (a party of persons) made a condition, or conditions, together; against him]. (TA.)

4 A$rT nafosahu *
He marked himself, and prepared himself, (S, K,) lika*aA (K) or liA^amori ka*aA [for such an affair]. (S.) ― -b2- He (a courageous man) marked himself for death. (TA.) ― -b3- A$rT nafosahu wamaAlahu fiY h`*aA AlA^amori He put forward, or offered, himself and his property in this affair. (TA.) ― -b4- A$rT A_ibilahu He made known that his camels were for sale. (K.) And A$rT TaAy^ifapF mino A_ibilihi waganamihi He set apart a portion of his camels, and of his sheep, or goats, and made known that they were for sale. (TA.) And A$rT mino A_ibilihi, (S, K,) and ganamihi, (S,) He prepared for sale some of his camels, (S, K,) and of his sheep, or goats. (S.) ― -b5- A^a$oraTotu fulaAnFA liEamali ka*aA I prepared such a one for such a work, or such an agency or employment, and made him to have the charge, or management, thereof. (AA.) ― -b6- A$rT A_ilayohi Alr~asuwla He hastened to him the messenger, (K, * TA,) and sent him forward: from A^a$oraATN signifying the “ beginnings ” of things. (TA.) -A2- A$rT bihaA, and fiyhaA, He held it to be, or made it, a thing of mean account, and perilled, hazarded, or risked, it. (TA.) [It is not said to what the pronoun refers.]

5 t$r~T fiY Eamalihi *
He acted, or performed, well, soundly and skilfully, or, nicely and exactly, in his work, (O, L, K,) and constrained himself to observe whatever conditions were imposed upon him. (L.)
6 ta$aAoraTa see 3.

8 A_i$otaraTa see 1, first signification. ― -b2- [Au$oturiTa It was made conditional, or a condition. And He, or it, was made to be conditionally intended, in, or by, a saying, duwna gayorihi exclusively of any other..]

10 Ast$rT AlmaAlu *
The camels, or the like, became in a bad state after having been in a good state. (Sgh, K.) [See $araTN.]

$aroTN * [A condition; a term; a stipulation; said to signify] the imposition of a thing as obligatory [upon a person], and the taking it upon oneself as such, in a sale and the like; (K;) [but this is a loose explanation, as is observed in the TK; the meaning being a thing imposed upon a person as obligatory, and taken upon oneself as such: in the S, it is merely said to be well known:] and ↓ $ariyTapN signifies the same: (S, Msb, K:) pl. of the former, $uruwTN: (S, Msb, K:) and of the latter, $araAy^iTu. (Msb, TA.) It is said in a trad., laA yajuwzu $aroTaAni fiY bayoEK [Two conditions in a sale are not allowable]; as when one says, “ I sell to thee this garment, or piece of cloth, for ready money for a deenár, and on credit for two deenárs. ” (TA.) And it is said in a prov., Al$~aroTu A^amolaku Ealayoka A^amo laka (TA) The condition is most valid, or binding, [whether it be against thee or in thy favour:] (Mgh in art. mlk:) relating to the keeping of conditions between brothers. (Sgh, TA.) [$aroTN also relates to other things beside sales and the like: for instance, you say, $aroTu AlmaSodari ka*aA waka*aA, meaning What is required to justify the application of the term mSdr is such a thing, and such a thing.] -A2- $aroTaA nahorK The two banks of a river. (TA.) ― -b2- [The pl.] $uruwTN also signifies Roads leading in different directions. (TA.) -A3- See also $araTN, in two places.

$araTN *
A sign, token, or mark, (S, Msb, K,) which men appoint between them; (TA;) as also ↓ $aroTN: (TA:) pl. of the former, A^a$oraATN. (Msb, K.) And hence, (Msb,) A^a$oraATu Als~aAEapi The signs of the resurrection, or of the time thereof; (S, Msb, TA;) mentioned in the Kur [xlvii. 20]: or the small events prior thereto, which men deny: (El-Khattábee:) or the means thereof, exclusive of the main circumstances thereof, and of the event itself. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] Al$~araTaAni The two stars [a and b] which are the two horns of Aries; (S, K, Kzw;) the brighter whereof is called Aln~aATiHu; (Kzw;) [and the other, Aln~aToHu;] the First Mansion of the Moon: (Kzw:) to- wards the north of them is a small star which some of the Arabs reckon with those two, saying that it (namely this mansion, K) consists of three stars, and calling them AlA^a$oraATu: (S, K:) IAar mentions an instance of the use of the sing., Al$~araTu; but the dual is more approved, and more commonly known: (TA:) the two stars above mentioned are the first asterism of the spring. (ISd, Z.) [See manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl.] Hassán Ibn-Thábit says,
fiY nadaAmaY biyDi Alwujuwhi kiraAmK
nub~ihuwA baEoda hajoEapi AlA^a$oraATi
meaning [Among fair-faced, generous cup-companions, roused from sleep after] the setting of the A$rAT: though another meaning, which see below, has been assigned to the last word. (Sgh.) ― -b3- And hence, (ISd, Z,) $araTN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The beginning of a thing; (ISd, * Z, * K;) as also ↓ mi$oraATN: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) pl. of the former, A^a$oraATN, which is applied to the beginnings of any event that happens because the $araTaAn are the first asterism of the spring: (ISd, Z:) the pl. of ↓ m$rAT in the sense here expl. is ma$aAriyTu. (K.) Hence, accord. to some, A^a$oraATu Als~aAEapi, expl. above. (TA.) -A2- The refuse, (S, Msb, K, TA,) such as the galled in the back, and the emaciated, (TA,) and the young, (K,) and the bad, (A'Obeyd,) of camels or the like, (S, K,) or of goats, (Msb,) or of goats also: (S:) used alike as sing. and pl. and masc. and fem.: and applied particularly to the young of camels, as a pl. and as a sing.: also, to a she-camel and to a he-camel: and to such, of camels, as is brought, or driven, from one place to another for sale; as the aged she-camel, and the camel that is galled in the back: (TA:) also the same, not ↓ $aroTN as in the K, [without restriction of its application,] low, base, vile, or mean; (K, * TA;) and so ↓ A^a$oraTu: (TA:) pl. A^a$oraATN, (S, K,) and pl. pl. A^a$aAriyTu. (S,* TA.) You say, Alganamu A^a$oraATu AlmaAli [Sheep, or goats, are the refuse, or meanest sort, of beasts that people possess]. (S.) And $araTN is also applied to men; (S, TA;) $araTu Aln~aAsi signifying The refuse, or lowest or basest or meanest sort, pf mankind or people. (TA.) In the verse of Hassán Ibn-Thábit cited above, AlA^a$oraAT is said to mean The guards, or watchmen, and the lowest or basest or meanest sort of people; (S, Sgh;) [so that hajoEap must be understood in the sense of “ a light sleep in the first part of the night; ”] but the correct meaning is that expl. before. (Sgh.) ― -b2- Also A^a$oraATN, The noble, eminent, or honourable, sort of men: thus the word has two contr. significations. (Yaakoob, S, K.) -A3- And A small water-course coming from a space of ten cubits: (AHn, O, K:) or what flows from even tracts of ground into the [larger water-courses called] $iEaAb. (TA.)

$aroTapN *
A single act of scarifying; a scarification. (Msb.)

$uroTapN *
A thing which one has made a condition. (Sgh, K.) You say, xu*o $uroTataka Take thou that which thou hast made a condition. (Sgh, K.) -A2- Also, and ↓ $uraTapN, (Mgh,) or $uraTN, (K,) which is the pl. (Mgh, K) of the former, (K,) The choice men of the army: (Mgh:) and such as compose the first portion of the army that is present in the war or fight, (Mgh, K,) and prepare for death; (K;) [the braves of an army;] they are the Sultán's choice men of the army; and the term $uroTapN is applied in a trad. to a party making it a condition to die, and not return, unless victorious: (TA:) or this appellation, and ↓ $uraTapN, which is a rare form, are applied to a body of soldiers; and the pl. is $uraTN: and the pl. is applied to the aids (A^aEowaAn [here app. meaning guards]) of the Sul- tán: (Msb:) $uroTapN, also, is applied to a wellknown body of the aids (A^aEowaAn [here meaning armed attendants, officers, or soldiers,]) of the prefects [of the police]; (K;) pl. $uraTN: (TA:) the $uraT, (As, S, Msb,) or the $uroTap, (K,) are so called because they assumed to themselves signs, or marks, whereby they might be known (As, S, Msb, K) to the enemies: (Msb:) or the $uraT are so called because they were prepared: (AO, S:) or as being likened to the $araT, or “ refuse, ” of goats; because they were low persons: (Msb:) [or, probably, because they were prepared, or exposed, to be slain:] a single person of the $uraT is called $uroTapN (S, Msb) and ↓ $uraTiY~N: (S:) or ↓ $uroTiY~N and ↓ $uroTiY~N are applied to a single person of the $uroTap: (K:) ↓ $uroTiY~N is a rel. n. from $uroTapN; and such also is ↓ $uraTiY~N from $uraTapN; not from $uraTN, because this is a pl. (Mgh.) SaAHibu Al$~uroTapi signifies The governor, or prefect, (Mgh, Msb,) [of the police, or] of a town, or city, or district, or province; to whom formerly pertained both religious and civil affairs; but now it is not so. (Mgh. [See ridofN.]) [In later times, this title has been commonly applied to The chief, or prefect, of the police.] ― -b2- Also The best, best part, or choice, of anything; as also ↓ $ariyTapN: the latter occurring in a trad., as related by Sh; but Az thinks it should be the former word. (TA.)
$uraTapN * : see $uroTapN, in two places.

$araTiY~N *
Of, or relating to, [the asterism called]
the $araTaAn and the A^a$oraAT; as also ↓ A^a$oraATiY~N; the latter being formed from the pl., (IB, TA,) because the stars thus called are regarded as composing one thing. (TA.) You say, rawoDapN ↓ A^a$oraATiy~apN, meaning [A garden, or meadow, &c.,] rained upon by the nawo' [q. v.] of the $araTaAn. (S. TA.) In the A we find ↓ nawo'N $iraATiY~N: but probably it should be $araTiY~N. (TA.)
$uroTiY~N * and $uraTiY~N: see $uroTapN, in five places.

$ariyTN *
A rope, or cord, of twisted palm-leaves: (S, Msb:) and threads of wool and of fibres of the palm-tree [twisted together]: (TA:) or palmleaves twisted together, with which is woven (yu$oraTu, as in the K, or, as in the O, accord. to the TA, yu$oraHu, [app. a mistake for yu$oraju,]) a couch, or bier, [app. meaning the part thereof upon which a man or corpse lies,] and the like: (O, K:) so called because its palm-leaves are split, and then twisted together: if of fibres of the palm-tree, it is called disaArN: (TA:) or a wide rope [or flat plait] woven of fibres or leaves of the palm-tree: (Mgh in art. qmT:) or a rope of any kind: pl. $araAy^iTu and $uruTN. (TA.) Also Threads of silk, or of silk and of gold, twisted together [or woven, so as to form a kind of flat lace, like tape]: so called as being likened to the threads of wool and of fibres of the palm-tree [twisted together]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also The [sort of basket, or small box, called] Eatiydap in which a woman puts her perfumes (IAar, O, K) and her utensils or apparatus. (IAar, O.) And The [sort of receptacle called] Eayobap [q. v.]. (IAar, O.)

$ariyTapN * : see $aroTN: ― -b2- and see also $uroTapN, last sentence. -A2- Also A she-camel having her ear slit: (K, TA:) of the measure faEiylapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN. (TA.) ― -b2- And A sheep or goat having a slight scar made upon its throat, like the scarification of the cupper, without the severing of the [veins called] A^awodaAj, and without making the blood to flow copiously: thus they used to do in the Time of Ignorance, cutting a little of the animal's throat, (K, TA,) and then leaving it to die; (TA;) and they considered it a lawful mode of slaughtering it; but the eating of such an animal is forbidden in a trad.: (K, TA:) or one scarified on account of some disease; and when such died, they said that they had slaughtered it. (TA.)
$iraATiY~N * : see $araTiY~N.

$irowaATN * , applied to a man, Tall: (O, K:) and, applied to a camel, (Ibn-'Abbád, O,) or to a hecamel, (Kudot;,) swift: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) or it is applied in the former sense to a man, and is also applied to a camel, male and female alike, ('Eyn, S,) as meaning tall and slender: ('Eyn:) or it means tall, spare of flesh, slender; applied to a man and to a camel, and to the female likewise, without p. (L.)

Alganamu A^a$oraTu AlmaAli *
Sheep, or goats, are the vilest sort of beasts that one possesses: an instance of a noun of superiority without a verb; which is extr.: (K, TA:) this is from the “ Isláh el-Alfádh ” of ISk: but in some of the copies of that work, we find A^a$oraAT in the place of A^a$oraT. (ISd, TA.) See $araTN.
A^a$oraATiY~N * : fem. with p: see $araTiY~N, in two places.

mi$oraTN *
A lancet (S, K, TA) with which the cupper scarifies; (TA;) as also ↓ mi$oraATN. (S, K, TA.)

mi$oraATN * : [pl. ma$aAriyTu:] see mi$oraTN: -A2- and see $araTN, in two places. -A3- A^axa*a liloA^amori ma$aAriyTahu He took his apparatus, [or prepared himself,] for the thing, or affair. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

1 $araEati Ald~awaAb~N fiY AlmaA='i * , (S, K,) aor.
$araEa , (S,) inf. n. $aroEN and $uruwEN, [the latter of which is the more common,] and ↓ ma$oruwEN, (TA, [there said to be syn. with $uruwEN, like as mayosuwrN is with yusorN,]) The beasts entered into the water, (S, K, TA,) and drank of it: (TA:) and $araEa, aor. as above, and so the inf. ns., he (one coming to water to drink) took the water with his mouth: (TA:) or $araEotu fiY AlmaA='i, inf. ns. as above, I drank the water with my hands: or I entered into the water: and $araEa AlmaAlu the cattle came to the water to drink: (Msb:) and Ald~aAb~apu ↓ $ar~aEati [if not a mistranscription for $ur~iEat] the beast was, or became, at the watering-place. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] $araEa fiY AlA^amori, (S, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (Msb,) inf. n. $uruwEN, (S, Msb, K,) He entered into the affair; (S, K;) he entered upon, began, or commenced, the affair. (Msb.) ― -b3- $araEa AlbaAbu A_ilaY AlT~ariyqi, inf. n. $uruwEN, The door, or entrance, communicated with the road. (Msb.) And $araEa Almanozilu The dwelling was upon, (S, K,) or had its door [opening] upon, (TA,) a road that was a thoroughfare. (S, K, TA.) ― -b4- $araEa said of a spear, It pointed directly [towards a person: see an explanation of the trans. verb in what follows]. (S, K: but in the latter, $araEat, said of spears.) See also $aroEN. ― -b5- And, said of a road, (Mgh,) and of an affair, or a case, (TA,) It was, or became, apparent, manifest, or plain. (IAar, Mgh, TA.) -A2- $araEa AlmaAla, aor. as above, [inf. n., app., $aroEN,] He brought the cattle to the watering-place; a also ↓ A$rEhu: (Msb:) and the former is trans. in this sense by means of bi: (Har p. 21:) or $araEa (TA) and ↓ $r~E, inf. n. of the latter ta$oriyEN, (S, TA,) he made the beasts, (S,) or his camels, (TA,) to enter into the water [to drink]: (S, TA: *) and naAqatahu ↓ A$rE he made his she-camel to enter into the watering-place: (TA:) or ↓ ta$oriyEN signifies the bringing camels to the wateringplace to drink without requiring in doing so to draw with the pulley and its appertenances nor to give them to drink in a watering-trough or tank. (O, K.) It is said in a prov, (S,) A^ahowanu ↓ Als~aqoYi Alt~a$oriyEu (S, K) The easiest mode of watering is the making of the camels to enter into the water: applied to him who takes an easy way of performing an affair, and does not exert himself therein. (Meyd. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 889.]) ― -b2- $araEa AlbaAba A_ilaY AlT~ariyqi He made the door, or entrance, to communicate with the road: (Msb:) and AlY AlTryq ↓ A$rEhu (S, Msb, K, TA) signifies the same; (Msb, TA;) or he opened it (i. e. the door, or entrance,) to the road. (S, Msb, K, TA.) And AljanaAHa A_ilaY AlT~ariyqi ↓ A$rE He put the jnAH [meaning projecting roof] towards the road. (Msb.) ― -b3- And $araEa (K) and ↓ A$rE (S, K, TA) and ↓ $r~E (TA) He directed (S, K, TA) a spear, (S, TA,) or spears, (K,) and a sword, (TA,) qibalaha (S) or naHowahu (TA) [i. e. towards him]: or ↓ A$rE signifies he inclined a spear. (Msb.) ― -b4- And $araEa, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) aor. as above, (Msb,) inf. n. $aroEN, (TA,) He made apparent, manifest, or plain, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) a road; (Mgh, TA;) as also ↓ A$rE; and ↓ $r~E, inf. n. ta$oriyEN: (K, TA:) and in like manner, an affair, or a case; and religion. (TA.) Accord. to Az, this meaning of $araEa is from $araEa AlA_ihaAba [which see in what follows]. (TA.) One says, $araEa A@ll~`hu lanaA ka*aA God made apparent, manifest, or plain, to us, such a thing. (Msb.) And $araEa fulaAnN Such a one made apparent, manifest, or plain, the truth, or right. (TA.) ― -b5- And $araEa lahumo i. q. san~a [i. e. He instituted, established, or prescribed, for them, or to them, a religious ordinance, a law, &c.]: (S, K) whence [accord. to some,] $ariyEapN and $iroEapN. (TA.) ― -b6- $araEa AlA_ihaAba, (S, K,) aor. as above, inf. n. $aroEN, (S,) He stripped off the hide: (S, K:) or, accord. to Yaakoob, as heard by him from Umm-El-Homáris El-Bekreeyeh, he slit the hide in the part between the two hind legs, (S, TA,) and then stripped it off: or he slit the hide, [and then stripped it off,] not making of it a ziq~ [q. v.], nor stripping it off [entire] by commencing from one hind leg. (TA.) ― -b7- $araEa AlHabola He loosed, or undid, the rope, or cord, or the slip-knot thereof, (A^ano$aTahu,) [then, app., doubled it in the middle, to put that part round something to be carried,] and inserted its two halves (quTorayohi) into the loop. (O, K.) ― -b8- And $araEa Al$~aYo'a He raised, or elevated, the thing much; (K;) as also ↓ A$rEhu. (TA.)
2 $ar~aEa see 1, in six places. -A2- $r~E Als~afiynapa, inf. n. ta$oriyEN, He made, or put, a sail ($iraAE) to the ship, or boat. (TA.)

4 A^a$oraEa see 1, former half, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, A$rE yadahu A_ilaY AlmiToharapi (assumed tropical:) He put his hand [to and] into the mThrp [or vessel for purification]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. (respecting the [ablution termed] wuDuwo'), Hat~aY A^a$oraEa fiY AlEaDudi meaning Until, or so that, he made the upper half of the arm to reach to (lit. to enter) the water. (TA. [This ex. is elliptical
and inverted; for Ht~Y A$rE AlEaDoda fiY AlmaA='i.]) ― -b3- And A^a$oraEaniY Alr~ajulu (assumed tropical:) The man sufficed me; or gave me what sufficed me: and A$rEnY Al$~aYo'u (assumed tropical:) The thing sufficed me. (TA.) ― -b4- And A^a$oraEa said of a plant, or of herbage, [app. for A^a$oraEa AlA_ibila,] (assumed tropical:) It became full-grown, and satiated the camels. (TA.) ― -b5- See, again, 1, latter half, in six places.

8 fulaAnN ya$otariEu $iroEatahu * [meaning Such a one originates, or embraces, or follows, his way of religion] is similar to the phrases yafotaTiru fiToratahu and yamotal~u mil~atahu; from $iroEapu Ald~iyni and fiToratuhu and mil~atuhu. (TA.)

$aroEN * , originally an inf. n.: ― -b2- then applied as a name for A manifest, a plain, or an open, track, or road, or way: ― -b3- and then, metaphorically, to The divine way of religion; so says Er-Rághib; (TA;) syn. with $ariyEapN, q. v. (Msb.) ― -b4- In the saying mararotu birajulK $aroEika, (so in the K,) or mrrt birajulK $aroEuka mino rajulK, (so in the S and O, [for huwa $aroEuka,]) with kesr and with damm to the E [of $rEk], (TA,) i. e. [I passed by a man] sufficing thee [as a man], (S, O, K,) the meaning is, of the sort to which thou directest thyself and which thou seekest (fiyhi wataTolubuhu ↓ ta$oraEu): (S, O:) and the word in this sense is used alike as sing. and pl. (S, O, K) and dual, because it is [originally] an inf. n. (S, O.) You say, $aroEuka h`*aA [and h`*aAni and h`w^ulaA='i] i. e. Sufficient for thee [is this and are these two and are these]. (S: and the like is said in the Mgh.) And it is said in a prov.,
$aroEuka maA bal~agaka AlmaHal~aA
thus correctly, for it is a hemistich; not AlmaHal~a, as in the S and K; (TA;) i. e. Sufficient travel-ling-provision for thee is that which will cause thee to reach the place [of alighting] to which thou repairest: (K, TA:) applied to the case of being content with little. (S, K.) ― -b5- See also $araEN, in two places. ― -b6- And see $iroEapN.

$iroEN * [in the CK, erroneously, $aroE,] The like of a thing; as also ↓ $iroEapN: (K, TA:) [but the former is masc. and ↓ the latter is fem.; for] one says, h`*aA $iroEu h`*aA This is the like of this; and so h`*ihi h`*ihi ↓ $iroEapu: and h`*aAni $iroEaAni these two are likes. (S, O, TA.) [The pls., or rather coll. gen. ns. and pls., following this meaning in the K belong to $iroEapN and $aroEapN in another sense; as is shown by exs. in the O and TA.] -A2- Also The chords of the barobaT, (O, K, TA,) which is the [Persian] Euwd [or lute]. (TA.) [In this sense, a coll. gen. n.:] see its n. un. $iroEapN. ― -b2- And hence, as being likened thereto, (TA,) (tropical:) The [thong called] $iraAk of a sandal. (O, K, TA.) It is related in a trad. that a man said, A_in~iY A^uHib~u AljamaAla Hat~aY fiY $iroEi naEoliY (O, TA) i. e. (tropical:) [Verily I love elegance, even] in the $rAk of my sandal. (TA.)

$araEN * : see $ariyEapN. -A2- One says, Aln~aAsu fiY h`*aA AlA^amori $araEN and ↓ $aroEN, (S, Msb, K,) the latter a contraction of the former, (Msb,) allowed by Kr and Kz, but disallowed by Yaakoob, (IDrst, TA,) The people are in this affair equals: (S, Msb, K:) in this sense, used alike as sing. and pl. and fem. (S, TA) and masc.: (TA:) [of $araEN] Az says that it seems to be pl. [or quasi-pl. n.] of ↓ $aAriEN, like as xadamN is of xaAdimN; i. e., [the phrase means] the people enter into this affair (ya$oraEuwna fiyhi) together. (TA.) One says also, Aln~aAsu $araEN waAHidN and wAHd ↓ $aroEN, meaning The people are one sort. (K.)
$aroEapN * : see the next paragraph, in two places.

$iroEapN * : see $ariyEapN, in two places. ― -b2- Also A custom. (TA.) ― -b3- See also $iroEN, first sentence, in three places. -A2- Also A snare for the birds called qaTFA, (Lth, O, K, TA,) with which to capture them, (O, TA,) made of sinews: (Lth, O, TA:) pl. $iraEN. (O.) ― -b2- Also, (S, O, K,) and ↓ $aroEapN, (K,) A string, or chord: (S, O, K, TA:) or such as is slender: or while continuing stretched upon the bow; (TA;) and so ↓ $iraAEN; (Lth, O, K;) or upon the lute; and so ↓ $iraAEN: (TA:) the pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] (of ↓ $iroEapN, S, O, [i. e. of this n. un. meaning the “ chord of a lute, ” as is shown by exs. in the O and TA,]) is ↓ $iroEN (S, O, K) and (that of ↓ $aroEapN, TA) ↓ $aroEN, (O, K, TA,) like as tamorN is of tamorapN, (O, TA,) and [the pl. properly so termed] (of $iroEapN, S, O) $iraEN, and pl. pl. $iraAEN: (S, O, K:) and the pl. of ↓ $iraAEN as a sing. syn. with $iroEapN is $uruEN. (TA.)

$araEapN *
i. q. saqiyfapN [i. e. A roof, or covering, such as projects over the door of a house &c.; or a place roofed over]: pl. A^a$oraAEN. (O, K.)

[
$aroEiY~N *
Of, or relating to, the religion or law. ― -b2- And Accordant to the religion or law; legal, or legitimate.]
$uraAEN * A plant, or herbage, full-grown, (O, K, TA,) that satiates the camels. (TA.)

$iraAEN * : see $ariyEapN. -A2- The $iraAEN of a ship or boat (S, Mgh, O, Msb) is called in Pers. baAdobaAn [i. e. A sail]; (MA, Mgh, KL;) i. q. qiloEN; (MA, TA;) a thing like a wide mulaA='ap [q. v.], (O, K, TA,) of cloth or of matting, (TA,) [raised, or attached,] upon a piece of wood [i. e. a mast or a yard]; which is beaten upon by the wind (tuSaf~iquhu Alr~iyHu,) and causes the ship, or boat, to go along: (O, K, TA:) so called because it is raised (yu$oraEu i. e. yurofaEu) above the ship, or boat: (TA:) pl. A^a$oriEapN and $uruEN; (O, K;) the former a pl. of pauc. (O.) ― -b2- And hence, as being likened thereto, (TA, [and the same is implied in the S and O,]) (tropical:) The neck of a camel. (S, O, K, TA.) Sometimes they said of a camel, rafaEa $iraAEahu, meaning (tropical:) He raised his neck: (S, O, TA.) ― -b3- One says also rajulN $iraAEu AlA^anofi, meaning (assumed tropical:) A man having the nose extended, and long. (TA. [See A^a$oraEu.]) ― -b4- See also $iroEapN, in three places.

$ariyEN *
Courageous; (O, K, TA;) applied to a man. (O, TA.) -A2- Also Good, or excellent, flax. (K.) ― -b2- And The lyf [or fibres that grow at the base of the branches of the palm-tree] of which the prickles ($awok) are strong, and such as, by reason of their thickness, are fit for the sewing of leather therewith. (TA.)

$araAEapN *
Courage; (O, K;) as an attribute of a man. (O.)

$ariyEapN * and ↓ ma$oraEapN (S, O, Msb, K) and ↓ ma$oruEapN (Msb, K) and ↓ ma$oraEN (TA) and ↓ $araEN (O, TA *) and maA='K ↓ $iraAEu (TA) A watering-place; a resort of drinkers [both men and beasts]; (S, O, K, TA;) a place to which men come to drink therefrom and to draw water, (Msb, * TA,) and into which they sometimes make their beasts to enter, to drink: (TA:) but the term ↓ m$rEp, (Az, Msb,) or $ryEp, (TA,) is not applied by the Arabs to any but [a watering-place] such as is permanent, and apparent to the eye, (Az, Msb, TA,) like the water of rivers, (Msb,) not water from which one draws with the well-rope: (Az, Msb, TA:) the pl. of $ariyEapN is $araAy^iEu; and that of ↓ ma$oraEapN or ↓ ma$oraEN [or of both] is ma$aAriEu; which is also expl. as meaning gaps, or breaches, in the banks of rivers or the like by which men or beasts come to water: (TA:) and [in like manner it is said that] $ariyEapN signifies a place of descent to water: (Lth, TA:) or a way to water. (Bd in v. 52.) ― -b2- And hence, (Lth, Kr, Msb, TA, and Bd ubi suprà,) Al$~ariyEapu, (Lth, Kr, S, Msb, K, &c.,) as also ↓ Al$~iroEapu, (Msb, K, &c.,) and ↓ Al$~aroEu, (Msb,) signifies likewise Ald~iynu; (Msb, and Bd ubi suprà;) because it is a way to the means of eternal life; (Bd ibid.;) or because of its manifestness; (Msb;) [i. e.] The religious law of God; (Lth, Kr, S, O, K, * TA;) consisting of such ordinances as those of fasting and prayer and pilgrimage (Lth, Kr, TA) and the giving of the poorrate (Kr, TA) and marriage, (Lth, TA,) and other acts (Lth, Kr, TA) of piety, or of obedience to God, or of duty to Him and to men: (Kr, TA:) pl. as above. (Msb.) $ariyEapN signifies also [A law, an ordinance, or a statute: and] a religion, or way of belief and practice in respect of religion: (Fr, TA:) and a way of belief or conduct that is manifest (Ibn-'Arafeh, Mgh, K) and right (Ibn-'Arafeh, K) in religion; (Mgh;) and so ↓ $iroEapN. (K.)

$uraAEiY~N * , as an epithet applied to A spear-head and a spear, of Shuráa, (TA,) which was the name of a certain man who made spear-heads and spears, (K, TA,) as they assert: but IAar says that it may be a reg. rel. n. from $uraAEN, or an irreg. rel. n. from some other name of which the radical latters are $rE: and [SM says also that,] applied to a spear, it signifies long: (TA:) or ↓ $iraAEiY~N, thus applied, has this meaning, a rel. n. [from $iraAEN]. (S, O.) $uraAEiy~apN and ↓ $iraAEiy~apN [in the
CK without teshdeed], applied to a she-camel, signify (tropical:) Long-necked; (O, K, TA:) thus expl. by ISh: but Az thinks the latter to be the more probably correct; the neck being likened to the $iraAE of the ship or boat, because of the height thereof. (O.)
$iraAEiY~N * ; and its fem., with p: see the next preceding paragraph.

$ar~aAEN *
A seller of the flax called $ariyE. (IAar, K.)

$aAriEN *
Entering into water [to drink]: pl. $ur~aEN and $uruwEN: (KL:) these pls. are applied in this sense to camels. (S, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Entering into an affair (fiY A^amorK). (Az, TA.) See $araEN. ― -b3- And sing. of $ur~aEN in the phrase HiytaAnN $ur~aEN, (TA,) which means Fishes lowering their heads to drink: (Aboo-Leylà, TA:) or raising their heads: (K, TA:) or directing themselves, or repairing, ($aAriEaAtN,) from the deep water to the bank, or side: (S, TA:) and HytAn $uruwEN signifies the same: (TA:) or $ur~aEFA in the Kur vii. 163, referring to fish, means appearing upon the surface of the water. (Bd, Jel. *) ― -b4- Also, applied to a place of alighting, or an abode, (manozilN,) Situate upon a road that is a thoroughfare: and $aAriEapN applied to a house (daArN) signifies the same; (K;) or having its door [opening] upon such a road; (TA;) or near to the road and to the people [or passengers]: (Mgh, * TA:) and duwrN $aAriEapN houses having their doors opening into the streets: or duwrN $awaAriEu, as expl. by IDrd, houses upon one open road. (TA.) It is said in a trad., kaAnati AlA^abowaAbu $aAriEapF A_ilaY Almasojidi The doors were opening towards the mosque. (TA.) ― -b5- And Anything near (K, TA) to a thing, or overlooking it: whence $aAriEapN applied to a house (daArN) near to the road and to the people, as expl. above. (TA.) [Hence,] nujuwmN $awaAriEu Stars near to setting. (K.) ― -b6- [Also Pointing directly towards a person; applied to a spear.] One says rimaAHN $aAriEapN and $awaAriEu (K, TA) and $ur~aEN as in some of the copies of the S (TA) Spears pointing directly: and ↓ rimaAHN ma$oruwEapN and ↓ mu$oraEapN spears directed. (K, TA.) ― -b7- Also [used as a subst.] A main road: (S, O:) or it signifies, (Mgh, TA,) or so TariyqN $aAriEN, (Msb,) (tropical:) a road, or way, into which people enter (yasolukuhu Aln~aAsu, Msb, or ya$oraEu fiyhi Aln~aAsu, Mgh, TA) in common, or in general; (Mgh, Msb, TA;) by a tropical attribution; (Mgh;) [i. e.] $aAriEN in this case has the meaning of ma$oruwEN [or ma$oruwEN fiyhi]; (Msb;) or as meaning *uw $aroEK mina Alxaloqi [having an entering of people]: (TA:) or it signifies a manifest, plain, or conspicuous, road or way: (Mgh, TA:) [in the present day, $aAriEN commonly signifies any great street that is a thoroughfare:] the pl. is $awAriEu. (Msb.) -A2- Al$~aAriEu also means The learned man who practises what he knows and instructs others: (K, TA:) or so Al$~aAriEu Alr~ab~aAniY~u. (O.) And hence it is applied to designate the Prophet: [or as meaning The legislator: or the announcer of the law:] or because he made manifest and plain the religion, or religious law of God. (TA.)
