A^a$oraEu * A nose of which the end is extended (K, TA) and elevated, and long. (TA.)
ma$oraEN * : see $ariyEapN, in two places.
mu$oraEN * : see its fem., with p, voce $aAriEN.
ma$oraEapN * and ma$oruEapN: see $ariyEapN, in four places.

bayotN mu$ar~aEN *
A high, or lofty, house or tent. (TA.)
ma$oruwEN * : see its fem., with p, voce $aAriEN: -A2- see also 1, first sentence.

1 $arufa * , (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
$arufa , (K,) inf. n. $arafN (S, * O, * Msb, * K, TA) and $araAfapN, (TA,) said of a man, (S, O, TA,) He was, or became, high, elevated, exalted, or eminent, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) [in rank, condition, or estimation,] in respect of religion or of worldly things: (K, TA:) [generally meaning he was high-born, or noble:] part. n. $ariyfN [q. v.]. (S, O, Msb, K, TA.) [See also $arafN, below.] ― -b2- [Hence one says,] $arufato nafosuhu Eani Al$~aYo'i His soul was above the thing; disdained, or scorned, it. (L in art. Anf.) ― -b3- $arafati Aln~aAqapu, and $arufat, (O, K,) aor. of each
$arufa , inf. n. $uruwfN, (K,) reg. as of the former verb, and irreg. as of the latter, (TA,) The she-camel was, or became, such as is termed $aArifN [q. v.]. (O, K.) -A2- $arafahu, aor.
$arufa , (IJ, S, O, K, TA,) inf. n. $arofN, (TA,) He overcame him, or surpassed him, in $araf [i. e. highness, elevation, or eminence, of rank, condition, or estimation; or nobility]; (IJ, S, O, K, TA;) and so $arufa Ealayohi: (Z, TA:) or he excelled him (TaAlahu, K, TA, in the CK [erroneously] TAwalahu,) in the grounds of pretension to respect or honour (fiY AlHasabi). (K, TA.) See 3. ― -b2- $arafa AlHaAy^iTa, (K, TA,) aor.
$arufa , inf. n. $arofN, (TA,) He put to the wall a $urofap [q. v.]. (K, TA.) [See also 2.] -A3- $arifati AlA^u*unu, and $arifa Almanokibu, aor.
$arafa , (K, TA,) inf. n. $arafN, (TA,) The ear, and in like manner the shoulder, was, or became, high, (K, TA,) and prominent: or, as some say, stood up. (TA.) -A4- And $arifa, [from $arafN signifying the “ hump ” of a camel,] (O, K,) said of a man, (O,) He kept constantly, or continually, to the eating of the [camel's] hump. (O, K.)

2 $r~fhu * , inf. n. ta$oriyfN, He (God) rendered him high, elevated, exalted, or eminent, [in rank, condition, or estimation; or ennobled him:] (S, KL, * PS: *) and he held him, or esteemed him, to be so. (MA, PS.) ISd thinks that the verb may also mean He regarded with more, or exceeding, honour. (TA.) [And Golius explains it as meaning He decked with a royal garment; on the authority of the KL; in my copy of which I find no other meaning assigned to it than the first mentioned above.] One says, $ar~afa A@ll~`hu AlkaEobapa, (O, K, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) [God rendered, or may God render, the Kaabeh an object of honour, or glorious,] from Al$~arafu, (O, K, TA,) i. e. Almajodu. (TA.) [ta$oriyfN is also used as a subst. properly so called; and as such is expl. by itself in this art.] ― -b2- Also He put to it $uraf [pl. of $urofapN, q. v.]; (O, K;) namely, his house, (K,) or a [palace, or pavilion, or other building such as is called] qaSor, &c.; inf. n. as above. (O.) [See also $arafa AlHaAy^iTa.] ― -b3- $r~f AlmarobaA^a, expl. in the K as syn. with A$rfhu and $Arfhu, is a mistake for t$r~fhu [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b4- $r~f Aln~aAqapa, inf. n. as above, means He almost severed the teats of the she-camel by binding them [tightly] with the SiraAr [q. v.]: (IAar, O, TA:) this being done for the preservation of her [stoutness of] body, and her fatness, so that burdens may be put upon her in the coming year. (TA.) ― -b5- [$r~f, app. for $r~f AlEunuqa, is also said by Reiske, as mentioned by Freytag in his Lexicon, to signify He (a camel going along) raised the neck: but his authority for this is not stated.]

3 $Arfhu * , (S, O, K,) inf. n. mu$aArafapN, (TA,) He vied with him, or contended with him for superiority, in $araf [i. e. highness, elevation, or eminence, of rank, condition, or estimation; or nobility]; (S, O, K, TA;) ↓ fa$arafahu and he overcame, or surpassed, him therein. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 5. ― -b3- Also He was, or became, near to it; he drew near to it, or approached it; namely, a thing: and he was, or became, near to attaining it, [and in like manner $Arf Ealayohi, as used in the S and K in the beginning of art. blg, he was, or became, at the point of reaching it, or attaining it, namely, a place,] or of obtaining it, or getting possession of it: [and he was, or became, at the point of experiencing it, (See Bd in lxxviii. 14,) and doing it; followed by A^ano and an aor.:] and, as some say, he looked for it, or expected it; his mind told him of it; he looked for its coming to pass. (TA.) See also 4, in two places.

4 A$rf *
It rose; or it was, or became, high or elevated; [so as to overtop, or overlook, what was around it or adjacent to it: overtopped, surmounted, overpeered, overlooked, overhung; was, or became, protuberant, prominent, or projecting: and rose into view, came within sight or view, or became within a commanding, or near, view:] said of a place [&c.]. (Msb.) One says of a piece of ground, A^a$orafa EalaY maA Hawolahu [It rose above, or overtopped, what was around it]. (Sh, TA.) And A^a$orafa liY $arafN famaA zilotu A^arokuDu Hat~aY Ealawotuhu [An eminence rose into view to me, and I ceased not to urge on my beast until I ascended, or mounted, upon it]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A^a$orafotu Ealayohi I looked upon it, or viewed it, (S, O, Msb, K, *) from above; (S, O, K;) [I overlooked it, or looked down upon it: and I came in sight of it: got a view of it: and got knowledge of it; became acquainted with it; or knew it: all of which meanings may be intended to be conveyed by the explanation in the Msb, which is AiT~alaEotu Ealayohi:]
and Al$~aYo'a ↓ $aArafotu signifies the same as A^a$orafotu Ealayohi [app. in the first of the senses expl. in this sentence, as well as in another sense expl. in what follows]: (S, O:) and ↓ $aArafuwhumo signifies the same as A^a$orafuwA Ealayohimo. (TA.) ― -b3- And A$rf EalaY Almawoti He (a sick man) was, or became, on the brink, or verge, or at the point, of death. (O, K.) And A$rf bihi EalaY Almawoti [He made him to be on the brink, or verge, or at the point, of death]. (T and K in art. *rf.) ― -b4- And A^a$orafato nafosuhu EalaY $aYo'K His soul was vehemently eager for a thing. (Mgh. [See also 10.]) A_i$oraAfN signifies The being eager, and the being vehemently eager: and hence the saying, in a trad., mano A^axa*a Ald~unoyaA biA_i$oraAfi nafosK lamo yubaArako lahu fiyhaA [Whoso takes the enjoyments of the present world with eagerness, or vehement eagerness, of soul, he will not be blessed therein]. (TA.) ― -b5- And A$rf Ealayohi He regarded him with solicitous affection or pity or compassion. (O, * K.) ― -b6- [And A$rf liY He, or it, came within sight, or view, to me; or came within a commanding, or near, view of me: see an ex. voce A^ajohada; and another voce rabaA^a.] ― -b7- And [hence,] A$rf laka Al$~aYo'u The thing became, or has become, within thy power or reach; or possible, practicable, or easy, to thee. (TA.) -A2- See also 5, in two places.

5 t$r~f * , said of a man, is from Al$~arafu, (O,) and signifies SaAra mu$ar~afFA [He became elevated, or exalted, in rank, condition, or estimation; or ennobled]. (K.) ― -b2- t$r~f bihi He became elevated, or exalted, in rank, condition, or estimation; or ennobled; by, or by means of, him, or it: (MA:) [or he gloried, or prided himself, by reason of it, or in it; i. e.] he reckoned it, (S,) or regarded it, (O,) as a glory or an honour [to himself], (S, O,) and a favour. (O.) -A2- t$r~f AlmarobaA^a, (S, O, TA,) in the K, erroneously, $ar~afahu; (TA;) and ↓ A$rfhu; (S, O, K;) and ↓ $Arfhu, (K,) inf. n. mu$aArafapN; (TA;) He (a man, S, O) ascended, or mounted, upon the elevated place of observation. (S, O, K.) And Al$~aYo'a ↓ A$rf and EalaY Al$~aYo'i signify the same as [t$r~fhu and] t$r~f Ealayohi, i. e. He ascended, or mounted, upon the thing. (TA.) ― -b2- It is said in a trad., with reference to certain future trials, or conflicts and factions, (fitan,) mano ↓ ta$ar~afa lahaA tasota$orifohu i. e. Whoso finds a place of refuge [for escaping, or avoiding them, let them invite him, or cause him, to seek, or take, refuge, virtually meaning] let him seek, or take, refuge therein. (O, TA. *) -A3- tu$ur~ifa Alqawomu The people, or party, had their A^a$oraAf [or eminent, or noble, men, pl. of $ariyf,] slain. (O, K.)

8 A$trf *
He, or it, stood up, or upright, or erect; (S, O, TA;) and (TA) so ↓ Ast$rf [if this be not a mistranscription, which I incline to think it may be as the former verb (of which see the part. n. below) is not mentioned in the K]. (K, TA.)

10 Ast$rf Al$~aYo'a * , (S, O, Msb, K,) and lil$~aYo'i, (Msb in art. TmH,) He raised his eyes (S, O, Msb, K) towards the thing, (O, K,) or to look at the thing, (Msb,) or looking at the thing, (S,) and expanded his hand over his eyebrow like as does he who shades [his eyes] from the sun. (S, O, K.) A poet says,
taTaAlalotu waA@sota$orafotuhu faraA^ayotuhu
faqulotu lahu A=A^anota zayodu AlA^araAmili
[I stretched up myself, and raised my eyes towards him, expanding my hand over my eyebrow like him who is shading his eyes from the sun; and I said to him, Art thou Zeyd-el-Arámil?]. (O.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) A^umironaA A^ano nasota$orifa AlEayona waAlA^u*una, (Mgh, * O, K, TA,) in a trad. (O, TA) relating to the sheep or goat to be slaughtered as a victim on the day of sacrifice, (TA,) means We have been commanded to pay much attention to the eye and the ear, and to examine them carefully, in order that there may not be any such defect as blindness of one eye or mutilation (Mgh, * O, K, TA) of an ear: (TA:) or, (Mgh, O,) as some say, (O,) [in the K “ that is, ”] to seek that they be of high estimation, by being perfect (Mgh, * O, K) and sound: (Mgh, O:) or, accord. to some, it is from Al$~urofapu signifying “ the choice ones, ” or “ best, ” of cattle; and the meaning is, we have been commanded to select them. (TA.) ― -b3- And yasota$orifu maEaAliYa AlA^umuwri (tropical:) He desires, or seeks, [or raises his eye to,] the means of attaining eminence. (Msb in art. $wf.) ― -b4- Ast$rf A_ibilahumo means He (a man) smote their camels with the [evil] eye; syn. taEay~anahaA: (S, TA:) or he looked at them (tEy~nhA) to smite them with the [evil] eye. (TA.) ― -b5- Ast$rfhu Haq~ahu He defrauded him of his right, or due. (O, K.) -A2- See also 5: -A3- and 8.

Q. Q. 1 $aroyafotu Alz~aroEa *
I cut off the $iroyaAf [q. v.] of the seed-produce; (S, O;) and so $aronafotuhu: (O and K * in art. $rnf:) of the dial. of El-Yemen: but Az doubts whether the word be with n; and the Y and n are both held by him to be augmentative. (O.)
$arofN * : see the next paragraph, near the end.

$arafN *
Highness, elevation, exaltation, or eminence, [in rank, condition, or estimation, in respect of religion or of worldly things: (see the first sentence of this art.:)] (S, O, Msb, K:) [generally meaning high birth:] glory, honour, dignity, or nobility; syn. majodN: or not unless [transmitted] by ancestors: (K:) [for] accord. to ISk, $arafN and majodN may not be unless [transmitted] by ancestors; but HasabN and karamN may be in a man though he have not ancestors [endowed therewith]: (O:) or, (K,) accord. to IDrd, (O,) it signifies highness of Hasab [which means grounds of pretension to respect or honour, consisting in any qualities (either of oneself or of one's ancestors) which are enumerated, or recounted, as causes of glorying]: (O, K:) and ↓ $urofapN signifies the same as $arafN; (TA;) or the same as faDolN and $arafN [meaning a favour and a glory or an honour]; as in the saying, A^aEud~u A_itoyaAnakumN $urofapF [I reckon your coming a favour, and a glory or an honour]; (O, K;) and A^araY *`lika $urofapF [I regard that as a favour, and a glory or an honour]: (O:) the pl. of $arafN is A^a$oraAfN, like as that of sababN is A^asobaAbN. (TA.) nuhobapN *aAtu $arafK means Spoil, or booty, of high value, at which men raise their eyes, and look, or which they smite with the [evil] eye: [see Aisota$orafa A_ibilahumo:] but the phrase is also related with s. (TA. See sarafN.) ― -b2- See also $ariyfN, with which, or with the pls. of which, it is said to be syn. ― -b3- Also An elevated place; an eminence: (S, Mgh, O, K:) accord. to Sh, any piece of ground that overtops what is around it, whether extended or not, only about ten cubits, or five, in length, of little or much breadth in its upper surface: (TA:) pl. A^a$oraAfN: (TA voce waTo'N:) and ma$aArifu AlA^aroDi signifies the high, or elevated, places, or parts, of the earth or ground: (S, Msb, K:) sing. ↓ ma$orafN, with fet-h to the m and r. (Msb. [See also mu$orafN.]) A poet says,
A=tiY Aln~adiY~a falaA yuqar~abu majolisiY
waA^aquwdu lil$~arafi Alr~afiyEi HimaAriY
[I come to the assembly, and my sitting-place is not made near to the chief person or persons, and I lead to the high elevated place my ass]: he means, I have become unsound in my intellect in consequence of old age, so that no profit is gotten from my opinion, and I am not able to mount my ass from the ground, unless from a high place. (S.) ― -b4- [Hence, (tropical:) The brink, verge, or point, of some event of great magnitude, or of any importance: not well expl. as meaning] the being on the brink, or verge, or at the point, of some event of great importance, good or evil: (O, K:) one says in the case of good, huwa EalaY $arafK mino qaDaA='i HaAjatihi (tropical:) [He is at the point of accomplishing the object of his want]: and in the case of evil, huwa EalaY $arafK mina AlhalaAki (tropical:) [He is on the brink, &c., of destruction]. (O, TA.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) The hump of a camel. (O, K, TA.) ― -b6- And app. sing. of A^a$oraAfN in a sense expl. below: see the latter word. (TA.) -A2- And A heat; a single run, or a run at once, to a goal, or limit: (O, K:) or, (K,) accord. to Fr, about a mile: (O, K:) or about two miles. (TA as from the K and on the authority of Fr.) One says, EadaA $arafFA A^awo $arafayoni [He ran a heat, or two heats]: (O:) and [in like manner,] Aisotan~atN $arafFA A^awo $arafayoni, (O, K,) occurring in a trad., said of a mare, or of horses. (O.) -A3- Also, (O, TA,) accord. to IAar, (O,) A red clay or earth: and i. q. magorapN [i. e. red ochre]; as also ↓ $arofN: accord. to Lth, a kind of trees, having a red dye: and said to be the same as [the Pers.] dAr PrnyAn [i. e. daAro ParoniyaAn, meaning Brazil-wood, which is commonly called in Arabic baq~am]. (O, TA: * in the former of which, the Pers. word here mentioned is written without the points to the P; and in the latter, AldAbrnyAn.)

$urofapN * : see the next preceding paragraph, first quarter. ― -b2- Also The choice ones, or best, of maAl [meaning cattle]. (S, O, K.) ― -b3- The $urofap of a [palace, or pavilion, or other building such as is called] qaSor (S, O, Msb, K) [and of a mosque] is
well-known; (K;) [An acroterial ornament, forming a single member of a cresting of a wall or of the crown of a cornice, generally of a fanciful form, and pointed, or small, at the top:] pl. $urafN, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K, TA,) a pl. of mult., and $urufaAtN and $urafaAtN and $urofaAtN, which are pls. of pauc., or, as some say, $rfAt [i. e. $urufaAtN] is pl. of ↓ $urufapN, with two dammehs: EshShiháb says that $urofaAt is expl. as meaning the highest portions of a qaSor; but what are thus termed are only what are built on the top of a wall, distinct from one another, [side by side, like merlons of a parapet,] according to a well-known form: (TA:) the $urofap is what is called by the [common] people ↓ $ur~aAfap: (Ham p. 824:) the $ur~aAfap of a mosque is a word used by the lawyers, and is one of their mistakes, as IB has notified: so says MF: its pl. is $araAriyfu. (TA.) ― -b4- The $urufaAt (thus with two dammehs, K) of a horse are The neck and qaTaAp [i. e. croup, or rump, or part between the hips or haunches,] thereof. (O, K.)
$urufapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

$ariyfN *
High, elevated, exalted, or eminent, (S, O, * Msb, K, TA,) [in rank, condition, or estimation,] in respect of religion or of worldly things: (TA:) [generally meaning high-born, or noble:] possessing glory, honour, dignity, or nobility: or such, and having also [such] ancestry: (TA:) [using it as not implying highness, or nobility, of ancestry,] you say, huwa $ariyfN Alyawoma [He is high, or noble, to-day], and Eano qaliylK ↓ $aArifN as meaning one who will be $ariyf [after a little while]: (Fr, S, K:) the pl. [of pauc.] is A^a$oraAfN and [of mult.] $urafaA='u (S, O, Msb, K) and ↓ $arafN, so in the K, app. denoting that this last is one of the pls. of $ryf, and it is said in the O that $arafN is syn. with $urafaA='u; but in the L it is said that it is syn. with $ariyfN; and hence the saying huwa $arafu qawomihi meaning He is the $ariyf of his people, and karamuhumo meaning the kariym of them; and thus it has been expl. as used in a trad.: (TA:) [but both these assertions are probably correct; for it seems to be, agreeably with analogy, an inf. n. used as an epithet, and therefore applicable to a single person and to a pl. number, and also to two persons, and likewise to a female as well as to a male.] ― -b2- [By the modern Arabs, and the Turks and Persians, it is also applied, as a title of honour, to Any descendant of the Prophet; like say~id. And, with the article Al, particularly to the descendant of the Prophet who is The governor of Mekkeh; now always a vassal of the Turkish Sultán.]

$uraAfiY~N * , applied to a [lizard of the kind called] Dab~, and to a jerboa, Large in the ears, and in the body: (TA:) and so $uraAfiy~apN applied to a she-camel; (O, K, TA;) as also ↓ $arofaA='u. (TA.) And A^u*unN $uraAfiy~apN i. q. $ufaAriy~apN [q. v.], (K, TA,) or An ear that is high, long, and having hair upon it. (IDrd, O, TA.) See also A^u*unN $arofaA='u, voce A^a$orafu. ― -b2- Also A kind of white garments or cloths: (O, K: *) or a garment, or piece of cloth, that is purchased from a country of the foreigners adjacent to the land of the Arabs. (As, O, K. *)
$ur~aAfapN * ; pl. $araAriyfu: see $urofapN.

$iroyaAfN * (S, O, K) and $ironaAfN (O and K in art. $rnf) [but see Q. Q. 1] The leaves of seedproduce that have become so long and abundant that one fears its becoming marred; wherefore they are cut off. (S, O, K.)

$aArifN * : see $ariyfN. ― -b2- Applied to a she-camel, (assumed tropical:) High [app. meaning much advanced] in age: (A, TA:) or advanced in age; (S, O, K;) decrepit; (IAar, K;) as also $aArifapN: (K:) [see daluwqN, in three places:] pl. $urofN, like buzolN and Euw*N pls. of baAzilN and EaAy^i*N, (S, O,) or $urufN, like kutubN, (K,) or the latter is allowable in poetry, (O,) or the former is a contraction of the latter, (IAth, TA,) and $awaArifu [also pl. of $aArifapN] (O, K) and $ur~afN and $uruwfN: (K:) it is said that $aArifN is not applied to the he-camel; but it is so applied, as well as to the she-camel, accord. to the Towsheeh of El-Jelál. (TA.) Hence, as being likened to black decrepit she-camels, (Aboo-Bekr, TA,) Al$~urufu Aljuwnu, with two dammehs, [which I think a mistake, unless it mean with a dammeh to each word,] (K,) or Al$~arofu Aljuwnu, (O, IAth, TA,) occurring in a trad., meaning (assumed tropical:) [Trials, or conflicts and factions,] like portions of the dark night: (O, * K, * TA:) thus expl. by the Prophet: (O, TA:) but some relate it otherwise, with q, (K,) saying Al$~uroqu Aljwn, pl. of $aAriqN, (O, * TA,) meaning “ [trials, &c.,] rising (O, K, TA) from the direction of the east. ” (O, TA.) ― -b3- Also applied to an arrow, as meaning Old: (S, O, K:) and applied to a garment or a piece of cloth [app. in the same sense]: (A and TA voce TariydN:) or an arrow long since laid by [expl. by baEiydu AlEahodi biAlS~iyaAbapi; but I think that the right reading is bEyd AlEhd liAlS~iyaAnapi, and have assumed this to be the case in my rendering]: or of which the feathers and the sinews [wherewith they are bound] have become uncompact: or slender and long. (TA.) ― -b4- dan~N $aArifN [A wine-jar] of which the wine is old. (TA.) ― -b5- And $aArifN [alone] A receptacle for wine, such as a xaAbiyap and the like thereof. (O, K.)

Al$~aAruwfu *
A kind of cord or rope; syn. HabolN: [so in the O, and in one of my copies of the S: in my other copy of the S, and in the K, jabalN, i. e. the name of a certain mountain:] a postclassical word. (S, O.) ― -b2- And $aAruwfN also signifies A broom: (S, O, K:) a Pers. word, (S,) arabicized, from jaAruwbN, (O, K,) originally jaAYo ruwbo, which means “ a place-sweeper. ” (O.)

A^a$orafu * [More, and most, high, elevated, exalted, or eminent, in rank, condition, or estimation; &c.; generally meaning more, and most, high-born or noble; (see $ariyfN;)] surpassing in $araf. (S, O.) ― -b2- manokibN A^a$orafu A high shoulder; (S, O, K;) such as has a goodly rising; which implies what is termed A_ihodaA=' [inf. n. of A^ahodaA^ahu, and here app. meaning the “ being curved in the back ”]. (TA.) And A^u*unN $arofaA='u A long ear; (S, O, K;) standing up; rising above what is next to it: and so A*n ↓ $uraAfiy~apN. (TA.) ― -b3- See also $uraAfiY~N [A^a$orafu also signifies Having a prominent, or an apparent, ear: opposed to A^asak~u, q. v. ― -b4- Hence,] AlA^a$orafu is an appellation of The bat; (O, K, TA;) because its ears are prominent and apparent: it is bare of downy and other feathers, and is viviparous, not oviparous: so in the saying of Bishr Ibn-ElMoatemir,
waTaAy^irN layosa lahu wakoru
waTaAy^irN A^a$orafu *uw jurodapK
[And a flying thing that has prominent and apparent ears and a denuded body, and a flying thing that has no nest]: (O, TA:) in the K is added, and another bird, that has no nest, &c.: but this is taken from an explanation of the latter hemistich of the verse cited above; which explanation is as follows: (TA:) the bird that has no nest is one of which the Bahránees [so in the TA, but accord. to the O “ the sailors, ”] tell that it does not alight save while it makes, of the dust, or earth, a place in which it lays its eggs, and which it covers over; then it flies into the air, and its eggs break open of themselves at the expiration of the term thereof; and when its young ones are able to fly, they do after the habit of their parents. (O, L, TA: and the same is said, less fully, in the K.) ― -b5- madiynapN $arofaA='u A city having $uraf, (Mgh, O, K, *) pl. of $urofapN [q. v.]: (O:) the pl. of A^a$orafu and of $arofaA='u, accord. to rule, is $urofN. (Mgh. [In the copies of the K, Al$~urufu is erroneously said to be pl. of Al$~arofaA='u.]) It is said in a trad. of Ibn- ' Abbás, A^umironaA A^ano naboniYa AlmadaAy^ina $urofFA waAlmasaAjida jum~FA i. e. We have been commanded to build cities with $uraf and mosques without $uraf. (Mgh, O. *)
A^a$oraAfN * The ears and nose of a man: (O, K, TA:) its sing. in this sense is not mentioned: it is app. ↓ $arafN; like sababN, sing. of A^asobaAbN. (TA.)

ta$oriyfN * inf. n. of 2 [q. v.]. (S &c.) ― -b2- [And also a post-classical term applied to An honorary present, such as a garment &c.: and a letter, i. e. an epistle, considered as conferring honour: pl. ta$oriyfaAtN.]
ma$orafN * : see $arafN, in the middle of the paragraph: and see also what here next follows.

mu$orafN * , (O, K,) like mukoramN, (K,) or ↓ ma$orafN [q. v. voce $arafN], (so in my two copies of the S,) A place from which one overlooks, i. e. looks upon, or views, [a thing] from above. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- Hence the saying in a trad., maA jaA='aka mino h`*aA AlmaAli waA^anota gayoru mu$orafK walaA saAy^ilK faxo*ohu (O, TA) i. e. [What comes to thee of this property] thou not coveting nor looking for it [nor asking it, take it]. (O.)

mu$orifN * [part. n. of 4;] High; (S, Mgh, Msb;)
[or overtopping; &c.;] applied to a mountain, (S,) or a place. (Mgh, Msb.)

suyuwfN ma$orafiy~apN *
Certain swords, (S, O, K,) so called in relation to ma$aArifu, (S,) or in relation to ma$aArifu Al$~aAmi, (O, Msb, K,) i. e. certain towns, or villages, of the land of the Arabs, near to the riyf [q. v.]: (S, O, Msb, K:) so says AO: (S, O:) or, as some say, this is a mistake, and they are so called in relation to a place of El-Yemen: (Msb:) [or, accord. to some, in relation to Alma$aArifu, certain towns, or villages, near Howrán: (see De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., iii. 53:)] and it is said that ma$oraf was the name of a blacksmith who made swords: (TA:) one says sayofN ma$orafiY~N, (S, O, Msb,) not ma$aArifiY~N, because a rel. n. is not formed from a pl. of the measure of ma$aArifu. (S, O.)

mu$ar~afN * [Elevated, or exalted, in rank, condition, or estimation; or ennobled]; (K, TA;) an epithet applied to a man; from Al$~arafu. (TA.) -A2- Also A garment, or piece of cloth, dyed with the red clay or earth [&c.] called $araf. (IAar, TA.)
ma$oruwfN * (S, TA) and ma$oruwfN Ealayohi (Z, TA) Overcome, or surpassed, in $araf [i. e. highness, elevation, or eminence, of rank, condition, or estimation; or nobility]. (S, Z, TA.)
mu$otarifN * A horse high in make. (S, O, K.)

1 $araqati Al$~amosu * , (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
$aruqa , (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. $uruwqN (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and $aroqN, (S, Msb,) The sun rose; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ A^a$oraqat: (K:) the sun rose from the east; and in like manner one says of the moon, and of the stars: (M:) or the sun rose so that its light began to fall upon the earth and trees: (T and TA in art. *r:) and ↓ A$rqt signifies, as distinguished from $araqat, (S, M, Mgh, Msb,) or signifies also, (K, TA,) for both verbs are correctly expl. in the K as above, (TA,) it shone, or gave its light, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) and spread (M, TA) upon the earth, or ground: (TA:) or, as some say, $araqat, and ↓ A$rqt are syn., (M, Msb,) as meaning it (the sun) shone: (M:) and $aroqN [as inf. n. of the former verb] signifies the shining of the sun. (K.) ― -b2- And $araqa Aln~axolu, and ↓ A$rq, The palm-trees showed redness in their fruit: (M, K: *) or showed the colours of their dates. (AHn, M.) [See also $ariqa in what follows.] -A2- $araqa Al$~aApa, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
$aruqa , (S, O, Msb,) inf. n. $aroqN, He slit the ear of the sheep, or goat, (S, O, Msb, K,) in the manner expl. voce $aroqaA='u. (Msb.) ― -b2- And $araqa Alv~amarapa, (Az, K,) inf. n. $aroqN, (IAmb, Az, TA,) He plucked the fruit: (Az, K, TA:) or cut it. (IAmb, Az, TA.) One says in crying baAqil~aA=' [or beans], $aroqu AlgadaApi TariY~N The cutting of the morning, fresh! meaning what has been cut, and picked, in the morning. (IAmb, Az, TA.) -A3- $ariqa, [aor.
$araqa ,] inf. n. $araqN, It (a place) was, or became, bright by reason of the sun's shining upon it; as also ↓ A$rq; (M, TA;) [whence,] A@loA^aroDu binuwri rab~ihaA ↓ waA^a$oraqati occurs in the Kur [xxxix. 69 as meaning And the earth shall shine with the light of its Lord]: (M:) [in other instances,] A^a$oraqati AlA^aroDu means The earth was, or became, bright with the sunshine. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps, or, though not immediately, from what here next follows, some other applications of this verb, to denote redness.] ― -b3- $ariqa biriyqihi, (S, M, Msb, K,) and biAlmaA='i, and the like, (M,) aor.
$araqa , (Msb,) inf. n. $araqN, (M, Msb,) He (a man, M, Msb) was, or became, choked with his spittle, (S, M, Msb, K,) and with water, &c. (M.) [And jariDa and gaS~a and $ajiYa are sometimes used in the same sense in relation to spittle &c.] ― -b4- [Hence,] $ariqa AljuroHu biAld~ami (assumed tropical:) The wound became [choked or] filled with blood. (Msb.) ― -b5- And $ariqa AlmawoDiEu biA^aholihi (tropical:) The place became [choked or] filled and straitened by its occupants. (TA.) ― -b6- And $ariqa Aljasadu biAlT~iybi (tropical:) [The body became choked in its pores with perfume]. (TA.) ― -b7- [And $ariqa Alv~awobu biAljaAdiY~i (assumed tropical:) The garment, or piece of cloth, became glutted, or saturated, with the dye of saffron: see the part. n. $ariqN.] ― -b8- And $ariqato Eayonuhu (tropical:) His eye became red [being surcharged with blood]; as also ↓ Ai$oraworaqatN: (M, TA:) and so $ariqa Ald~amu fiY Eayonihi: (K, TA:) or this last signifies the blood appeared in his eye: (M:) and $ariqato biAld~ami it (the eye) had the blood apparent in it, [as though it were choked therewith,] without its running from it. (TA.) ― -b9- And $ariqa lawonuhu, inf. n. $araqN, (assumed tropical:) His colour, or complexion, became red, by reason of shame, or shame and confusion. (TA.) ― -b10- And [hence, app.,] $ariqa Al$~aYo'u, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) The thing became intensely red, with blood, or with a beautiful red colour. (M, TA.) ― -b11- And also (assumed tropical:) The thing became mixed, commingled, or blended. (M, TA.) ― -b12- $ariqati Al$~amosu, inf. n. as above, means (tropical:) The sun had a duskiness blended with it, and it [app. the duskiness] then became little: (TA:) or it was near to setting: (M, K:) or became feeble in its light; (O, K;) app. from $ariqN applied to flesh-meat as meaning “ red, having no grease, or gravy, ” and applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, as meaning “ red, that has become glutted, or saturated, ($ariqa,) with dye; ” because its colour, in the last part of the day, when it is setting, becomes red. (O.) ― -b13- The phrase yuw^ax~iruwna AlS~alaApa A_ilaY $araqi AlmawotaY, (S, M, O, K, [in the CK, erroneously, $aroqi,]) occurring in a trad., (S, M, O,) in a saying of the Prophet, (O, K,) is expl. as meaning Who postpone, or defer, the prayer until there remains not, (S, M, O, K,) of the sun, (S,) or of the day, (M, O, K,) save as much as remains (S, M, O, K) of the life, (S,) or of the breath, (M, O, K, [but in the CK, nafosi is put in the place of nafasi,]) of the dying who is choked with his spittle: (S, M, O, K:) or the meaning is, until the sun is [but just] above the walls, and [diffusing its feeble light] among the graves (M, O, K *) as though it were a great expanse of water. (M, O.) AZ says, yukorahu AlS~alaApu bi$araqi AlmawotaY means Prayer is disapproved when the sun becomes yellow: and faEalotu *`lika bi$araqi AlmawotaY I did that when the sun was becoming yellow. (TA.) -A4- $ariqati Al$~aApu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
$araqa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. $araqN, (S, Msb,) The sheep, or goat, had its ear slit (S, Msb, K) in the manner expl. voce $aroqaA='u. (Msb, K.)

2 $r~q * , (TA,) inf. n. ta$oriyqN, (S, O, K,) He took to the direction of the east, or place of sunrise: (S, O, K, TA:) he went to the east: he came to the east: (M, TA:) and he directed himself to the east. (TA.) ― -b2- And He prayed at sunrise: and hence, app., He performed the prayer of the festival of the sacrifice: (TA:) or this meaning is from $araqati Al$~amosu. (Mgh: it is also mentioned in the M.) ― -b3- $r~qt AlA^aroDu, inf. n. as above, The land became affected with drought, and dryness of the earth, being [parched by the sun and] not reached by water: whence the term ↓ $araAqiY~ [q. v.] in the dial. of Egypt. (TA.) ― -b4- ta$oriyqN also signifies The being beautiful, and [sunny or] shining in face. (Sh, O, K.) -A2- $r~q All~aHoma, (M, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. as above, (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) He cut the flesh-meat into strips, and dried it in the sun, or spread it in the sun to dry: (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K:) or [simply] he cut it into pieces, and into strips. (Msb.) [In like manner also] ta$oriyqu Al$~aEiyri signifies The throwing barley in a sunny place in order that it may dry. (Mgh.) And one says of the [wild] bull, yu$ar~iqu matonahu, meaning He exposes his back to the sun in order that what is upon it of the dew of night may dry: in this sense the phrase is used by Aboo-Dhu-eyb. (M.) ― -b2- A^ay~aAmu Alt~a$oriyqi is an appellation of The three days next after the day of sacrifice: (S, M, O, Msb:) [i. e. the eleventh and twelfth and thirteenth days of Dhu-l-Hijjeh:] these days were so called because the flesh of the victims was therein cut into strips, and dried in the sun, or spread in the sun to dry: (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K: *) or because the victims were not sacrificed until the sun rose: (IAar, S, O, K:) or from the prayer of the day of sacrifice, which they follow: (Mgh:) or because they used to say, [on that day,] (S, M, O,) in the Time of Ignorance, (M,) vabiyro kayomaA nugiyro ↓ A^a$oriqo, (S, M, O,) which means Enter thou upon the time of sunrise, Thebeer, (addressing one of the mountains of Mekkeh, M, * Mgh,) that we may push, or press, on, or forward, (M, Mgh, Msb,) to return from Minè: (M: [see also 4 in art. gwr:]) Aboo- Haneefeh used to hold that Alt~a$oriyq means Alt~akobiyr [i. e. the saying Aall~`hu A^akobaro]; but none beside him has held this opinion. (TA.) It is said in a trad. that the days thus called are days of eating and drinking, and of celebrating the praises of God. (O.) ― -b3- $r~q Alv~awoba (assumed tropical:) He made [or dyed] the garment, or piece of cloth, yellow: (Ibn-'Abbád, O:) [or he dyed it red: (see the pass. part. n., below:)] or ta$oriyqN signifies the dyeing with saffron, (M, L,) so that the thing dyed is saturated, (L,) or not so that the thing is saturated: (so in a copy of the M:) it is not with safflower. (M, L.
[See also 4, last signification.]) -A3- $r~q AlaHowaD is sometimes said for Sar~ajahu, meaning He plastered the watering-trough, or tank, with $aAruwq [q. v.], or SaAruwj. (M in art. Srj.)

4 A$rq * : see 1, in six places. One says also, A$rq wajohuhu, (S,) and lawonuhu, (M,) His face, (S,) and his colour, or complexion, (M,) shone, (S, M,) and was bright, with beauty. (S.) ― -b2- Some allow its being made trans.; [meaning It caused, or made, to shine;] as in the saying,
valaAvapN tu$oraqu Ald~unoyaA bibahojatihaA
$amosu AlD~uHaY waA^abuw A_isoHaAqa wAlqamaru
[There are three things, with the beauty of which the world is made to shine; the sun of the bright early morning, and Aboo-Is-hák, and the moon]: but there is no proof in this, because [the right reading may be tu$oriqu, and so] AldnyA may be an agent; therefore the making the verb trans. [in this sense] is said to be post-classical, though it is mentioned by the author of the Ksh. (MF, TA.) ― -b3- It signifies also He entered upon the time of sunrise: (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K:) similarly to A^afojara, and A^aSobaHa, and A^aZohara. (TA.) See 2. -A2- A$rq Eaduw~ahu He caused his enemy to become choked [with his spittle, or with water, or the like: see 1]. (O, K.) And A^a$oraqotu fulaAnFA biriyqihi (tropical:) [I choked the utterance, or impeded the action, of such a one;] I did not allow such a one to say, or to do, a thing. (Z, TA.) ― -b2- A$rq Alv~awoba biAlS~ibogi, (Moheet, A, O,) or fiY AlS~ibogi, (K,) (tropical:) He exceeded the usual degree in dyeing the garment, or piece of cloth; [saturated it with dye;] or dyed it thoroughly. (K, TA. [See also 2, last signification but one.])

5 t$r~q *
He sat in a sunny place (S, O, K) [at any season, (see ma$oruqapN,) or particularly] in winter. (O, K.) ― -b2- And t$r~qwA They looked through the mi$oriyq of the door, i. e. the chink thereof into which the light of the rising sun falls. (O.)

7 An$rqt Alqawosu *
The bow split. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
12 Ai$oraworaqato Eayonuhu * : see 1, latter half. ― -b2- Ai$oraworaqa biAld~amoEi (tropical:) He became drowned in tears. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K, TA.)

$aroqN * [an inf. n.: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Also] The sun; (S, O, K;) and so ↓ $araqN: (K, and thus in one of my copies of the S in the place of the former:) [or] ↓ $aroqapN has this signification: (M, Msb:) and $aroqN signifies the rising sun; (M, TA;) as some say; (M;) thus accord. to AA and IAar; (TA;) and so ↓ $araqN, (M, Msb,) and ↓ $aroqapN, and ↓ $ariqapN, (M, K,) and ↓ $araqapN, (TA,) and ↓ $aAriqN, (S, * M, K,) and ↓ $ariyqN: (M, K:) one says, TalaEati Al$~aroqu The sun rose; (S, M, O; in one of my copies of the S ↓ Al$~araqu;) but not garabati Al$~aroqu: (M:) and ↓ A=tiyka kul~a $aAriqK I will come to thee every day that the sun rises: or, as some say, $aAriqN signifies the upper limb (qaron) of the sun: (M:) and one says, laA A=tiyka maA *ar~a $aAriqN [I will not come to thee as long as a sun, or the upper limb of a sun, rises, or begins to rise]. (S, M.) ― -b3- See also ma$oriqN, in three places. ― -b4- Also A place where the sun shines (Hayovu tu$oriqu Al$~amosu). (K.) See ma$oruqapN. ― -b5- The warmth of the sun. (TA.) ― -b6- The light that enters from the chink of a door; (IAar, Th, K;) as also ↓ $iroqN. (K.) In a trad. of I'Ab, (TA,) it is said of a gate in Heaven, called ↓ Almi$oriyqu [q. v.], qado rud~a Hat~aY maA baqiYa A_il~aA $aroquhu (O, K, TA) i. e. It had been closed so that there remained not save its light entering from the chink thereof: so says I'Ab. (O, TA.) ― -b7- And A chink, or fissure. (K, TA.) One says, maA daxala $aroqa famiY $aYo'N Nothing entered the chink of my mouth. (Z, TA.) -A2- Also A certain bird, (Sh, M, K,) one of the birds of prey, (M,) between the kite and the hawk, or falcon, (Sh, K,) or between the kite and the [species of falcon called] $aAhiyn [q. v.]: (O:) pl. $uruwqN. (M.)
$iroqN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

$araqN * [inf. n. of $ariqa, q. v. ― -b2- And also a subst.]: see $aroqN, in three places. ― -b3- Also A thing [such as spittle and the like (see $ariqa)] obstructing, or choking, the throat, or fauces. (S, and Har p. 477.)

$ariqN * A place bright by reason of the sun's shining upon it; as also ↓ mu$oriqN. (M, TA.) ― -b2- A man choked with his spittle, or with water, or the like. (M, TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A plant, or herbage, having plentiful irrigation; or flourishing and fresh, or juicy, by reason of plentiful irrigation; syn. ray~aAnu. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A garment, or piece of cloth, red; that is glutted, or saturated, [so I render Aal~a*iY $ariqa,] with dye: (O:) and $ariqN biAljaAdiY~i applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, [app. signifies (assumed tropical:) glutted, or saturated, with the dye of saffron: see also mu$ar~aqN, and see 4.] (TA.) One says also SariyEN $ariqN bidamihi (assumed tropical:) [Prostrated,] dyed with his blood. (M, TA.) ― -b5- (tropical:) Flesh-meat (S, M, O, TA) that is red, (M, O, TA,) having no grease, or gravy. (S, M, O, TA.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) A thing intensely red, with blood, or with a beautiful red colour. (M.) ― -b7- And (assumed tropical:) A thing mixed, commingled, or blended. (M.)
$aroqapN * : see $aroqN, in two places: ― -b2- and see ma$oruqapN, in two places.
$uroqapN * (assumed tropical:) Anxiety, grief, or anguish; syn. in Pers. A^anoduwho. (KL.)
$araqapN * : see $aroqN: ― -b2- and see ma$oruqapN. -A2- Also A brand with which a sheep, or goat, such as is termed $aroqaA=', is marked. (O, K.)
$ariqapN * : see $aroqN.

$aApN $aroqaA='u *
A sheep, or goat, having its ear slit (S, Mgh, O, K) lengthwise, (K,) without its being separated: (TA:) or having the ear slit in two, (As, Msb, TA,) as though it were a zanamap [q. v.]: (As, TA:) or $aroqaA='u applied to an ear signifies cut at its extremities, without having anything thereof separated: and applied to a she-goat (maEozap), having its ear slit lengthwise, without its being separated: and, as some say, applied to a $Ap, having the inner part of its ear slit on one side with a separating slitting, the middle of its ear being left sound: or, accord. to Aboo-'Alee in the “ Tedhkireh, ” $aroqaA='u signifies having its ears slit with two slits passing through, so as to become three distinct pieces. (M.)

$aroqiY~N * [Of, or relating to, the east, or place of sunrise; eastern, or oriental]. ― -b2- laA $aroqiy~api walaA garobiy~apK, (K, TA,) in the Kur [xxiv. 35], (TA,) means Not such that the sun shines upon it at its rising only (Fr, K, TA) nor at its setting only, (Fr, TA,) but such that the sun lights upon it morning and evening: (Fr, K, TA:) or, accord. to El- Hasan, it means not of the trees of the people of the present world, but of the trees of the people of Paradise: Az, however, says that the former explanation is more fit and more commonly receive. (TA.) And makaAnN $aroqiY~N signifies A place, of the earth, or ground, in, or upon, which the sun rises, or shines. (TA.) See also $aAriqN [and $ariqN and ma$oruqapN]. -A2- Also A certain red dye. (TA.)

$ariyqN * : see $aroqN. ― -b2- Also A boy, or young man, goodly, or beautiful, (K, TA,) in face: (TA:) pl. $uruqN, (K, TA, [in the CK $aroqN, but correctly]) with two dammehs. (TA.) ― -b3- And A woman small in the vulva: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) or having her vagina and rectum united by the rending of the separation between them; syn. mufoDaApN. (M, K.) ― -b4- And Al$~ariyqu is the name of A certain idol. (M, TA.)

[
$urayoqap * The first part of the rising sun. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.) See also $aAriqN, voce $aroqN.]
$araAqiY~u * [The lands that are not reached by the water, or inundation, and that are consequently parched by the sun]: a word of the dial. of Egypt. (TA.) See 2.

$aAriqN * : see $aroqN, in two places. ― -b2- Also The side that is next the east; (O;) the eastern side; (K;) of a hill, and of a mountain: you say, h`*aA $aAriqu Aljabali and ↓ $aroqiy~uhu [This is the eastern side of the mountain], and h*A gaAribu Aljabali and garobiy~uhu [in the opposite sense]: (TA:) pl. $uroqN. (O, K.) Hence, in a trad., as some relate it, Al$~uroqu Aljuwnu [meaning (assumed tropical:) Trials, or conflicts and factions, like portions of the dark night, rising from the direction of the east]: but it is otherwise related, with f [in the place of the q: see $aArifN]. (TA.) ― -b3- And Al$~aAriqu is the name of A certain idol, of the Time of Ignorance; (IDrd, M, K;) whence Eabodu Al$~aAriqi, a proper name [of a man]. (IDrd, M.) -A2- Also [if not a mistranscription for $aAruwqN, q. v., app. Clay, or some other
substance or mixture, with which a place is plastered,] maA yuTay~anu bihi makaAnN. (Ibn-' Abbád, O.)
$aAruwqN * signifies [The kind of plaster called] kilosN, [q. v.,] (Kr, M,) i. q. SaAruwjN. (K. [See this last word: and see also the last sentence of the next preceding paragraph above.])
ma$oraqN * : see what next follows.

ma$oriqN * (S, M, O, Msb, K,) which by rule should be ↓ ma$oraqN, (M, Msb,) but this latter is rarely used, (Msb,) The place, (M,) or quarter, or direction, (Msb,) of sunrise; (M, Msb;) [the east, or orient;] and ↓ $aroqN signifies the same; (S, M, O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ mi$oriyqN: (Seer, M:) the pl. of the first is ma$aAriqu; and the pl. of ↓ $aroqN is A^a$oraAqN. (M.) The dual, Alma$oriqaAni, means The place of sunrise of summer and that of winter [E. 26 degrees N. and E. 26 degrees S. in Central Arabia]. (S, O, TA.) And also The place of sunrise and the place of sunset; [or the east and the west;] (M, O;) the former being thus made predominant because it denotes existence, whereas the latter denotes non-existence: (M:) thus in the saying, (M, O,) in the Kur [xliii. 37], (O,) yaA layota bayoniY wabayonaka buEoda A@loma$oriqayoni [O, would that between me and thee were the distance of the east and the west]. (M, O.) And [in like manner] one says ↓ maA bayona Al$~aroqayoni, meaning What is between the place of sunrise and the place of sunset. (M.) ― -b2- See also ma$oruqapN. ― -b3- The saying, cited by IAar,
qulotu lisaEodK wahowa biAlA^azoAriqi
Ealayoka biAlmaHoDi wabiAlma$aAriqi
he explains as meaning [I said to Saad, he being at El-Azárik (a certain water in the baAdiyap, TA in art. zrq)], Keep thou [to pure milk, and] to the sun [or the places of sunshine] in winter: but [ISd says,] in my opinion, Alma$aAriq is here pl. of ↓ mu$ar~aqN applied to flesh-meat that is “ [cut into strips and] spread in the sun [to dry]; ” and this is confirmed by his saying bAlmHD, each of them being food. (M.)
mu$oriqN * : see $ariqN. ― -b2- Also Entering upon the time of sunrise: the pl. occurs in this sense in the Kur xv. 73 and xxvi. 60. (TA.)

ma$oruqapN * and ma$oraqapN (S, M, O, K) and ma$oriqapN, (M, O, K,) the last mentioned by Ks, (O,) A place of sitting in the sun; (S, O, K;) accord. to some, peculiarly, (TA,) in the winter; (O, K, TA;) and ↓ $aroqapN and ↓ mi$oraAqN (S, O, K) and ↓ mi$oriyqN (O, K) signify the same: (S, O, K:) or a place upon which the sun shines; accord. to some, peculiarly, in the winter, (M,) as also ↓ $aroqapN and ↓ $araqapN (M, TA) and ↓ $aroqN (M) and m$rq [app. ↓ ma$oriqN, of the pl. of which, or of one of the first three words in this paragraph, see an ex. in a verse cited voce ma$oriqN if the explanation of that verse by IAar be correct]. (TA.)
ma$oriqiY~N * (Msb, TA) and ma$oraqiY~N both [applied to a man] signify Of the east; or eastern: (Msb:) pl. ma$aAriqapN. (TA.)

mu$ar~aqN *
A place of prayer; syn. muSal~FY; (As, S, M, Mgh, K;) i. e., in an absolute sense: (TA:) or the place of prayer of the festival (AlEiyd): (TA:) or the place of prayer of the two festivals: and Almu$ar~aqu is said to mean the place of prayer of the festival at Mekkeh: (M, TA:) and the mosque of El-Kheyf. (S, K.) ― -b2- And The festival (AlEiyd) [itself]: because the prayer thereon is after the $aroqap, i. e. the [rising] sun. (M.) -A2- Also Flesh-meat [cut into strips and] spread in the sun [to dry: see its verb, 2]. (M.) See also ma$oriqN, last sentence. ― -b2- And A garment, or piece of cloth, [dyed yellow: or with saffron: see, again, its verb: or] dyed with a red colour. (O, K.) -A3- And a fortress [or a watering-trough or tank (see 2, last sentence,)] plastered with $aAruwq. (O, K.)

mu$ar~iqN *
Taking to the direction of the east, or place of sunrise: one says, $at~aAna bayona mu$ar~iqK wamugar~ibK [Different, or widely different, are one going towards the east and one going towards the west]. (S.)
mi$oraAqN * : see ma$oruqapN. -A2- Also A man accustomed to make his enemy to be choked with his spittle. (Z, TA.)

mi$oriyqN * : see ma$oriqN: ― -b2- and ma$oruqapN. ― -b3- Also, (M, O, K,) of a door, (M, K,) A chink into which the light of the rising sun falls. (M, * O, K. *) ― -b4- And Almi$oriyqu is the name of A gate for repentance, in Heaven. (I'Ab, O, K.) See $aroqN.
$iriqoraAqN * and its vars.: see art. $qrq.

1 $arikahu fiyhi * , aor.
$araka , inf. n. $irokapN (S, Mgh, * Msb, K) and $arikapN, the former a contraction of the latter, but the more usual, (Msb,) and $irokN (Mgh, Msb) and $arikN, the former of these two a contraction of the latter, but the more usual, (Msb,) or $irokN [q. v. infrà] is a simple subst., (S, K,) [He shared, participated, or partook, with him in it;] he was, or became, a $ariyk [or copartner &c.] to him in it; (Msb;) namely, a sale or purchase, and an inheritance, (S, K,) or an affair; (Msb;) and fyh ↓ $Arkhu [signifies the same]. (Mgh, Msb, * K. * [It is said in the TA, after the mention of $arikahu with its inf. n. $irokapN, that it is more chaste than ↓ A$rkhu; by which it is implied that this latter is sometimes used as syn. with the former; for which I do not find any express authority.] And He entered with him into it; [or engaged with him in it;] namely, an affair. (TA.) -A2- $arikati Aln~aEolu, aor.
$araka , The sandal had its $iraAk broken; (Ibn-Buzurj, K;) inf. n. $arakN. (TK.)

2 $ar~aka see 4. ― -b2- [The inf. n.] ta$oriykN also signifies The selling a part [or share] of what one has purchased for that for which it was purchased. (Mgh, K.) -A2- $r~k Aln~aEola, (S, * Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. ta$oriykN, (S, K,) He put a $iraAk to the sandal; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ A^a$orakahaA, (S, TA,) inf. n. A_i$oraAkN. (TA.)

3 $aArakotu fulaAnFA * , (S, TA,) inf. n. mu$aArakapN, (TK,) [I shared, participated, or partook, with such a one;] I was, or became, the $ariyk [or copartner &c.] of such a one. (S, TA.) El-Jaadee says,
wa$aArakonaA qurayo$FA fiY tuqaAhaA
AlEinaAni ↓ wafiY A^aHosaAbihaA $iroka
[And we shared with Kureysh in their piety and in their several grounds of pretension to respect, with a sharing exclusive of other properties]. (S.) See also 1. [And see 8.]

4 A^a$orakotuhu fiY AlA^amori *
I made him a $ariyk [or copartner &c.] to me in the affair: and ↓ $ar~akotu bayonahumo fiY AlmaAli [I made them copartners in the property; and $ar~akahumo, occurring in this art. in the TA, on the authority of Esh-Sháfi'ee, means, in like manner, he made them copartners; and A^a$oraka bayonahumo is used in this sense in the present art. in the K]. (Msb.) waA^a$orikohu fiY A^amoriY, in the Kur [xx. 33], means And make Thou him my $ariyk [or copartner, or associate, or colleague,] in my affair. (S.) And one says also, A$rkhu maEahu fiY AlA^amori He made him to enter [or engage] with him in the affair: and A$rk fulaAnFA fiY AlbayoEi He made such a one to enter [or share] with him in the sale or purchase. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A$rk biA@ll~`hi He attributed to God a $ariyk [or copartner &c.] (Mgh, TA) in his dominion: (TA:) [or he attributed to God $urakaA=' i. e. copartners &c., such as the angels and the devils: (see Kur vi. 100, &c., and any of the expositions thereof:) i. e. he believed in a duality, or a plurality, of gods:] and [in a wider sense,] he disbelieved [or misbelieved] in God: syn. kafara: (S, * Msb, K, TA:) used in this latter sense because Alkuforu is not free from some kind of $irok. (Kull p. 49.) -A2- See also 1: -A3- and 2.
6 ta$aAoraka see the next paragraph, in three places.

8 A$trkwA * and ↓ t$ArkwA, (Mgh, Msb,) and A$trkA and ↓ t$ArkA, (K,) and A$trknA and ↓ t$ArknA, (S,) [They, and they two, and we, shared, participated, or partook, one with another, and each with the other; or were, or became, copartners, &c.;] fiY ka*aA [in such a thing]. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlAi$otiraAku in lexicology signifies The being homonymous; lit. the being shared, or participated, in by several meanings: [used as a subst., homonymy:] (Mz, 25th nwE; and Intr. to the TA:) one says of a noun [or word] that is termed mu$otarakN [q. v.], ta$otariku fiyhi maEaAnK kaviyrapN [Many meanings share, or participate, in it]. (TA.) ― -b3- And A$trk AlA^amoru (assumed tropical:) The affair, or case, was, or became, confused, and dubious. (TA.)
$arokN * : see what next follows.

$irokN * is an inf. n. of $arikahu, as mentioned in the
first sentence of this art.: (Mgh, Msb:) or a subst. therefrom: (S:) and is syn. with ↓ $irokapN, [signifying A sharing, participating or participation, partaking, or copartnership, and mentioned before as an inf. n.,] (K,) as also are ↓ $arikN and ↓ $arikapN, [likewise mentioned before as inf. ns.,] and ↓ $arokN and ↓ $arokapN, (MF, TA,) and so is ↓ $urokapN, with damm, (K,) this last said by MF to be unknown, but it is common in Syria, almost to the exclusion of the other dial. vars. mentioned above. (TA.) An ex. of the first occurs in a trad, of Mo'ádh, A^ajaAza bayona A^aholi Alyamani Al$~iroka, meaning [He allowed, among the people of El-Yemen,] the sharing, one with another, (AlAi$otiraAk,) in land [and app. its produce], by its owner giving it to another for the half [app. of its produce], or the third, or the like thereof: and a similar ex. of the same word occurs in another trad. (TA.) See also an ex. in a verse cited above, conj. 3. And one says, ragibonaA fiY $irokikumo, meaning We are desirous of sharing with you in affinity, or relationship by marriage. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- And A share: (Mgh, O, Msb, TA:) as in the saying, biyEa $irokN mino daArihi [A share of his house was sold]: (Mgh:) and as in the saying, A^aEotaqa $irokFA lahu fiY EabodK [He emancipated a share belonging to him in a slave]: (Msb:) pl. A^a$oraAkN. (O, Msb, TA.) [See a verse of Lebeed cited voce zaEaAmapN.] ― -b3- It is also a subst. from A^a$oraka biA@ll~`hi; (Mgh, Msb, K, TA;) thus in the Kur xxxi. 12; (Mgh, TA;) meaning The attribution of a $ariyk [or copartner &c., or of $urakaA=' i. e. copartners &c., (see 4,)] to God: (Mgh:) [so that it may be rendered belief in a plurality of gods:] and [in a wider sense,] unbelief [or misbelief]; syn. kuforN. (S, Msb, K, TA.) And it is also expl. as meaning Hypocrisy: (Mgh, TA:) so in the saying of the Prophet, A_in~a A^axowafa maA A^axaAfu EalaY A^um~atiY Al$~iroku [Verily the most fearful of what I fear for my people is hypocrisy]: (Mgh:) and so in the trad., Al$~iroku A^axofaY fiY A^um~atiY mino dabiybi Aln~amoli [Hypocrisy is more latent in my people than the creeping of ants]. (IAth, TA.) ― -b4- See also $ariykN, in two places.

$arakN * The HibaAlap [properly a sing., meaning snare, but here app. used as a gen. n., meaning snares, as will be seen from what follows,] of the SaAy^id [i. e. sportsman, or catcher of game, or wild animals, or birds]; one of which is called ↓ $arakapN: (S, O:) the meaning of the $arak of the SaAy^id is well known; and the pl. is A^a$oraAkN; like sababN and A^asobaAbN: or, as some say, $arakN is the pl. of ↓ $arakapN, [or rather is a coll. gen. n. of which ↓ $arakapN is the n. un.,] like qaSabN and qaSabapN: (Msb:) [i. e.,] $arakN signifies the HabaAy^il [or snares, or by this may perhaps be meant the cords composing a snare, for HabaAy^ilu is an anomalous pl. of HabolN,] for catching wild animals or the like; and what is, or are, set up for [catching] birds: (K, TA:) one whereof is said to be called ↓ $arakapN [a term used in the K, in art. $bk, as the explanation of $abakapN, which means a net]: (TA:) and the pl. of $arakN is $urukN, with two dammehs, which is extr. [with respect to analogy, like fulukN pl. of falakN]. (K.) Hence the trad., A^aEuw*u bika mino $ar~i Al$~ayoTaAni wa$arakihi, meaning HabaAy^ilihi wamaSaAyidihi [i. e. I seek protection by Thee from the mischief of the Devil, and his snares]. (TA.) ― -b2- $araku AlT~ariyqi means The main and middle parts of the road; (S, K;) syn. jawaAd~uhu: or the tracks that are [conspicuous and distinct,] not obscure to one nor blended together: (K:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of ↓ $arakapN: (S:) or the A^anosaAE of the road; (As, TA;) i. e. the furrows of the road, made by the beasts with their legs [or feet] in its surface, a ↓ $arakap here and another by the side of it: (TA:) or A^a$oraAkN [is its pl., and] signifies the small tracks that branch off from the main road and then stop, or terminate. (Sh, TA.) [See A^us~N.]
$arikN * : see $irokN, first sentence.
$arokapN * : see $irokN, first sentence.
$urokapN * : see $irokN, first sentence.
$irokapN * : see $irokN, first sentence. ― -b2- Also A piece of flesh-meat; of the dial. of El-Yemen; originally, of a slaughtered camel, in which people share, one with another. (TA.)
$arakapN * : see $arakN, in six places.
$arikapN * : see $irokN, first sentence.

$urakiY~N * and $ur~akiY~N A quick, or swift, pace: (K:) so says ISd. (TA.) And laTomN $urakiY~N A quick and consecutive slapping, (S, O, K,) like the camel's slapping when a thorn has entered his foot and he beats the ground with it with a consecutive beating. (S, * O.) Ows Ibn-Hajar says,
wamaA A^ana A_il~aA musotaEid~N kamaA taraY
A^axuw $urakiY~i Alwirodi gayoru muEat~imi
[And I am none other than one who is ready, as thou seest; one in the habit of quick and consecutive coming to water; not one who is dilatory]: i. e., one coming to water time after time, consecutively: he means, I will do to thee what thou dislikest, not delaying to do that. (S.)

$iraAkN * The thong, or strap, of the sandal, (Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) that is on the face thereof, (TA,) upon the back [meaning upper side] of the foot, (Mgh, Msb,) [extending from the thong, or strap, that passes between two of the toes, towards the ankle, and having two arms (its EaDudaAni), which are attached to the A^u*unaAni (q. v.), or pass through these and unite behind the foot: see also xizaAmapN, and faraSahu, whence it appears to mean also each arm, and the two arms, of the $iraAk properly so called: and see sayorN, where it appears to be used as meaning a thong or strap, absolutely:] the $iraAk of the sandal is well known: (O:) pl. $urukN, (O, K, TA,) and accord. to the K A^a$orukN also, but this is a mistake. (TA.) To this is likened, in a trad., the shadow at the base of a wall, on the eastern side thereof, when very small [or narrow], showing that the sun has begun to decline from the meridian. (Mgh, Msb,) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A streak of herbage: (S, O, K:) pl. $urukN, (S, O, TA,) expl. by AHn as meaning herbage in streaks; not continuous. (TA.) One says, AlkalaA^u fiY baniY fulaAnK $urukN (assumed tropical:) The herbage among the sons of such a one is composed of streaks. (Aboo-Nasr, S, O.) ― -b3- [In the K voce banaqa it is used as meaning (assumed tropical:) A row of shoots, or offsets, cut from palm-trees and planted, such as are termed, when planted, muban~aqN and munab~aqN.] ― -b4- [Hence,] one says, maDawoA EalaY $iraAkK waAHidK (tropical:) [They went away in one uniform line or manner]. (TA.) And AijoEali AlA^amora $iraAkFA waAHidFA (assumed tropical:) Make thou the affair, or case, [uniform, or] one uniform thing. (Fr, TA in art. bA^j.)

$ariykN * act. part. n. of $arikapN; (Mgh;) i. q. ↓ mu$aArikN [A sharer, participator, partaker, or partner, with another; a copartner, an associate, or a colleague, of another]; (K;) and ↓ $irokN signifies the same: (Az, K, TA:) a sharer in what is not divided: (K and TK in art. xlT:) or a sharer in the rights of a thing that is sold: (Mgh in that art.:) pl. $urakaA='u and A^a$oraAkN, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) like $urafaA='u and A^a$oraAfN pls. of $ariyfN; (S, O, TA;) or the latter is pl. of ↓ $irokN: (Az, TA:) a woman is termed $ariykapN; (S, O, K;) which is applied to a man's jaArap [i. e. wife, or object of love]; (TA;) and the pl. of this is $araAy^iku. (S, O, K.) Az mentions his having heard one of the Arabs say, fulaAnN $ariyku fulaAnK meaning Such a one is married to the daughter, or to the sister, of such a one; what people call the xatan [of such a one]. (TA.)

mu$orikN * and ↓ mu$orikiY~N, (S, O, K,) like as one says daw~N and daw~iY~N, and qaEosarN and qaEosariY~N, (S, O,) One who attributes to God a $ariyk [or copartner &c., or $urakaA=' i. e. copartners &c. (see 4)]: (O:) [i. e. a believer in a duality, or a plurality, of gods:] and [in a wider sense,] a disbeliever [or misbeliever] in God. (S, O, K.) Abu-l-'Abbás explains [the pl.] mu$orikuwna in the Kur xvi. 102 as meaning Those who are m$rkwn by their obeying the Devil; by their worshipping God and worshipping with Him the Devil. (TA.) ― -b2- [In one place, in the CK, the former word is erroneously put for mu$otarakN, q. v., last sentence.]
mu$orikiY~N * : see the next preceding paragraph.

AlfariyDapu Almu$ar~akapu * , (O, K, TA,) or AlmasoA^alapu Alma$ar~akapu, (Msb,) for Almu$ar~aku fiyhaA, (Msb, TA,) is That [assigned portion of inheritance, or the question relating thereto (AlmasoA^alapu Almu$ar~akapu being for masoA^alapu AlfariyDapi Almu$ar~akapi),] in which the brothers by the mother's side [only] and those by [both] the father's and the mother's sides are made to share together; (O, Msb, * K, TA;) also called ↓ Almu$ar~ikapu [that makes to share], tropically;
(Msb;) and called also ↓ Almu$otarakapu [for Almu$otaraku fiyhaA i. e. that is shared in]: (Lth, K, TA:) this is the case of a husband and a mother and brothers by the mother's side and brothers by the father's and mother's sides: (O, K, TA:) for the wife is half; and for the mother, a sixth; and for the brothers by the mother's side, a third, and the brothers by the father's and mother's sides share with them: (O, TA:) 'Omar decided in a case of this kind by assigning the third to two brothers by the mother's side, and not assigning anything to the brothers by the father's and mother's sides; whereupon they said, yaA A^amiyra Almuw^ominiyna habo A^an~a A^abaAnaA kaAna HimaArFA faA^a$orikonaA biqaraAbapi A^um~anaA [O Prince of the Believers, suppose that our father was an ass, and make us to share by reason of the relationship of our mother]: so he made them to share together (faA^a$oraka bayonahumo [thus in the O and K, but correctly fa$ar~aka bynhm, or, as afterwards in the TA, fa$ar~akahumo]): (O, K, TA:) therefore it (i. e. the fariyDap, TA) was called mu$ar~akap [and mu$ar~ikap] and mu$otarakap, [in the CK, erroneously, mu$orakap,] and also HimaAriy~ap: (K, TA:) and it is also called Hajariy~ap, because it is related that they said, habo A^an~a A^abaAnaA kaAna HajarFA muloqFY fiY Alyam~i [suppose that our father was a stone thrown into the sea]; and [therefore] some called it yam~iy~ap: and it was called also Eumariy~ap. (TA. [More is there added, explaining different decisions of this case.])
Almu$ar~ikapu * : see the next preceding paragraph.
mu$aArikN * : see $ariykN. ― -b2- riyHN mu$aArikN means A wind to which the nakobaA=' [q. v.] is nearer than the two winds between which this blows. (K.)

mu$otarakN * , applied to a road (Tariyq, Mgh, Msb, TA), is for mu$otarakN fiyhi, (Msb,) meaning [Shared in: or] in which the people are equal [sharers]. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, AlA^ajiyru Almu$otaraku [in my copy of the Mgh, erroneously, Almu$otariku,] The hired man [that is shared in; i. e.,] whose work no one has for himself exclusively of others, but who works for every one who repairs to him for work, like the tailor in the sitting-places of the markets; (Msb;) or who works for whom he pleases: as to A^ajiyru Almu$otaraki, it is not right, unless the word thus governed in the gen. case be expl. as an inf. n. (Mgh.) ― -b3- See also AlfariyDapu Almu$ar~akapu, above. ― -b4- AisomN mu$otarakN [in like manner for mu$otarakN fiyhi A noun shared in by several meanings; i. e. a homonym;] a noun shared in by many meanings, such as EayonN and the like: (Mz, 25th nwE; and TA in the present art. and in the Intr.:) or mu$otarakN signifies a word having two, or more, meanings; and is applied to a noun, and to the pret. of a verb as denoting predication and prayer, and to the aor. as denoting the present and the future, and to a particle: (Mz ubi suprà:) [mu$otarakN used as a subst., meaning a homonym, has for its pl. mu$otarakaAtN.] ― -b5- [AlHis~u Almu$otaraku, for Almu$otaraku fiyhi, signifies, in the conventional language of the philosophers, The faculty of fancy; so called because “ participated in ” by the five senses: but it is vulgarly used as meaning common sense.] ― -b6- mu$otarakN applied to a man, [for mu$otarakN fiyhi,] means (assumed tropical:) Talking to himself, like him who is affected with anxiety; (As, S, K, TA; [in the CK, erroneously, mu$orikN;]) his judgment being shared in; not one. (TA.)

1 $aramahu * , (S, K,) aor.
$arima , (K,) inf. n. $aromN, i. q. $aq~ahu [meaning He slit it; or rent it; and perhaps also he clave it, split it, &c.]. (S, K.) ― -b2- It is also said in the K that Al$~aromu signifies qaToEu maA bayona AlA^aronabapi: but mA byn should be struck out: and the passage, moreover, is defective: it should be, as in the M, Al$~aromu and ↓ Alt~a$oriymu signify The cutting (qaToE [or rather $aq~ i. e. slitting or rending]) of the end, or tip, of the nose, and of the vafor [here meaning the vulva, or the orifice of the vagina,] of a she-camel: specially said of these two things. (TA. [See also 2; and see $ariymN.]) ― -b3- $arama Alv~ariydapa, aor. and inf. n. as above, and the latter, by poetic license, $aramN, He ate of the sides, or of the edge, of the vrydp [or mess of crumbled bread moistened with broth]. (TA.) ― -b4- $arama lahu mino maAlihi, (S, K,) aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) He gave him little of his mAl (i. e. property, or cattle]. (S, K.) -A2- $arima, aor.
$arama , is quasi-pass. of $aramahu; [i. e. it signifies It was, or became, slit, or rent;] (TA;) as also ↓ An$rm. (S, TA. [In the former it is implied that the meaning of the latter verb is Aino$aq~a.]) ― -b2- Also, aor. as above, (Msb,) inf. n. $aramN, (S, * Msb, K, *) He (a man) had his nose slit: (Msb:) or he had the end, or tip, of his nose cut. (S, * Msb, K. *)

2 ta$oriymN *
i. q. ta$oqiyqN [meaning The slitting, or rending, and perhaps also cleaving, splitting, &c., much, or in several places]: (S, K, TA: [see 2 in art. xrm:]) one says, $r~mhu [he slit it &c.], in relation to the ear &c.: (TA:) [it is used in relation to the end, or tip, of the nose; and to the orifice of the vagina of a she-camel; as shown above:] see 1, second sentence. ta$oriymu AlZ~iy^aAri is [The scarifying of the vulva, or of the orifice of the vagina, for the purpose of] the making a she-camel to affect and suckle a young one not her own [by causing her to imagine, from the pain thus occasioned, that she has recently brought forth that young one]; (TA;) t$rym in this phrase signifying ta$oqiyq. (T in art. ZA^r.) It is said in a trad. of Ibn-'Omar, that he purchased a she-camel, and, seeing in her what is thus termed, returned her: (S:) in this instance, t$rym AlZy^Ar means The laceration of the two edges of the vulva on the occasion of Zy^Ar. (T and TA in art. ZA^r: see 1 in that art.) ― -b2- ta$oriymu AlS~ayodi is The wounding of the skin of the animal of the chase without piercing into the belly, or inside, (L in art. Hq, [see 8 in that art.,]) so that the animal escapes wounded. (S, K. *)

5 t$r~m * , (S, K,) said of the skin, (TA,) or of a thing, (S,) It was, or became, rent, or slit, in several places; (S, K, TA;) quasi-pass. of $ar~amahu. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Kaab, A^ataY Eumara bikitaAbK qado ta$ar~amato nawaAHiyhi i. e. ta$aq~aqato [meaning He brought to 'Omar a book of which the sides were slit, or rent, in several places]. (TA.)
7 A_ino$arama see 1, near the end.

$aromN *
A canal, or cut, (xaliyj,) from a baHor [i. e. sea, or large river]: (S, K:) [now applied to a creek of a sea:] or the luj~ap [i. e. main body, or fathomless deep,] of the baHor [or sea]: (K:) or the deepest part thereof: (TA:) or a gamorap [or submerging deep] thereof: pl. $uruwmN. (IB, TA.) ― -b2- And Any fissure in a mountain or rock, not passing through. (TA.) -A2- Also A certain kind of tree. (K.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) or Eu$obN $aromN, (S, [in one of my copies of the S $arimN,]) Abundant herbs or herbage, of which the upper parts are eaten, the middle parts not being required, (S, K,) nor the lower parts. (S.)
$aruwmN * : see what next follows.

$ariymN * A woman having her vagina and rectum united by the rending of the separation between them; syn. mufoDaApN; (S, Mgh, K;) as also ↓ $aruwmN, (S, K,) and ↓ $aromaA='u; (K;) or the last of these in this sense has not been heard, though mentioned in the sense here following. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Also A she-camel having her vafor [here meaning the vulva, or the orifice of the vagina,] cut [or rather slit or rent]; and so ↓ $aromaA='u, and ↓ ma$oruwmapN: (M, TA:) or ↓ $aromaA='u applied to a she-camel and to a she-ass, accord. to the Tekmileh, means having the vulva slit, or rent: therefore the first-mentioned meaning of this epithet, applied to a woman, if correct, may be tropical. (Mgh.) ― -b3- Also The faroj [or vulva]; (K;) because of its being cleft. (TA.)
$aArimN * An arrow that slits, or rends, (ya$orimu,) the side of the target. (S, K, TA.)

A^a$oramu * , applied to a man, (IAar, S, Msb, K,) i. q. AlA^anofi ↓ ma$oruwmu; (S, K,) [i. e.] Having the nose slit; (IAar, Msb, TA;) like A^axoramu: (IAar, TA:) or having the end, or tip, of the nose cut: (Msb:) and having the lower lip slit; like A^afolaHu: and having the upper lip slit; like A^aEolamu: and having the ear slit; like A^axorabu: and having the eyelid slit; like A^a$otaru: it has all these meanings: (IAar, TA:) fem. $aromaA='u, applied to a woman. (Msb.) ― -b2- For the fem., see also $ariymN, in three places. ― -b3- The fem. is also applied to an ear (A^u*unN), meaning Having a small portion cut from the upper part; and so ↓ mu$ar~amapN. (TA.)

mu$ar~amN *
Slit, or rent, in several places: so in a trad., where it is said, fajaA='ahu bimuSoHafK mu$ar~ami AlA^aToraAfi [And he brought him a copy of the Kur-án having the extremities slit, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also A^a$oramu, last sentence.
ma$oruwmN * : see A^a$oramu: ― -b2- and see also $ariymN.

div2.head: Quasi $rnf
div2.entryFree: $aronafotu Alz~aroEa * , mentioned under this head in the O and K: see Q. Q. 4 in art. $rf. The n is held by Az to be augmentative, if not a mistake for Y. (O.)
$ironaAfN * : see $iroyaAfN, art. in $rf.

$ariha * (S, MA, Mgh, Msb, K) EalaY AlT~aEaAmi (MA, Mgh, Msb) wagayorihi, (Msb,) or A_ilaY AlT~aEaAmi, (TA, [perhaps a mistranscription,]) aor.
$araha , (Msb, K,) inf. n. $arahN, (S, MA, Mgh, Msb,) said of a man, (S,) He was vehemently desirous, or greedy; (MA;) or very vehemently desirous, or very greedy; (Mgh, Msb;) or overcome by vehement desire, or greediness; (S, K;) of the food (MA, Mgh, Msb) &c.: (Msb:) or, as some say, he was affected with the worst of vehement desire, or of greediness. (TA.)

$arihN * (S, Msb, K) and ↓ $arohaAnu (Lth, K) [Vehemently desirous, or greedy; (see 1;) or] very vehemently desirous, or very greedy; (Msb;) or overcome by vehement desire, or greediness: (K:) or, accord. to some, affected with the worst of vehement desire, or of greediness. (TA.)
$arohaAnu * : see the next preceding paragraph.

A_ihoyaA A^a$aro A_ihoyaA * , with kesr to the ' in AhyA, and with fet-h to the ' in A$r, and to the $, (K, TA,) and with the r quiescent, (TA,) [mentioned in this art. in consequence of the supposing A$r with AhyA after it to compose one word,] but this is not its proper place; (K, TA;) so says Sgh; (TA;) an ancient Greek expression, (K, TA,) or Syriac, or, more correctly, Hebrew; (TA;) [the truth is that it is a mode of writing the Hebrew words אני אהיה שאני “ I shall be that I am, ” in Exod. iii. 14, rendered in our Authorized Version “ I am that I am; ”] said in prayer; (TA;) [virtually] meaning The existing from eternity, that will not cease to be: (K:) Sgh says, thus one of the learned men of the Jews pronounced it to me in 'Adan Abyan: and some say hyA $rAhyA, as though abridging it, meaning yaA HaY~u yaA qay~uwmu [which may be rendered O Ever-living, O Selfsubsisting by Whom all things subsist; but the latter epithet is variously explained]; so says Lth: (TA:) the people now say A^ahoyaA $araAhiyaA, (so in some copies of the K,) with fet-h to the ' in AhyA, and dropping the ' in what follows this word, [which, however, probably means that they say A^ahoyaA $aro A^ahoyaA,] or, as in the handwriting of Sgh, with medd to the ' in the former; (TA;) [in my MS. copy of the K A=hiyaA $arAhyA; in the CK, A=hiy~FA $arAhiy~FA;] which is said in the K to be a mistake accord. to the assertion of the learned men of the Jews: but this, which is said to be a mistake, is what commonly obtains in the books of the people, [i. e. of the Jews,] and they seldom, or never, pronounce it otherwise than thus: As says that the vulgar say yaA hiyaA, which is post-classical; correctly yaA hayaAha [or yaA hayaA], with fet-h to the ': AHát says, I think it to be originally yaA hayaA $rAhyA [which is inconsistent with the Hebrew]: and Ibn-Buzurj says, they said yaA hiyaA and yaA hayaA in speaking to one from a near place. (TA.)

$arowN *
Honey: (K:) or white honey: mentioned by Sgh: formed by transposition from $aworN: (TA:) and also written ↓ $irowN. (K.)
$irowN * : see what precedes.
$arowaY * , originally $aroyaA: see art. $rY.
$irawiY~N * , originally $irayiY~N: see art. $rY.

$irowaAlN * is [said to be] a dial. var. of sirowaAlN: (K:) IAmb says that Es-Sijistánee mentions his having heard some of the Arabs of the desert say $irowaAl for sirowaAl; but that it seems he heard them use the Pers. word, [which, it appears, is $arowaAl as well as $alowaAr,] and knew it not: (O, TA: *) $rwAl is a vulgar word, [now commonly pronounced $arowaAl,] and some of the vulgar say $alowaAr, with fet-h to the $. (TA.)

1 $araAhu * , (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
$ariYa , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. $irFY (S, Mgh, Msb, TA) and $iraA='N, (S, * Mgh, Msb, * TA,) the former inf. n. the more in repute, (Msb, TA,) and this is of the dial. of Nejd, the latter being of the dial. of El-Hijáz, or the latter may be said to be with medd for the purpose of assimilating it to a preceding word, accord. to El-Munádee, or it may be regarded as an inf. n. of $aAraAhu, (TA,) i. q. baAEahu [in the sense in which this is generally used, i. e. He sold it]; (S, Mgh, K;) he gave it for a price: (Msb:) and i. q. ↓ Ai$otaraAhu [in the sense in which this is generally used, i. e. he bought it]; (S, Mgh;) i. e. $araAhu signifies also he took it, or acquired it, for a price: (Msb:) or this and ↓ A$trAh both signify baAEahu [as meaning he sold it]; (T, * K, TA;) but the former is more used than the latter in this sense: (T, TA:) and both signify also [he bought it; i. e.] he possessed it by sale; (K;) which is the more usual meaning of the latter: (T, TA:) thus the former has two contr. meanings, (S, Msb, K,) and the latter also: (K:) for the two persons selling and buying sell and buy the price and the thing upon which the price is put; so that each of the things given in exchange is sold in one point of view and bought in another. (Msb, TA.) It is said in the Kur [ii. 203], wamina A@ln~aAsi mano ya$oriY nafosahu A@botigaA='a maroDaApi A@ll~`hi i. e. [And of men is he] who sells [himself in the endeavour to obtain the approval of God]. (S, * TA.) And in the same, [xii. 20], wa$arawohu bivamanK baxosK i. e. And they sold him [for a deficient, or an insufficient, price]. (S, TA.) And in the same [ii. 15], A^uwlaAy^ika A@l~a*iyna A@lD~alaAlapa biA@lohudaY ↓ A@$otarawuA, originally A@$otarayuwA, (S,) [lit. Those are they who have purchased error with right direction,] meaning, (tropical:) who have taken AlDlAlp in exchange for AlhdY: (Ksh, Bd, Jel:) or (tropical:) who have preferred AlDlAlp to AlhdY: (Ksh, Bd:) [for] of any one who relinquishes a thing and lays hold upon another thing, one says A$trAh; (K, TA;) which is thus tropically used [as meaning (tropical:) he took it in exchange bigayorihi by giving up another thing]; (TA;) and hence this saying in the Kur-án. (K, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] $araY binafosihi Eani Alqawomi (tropical:) He advanced before the people, or party, (K, TA,) to their enemy, (TA,) and fought in defence of them: or (tropical:) he advanced to the Sultán, and spoke for the people: (K, TA:) [as though he sold himself for them; the b in bnfsh being app. redundant:] or, as in the Tekmileh, $araY binafosihi A_ilaY Alqawomi (tropical:) he advanced to the people, or party, and fought them. (TA.) ― -b3- And $araY fulaAnFA, (K,) inf. n. $irFY, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He mocked at, scoffed at, laughed at, derided, or ridiculed, such a one: (K:) [and] so ↓ $ar~aAhu. (TA voce jad~aEahu [q. v.: thus there written, perhaps for the purpose of assimilating it to jad~aEahu].) ― -b4- And i. q. A^arogamahu (assumed tropical:) [He angered such a one; or did evil to him, and angered him]: (Lh, K, TA:) and so A^aworamahu, and gaTaAhu [or perhaps EaZaAhu, for both are expl. alike]: all said of God. (Lh, TA.) And faEala bihi maA $araAhu (assumed tropical:) He did to him that which occasioned evil to him; or that which displeased, grieved, or vexed, him; syn. saA='ahu. (TA.) And laHaAhu A@ll~`hu wa$araAhu (assumed tropical:) [May God remove him far from good or prosperity, or curse him, and do evil to him, or displease or grieve or vex him]. (TA.) -A2- $araY A@ll~`hu fulaAnFA, (K,) inf. n. $irFY, (TA,) also signifies God smote him, or may God smite him, with the eruption termed $arFY [q. v.]. (K, TA.) -A3- And $araAhu, (K,) aor.
$ariYa , inf. n. $irFY, (TA,) i. q. $ar~arahu, (K, TA,) i. e. He spread it [to dry]; (TA;) [in copies of the K, in art. $r, written, in this sense, ↓ $ar~aAhu;] namely, flesh-meat, and a garment, or piece of cloth, and [the preparation of curd called] A^aqiT. (K.) -A4- $ariYa, aor.
$araYa , inf. n. $arFY, (S, K,) said of lightning, (S, K, &c.,) It shone, or gleamed, much: (S:) or it shone, or gleamed, (K, TA,) and spread in the face of the clouds, or, as in the T, became dispersed in the face of the clouds: (TA:) and ↓ A$rY signifies the same; (K;) or it shone, or gleamed, consecutively: the latter verb mentioned by Sgh. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (S,) said of the nose-rein of a camel, (S, TA,) It was, or became, in a state of commotion, (TA,) or, of much commotion. (S, TA.) [See also 12.]) ― -b3- Also, (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He (a man) was, or became, angry: (K, TA:) or he was, or became, flurried by reason of anger. (S, TA.) ― -b4- And, said of evil, or mischief, It spread, bayonahumo among them: (K, TA:) or became great, or formidable; and in like manner said of an affair, or event. (Nh, TA. [See also 10.]) ― -b5- Also, and ↓ Ast$rY, He (a man, S) persisted, or persevered, (S, K,) in an affair, (S,) or in his error, and his corrupt conduct: and the former, said of a man, is like gariYa in measure and meaning [i. e. he persisted, or persevered, in his anger]. (TA.) One says of a horse, $ariYa fiY sayorihi, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He per-
sisted, or persevered, in his pace, or going; as also ↓ Ast$rY: (S:) or he exceeded the usual bounds therein, (K, TA,) and went on without languor: (TA:) and fiY Eadowihi ↓ Ast$rY he (i. e. a horse) persisted, or persevered, in his running: (Mgh:) and $ariYa fiY lijaAmihi he (a horse) strained his bridle. (A, TA.) And $ariyato Eayonuhu biAld~amoEi His eye persisted, or persevered, in the shedding of tears, the tears pouring forth consecutively. (TA.) -A5- And $ariYa, (S, K, TA,) aor.
$araYa , inf. n. $arFY, (K, * TA,) He, (TA,) or his skin, broke out with the eruption termed $arFY [q. v.]. (S, K, TA.)
2 $ar~aYa see the preceding paragraph, in two places.

3 $aAraAhu * , inf. n. mu$aAraApN and $iraA='N, i. q. baAyaEahu [as signifying He sold and bought with him: and he bartered, or exchanged commodities, with him: that $ArAh has both of these meanings (like bAyEh) is shown by the fact that mu$aAraApN is also expl. in the TA, on the authority of Er-Rághib, as signifying the same as qibaADN]. (K.) ― -b2- Also, (Mgh,) inf. n. mu$aAraApN, (TA,) He persisted in contention, litigation, or wrangling: (Mgh:) one says, huwa yu$aAriyhi (T, M, K) He persists in contention, litigation, or wrangling, with him: (M, TA:) or he contends in altercation, disputes, or litigates, with him; or does so vehemently, or obstinately; syn. yujaAdiluhu: (K, TA:) and it is said of the Prophet, in a trad., kaAna laA yu$aAriY walaA yumaAriY [He used not to persist in contention, &c.]: (Mgh, TA:) meaning accord. to Th, biAl$~ar~i ↓ kaAna laA yasota$oriY [he used not to persist, or persevere, with evil conduct]: (TA:) from Aisota$oraY fiY Eadowihi [expl. above (see 1 near the end)] as said of a horse: (Mgh:) or, accord. to Az, (TA,) originally yu$aAriru; one of the rs being changed into Y. (K, * TA. [See 3 in art. $r: and see also 3 in art. jrY.])

4 A$rY * , said of lightning: see 1, latter half. ― -b2- Said of a camel, He sped, or went quickly. (IKtt, TA.) ― -b3- A$rY bayonahumo He excited discord, strife, or animosity, between them, or among them. (Az, K.) ― -b4- A$rY AlHamalu (K accord. to the CK, [which, I think, evidently gives the right reading,] in the TA and in my MS. copy of the K Aljml,) i. q. tafal~aqato Eaqiyqatuhu [i. e. The lamb had its wool cleaving open, or becoming cleft]: (K: [Freytag, following the TK, and reading AlHimolu, explains the verb as said of fruit, and meaning “ diffissos habuit nucleos; ” but I cannot find any authority for the signification that he thus assigns to Eaqyqp:]) mentioned by Sgh. (TA.) ― -b5- A$rt Al$~ajarapu The plant [crept upon the ground, or] was like the cucumber and the melon; as also ↓ Ast$rt. (TA.) ― -b6- See also 5. -A2- A$rAhu He filled it; (S, K;) namely, a watering-trough: and in like manner A$rY jafonapF he filled a bowl, (S,) or jifaAnahu his bowls for the guests. (TA.) ― -b2- And He made it to incline, (K, TA,) fiY naAHiyapi ka*aA [in the direction of such a thing]. (TA.) Hence the saying of a poet,
waA^an~aniY HayovumaA yu$oriY AlhawaY baSariY
mino HawovamaA salakuwA A^adonuw faA^anoZuwru
