[And that I, wherever love makes my eye, or eyes, to incline, wherever they travel, approach and look: fAnZwr being for faA^anoZuru]: or, as some relate it, A^avoniY faA^anoZuwru [i. e. turn myself, or my eyes, and look]. (TA.) ― -b3- [Also He put it in motion; namely, a bridle. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)]

5 t$r~Y *
It became scattered, or dispersed: (K:) accord. to the M, said in this sense of a company of men. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, said of a man, (S,) or of a party, or company of men, (TA,) He, or they, became like the $uraAp [pl. of $aArK q. v.] in his, or their, actions; (S, * TA;) and so ↓ A$rY. (IAth, TA.)

6 ta$aArayaA *
They sued each other; or cited each other before a judge; syn. taqaADayaA. (A, TA.)
8 A_i$otaraYa see the first paragraph, in three places.

10 Ast$rY * : see 1, latter part, in three places: and see 3. ― -b2- Also He persisted, or persevered, in consideration, or examination. (TA.) ― -b3- And Ast$rY fiY diynihi He strove, or exerted himself, or was diligent, or studious, and was careful, or mindful, or regardful, in his religion. (TA.) ― -b4- And Ast$rt AlA^umuwru bayonahumo The affairs, or events, were, or became, great, or formidable, between them, or among them. (K, * TA. [See also $ariYa.]) ― -b5- And see 4.

12 Ai$oraworaY *
It was, or became, in a state of commotion. (K. [See also $ariYa.])

$aroYN * The colocynth: (S, K:) or it signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (S,) the plant thereof: (S, K:) n. un. with p: (S:) and ↓ $aroyaAnN also signifies the colocynth; as a dial. var. of $aroYN: or the leaves thereof. (TA.) One says, huwa A^aHolaY mina AlA^aroYi waA^amar~u mina Al$~aroYi [He, or it, is sweeter than honey and more bitter than colocynth]. (TA.) And fulaAnN lahu TaEomaAni A^aroYN wa$aroYN [Such a one has two flavours, that of honey and that of colocynth]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And Any kind of plant that spreads upon the ground, running [or creeping] and extending; such as the melon and the cucumber. (AHn, O voce suT~aAHN, q. v., and TA * in the present art.) ― -b3- And Palm-trees that grow from the datestones: (K:) and with p [as the n. un.] one of such palm-trees. (S.) ― -b4- And, accord. to IJ, A kind of tree of which bows are made. (L voce Hat~N, q. v. [See also $iroyaAnN.]) -A2- See also $arFY. -A3- And see $arowaY.

$arFY *
A road, (K, TA,) in a general sense. (TA.) And, (K,) with the article Al, [particularly] A road of Selmà, (S, K, TA,) the mountain so called, (TA,) abounding with lions: (S, K, TA:) whence they say of courageous men, maA humo A_il~aA A^usuwdu Al$~araY [They are no other than the lions of Esh-Sharà]. (TA.) ― -b2- And i. q. naAHiyapN [as meaning An adjacent tract or region]; (S, K;) as also ↓ $araA='N: (K:) accord. to some, of the right hand: (TA:) pl. A^a$oraA='N. (S, K.) Hence, $araY AlfuraAti The adjacent tract (naAHiyap) of the Euphrates: (TA:) and A^a$oraA='u AlHarami the adjacent tracts of the Sacred Territory; syn. nawaAHiyhi. (S.) ― -b3- And A mountain. (K.) -A2- Also The bad, or worse, or worst, of cattle: accord. to J, [in the S,] ↓ $aroYN, [said in the S to be like $awaY AlmaAli,] which is [said to be] a mistake: (K:) but ElBedr El-Karáfee questions it being so: (TA:) and the good, or better, or best, thereof; as also ↓ $araApN: thus having two contr. significations: (K:) and so says ISk: but ISd says that A_ibilN ↓ $araApN, like saraApN, means choice camels. (TA.) -A3- And A certain eruption upon the body, resembling dirhems: (TA:) or small pimples or purulent pustules, having a burning property: (S:) or small pimples or purulent pustules, red, itching, and distressing, generally originating at once, (K, TA,) but sometimes gradually, (TA,) and becoming [more] severe by night in consequence of a hot vapour breaking forth at once upon the body: (K, TA:) thus in the “ Kánoon ” of Ibn-Seenà [or Avicenna]. (TA.) -A4- *uw Al$~araY A certain idol of [the tribe of] Dows (dawos), (K, TA,) in the Saráh (Als~araAp): so says Nasr. (TA.)

$arK *
Having the eruption termed $arFY, described in the next preceding paragraph. (S, K.)

$irFY * , (S, TA,) an inf. n. of $araY, aor. ya$oriY, (TA,) [when used as a simple subst., signifying A sale and also a purchase,] has A^a$oriyapN for its pl., which, as pl. of a sing. of the measure fiEalN, is anomalous. (S, TA.)
$araApN * : see $arFY, in two places.
$araA='N * : see $arFY.

$ariY~N *
Sold: and also bought: applied in this sense to a male slave; and $ariy~apN to a female slave. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also A horse that persists, or perseveres, in his pace, or going: (S:) or that exceeds the usual bounds therein, (K, TA,) and goes on without languor: (TA:) or a choice horse: (A, TA:) or an excellent, choice horse. (TA.)

$ariy~apN *
A way, course, mode, or manner, of acting or conduct or the like: and a nature; or a natural, a native, or an innate, disposition or temper or the like. (K.) -A2- Also, of women, Such as bring forth females. (K.) One says, tazaw~aja fiY $ariy~api nisaA='K He married among women such as bring forth females. (TA.)

$arowaY * , in which the w is a substitute for Y, as it is in taqowaY and the like, (TA,) The like (S, K) of a thing: (S:) because a thing is sometimes bought with the like thereof: (TA:) [used alike as sing. and pl.: and, accord. to the TA, it seems that ↓ $aroYN signifies the same.] It is said of Shureyh, kaAna yuDam~inu AlqaS~aAra $arowaY Alv~awobi Al~a*iY A^aholakahu [He used to make the washer responsible for the like of the garment, or piece of cloth, that he destroyed]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. of 'Omar, relating to the [collecting of the] poorrate, falaA yaA^oxu*u A_il~aA tiloka Als~in~a mino $arowaY A_ibilihi [i. e. And he shall not take any save of that age, of the likes of his camels]. (TA.)

$irawiY~N * , in which the w is a substitute for Y, and ↓ $iraAy^iY~N, [both signifying Of, or relating to, selling, and also of, or relating to, buying,] are rel. ns.; the former, of the inf. n. $irFY; and the latter, of the inf. n. $iraA='N. (Msb, TA.)
$aroyaAnN * see $aroYN: ― -b2- and see what next follows.

$iroyaAnN * and ↓ $aroyaAnN, (S, K,) the former of which is the more in repute, (TA,) the former said to be quasi-quadriliteral, like jiroyaAlN, [and therefore mentioned also in the TA in art. $rn,] but held by IB to be of the measure fiEolaAnN, (TA in art. $rn,) A kind of tree, (S, K, TA,) of the EiDaAh [q. v.] of the mountains, (TA,) of which bows are made: (S, K, TA:) n. un. with p: the tree thus called grows in the manner, and of the height and width, of the [species of lote-tree called] sidor, and has a yellow, sweet nabiqap [or drupe]: so says AHn: and he adds, Aboo-Ziyád says, bows are made of the $ryAn, and the bow made thereof is good, but black tinged with redness; its wood being of those woods of which good bows are [commonly] made; and they assert that it seldom, or never, becomes crooked: Mbr says that the naboE and $awoHaT [q. v.] and $ryAn are one kind of tree, but differing in name and estimation according to the places of growth; such thereof as is upon the summit of the mountain being the nbE; and such as is at the base, or foot, or lowest or lower part, thereof, the $ryAn. (TA. [But see $awoHaTN.]) ― -b2- Also sing. of $araAyiynu signifying The arteries; i. e. the pulsing veins; (S, K;) which spring from the heart: (S:) but the anatomists assert that they spring from the liver, and pass by the heart. (TA.) ― -b3- $iroyaAnN, with kesr, signifies also A crack, or fissure, [in a rock,] such as is termed vat~N. (Az, TA.)
$iraAy^iY~N * : see $irawiY~N.

$aArK *
Selling, or a seller: (Mgh, TA:) and buying, or a buyer: as also ↓ mu$otarK [in both senses, but generally in the latter sense; whereas $aArK is generally used in the former sense]: (TA:) pl. of the former $uraApN. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Also, (S, TA,) and ↓ $aAriY~N, in which latter the Y is not the Y of a rel. n. but is an affix corroborative of the epithet, as in the cases of A^aHowaru and A^aHowariY~N [or A^aHomaru and A^aHomariY~N] and Sul~abN and Sul~abiY~N, (TA,) One of the people to whom is applied the appellation Al$~uraApu, (S, TA,) which means the [heretics, or schismatics, commonly known by the name of] xawaArij [pl. of xaArijiY~N, q. v.]: (S, M, Mgh, K, &c.:) so called because they said, We have sold ourselves in obedience to God, i. e., for Paradise, when we separated ourselves from the erring Imáms: (S:) or because they sold themselves for the sake of what they believed: or because they said, Verily God has purchased us and our possessions: (Mgh:) but ISk says, because of their vehement hatred of the Muslims: and the author of the K says that it is from $ariYa signifying “ he was angry, ” and “ he persisted, or persevered; ” and he charges J with error in his explaining it as above, from their saying “ we have sold ourselves ” &c.; but this charge is senseless, for J has followed herein more than one of the leading authorities: the author of the K has followed ISd, who, however, adds, as to themselves, they say “ We are the $uraAp ” because of the saying in the Kur ii. 203 [cited in the first paragraph of this art.], and the saying [in ix. 112] “ Verily God hath purchased, of the believers, themselves ” [&c.]; and the like is said in the Nh, with this addition, that $uraApN is the pl. of $aArK; i. e., it is from $araY, aor. ya$oriY; or it may be from Almu$aAraApu meaning AlmulaAj~apu: moreover, the part. n. of $ariYa is $arK; and this has not $uraApN for its pl. (TA.)
$aAriY~N * : see the next preceding paragraph.
mu$otarK * : see $aArK. -A2- Almu$otariY A certain star, (S, K,) well-known; (K;) [Jupiter;] one of the Seven Stars. (TA.) -A3- And A certain bird. (K.)

1 $azaba * , (S, A, O, K,) and $azuba, (O, K,) aor. of each
$azuba , (K,) inf. n. $uzuwbN (S, A, O, K) and $azobN, (K,) He was, or became, such as is termed $aAzibN meaning as expl. below: (S, A, O, K:) [mostly] said of a horse. (S, A, O, TA.)

2 $z~bhu * , (O, K,) inf. n. ta$oziybN, (K,) He, or it, caused it (a rod, O) to wither: (O, K, TA:) and he, or it, made him to become lean, or light of flesh; slender, and lean; or lean, and lank in the belly. (TA.)
$azobapN * : see what follows.

$aAzibN *
Lean, or light of flesh; slender, and lean; or lean, and lank in the belly; applied to a horse: (S, O:) [or] ↓ $azobapN signifies thus, applied to a she-ass, (K, TA,) and a she-camel: (so accord. to the CK:) and $aAzibN, lean, &c., as above; and tough; (A, K;) applied to a horse, (A, TA,) and to a man, &c.: (TA:) or lean, or light of flesh, though not emaciated: (As, TA:) and, applied to a man, very slender or slim or spare: (A:) pl. $uz~abN, (S, A, O, K,) applied to horses, (S, A, O,) and [as also of $aAzibapN] $awaAzibu. (K.) And $aAzibapN A she-gazelle lean, or light of flesh; or slender, and lean; or lean, and lank in the belly; in consequence of her having come from after: pl. $awaAzibu. (TA.) ― -b2- And Rough; (S, K, TA;) applied to a place. (S, TA.)

1 $azarahu * , and $azara A_ilayohi, aor.
$azira , (K,) inf. n. $azorN, (TA,) He looked askew, or sideways, at him, (IAmb, K,) not turning his face towards him, (TA,) [or with a slight turning of the face, (see laHaZahu,)] by reason of hatred or of awe: (IAmb:) or he looked at him with a look of aversion: or he looked at him from the right and left: (K:) or from the outer angle of the eye: generally, in anger: or with hatred and anger: (TA:) or, (K,) as also naZara A_ilayohi $azorFA, (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) he looked at him from the outer angle of the eye, (S, A, Msb, K,) with anger, (S, K,) or with aversion, like as one looks who hates another, (A, Mgh,) or like one who is averse and angry: (Msb:) or $azarahu signifies he looked at him with the look of an enemy. (TA.) The saying of 'Alee, AiloHaZuwA Al$~azora waA@ToEunuwA Alyasora, is expl. as signifying Look ye from the right and left [and thrust ye straight forward]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also $azarahu, (Fr, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Fr,) He smote him with the [evil] eye. (Fr, K.) ― -b3- Also $azarahu He thrust him, or pierced him, (K,) with a spear-head. (TA.) And TaEanahu $azorFA He thrust him, or pierced him, sideways. (A.) ― -b4- $azara Aljabola, aor.
$azira and
$azura , (K,) inf. n. $azorN, (TA,) He twisted the rope, or cord, from the left [by rolling it against his body from left to right]: (ISd, K:) or he twisted it upwards [by rolling it upwards against his thigh or body]: (As, AM:) or he twisted it from without [by rolling it against his thigh], and turned it towards his belly [contrarily to the usual manner, which is termed yasorN, and which is the twisting downwards, by rolling the rope or cord downwards either against the body or against the thigh]; (ISd, K;) as also ↓ Ast$zrhu. (K.) [See also $azorN, below.]
3 $Azrhu * , inf. n. mu$aAzarapN, He treated him, or regarded him, with enmity, or hostility: whence [the manner of looking termed] Al$~azoru. (AA.)

4 A$zrhu A@ll~`hu *
God cast him into an evil case from which he could not extricate himself. (TA.)

5 t$z~r *
He was angry. (K.) [See also t$*~r.] ― -b2- He prepared himself, liloqitaAli for fight, (K,) and lils~ujuwdi [for prostration in prayer]. (Mgh.)

6 t$AzrwA *
They looked, one at another, in the manner termed $azorN, (S, K,) from the outer angle of the eye. (TA.) [See 1.]
10 Ast$zr * : see 1, last sentence but one. -A2- Also It (a rope or cord) was twisted in the manner described above, in the explanation of $azara AlHabola. (K.)

TaEonN $azorN *
A thrusting, or piercing, from the right and from the left: (S, M, TA:) or with the right hand and the left. (TA.) ― -b2- fatolN $azorN A twisting upwards, contrarily to the manner in which the spindle [usually] turns. (S.) [See 1.] ― -b3- gazolN $azorN Spun thread [app. twisted in a manner the reverse of that which is usual: (see 1; and see also radonN:) or] that is uneven. (K.) ― -b4- TaHana biAlr~aHaY $azorFA, [in which $azorFA appears to be an inf. n., though its verb is not mentioned,] He ground with the hand-mill turning it from his right: [i. e., making it to revolve in the same course as do the hands of a watch:] (S, A, K: *) the contrary [which is the common way] is termed bat~FA (A, TA.) ― -b5- And maA zaAla $azorFA He ceased not to be taking the wrong way. (IAar, TA.) -A2- $azorN also signifies Difficulty (K) in an affair. (TA.)

fiY laHoZihi $azarN * [In his glance is a sidelong and
angry look, from the outer angle of the eye: see 1]. (S, K. *) ― -b2- $azarN signifies [also] Disquietude. (Mgh.)

entryFree.key: A^ataAhu Ald~ahoru bi$azorapK laA yanoHal~u minohaA

div2.entryFree: A^ataAhu Ald~ahoru bi$azorapK laA yanoHal~u minohaA * [Time, or fortune, brought him a calamity from which he was not to be extricated;] meaning, destroyed him. (TA.)
$uzorapN * (tropical:) Redness in the eye, and, or with, (so in the K accord. to the TA, but in the CK “ or, ”) what is termed $azarN in the glance thereof. (K.)

labanN A^a$ozaru * (tropical:) Red milk. (TS, K.) ― -b2- EayonN $azoraA='u (tropical:) An eye that is red, and (so in the K accord. to the TA, but in the CK “ or, ”) with what is termed $azarN in the glance thereof. (K.)

HabolN ma$ozuwrN *
A rope, or cord, twisted from the left; (Lth, A, Msb, TA;) which is the stronger way: (Lth, A:) or upwards: (As, T, S:) [see 1:] and ↓ gadaAy^iru musota$oziraAtN, (S, TA,) and ↓ musota$ozaraAtN, (TA,) [Pendent locks of hair] so twisted. (S, TA.)
musota$ozarN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

1 $asaEa Aln~aEola * , (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
$asaEa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. $asoEN, (O, K,) He put a $isoE [q. v.] to the sandal; (S, * Msb, * K;) as also ↓ $as~aEahaA, and ↓ A^a$osaEahaA. (S, O, K.) -A2- $asiEati Aln~aEolu, aor.
$asaEa , The sandal had its $isoE broken. (Ibn-Buzurj, O, K.) ― -b2- $asiEa Alfarasu, aor. as above, inf. n. $asaEN, The horse had a gap, or space, between his central incisor and the tooth next to it. (Aboo-Málik, IDrd, O, K. *) -A3- $asaEa, aor. as above, inf. n. $asoEN and $usuwEN, It was, or became, distant, or remote; said of a place of alighting, or abode. (K.) And, said of anything, i. q. tanaA='aY [It was or became, far from another thing]: and $axaSa [it rose, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- $asaEa He put, or sent, or removed, him, or it, away, or far away; as also ↓ A$sEhu. (TA.)
2 $as~aEa see the preceding paragraph.
4 A^a$osaEa see 1, first and last sentences.

$isoEN * (S, O, Msb, K, &c.) and $isiEN (K) and ↓ $isoEan~N, so in some of the copies of the K, (TA,) [thus in my MS. copy of the K, and also in the O,] with an augmentative n, (O, TA,) The qibaAl of the sandal; (K;) [i. e.] the appertenance of the sandal that is attacked, or tied, to its zimaAm; (S;) [meaning] one of the thongs, or straps, or strips of leather, of the sandal, being that which passes between two toes, of which the [lower] end enters the hole, or perforation, that is in the fore part of the sandal, and which is attacked [at its upper end] to the zimaAm [or, as it is also called, the $iraAk, a thong, or strap, or strip of leather, extending towards the ankle, and having two arms, (its EaDudaAni,) which are attacked to the A^u*unaAni (q. v.), or pass through these and unite behind the foot]: (IAth, TA:) a poet says, referring to camels,
↓ A^aHoduw bihaA munoqaTiEFA $isoEan~iY
[I urge them on by singing to them, with the interdigital thong of my sandal broken]: (Lth, O, TA:) the pl. of $isoEN is $usuwEN (S, O, Msb, K, TA) and A^a$osaAEN: (O, K, TA:) ISd and Z affirm that it has only the former pl.; but AHei contradicts this: (TA:) the latter pl. [a pl. of pauc.] occurs in the saying of 'Obeyd Ibn-Eiyoob El- 'Amberee,
yudiyru naEolayohi liy^al~aA tuEorafaA
yajoEalu A^a$osaAEahumaA naHowa AlqafaA
[He turns round his sandals, in order that they may not be known by their prints upon the ground; putting the interdigital thongs thereof in the direction of the back of the neck]. (O, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] qibaAlu Al$~isoEi signifies (assumed tropical:) The serpent; mentioned by IAar with qibaAlu Al$~ibori. (TA.) ― -b3- And $isoEN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The extremity of a place. (O, K.) One says, HalalonaA $isoEa Ald~ahonaA='i (assumed tropical:) [We alighted in the extremity of the sandy desert, or of the desert called Ed-Dahnà]. (O.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) A narrow tract of land. (O, K.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) Somewhat remaining of property or cattle. (IAar, O, K, TA.) And (K) (tropical:) A small quantity or number of property or cattle. (Mohárib, O, K, TA.) One says, lahu $isoEu maAlK (tropical:) He has a small quantity of property, or a small number of cattle; (Mohárib, O, K, TA;) or a small collection of camels and of sheep or goats: (K, TA:) and Fr adds maAlK ↓ $asiyEu [app. in the same sense: but see another explanation of $isoEu maAlK in what follows]. (O.) ― -b6- And (tropical:) The greater portion or number of property or cattle. (El-Mufaddal, O, K, TA.) Thus it has two contr. [?] significations. (K.) One says, *ahaba $isoEu maAlihi (tropical:) The greater portion of his property, or the greater number of his cattle, went, or passed, away. (El-Mufaddal, O, TA.) ― -b7- And fulaAnN $isoEu maAlK (tropical:) Such a one is a good manager of cattle or camels &c.; (S, O, K, TA;) one who keeps assiduously to the tending, or pasturing, thereof: (A, TA:) and Fr says, huwa maAlK ↓ $asiyEu, as syn. with $isoEu maAlK. (TA: [but see above.])
$isoEan~N * : see $isoEN, in two places.
$asuwEN * : see $aAsiEN.
$asiyEu maAlK * : see $isoEN, in two places.

$aAsiEN * A man having his $isoE broken. (O, K.) ― -b2- Also Distant, or remote; and so ↓ $asuwEN: (S, O, K:) both applied to a place of alighting, or abode: (O, K:) pl. [of either, irreg.,] $usoEN. (K.) One says bilaAdN $aAsiEapN [Distant countries or towns]. (Msb.) And rajulN $aAsiEu Ald~aAri A man whose house, or abode, or country, is distant. (TA.) And $afarN $aAsiEN A far journey. (TA.)
$awo$abN * , mentioned in the K under this head and in art. $b: see the latter art.

1 $aSara * , (A 'Obeyd, O,) aor.
$aSura , (O,) inf. n. $aSorN, (A 'Obeyd, S, O, K,) He sewed (a garment, or piece of cloth, A 'Obeyd) with wide stitches, or with stitches far apart, (S, O, K,) as in the manner termed ba$okN. (A 'Obeyd.) ― -b2- $aSara Eayona AlbaAziY, (S, O,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S,) He sewed up the eye of the hawk. (S, O.) ― -b3- $aSara Aln~aAqapa, (M, O, K,) aor.
$aSura and
$aSira , (O, K,) inf. n. as above, (S, M, O, K,) He transfixed the sides of the she-camel's vulva with small sharp-pointed pieces of wood, or prickles, (M, O, * K, *) and twisted round behind them sinews, (M,) or a string made of hairs from her tail, (M, O, * K, *) on account of the protruding of her womb on the occasion of her bringing forth; (M, O, K;) syn. of the inf. n. tazoniydN. (S.) See also $iSaArN, below. ― -b4- And $aSara Aln~aAqapa, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) signifies also He inserted the piece of wood called $iSaAr between the nostrils of the she-camel; and so ↓ $S~rhA, (K,) inf. n. ta$oSiyrN. (TA.) ― -b5- $aSaratohu $awokapN, (O, K,) inf. n. as above, (K,) A thorn pricked, or pierced, him. (O, K.) ― -b6- $aSarahu biAlr~umoHi, (O,) inf. n. as above, He pierced him (O, K *) with the spear. (O.) ― -b7- $aSorN also signifies A bull's, (O, K,) and a gazelle's, (TA,) smiting (O, K, TA) a man (O, TA) with his horn. (O, K, TA.) -A2- And $aSara, (IAar, O,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He leaped, or leaped upwards; syn. Tafara. (IAar O, K. *) ― -b2- $aSara baSaruhu, aor.
$aSira , (O, K, in the L
$aSura ,) inf. n. $uSuwrN, His eye, or eyes, became fixedly open, or raised, or stretched and raised, or his eyelids became raised and he looked intently and became disquieted or disturbed, (syn. $axaSa,) and the eye became inverted; at the time of death: (O, K:) thus, nearly in the same words, expl. by Lth and IF and Ibn-'Abbád: (O:) or the correct word is $aSaA, or $aTara; (so accord. to different copies of the K, the latter being the reading in the TA;) or both; for Az says that this explanation of $Sr bSrh is in his opinion a mistake, and that it is correctly $aSaA baSaruhu and $aTara, meaning that he was as though he looked at thee and at another. (O, TA. *)
2 $aS~ara see the preceding paragraph.
$iSorN * , and its dual: see $iSaArN.

$aSarN * (A 'Obeyd, S, K) and ↓ $aASirN (Lth, S, K) and ↓ $awoSarN (K) The young one of the gazelle, when he has become strong and active: (A 'Obeyd, S, L, &c.:) in the K, when he has become strong, but not active; but this is a mistake: (TA:) or that has become old enough to smite with his horn: or that has become a month old: or that has not yet cropped the herbage [but only sucked his mother]; expl. by Al~a*iY lamo yaHotaniko: (K:) A 'Obeyd states that it is said by more than one of the Arabs of the desert that the young one of the gazelle is called TalFA; then, xi$ofN; and when his horns come forth, $aAdinN; and when he has become strong and active, $aSarN, of which the fem. [as is also said in the K] is $aSarapN; then, ja*aEN; and
then, vaniY~N, which name he continues to have until he dies: (S:) [perhaps correctly corresponding to our six terms which are as follows: a fawn (applied to a buck or doe of the first year), a pricket (to a buck of the second year), a sorel (to a buck of the third year), a sore (to a buck of the fourth year), a buck of the first head (to one of the fifth year), and a great buck (to one of the sixth year):] or ↓ $aASirN is applied to a young gazelle when his horn has come forth: (Lth:) pl. [of $aSarN,] A^a$oSaArN. (K.) ― -b2- $aSarN also signifies A certain bird, smaller than the EuSofuwr [or sparrow], (AA, O, K,) of the colour thereof. (AA, O.)

$iSaArN * The small sharp-pointed piece of wood, or prickle, (K,) or the small sharp-pointed pieces of wood, or prickles, (IDrd, S,) with which the operation termed tazoniydN [which is that described above in the explanation of $aSara Aln~aAqapa] is performed; (IDrd, S, K;) as also ↓ $iSorN: (K:) or ↓ $iSoraAni, or $iSaAraAni, is a term applied to two pieces of wood, which are thrust through the edge of the rectum of a she-camel, and then bound with a strong string of the fibres of the palm-tree, behind them: this is done when they desire to make a she-camel affect the young one of another: they take a stuffed durojap [q. v.], and insert it into her rectum, and transfix the rectum with two sharp-pointed pieces of wood, which they bind as above described: this operation is termed ↓ $aSorN and tazoniydN. (ISh.) [See also 1.] ― -b2- Accord. to the T, A piece of wood, which is bound between the two edges of a she-camel's vulva. (TA.) ― -b3- And A piece of wood, which is inserted between the nostrils of a she camel. (K.)

$aSiyrN *
A prick of a thorn. (O, K.)
$aASirN * : see $aSarN, in two places.
$awoSarN * : see $aSarN.

$aASirapN *
One of the snares with which beasts of prey are caught. (O, K, TA.)

div2.head: $Sw and $SY
div2.entryFree:
1 $aSaA baSaruhu * , (S, K,) aor.
1a2u3a , (S, TA,) inf. n. $uSuw~N, (S, TA, and so in copies of the K, accord. to the CK $aSowN, [and this, though wrong, is agreeable with a rule generally observed in the K, as it is not there followed by any indication of the form,]) like Euluw~N, (TA,) His eye, or eyes, became fixedly open, or raised, or stretched and raised, or his eyelids became raised and he looked intently and became disquieted or disturbed, syn. $axaSa, (S, K, TA,) [at the time of death, (see $aSara,)] as though he looked at thee and at another. (TA.) ― -b2- And $aSaA Als~aHaAbu The clouds rose, or rose high, (T, S, K,) in their first appearing. (T, TA.) And $aSaA said of anything, It rose, or rose high. (T, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] $aSati Alqirobapu, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) The water-skin being filled with water, (K, TA,) and in like manner, being inflated, (TA,) its legs became raised, or raised high. (K, TA.) And thus also, $aSaA Alz~iq~u, The wine-skin being filled with wine, its legs became raised or raised high. (TA.) ― -b4- And $aSaY, aor.
1a2i3a ; (Ks, S, TA;) or $aSaA, aor.
1a2u3a ; and and $aSiYa aor.
1a2a3a ; (K;) but this last requires consideration, differing as it does from what is in the S [without any allusion to the latter's being wrong]; (TA; [see also $aZaY;]) said of a corpse; (Ks, S, K;) Its arms and legs rose, or rose high; (K;) or it became inflated, or swollen, and its arms and legs rose, or rose high. (Ks, S.) ― -b5- And $aSaY birijolihi He raised, or raised high, his leg. (TA.)
4 A$SY baSarahu * [He made his eye, or eyes, to become fixedly open, or raised, &c.: see 1, first sentence: or] he raised, or he raised high, his eye, or eyes. (S, K, * TA.)

$aSowN *
i. q. $id~apN [app. as meaning Hardship, distress, or adversity]. (Az, K.) -A2- And A siwaAk [or piece of stick with which the teeth are cleansed]. (IAar, Az, TA. [See also $awoSN.])

$aASK * ; fem. $aASiyapN, pl. of the latter $aASiyaAtN and $awaASK; part. n. of 1 (S, TA) as said of the eyes [i. e. Fixedly open, or being raised, &c.]: (TA:) and of a water-skin, meaning Filled, or inflated, so that its legs are raised; and of a wine-skin, meaning filled, so that its legs are raised: and of a corpse, meaning Inflated, &c. (S, TA.) It is said in a prov.,
A_i*aA A@rojaHan~a $aASiyFA faA@rofaEo yadaA
[expl. in art. rjHn, q. v.]. (S, TA.)

1 $aT~a * , aor.
$aTi3a and
$aTu3a , (S, Msb, K,) [the latter contr. to analogy,] the pret. like Daraba and qatala, (Msb, [and the like is said in the TA,]) inf. n. $aT~N and $uTuwTN, (S, K,) It (a house, or dwelling, S, Msb, TA, and a place of visitation, TA) was, or became, distant, remote, or far off. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- $aT~a fiY Als~awomi, (Msb, K,) aor.
$aTi3a and
$aTu3a , (Msb,) inf. n. $aT~u and $aTaTN; (TA;) or fiyhi ↓ A^a$aT~a; (S;) or both, (Msb, K,) but the latter is the more common; (K;) and ↓ A$tT~; (S;) He went far, (S, K,) or beyond the due bounds, in offering a thing for sale and demanding a price for it, or in bargaining for a thing: (S, Msb, K:) the verb in this phrase is also followed by Ealayohi [against him]. (TA.) IB says that $aT~a signifies baEuda [meaning He, or it, was, or became, distant, &c.]: and that ↓ A^a$aT~a signifies A^aboEada [meaning he went far, &c.]. (TA.) You say also, fiY TalabiY ↓ A^a$aT~uwA They went far, or very far, or to a great or an extraordinary length, in seeking me. (S, K. *) And Alqawomu fiY TalabinaA ↓ A^a$aT~a The people, or company of men, sought us walking and riding. (TA.) And fiY AlmafaAzapi ↓ A^a$aT~a He went away in the desert: (K:) as though he went far in it. (TA.) And $aT~a fiY siloEatihi, inf. n. $aTaTN, He exceeded the due bounds, and went far from what was right, in respect of his commodity, or article of merchandise. (K.) And $aT~a fiY Hukomihi, (Msb, K,) aor
$aTi3a , (K, TA,) only, (TA,) or
$aTi3a and
$aTu3a , (Msb,) the latter aor. is mentioned in the L, (TA,) inf. n. $aTaTN, (Msb, TA,) in the K, erroneously, $aTiyTN, (TA,) and $uTuwTN also; (Msb;) and ↓ A$T~; (Msb, K;) and ↓ A$tT~; (K;) or fiY AlqaDiy~api ↓ A$T~; (S;) He acted unjustly, wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically, (S, Msb, K,) in his judging, or exercising jurisdiction or rule, or passing sentence, (Msb, K,) or in judging, &c., (S,) Ealayohi against him. (K.) And $aTaTotu Ealayohi, (S, L,) aor.
$aTu3a , (L,) and ↓ A^a$oTaTotu; (S, L;) I acted unjustly, wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically, against him: mentioned by A'Obeyd. (S, L.) It is said in the Kur [xxxviii. 21], walaA ta$oTuTo, or ↓ tu$oTiTo, or ↓ tu$aT~iTo, or ↓ tu$aATiTo, accord. to different readings, And go not thou far from what is right: (K, TA:) all having this meaning: (TA:) or exceed not the due bounds. (Bd.) $aTaTN signifies The exceeding the due bounds (AA, S, Mgh) in selling, and in demanding or seeking, and in exercising jurisdiction, &c., (AA,) or in everything. (S.) It is said in a trad. lahaA mahoru mivolihaA laA wakosa walaA $aTaTa [She shall have the dowry of her like:] there shall be no falling short nor exceeding. (S.) And you say of a just sale, laA baxosa fiyhi walaA $aTaTa, (S in art. bxs,) or wlA $uTuwTa, (T and TA in that art.,) [There is no deficiency in it nor excess.] You also say $aT~a fiY Alqawoli, aor.
$aTi3a and
$aTu3a , inf. n. $aTaTN and $uTuwTN, He was rough, harsh, or coarse, in speech. (Msb.) -A2- $aT~a used transitively, [aor.
$aTu3a ,] He passed, or passed beyond, [or, probably, passed far away from,] a place. (TA.) ― -b2- $aT~a fulaAnFA, (K,) aor.
$aTu3a , (TA,) inf. n. $aT~N and $uTuwTN, (K,) He distressed, or afflicted, such a one, and treated him, or used him, unjustly, wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically: (K:) so say AZ and Aboo-Malik. (TA.) ― -b3- $aAT~ahu fa$aT~ahu: see 3.

2 $T~T * , inf. n. ta$oTiyTN, He strove, laboured, exerted himself, or did his utmost, in acting unjustly, wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically, and exceeding the due bounds. (K, * TA.) See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.

3 $AT~hu * , (K,) inf. n. mu$aAT~apN, (TA,) He vied with him in Ai$otiTaAT [i. e. going far, or beyond the due bounds, in offering a thing for sale and demanding a price for it, or in bargaining for a thing; or acting unjustly, wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically, in judging, &c.]. (K.) You say, ↓ $AT~hu fa$aT~ahu [He vied with him in so doing, and surpassed him, or overcame him, therein]. (TA.) See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.
4 A^a$oTa3a see 1, in nine places.
8 A_i$otaTa3a see 1, in two places.

$aT~N * The bank, or side, of a river: (S, Msb, K:) and of a valley: (S, Msb:) or, of the latter, the rising ground next the bottom: (AHn:) pl. $uTuwTN (Msb, K) and $uT~aAnN; (K;) the latter occurring in a verse, accord. to one relation; but
accord. to another relation, it is $uToA=nN, pl. of $aATiy^N, which is syn. with $aT~N. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) The side of a camel's hump; (S, K;) any side thereof: (S:) or the half thereof: (K:) pl. $uTuwTN. (S, K.)
$aT~apN * : see $aAT~N.
$iT~apN * : see $aTaATN, in two places.

$aTaTN * , for A^amorN *uw $aTaTK, (Mgh,) and qawolN *uw $aTaTK, (Bd in lxxii. 4,) An action, or affair, (Mgh,) and a saying, (Bd,) that is extravagant, or exorbitant, or exceeding the due bounds. (Mgh, Bd.) [See 1, of which it is an inf. n.]

$aTaATN *
Distance; remoteness; (S, K, TA;) as also ↓ $iTaATN and ↓ $iT~apN, with kesr, (K,) and ↓ ma$aT~apN. (TA.) It is said in a trad., Aall~`hum~a A^aEuw*u bika mino wasuwo'i Almunoqalabi ↓ waEovaA='i Als~afari wakaA=bapi Al$~iT~api i. e. [O God, verily I seek protection by Thee from trouble of travel, and grievousness] of distance of the space to be journeyed over, [and evilness of return to my home.] (TA.) ― -b2- And Distance, or farness, between the two extremities of a man; as also ↓ $iTaATN and ↓ $aTaATapN. (K.) And Tallness, and beauty of stature: (K:) or justness of stature: (IDrd, S, K:) as also ↓ $iTaATN, (S, K,) in either sense. (K.) -A2- Also, and ↓ $iTaATN, Fragments of baked bricks. (K.) ― -b2- [Freytag erroneously assigns the first and last meanings in this paragraph to $aT~apN: and he adds, from Reiske, a meaning belonging to $iZaAZN.]
$iTaATN * : see $aTaATN, in four places.
$aTuwTN * A she-camel having a large hump; (As, S, K;) as also ↓ $aTawoTaY: (K:) or large in the two sides of the hump: (TA:) pl. $aTaAy^iTu. (K.)
$aTaATapN * : see $aTaATN.
$aTawoTaY * : see $aTuwTN.

$aTo$aATN *
A certain bird: (K:) IDrd says that it is asserted to have this meaning; but is not of established authority. (O.)

$aAT~N * Anything Distant, remote, or far. (TA.) ― -b2- A man whose two extremities are far from each other. (K.) ― -b3- jaAriyapN $aAT~apN, (S, K,) and ↓ $aT~apN, (K,) A girl tall, and of beautiful stature: (K:) or of just stature. (S, K.) -A2- A_in~aka la$aAT~iY Verily thou art acting unjustly, wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically, towards me in judging: occurring in a trad. (A'Obeyd, Az, S.)
ma$aT~apN * : see $aTaATN. ― -b2- Also Difficulty, distress, affliction, trouble, or inconvenience. (TA.)

1 $aTaA^a * : see 4. -A2- Also He walked on the $aATiy^, i. e. bank, or side, of the river. (K, * TA.) -A3- And He cut lengthwise [into slices, or strips,] the hump of a camel, and a skin, or hide. (TA.) -A4- He subdued, overcame, overpowered, or mastered, a man. (K.) ― -b2- He compressed his wife. (K.) [And saTaA^a and Ta$aA^a signify the same.] ― -b3- $aTaA^aAln~aAqapa, (AA, S, K,) aor.
$aTaAa [as in other senses], (TA,) inf. n. $aTo'N, (AA, S,) He bound the saddle upon the she-camel. (AA, S, K.) ― -b4- And $aTaA^a biAlHimoli He burdened heavily, or overburdened, the camel with the load; (K;) inf. n. as above. (TA.) [But see what follows.] -A5- Accord. to ISk, (TA,) this last phrase signifies also, (K,) or $aTaA^ato biAlHimoli, as in the L, (TA,) He, (a man, K,) or she, (a camel, L, TA,) had strength, or power, to bear the load. (L, K, TA.) -A6- $aTaA^ato bihi She (his mother) cast him forth [from her womb]. (K.) One says, laEana A@ll~`hu A^um~FA $aTaA^ato bihi, and so faTaA^ato bh, May God curse a mother who cast him forth [from her womb]. (TA.)
2 $T~A^ * , inf. n. ta$oTiYo'N, It (a valley) had its two sides ($aATiy^aAhu, TA) flowing [with water]. (IAar, K.)

3 $aATaA^otuhu *
I walked upon one $aATiy^ [i. e. bank, or side, of a river or valley,] while he walked upon the other $ATy^. (S, K. *)

4 A$TA^ * ; (S, Msb;) or ↓ $aTaA^a, aor.
$aTaAa , inf. n. $aTo'N and $uTuwo'N; (K;) or both; (TA;) It put forth its $aTo' [or sprouts, &c.]; (S, K;) syn. far~axa; (Msb;) said of seed-produce; (S, Msb, K;) and in like manner said of palm-trees (naxol); and the former verb, said of trees ($ajar), they put forth sprouts around their bases, or stems. (K.) And A$TA^t Al$~ajarapu biguSuwnihaA The tree put forth its branches. (TA.) ― -b2- And the former verb, (assumed tropical:) He (a man) had a son who had attained to manhood and become like him; (AHn, K;) like A^aSoHaba. (TA.)
Q. Q. 1 $aToyaA^a * , (K, TA,) said of a man, (TA,) i. q. rahoyaA^a, (K, TA,) meaning He was weak (TA) in his opinion, or judgment, (K, TA,) and in his affair. (TA.)

$aTo'N * (S, Msb, K, &c.) and ↓ $aTaA^N (TA as from the K [but not in the CK nor in my MS. copy of the K, though a known dial. var. of the former as will be shown in what follows,]) The firaAx [or sprouts] of seed-produce, (IAar, S, Msb, K,) and of plants, or herbage, (S,) and of palm-trees: or the leaves thereof; (K. TA;) i. e. of seed-produce: (TA:) and the shoots that come forth (Msb, K) from, (Msb,) or around, (K,) the bases, or stems, (Msb, K,) of plants, or herbage, (Msb,) or of trees: (K:) pl. A^a$oTaA='N, (S,) or $uTuwo'N. (K.) A^axoraja $aToA^ahu, in the Kur xlviii. last verse, means That has put forth its firaAx [or sprouts]: (Bd, Jel:) or, accord. to Akh, its extremity: (S:) or its ears, (Msb, TA,) accord. to Fr; each grain, he says, producing ten, or eight, or seven: or, accord. to Zj, its plants: (TA:) and some read ↓ $aTaA^ahu, (Bd, Jel,) which is a dial. var.; and $aTaAhu, and $aTaA='ahu, and $aTahu, and $aTowahu. (Bd.) ― -b2- [See also $aToA^apN.] -A2- And see $aATiy^N.
$aTaA^N * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

$aToA^apN * [app. a n. un. of $aTo'N, q. v. ― -b2- Also] A green palm-branch: one says, lahaA qad~N kaAl$~aToA^api She has a figure like the green palm-branch. (A, TA.) ― -b3- And A slice, or strip, i. e. a piece cut lengthwise, of a camel's hump, and of a skin, or hide. (A, TA.)

$aATiy^N * (S, Msb, K) and ↓ $aTo'N (K) The bank, or side, ($aT~, S, K, and jaAnib, S, Msb,) of a valley (S, Msb, K) and of a river: (K:) and some say that the former signifies the extremity, or edge, or side, (Taraf,) of a river; and the shore of the sea: the pl. of the latter is $uTuwo'N; and of the former, $awaATiy^u and $uToA=nN; (K, TA;) or this last, as is said in the M, may be pl. of $aTo'N. (TA.) Accord. to the S, one says also $aATiy^u AlA^awodiyapi [meaning The sides of the valleys]; not assigning to $ATy^ any pl.: but the truth is that the pl. is as stated above. (TA.)

1 $aTaba * , (K, TA,) aor.
$aTuba , (TA,) inf. n. $aTobN, (AZ, TA,) He cut (K, TA) into oblong pieces, or strips, flesh-meat, and a camel's hump, and a hide, or leather: (TA:) or he cut into strips, but without separating them, a camel's hump. (AZ, TA.) ― -b2- And $aTabati Aljariyda, [aor.
$aTuba ,] inf. n. $aTobN, She (a woman) split the palm-sticks, or palmbranches stripped of their leaves, to make of them mats: which being done, says A'Obeyd, [or when they have been peeled,] the $aATibap [q.v.] throws them to the munaq~iyap. (S.) [Or] $aTabat, aor.
$aTuba , inf. n. $uTuwbN, She removed the upper peel of the $aTob, or [fresh, green] palm-branches. (ISk, TA.) -A2- $aTaba also signifies It inclined, or declined, turned aside or away, deflected, or deviated, and became distant, or remote; (As, O, K;) and so $aTafa; and both signify it went away. (As, TA.) One says, $aTaba Eanohu It turned aside or away, and became distant, or remote, from him, or it. (K.) Thus, in a trad., $aTaba Alr~umoHu Eano maqotalihi The spear deflected from, and failed to reach, his vital part. (O, TA. *) And one says also, $aTabati Ald~aAru The dwelling was, or became, distant, or remote. (O.)

7 An$Tb *
It flowed; (S, K;) said of water, &c. (K.)

$aTobN * pl. of ↓ $aTobapN, (S, Msb,) [or rather a coll. gen. n., of which the latter is the n. un.,] like as tamorN is of tamorapN; (Msb;) Fresh, (A,) or green, (Msb,) or green and fresh, (S, K,) palm-branches (S, A, Msb, K) stripped of their leaves: (A:) or they are less than what are termed $aTaAy^ibu, of which the sing. is ↓ $aTiybapN; and the $TAy^b are less than the karaAniyf: [i. e. the kironaAf is the thickest part of the palm-branch; next is the $aTiybap; and next to this, the $aTobap:] or ↓ $aTobapN signifies a green palm-branch. (K.) kamasal~i
↓ $aTobapK, in a trad. of Umm-Zara, [as expl. in art. sl, q. v.,] means Like a green palm-stick drawn forth from its skin: or like a sword drawn forth [from its scabbard]: (TA in art. sl:) [for] ― -b2- ↓ $aTobapN signifies also A sword. (Aboo-Sa'eed, K.) ― -b3- [Hence, app.,] $aTobN is used also as an epithet, meaning (tropical:) Tall, and well made; (A, K, TA;) applied to a man and to a horse. (TA.) And, applied to a boy, or young man, (tropical:) Plump; or fat, soft, thin-skinned, and plump: and so ↓ $aTobapN applied to a girl, or young woman: (A:) or the former, applied to a boy, or young man, well made, and neither tall nor short: (TA:) or, so applied, light, or active, in body, and sharpheaded: (IAar, TA in art. EDb, voce EaDobN:) or it means, so applied, long and even (sabiTN) in the bones, light of flesh; likened to the palm-stick that is split: but this epithet is mostly used with p, i. e. ↓ $aTobapN, which is applied to a mare: (Ham p. 298:) or this epithet, $aTobapN, applied to a mare, means lank (sabiTapN) in flesh; (K, TA;) or tall; (TA;) as also ↓ $iTobapN in the former sense, (K, TA,) or in the latter; and the masc. is not thus used, applied to a horse: (TA:) and ↓ $aTobapN, (S,) or ↓ $iTobapN, (K,) or both, but the former is the more approved, (TA,) beautiful; plump; or fat, soft, thin-skinned, and plump; (K, TA;) and tall: (K:) or simply tall; (S, TA;) as also ↓ ma$oTuwbN and ↓ mu$aT~abN applied to a man. (TA.)
$aTobapN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in seven places: ― -b2- and see what next follows.

$uTobapN * (S, K) and ↓ $iTobapN (K) and ↓ $aTobapN (TA) and ↓ $uTabapN, (K,) which last is said by some to be a n. un. of $uTabN [mentioned in what follows as a pl.], (MF,) A [raised] line (Tariyqap, S, O, or Tariyq, K, [meaning a ridge, and sometimes also a depressed line, as shown voce mu$aT~abN, i. e. a channel,]) in the maton [i. e. broad side, or middle of the broad side, of the blade] (S, O) of a sword: (S, O, K:) pl. $uTabN and $uTubN, (S, O,) or $uTuwbN and $uTabN and $uTubN: (K: [in which it is said that the pl. is $uTuwbN and $uTabN like gurafN and kutubN: but I think that $uTuwbN is a mistranscription, and that the right reading is $uTabN and $uTubN like gurafN and kutubN:]) hence it would seem that $uTabN and $uTubN are pls. of one sing.; but Ibn-Hishám El-Lakhmee expressly states that the former is pl. of $uTobapN; and the latter, of ↓ $aTiybapN; (MF;) of which $aTaAy^ibu also is a pl.; (L in art. Emd;) and which signifies [the same as $uTobapN, i. e.] the rising Eamuwd [i. e. the ridge] in the maton of a sword. (ISh, TA.) [See also mu$aT~abN: and see EamuwdN and mayonN.]
$aTobapN * : see $aTobN (near the end) in two places: ― -b2- and see also $uTabapN: ― -b3- and $aTiybapN, in three places.
$uTabapN * : see $uTobapN.
$iTaAbN * The instrument with which a baro*aEap [or cloth put beneath a camel's saddle] is quilted. (K.)

$aTiybapN *
A slice, or strip, of flesh-meat: (TA:) or a piece cut lengthwise of a camel's hump; (S, O, K, TA;) as also ↓ $iTobapN: (O, K:) or a piece cut in the form of a strip, but not separated, of a camel's hump; and so ↓ the latter word: pl. of the former $aTaAy^ibu. (AZ, TA.) ― -b2- And A piece cut lengthwise of a hide or of leather; (S, O;) as also ↓ $iTobapN. (O.) ― -b3- And A piece of [the tree called] naboE of which a bow is made. (S, O.) ― -b4- See also $aTobN. ― -b5- And see $uTobapN. ― -b6- Also, applied to a she-camel, Tough; syn. yaAbisapN. (K.) ― -b7- And [the pl.] $aTaAy^ibu Different, or various, parties, sects, or classes, (K, TA,) and sorts, of men &c. (TA.) ― -b8- And Difficulties, or distresses; (Abu-l-Faraj, O, K;) as also $aSaAy^ibu. (Abu-l-Faraj, O, TA.)
$aTiybiy~apN * , (as in the TA,) or ↓ mu$aT~abapN, (as implied in the K,) A quilted baro*aEap [or cloth that is put beneath a camel's saddle]. (K, TA.)

$aT~aAbN *
A butcher. (Fr, TA in art. sTr.)

$aATibN * [act. part. n. of the trans. verb $aTaba]. ― -b2- [Hence,] $awaATibu [the pl. of $aATibapN] signifies Women who cut skin, or leather, into strips, after having shaven it or measured it: so accord. to different copies of the K; i. e. baEoda maA yaHoliqonahu or yaxoluqonahu. (TA.) ― -b3- And Women who split palmleaves, and peel the [palm-branches stripped of their leaves, or the portions thereof termed] Easiyb, to make of them mats, and then throw them to the munaq~iyaAt: (TA:) or the sing., $aATibapN, signifies a woman who peels the Easiyb, (As, TA,) or who splits the palm-sticks, to make of them mats, (S,) and then throws them to the munaq~iyap, (As, S, TA,) who removes all that is upon them with her knife until she has made them slender, when she throws them back to the $aATbp: (As, TA:) or a woman who makes mats of $aTob, i. e. [green, fresh] palm-branches [stripped of their leaves]: (ISk, TA:) the pl. occurs in a verse cited voce ta*ar~aEa. (S, TA.) -A2- Also, [from the intrans. verb $aTaba,] TariyqN $aATibN A road inclining, declining, or turning aside or away. (S, K.) ― -b2- And ramoyapN $aATibapN A shot, or throw, that deflects, or deviates, from a vital part; as also $aATifapN. (TA.) ― -b3- And rajulN $aATibu AlmaHal~i i. q. $aATinN [i. e. A man remote, or distant, in respect of the place of alighting or abode]. (TA.)

mu$aT~abN * A sword (S, A, K) having $uTab [pl. of $uTobapN], (A, K,) i. e. (A, TA) having TaraAy^iq [here meaning ridges, as expl. above, voce $uTobapN], (S, A, TA,) in its maton; [or ridges and channels,] these being in some cases elevated and depressed [lines]; (TA;) as also ↓ ma$oTuwbN: (K, TA:) said by some, [but not so accord. to the A,] to be tropical, as being likened to pieces of a camel's hump cut in strips. (TA.) And in like manner, A garment, or piece of cloth, having TaraAy^iq [as meaning lines, or streaks, or stripes]. (S, TA.) And A^aroDN mu$aT~abapN (tropical:) Land that is furrowed (A, Msb, K) a little, (K,) not much, (Msb,) by a torrent. (A, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Flowing [water &c.; because of the streaks, or lines, with which its surface is diversified]. (TA.) ― -b3- See also $aTiybiy~apN. ― -b4- And see $aTobN, last sentence.

ma$oTuwbN * : see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- farasN ma$oTuwbu Almatoni waAlkafali means A horse swollen with fat in the two portions of flesh and sinew next the back bone, on each side, [and in the rump,] (O, K,) and whose creases of the skin are far apart. (O.) ― -b3- See also $aTobN, last sentence.

1 $aTarahu * , (A, MA, O, TA,) [aor.
$aTura ,] inf. n. $aTorN; (MA;) and ↓ $T~rhu, (K,) inf. n. ta$oTiyrN; (TA;) He halved it; divided it into halves. (A, MA, O, K, TA.) ― -b2- $aTarahaA, aor.
$aTura , (S,) inf. n. $aTorN, (S, K,) He milked one $aTor of her, (namely, a camel, or a ewe or goat, S, [i. e., in the former case one pair of teats, and in the latter case one teat,]) and left the other $aTor. (S, K.) -A2- $aTarato and $aTurato, aor.
$aTura , (K,) inf. n. $iTaArN, (TA,) She (a ewe or goat) had one of her teats dried up: or had one teat longer than the other. (K.) [$iTaArN seems to be also Syn. with HiDaAnN as expl. in this Lex.: see also the latter word in Freytag's Lex.: Reiske, as cited by Freytag, explains the former word as meaning “ quando latus unum vulvæ præ altero propendet. ”] ― -b2- $aTara baSaruhu, (S, K, TA, and so in the O voce saSara, q. v., [in some copies of the S and K and in a copy of the A, erroneously, baSarahu,]) aor.
$aTura , (S,) inf. n. $uTuwrN (S, K) and $aTorN, (TA,) He was as though he were looking at thee and at another: (S, A, K:) on the authority of Fr. (TA.) ― -b3- $aTara $aTorahu He repaired, or betook himself, in the direction of him, or it: or Al$~aToru in the sense of Aljihapu and Aln~aAHiyapu has no verb belonging to it. (K.) ― -b4- $aTarati Ald~aAru The house, or abode, was distant, or remote. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b5- $aTara, (S, K,) aor.
$aTura ; (K;) and $aTura, aor.
$aTura ; inf. n. $aTaArapN, of both verbs, (S, K,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) and $uTuwrN; (L;) [and ↓ t$ATr; (A in art. E*r;)] He was, or became, or acted, like a $aATir [q. v.]. (S, K.) And $aTara EalaY A^aholihi, (A, Msb,) or $aTara Eanohumo, (S, * K,) aor.
$aTura , (Msb,) inf. n. $uTuwrN and $uTuwrapN and $aTaArapN, (K,) or this last is a simple subst., (Msb,) He withdrew far away (S, * A, K *) from his family; or broke off from them, or quitted them, in anger: (A, K:) or he disagreed with his family, and wearied them by his wickedness (Msb, TA) and baseness. (Msb.)

2 $aT~ara see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- $T~r naAqatahu, (S,) or binaAqatihi, (K,) inf. n. ta$oTiyrN, (S, K,) He bound two of the teats of his she-camel with the SiraAr [q. v.], (S, K,) leaving (the other) two (unbound). (K.)

3 $aATarotuhu maAliY *
I halved with him my property; (S, K;) I retained half of my property and gave him the other half. (M, TA.) ― -b2- And $aATarotu
Taliy~iY I left for my lamb, or kid, one teat [of the mother], having milked the other teat and bound it with the SiraAr [q. v.]. (S.)
6 ta$aAoTara see 1, last sentence but one.

$aTorN * The half of a thing; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ $aTiyrN: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^a$oTurN (S, K) and [of mult.] $uTuwrN. (K.) It is said in a prov., AuHolubo HalabFA laka $aToruhu [Milk thou a milking of which half shall be for thee]. (S.) And one says $aEarN $aToraAni Hair [half] black and [half] white. (A.) Accord. to Ibráheem El-Harbee, (O,) the saying of the Prophet, mano manaEa SadaqapF faA_in~aA A=xi*uwhaA wa$aTora maAlihi [Whoso refuses to render a poor-rate, verily we take it from him, and half of his property], thus related by Bahz, is a mistake, and the right wording is, wa$uTira maAluhu, meaning and his property shall be divided into two halves, and the collector of the poor-rate shall have the option given him and shall take that rate from out of the better of the two halves, as a punishment for the man's refusal of the rate; (O, K;) but it is said that this law was afterwards abrogated: (O:) Esh-Sháfi'ee, however, says that, in the old time, when one refused the poor-rate of his property, it was taken from him, and half of his property was taken as a punishment for his refusal; and he adduces this trad. as evidence thereof; but says that in recent times, only the poor-rate was taken from him, and this trad. was asserted to be abrogated. (TA. [More is there said on this subject, but I omit it as unprofitable.]) ― -b2- It occurs in two trads. as meaning Half a mak~uwk [q. v.], or half a wasoq [q. v.], of barley. (TA.) ― -b3- [In prosody, Half a verse.] ― -b4- Also (tropical:) A part, or portion, or somewhat, of a thing; (Mgh, K;) and so ↓ $aTiyrN. (TA.) In the trad. of the night-journey, fawaDaEa $aTorahaA means (assumed tropical:) [And He remitted] part, or somewhat, thereof; (K;) i. e., of the prayer. (TA.) And similar is the saying in another trad., AlT~ahuwru $aToru AlA_iymaAni (assumed tropical:) [Purification is part of faith]. (TA.) ― -b5- Either the fore pair or the hind pair of the teats of a she-camel: she has two pairs of teats, a fore pair and a hind pair, and each pair is thus called: (S, K:) and either of the two teats of a ewe or she-goat: (IAar, TA:) pl. A^a$oTurN. (S, TA.) Hence the saying, (S,) fulaAnN Halaba Ald~ahora A^a$oTurahu (tropical:) Such a one has known, or tried, varieties of fortune: (S, * TA:) has experienced the good and evil of fortune; (S, K, TA;) its straitness and its ampleness: being likened to one who has milked all the teats of a camel, that which yields plenty of milk and that which does not; the fore pair being the good; and the hind pair, the evil: or, as some say, A^a$oTur means streams, or flows, of milk: and [in like manner] one says, Halaba Ald~ahora $aTorayohi. (TA.) And, as is said in the “ Kámil ” of Mbr, one says of a man experienced in affairs, fulaAnN qado Halaba A^a$oTurahu (tropical:) Such a one has endured the difficulties and [enjoyed] the ampleness of fortune, and managed his affairs in poverty and in wealth: lit., has milked his pairs of teats, one pair after another. (TA.) ― -b6- Also A direction in which one looks or goes or the like. (S, A, Msb, K.) One says, qaSada $aTorahu He went in his, or its, direction; towards him, or it. (S, A.) And it is said in the Kur [ii. 139 and 144 and 145], fawal~i wajohaka $aTora A@lomasojidi A@loHaraAmi Then turn thou thy face in the direction of the Sacred Mosque. (Fr, S.) The noun in this sense has no verb belonging to it: or one says, $aTara $aTorahu [expl. above: see 1]. (K.) ― -b7- Also Distance, or remoteness. (TA.)
$uTurN * : see $aTiyrN [of which it is both a syn. and a pl.].

waladu fulaAnK $iTorapN *
The offspring of such a one are half males and half females. (S, A, K. [In the Ham p. 478, it is written $aTorp.])
$aToraAnu * , (S, A, K,) fem. $aToraY, (K,) A bowl, (S, K,) or vessel, (A, K,) half full. (S, A, K.)

$aTuwrN * A ewe, or she-goat, having one teat longer than the other; (S, O, K;) like HaDuwnN in this sense [and perhaps in others also, agreeably with what is said of $iTaArN in the first paragraph of this art.]: (S in art. HaDn:) and (so in the S and O, but in the K “ or ”) one having one of her teats dried up: (S, O, K:) and a she-camel having two of her teats dried up; for she has four teats. (S, O.) And A garment, or piece of cloth, having one of the two extremities of its breadth longer than the other. (O, K.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

$aTiyrN * : see $aTorN, in two places. -A2- Also Distant, or remote; (As, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) applied to a town, or country, (As, S,) an abode, (A, Mgh, Msb,) and a tribe. (A.) And so ↓ $uTurN in the phrase nawFY $uTurN [A distant tract, or region, towards which one journeys]: (S, K:) so too ↓ $aTuwrN in the phrase niy~apN $aTuwrN [which may mean as above, (like niy~apN $aTuwnN,) or a remote, or farreaching, intention, or aim, or purpose]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A stranger; (S, O, Msb, K;) because of his remoteness from his people; (TA;) as in a verse cited voce A_i*FA: (S, O:) or one who is alone, or solitary: (A:) pl. $uTurN. (TA.)

$aATirN * [One who withdraws far away from his family; or breaks off from them, or quits them, in anger: (see 1, last sentence:) or] one who disagrees with his family, (Msb,) and who wearies them by his wickedness (S, Msb, K) and baseness (Msb) and guile: (TA:) i. q. xaliyEN [meaning as above, and having other similar meanings; generally vitious, or immoral; bad, evil, wicked, or mischievous]: (A:) accord. to some, it is post-classical: Aboo-Is-hák says that it signifies one who takes a wrong course: it is also expl. as signifying one who outstrips; like the [messenger called] bariyd, who takes a long journey in a short space of time: and hence, [as a conventional term of the mystics,] it is applied to one who outstrips, and is quick, in attaining nearness to God: or as meaning one who has wearied his family, and withdrawn far from them [n spirit], though with them [bodily], because of their inviting him to carnal lusts, and accustomed ways [of the world]: (TA:) [in the present day, it is applied to a sharper, or clever thief: and to any clever, or cunning, person:] pl. $uT~aArN. (TA.)

ma$oTuwrN * [Halved. ― -b2- And hence,] A verse of the metre termed Alr~ajaz, (O, K,) and of that termed Als~ariyE, (TA,) having three of its six feet wanting; (O, K;) properly, having half thereof taken away. (O.) -A2- Also Bread done over with [the seasoning, or condiment, called] kaAmax. (O, K.)

humo mu$aATiruwnaA *
They are persons whose houses adjoin ours. (O, K.).

$iToranojN * (O, L, Msb, K) and $aToranojN; (L, Msb;) some say the former; and some, the latter; (Msb;) the latter said to be of established authority, as a dial. var., though disallowed in the K [and in the O]; but the former is the more approved on account of its being conformable with Arabic words, (Msb, TA,) such as jirodaHolN, (TA,) which the latter is not; (Msb, TA;) and sometimes it is pronounced with the unpointed s, (O,) this being a dial. var.; (K;) A wellknown game; [namely, chess:] (O, L, K:) a Pers. word, (TA,) arabicized; (Msb, K, TA;) [said to be] from Sado ranoG “ a hundred stratagems; ” or from $udo ranoj “ trouble departed, ” meaning that trouble departs from him who plays at it; (TA;) [or from $aAho ranoj “ the royal care or sorrow; ” or from $a$o ranoG “ six species or ranks, ” because the pieces are of so many species: (Richardson's Pers. Arab. and Engl. Dict., Johnson's ed.:)] or [accord. to some] it is from Al$~aTaArapu, (O, K,) or Almu$aATarapu, referring to the word $Trnj; (TA;) or from Alt~asoTiyru, (O, K,) referring to the word sTrnj; so says Ibn-Hishám El-Lakhmee: but, as IB and others have said, these derivations are only partial, making the n and the j to be augmentative letters, and are manifestly incorrect. (MF, TA.)

1 $aTana * , (S, TA,) [aor.
$aTuna ,] inf. n. $uTuwnN, (PS,) He was, or became, distant, or remote, (S, TA,) Eanohu [from him, or it]. (S.) And $aTanati Ald~aAru, (Msb, TA,) aor. as above, (Msb,) and so the inf. n., The abode, or dwelling, was distant, or remote. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, remote, or far, from the truth, and from the mercy of God. (Msb.) ― -b3- And $aTana fiY AlA^aroDi, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) It entered into the earth, either raAsixFA [app. as meaning becoming firmly fixed therein], or waAgilFA [app. as meaning penetrating, and becoming concealed]. (K.) -A2- $aTanahu, (S, K,) aor.
$aTuna , inf. n. $aTonN, (S,) He turned away in opposition to him (namely, his companion, K) from his design, or aim, or his direction that he was pursuing, and his way, or
course; expl. by the words xaAlafahu Eano niy~atihi wawajohihi. (ISk, S, K.) -A3- And $aTanahu, (S, K,) aor.
$aTuna , (S,) inf. n. $aTonN, (TA,) He bound him with the $aTan [or rope, or long rope, &c.]. (S, K.)

4 A$Tnhu *
He made him, or caused him, to be, or become, distant, or remote. (S, K.)

Q. Q. 1 $ayoTana *
He acted as a $ayoTaAn [i. e., as implied in the context, a devil; or one excessively, or inordinately, proud or corrupt or unbelieving or rebellious, or one insolent and audacious in pride and in acts of rebellion]; (K;) and ↓ ta$ayoTana; (S, K;) both signify the same; (K, TA;) he became, and acted, like the $ayoTaAn. (TA.)
Q. Q. 2 ta$ayoTana * : see what next precedes.

$aTanN *
A rope, (S, Msb, K,) in a general sense: (K:) or a long rope: (Kh, S, K:) or a long and strongly-twisted rope by means of which one draws water: (TA:) pl. A^a$oTaAnN. (S, Msb, K.) Mention is made, in a trad., of a horse as being marobuwTN bi$aTanayoni [i. e. Tied with two ropes, or long ropes, &c.,] because of his strength. (TA.) And one says of a strong-spirited horse, A_in~ahu layanozuw bayona $aTanayoni [Verily he leaps between two ropes, or long ropes, &c.]: a saying applied as a prov. to him who exults, or exults greatly, or excessively, and behaves insolently and ungratefully, and is strong. (TA.) An Arab of the desert described a horse (S, Msb) that did not become abraded in the sole of his hoof (so in a copy of the S) by saying, kaA^an~ahu $ayoTaAnN fiY A^a$oTaAnK [As though he were a devil in ropes, or long ropes, &c.]. (S, Msb.)

nawFY $aTuwnN * (S) or niy~apN $aTuwnN (K) [A place to which one purposes journeying] that is distant, or remote. (S, K.) And gazowapN $aTuwnN [A warring and plundering expedition] that is distant. (K.) And HarobN $aTuwnN [Distant war: or] (assumed tropical:) war that is difficult [because distant]. (TA. See an ex. in a verse cited voce jub~apN.) [See also $aTiynN, and $aATinN.] ― -b2- biy^orN $aTuwnN (tropical:) A deep well, (S, K, TA,) curving in its interior: (TA:) or a well from which the bucket is drawn out by means of two ropes, from its two sides, wide in the upper part and narrow in the lower part; (K, TA;) so that if one draws out the bucket from it by means of one rope, one draws it against the casing, and it becomes rent. (TA.) And rumoHN $aTuwnN (assumed tropical:) A long and crooked spear. (TA.)

$aTiynN *
Distant, or remote. (TA. [See also $aTuwnN, and $aATinN.])

$aATinN * [Distant, or remote, in respect of the place of alighting or abode]; i. q. $aATibN [q. v.]. (TA in art. $Tb. [See also $aTuwnN, and $aTiynN.]) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Far from the truth [and from the mercy of God: see 1]. (TA.) ― -b3- And i. q. xabiyvN (assumed tropical:) [Bad, corrupt, &c.; like saATinN]. (K.) Umeiyeh (S, TA) Ibn-Abi-s-Salt, referring to Solomon, (TA,) says,
A^ay~umaA $aATinK EaSaAhu EakaAhu
vum~a yuloqaY fiY Als~ijoni waAlA^agolaAli
[Whatever bad one disobeyed him, he bound him in irons; then he was cast into the prison and the shackles for the neck and hands]. (S, TA.)

$ayoTaAnN * a word of well-known meaning [i. e. A devil; and with the article Al, the devil, Satan]: (S, K:) any that is excessively, or inordinately, proud or corrupt or unbelieving or rebellious, or that is insolent and audacious in pride and in acts of rebellion, of mankind, and of the jinn, or genii, and of beasts; (A'Obeyd, S, Msb, K;) as is shown in relation to the first and second of these by what is said in the Kur vi. 112, and ii. 13 and 96: (TA:) the n is radical, (S, Msb, TA,) the word being of the measure fayoEaAlN, from $aTana, (Msb, TA,) signifying “ he was, or became, distant, or remote, ” (TA,) or signifying “ he was, or became, remote, or far, from the truth, and from the mercy of God; ” (Msb;) as is indicated by the pl. $ayaATiynu; [for] the reading of El-Hasan in the Kur xxvi. 210, Al$~ayaATuwna, is anomalous, [like basaAtuwna for basaAtiynu,] and is said by Th to be a mistake: (TA:) or, as some say, the n is augmentative, (S, Msb, TA, *) and the Y is radical, so that the word is of the measure faEolaAn, (Msb,) from $aATa, aor. ya$iyTu, (Msb, TA,) signifying “ it was, or became, null, void, of no account, ” and the like, and “ it burned, ” or “ became burnt, ” (Msb,) or signifying “ he burned with anger: ” but the former opinion is the more common: (TA:) [in the Kur, the word is always perfectly decl.; and so it is said to be by SM, in art. $yT of the TA; unless used as a proper name: but J says,] if you make it to be of the measure fayoEaAl from ta$ayoTana said of a man, [or rather because they say of a man t$yTn,] you make it perfectly decl.; but if you make it to be from $ay~aTa [“ he burned ” a thing], you make it imperfectly decl., because it is of the measure faEolaAn. (S.) ― -b2- Also The serpent: (S, K:) or a certain species of serpents; (Fr, S, TA;) having a mane, of foul aspect: or, as some say, a slender, light, or active, serpent. (TA.) ― -b3- Respecting the saying in the Kur [xxxvii. 63], TaloEuhaA kaA^an~ahu ruw^uwsu Al$~ayaATiyni [Its fruit is as though it were the heads of the $yATyn], Fr says that there are three ways in which it may be explained: one is, that the TlE is likened to the heads of the $yATyn [meaning devils] in respect of foulness, or ugliness, because these are described as foul, or ugly: (S:) or it is likened to the evil in disposition of the jinn, because these are imagined as foul, or ugly: Zj says, in explaining it, that one says of a thing deemed foul, or ugly, kaA^an~ahu wajohu $ayoTaAnK [as though it were the face of a devil], and kaA^an~ahu raA^osu $ayoTaAnK [as though it were the head of a devil]; for though the $yTAn is not seen, he is conceived in the mind as the foulest, or ugliest, of things: (TA:) the second is, that [the meaning is foul, or ugly, serpents; for] the Arabs apply the name $yTAn to a sort of serpents, having a mane, foul, or ugly, in the head and face: (S, TA: *) the third is, that a certain foul, or ugly, plat is named ruw^uwsu Al$~ayaATiyni; (S, TA;) which is expl. in the K only as meaning a certain plant. (TA.) ― -b4- $ayoTaAnu AlfalaA [lit. The devil of the waterless deserts] means (assumed tropical:) thirst. (K.) ― -b5- $ayoTaAnN signifies also (assumed tropical:) Any blamable faculty, or power, [or propensity,] of a man. (Er-Rághib, TA.) One says, rakibahu $ayoTaAnuhu i. e. (assumed tropical:) [His anger got the ascendency over him; or] he was, or became, angry. (TA.) And nazaEa $ayoTaAnahu (assumed tropical:) He plucked out his pride. (TA.) ― -b6- Also, [probably as being likened to a serpent,] (assumed tropical:) A mark made with a hot iron in the upper part of the haunch of a camel, perpendicularly, upon the thigh, extending to the hock; (K, TA;) from the “ Tedhkireh ” of Aboo-'Alee; (TA;) likewise called ↓ mu$ayoTanapN. (AZ, K, TA.)

Al$~ayoTaAniy~apu *
A certain sect of the extravagant zealots of [the schismatics called] the $iyEap; so named from [their founder] $ayoTaAnu AlT~aAqi, (TA,) an appellation of Mohammad Ibn-En-Noaman. (K and TA in art. Twq.)

mu$aATinN *
One who draws out the bucket from the well bi$aTanayoni, (K, TA,) i. e. with two ropes. (TA.)
mu$ayoTanapN * : see $ayoTaAnN, last sentence.

1 $aZ~a AljuwaAliqa * , (S,) or AlwiEaA='a, (K,) aor.
$aZu3a , inf. n. $aZ~N, (TA,) He fastened its $iZaAZ [q. v.] upon the sack: (S:) or he put the $iZaAZ into the bag; [meaning into its loop, or handle;] as also ↓ A$Z~hu: (K:) or the latter signifies he put to it, or made for it, (namely the sack,) a $iZaAZ. (S.)
4 A^a$oZa3a see the preceding paragraph.

$iZaAZN * The stick, or piece of wood, which is inserted into the loop, or handle, of a sack; (S;) a curved piece of wood, (K, TA,) with a pointed extremity, (TA,) which is put into the two loops, or handles, of a pair of sacks, (K, TA,) when they are bound upon the camel: (TA:) there are two such pieces of wood: (S, * TA:) pl. A^a$iZ~apN. (K.) And A piece of wood, or peg, with which they make fast the rope of a burden. (Ibn-Maaroof, as cited by Golius.)
$aZiyZN * A sack made fast, or bound. (Fr. K.) -A2- A stick, or piece of wood, split in several places. (Fr, K.)

1 $aZufa Al$~ajaru * , (S, O, K,) aor.
$aZufa ; (K;) and $aZifa, (O, K,) aor.
$aZafa ; (K;) inf. n. $aZaAfapN, (O, K,) of the former verb; (O;) The trees, not being sufficiently watered, became hard, without losing their moisture. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- And $aZifato yaduhu His hand became rough, or coarse. (Har p. 70.) ― -b3- And $aZifa AlEayo$u The means of subsistence became dry and hard. (K, * TA.) -A2- $aZifN Als~ahomu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
$aZafa , (K,) The arrow entered between the skin and the flesh. (S, Msb, K, Omitted in the TA.) -A3- $aZafotuhu Eani Al$~aYo'u,
(O, TA,) inf. n. $aZofN, (O, K,) I withheld, restrained, or debarred, him from the thing. (O, K, * TA.) ― -b2- And $aZofN signifies also The drawing forth the testicles of a ram: (O, K:) or the compressing them between two pieces of wood, or stick, and binding them with sinew (biEaqabK, in the CK [erroneously] bEaqibK,) so that they wither. (K.)

5 t$Z~f *
He subjected himself to a hard, or difficult, life. (L in art. mEd.)

$aZofN *
A splinter, or piece split off, of a staff, or stick. (IAar, O, K.)

$iZofN *
Dry bread. (O, K.) ― -b2- And A small piece of wood, or stick, like a peg: pl. $iZafapN. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

$aZafN * and ↓ $aZaAfN Straitness; and hardness, or difficulty, or distress; (AZ, S, O, K;) like DafafN: (AZ, S, O:) ISd thinks that the second is a dial. var. of the first; and IB mentions that, in a verse of El-Kumeyt, as related by some, it is with kesr, i.e. $iZaAf [which see in what here follows]: (TA:) and (K) as some say, (TA,) dryness, and hardness, of the means of subsistence: (K:) or $aZafN signifies hardness, and straitness, of the means of subsistence: (Msb:) or hardness, and coarseness, or roughness, thereof; from $aZifato yaduhu [expl. above]: (Har p. 70:) pl. $iZaAfN. (K.) ― -b2- Also A disintegration of the flesh, separating it from the border around the nail. (TA.)

$aZifN *
Dry and hard means of subsistence. (K, * TA. [See 1.]) ― -b2- Evil in disposition. (O, K.) ― -b3- Vehement in fight. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b4- A man alighting, or taking up an abode, in places where the herbage is dried up, and in a desert where is no water (falaAp). (TA in art. EZb.) ― -b5- baEiyrN $aZifu AlxilaATi [A stallion-camel] vehement in leaping, or compressing, the she-camels. (S, O, K.) ― -b6- A^aroDN $aZifapN Rough, or rugged, land or ground. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

$iZofapN *
Bread that has become burned. (IAar, O.)
$ZaAfN * : see $aZafN.

$ZaAfN *
Distance, or remoteness. (O, K.)

$ajarN $aZiyfN *
Trees that, not being sufficiently watered, have become hard, without losing their moisture. (S, O, K.)

mi$oZafN *
One who utters oblique, indirect, or ambiguous, speech or language, deviating from the right way or course. (O, K. Omitted in the TA.)

1 $aZiYa * , [aor. and inf. n. as in the next sentence,] said of a stick, or branch, or piece of wood, [&c.,] It was, or became, split. (AHn, TA.) ― -b2- Said of a horse, (As, S, Mgh, K,) aor.
$aZaYa , inf. n. $aZFY, (K,) His $ZY, (As, S, Mgh, K,) i. e. the small bone called Al$~aZaY, (As, S, Mgh, *) moved from its place, (As, S, Mgh,) or became displaced, syn. zuwiYa, (A, TA,) or became unsteady, or wabbling: (K:) and so ↓ t$Z~Y, (K, TA,) this latter on the authority of ISd: (TA:) or [the inf. n.] $aZFY, accord. to some, signifies the sinews' becoming split, or slit: (As, S, Mgh:) or $aZFY has this meaning also; (K;) and so ↓ ta$aZ~. (ISd, K, TA.) -A2- Accord. to the K, $aZiYa, said of a corpse, is syn. with $aSiYa: but correctly, the former verb is $aZaY, aor.
$aZiYa , inf. n. $uZiY~N, and the latter verb is $aSaA [q. v.], as they are said to be by Az: and in like manner, $aZiY, aor.
$aZiYa , is said of a siqaA=' [or skin for water or milk], meaning It being filled, its legs became raised, or raised high. (TA.)

2 $Z~Y * , (TA,) inf. n. ta$oZiyapN, (K, TA,) He separated into several, or many, portions or divisions; or dispersed, or scattered; (K, * TA;) [a thing; or] (tropical:) a company of men. (TA.) ― -b2- And He made [a horse] to be such that his $ZY ($aZaAhu) became unsteady, or wabbling. (TA.)

4 A$ZAhu *
He, or it, hit, or hurt, his $ZY ($aZaAhu): (K:) Sgh says, by rule it should be $aZaAhu [i. e. the verb should be thus, being derived from Al$~aZaY, like qafaAhu from AlqafaA]. (TA.)

5 t$Z~Y * , said of a stick, or branch, or piece of wood, (A, Msb, K, TA,) or of a thing, (S, TA,) It split, or became split, in pieces, or in several or many places: (A, Msb, TA:) or it became scattered, or dispersed, in splinters, or pieces split off: (S, K:) and it [i. e. anything, nothing in particular being specified,] became separated into several, or many, portions or divisions; or dispersed, or scattered. (TA.) One says also, t$Z~Y All~uw^oluw^u Eani AlS~adafi (tropical:) [The pearls became separated, or scattered, from the oyster-shells]. (A, TA.) See also 1, in two places.

7 An$ZY *
It broke, or became broken. (TA.) One says, An$Zt Alr~abaAEiyapu The [tooth called the] rbAEyp broke, or became broken. (TA.)

$aZFY * , of a staff, or stick, The like of a liyTap [i. e. a piece, or sharp piece, of the exterior portion], that enters into the hand, and wounds it. (Ham p. 474. [But $aZiy~apN is more commonly used in this and similar senses.]) ― -b2- A small bone, (EuZayomN, K, TA, [in the CK EaZomN, i. e. a bone, and so in my copy of the Mgh,]) or a slender small bone, (As, S,) adhering to the *iraAE [here app. meaning the arm-bone of a horse], (As, S, K,) or to the bone of the *iraAE, (Mgh,) which sometimes moves from its place; (As, S, Mgh; [see $aZiy~apN;]) or to the knee; (K;) thus in the M; (TA;) or to the waZiyf [app. here meaning the fore shank of a horse]; (K;) thus in the A: (TA:) or certain small sinews (EaSab) therein; (K;) i. e. in the wZyf; thus in the T. (TA.) AO says that taHar~uku Al$~aZaY [i. e. The motion of the $ZY from its place (see 1)] is like what is termed Ainoti$aAru AlEaSabi, except that the horse has more power of endurance of the latter than of the former. (T, TA.) ― -b3- And Portions of a thing that are separated, or dispersed, or scattered. (Har p. 160.) It is said by ISd to be a pl. [or rather it is a coll. gen. n.] of which the sing. [or n. un.] is $aZaApN. (TA.) ― -b4- Also A portion of fur upon the mark left by a gall, or sore, on the back [of a camel], such as reaches the utmost extent thereof: (K, accord. to the TA: [Al$~aZaY being there expl. by the words Alwbrp ElY Avr Aldbrp HtY tblg AqSAhA: in the CK, and in my MS. copy of the K, Ald~abarapu ElY A^avari Ald~abarapi fY AlmazoraEapi Hat~aY taboluga A^aqoSaAhaA; which Freytag renders “ sulcus ad latus alterius in arvo ductus, ut ejus extremum attingeret; ” but which, I think, evidently presents a mistranscription and an interpolation:]) the pl. is A^a$oZiyapN: and sometimes there are ten [?] portions of fur [of this description, app. meaning, upon one camel: the word that I here render “ ten ” is more like E$h than E$r; but the final letter, as is often the case in the MS. of the TA, is written in a form differing little from a common form of r]: mentioned by ISh, from Et-Táïfee; as is said in the T. (TA.) ― -b5- Also (assumed tropical:) The followers, and incorporated confederates, of a people, or party; (S, K;) contr. of the Samiym thereof: (S:) or the freedmen and followers. (M, TA.)
$aZiY~N * and $iZiY~N: see the next paragraph.

$iZiy~apN *
A splinter, or piece split off, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) of a staff, or stick, and the like, (S,) or of wood, (T, Mgh, Msb,) and the like, (Msb,) or of a reed, or cane, (T, Mgh,) or of silver, (T, TA,) or of bone, (T, Mgh,) or of anything: (M, K:) pl. $aZaAyaA (S, Msb, K, &c.) and ↓ $aZiY~N, (K,) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] like as rakiY~N is of rakiy~apN, (TA,) or a quasi-pl. n., like EabiydN, improperly said by IAar to be pl. of $aZFY, (ISd, TA,) and ↓ $iZiY~N, (K, TA, [in the latter as omitted in the K, with kesr to the $ on account of the same vowel-sound following,]) mentioned by Sgh, from Ks. (TA.) AO terms the A_iborap [q. v.] at the head of the elbow [of the horse] a $aZiy~ap adhering to the *iraAE, but not [forming a portion] of it. (TA. [See $aZFY.]) ― -b2- Also A bow: (K:) because its wood is split: on the authority of AHn. (TA.) ― -b3- And The shankbone. (K.) ― -b4- And A great mass of rock wrenched from the side of a mountain; (K, TA;) as though it were a piece split off, broken [off] but not parted so as to form an interstice, or a gap: and also a piece cut from a mountain, like a house or a tent: and it is said in the copies of the K that $iZoyapN, with kesr, signifies the same; but the word is correctly ↓ $inoZiyapN, with an augmentative n as in the T, and mentioned also by Hr in the “ Ghareebeyn: ” pl. of the former $aZaAyaA. (TA.) ― -b5- See also $anoZaApN.
$aAZK * part. n. of $aZiYa [q. v.] said of a horse. (TA.)

$anoZaApN * The head, or top, of a mountain, (K, TA,) [and so ↓ $aZiy~apN, (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees,)] resembling the $urofap [q. v.]
of a mosque: pl. $anaAZK: and AljibaAli ↓ $awaAZiY [likewise] signifies the heads, or tops, of the mountains. (TA.)
$inoZiyapN * : see $aZiy~apN, near the end.
$awaAZiY AljibaAli * : see $anoZaApN.

[
ma$oZFY * , pl. ma$aAZiY, A fragment of wood: (Freytag, from the Deewán of Jereer:) but the pl., when indeterminate, is correctly ma$aAZK.]

1 $aE~a * , (O, K, TA,) aor.
$aEi3a , (O, TA,) inf. n. $aEaAEN (S, * O, * K, * TA) and $aE~N, (TA,) It became scattered, or dispersed; (S, O, K, TA;) said of a thing; like $aAEa, aor. ya$iyEu; (TA;) of the urine of a camel; (O, K;) and of a people, or party; (IAar, O, K;) [like $ag~a;] and [in like manner] $aEaAEN is used in relation to blood, &c., as meaning the being scattered. (S, O, K, TA. [See also $aEaAEN, below; and $uEaAEN.]) -A2- $aE~a bawolahu, (S, O, K,) aor.
$aEu3a , (S, O,) inf. n. $aE~N (O, TA) and $aEaAEN, (K, * TA,) He (a camel) scattered his urine; as also ↓ A$E~hu: (S, O, K:) or both signify he scattered his urine, and stopped it. (TA.) ― -b2- And $aE~a AlgaArapa, (K, TA,) inf. n. $aE~N; and ↓ $aEo$aEahaA; (TA;) He poured upon them the horsemen making a sudden attack and engaging in conflict, or urging on their horses; (K, TA;) and in like manner, Alxayola. (TA.)

4 A^a$oEa3a see 1. ― -b2- A$E~t Al$~amosu The sun spread, or diffused, its $uEaAE [or beams], (S, K,) or its light. (TA.) ― -b3- A$E~ Alz~aroEu The corn put forth its $aEaAE, (S, K, TA,) i. e., its awn. (TA.) ― -b4- And A$E~ Als~unobulu The ears of corn became compact in their grain, (K, TA,) and dry therein. (TA.)

7 An$E~ Al*~iy^obu fiY Alganami *
The wolf made an incursion among the sheep or goats. (O, K, TA.)

R. Q. 1 $aEo$aEahu * , (S, O, K,) inf. n. $aEo$aEapN, (TA,) He mixed it, namely, wine, (S, O, K,) with water. (O.) And He mixed one part of it, namely, a thing, with another part, (O, * K,) like as one mixes wine with water. (O.) And $aEo$aEa Alv~ariydapa He mixed the vrydp [or mess of crumbled bread] with olive-oil: (O:) or he put much clarified butter to it, (ISh, O, K,) and much grease, or gravy: (K:) or he raised its head; (O, K;) as some say: (Sh, O:) or he made its head high; (O, K;) as some say; from $aEo$aAEN as an epithet applied to a man, meaning “ tall. ” (O.) But the verb is used more in relation to wine than to vryd. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1.

R. Q. 2 ta$aEo$aEa * , said of a man, is from ↓ $aEo$aAEN applied to a man as meaning HulowN xafiyfN [i. e. “ such as is excited to briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, and esteemed pleasing in the eye, and is light, or active; ” so that the verb may be rendered He was, or became, such as is excited to briskness, &c.: or he was, or became, such as is termed $aEo$aAEN, q. v.]. (Ham, p. 246.) ― -b2- Said of the month It nearly came to an end; little remained of it: (K, TA:) occurring in a trad.: but accord. to one relation thereof, it is ta$aEosaEa; from Al$~usuwEu “ the being distant, or remote: ” and accord. to another, ta$aEosaEa, with two ss. (TA.)

$aE~N * : see $aEaAEN, first and last sentences. -A2- Also Haste: (IAar, K, TA:) and so $aEiyEN accord. to the K; but this is wrong; the meaning of the latter word being only that given below, voce $aEaAEN. (TA.)

$uE~N *
A spider's web. (AA, K.) ― -b2- See also $uEaAEN.

$aEaAEN * [an inf. n. (see 1) used as an epithet, and therefore as masc. and fem. and sing. and pl.;] Scattered, or dispersed; and disordered, or unsettled; syn. mutafar~iqN; (S, K;) as also ↓ $aE~N, [likewise an inf. n. used as an epithet,] applied [like the former] to anything, (K, TA,) such as blood, and an opinion, and a purpose, or an intention; (TA;) and ↓ $aEiyEN, which is wrongly expl. in the K as syn. with $aE~N in another sense, as stated above; (TA;) and ↓ $aEo$aAEN. (S, K.) One says, *ahaba damuhu $aEaAEFA His blood went scattered, or dispersed: (TA:) or $aEaAEN applied to blood signifies spirtling from a wound made with a spear or the like; as in a verse cited voce nafa*N. (Az, TA. [See also $uEaAEN.]) And *ahabuwA $aEaAEFA They went away scattered, or dispersed. (K.) And A^um~apN $aEaAEN A nation, or people, scattered, or dispersed. (TA, from a trad.) And taTaAyarati AlEaSaA $aEaAEFA The staff, or stick, broke into scattered pieces; as when one has broken it by striking with it upon a wall: and in like manner, AlqaSabapu the reed, or cane. (TA.) And raA^oYN $aEaAEN A disordered, or an unsettled, opinion. (S, K.) And nafosN $aEaAEN A mind of which the purposes, or intentions, (himamuhaA, as in the S [and O], for which, in the K, humuwmuhaA is erroneously substituted, TA,) and the opinions, (Z, TA,) are disordered, or unsettled, (S, K, TA,) so that it is not directed to a decided affair. (Z, TA.) And TaAra fuw^aAduhu $aEaAEFA [His mind fled in a disordered, or an unsettled, state, as though dissipated; expl. as] meaning tafar~aqato humuwmuhu [a mistranscription, as before: correctly tfr~qt himamuhu i. e. his purposes, or intentions, became disordered, or unsettled: see also Ham p. 44, and Har p. 366]. (K.) And a rájiz says,
Algadaro ↓ Sadoqu All~iqaA='i gayoru $aEo$aAEi
meaning [Firm, or steady, in encounter, or conflict,] not disordered, or unsettled, in respect of purpose, or intention. (S.) ― -b2- Hence, app., (TA,) Milk mixed with much water; (ISh, O;) syn. DayaAHN. (ISh, O, K, TA.) -A2- Also [as a subst.] The awn, or beard, of the ears of corn; (S, O, K;) and so ↓ $uEaAEN and ↓ $iEaAEN (K) and ↓ $aE~N: (TA:) or the awn, or beard, when it has become dry, as long as it remains on the ears; as also ↓ $uEaAEN. (Lth, O.)
