$aEaAEN * (S, O, K) and ↓ $uE~N (AA, K) [The rays, or beams, of the sun; or] what one sees, (S, O, K,) of the light, like rods, (S,) or extending like spears, (O, K,) at the rising, or the beginning of the rising, (S,) or a little after the rising, (O, K,) of the sun; (S, O, K;) or what one sees, like cords coming towards him, when looking at the sun; or the dispersing light of the sun: (K:) n. un. with p: (S, O, K) [and Freytag states that ↓ $iEo$iEapN is said by Jac. Schultens to signify rays: but this I do not find in any lexicon:] the pl. (of $uEaAEN, O) is A^a$iE~apN, (O, K,) accord. to analogy, (O,) [a pl. of pauc.,] and $uEuEN (O, K) and ↓ $iEaAEN; (K;) the last anomalous. (TA.) Hence, in a trad. respecting [the night called] layolapu Alqadori, it is said, A_in~a Al$~amosa taToluEu mino gadi yawomihaA laA $uEaAEa lahaA [Verily the sun will rise on its morrow having no rays]. (S: in the O, mino gadihaA.) ― -b2- In the verse cited voce nafa*N, As is related to have read Al$~uEaAEu instead of Al$~aEaAEu, as meaning The light, [or brightness] and redness, and scattered state, of the blood: ISd says, I know not whether he said it meaning by original application or by way of comparison. (TA.) ― -b3- See also $aEaAEN, last sentence, in two places.
$iEaAEN * : see $aEaAEN, last sentence: ― -b2- and see also $uEaAEN.
$aEiyEN * : see $aEaAEN, first sentence.

$aEo$aEN * , (S, O,) or ↓ $aEo$aAEN, (K,) or both, (TA,) and ↓ mu$aEo$aEN, (S, TA,) Shade that is not thick, or dense; (S, O, K, TA;) or which has not wholly shaded one, having in it interspaces. (TA.) ― -b2- See also $aEo$aAEN, in two places.
$uEo$uEN * : see the next paragraph but one, in two places: and see $ulo$ulN.
$iEo$iEapN * : see $uEaAEN.

$aEo$aAEN * : see $aEaAEN, in two places: and $aEo$aEN. ― -b2- Also, (S, O, S,) and ↓ $aEo$aEN (O, K) and ↓ $aEo$aEaAnN (IDrd, S, O, K) and ↓ $aEo$aEaAniY~N, (O, K,) in which last the relative Y is without cause, as in A^aHomariY~N and daw~aAriY~N, (TA,) applied to a man, (S,) Tall: (O, K:) or tall and goodly (S, TA) and light of flesh; applied to a man as being likened to the thin [or much diluted] wine termed mu$aEo$aEap: or the first signifies long-necked; and so ↓ the third, and ↓ the fourth; applied to anything, or the last, accord. to the R, applied to a man only: and the first, long applied to a neck: (TA:) and light, or active: (O, K:) or so in journeying; as also ↓ $uEo$uEN like hudohudN, applied to a man, or, accord. to Th, to a boy, or young man: or light in spirit: (TA:) see also R. Q. 2: and (K) as some say, (O,) the first signifies goodly, or beautiful, (O, K, TA,) in face: (TA:) and ↓ $aEo$aEN, (so in the O,) or ↓ $uEo$uEN, with damm to the $, (TA,) a boy, or young man,
goodly, or beautiful, in face, light in spirit; (O, TA;) on the authority of AA. (TA.) -A2- Also Certain trees; or a kind of tree. (TA.)

$aEo$aEaAnN * : see $aEo$aAEN, in two places. With p, applied to a she-camel, meaning Tall: (S, * O:) or large in body: (TA:) pl. $aEo$aEaAnaAtN. (S, O. [In the TA, $aEo$aEaAnaAtN is said to be mistranscribed in the S $aEo$aEaAnaAn: but it is not so in either of my copies.])
$aEo$aEaAniY~N * : see $aEo$aAEN, in two places. Also Long and thin; applied to a camel's lip. (TA.)
mu$aEo$aEN * : see $aEo$aEN. ― -b2- With p, applied to wine (xamorN), Mixed with water: (O, * EM p. 183:) accord. to some, [much diluted; i. e.] mixed so as to be thin. (TA.)

1 $aEaba * , (S, Msb,) aor.
$aEaba , (Msb,) inf. n. $aEobN, (A, Msb, K,) He collected; brought, gathered, or drew, together; or united; (S, A, Msb, K;) a thing, (S,) any thing or things, and a people or party: (Msb:) and he separated; put apart, or asunder; divided; disunited; or dispersed or scattered; (S, A, Msb, K;) a thing, (S,) any thing or things, and a people or party: (Msb:) thus having two contr. significations: (S:) so expressly state A'Obeyd and Aboo-Ziyád: (TA:) but accord. to IDrd, it has not two contr. significations [in one and the same dial.]: he says that the two meanings are peculiar to the dials. of two peoples, (Msb, TA, *) each meaning belonging to the dial. of one people exclusively. (TA.) [Hence, as it seems to be indicated in the S and A, or from $aEobN meaning “ a tribe, ” as it seems to be indicated in the Ham p. 538,] one says, tafar~aqa $aEobuhumo, (S,) or $at~a $aEobuhumo, (A, Ham,) (tropical:) [Their union became dissolved, or broken up; or their tribe became separated;] meaning they became separated after being congregated: (S, Ham:) and AilotaA^ama $aEobuhumo (S, A, Ham) (tropical:) [Their separation became closed up, or their tribe drew together;] meaning they drew together after being separated. (S, Ham.) And $aEabatohumu Almaniy~apu Death separated them: (S:) and $aEabatohu $aEuwbu [Death separated him from his companions]; (TA;) said of a man when he has died. (O in art. Ebl: in the K, in that art., ↓ Ai$otaEabatohu [perhaps a mistranscription].) And it is said in a trad., maA h`*ihi AlfutoyaA A@l~atiY $aEabota bihaA Aln~aAsa i. e, [What is this judicial decision] with which thou hast divided the people? (S. [In the TA, on the authority of IAth, AltY $agabato fiY Aln~aAsi, which means, “ which has excited evil among the people. ”]) One says also, $aEaba Alr~ajulu A^amorahu (assumed tropical:) The man broke up, discomposed, deranged, or disorganized, [or rendered unsound, impaired, or marred, (agreeably with another explanation of the verb in what follows,)] his state of affairs: (As, A'Obeyd, TA:) whence the saying of 'Alee Ibn-El-'Adheer El-Ghanawee,
waA_i*aA raA^ayota Almaro'a ya$oEabu A^amorahu
$aEoba AlEaSaA wayalaj~u fiY AlEiSoyaAni
(assumed tropical:) [And when thou seest the man break up his state of affairs as with the breaking up of the staff, and persevere in disobedience, or rebellion]. (A'Obeyd, TA.) ― -b2- Also, aor, as above, (Msb,) and so the inf. n., (S, A, Msb, K,) He repaired a cracked thing [such as a wooden bowl or some other vessel, by closing up its crack or cracks, or by piecing it: see 2, which has a similar signification, but implying muchness]: (S, Msb:) and [in a general sense,] he repaired, mended, amended, adjusted, or put into a right, or proper, state: (A, K, TA:) and it signifies the contr. also [of the former meaning and] of this, in the same, or in another, dial.: (TA:) [i. e.] he cracked a thing [such as a wooden bowl &c.]: (A, Msb:) and he corrupted, rendered unsound, impaired, or marred. (A, K, TA.) $aEobN SagiyrN mino $aEobK kabiyrK, occurring in a trad. of 'Omar, means A little repairing, of, or amid, much impairing. (TA.) ― -b3- [He gave a portion of property; as though he broke it off.] One says, Ai$oEabo liY $uEobapF mina AlmaAli Give thou to me a portion of the property. (TA.) ― -b4- He (the commander, or prince, S) sent a messenger (S, K) A_ilayohi [to him], (K,) or A_ilaY mawoDiEi ka*aA [to such a place]. (S.) ― -b5- He turned, or sent, him, or it, away, or back: (K, TA:) aor. and inf.n. as above. (TA.) And $aEaba All~ijaAmu Alfarasa The bridle turned away or back, or withheld, or restrained, the horse from the direction towards which he was going. (K.) ― -b6- He, or it, diverted a man by occupying him, busying him, or engaging his attention. (K, TA.) One says, maA $aEabaka Ean~iY [What diverted thee, or what has diverted thee, &c., from me?]. (TA.) -A2- It is also intrans.: see 4. ― -b2- [Thus it signifies He quitted his companions, desiring others.] One says, $aEaba A_ilayohimo (K, TA) fiY Eadadi ka*aA (TA) He yearned towards them [with such a number of men], and quitted his companions. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And He, or it, appeared [distinct from others]: (K, TA:) whence the month [$aEobaAn, q. v.,] is [said to be] named. (TA.) -A3- Also, (K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) said of a camel, He cropped (AihotaDama) the upper, or uppermost, parts of trees [or shrubs]. (K, TA.) -A4- $aEiba, aor.
$aEaba , (K,) inf. n. $aEabN, (S, * K, * TA,) He (a goat, S, TA, and a gazelle, TA) was wide, (K,) or very wide, (S,) between the horns, (S, K,) and between the shoulders. (K, * TA.) [See also $aEabN, below.]

2 $E~b * [app. signifies He collected several things; or he collected much: and] he separated several things; or he separated much. (O.) ― -b2- Also He repaired a cracked wooden bowl [or some other vessel] in several places [by closing up its cracks, or by piecing it]: (S, O:) [and app., in a general sense, he repaired, mended, amended, adjusted, or put into a right, or proper, state, several things; or he repaired, &c., much: and it seems to signify also the contr. of these two meanings: i. e. he cracked several things; or he cracked in several places: and he corrupted, rendered unsound, impaired, or marred, several things; or he corrupted, &c., much.] -A2- It is also intrans.: see 4. ― -b2- Thus, said of seed-produce, It branched forth, or forked, after being in leaf, or blade; (TA;) like ↓ t$E~b. (K, * TA.) [Hence,] one says, A_in~iY A^araY Al$~ar~a $aE~aba (assumed tropical:) [Verily I see the evil to have grown like seed-produce when it branches forth]; like as one says, qaS~aba, and nab~aba. (TA in art. nb.)

3 $AEbhu *
He became distant, or remote, from him; (K, TA;) namely, his companion. (TA.) [Hence,] $AEb AlHayaApa (assumed tropical:) [He quitted life]. (TA.) And $aAEabato nafosuhu (K, TA) His soul [departed, or] quitted life; (TA;) meaning he died; (K, TA;) as also ↓ An$Eb [i. e. An$Eb huwa]. (K.) [See also what next follows.]

4 A$Eb *
He died: (S, K: [see also 3:]) or (so in the S and TA, but in the K “ and ”) he separated himself from another or others, never to return; (S, K;) as also ↓ $E~b or ↓ $aEaba, accord. to different copies of the K, the latter as in the L. (TA.) A poet says, (S,) namely, En-Nábighah El-Jaadee, (IB, TA.)
wakaAnuwA A^unaAsFA mino $uEuwbK faA^a$oEabuwA
(S, IB, TA,) or wakaAnuwA $uEuwbFA mino A^unaAsK, accord. to different readings: [app. meaning, And they were men of divided races or tribes, or were divided races or tribes of men; so they perished; or separated, never to return:] IB says, after mentioning the former reading, i. e. they were of men who should perish; so they perished: having previously mentioned the latter reading, and added, i. e. they were of those whom $Ewb should overtake. (TA. [IB's explanations seem at first sight to indicate that he read $aEuwba and $aEuwbFA; neither of which is admissible: each of his explanations app. relates to both readings; as though he understood the poet to mean, they were men separated from different tribes, to be overtaken by others; so they perished.])

5 t$E~b * and ↓ An$Eb are quasi-pass. verbs, the former of $aE~aba and the latter of $aEaba: (TA:) [the former, therefore, is most correctly to be regarded and used as intensive in its significations, or as relating to several things or persons: but it is said that] both signify alike: [app. It became collected; it became brought, gathered, or drawn, together; or it became united: and also] it became separated, put apart or asunder, divided, disunited, or dispersed or scattered: (S, K:) and it, or he, became distant, or remote. (K.) One says, ta$aE~abuwA fiY Talabi AlmiyaAhi [They became separated, &c., or they separated themselves, &c., in search of the waters], and fiY AlgaAraAti [in predatory excursions]. (TA.) And Ean~iY ↓ An$Eb fulaAnN Such a one became distant, or remote, from me; or withdrew to a distance, or for away, from me. (TA.) And AlT~ariyqu ↓ An$Eb [and t$E~b] The road separated. (S, A, Msb.) And ↓ An$Eb Aln~ahoru and t$E~b The river separated [or branched forth] into other rivers. (TA.) And ↓ An$Ebt A^agoSaAnu Al$~ajarapi (S, Msb, TA) and t$E~bt (TA) The branches of the tree separated, divided,
straggled, or spread out dispersedly; (S, TA;) or branched forth from the stem, and separated, divided, &c. (Msb.) See also 2. One says also, t$E~b A^amoru Alr~ajuli (assumed tropical:) [The state of affairs of the man became broken up, discomposed, deranged, disorganized, or (agreeably with another explanation of the verb in what follows) rendered unsound, impaired, or marred]. (A.) ― -b2- Also ↓ the latter verb, [or each,] It became closed up; [or repaired by having a crack or cracks closed up, or by being pieced;] said of a cracked thing: (TA:) and ↓ both verbs, i. q. AinoSalaHa [which means, in a general sense, it became rectified, repaired, mended, amended, adjusted, or put into a right, or proper, state; &c.; but I have not found this verb (AnSlH) in its proper art. in any of the Lexicons]: (K, TA:) and ↓ the latter signifies also it became cracked; (A;) [and in like manner the former, said of a number of things; or it became cracked in several places when said of a single thing: and hence ↓ both signify, in a general sense, it became corrupted, rendered unsound, impaired, or marred; a meaning which may justly be assigned to the former verb in the phrase mentioned in the next preceding sentence.]
7 A_ino$aEaba see 5, in nine places: and see also 3.
8 A_i$otaEaba see 1, in the former half of the paragraph.

$aEobN * inf. n. of $aEaba [q. v.]. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Used as a simple subst., it signifies Collection, or union: and also separation, division, or disunion; and] a state of separation or division or disunion; (K, TA;) as also ↓ $uEobapN: (S, TA:) pl. of the former $uEuwbN. (TA.) ― -b3- And [hence, perhaps, as implying both union and division,] Such as is divided [into sub-tribes], of the tribes of the Arabs and foreigners: (S: [in my copy of the Msb, mA Anqsmt fyh qbAy^l AlErb, as though it meant the tribes of the Arabs collectively, agreeably with another explanation to be mentioned below; but I think that there may be a mistranscription in this case:]) pl. $uEuwbN: (S, Msb:) or it signifies, as some say, (Msb,) or signifies also, (S,) a great tribe; syn. qabiylapN EaZiymapN, (S, A, K,) or HaY~N EaZiymN; (Msb;) the parent of the [tribes called] qabaAy^il, to which they refer their origin, and which comprises them: (S:) or, as some say, a great tribe (HaY~N EaZiymN) forming a branch of a qabiylap: or a qabiylap itself: (TA:) A' Obeyd says, on the authority of Ibn-El-Kelbee, on the authority of his father, that the $aEob is greater than the qabiylap; next to which is the faSiylap; then, the EamaArap; then, the baTon; then, the faxi*: (S, TA:) but IB says that the true order is that which Ez-Zubeyr Ibn-Bekkár has stated, and is as follows: (TA:) [i. e.] the genealogies of the Arabs consist of six degrees; (Msb;) first, the $aEob; then, the qabiylap; then, the EamaArap, (Msb, TA,) with fet-h and with kesr, to the E; (Msb;) then, the baTon; then, the faxi*; and then, the faSylap: thus, Khuzeymeh is a $Eb; and Kináneh, a qbylap; and Kureysh, an EmArp; and Kuseí, a bTn; and Háshim, a fx*; and El-'Abbás, a fSylp: (Msb, TA:) and Aboo-Usámeh says that these classes are agreeable with the order obtaining in the structure of man; the $Eb is the greatest of them, derived from the $aEob [or suture] of the head; next is the qbylp, from the qbylp [which is a term applied to any one of the four principal bones] of the head; then, the EmArp, which is the breast; then, the bTn [or belly]; then, the fx* [or thigh]; and then, the fSylp, which is the shank: to these some add the Ea$ityrap, which consists of few in comparison with what are before mentioned: (TA:) and some add after this the rahoT: some also add the ji*om before the $Eb: (TA in art. bTn:) the pl. is as above. (TA.) It signifies also A nation, people, race, or family of mankind; syn. jiylN; as expl. by IM and others: in the K, [and in a copy of the A,] erroneously, jabal [a mountain]: (TA:) but it is [strangely] said by Aboo-'Obeyd El-Bekree that accord. to all except Bundár, the word in this sense is ↓ $iEobN, with kesr. (MF.) And the pl., $uEuwbN, is [said to be] especially applied to denote the foreigners (AlEajam): (TA:) [thus it is said that] the phrase, in a trad., A_in~a rajulFA mina Al$~uEuwbi A^asolama means [Verily a man] of the foreigners (AlEajam) [became a Muslim: but see Al$~uEuwbiy~apu]. (S.) ― -b4- Also, [as implying separation,] Distance, or remoteness. (A, K.) So in the phrase $aEobu Ald~aAri [The distance, or remoteness, of the abode, or dwelling]. (TA.) ― -b5- And A crack (S, A, K, TA) in a thing, (S,) which the $aE~aAb repairs. (S, * TA.) ― -b6- And The place of junction [i. e. the suture] of the qabaAy^il [or principal bones] of the head; (K;) the $aA^on which conjoins the qbAy^l of the head: the qbAy^l in the head being [the frontal bone, the occipital bone, and the two parietal bones; in all,] four in number. (S.) ― -b7- [Hence, perhaps,] humaA $aEobaAni (assumed tropical:) They two are likes [or like each other]. (S.) ― -b8- See also $iEobN. -A2- Also Distant, or remote; (K;) as in the phrase maA='N $aEobN [Distant, or remote, water]: pl. $uEuwbN. (TA.)
$uEobN * : see the dual $uEobaAni voce $uEobapN.

$iEobN *
A road: (Msb:) or a road in a mountain: (S, A, O, L, Msb, K:) primarily a road in a mountain (Har p. 29) and in valleys: (Id. p. 72:) afterwards applied to any road: (Id. p. 29:) [see also ma$oEabN:] pl. $iEaAbN. (S, O, Msb.) And A water-course, or place in which water flows, in [a low, or depressed, tract, such as is called] a baTon of land, (ISh, A, O, K,) having two elevated borders, and in width equal to the stature of a man lying down, and sometimes between the two faces, or acclivities, of two mountains. (ISh, O.) Or it signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (A,) A ravine, or gap, [or pass,] between two mountains. (A, K.) ― -b2- Also [A reef of rocks in the sea: so in the present day: or] a zirobap or zarabap (accord. to different copies of the K in art. jhn [but neither of these two words do I find in their proper art. in any Lex.]) in the sea, such as is connected with the shore: if not connected with the shore, a bowshot distant, it is called juhonN. (K and TA in art. jhn.) ― -b3- And A brand, or mark made with a hot iron, (S, K,) upon camels, (K,) peculiar to the Benoo-Minkar, in form resembling the [hooked stick called] miHojan: (S:) or a brand upon the thigh, lengthwise, [consisting of] two lines meeting at the top and separated at the bottom: (ISh, TA:) or a brand united [at the upper part and] at the lower part separated: (Aboo-' Alee in the “ Tedhkireh, ” TA: [but there is an omission here, so that the reverse may perhaps be meant:]) or a brand upon the neck, like the miHojan: (Suh in the R, TA:) in a marginal note in the copy of the L, it is said that $Eb signifying a brand is with kesr to the $ and with fet-h [i. e. $iEobN and ↓ $aEobN]. (TA.) ― -b4- See also $aEobN. ― -b5- [And see the pl. $iEaAbN below.]

$aEabN *
Width, or distance, (A, K,) or great width or distance, (S,) between the horns (S, A, K) of a goat (S, TA) and of a gazelle, (TA,) and between the shoulders, (A, K,) and between two branches. (A.) [See also 1, last signification.]

$uEobapN * : see $aEobN, second sentence. ― -b2- Also The space, or interstice, between two horns: and between two branches: (K:) pl. $uEabN and $iEaAbN, (K, * TA,) in this and all the following senses. (TA.) ― -b3- And A cleft in a mountain, to which birds (AlT~ayoru, for which AlmaTaru is erroneously substituted in [several of] the copies of the K, TA) resort: pl. as above. (K, TA.) ― -b4- Also A branch of a tree, (S, A, * Mgh, * Msb, TA,) growing out a part, or divaricating, therefrom: (Msb, * TA:) or the extremity of a branch: (K, TA: [said in the latter to be tropical in this latter sense; but why, I see not:]) pl. $uEabN (S, Mgh, Msb, TA) and $iEaAbN, as above. (TA.) And $uEabu AlguSoni The divaricating, or straggling, [branchlets, or] extremities [or shoots or stalks] of the branch. (TA.) And [hence] EaSFA fiY raA^osihaA $uEobataAni [A staff having at his head two forking portions or projections]; (A, TA;) and Az mentions, as heard by him from the Arabs, ↓ $uEobaAni, without t, instead of $uEobataAni in this phrase. (L, TA.) And $uEobapN mino rayoHaAnK [A sprig, spray, bunch, or branchlet, of sweet basil, or of sweet-smelling plants]: and $uEobapN mino $aEarK [and mino SuwfK A lock, or flock, of hair and of wool]. (JK in art. Twq.) And A^anaA $uEobapN mino dawoHatika (tropical:) [I am a branch, or branchlet, of thy great tree]. (A, TA.) And masoA^alapN kaviyrapu Al$~uEabi (assumed tropical:) [A question having many branches, or ramifications]. (Msb.) And [the pl.] $uEabN [as meaning] (tropical:) The fingers: (K, TA:) one says, qabaDa Ealayohi bi$uEabi yadihi (tropical:) He laid hold upon it with his fingers. (A, TA.) And qaEada bayona $uEobatayohaA (tropical:) He sat between her two legs: (A:) and bayona $uEabihaA AlA^arobaEi (tropical:) [He sat (in the Mgh qaEada, as implied in the A, and in the Msb jalasa,)] between her arms and her legs; (A, Mgh, Msb, K;) or between her legs and the $uforaAni [dual of $uforN, q. v.,] of her faroj; (A, Mgh, K;) occurring in a trad.; (Mgh, Msb;) an allusion to jimaAE. (A, Mgh, Msb, K.) And $uEobataA Alr~aHoli (assumed tropical:) The $aroxaAni [or two upright pieces of wood] of the
camel's saddle; its qaAdimap and its A=xirah. (Mgh.) And Aigorizi All~aHoma fiY $uEabi Als~af~uwdi (tropical:) [Infix thou the flesh-meat upon the prongs of the roastinginstrument]. (A, TA.) And $uEobapu minojalK (assumed tropical:) [A tooth of a reaping-hook]. (K in art. sn.) And $uEobapN mino $uEabi Als~iyni (assumed tropical:) [A tooth, or cusp, of the teeth, or cusps, of the s]; the $uEab of the s being three. (S and L in art. s.) And $uEabu Alfarasi (tropical:) The outer parts, or regions, of the horse (A^aqoTaAruhu, A, or nawaAHiyhi, K); all of them: (K:) or the prominent parts (S, K) of them, (K,) or of him; (S, and so in some copies of the K;) as the neck, and the minosaj [or withers, &c.], (S, TA,) and the crests of the hips, (TA,) or such as his head, and his HaArik [or withers, &c.], and the crests of his hips. (A.) ― -b5- Also A small water-course, or channel in which water flows; as in the phrase $uEobapN HaAfilN a small water-course filled with a torrent: (S:) or a water-course in sand; (K;) or in the elevated part of a depressed tract into which sand has poured and remained. (TA.) And A small portion of a [water-course such as is called] taloEap; or what is smaller than a taloEap; accord. to different copies of the K; Al$~uEobapu being expl. as meaning maA Sagura mina Alt~aloEapi, and, in one copy, Eani Alt~aloEapi. (TA.) And Such as is large, of the channels for irrigation of valleys: (K, TA:) or, as some say, a branch from a taloEap, and from a valley, or torrent-bed, taking a different course therefrom: pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b6- And A portion, part, or piece, of a thing; or somewhat thereof: (S, Msb, K, TA:) pl. as above. (TA.) One says, Ai$oEabo liY $uEobapF mina AlmaAli Give thou to me a portion of the property. (TA.) And fiY yadihi $uEobapu xayorK (assumed tropical:) [In his hand is somewhat of good, or of wealth]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., AlHayaA='u $uEobapN mina AlA_iymaAni (assumed tropical:) Modesty is a part of faith: and in another, Al$~abaAbu $uEobapN mina Aljunuwni (assumed tropical:) [Youth is a part of insanity]. (TA.) In explanation of the phrase, in the Kur [lxxvii. 30], A_ilaY Zil~K *iY valaAvi $uEabK [Unto a shade, or shadow, having three parts, or divisions], it is said that the fire [of Hell], on the day of resurrection, will divide into three parts; and whenever they shall attempt to go forth to a place, it will repel them: by Zil~ being here meant that the fire will form a covering; for [literally] there will be no Zil~ in this case. (Th, L.) ― -b7- And A piece such as is called ruw^bap, with which a wooden bowl [or the like] is repaired. (S.) ― -b8- Accord. to Lth, (T, TA,) $uEabu Ald~ahori means (tropical:) The changes, or vicissitudes, of time or fortune; (T, A, TA;) and he cites the saying of Dhu-r-Rummeh,
walaA tuqas~imu $aEobFA waAHidFA $uEabu
which he explains by saying, i. e. I thought that one thing, or state of things, would not be divided into many things, or states: [i. e. Nor did I think that the vicissitudes of fortune would divide one whole body of men into many parties:] but Az disapproves of this explanation, and says that $uEab here means Intentions, designs, or purposes: he says that the poet describes tribes assembled together in the [season called] rabiyE, who, when they desired to return to the watering-places, differed in their intentions, or designs; wherefore he says, Nor did I think that various intentions would divide [one whole body of men who before had] a consentient intention. (L, TA.) ― -b9- [See also the pl. $iEaAbN below.]

$aEobaAnu * , imperfectly decl., (Msb,) The name of a month [i. e. the eighth month of the Arabian year]: pl. $aEobaAnaAtN (S, Msb, K) and $aEaAbiynu: (Msb, K:) so called from ta$aE~aba “ it became separated; ” (K, TA;) because therein they used to separate, or disperse themselves, in search of water [when the months were regulated by the solar year; this month then corresponding partly to June and partly to July, as shown voce zamanN, q. v.]; or, as some say, for predatory expeditions [after having been restrained therefrom during the sacred month of Rejeb]; or, accord. to some, as Th says, from $aEaba “ it appeared; ” because of its appearance between the months of Rejeb and Ramadán. (TA.) ― -b2- gazaAlu $aEobaAna A certain insect, (K, * TA,) a species of the junodab, or of the juxodub. (TA.)

$iEaAbN * pl. of $iEobN: (S, O, Msb:) and of $uEobapN. (K, TA.) ― -b2- $agalato $iEaAbiY jadowaAYa is a prov., [expl. as] meaning The abundance of the food [that I have to procure for my family] has occupied me so as to divert me from giving to people: (S, TA:) [Z considers $EAb, here, as pl. of $uEobapN “ a branch, ” and as meaning duties, and relations: (Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 653:)] but El-Mundhiree says that $iEaAbiY is a mistranscription: the other reading is saEaAtiY, meaning “ my expending upon my family. ” (Meyd. [See also saEaApN, in art. sEw and sEY.])

$aEuwbu * , (S, A, Msb, K,) without the article Al, and imperfectly decl., (Msb,) and Al$~aEuwbu, (A, Msb, K,) with the article, and perfectly decl., (Msb,) but several authors disallow this latter, accounting it wrong; (TA;) a name for Death; (S, A, * Msb, K; *) so called because it separates men: (S, Msb:) the former is a proper name: (Msb:) J says [in the S] that it is determinate, and does not admit the article Al: in the L, it is said that $aEuwbu and Al$~aEuwbu both signify as above; and that in either case it may be originally an epithet, being like the epithets qatuwl and Daruwb; and if so, the article in this case is as in AlEab~aAsu and AlHasanu and AlH`rivu: and this opinion is confirmed by what is said of its derivation: but he who says $aEuwb, without the article, makes the word a pure substantive, and deprives it literally of the character of an epithet; wherefore the article is not necessarily attached to it, as it is not to Eab~aAs and H`riv; yet the essence of an epithet is in it still, as in the instance of jaAbiru bonu Hab~apa, a name for “ bread, ” so called because it reinvigorates the hungry; and as in waAsiT, [a certain town] so called, accord. to Sb, because midway between El-'Irák [' Irák el-'Ajam] and El-Basrah: thus in the L. (TA.) One says of a person when he has been at the point of death and then escaped, A^aqaS~atohu $aEuwbu [Death became near to him]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., famaA zilotu waADiEFA rijoliY EalaY xad~ihi Hat~aY A^azarotuhu $aEuwba, i. e. [And I ceased not putting my foot upon his cheek until] I made death to visit him. (TA.)

$aEiybN *
A [leathern water-bag such as is called] mazaAdap [q. v.]; (A'Obeyd, S, K;) as also raAwiyapN and saTiyHapN: (A'Obeyd, S:) or one that has been repaired, or pieced: (TA:) or one that is made of two hides: (K:) or one that is made of two hides facing each other, without fiy^aAm at their corners; fy^Am in [the making of] mazaAyid being the taking of the hide and folding it, and then adding at the sides what will widen it: or one that is pieced (tufoA^amu) with a third skin, between the two skins, that it may be rendered wider: or one that is made of two pieces joined together: (TA:) or one that is sewed (maxoruwzap, K and TA, in the CK maHozuwzap,) on both sides: (K:) called thus because one part is joined to another: (L, TA:) pl. $uEubN. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- Also An old, worn-out skin for water or milk: (K:) because it is pieced, or repaired: (TA:) pl. as above. (K.) ― -b3- And A camel's saddle; syn. raHolN: because it is joined, part to part: so in the saying of El-Marrár, describing a she-camel,
A_i*aA hiYa xar~ato xar~a mino Eano yamiynihaA
$aEiybN bihi A_iHomaAmuhaA waluguwbuhaA
[When she falls down, or fell down, there falls down, or fell down, from her right side a saddle by reason of which was her fevered and jaded state]. (TA.) ― -b4- And rajulN $aEiybN i. q. gariybN [A man who is a stranger, &c.]. (AA, TA voce gariybN.)
$iEaAbapN * The art, or craft, of repairing cracks [in wooden bowls &c., by piecing them]. (TA.)
$uEuwbiY~N * : see what next follows.

Al$~uEuwbiy~apu *
A sect which does not prefer, or exalt, the Arabs above the 'Ajam [or foreigners or Persians]: (S:) or a sect which prefers, or exalts, the 'Ajam above the Arabs: (Msb:) or those who despise the circumstances, or condition, of the Arabs; (A, * K;) one of whom is called ↓ $uEuwbiY~N; (A, K;) a rel. n. formed from the pl., (IM, Msb, TA,) $uEuwbN being predominantly applied to the 'Ajam; (IM, TA;) like A^anoSaAriY~N [from AlA^anoSaAru]. (IM, Msb, * TA.) In the phrase A_in~a rajulFA mina Al$~uEuwbi A^asolama, occurring in a trad., [and mentioned before, voce $aEobN,] Al$Ewb may mean AlEajam; or it may be [used as] a pl. of Al$~uEuwbiY~u, like as Alyahuwdu and Almajuwsu are [used as] pls. of AlyahuwdiY~u and AlmajuwsiY~u. (IAth, TA.)

$aE~aAbN *
A repairer of cracks [in wooden bowls &c., by piecing them]. (S, Msb, TA.)

Al$~aAEibaAni *
The two shoulders: (K:) because wide apart: of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)

A^a$oEabu * A goat, (S, TA,) and a gazelle, (A, TA,) wide, (A,) or very wide, (S, TA,) between the horns: (S, A, TA:) [and app., between the shoulders: (see $aEiba:)] fem. $aEobaA='u: (TA:) and pl. $uEobN. (S, A, TA.) -A2- It is also the name of a certain very covetous man [who became proverbial for his covetousness, and hence it is used as an epithet]: (S, K:) so in the saying, laA takuno A^a$oEaba fatatoEaba [Be not thou an Ash'ab, for in that case thou wilt become fatigued, or wearied, by thy endeavours]; (K;) a prov.: (TA:) and so in the prov., A^aTomaEu mino A^a$oEaba [More covetous than Ash'ab]. (S.)

ma$oEabN *
A way, road, or path, (S, Msb, K,) [in an absolute sense, or] branching off from another. (Msb.) ma$oEabu AlHaq~i means The way [of truth, or] that distinguishes between truth and falsity. (K.)

mi$oEabN *
An instrument by means of which a crack in a [wooden bowl or some other] thing is repaired [by piecing it]; an instrument used for perforating, a drill, or the like, (K, TA,) by means of which the $aE~aAb repairs a vessel. (TA.)
qaSoEapN mu$aE~abapN * [A wooden bowl] repaired in several places [by closing up its cracks, or by piecing it]. (S.) ― -b2- See also what follows.
ma$oEuwbN * applied to a camel, (K,) and ↓ mu$aE~abapN applied to a number of camels, (TA,) Marked with the brand called $iEob. (K, TA.)
Q. 1 $aEoba*a * , and its inf. n. $aEoba*apN: see $aEowa*a and $aEowa*apN in art. $E*.
mu$aEobi*N * : see mu$aEowi*N in art. $E*.

1 $aEiva * , aor.
$aEava , (Msb,) inf. n. $aEavN, (A, Mgh, Msb,) It (hair) was, or became, shaggy, or dishevelled, (A, Mgh,) and frouzy, or altered in odour, (Mgh,) in consequence of its being seldom dressed: (A, Mgh:) or it was, or became, defiled with dust, and matted, or compacted, in consequence of its being seldom anointed: (Msb:) or, accord. to El-Ghooree, it wanted oil, or ointment: (Har p. 50:) and ↓ t$E~t signifies [the same: or] it was, or became, matted, or compacted, (K, TA,) and dusty. (TA.) And the former verb, [and app. ↓ the latter also,] It (the head) was, or became, dusty, not being renovated [by dressing or anointing], nor cleansed. (Msb.) Also the former verb, aor. as above, (L, K, and Ham p. 469,) inf. n. $aEavN (S, L, K, and Ham) and $uEuwvapN, (L and Ham,) He was, or became, shaggy, or dishevelled, in the hair, (JM, PS,) and frouzy, or altered in odour, in consequence of its being seldom dressed: (JM:) or it signifies (or signifies also, JM) he had a dusty head, (S, L, K, JM,) and plucked hair, unanointed; (L;) or he had matted, or compacted, and dusty, hair: (L, and Ham p. 469:) and in like manner ↓ t$E~v. (L.) ― -b2- $aEavN, (Msb,) or ↓ ta$aE~uvN, (S, K, TA,) [or each,] also signifies (tropical:) The being separated, or disunited, (S, Msb, K, TA,) and spread out, (Msb,) and uncompacted, (TA,) like as is the head of the siwaAk [or tooth-stick, by its being bruised, or battered, or mangled by blows]. (Msb, TA.) You say, raA^osu Als~iwaAki ↓ t$E~v, (Msb, TA,) and Alwatidi, (A, TA,) (tropical:) The head of the tooth-stick, and of the wooden peg or stake, became disintegrated; or separated, disunited, or uncompacted, in its component parts [or its fibres; or rendered brushy; by its being bruised, or battered, or mangled by blows]. (TA.) And ↓ t$E~vwA (tropical:) They [meaning men] became separated, disunited, dispersed, or scattered. (A.) ― -b3- And $aEiva, aor. as above, (TK,) inf. n. $aEavN, said of the state of affairs, (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, dissolved, broken up, discomposed, deranged, disorganized, disordered, or unsettled. (S, * A, * K, * TA, TK. [In the S and A and K, this is placed as the first of all the meanings in this art.; and in the A, it is mentioned among the meanings that are proper, not tropical; but in my opinion it is tropical. See also $aEavN below.])

2 $aE~vhu * , inf. n. ta$oEiyvN, He rendered it (i. e. hair) [shaggy, or dishevelled, and frouzy: (see 1:) or] matte, or compacted, and dusty: or he rendered him [shaggy, or dishevelled, and frouzy, in his hair: or] matted, or compacted, and dusty, in his hair. (TA.) ― -b2- ta$oEiyvN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The separating, disuniting, dispersing, or scattering, a thing. (S.) And (assumed tropical:) The making to separated like as do rivers and branches. (L.) [Hence,] $E~v raA^osa Als~iwaAki (tropical:) [He made the head of the tooth-stick to become disintegrated; or separated, disunited, or uncompacted, in its component parts or its fibres; or rendered it brushy; by bruising it, battering it, or mangling it by blows: see 1]. (A.) ― -b3- $E~v Als~anaA (tropical:) He took of the straggling branches, or sprigs, of the senna, without pulling it up by the roots. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b4- See also 5, in two places. ― -b5- $E~v Aln~aAsu fiY AlT~aEoni Ealayohi (assumed tropical:) The people took, or began, to impugn his character, censure him, reproach him, or speak against him, by befouling his reputation (bita$oEiyvi EiroDihi). (TA, from a trad.) ― -b6- And $E~v minohu (assumed tropical:) He detracted from his reputation; syn. gaD~a minohu and tanaq~aSahu: from Al$~aEavu [as inf. n. of 1 in the last of the senses assigned to it above,] meaning Ainoti$aAru AlA^amori. (L.) ― -b7- And also, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) He repelled from him, or defended him: (K:) or he defended his reputation. (TA.) [Thus it has two contr. meanings.]

4 A$Ev min~iY fulaAnN * (tropical:) Such a one was angry by reason of me; syn. gaDiba. (A. [But this I have not found elsewhere; and I almost think that A$Ev, in my copy of the A, may be a mistranscription for $E~v; and gaDiba, for gaD~a.])

5 ta$aE~ava see 1, in six places. -A2- ta$aE~uvN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The act of taking; syn. A^axo*N; (K, TA;) and so ↓ ta$oEiyvN. (TA.) One says, t$E~vhu Ald~ahoru (assumed tropical:) Time, or fortune, took him. (TA.) And t$E~v maAlahu He took his property. (TK.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) The eating little of food; (K, TA;) and so ↓ ta$oiEyvN: whence one says, $aE~avotu mina AlT~aEaAmi I ate little of the food. (TA.)
$aEovN * : see the next paragraph.

$aEavN * inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (L, Msb, &c.) ― -b2- [Hence,] lam~a A@ll~`hu $aEavaka, (S,) and $aEavakumo, (A,) i. e. (tropical:) [May God rectify, or repair, and consolidate, what is discomposed, deranged, disorganized, disordered, or unsettled, of thy, and your, affairs; (see art. lm;) or] consolidate thy, and your, disorganized, disordered, or unsettled, state of affairs: (S, A: * [in the latter expressly distinguished as tropical:]) [and so ↓ $aEovaka, and $aEovakumo; perhaps by poetic license; for] Kaab Ibn-Málik El-Ansáree says,
lam~a A@loA_il`hu bihK $aEovFA waram~a bihi
A^umuwra A^um~atihi waAlA^amoru munota$iru
(assumed tropical:) [God rectified and consolidated, by him, a discomposed, deranged, disorganized, disordered, or unsettled, state of affairs, and repaired, by him, the affairs of his people, when the state of affairs was broken up]. (TA.) It is said in a trad., as a form of prayer, A^asoA^aluka raHomapF talum~u bihaA $aEaviY i. e. (tropical:) [I ask of Thee mercy] whereby thou shalt consolidate what is discomposed, deranged, disorganized, disordered, or unsettled, of my state of affairs. (TA.)

$aEivN * , applied to hair, Shaggy, or dishevelled: (MA:) [or shaggy, or dishevelled, and frouzy, or altered in odour, in consequence of its being seldom dressed: (see 1, first sentence:)] or defiled with dust, and matted, or compacted, in consequence of its being seldom anointed. (Msb.) And in a similar sense applied to the head of a misowaAk [or tooth-stick, meaning (assumed tropical:) Disintegrated; or separated, disunited, or uncompacted, in its fibres; or rendered brushy; by its being bruised, &c.; and so as applied to the head of a wooden peg or stake; as indicated by an explanation of its verb]. (MA.) [And in the TA it is applied to a plant, as meaning (assumed tropical:) Straggling.] See also A^a$oEavu. ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A man dirty in the body. (Msb.)

$aEavapN *
A place of [or in] the hair that is $aEiv [or shaggy, or dishevelled, &c.]. (TA.)
$aEovaAnu * , and $aEovaAnu Alr~aA^osi: see what next follows.

A^a$oEavu * , (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and A^a$oEavu Alr~aA^osi, (K,) and ↓ $aEivN, (Mgh, TA,) [and $aEivu Alr~aA^osi,] and ↓ $aEovaAnu, (TA,) and $aEovaAnu Alr~aA^osi, (K,) applied to a man, (A, Mgh, Msb,) Having the hair shaggy, or dishevelled, and frouzy, or altered in odour, in consequence of its being seldom dressed: (Mgh:) or having the hair defiled with dust, and matted, or compacted, in consequence of its being seldom anointed: (Msb:) or having the head dusty, (S, A, K, TA,) and the hair plucked, and unanointed: (TA:) fem. of the first $aEovaA='u, applied to a woman: (A, Msb:) and $uEovN [is its pl., and] is applied to horses, as meaning [having shaggy coats,] not curried: (S:) or dusty by
reason of long journeying. (Ham p. 130, [See and ex. from a poet, voce A=yapN.]) The first [or each] is also applied to a head, as meaning Dusty, not renovated [by dressing or anointing], nor cleansed. (Msb.) ― -b2- AlA^a$oEavu (tropical:) The wooden peg or stake: (A, K, TA:) so in a verse of El-Kumeyt cited in the first paragraph of art. Hf: an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant: (TA:) so called because its head is disintegrated; or separated, disunited, or uncompacted, in its component parts [or its fibres; by its being battered by blows]. (A, * TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) What has dried up of the [barley-grass called] buhomaY: (K, TA:) [or] it is so called when its prickles have dried. (TA.)

Q. Q. 1 $aEowa*a * , (A, Msb,) inf. n. $aEowa*apN, (A, L, Msb, K,) He practised the art termed $aEowa*ap, expl. below: (A, L, Msb, K:) as also $aEoba*a, (Msb, K,) inf. n. $aEoba*apN: (A, Msb, K:) so some say. (Msb.) [See what here follows.]

$aEowa*apN *
Legerdemain, or sleight-of-hand, (A, L, K,) and false miracles, (TA,) and fascinations, (K,) or fascination, (A, L,) or a kind of play, (Msb,) like siHor, (A, L, Msb, K,) making a thing to appear different from what it really is, (L, K,) or showing a man what has no real existence: (Msb:) or making what is false to assume the form of what is true: (TA:) as also $aEoba*apN: (A, Msb:) vulgarly termed $aEobavapN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Quickness: or lightness, or agility, in any affair. (L.) ― -b3- It is not a word of the language of the people of the desert. (Lth, L, Msb.)

$aEowa*iY~N *
A messenger of princes or governors, (L, K,) who journeys on affairs of importance for them (L) upon post-horses or other beasts appointed for their conveyance: (L, K:) so called because of his quickness. (L.) It is not a word of the language of the people of the desert. (Lth, L.) ― -b2- See also what follows.

mu$aEowi*N * and mu$aEowa*N A man who practises the art termed $aEowa*ap; (L, K;) as also ↓ $aEowa*iY~N: (TA in art. Ejb:) improperly called mu$aEobi*N, and surnamed A^abuw AlEajabi. (Eth-Tha'álibee, TA.)

1 $aEara bihi * , (S, Msb, K, &c.,) and $aEura bihi, (K,) which latter is disallowed by some, but both are correct, though the former is the [more] chaste, (TA,) aor.
$aEura , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. $iEorN (S, Msb, K, &c.) and $aEorN (K, TA) and $aEarN, (TA, and so in the CK in the place of $aEorN,) but the first is the most common, (TA,) and $iEorapN (Msb, K) and $aEorapN and $uEorapN, (K,) of which last three the first is the most common, (TA,) and $iEoraY and $uEoraY (K) and $aEoraY (TA) and $uEuwrN (Msb, K) and $uEuwrapN, (K,) which is said to be the inf. n. of $aEura, (TA,) and ma$oEuwrN and ma$oEuwrapN (Lh, K) and ma$oEuwraA='u, (K,) which is of extr. form, (TA,) He knew it; knew, or had knowledge, of it; was cognizant of it; or understood it; (S, * A, Msb, K, TA;) as also $aEara lahu: (Lh, TA:) or he knew the minute particulars of it: or he perceived it by means of [any of] the senses. (TA.) Lh mentions the phrase A^a$oEuru fulaAnFA maA Eamilahu and A^a$oEuru lifulaAnK maA Eamilahu [I know what such a one did or has done], and maA $aEarotu fulaAnFA maA Eamilahu [I knew not what such a one did], as on the authority of Ks, and says that they are forms of speech used by the Arabs. (TA.) [See also $iEorN, below.] ― -b2- $aEara, (A, Msb, K,) aor.
$aEura , (Msb, K,) inf. n. $iEorN and $aEorN, (K, TA,) or $aEarN, (so accord. to the CK instead of $aEorN,) He said, or spoke, or gave utterance to, poetry; spoke in verse; poetized; or versified; syn. qaAla $iEorFA; [for poetry was always spoken by the Arabs in the classical times; and seldom written, if written at all, until after the life-time of the author;] (A, Msb, K;) as also $aEura: (K:) or the latter signifies he made good, or excellent, poetry or verses; (K, MF;) and this is the signification more commonly approved, as being more agreeable with analogy: (MF:) or the latter signifies he was, or became, a poet; (S;) as also $aEira, aor.
$aEara . (TA.) One says, $aEarotu lifulaAnK I said, or spoke, poetry, &c., to such a one. (TS, O, TA.) And lawo $aEura binaqoSihi lamaA $aEara [Had he known his deficiency, he had not spoken poetry, or versified]. (A.) -A2- $aAEarahu fa$aEarahu: see 3. -A3- $aEara as a trans. verb syn. with A$Er: see 4. ― -b2- As syn. with $AEr: see 3. -A4- $aEira, aor.
$aEara , (K,) inf. n. $aEarN, (TA,) His (a man's, TA) hair became abundant (K, TA) and long: (TA:) and said likewise of a goat, or other hairy animal, his hair became abundant. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) He possessed slaves. (Lh, K.)
2 $E~r * as an intrans. verb: see 4: ― -b2- and as a trans. verb also: see 4.

3 $aAoEara ↓ $aAEarahu fa$aEarahu, (S, K,) aor. of the latter
$aEara , that is with fet-h, (S, MF,) accord. to Ks, who holds it to be thus even in this case, where superiority is signified, on account of the faucial letter; or, accord. to most,
$aEura , agreeably with the general rule; (MF;) He vied, or contended, with him in poetry, and he surpassed him therein. (S, K, MF.) -A2- And $AErhu, (S,) and $AErhA, (A, Msb, K,) and ↓ $aEarahaA, (A, K,) He slept with him, and with her, (naAwamahu, S, and naAma maEahaA, Msb, K, or DaAjaEahaA, A,) in one $iEaAr [or innermost garment]. (S, A, Msb, K.) -A3- [Reiske, as mentioned by Freytag, explains $AEr as signifying also Tractavit, prensavit, vellicavit: but without naming any authority.]

4 A$Erhu *
He made him to know. (S.) You say, A$Erhu biAlA^amori and AlA^amora, (K,) the latter of which is less usual than the former, because one says $aEara bihi but not $aEarahu, (MF,) He aquainted him with the affair; made him to know it. (K.) And A^a$oEarotu A^amora falaAnK I made known the affair of such a one. (A.) And A^a$oEarotu fulaAnFA I made such a one notorious for an evil deed or quality. (A.) ― -b2- Also, (inf. n. A_i$oEaArN, Msb,) He marked it, namely a beast destined for sacrifice at Mekkeh, (S, * Mgh, Msb, * K, TA,) by stabbing it in the right side of its hump so that blood flowed from it, (S,) or by making a slit in its skin, (K,) or by stabbing it (K, TA) in one side of its hump with a miboDaE or the like, (TA,) so that the blood appeared, (K, TA,) or by making an incision in its hump so that the blood flowed, (Msb,) in order that it might be known to be destined for sacrifice. (S, Msb.) ― -b3- [Hence, app.,] (assumed tropical:) He wounded him so as to cause blood to come. (TA.) It is said in a trad. respecting the assassination of 'Othmán, A^a$oEarahu mi$oqaSFA (assumed tropical:) He wounded him so as to cause blood to come with a m$qS [q. v.]: (TA:) and in another trad., A^a$oEira A^amiyru Almuw^ominiyna (assumed tropical:) [The Prince of the Faithful was wounded so that blood came from him]. (S.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) He pierced him with a spear so as to make the spearhead enter his inside: and A$Erhu sinaAnFA (tropical:) he made the spear-head to enter into the midst of him: [but this is said to be] from A$Erhu bihi “ he made it to cleave to it. ” (TA.) A^a$oEira is said specially of a king, meaning He was slain. (A, TA.) ― -b5- Also He made it to be a distinguishing sign: as when the performance of a religious service is made, or appointed, by God to be a sign [whereby his religion is distinguished]. (TA.) ― -b6- And A$ErwA They called, uttering their $iEaAr [whereby they might know one another]: or they appointed for themselves a $iEaAr in their journey. (Lh, K, TA. [See also 10.]) -A2- maA A^a$oEarahu [How good, or excellent, a poet is he !]. (TA in art. xzY: see muxozK in that art.) -A3- A$Er [from $aEorN or $aEarN signifying “ hair ”] It (a fœtus, S, A, K, in the belly of its mother, TA) had hair growing upon it; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ t$E~r; (S, K;) and ↓ $E~r, inf. n. ta$oEiyrN; and ↓ Ast$Er. (K.) ― -b2- And A$Ert She (a camel) cast forth her fœtus with hair upon it. (Ktr, K.) ― -b3- And A$Er He lined a boot, (A, K,) and a jub~ap, (A,) and the miyvarap of a horse's saddle, and a qalanosuwap, and the like, (TA,) with hair; (A, K;) as also ↓ $aEara; (Lh, A, K;) and ↓ $E~r, (K,) inf. n. ta$oEiyrN: (TA:) or, said of a myvrp, he covered it with hair. (A.) ― -b4- And A$Erhu He clad him with a $iEaAr [i. e. an innermost garment]. (S, A, K.) And He put on him a garment as a $iEaAr, i. e., next his body. (TA.) [Hence,] A$Erhu fulaAnN $ar~FA (tropical:) Such a one involved him in evil. (S, A.) And A$Erhu AlHub~u maraDFA (assumed tropical:) [Love involved him in disease]. (S.) And A$Erhu bihi (assumed tropical:) He made it (i. e. anything) to cleave, or stick, to it, [like the $iEaAr to the body,] i. e., to another thing. (K.) ― -b5- [And (assumed tropical:) It clave to him, or it, as the $iEaAr cleaves to the body. Hence,] A$Erhu Alham~u (tropical:) [Anxiety clave to him as the $iEaAr cleaves to the body]. (A.) And A$Er Alham~u qalobiY (tropical:) Anxiety clave to my heart (K, TA) as the $iEaAr cleaves to the body. (TA.) And A^a$oEara Alr~ajulu ham~FA (tropical:) The man clave to anxiety as the $iEaAr cleaves to the body. (S, TA. [In one of my copies of the S, A^u$oEira, accord. to which reading, the phrase
should be rendered The man was made to have anxiety cleaving to him &c.]) -A4- A$Er Als~ik~iyna (tropical:) He put a $aEiyrap [q. v.] to the knife. (S, A, K. *)
5 ta$aE~ara see 4, in the latter half of the paragraph.

6 t$AEr *
He affected, or pretended, to be a poet, not being such. (See its part. n., below.)]

10 Ast$Ert Albaqarapu *
The cow uttered a cry to her young one, desiring to know its state. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And Ast$ErwA They called, one to another, uttering the $iEaAr [by which they were mutually known], in war, or fight. (TA. [See also 4.]) -A2- Ast$Er as syn. with A$Er and t$E~r: see 4, in the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b2- Also, (A,) or Ast$Er $iEaArFA, (K,) He put on, or clad himself with, a $EAr [i. e. an innermost garment]. (A, K.) [Hence,] Aisota$oEiro xa$oyapa A@ll~`hi (tropical:) Make thou the fear of God to be $iEaAra qalobika [i. e. the thing next to thy heart]. (TA.) And Ast$Er xawofFA (tropical:) He conceived in his mind fear. (S, A. *)

$aEorN * and ↓ $aEarN, (A, Msb, K, but only the latter in my copies of the S and in the O,) two wellknown dial. vars., the like being common in cases of this kind, in which the medial radical letter is a faucial, (MF,) [but the latter I have found to be the more common,] Hair; i. e. what grows upon the body, that is not Suwf nor wabar; (K;) it is an appertenance of human beings and of other animals: (S, A, Msb:) [when spoken of as used in the fabrication of cloth for tents &c., the meaning intended is goats' hair: (see 4 in art. bnY:)] of the masc. gender: (Msb, TA:) pl. (of the former, Msb) $uEuwrN and (of the latter, Msb) A^a$oEaArN (S, Msb, K) and (of the latter also, TA) $iEaArN: (K, TA:) and ↓ A^u$ayoEaArN, properly dim. of A^a$oEaArN, is used, accord. to Aboo-Ziyád, as dim. of $uEuwrN: (TA:) the n. un. is with p: (S, A, * Msb, K:) and this, i. e. $aEorapN [or $aEarahN], is also used metonymically as a pl. (K, TA.) One says, bayoniY wabayonaka AlmaAlu $aq~u Al$~aEorapi and $aq~u AlA^ubolumapi (assumed tropical:) [The property is, or shall be, equally divided between me and thee]. (TA.) And raA^aY fulaAnN Al$~aEorapa Such a one saw, or has seen, hoariness, or white hairs, (Yaakoob, S, A, TA,) upon his head. (TA.) ― -b2- [The n. un.] $aEorapN is also used, metonymically, as meaning (tropical:) A daughter. (TA.) ― -b3- And ↓ $aEarN (K, and so accord. to the TA, but in the CK ↓ $uEorN,) signifies also (tropical:) Plants and trees; (K, TA;) as being likened to hair. (TA.) ― -b4- And the same, (A, K, TA, but in the CK ↓ $uEorN,) (tropical:) Saffron (A, K) before it is pulverized. (A.)
$uEorN * : see the next two preceding sentences.

$iEorN * [an inf. n., (see 1, first sentence,) and used as a simple subst. signifying] Knowledge; cognizance: (K, TA:) or knowledge of the minute particulars of things: or perception by means of [any of] the senses. (TA.) One says, layota $iEoriY fulaAnFA maA SanaEa, (Ks, Lh, S, * Msb, * K, *) and layota $iEoriY lahu maA SanaEa, and layota $iEoriY Eanohu maA SanaEa, (Ks, Lh, K, *) i. e. Would that I knew what such a one did, or has done; (S, * K, * Msb, * TA;) for would that my knowledge were present at, or comprehending, what such a one did, or has done; the phrase being elliptical: (TA:) accord. to Sb, layota $iEoriY is for lyt $iEoratiY, the p being elided as in huwa A^abuw Eu*orihaA [for hw Abw Eu*oratihaA], (S, TA,) the elision of the p in this latter instance, as Sb says, being peculiar to the case of the words being preceded by Abw; [but see Eu*orapN;] and as in A_iqaAmap when used as a prefixed noun; though layota $iEoratiY is not now known to have been heard. (TA.) One says also, layota $iEoriY maA kaAna Would that I knew what happened, or has happened. (A.) ― -b2- The predominant signification of $iEorN is Poetry, or verse; (Msb, K;) because of its preeminence by reason of the measure and the rhyme; though every kind of knowledge is $iEorN: (K:) or because it relates the minute affairs of the Arabs, and the occult particulars of their secret affairs, and their facetiæ: (Er-Rághib, TA:) it is properly defined as language qualified by rhyme and measure intentionally; which last restriction excludes the like of the saying in the Kur [xciv. 3 and 4], Aal~a*iY A^anoqaDa Zahorako warafaEonaA laka *ikorako, because this is not intentionally qualified by rhyme and measure: (KT; and the like is said in the Msb:) and sometimes a single verse is thus termed: (Akh, TA:) pl. A^a$oEaArN. (S, K.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) Falsehood; because of the many lies in poetry. (B, TA.)
$aEarN * : see $aEorN, in two places.

$aEirN * : see A^a$oEaru. ― -b2- [The fem.] $aEirapN signifies [particularly] A sheep or goat ($aApN) having hair growing between the two halves of its hoof, which in consequence bleed: or having an itching in its knees, (K, TA,) and therefore always scratching with them. (TA.)
$aEorapN * and $aEarapN ns. un. of $aEorN [q. v.] and $aEarN.

$iEorapN * The hair of the pubes; (T, Msb, K;) as also ↓ $iEoraA=', [accord. to general analogy with tenween,] or ↓ $aEoraA=', [and if so, without tenween,] accord to different copies of the K; (TA;) of a man and of a woman; and of the hinder part of a woman: (T, Msb:) or the hair of the pubes of a woman, specially: (S, O, Msb:) and the pubes (EaAnap) [itself]: (K:) and the place of growth of the hair beneath the navel. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- Also A portion of hair. (K, * TA.)

Al$~iEoraY * [The star Sirius;] a certain bright star, also called Almirozamu; (TA; [but see this latter appellation;]) the star that rises [aurorally] after AljawozaA=' [by which is here meant Gemini], in the time of intense heat, (S, TA,) and after AlhaqoEap [app. a mistranscription for AlhanoEap]: (TA:) [about the epoch of the Flight, it rose aurorally, in Central Arabia, on the 13th of July, O. S.: (see Aln~avorapu; and see also manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl:) on the periods of its rising at sunset, and setting aurorally, see dabarN and dabuwrN:] the Arabs say, A_i*aA TalaEati Al$~iEoraY jaEala SaAHibu Aln~axoli yaraY [When Sirius rises aurorally, the owner of the palm-trees begins to see what their fruit will be]: (TA:) there are two stars of this name; Al$~iEoraY AlEabuwru and Al$~iEoraY AlgumayoSaA='u, (S, K,) together called Al$~iEorayaAni: the former is that [above mentioned] which is in [a mistake for “ after ”] AljawozaA=', and the latter is [Procyon,] in the *iraAE [by which is meant Al*~iraAEu AlmaqobuwDapu, not Al*~iraAEu AlmabosuwTapu]; (S;) and both together are called the two Sisters of Suheyl (suhayol [i. e. Canopus]): (S, K:) the former was worshipped by a portion of the Arabs; and hence God is said in the Kur-án to be Lord of Al$~iEoraY: (TA:) it is called AlEabuwr because of its having crossed the Milky Way; and the other is called AlgumayoSaA=' because said by the Arabs to have wept after the former until it had foul thick matter in the corner of the eye: (K in art. gmS:) the former is also called Al$~iEoraY AlyamaAniy~apu [the Yemenian, or Southern, $ErY]; and the latter, Al$~iEoraY Al$~aAmiy~apu [the Syrian, or Northern, $ErY]. (Kzw.)
$aEoraA='u * fem. of A^a$oEaru [q. v.: under which head it is also mentioned either as a subst. or as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant]. ― -b2- See also $iEorapN.
$iEoraA=' * [app., if correct, with tenween]: see $iEorapN.

$iEoriY~N * [Of, or relating to, poetry; poetical. ― -b2- And also (assumed tropical:) False, or lying]. One says A^adil~apN $iEoriy~apN (assumed tropical:) False, or lying, evidences or arguments: because of the many lies in poetry. (B, TA.) -A2- [And Of, or relating to, Al$~iEoraY, i. e. Sirius.] You say, raEayonaA $iEoriY~a AlmaraAEiY We pastured our cattle upon the herbage of which the growth was consequent upon the nawo' [i. e. the auroral rising or setting] of Al$~iEoraY [or Sirius]. (A.)
$aEariy~aAtN * The young ones of the raxam [i. e. vultur percnopterus]. (K.)

$aEoraAnu * : see A^a$oEaru. ― -b2- $aEoraAn [app. without tenween, being probably originally an epithet, also] signifies (assumed tropical:) The [shrub called] rimov, (K,) or a species thereof, (Tekmileh, TA,) green, inclining to dust-colour: (Tekmileh, K, TA:) or a species of [the kind of plants called] HamoD, dust-coloured: (TA:) or HamoD upon which hares feed, and in which they [make their forms, i. e.] lie, cleaving to the ground; it is like the large A^u$onaAnap [here app. used as the n. un. of A^u$onaAnN, i. e. kali, or glasswort], has slender twigs, and appears from afar black. (AHn, TA.)

$uEoruwrN * [A poetaster]: see $aAEirN. -A2- Also, accord. to analogy, sing. of $aEaAriyru, which is (assumed tropical:) Syn. with $uEorN [as pl. of $aEoraA='u, q. v. voce A^a$oEaru], meaning the flies that collect upon the sore on the back of a camel, and, when roused, disperse themselves from it. (TA.) [Hence the saying,] *ahaba Alqawomu $aEaAriyra (assumed tropical:) The people dispersed themselves, or became dispersed: (S:) and *ahabuwA $aEaAriyra biqu*~aAna, (K,) or biqa*~aAna, and biqi*~aAna, (TA,) and biqinodaHorapa, (K,) and
biqino*aHorapa, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) They went away in a state of dispersion, like flies: (K:) $EAryr thus used being pl. of $uEoruwrN; (TA;) or having no sing. (Fr, Akh, S, TA.) And A^aSobaHato $aEaAriyra biqirodaHomapa, and biqiro*aHomapa, and biqinodaHorapa and biqid~aHorapa, and biqi*~aHorapa, (assumed tropical:) They became beyond reach, or power. (Lh, TA.) ― -b2- And the same pl. $aEaAriyru, having no sing., also signifies (assumed tropical:) A certain game (S, K, TA) of children. (TA.) You say, laEibonaA Al$~aEaAriyra [We played at the game of Al$EAryr]: and h`*aA laEibu Al$~aEaAriyri [This is the game of Al$EAryr]. (S.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) A sort of women's ornaments, like barley [-corns], made of gold and of silver, and worn upon the neck. (TA.) ― -b4- And $uEoruwrapN [n. un. of $uEoruwrN] signifies A small qiv~aA=' [or cucumber]: pl. $aEaAriyru [as above]. (S, K.)
$aEoraAniY~N * : see A^a$oEaru. -A2- A^aronabN $aEoraAniy~apN A hare that feeds upon the $aEoraAn [q. v.], and that [makes its form therein, i. e.] lies therein, cleaving to the ground. (AHn, TA.)

$aEaArN * (tropical:) Trees; (ISk, Er-Riyáshee, S, A, K;) as also ↓ $iEaArN: (As, ISh, K:) or tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, trees; (T, K;) as also ↓ $iEaArN: (Sh, T, K:) or (TA, but in the K “ and ”) trees in land that is soft (K, TA) and depressed, between eminences, (TA,) where people alight, (K, TA,) such as is termed dahonaA=', and the like, (TA,) warming themselves thereby in winter, and shading themselves thereby in summer, as also ↓ ma$oEarN: (K, TA:) or this last signifies any place in which are a xamar [or covert of trees, &c.,] and [other] trees; and its pl. is ma$aAEiru. (TA.) One says, A^aroDN kaviyrapu Al$~aEaAri (assumed tropical:) A land abounding in trees [&c.]. (S.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph, latter half.

$iEaArN *
A sign of people in war, (S, Msb, K,) and in a journey (K) &c., (TA,) i. e. (Msb) a call or cry, (A, Mgh, Msb,) by means of which to know one another: (S, A, Mgh, Msb:) and the $iEaAr of soldiers is a sign that is set up in order that a man may thereby know his companions: (TA:) and $iEaAr signifies also the banners, or standards, of tribes. (TA in art. brm.) It is said in a trad. that the $iEaAr of the Prophet in war was yaA manoSuwru A^amito A^amito [O Mansoor, (a proper name of a man, meaning “ aided ” &c.,) kill thou, kill thou]. (TA.) And it is said that he appointed the $iEaAr of the refugees on the day of Bedr to be yAbaniY Eabodi Alr~aHom`ni: and the $EAr of El-Khazraj, yA baniY Eabodi A@ll~`hi: and that of El-Ows, yaA baniY Eubayodi A@ll~`hi: and their $EAr on the day of El-Ahzáb, H`m= laA yunoSaruwna. (Mgh.) ― -b2- And Thunder; (Tekmileh, K;) as being a sign of rain. (TK.) ― -b3- $iEaAru AlHaj~i means The religious rites and ceremonies of the pilgrimage; and the signs thereof; (K;) and, (TA,) as also ↓ Al$aEaAy^iru, (S,) the practices of the pilgrimage, and whatever is appointed as a sign of obedience to God; (S, Msb, * TA;) as the halting [at Mount 'Arafát], and the circuiting [around the Kaabeh], and the saEoY [or tripping to and fro between Es-Safà and El-Marweh], and the throwing [of the pebbles at Minè], and the sacrifice, &c.; (TA;) and ↓ $aEiyrapN and ↓ $iEaArapN and ↓ ma$oErN signify the same as $iEaArN: (L:) ↓ $aEiyrapN is the sing. of $aEaAy^iru meaning as expl. above; (As, S, Msb;) or, as some say, the sing. is ↓ $iEaArapN: (As, S:) or ↓ $aEiyrapN and ↓ $iEaArapN, by some written ↓ $aEaArapN, and ↓ ma$oEarN, signify a place [of the performance] of religious rites and ceremonies of the pilgrimage; expl. in the K by muEoZamuhaA, which is a mistake for mawoDiEuhaA; (TA;) and ↓ ma$aAEiru, places thereof: (S:) or AlHaj~i ↓ $aEaAy^iru signifies the maEaAlim [or characteristic practices] of the pilgrimage, to which God has invited, and the performance of which He has commanded; (K;) as also ↓ Alma$aAEiru: (TA:) and A@ll~`hi ↓ $aEaAy^iru, all those religious services which God has appointed to us as signs; as the halting [at Mount 'Arafát], and the saEoY [or tripping to and fro between Es-Safà and El-Marweh], and the sacrificing of victims: (Zj, TA:) or the rites and ceremonies of the pilgrimage, and the places where those rites and ceremonies are performed; (Bd in v. 2 and xxii. 33;) among which places are Es-Safà and El-Marweh, they being thus expressly termed; (Kur ii. 153;) and so accord. to Fr in the Kur v. 2: (TA:) or the obligatory statutes or ordinances of God: (Bd in v. 2:) or the religion of God: (Bd in v. 2 and xxii. 33:) the camels or cows or bulls destined to be sacrificed at Mekkeh are also said in the Kur xxii. 37, to be mino $aEaAy^iri A@ll~`hi, i. e. of the signs of the religion of God: (Bd and Jel:) and [hence the sing.] ↓ $aEiyrapN signifies [sometimes] a camel or cow or bull that is brought to Mekkeh for sacrifice; (S, K;) such as is marked in the manner expl. voce A^a$oEara; (Msb;) and $aEaAy^iru is its pl.; (K;) and is also pl. of $iEaArN: and the [festival called the] Eiyd is said to be a $iEaAr of the $aEaAy^ir [i. e. a sign of the signs of the religion] of El-Islám. (Msb.) ― -b4- $iEaAru Ald~ami is said to mean (tropical:) The piece of rag: or (tropical:) the vulva: because each is a thing that indicates the existence of blood. (Mgh.) -A2- Also The [innermost garment; or] garment that is next the body; (S, Msb;) the garment that is next the hair of the body, under the divaAr; as also ↓ $aEaArN; (K;) but this is strange: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^a$oEirapN and [of mult.] $uEurN. (K.) [Hence,] one says, labisa $iEaAra Alham~i (tropical:) [He involved himself in anxiety]. (A.) And jaEala Alxawofa $iEaArahu (assumed tropical:) [He made fear to be as though it were his innermost garment], by closely cleaving to it. (TA in art. drE.) [Hence, also,] it is said in a prov., humu Al$~iEaAru duwna Ald~ivaAri, meaning (assumed tropical:) They are near in respect of love: and in a trad., relating to the Ansár, A^anotumu Al$~iEaAru waAln~aAsu Ald~ivaAru (assumed tropical:) Ye are the special and close friends [and the people in general are the less near in friendship]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A horse-cloth; a covering for a horse to protect him from the cold. (K.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) A thing with which wine [app. while in the vat] is protected, or preserved from injury: (L, K: [for Alxamoru, the reading in the CK, the author of the TK has read Alxumuru (and thus I find the word written in my MS. copy of the K) or Alxumoru, pls. of AlximaAru; and Freytag has followed his example: but Alxamoru is the right reading, as is shown by what here follows:]) so in the saying of El-Akhtal,
fakaf~a Alr~iyHa waAlA^anodaA='a EanohaA
mina Alz~arajuwni duwnahumaA Al$~iEaAru
[evidently describing wine, and app. meaning (assumed tropical:) And the $EAr of the wine, (Al$~iEaAru mina Alz~arajuwna, i. e. $iEaAru Alz~arajuwni,) while yet in the vat, intervening as an obstacle to them, kept off the wind and the rains, or dews, or day-dews, from it, namely, the wine]. (L.) ― -b4- See also $aEaArN, in two places. -A3- Also Death. (O, K.)

$aEiyrN * , (S, Msb, K,) which may be also pronounced $iEiyrN, agreeably with the dial. of Temeem, as may any word of the measure faEiylN of which the medial radical letter is a faucial, and, accord. to Lth, certain of the Arabs pronounced in a similar manner any word of that measure of which the medial radical letter is not a faucial, like kabiyrN and jaliylN and kariymN, (MF,) [and thus do many in the present day, others pronouncing the fet-h in this case, more correctly, in the manner termed A_imaAlap, i. e. as “ e ” in our word “ bed: ” Barley;] a certain grain, (S, Msb,) well known: (Msb, K:) of the masc. gender, except in the dial. of the people of Nejd, who make it fem.: (Zj, Msb:) n. un. with p [signifying a barleycorn]. (S, K.) -A2- Also An accompanying associate; syn. Ea$iyrN muSaAHibN: on the authority of En-Nawawee: (K, TA:) said to be formed by transposition: but it may be from $aEarahaA meaning “ he slept with her in one $iEaAr; ” [see 3; and so originally signifying a person who sleeps with another in one innermost garment;] then applied to any special companion. (TA.)
$iEaArapN * , and, as written by some, $aEaArapN: see $iEaArN, in four places.

$aEiyrapN *
A sign, or mark. (Mgh.) ― -b2- See this word, and the pl. $aEaAy^iru, voce $iEaArN, in seven places. -A2- Also n. un. of $aEiyrN [q. v.]. (S, K.) ― -b2- And [hence,] (tropical:) The iron [pin] that enters into the tang of a knife which is inserted into the handle, being a fastening to the handle: (S:) or a thing that is moulded of silver or of iron, in the form of a barley-corn, (K, TA,) entering into the tang of the blade which is inserted into the handle, (TA,) being a fastening to the handle of the blade. (K, TA.) ― -b3- [And (assumed tropical:) A measure of length, defined in the law-books &c. as equal to six mule's hairs placed side by side;] the sixth part of the A_iSobaE [or digit]. (Msb voce miylN.) ― -b4- [And (assumed tropical:) The weight of a barley-corn.]

[
$uEayorapN * dim. of $aEorapN and $aEarapN: pl. $uEayoraAtN.]
$uEayoraA='u * [dim. of $aEoraA='u fem. of A^a$oEaru. -A2- Also] A kind of trees; (Sgh, K;) in the dial. of Hudheyl. (Sgh, TA.) ― -b2- See also A^a$oEaru, last signification but one.

$aEiyriY~N *
A seller of $aEiyr [or barley]: one does
not use in this sense either of the more analogical forms of $aAEirN and $aE~aAr. (Sb, TA.)

$aAEirN *
A poet: (T, S, Msb, K:) so called because of his intelligence; (S, Msb;) or because he knows what others know not: (T, TA:) accord. to Akh, it is a possessive epithet, like laAbinN and taAmirN: (S:) pl. $uEaraA='u, (S, Msb, K,) deviating from analogy: (S, Msb:) Sb says that the measure faAEilN is likened in this case to faEiylN; and hence this pl.: (TA:) or, accord. to IKh, the pl. is of this form because the sing. is from $aEura, and therefore should by rule be of the measure faEiylN, like $ariyfN [from $arufa]; but were it so, it might be confounded with $aEiyr meaning the grain thus called, therefore they said $aAEirN, and regarded in the pl. the original form of the sing. (Msb.) A wonderful poet is called xino*iy*N: one next below him, $aAEirN: then, ↓ $awayoEirN [the dim.]: (Yoo, K:) then, ↓ $uEoruwrN: and then, ↓ mata$aAEirN. (K.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A liar: because of the many lies in poetry: and so, accord. to some, in the Kur xxi. 5. (B, TA.) ― -b3- $iEorN $aAEirN Excellent poetry: (Sb, T, K:) or known poetry: but the former explanation is the more correct. (TA.) One also says, sometimes, kalimapN $aAEirapN, [by klmp] meaning qaSiydapN: but generally in a phrase of this kind the two words are cognate, as in wayolN waAy^ilN and layolN laAy^ilN. (TA.)
$uwayoEirN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

A^a$oEaru * [More, and most, knowing or cognizant or understanding: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- And,] applied to a verse, (T,) or to a poem, (S,) More [and most] poetical. (T, S. *) -A2- Also, (S, A, K,) and ↓ $aEirN, (A, K,) and ↓ $aEoraAniY~N, (K,) which last (SM says) I have seen written $aEaraAniY~N, (TA,) A man having much hair upon his body: (S, A:) or having hair upon the whole of the body: (IAth, L voce A^ajoradu [q. v.], in explanation of the first:) or having much and long hair (K, TA) upon the head and body: (TA:) and the first and second, a goat having much hair: fem. of the first $aEoraA='u: (TA:) and pl. of the first $aEorN. (S, K.) One says A^$oEavu A^a$oEaru, meaning Having his head unshaven and not combed nor anointed. (TA.) And fulaAnN A^a$oEaru Alr~aqabapi [lit. Such a one is hairy in the neck] is said of a man though he have not hair upon his neck, as meaning (tropical:) such a one is strong, like a lion. (A, * TA.) ― -b2- [The fem.] $aEoraA='u also signifies A testicle, or scrotum, (xuSoyapN,) having much hair: (TA:) and the sawo'ap [or pudendum]: thus used as a subst. (IAar, TA in art. mET.) See also $iEorapN. ― -b3- And A furred garment. (Th, K.) ― -b4- And as an epithet, (tropical:) Evil, foul, or abominable: [as being likened to that which is shaggy, and therefore unseemly:] (K, * TA:) in the K, Alxa$inapu is erroneously put for Alxabiyvapu. (TA.) One says, daAhiyapN $aEoraA='u, (S, A, K,) and waboraA='u, (S, A,) and zab~aA='u, (TA in art. zb,) (tropical:) An evil, a foul, or an abominable, (TA,) or a severe, or great, (K,) calamity or misfortune: pl. $uEorN. (K, TA.) And one says to a man when he has said a thing that one blames or with which one finds fault, jiy^ota bihaA $aEoraA='a *aAta wabarK (tropical:) [Thou hast said it as a foul, or an abominable, thing]. (S, A. *) ― -b5- And A^a$oEaru signifies also The hair that surrounds the solid hoof: (S:) or [the extremity, or border, of the pastern, next the solid hoof; i. e.] the extremity of the skin surrounding the solid hoof, (K, TA,) where the small hairs grow around it: (TA:) or the part between the hoof of a horse and the place where the hair of the pastern terminates: and the part of a camel's foot where the hair terminates: (TA:) pl. A^a$aAEiru, (S, TA,) because it is [in this sense] a subst. (TA.) ― -b6- Also The side of the vulva, or external portion of the female organs of generation: (K:) it is said that the A^a$oEaraAni are the A_isokataAni, which are the two sides [or labia majora] of the vulva of a woman: or the two parts next to the $uforaAni, which are the two borders of the A_isokataAni: or the two parts between the A_isokataAni and the $uforaAni: (L, TA:) or the two parts next to the $uforaAni, in the hair, particularly: (Zj, in his “ Khalk el-Insán: ”) the A^a$aAEir of the HayaA=' [or vulva of a camel &c.] are the parts where the hair terminates: (TA:) and the A^a$aAEir of a she-camel are the sides of the vulva. (S, L, TA.) ― -b7- And A thing that comes forth from [between] the two halves of the hoof of a sheep or goat, resembling a vuw^oluwl [or wart]; (Lh, K;) for which it is cauterized. (Lh, TA.) ― -b8- And Flesh coming forth beneath the nail: pl. $uEurN, (K, TA,) with two dammehs, (TA,) or $uEorN. (So in the CK.) ― -b9- And [the fem.] $aEoraA='u also signifies (tropical:) Land (A^aroD) containing, or having, trees: or abounding in trees: (A, K:) [and so, app., ↓ $aEoraAnu; for] there is a mountain in [the province of] El-Mowsil called $aEoraAnu, said by AA to be thus called because of the abundance of its trees: (S:) or $aEoraA='u signifies many trees: (A 'Obeyd, S:) or i. q. A^ajamapN [i. e. a thicket, wood, or forest; &c.]: (TA:) and a meadow (rawoDapN, AHn, A, K, TA) having its upper part covered with trees, (AHn, K * TA,) or abounding in trees, (TA,) or abounding in herbage: (A:) and a tract of sand (ramolapN) producing [the plant called] naSiY~ (Sgh, L, K) and the like. (Sgh, K.) ― -b10- And (assumed tropical:) A certain tree of the kind called HamoD, (K, TA,) not having leaves, but having [what are termed] hadab [q. v.], very eagerly desired by the camels, and that puts forth strong twigs or branches; mentioned in the L on the authority of AHn, and by Sgh on the authority of Aboo-Ziyád; and the latter adds that it has firewood. (TA.) ― -b11- And (assumed tropical:) A certain fruit: (AHn, TA:) a species of peach: (S, K:) sing. and pl. the same: (AHn, S, K:) or a single peach: (IKtt, MF:) or AlA^a$oEaru is a name of the peach, and the pl. is $uEorN. (Mtr, TA.) ― -b12- Also (assumed tropical:) A kind of fly, (S, K,) said to be that which has a sting, (S,) blue, or red, that alights upon camels and asses and dogs; (K;) as also ↓ $uEayoraA='u: (TA:) a kind of fly that stings the ass, so that he goes round: AHn says that it is of two species, that of the dog and that of the camel: that of the dog is well known, inclines to slenderness and redness, and touches nothing but the dog: that of the camel inclines to yellowness, is larger than that of the dog, has wings, and is downy under the wings: sometimes it is in such numbers that the owners of the camels cannot milk in the day-time nor ride any of them; so that they leave doing this until night: it stings the camel in the soft parts of the udder and around them, and beneath the tail and the belly and the armpits; and they do not protect the animal from it save by tar: it flies over the camels so that one hears it to make a humming, or buzzing, sound. (TA. [See also $uEoruwrN, under which its pl. $uEorN is mentioned.]) ― -b13- And [hence, perhaps, as this kind of fly is seen in swarms,] (assumed tropical:) A multitude of men. (K.)
A^u$ayoEaArN * : see $aEorN.

ma$oEarN *
i. q. maEolamN [meaning A place where a thing is known to be]. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, A place of the performance of religious services. (TA.) See this word, and its pl. ma$aAEiru, voce $iEaArN, in four places. ― -b3- [The pl.] Alma$aAEiru also signifies The five senses; (S, * A, * TA;) the hearing, the sight, the smell, the taste, and the touch. (S and Msb in art. Hs.) -A2- See also $aEaArN.

diyapu Almu$oEarapi *
The bloodwit that is exacted for killing kings: it is a thousand camels. (A, TA. [See 4.])
muta$aAEirN * One who affects, or pretends, to be a poet, but is not. (S, * L, * K, * TA.) See $aAEirN.

1 $aEafa * , (S, O, K,) aor.
$aEafa , (K,) inf. n. $aEafN, though it is implied in the K, by its being said that the verb is like manaEa, that it is $aEofN, (TA,) He smeared, anointed, or overspread, a camel [suffering from the mange, or scab], with tar, (S, O, K, and Bd in xii. 30,) and burned him by so doing. (Bd ibid.) Imra-el-Keys says,
liyaqotulaniY waqado $aEafotu fuw^aAdahaA
kamaA $aEafa Almahonuwo'apa Alr~ajulu AlT~aAliY
[That he should slay me, I having overspread her heart with love of me, like as the man anointing overspreads her (meaning the camel) that is smeared with tar]: but it is also related otherwise, i. e. qaTarotu fuw^aAdahaA kamaA qaTara: (O, TA:) Aboo-'Alee El-Kálee says that she [the camel] that is smeared with tar experiences, by reason of the tar, a pleasurable sensation with a burning. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, [as indicated above,] qado $aEafahaA Hub~FA [He has overspread and burned her heart with love]; as some read in the Kur xii. 30; others reading $agafahaA: (Bd:) [or he has burned her heart with love; for] $aEafahu AlHub~u means love burned his heart: (S:) there are two readings of the words of the Kur above; (O, K;) [as well as two other readings mentioned in art. $gf;] qado $aEafahaA Hub~FA, (S, O, K,) one, a reading of El-Hasan (S, O) and others; meaning [as above: or], accord. to AZ, he has diseased her heart with love, (S, * O,) and
melted it: (O:) or, accord. to El-Hasan, he has penetrated into her with love: (S:) the other reading is qado $aEifahaA Hub~FA, (O, K,) meaning he has become attached to her with love, and loved her excessively: (O:) [but it is also said that] $aEafaniY Hub~uhu means The love of him overspread my heart from above; (O, K;) from $aEafapN signifying the “ head ” of the heart, “ at the place of suspension of [or from] the niyaAT; ” (O, * K;) and in like manner, $uEifotu bihi and biHub~ihi, (O, and so in the CK,) or $aEifotu: (so in other copies of the K, in which, and in the CK, the verb in this case is said to be like fariHa: [but this I regard as a mistake:]) and $aEafa Alqaloba He, or it, struck, or smote, the $aEafap, or uppermost part, of the heart: (Ham p. 545:) Az, however, says, I know not any one that has assigned to the heart a $aEafap, except Lth; and vehement love takes possession of the core (sawaAd) of the heart; not of its extremity: [but] accord. to Fr, $uEifa bifulaAnK, like EuniYa, means The love of such a one rose to the highest places of his heart: others say that Al$Ef [app. Al$~aEafu] signifies the being frightened, and disquieted, like the beast when it is frightened; and that the Arabs transferred its attribution from beasts to human beings: (TA:) Abu-l-'Alà says that Al$~aEafu signifies a thing's falling into the heart: (IB, TA:) one says also, $aEafahu AlmaraDu Disease melted him: (TA:) and accord. to AZ, $uEifa bika*aA means He became diseased by such a thing. (S.)

$aEafN * : see $aEafapN, in two places. ― -b2- Also The upper, or uppermost, part of the hump of the camel: (O, K:) Lth says that it is like the heads of truffles, and the three stones upon which the cooking-pot is placed, that are round in their upper, or uppermost, parts. (O.) -A2- Also Vehemence of love: (L:) [or simply love: for] one says, A^aloqaY Ealayohi $aEafahu, meaning [He cast] his love [upon him, or it]; as also $agafahu. (TA.)

$aEafapN * The head [or summit] of a mountain: (S, O, K:) and the upper, or uppermost, part of anything: (Ham pp. 130 and 545:) pl. ↓ $aEafN [or rather this is a coll. gen. n., and accord. to Freytag it is used as a sing., in the two senses above mentioned, in the Deewán of Jereer,] and [the pl. is] $uEuwfN and $iEaAfN and $aEafaAtN: (S, O, K:) and ↓ $aEafN is also expl. as signifying an elevated part of the earth or ground. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A lock of hair (xuSolapN) upon the head, (K,) or upon the upper, or uppermost, part of the head. (O, TA.) And $iEaAfN (its pl., TA) signifies The hair of the head: so in the phrase rajulN Suhobu Al$~iEaAfi [A man whose hair of the head is red, or red in the outer part and black beneath, or of a red colour tinged over with blackness, &c.]. (S, O, K.) ― -b3- And The [pendent lock of hair termed] *uw^aAbap of a boy, or young man. (S.) ― -b4- And $aEafapu Alqalobi signifies The head of the heart, at the place of suspension of [or from] the niyaAT [q. v.]. (O, TA. [But see, in the first paragraph, what Az says respecting this meaning.])
$aEaAfN * , like saHaAbN, Love's making away with the heart. (TA.)

$uEaAfN *
Insanity, or madness. (O, K.)

[
$uEayofapN * dim. of $aEafapN: pl. $uEayofaAtN.] One says, maA EalaY raA^osihi A_il~aA $uEayofaAtN There is not upon his head aught save some small hairs of the [pendent lock of hair termed] *uw^aAbap. (S, O, K.)

ma$oEuwfN * [Burned in the heart by love: (see 1:) or] diseased [therein]: (AZ, S:) or struck, or smitten, in the $aEafap of his heart by love, or by fright, or by insanity, or madness. (O, K.) Insane, or mad. (O, K.) Bereft of his heart. (TA.) [See also ma$oguwfN.]

1 $aEalati Aln~aAru * : see 8. ― -b2- [Hence,] $aEalati Alxayolu fiY AlgaArapi (assumed tropical:) [The horsemen became spread or dispersed, or spread or dispersed themselves, in the hostile, or predatory, incursion]; quasi-pass. of A^a$oEalotuhaA. (Ham p. 715.) ― -b3- And $aEala fiyhi, aor.
$aEala , (K,) inf. n. $aEolN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He went far in it; (K;) namely, an affair. (TK.) -A2- $aEala Aln~aAra: ― -b2- and AlHaroba: see 4. -A3- $aEila, aor.
$aEala , (K,) inf. n. $aEalN, (TA,) He (a horse) had the whiteness termed $aEalN and $uEolapN [expl. below]; (K;) as also ↓ A$EAl~, (Mgh, K, TA,) which occurs in poetry with the A made movent, i. e. ↓ Ai$oEaA^al~a, inf. n.
