Ai$oEiylaAlN; (TA; [in my copy of the Mgh written Ai$oEilaAl;]) or ↓ A$El~, (S,) or this last also, (TA,) inf. n. Ai$EilaAlN. (S, TA.) Among the faults in the “ Khizánet el-Fik-h ” is ↓ AlA_i$oEaAlu, [expl. as meaning The having] a whiteness of the A^a$ofaAr [or edges of the eyelids]. (Mgh.)
2 $E~l Aln~aAra * : see what next follows.

4 A$El Aln~aAra * ; (AZ, S, O, Msb, K;) and ↓ $aEalahaA, (AZ, O, Msb, K,) aor.
$aEala , inf. n. $aEolN; (TA;) and [in an intensive sense] ↓ $E~lhA, (K,) inf. n. ta$oEiylN; (TA;) He kindled the fire; or made it to burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame; syn. A^aDoramahaA, (S, O, TA,) or A^awoqadahaA, (Msb, by implication,) or A^alohayahaA; (K, TA;) fiY AlHaTabi [in the firewood]. (S, O, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says also, A^a$oEalotu AlHaroba (assumed tropical:) [I kindled war, or the war; or made it to burn fiercely, or to rage]; and ↓ $aEalotuhaA; mentioned by Abu-l-'Alà. (Ham p. 715.) 'Amr Ibn-El-Itnábeh says,
layosuwA biA^anokaAsK walaA miylK A_i*aA
↓ maA AlHarobu $ub~ato A^a$oEaluwA biAl$~aAEili
(S, O, and Ham ubi suprà,) (assumed tropical:) They are not persons in whom is no good, nor such as are not firm on their horses: [when war is kindled,] they make to burn fiercely, and excite, that which is slightly burning: such may be the meaning; for it may be that the b in bAl$AEl is pleonastically inserted, and Al$AEl may mean as above: or bAl$AEl may mean by him who makes it to burn fiercely, [as is implied in the S and O,] or by that which does so. (Ham.) ― -b3- And A^a$oEalotuhu gaDabFA (O, TA, and Ham p. 194) (tropical:) I excited him, or inflamed him, with anger. (TA.) ― -b4- And A$El A_ibilahu biAlqaTiraAni (assumed tropical:) He smeared his camels much with tar; (S, O, K, TA;) [which has a burning effect;] smearing them generally, and not merely the scattered scabs exclusively of the other parts of the body. (TA.) ― -b5- And A$El Alxayola fiY AlgaArapi (tropical:) He spread, or dispersed, the horsemen in the hostile, or predatory, incursion: (O, K, TA:) and [in like manner] one says A$ElwA AlgaArapa (assumed tropical:) [They spread, or dispersed, themselves, or their horsemen, in the hostile, or predatory, incursion]. (S and K in art. $Ew.) And A^a$oEalotu jamoEahumo (assumed tropical:) I dispersed or scattered, their congregation. (O, TA.) And A$El AlA_ibila (assumed tropical:) He dispersed the camels. (Lh, K, (TA.) ― -b6- And A$El Als~aqoYa (assumed tropical:) He made [the water-ing or] the water [of the irrigation] abundant. (IAar, K, TA.) -A2- A^a$oEalati AlgaArapu (assumed tropical:) The horsemen making a hostile, or predatory, incursion became dispersed, or dispersed themselves. (S, K.) ― -b2- A$Elt AlT~aEonapu (assumed tropical:) The spear-wound, or the like, emitted its blood in a scattered state. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) And A$Elt Alqirobapu, and AlmazaAdapu, (assumed tropical:) The water-skin, and the leathern water-bag, shed its water in a scattered state. (S, K.) And A$Elt AlEayonu (assumed tropical:) The eye shed its tears copiously. (O, K.) ― -b3- See also 1, last sentence.
5 ta$aE~ala see what next follows.

8 A$tElt Aln~aAru * ; (Lh, S, O, Msb, K, TA;) and ↓ $aEalat, aor.
$aEala ; (Msb;) and [in an intensive sense] ↓ t$E~lt; (K, TA;) The fire became kindled; or it burned up, burned brightly or fiercely, blazed, or flamed; syn. taA^aj~ajat, (Lh, TA,) or AiDoTaramat, (S, O, TA,) or tawaq~adat, (Msb,) and Ailotahabat; (K, * TA;) fiY AlHaTabi [in the firewood]. (Lh, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, Ai$otaEala gaDabFA (tropical:) He became excited, or inflamed, with anger: (TA:) or he became filled with wrath. (Msb.) ― -b3- Hence also, A$tEl Al$~ayobu fiY Alr~aA^osi (tropical:) Whiteness of the hair became glistening in the head; including the hair of the beard. (TA.) And A$tEl Alr~aA^osa $ayobFA [in the Kur xix. 3, expl. in art. $yb]. (S, Msb.)
9 A_i$oEal~a see 1.
11 A_i$oEaAol~a see 1. ― -b2- A$EAl~ raA^osuhu, (O, K,) inf. n. Ai$oEiylaAlN, (TA,) His hair became separated, or loosened, and ruffled, or bristling up. (O, K.)
Q. Q. 4 Ai$oEaA^al~a * : see 1.
$aEolN * (assumed tropical:) A man light, agile, or active, and clever, ingenious, acute, or sharp: (O, K:) and so maEolN. (O, TA.)

$aEalN * [inf. n. of $aEila (q. v.)] and ↓ $uEolapN [properly a subst. as distinguished from an inf. n.] (assumed tropical:) A whiteness in the tail of a horse, and the forelock, and the qa*aAl [or place where the Ei*aAr, i. e. each of the two cheek-straps of the headstall, is tied, behind the forelock]: (K:) or in some part of the forelock; or, as some say, in a side thereof: and
sometimes in the q*Al: but mostly in the tail: (TA:) or the former signifies a whiteness in the extremity of the tail of a horse: or, accord. to Lth, a whiteness in the forelock and the tail: or, as some say, in the head and the forelock: [or the quality of having such whiteness: for it is added that] the subst. [app. signifying such whiteness itself] is ↓ $uEolapN: (Mgh:) or the former, a whiteness in the side of the tail: [or,] accord. to As, ↓ $uEolapN is a term applied to a whiteness of the tail when it intermixes with any other colour; and the horse is said to be bay~inu Al$~aEali [i. e. one that exhibits the quality of having such whiteness]. (S.)

$uEolapN *
A firebrand; a piece of wood in which fire is kindled; (Az, K, * TA;) like ji*owapN and qayasN and $ihaAbN: (Az, TA:) [this is what is meant by its being said that] what is termed $uEolapN mino naArK [the only indication of the meaning in the S and O] is well known: (Msb:) pl. $uEalN; (S, O, TA;) erroneously said in the K to be like kutubN. (TA.) [Hence,] one says, fulaAnN $uEolapu naArK (assumed tropical:) [Such a one is a firebrand]. (Er-Rághib, TA voce *akaA='N, q. v.) ― -b2- And [A lighted wick: so in the present day: (see also $aEiylapN:) or] the burnt [or lighted] extremity of a wick. (S voce qiraATN. [And the same meaning is intended there in the K; and also in the TA voce ji*owapN.]) ― -b3- And The flame of fire; as also ↓ $uEoluwlN. (K, * TA. [In the CK $uEuwl; as though it were a second pl. of $uEolapN.]) ― -b4- And $uEolapu, (O, K, TA,) without Al, (K, TA,) is the name of A mare of Keys Ibn-Sebáa; (O, K, TA;) likened to the kindling of fire, because of her swiftness. (TA.) ― -b5- See also $aEalN, in three places.
$uEoluwlN * : see the next preceding paragraph. -A2- Also A party, division, sect, or distinct body or class, of men &c. (TA.) [See $aEaAliylu, below.]
$aEiylN * The like of stars, at the bottom of a cooking-pot; and in tinder, or burnt rag into which fire has fallen. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, TA.) ― -b2- See the next paragraph. ― -b3- And see also A^a$oEalu.

$aEiylapN * [A lighted wick; i. e.] a wick in which is fire; (S, O, K;) a wick soaked with oil or grease, in which is fire, used for giving light, and not thus called unless kindled with fire: (TA: [see also $uEolapN:]) or the fire that is kindled in a wick: (K:) pl. $uEulN, like as SuHufN is pl. of SaHiyfapN; (T, S, O, TA;) in the K erroneously said to be ↓ $aEiylN [which, however, may be correct as a coll. gen. n.]. (TA.)

$aEaAliylu * [a pl., of which the sing. is app. $uEoluwlN, q. v.; Things, and persons, scattered, or dispersed]. Aboo-Wejzeh says,
Hat~aY A_i*aA maA danato minohu sawaAbiquhaA
walil~ugaAmi biEiTofayohi $aEaAliylu
[Until, or until when, those of them that outstripped approached him, and there were scattered portions of foam upon his two sides]. (TA.) And one says, *ahabuwA $aEaAliyla, (S, O, K,) like $aEaAriyra, i. e., (S, O,) [They went away] in a state of dispersion; (K;) [or] they dispersed themselves, or became dispersed. (S, O.)

$aAEilN * as used in a verse cited above (see 4) [may be the part. n. of the intrans. verb in the phrase $aEalati Aln~aAru, and thus] may mean [Burning &c.; or] slightly burning: (Ham p. 715:) [or] it signifies *uw A_i$oEaAlK [having the quality of kindling, &c.; being said to be a possessive epithet], (S, O, K,) like taAmirN and laAbinN, having no verb: (S, O: [but see 4, first sentence:]) or it may be for *uw $aEolK, meaning mu$oEilN. (Ham ubi suprà. [See, again, 4.]) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

A^a$oEalu * A horse having the whiteness termed $uEolapN (As, S, Mgh, O, K) or $aEalN [q. v.]; (Mgh, K;) as also ↓ $aEiylN and ↓ $aAEilN: (O, K:) fem. of the first $aEolaA='u. (S, K.) ― -b2- And gur~apN $aEolaA='u [A blaze on a horse's forehead or face] taking in, i. e. including, one of the eyes. (Mgh, TA.)

ma$oEalN *
A [lamp of the kind called] qinodiyli [q. v.]. (K.) ― -b2- See also ma$oEalapN.

mu$oEalN * [pass. part. n. of 4, q. v.]. One says naArN mu$oEalapN [A fire kindled, &c.; or] burning up, burning brightly or fiercely, blazing, or flaming. (Lh, TA.) And jaA='a fulAanN kaAlHariyqi Almu$oEali i. e. [Such a one came like the fire that is] kindled, &c. (S, O.) See also the next paragraph.

jaraAdN mu$EilN * (tropical:) Locusts that are numerous, (K, TA,) spreading, (S, O,) in a state of dispersion, (K,) running in every direction. (S, O.) One says, (S, O, TA,) of an army, (TA,) jaAw^uwA kaAljaraAdi Almu$oEili (S, O, TA) (tropical:) They came [like locusts numerous and spreading, &c.,] coming forth from every direction: thus the last word is written accord. to Az [and J] and Sgh; and thus, and also ↓ Almu$oEali, accord. to Z. (TA.) And katiybapN mu$oEilapN (assumed tropical:) [A military force] spreading, or in a state of dispersion. (S, O.)

mi$oEalN *
A certain thing, (S, O, K,) used by the Arabs of the desert, (S, O,) made of skins (S, O, K) sewed together, like the niTaE [q. v.], (S, O,) having four legs (S, O, K) of wood, to which it is bound, so that it becomes like the wateringtrough; (S, O;) [the beverage called] nabiy* is prepared in it, (S, O, K,) because [generally] they have not jars: (S, O:) also called ↓ mi$oEaAlN: (O, K:) pl. ma$aAEilu. (S, O.) $ariba mi$oEalFA occurs in a trad. [as meaning He drank the quantity that filled a mi$oEal of nabiy*]. (O.) ― -b2- Also i. q. miSofaApN [A clarifier, or strainer, for wine &c.]: (O, K:) pl. as above. (TA.)

ma$EalapN *
A particular sort of large support for a light: (KL:) [i. e. a sort of cresset, consisting of a staff with a cylindrical frame of iron at the top which is filled with flaming pine-wood or the like or tarred rags, or, as is sometimes the case, having two, three, four, or five, of these receptacles for fire: it is borne before travellers and others at night; and is thus called in the present day, and also, more commonly, ↓ ma$oEal: (two cressets of the sort thus called are figured in my “ Modern Egyptians, ” ch. vi.: see also ma$aAEiliY~N, below:)] the place in which fire is kindled: (TA: [a loose explanation, meaning a cresset:]) what is thus called is the thing of which the pl. is ma$aAEilu: (S, O:) [accord. to El-Wáhidee, it is ↓ mi$oEalapN; for he says that] Alm$Elp with kesr to the m means the instrument in which fire is carried: and ma$oElp [thus, with a fet-hah over the nAr,] means fire kindled; or made to burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame; syn. mwqdp mwqdp. (W p. 51.)
mi$oEalapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
mi$oEaAlN * : see mi$oEalN.

[
ma$aAEiliY~N * , a rel. n. formed from ma$aAEilu pl. of ma$oEalapN, is a n. un. of which the coll. gen. n. is ma$aAEiliy~apN, and signifies A bearer of the cresset called ma$oEalap: hence applied also to a nightman: and hence, to a cleanser of wells: a scavenger; or remover of offal and the like: and to an executioner. (See De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., i. 201 — 203; and Quatremère's “ Hist. des Sultans Mamlouks, ” sec. part, 4 and 5.)]

4 A$EY Alqawomu AlgaArapa * , (S, K,) inf. n. A_i$oEaA='N, (S,) The people, or party, spread, or dispersed, themselves, or their horsemen, in the hostile, or predatory, incursion; syn. A^a$oEaluwhaA. (S, K.) -A2- And A$EY bihi, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He was, or became, grieved, or disquieted, by it; syn. Aihotam~a. (Ibn-Habeeb, Sgh, K.)

gaArapN $aEowaA='u *
A raid, or hostile or predatory incursion, spreading widely and dispersedly. (S, K. *) [See an ex. in the last of the verses cited voce rub~a.] ― -b2- And $ajarapN $aEowaA='u A tree having spreading branches. (ISd, K.)
jaA='ati Alxayolu $awaAEiYa * , (S, K,) and $awaAy^iEa, from which $wAEY is [said to be] formed by transposition, (S,) The horsemen came scattered, or dispersed, or in a state of dispersion. (S, K.)

1 $agaba Ealayohimo * , (S, A, Msb, K,) and bihimo, (S, Msb, K,) and fiyhimo, (TA,) and $agabahumo, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
$agaba , (A, Msb, K,) inf. n. $agobN, (S, * A, * K, * TA,) with which $agabN is syn., (A, K,) a syn. sometimes used, (A,) or this latter is not allowable, (S, K,) as some say, (K,) and is ascribed by IAth to the vulgar, and said by El-Hareeree in the “ Durrat el-Ghowwás ” to be a mistake, but IB says in the commentaries on the “ Durrah ” that it is correct, mentioned by IDrd, and MF says that it is mentioned by IJ, as well as by Z in the A; (TA;) and one says also $agiba Elyhm, [and it seems to be implied that one says likewise $agiba
bhm, and $agibahumo,] aor. as above, (S, K,) inf. n. $agabN; (S, TA;) but this latter form of the verb, with kesr, is of weak authority; (S, * TA;) [whence it seems that $agabN is correct as inf. n. of $agiba, but disallowed by some who knew not this form of the verb;] He excited, or stirred up, (S, A, Msb, K, TA,) [against them, or] among them, (Msb,) evil, or mischief, (S, A, Msb, K, TA,) and conflict, faction, sedition, or discord, and contention, or altercation, and opposition: (TA:) and [it is said that] ta$ogiybN is like $agobN signifying the exciting, or stirring up, evil, &c.; (K, TA;) [but] ↓ $g~b, inf. n. ta$ogiybN, signifies he excited, or stirred up, evil, &c., much, or often. (O.) A trad. mentioned in [the first paragraph of] art. $Eb is quoted by IAth thus: maA h`*ihi AlfotoyaA Al~atiY $agabato fiY Aln~aAsi [What is this judicial decision which has excited evil, &c., among the people?]. (TA.) ― -b2- [See also $agobN below.] ― -b3- The saying of 'Amr Ibn-Kameeäh,
faA_ino ta$ogibiY faAl$~agobu min~iY sajiy~apN
means (tropical:) And if thou oppose, or contravene, me, and do that which is not agreeable to me, [know that opposition, &c., is a natural disposition of mine; EalaY~a being understood after t$gbY, as appears from what here follows.] (TA. [See also 3, and 6.]) Accord. to El-Báhilee, *aAtu $agobK [applied to a she-ass] means (tropical:) Having the quality of opposing or contravening [the male]: so in the saying of El-'Ajjáj,
kaA^an~a taHotiY *aAta $agobK samoHajaA
qawodaA='a laA taHomilu A_il~aA muxodajaA
(tropical:) [As though beneath me were a she-ass] such as opposes or contravenes [the male], long-bodied, long-necked, [that would not bear in her womb aught save a fœtus imperfectly formed;] meaning, laA tuw^aAtibhi wata$ogabu Ealayohi [i. e. that she (the beast that he was riding) would not comply with his desire, and was contravening him]. (TA.) [Accord. to J,] *aAtu $agobK waDigonK, [in the TA wSgb, and so in a copy of the A, an evident mistranscription,] applied to a she-ass that has not conceived during a year or two years or some years, means (tropical:) Refractory, or incompliant, to the strong, or bulky, male. (S: there expl. by the words A_i*aA waHimato waA@sotaSoEabato EalaY AljaA^obi [which have been misunderstood by Golius, and rendered by him, and by Freytag after him, as applied to a woman, and meaning respuens maris congressum, aut picâ laborans].) ― -b4- And $agaba signifies also (assumed tropical:) He declined, or deviated, from the right way or course: (Sh, TA:) or $agaba Eani AlT~ariyqi, aor.
$agaba , (K,) inf. n. $agbN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He declined, or deviated, from the road or way. (K.)
2 $ag~aba see 1, end of the first sentence.

3 $Agbhu * , (S, A, K, TA,) inf. n. mu$aAgabapN and $igaAbN, (TA,) He acted with him in an evil manner; treated him with enmity, or hostility; contended in altercation with him; or did evil to him, obliging him to do the like in return: (A, K, TA:) he opposed, or contravened, him. (TA.)
6 Talabotu minohu ka*aA fata$aAgaba waA@motanaEa * (tropical:) I sought, or demanded, of him such a thing, and he manifested incompliance (taEaASaY), and refused. (A, TA.)

$agobN * inf. n. of $agaba [q. v. passim]. (S, * A, * K, * TA.) ― -b2- Also Clamour, or a confusion of cries or shouts or noises: (Ham p. 505:) or much clamour and confused or indistinct speech, leading, or conducing, to evil, or mischief. (Har p. 311.) One says $agobu Aljunodi [The clamour, &c., of the army]. (S, and Ham ubi suprà.) ― -b3- [Hence, app., this word, or the next, is used by some postclassical writers as signifying The plaintive cry of the bulobul. (See De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., iii. 500 — 502.)]
$agabN * inf. n. of $agiba [q. v.]. (S, TA.)

$agibN * , (S, O, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, $igobN,]) like katifN, (O,) and ↓ $ag~aAbN, (S, O, K,) the latter in an intensive sense, (TA,) and ↓ $igab~N, (O, K,) [also in an intensive sense,] and ↓ mi$ogabN, (S, O, K,) [likewise] in an intensive sense, (O,) and ↓ mu$ag~ibN, [also in an intensive sense accord. to the explanation of its verb in the O,] (S,) and ↓ mu$aAgibN, and ↓ *uwma$aAgiba, (K,) One who excites, or stirs up, evil, or mischief, (S, * K, TA,) and conflict, faction, sedition, or discord, and contention, or altercation, and opposition. (TA.)
$igab~N * : see the next preceding paragraph.
$ag~aAbN * : see $agibN. ― -b2- naAqapN $ag~aAbapN (tropical:) A she-camel that does not pursue a direct course, but deviates [therefrom]. (A, TA.)
mi$ogabN * : see $agibN. ― -b2- fulaAnN mi$ogabN (assumed tropical:) Such a one is a person who deviates from what is right, or from the truth. (O, TA.)
mu$ag~ibN * : see $agibN.
*uw ma$aAgiba * : see $agibN.
mu$aAgibN * : see $agibN.

1 $agVra The inf. n. $agorN, accord. to Ibn-Nubáteh, primarily signifies The raising the leg or hind leg, without restriction; and then by a metaphorical usage, the doing so for the purpose of copulation, and for making water: but the explanations of J [and of Z in the A] and of Fei and of F are at variance with his assertion. (MF.) [Accord. to these authorities,] $agara, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
$agara , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. as above, (Msb, TA,) signifies He (a dog) raised one of his hind legs (S, A, Msb, K) to make water, (S, Msb,) or and made water, or whether he made water or did not: (A, K:) and $agara birijolihi he (a dog) raised his hind leg, and made water. (TA.) And $agarato She (a camel) raised her hind leg, and struck [with it, or kicked,] the young one. (A.) And, said of a woman, (Msb, K,) She raised her leg, (Msb, and so in some copies of the K,) or her legs, (so in other copies of the K,) for the purpose of copulation. (Msb, K.) And the verb is also trans.: you say, $agara AlmaroA^apa, (Msb, K,) inf. n. $uguwrN, (K, [but this is a strange form in the case of a trans. verb,]) He raised the woman's leg, (Msb, and so in some copies of the K) or legs, (IDrd, O, and so in some copies of the K,) for the purpose of copulation; and so ↓ A$grhA. (IDrd, O, Msb, K.) And $agorN as the act of a stallion [camel] signifies His striking with his head beneath the she-camel, at the part next the udder, and so raising her, and throwing her down [app. for the purpose of copulation]. (K.) ― -b2- $agarotu birijoliY fiY Algariybi means (assumed tropical:) I overcame the people in guarding, or protecting, the stranger. (AA, O, K.) ― -b3- And $agorN signifies also (assumed tropical:) The being distant, or remote. (Fr, K.) One says, $agara Albaladu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
$agura , inf. n. $uguwrN, (Msb, [accord. to the K, app., $agorN,]) (assumed tropical:) The country, or town, was, or became, remote from him who should aid it against the enemy, and him who should exercise sovereign sway, (K, TA,) and from him who should manage its affairs with prudence, precaution, or sound judgment: (TA:) or destitute of a guardian, or protector, to defend it: (Msb:) or destitute of people: [and so, app., $agara Albaladu birijolihi; for it is immediately added,] one says balodapN $aAgirapN birijolihaA meaning as expl. below: (S:) and $agarati AlA^aroDu the land had not remaining in it any one to defend it, and to manage its affairs with prudence, precaution, or sound judgment. (K.) -A2- Also, i. e. $agorN, The making [another, or others,] to go forth [from a place]. (K.) One says, $agarotuhu Eani AlA^aroDi I made him to go forth from the land: (AA, TA:) and $agarotu baniY fulaAnK mino mawoDiEi ka*aA I made the sons of such a one to go forth from such a place: (S:) or $agaruwA fulaAnFA Eano baladihi They drove away, expelled, or banished. such a one from his country, or town; and the inf. n. is $agorN and $igaArN. (TA.) ― -b2- And i. q. taforiqapN [The act of scattering, or dispersing]. (K.)

3 $Agrhu * , (Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. $igaArN, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) He gave him in marriage a woman on the condition of his giving him in marriage another, without dowry [from either]; concubitus with each of the said women being [in lieu of] the dowry for the other: or it applies peculiarly to female relations [of the men so contracting]; (K;) so that the meaning is only he gave him in marriage his female relation on the condition of his doing the like to him: (TA:) or he gave him in marriage a female under his guardianship, the other man doing to him the like, on the condition that concubitus with each one of the said females should be [in lieu of] the dowry for the other: (Mgh, * Msb:) or he gave him in marriage his sister on the condition of receiving in marriage the other's sister, without any dowry beside this: (A:) or he said to him, Give me in marriage thy daughter, or thy sister, on the condition of my giving thee in marriage my daughter, or my sister, concubitus with each one of the said females being [in lieu of] the dowry of the other. (S.) The practice of $igaAr was common in the Time of Ignorance, (Msb,) but is
forbidden to the Muslims. (S, A.) ― -b2- $igaArN also signifies Two men's going forth into the field from two armies, and, when one of them has almost overcome his fellow, two men's coming to aid one of them, whereupon the other cries out, laA $igaAra laA $igaAra: (TA:) or two men's acting wrongfully, or injuriously, towards another man: (K, TA:) thus expl. by ISd. (TA.) And The acting with enmity, or hostility. (TA.)

4 A$gr AlmaroA^apa * : see 1. -A2- A$grt Alr~ufoqapu [and app. ↓ A$tgrt also (see the last sentence of this art.)] (assumed tropical:) The party journeying together withdrew by themselves from the beaten road. (K, TA.) ― -b2- See also 8, first sentence. ― -b3- A$grt said of a she-camel, She went with wide steps, and quickly. (TA.) ― -b4- See, again, 8.

5 t$g~r *
He (a camel) exerted his utmost power, (K,) or spared no exertion, (A'Obeyd, S,) in his pace: (A'Obeyd, S, K:) or ran vehemently: (K:) or went a pace above that termed All~abaTapu. (TA.) ― -b2- t$g~r fiY A^amorK qabiyHK He (a man, O) persevered in an evil, or a foul, affair, and went deep into it. (O, K. *)

8 A$tgr * , (JK, T,) or ↓ A$gr, (S, K,) It (a watering-place) was on one side of the beaten track: (JK, T, S, K:) [both verbs may be correct: that the former is so appears from the fact that] a poet, cited in the T, [describing a water-ing-place,] uses the phrase ↓ baEiydu Alu$otagari [app. meaning far off on one side of the road]. (TA.) See also 4. ― -b2- A$tgr AlEadadu The number was, or became, large. (S, K.) ― -b3- A$tgr AlA_ibilu The camels were, or became, many and various. (K.) ― -b4- A$tgrt Ealayohi DayoEatuhu i. q. fa$ato, (A,) i. e. His affairs became disordered so that he knew not with which of them to begin. (TA in art. f$w.) ― -b5- A$tgr AlA^amoru The affair became confused: (K:) or became large, or wide, and great, bifulaAni [with such a one]. (AZ, TA.) ― -b6- A$tgrt AlHarobu The war, or battle, became wide and great. (TA.) ― -b7- A$tgr Ealayohi HisaAbuhu, (T, S, A,) in the K ↓ A^a$ogara, but the former is the right, (TA,) (tropical:) What he had to reckon was, or became, too diffuse and numerous to him; (T, K;) such that he could not find the way to sum it up. (S, A.) ― -b8- *ahaba fulaAnN yaEud~u baniY fulaAnK faA@$otagaruwA Ealayohi Such a one went to number the sons of such a one, and they were too numerous for him. (TA.) ― -b9- A$tgr fiY AlfalaApi He went far into the desert. (S, K.) ― -b10- A$tgr EalayonaA He exalted himself above us, and boasted against us. (K.)

tafar~aquwA $agara bagara * and $igara bigara They dispersed themselves, or became dispersed, in every direction: (S, K:) and in like manner one says of sheep or goats, biagara tafar~aqati Alganamu $agara: (TA:) $gr bgr is a compound of two nouns made into one, and indecl., with fet-h for the termination. (S.) The like is not said in the case of [persons &c.] coming, or advancing. (TA.)

$agoraY *
A stone at which dogs raise the kind leg and make water, or to make water: (K:) so in the Tekmileh. (TA.)

$agaArN *
Empty. (Sgh, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Also, used as sing. and pl., A well, and wells, having much water: (K:) or, as is said in the Nawádir, thus used, having much water; wide, or spacious, in the adjacent part where the camels lie down. (TA.) -A2- Also, accord. to the K, Two veins, or ducts, (EiroqaAni,) in the side of the camel: but correctly, as in the Tekmileh, the $agaAraAni are the HaAlibaAni, i. e. two veins or ducts, (EiroqaAn,) in the two sides of the camel. (TA.)
$aguwrN * A tall she-camel, that raises her legs (ta$ogaru biqawaAy^imihaA) when she is taken to be ridden (K, TA) or to be milked. (TA.)
$ag~aArapN * A she-camel that raises her legs to strike [with them, or kick]. (TA.)

$aAgirN * A dog raising one of his kind legs, and making water, or whether making water or not. (A.) ― -b2- balodapN $aAgirapN birijolihaA (tropical:) A country, or town, that does not defend itself from a hostile attack (S, A, K) made by any one, (S, K,) by reason of its being destitute (K, TA) of any to protect it. (TA.) And A^aroDN $aAgirapN (assumed tropical:) A land having no one remaining in it, to defend it, and to manage its affairs with prudence, precaution, or sound judgment. (K.) One says also, AlA^aroDu lakumo $aAgirapN, meaning (assumed tropical:) The land, or the earth, is wide, or ample, for you. (TA.)
mu$otagarN * : see 8 [of which it is app. an inf. n.].
rufoqapN mu$otagirapN * , A party journeying together far from the beaten road. (TA.)

Q. 1 $agorabahu *
i. q. $agozabahu, q. v. (AZ, TA.)
$agorabaY * (TA) and $agorabiy~apN (K) i. q. $agozabaY and $agozabiy~apN. (K, TA.)

Q. 1 $agozabahu * , inf. n. $agozabapN, He threw him down by the trick called $agozabiy~ap, expl. below; (S, K;) and $agorabahu signifies the same. (AZ, TA.) Accord. to IAth, the primary meaning of $agozabapN is A twisting, in a neuter sense; and artifice. (TA.) ― -b2- Also He took him, or seized him, violently. (K.)

Q. 2 ta$agozabati Alr~iyHu *
The wind whirled (Ailotawat) in its blowing. (K.)
$agozabaY * : see $agozabiy~apN.

$agozabiY~N *
Difficult; (K;) anything deemed difficult. (IAth, TA.) ― -b2- A [watering-place such as is termed] manohal lying out of the way. (K, TA.) ― -b3- Al$~agozabiY~u The jackal; syn. Aibonu A=waY. (IAth, TA.)

$agozabiy~apN * (S, K) and ↓ $agozabaY, as also $agorabiy~apN (K) and $agorabaY, but more chastely with z, (TA,) A sort of trick in throwing down [or wrestling]; (S, TA;) the twisting of one's leg with the leg of another, (S, K, TA,) and throwing him down (K, TA) in the manner termed $azorFA [or sideways]: (TA:) and one says also, A^axa*ahu biAl$~agozabiy~api, (S, TA, [in one of my copies of the S biAl$~agozabapi,]) meaning the same: (TA:) and SaraEahu SaroEapF $agozabiy~apF: (AZ, TA:) [the pl. is $agaAzibu:] Dhu-r-Rummeh says,
walab~asa bayona A^aqowaAmK fakul~N
A^aEad~a lahu Al$~agaAziba waAlmiHaAla
[And he involved affairs in confusion between parties, so all prepared for him tricks by which to overthrow him, and artifice] (S, TA.)

Hat~aY yakuwna $ugozub~FA * occurs in the “ Sunan ” of Aboo-Dáwood, in the chapter on the Eaqiyqap and Eatiyrap; but it is thought by El-Harbee that the last word is for zuxozub~FA, meaning Firm in flesh, and thick, big, or bulky. (L, TA.)

1 $agafahu * , (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
$agafa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. $agofN, (Msb,) He, or it, struck, or smote, his $agaAf; (O, K;) like kabadahu meaning “ he, or it, struck, or smote, his kabid ” [or “ liver ”]; (O, TA;) so says Yoo: (TA:) or it (i. e. love) rent the $agaAf of his heart: (Fr, TA:) or it (love) reached his $agaAf: (ISk, S, TA:) or $agafa qalobahu it (love) reached the $agaAf of his heart, i. e. his pericardium. (Msb.) I'Ab read, [in the Kur xii. 30,] qado $agafahaA Hub~FA, and expl. the meaning to be [He has affected her so that] the love of him has entered beneath the $agaAf: (S, TA:) or the meaning is, the love of him has struck, or smitten, her $agaAf: (Lth, O, TA:) or he has rent the $agaAf of her heart, i. e. its HijaAb, [app. meaning her midriff,] so as to reach her heart, with love: (Bd:) Abu-l-Ash-hab read qado $agifahaA Hub~FA, with kesr to the g, [meaning he has became attached to her, or has loved her,] like the reading of Thábit El-Bunyánee, $aEifahaA, with kesr to the unpointed ': (O, TA:) [for] $agifahu, aor.
$agafa , [inf. n. app. $agafN,] signifies he became attached to him, or loved him. (K, TA.) One says also, $agafahu AlmaAlu, meaning The property became embellished to him, [or pleasing to him,] so that he loved it. (Msb.) And $ugifa biAl$~aYo'i, like EuniYa, He was, or became, vehemently desirous of the thing; or fond of it. (TA.) And $agifa biAl$~aYo'i, like fariHa, He became disquieted, or disturbed, by the thing. (TA.)

entryFree.key: maA h`*ihi AlfutoyaA Al~atiY ta$ag~afati Aln~aAsa

div2.entryFree: 5 maA h`*ihi AlfutoyaA Al~atiY ta$ag~afati Aln~aAsa * , a saying of I'Ab, means [What is this judicial sentence] that has put vain suggestions into the minds of the people, and separated them? as though it entered the $agaAf of their hearts. (TA.) [See also 1 in arts. $Eb and $gb.]
$agofN * : see $agaAfN in two places.

$agafN * [app. inf. n. of $agifa: and accord. to Fei, app., Love reaching to the pericardium; or heartfelt love; see an ex. in a verse cited voce balo; and see also Hub~N, and $aEafN;] a subst. from $agafa qalobahu, said of love. (Msb.) -A2- See also $agaAfN, in two places. -A3- Also The bark (najab, AHn, O, or qi$or, K) of the kind of tree called gAf. (AHn, O, K. *)

$agaAfN * The pericardium; i. e. the gilaAf, (S, O, K,) or gi$aA=', (Msb,) of the heart: (S, O, Msb, K:) or [app. a mistake for “ and, ” as will be shown by what follows,] its HijaAb [generally meaning the midriff], (K,) [here said to be,] accord. to AHeyth, a certain fat that clothes the heart: (TA:) [J seems to confound the gilaAf of the heart with its HijaAb; for after “ the galAf of the heart, ” he adds, “ and it is a skin beneath it (duwnahu), like the HijaAb: ”] or the Hab~ap (K) or the suwayodaA=' [both generally meaning the core] thereof: (O, K:) or the place of entrance (mawolj) of the phlegm: (Lth, O, K:) and ↓ $agofN and ↓ $agafN signify the same in the two senses, (K,) or in the first and second senses: (TA:) or Alqalob ↓ $agofu and ↓ $agafuhu signify the same as $agaAfuhu, accord. to AHeyth: (O:) the pl. of the $agaAf of the heart is $ugufN; which is metaphorically applied in a saying of 'Alee to the place of the fœtus [in the belly]. (TA.) -A2- Also, (A'Obeyd, S, O, K,) and ↓ $ugaAfN, (K,) the latter agreeable with analogy as the name of a disease, (TA,) A certain disease that attacks one, beneath the $araAsiyf [pl. of $urosuwfN, q. v.], in the right side: (A'Obeyd, S, O, K:) and (some say, TA) a pain of the belly: (K, TA: [in the CK, AlbaZor is erroneously put for AlbaTon:]) and (some say, TA) a pain of the $agaAf of the heart: (K, TA:) accord. to As, $agaAfN signifies a certain disease in the heart, which, if it reaches to the spleen, kills the patient. (TA.)
$ugaAfN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

ma$oguwfN *
Insane, or mad; (O, K;) like ma$oEuwfN. (O.) And ma$oguwfN bimaAlK One to whom property is embellished [or rendered pleasing,] so that he loves it. (Msb.)

1 $agalahu * , (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
$agala , (O, K, MS,) inf. n. $agolN (Msb, K) and $ugolN, (K,) the latter on the authority of Sb, (TA,) He, or it, (a man, S, or an affair, Msb,) busied him, occupied him, or employed him; (K;) i. q. A^alohaAhu [signifying as above; and particularly he, or it, busied him, &c., so as to divert him from (Eano) something; or diverted him from a thing by busying him, &c.]: (S and Msb and K in art. lhw, and Bd and Jel in xv. 3, &c.:) [↓ $g~lhu signifies he, or it, busied him, &c., much; i. e.] with teshdeed it denotes muchness: (Bd in xlviii. 11:) ↓ A$glhu is a good dial. var. of $agalahu; or is rare; or bad: (K:) accord. to IDrd [and J], (O,) one should not say A^a$ogalotuhu; (S, O;) for it is bad: (S:) accord. to IF, they scarcely ever say A^a$ogalotu, [thus in the O, but in the Msb ↓ Ai$otagala,] but it is allowable: (O:) none of the leading lexicologists is known to have pronounced it good. (TA.) [Hence the saying, $agalato saEaAtiY jadowaAYa (see art. sEw and sEY), or, as some relate it, $glt $iEaAbiY jdwAY (see art. $Eb).] See another ex. voce $aAgilN. One says also $ugila bihi, (Msb, K,) meaning talah~aY [i. e. He was, or became, busied, &c., by it], (Msb,) and bh ↓ A$tgl [meaning the same]; (Az, Msb, K;) and $ugilotu Eanoka bika*aA [I was, or became, busied, &c., so as to be diverted from thee, by such a thing], (S, O,) and ↓ Ai$otagalotu [in the same sense]: (S:) and Eanohu ↓ t$Agl, (TA,) which likewise signifies talah~aY [meaning as expl. above, or he busied himself, &c., so as to divert himself from him, or it]: (TA in art. lhw, and Bd and Jel in lxxx. 10:) some disallow ↓ Ai$otagala, in the form of an active verb, but say Au$otugila, in the form of a pass. verb; but it is originally quasi-pass of A^a$ogalotuhu, like as are AiHotaraqa and Aikotahala of A^aHoraqotuhu and A^akohalotuhu; [though why of A^a$ogalotuhu rather than of $agalotuhu, I do not see:] Az mentions the usage of its act. and pass. part. ns.: (Msb:) accord. to AHát and IDrd, one should not say ↓ Ai$otagala; but IF mentions, as transmitted from the Arabs, Au$otugila fulaAnN biAl$~aYo'i, and the pass. part. n. (O.) ― -b2- One says also, naHonu na$ogalu Eanoka AlmarotaEa (assumed tropical:) [We occupy the place of pasturage so as to keep it from thee], and AlmaA='a [the water]; meaning, it is sufficient for us without being more than sufficient. (S in art. $fh.) And $ugila Eanoka maA EinodanaA (assumed tropical:) [What we had was employed so as to be kept from thee]. (JK in that art.)
2 $ag~ala see the preceding paragraph.

4 A$glhu * : see 1. ― -b2- maA A^a$ogalahu [meaning How much is he busied! &c.], (Th, S, K,) denoting wonder, (Th, TA,) is anomalous, because one does not [regularly] form a verb of wonder from one in the form of a pass. verb. (Th, S, K.)

6 t$Agl Eanohu * : see 1. [Accord. to Golius, t$AglwA signifies They occupied one another, on the authority of the KL; in which, however, I find only ta$aAgulN expl. as meaning xwdrA bJyzY m$gwl krdn i. e. To make oneself busied, &c., with a thing.]

8 A_i$otagala see 1, in five places. ― -b2- One says also, Ai$otagala fiyhi Als~am~u The poison crept into him, or pervaded him; syn. saraY: and A$tgl fiyhi Ald~awaA='u The medicine entered into him, and produced an effect upon him, or showed its effect upon him; syn. najaEa. (TA.)
$agolN * an inf. n. of 1. (K, Msb.) See the next paragraph. -A2- And see also $agolapN.

$ugolN * and ↓ $agolN and ↓ $ugulN (S, O, Msb, K) and ↓ $agalN (S, O, K;) Business, occupation, or employment; (PS;) contr. of faraAgN: (K:) [and particularly business, &c., that diverts one from a thing:] or an occurrence that causes a man to forget, or neglect, or be unmindful: (Er-Rághib, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^a$ogaAlN (S, O, K) and [of mult.] $uguwlN: (K:) $ugolN is mentioned by Sb as an instance of an inf. n. having a pl., namely, A^a$ogaAlN; like EaqolN and maraDN. (TA in art. mrD.) [See also A^u$oguwlapN.]
$agalN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

$agilN *
Busy, or busied, occupied, or employed: (K:) [and particularly busy, &c, so as to be diverted from a thing:] thought by ISd to be a possessive epithet [meaning *uw $ugolK], because it has no verb to which it is conformable: (TA:) it is an epithet applied to a man, from Al$~agolu [or Al$~ugolu]: (IAar, in O:) and ↓ ma$oguwlN signifies the same; (Msb, TA;) and ↓ mu$otagilN (Az, Msb, K) and ↓ mu$otagalN, (Az, IF, O, Msb, K,) the latter [said to be] extr. [meaning anomalous, for Au$otugila is not mentioned by F]. (K.)
$ugulN * : see $ugolN.

$agolapN *
Reaped grain or wheat, collected together, in the place where it is trodden out; syn. bayodarN and kudosN (IAar, O, K) and EaramapN; (IAar, O;) as also ↓ $agalapN: (IAth, TA:) pl. [or coll. gen. n.] of the former ↓ $agolN, (O, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, $ugalN,]) like as tamorN is of tamorapN. (O, TA.)
$agalapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
$ag~aAlN * signifies kaviyru Al$~ugoli [i. e. Having much business or occupation or employment; or who busies or occupies or employs himself much]. (TA.)

$aAgilN * act. part. n. of $agalahu; [Busying, occupying, or employing; &c.;] (S, Msb;) applied to a man, (S,) or to an affair. (Msb.) [Hence,] one says, Eanoka Al$~awaAgilu ↓ $agalatoniY [Busying affairs busied me, or have busied me, so as to divert me from thee]: the last word being pl. of $aAgilN. (TA.) $ugolN $aAgilN [lit. Busying business, or the like,] has an intensive meaning: (K:) the latter word in this case is a corroborative, as in layolN laAy^ilN. (S.)

A^a$ogalu * [More, and most, busy &c.]. A^a$ogalu mino *aAti Aln~iHoyayoni [More busy than she who was the owner of the two skins of butter] is a prov. [mentioned in the TA]: she was a woman of [the tribe of] Teym-Allah: she used to sell clarified butter, in the Time of Ignorance; and Khowwát Ibn-Jubeyr El-Ansáree came to her, demanding to buy clarified butter of her, and saw no one with her, and he bargained with her: so she untied a skin, and he looked at it: then he said to her, “ Hold thou it until I look at another: ” and she said, “ Untie thou another skin: ” and he did so, and looked at it, and said, “ I desire other than this; therefore hold thou it: ” and she did so: and when her hands were [thus] occupied, he assaulted her, and she was unable to repel the him. (Meyd.)

A^u$oguwlapN * an instance of the measure A^ufoEuwlapN from Al$~ugolu [similar to A^ulohuw~apN and A^ulohiy~apN, and to A^uloEuwbapN, &c.; app. meaning A thing with which one is busied, &c.: and also syn. with $ugolN]. (O, K.)

ma$ogalapN *
A thing that causes one to be busied, &c.: (K, * TA:) pl. ma$aAgilu. (TA.)

ma$oguwlN * : see $agilN. ― -b2- [Hence,] fulaAnN faArigN ma$oguwlN Such a one is devoted to that which is unprofitable. (TA.) ― -b3- And jaAriyapN ma$oguwlapN A young woman having a husband. (TA.) ― -b4- And maAlN ma$oguwlN Property devoted to commerce. (TA.) ― -b5- And daArN ma$oguwlapN A house in which are inhabitants. (TA.)
mu$otagilN * and mu$otagalN: see $agilN.

div2.head: $gw and $gY
div2.entryFree:
1 $agiYa * , aor.
1a2a3a , inf. n. $agFA, [signifies accord. to some] He (a man) had a tooth, or teeth, exceeding the other teeth: and [accord. to others, agreeably with what is said to be the right meaning of $aAgiyap below,] he had a tooth, or teeth, differing in the manner of growth from the other teeth. (S.) [And] $agiyati Als~in~u, aor.
1a2a3a ; (Msb, K;) and $agat, aor.
1a2u3a ; (K;) inf. n. (of the former, Msb, TA) $agFA (Msb, K, TA) and [of the latter] $uguw~N, (K, TA, [in the CK $agow, but]) like Euluw~N; (TA;) [accord. to some] The tooth exceeded the other teeth: (Msb:) and [accord. to others] (Msb) the tooth differed from the other teeth (Msb, K, TA) in an absolute sense, (TA,) or in respect of its place of growth, (Msb,) or in its manner of growth, in length, and shortness, and receding, and projecting: (K, TA:) or, accord. to the A, $agFA signifies the differing in respect of the manner of growth and of collocation: or the upper teeth's not falling upon the lower: (TA:) or, as IF says, the advancing of the upper teeth beyond the lower. (Msb.) The epithet applied to a man is ↓ A^a$ogaY; and to a woman, $agowaA='u; and the pl. is $ugowN: (S, Msb:) [and] the epithet applied to a tooth is $agowaA='u and $agiyaA='u; (K;) or ↓ $aAgiyapN; (S, Msb;) which last is said by Az to have two meanings; one whereof is exceeding [the other teeth]; and the other, being longer and larger, and differing in respect of the place [or more probably the manner] of its growth from those next to it: (Msb:) or, accord. to a marginal note in the S, in the handwriting of Aboo-Zekereeyà, this signifies differing in the manner of its growth from the manner of growth of the others, whether exceeding or not exceeding: or, accord. to a marginal note in the copy of Aboo-Sahl El-Harawee, crooked; not exceeding. (TA.)

2 ta$ogiyapN * signifies The dribbling of the urine, (Lth, K, TA,) little by little. (Lth, TA.) One says of a man, $ag~aY, (TK,) and bibawolihi ↓ A$gY, (IAth, TA,) He dribbled his urine, (IAth, TA, TK,) little by little. (IAth, TA.)

4 A^a$ogawoA bihi * (assumed tropical:) They disagreed with, differed from, or opposed, the people, in respect of his affair, or case: (K:) as though taken from $agaA AlA^asonaAni. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 2.
$agFA * inf. n. of $agiYa said of a man, (S,) or of $agiyat said of a tooth. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- Also a subst. signifying A dribbling of the urine; and so ↓ $agoyapN. (K.)
A^um~u $agowap * : see $agowaA='u, voce A^a$ogaY.
$agoyapN * : see $agFA.
$aAgiyap * : see 1, last sentence.

A^a$ogaY * ; fem. $agowaA='u and $agoyaA='u; and pl. $ugowN: see 1, last sentence. ― -b2- $agowaA='u also signifies An eagle; (S, Msb, K;) because its upper mandible exceeds the lower: (S, Msb:) and so ↓ A^um~u $agowap. (T in art. Am.)

mu$otagK * One who separates himself from every yoke-fellow, or familiar: ― -b2- and one whose age (sin~uhu) is deficient: ― -b3- in both of these senses expl. as an epithet applied by Ru-beh to a rubaAEiY~ [or boy four spans in height]. (TA.)

1 $af~a * , aor.
$afi3a , inf. n. $ufuwfN (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and $afiyfN (S, O, K) and $afafN, (CK, [but not in my MS. copy of the K nor in the TA,]) It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) was thin, fine, or delicate, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) so that what was behind it was visible, (S, * IB, Mgh, [for xalaqahu in some copies of the S, and xalofahu in others, I read maA xalofahu, which is the right reading accord. to IB and the TA, agreeably with the reading in the Mgh, which is maA waraA='ahu,]) or so as to tell what was beneath it: (O, K:) [and it, (a gem, or the like,) was translucent: or was transparent. (See $af~aAfN.)] One says, $af~a Ealayohi vawobuhu His garment was thin, &c., upon him. (S.) ― -b2- ― -b3- And $af~a jisomuhu, aor.
$afi3a , inf. n. $ufuwfN, His body became lean, or emaciated. (S, O, K.) -A2- $af~a, aor.
$afi3a , inf. n. $if~N, It (a thing, O, Msb) exceeded; or was, or became, redundant. (S, O, Msb, K.) Hence, in a trad., $af~a naHowFA mino daAniqK It exceeded by about a dAnq. (Sh, O.) And one says, $af~a Ealayoh, aor. ya$uf~u, [so in the L and TA, contr. to rule, probably a mistranscription for ya$if~u,] inf. n. $ufuwfN; and ↓ $f~f, and ↓ Ast$f~; [app. meaning, as seems to be indicated by the context, It exceeded it:] and $afifotu fiY Als~iloEapi [app. a mistranscription for $afafotu] I gained in, or upon, the the article of merchandise: (TA: [and so, app., ↓ $af~afotu: see $af~aY:]) and fY tijaAratihi ↓ Ast$f~ [He obtained what is termed $if~N in his traffic; i. e.] he made gain, or profit, in his traffic; syn. rabiHa. (S and K in art. rbH.) ― -b2- And sometimes (Msb) it signifies also the contr.; i. e. It fell short; or was, or became, deficient. (Msb, K.) One says, (O, Msb,) of a dirhem, (O,) h`*aA ya$if~u qaliylFA This falls short, or is deficient, a little. (O, Msb.) And $af~a Eanohu Alv~awobu, aor.
$afi3a , The garment was too short for him. (TA.) -A3- Also $af~a, (O, K,) aor.
$afi3a , (O,) It (a thing, O) was, or became, in a state of motion, commotion, or agitation. (O, K.) -A4- And $af~a laka Al$~aYo'u i. q. daAma and vabata [app. meaning The thing belonged, or pertained, to thee permanently, or constantly; or may the thing belong, &c.]. (TA.) -A5- $af~ahu, (S, M, O, K,) aor.
$afu3a , inf. n. $af~N (S, M, TA) and $ufuwfN, (M, TA,) It (anxiety) rendered him lean, or emaciated; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ $afo$afahu; (S;) both are also expl. as meaning it rendered him lean, or lank in the belly, so that he became slender: (TA:) or, accord. to the M, it (grief, and love,) pained his heart: or rendered him lean, or emaciated: or deprived him of his reason: and it is said of grief as meaning it manifested what he felt of impatience. (TA.) And $af~a Aln~ufuwsa, as used in a verse of Towbeh Ibn-El- Homeiyir, It hurt and melted the souls. (Ham p. 594.) -A6- See also 8, in two places.
2 $af~a3a see the preceding paragraph, in two places.

4 A^a$ofafotuhumo *
I preferred them, or judged them to excel. (K.) You say, A^a$ofafotu baEoDa waladiY EalaY baEoDK I preferred some of my children above some. (S. [And the like is said in the Mgh.]) And A^a$ofafotu h`*aA EalaY h`*aA I preferred this above this. (Msb.) ― -b2- And A$f~ fulaAnN Ald~irohama Such a one made the dirhem to exceed: or, made it to fall short. (TA.) -A2- A^a$af~a Ealayohi [if not a mistranscription for A^u$if~a, which I rather think it to be,] He excelled him, or surpassed him. (TA.) -A3- A^a$af~a Alfamu The mouth had in it a fetid odour. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA.)

6 ta$aAfafotuhu *
I took away his or its, $if~, i. e. excess, or redundance. (O, K.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph, in three places.

8 A$tf~ maA fiY AlA_inaA='i * (S, O, K) kul~ahu (K) He drank what was in the vessel, all of it, (S, O, K,) even the $ufaAfap [or last drop or remains], (O,) not leaving any of it remaining; (S;) [and so Aijotaf~a;] as also ↓ t$Af~: (S, O, K:) and ↓ Ast$f~ AlmaA='a He drank the water to the uttermost, not leaving any of it remaining; as also ↓ $af~ahu, aor.
$afu3a , inf. n. $af~N: and AlmaA='a ↓ $afafotu I drank much of the water without having my thirst satisfied. (TA.) [Hence,] in the trad. of Umm-Zara, waA_ino $ariba A@$otaf~a [And if he drank, he drank up all that was in the vessel]. (S, O.) And it is said in a prov., ↓ layosa Alr~iY~u Eani Alt~a$aAf~i (S, O, TA) i. e. The satisfying of thirst is not from the drinking up all that is in the vessel; for it is sometimes effected by less than this: (O, TA:) it is applied in forbidding one's going to the utmost in an affair, and persevering therein. (S, * O, TA.) Accord. to IAar, one says also ta$aAfayotu AlmaA='a I exhausted the water; which, ISd says, is originally ↓ ta$aAfaftu. (TA.) ― -b2- 'Abd-Allah Ibn-Sebreh El-Harashee uses the first of these verbs metaphorically in relation to death; saying,
saAqayotuhu Almawota Hat~aY A@$otaf~a A=xirahu
meaning (tropical:) [I vied with him in giving the draught of death] until he drank the last of it, i. e., the last of death. (TA.) ― -b3- And A$tf~ AlbaEiyru AlHizaAma kul~ahu means The camel filled, and took up wholly, the girth, (O, K, TA,) so that nothing remained of it redundant, by reason of the largeness of the middle of his body. (TA.)

10 Ast$f~hu * , (O, K,) or Ast$f~ maA waraA='ahu, (S, Msb,) He saw what was behind it. (O, Msb, K.) [Thus the former signifies He saw through it: and it is used in this sense both properly and tropically.] ― -b2- Hence the saying to the seller of cloths, Aisota$if~a h`*aA Alv~awoba, [which may be rendered Look thou through this garment, or piece of cloth; but is expl. as] meaning make thou this garment, or piece of cloth, single, [by unfolding it,] and raise it, or hold it up, in shade, in order that I may see whether it be close in texture or flimsy. (TA.) ― -b3- Ast$f~ also signifies [agreeably with the explanation of Ast$f~ maA waraA='ahu mentioned above] (assumed tropical:) He distinguished a thing plainly, like as one distinguishes plainly a thing behind glass. (Har p. 244.) ― -b4- And one says, katabotu kitaAbFA faA@sota$af~ahu, meaning (assumed tropical:) [I wrote a letter, or writing, &c., and] he examined attentively what was in it. (TA.) -A2- See also 8. -A3- And see 1, in two places. -A4- [Freytag mentions as a signification of Ast$f~ “ Desiderio alicujus rei implevit; ” with AlY before the object: but he names no authority for this; and I doubt its correctness.]

R. Q. 1 $afo$afahu * : see 1, latter part. ― -b2- Also, accord. to IAar, (O, TA,) inf. n. $afo$afapN, (K, TA,) It (heat, and cold,) dried it up; namely, a thing, (O, K, TA,) such as herbage, (O, TA,) &c. (TA.) And accord. to AA, Al$~afo$afapu signifies The hoar-frost's burning [meaning blasting] the herbage of the earth: or the burning of a medicament that is sprinkled upon a wound: (O:) or it has the former of these two meanings, and signifies also the sprinkling of a medicament upon a wound. (K. [But I think that, for wa*ar~u Ald~awaA='i in the K, we should read wa*ar~i Ald~awaA='i, and thus reconcile the K in this case with the O: see, however, what next follows; which may be regarded either as confirming the reading in the K, or as having misled its author, in this instance.]) -A2- Al$~afo$afapu signifies also The sprinkling of urine and the like. (K.) You say, $afo$afa bibawolihi He sprinkled his urine. (O.) -A3- Also The trembling, and the being confused (AlAixotilaATu), (O, K, TA,) resulting from intense jealousy. (TA. [See mu$afo$afN.]) ― -b2- And $afo$afa Ealayohi He was solicitously affectionate, or pitiful or compassionate, towards him, (TA.) [See, again, mu$afo$afN.])
R. Q. 2 ta$afo$afa * , said of herbage, It began to dry up. (TA.)

$af~N * A thin, fine, or delicate, garment or piece of cloth; (AZ, S, Mgh, O, * Msb, K; *) as also ↓ $if~N (AZ, S, O, Msb, K) and ↓ $afiyfN: (Msb:) you say vawobN $af~N (S, Mgh, Msb) and ↓ $if~N (S, Msb) and ↓ $afiyfN. (Msb:) [see also $af~aAfN:] and the garment, or piece of cloth, itself, is termed $af~N and ↓ $if~N: (Har p. 70:) [i. e. each of these words is also used as a subst.; and this is perhaps meant in the O and K: or] $af~N signifies also a certain thin, fine, or delicate, veil or covering: or, accord. to Aboo-Nasr, a certain thin, fine, or delicate, veil or covering, of wool, through which one sees what is behind it: (S:) pl. $ufuwfN. (O, Msb, K.) Among the verses of “ the Book ” [of Sb, cited as exs. therein], is the following:
lalobosu EabaA='apK wataqar~u EayoniY
A^aHab~u A_ilaY~a mino lubosi Al$~ufuwfi
[Verily the wearing of a woollen cloak, my eye being therewithal unheated by tears, is more pleasing to me than the wearing of thin, fine, or delicate, garments]. (O.) -A2- See also $if~N. -A3- $f~ [app. $af~N] also signifies Pimples, or small pustules, that come forth and then go away. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA.)

$if~N * : see $af~N, in three places. -A2- Also, (S, Mgh, O, K,) and ↓ $af~N, (L, K,) but the former is that which is well known, (L, TA,) and ↓ $afiyfN, (TA,) Gain, or profit; increase obtained in traffic: and excess, surplus, or redundance: syn. riboHN [q. v.] : and faDolN; (S, Mgh, O, K;) and ziyaAdapN. (Mgh, TA.) Hence (Mgh) nahaY Eano $if~i maA lam yuDomano, meaning [He (the Prophet, TA) forbade] the riboH [i. e. gain, or profit, of that for which one has not made himself responsible to the purchaser]. (O, Mgh.) And one says, lih`*aA EalaY h`*aA $if~q [There is, or pertains, to this, an excess above this]. (Ksh in ii. 15.) And qaAla qawolFA $if~FA He said a saying that was a redundance. (TA.) ― -b2- And A deficiency: thus having two contr. meanings. (ISk and S and O in explanation of the first word, K in explanation of the first and second words, and TA in explanation of all.) ― -b3- Also, the first word, i. q. mahonaA^N: one says to a person when regarding him with a wish for the like of a thing that he has attained, or that he possesses, without desiring that it should pass away from him, $if~N laka yaA fulaAnu [May it be an unalloyed gratification to thee, O such a one]. (TA.) ― -b4- And A thing that is little, or small, in quantity; mean, or paltry. (TA.) [See also $afiyfN, last signification.]

$afafN * : see $afiyfN, last signification. -A2- Also i. q. xif~apN [Lightness, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- And sometimes it signifies Evilness, or narrowness of the circumstances, (riq~ap,) of one's state, or condition. (TA.)
$ufaAfN * : see $ufaAfapN.

$afiyfN * : see $af~N, in two places: -A2- and see $if~N. -A3- Also Cold, as a subst.; (ISk, S, O, Msb;) thus in the saying, wajada fiY A^asonaAnihi $afiyfFA [He felt, or experienced, in his teeth, cold]; (S, O;) and so ↓ $af~aAnN: (ISk, Msb:) or, as some say, (O,) the hurting, or paining, (la*oE, [in the CK ladog,] of cold: (S, O, K:) and intense cold, with rain and wind; and $ifaAfN is its pl.: (TA:) or intense cold [alone]: (Msb:) or a cold wind in which is moisture: (O:) and ↓ $af~aAnN signifies the cold of a wind in which is moisture: (S:) or $afiyfN has this last signification; and ↓ $af~aAnN, the signification next preceding it: one says, lahaA ↓ A^alojaA^ahu $af~aAnN $afiyfN A cold and moist wind, having [much] cold and moisture, made him to betake himself to a covert: (IDrd, IF, Msb:) or $afiyfN signifies rain and hail: (O:) or so ↓ $af~aAnN; [or rain and cold: for brd is written in my original without any syll. sign;] wherefore some of the lawyers say that it is rain and more: (Msb:) or $afiyfN signifies also rain in which is hail: (K, TA:) or rain in which is cold: (CK:) or a cold wind; (K;) as also ↓ $afo$aAfN: (O, K:) or this last signifies a wind of mild cold: (S, TA:) and ↓ $af~aAnN, cold and wind: (O, K:) one says, gadaApN *aAtu $af~aAnK a morning having cold and wind (S, * O, K) with moisture. (S.) ― -b2- And Intense heat (IDrd, EsSarakustee, O, Msb, K) of the sun: (IDrd, O, K:) thus having two contr. significations. (K.) ― -b3- And Pain in the stomach. (Aboo-Sa'eed, O.) -A4- [Also Affected with pain: or with hurt, or grief. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)] -A5- Also Small, or little, in number, quantity, or amount; and so ↓ $afafN. (O, K.) [See also $if~N, last signification.]

$ufaAfapN *
A portion of water remaining in a vessel; (S, O, K;) and likewise, of milk: (TA:) or the last drop remaining in a vessel: (Ham p. 239:) IAth says that some of the later writers mention it as being with s. (TA.) Dhu-rRummeh uses the phrase Al$~afaA ↓ $ufaAfa, in a verse, as meaning In the remaining portion of the day. (O.)

$af~aAfN *
Extremely [or very] thin or fine or delicate, so that a thing behind it is visible: (KL:) [translucent:] transparent: applied to a gem, or the like; and to a garment, or piece of cloth. (TA.) [See also $af~N.]
$af~aAnN * : see $afiyfN, in six places.
$afo$aAfN * A garment, or piece of cloth, not well or strongly or compactly [woven or] made. (O, K.) -A2- See also $afiyfN.

$afaA$ifu *
Vehement thirst. (O, K.)

A^a$af~u * [a noun denoting excess]. It is said in a trad. of Ráfi', fakaAna AlxaloxaAlu A^a$af~a minohaA qaliylFA, meaning [And the anklet, or pair of anklets, was] more than they [in value or weight]; (syn. A^afoDal and A^azoyad;) i. e. more [in value or weight] than the dirhems. (Mgh.) And one says, fulaAnN A^a$af~u mino fulaAnK, meaning Such a one is a little greater, or older, (A^akobaru qaliylFA,) than such a one. (TA.)

ma$ofuwfN * is said by Ibn-Buzurj to be like majofuwfN
[part. n. of jaf~ahu; i. e. Collected; or collected together and taken away]. (TA.)

mu$afo$afN * (O, K) and ↓ mu$afo$ifN, (K,) the latter on the authority of IAar, (TA,) Slender, shallow, or weak, in intellect, and evil in disposition. (O, K.) And [both words agreeably with different explanations of the verb] One in whom is, (K,) or, accord. to Saad, one who is as though there were in him, (O,) a trembling, and confusion, (O, K,) resulting from jealousy, (K,) or from vehement jealousy, (O,) and solicitous affection, or pity or compassion, for his Huram [or wives, or women under covert, and household, (in the CK his Haram,)] as though jealousy wasted his heart, and made him lank and lean: or evil in disposition, and very jealous: and ↓ the latter word, solicitously affectionate; or pitying, or compassionating. (TA.)
mu$afo$ifN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

1 $afVra The primary signification of [the inf. n.] $fr [i. e. $aforN, of which the verb is app. $afara,] is The act of cutting, or cutting off; syn. qaToEN. (Ham p. 57.) -A2- $afarahaA, (K,) inf. n. $aforN, (TA,) He struck her (a woman's) $ufor (K, TA) in compressing her. (TA.) ― -b2- And $afara [or app. $afara A_inosaAnFA] He annoyed, molested, harmed, or hurt, a man. (IAar, O, TA.) -A3- $afirato, aor.
$afara , inf. n. $afaArapN, She (a woman) was one whose gratification of her venereal lust ($ahowatuhaA) soon took place: (K:) or she emitted; [or, app., emitted soon;] syn. A^anozalato. (TA.) -A4- And $afira, aor.
$afara , It decreased, diminished, or became defective or deficient. (IAar, K.)

2 $f~rhA * , (K,) inf. n. ta$ofiyrN, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) He compressed her (i. e. a woman, Ibn-'Abbád, O) on the $ufor of her faroj. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b2- And $af~arotu Al$~aYo'a, inf. n. as above, I eradicated, or extirpated, the thing. (TA.) -A2- $f~r AlmaAlu, (O, K,) inf. n. as above, (K,) The property became little: (O, K:) and went away: (K:) from IAar. (TA.) ― -b2- And $f~r said of a man, He gave little. (Ham p. 242.) ― -b3- And $f~rt Al$~amosu (O, K) liloguruwbi (O) (assumed tropical:) The sun became near to setting; (O, K;) being likened to a man whose property has become little, and gone away. (TA.) ― -b4- And in like manner, (TA,) $f~r EalaY A^amorK (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K) and liA^amorK, (Ibn-'Abbád, O,) said of a man, (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, on the brink, or verge, of the affair, or event, or case. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)
4 A$fr * is said in the Tekmileh to signify He (a camel) strove, or exerted himself, in running: but perhaps it should be A$gr, mentioned before [in art. $gr]. (TA.)
$aforN * : see the next paragraph, in four places.

$uforN * The place of growth of the eyelash, (Sh, T, S, A, Msb, K,) which is the edge of the eyelid; (S, Msb;) as also ↓ $aforN (Kr, A, K) and ↓ $afiyrN: (K:) or, accord. to some, this last signifies the upper side of the inner angle of the eye: (TA:) and with the vulgar, the first signifies the eyelash; but this is [said to be] a mistake: (IKt, Msb:) it occurs, however, in this sense, in a trad. of Esh-Shaabee; (IAth, TA;) and in like manner the pl. occurs in another trad.; but the word $aEar should be considered as understood before it; or what grows is thus called by the name of the places of growth, and the like of this is not rare: (Mgh:) it is of the masc. gender: (Lh, K:) and the pl. is A^a$ofaArN, (Sb, S, Mgh, Msb,) the only pl. form. (Sb, TA.) [Hence,] one says, ↓ maA biAld~aAri $aforN, (Ks, Fr, T, S, Msb, K,) and $uforN, (Lh, Msb, K,) but Sh disallows this latter, (TA,) and ↓ $aforapN, (Fr, Sgh, K,) (tropical:) There is not in the house any one: (S, Msb, K, &c.:) and maA raA^ayotu ↓ minohumo $aforFA (tropical:) I saw not of them any one: from the $fr of the eye: meaning one having a $fr: (A:) and $fr is also used in this sense without a negation. (TA.) One says likewise, maA tarakati Als~anapu ZuforFA walaA $uforFA (tropical:) The year of drought left not anything: and sometimes they said ↓ $aforFA, with fet-h, and in this case they said ZaforFA, for assimilation. (A.) ― -b2- Also, (S A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and ↓ $afiyrN, (S, A, Msb, K,) The edge, border, margin, brink, brow, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or side, (A, K,) of anything; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) as of a valley and the like, (S,) or as of a river &c.: (Mgh and Msb, in relation to the latter word:) one says, Aln~ahori ↓ qaEaduwA EalaY $afiyri, and Albiy^ori, and Alqabori, They sat upon the side of the river, and of the well, and of the grave: (A:) and both words signify the side of the upper part of a valley. (K.) ― -b3- And Al$~uforu, (K,) or $uforu Alfaroji, (Msb,) and $uforu AlmaroA^api, (TA,) The edge, (Msb, K,) or border, (TA,) of the vulva, or external portion of the organs of generation, [meaning, of each of the labia majora,] of a woman: (Msb, K, TA:) pl. A^a$ofaArN: (Msb:) the A_isokataAni are the two sides [or labia majora] of the vulva of a woman; and the $uforaAni are the two borders of the said AsktAn: (AHeyth, Mgh, TA:) Lth says that the ↓ $aAfiraAni are [two parts] of the pudendum muliebre: (TA:) and $uforu Alr~aHimi and ↓ $aAfiruhaA signify [in like manner] the edges of the vulva: (S:) and $uforaA AlmaroA^api and ↓ $aAfiraAhaA, the two edges of the raHim [or vulva (for Alr~aHim is here used tropically, for Alfaroj, as it is in many other instances,)] of a woman. (TA.)
$iforN * : see $aforapN, first sentence.
$afarN * : see safanN, first sentence.

$afirN * [an epithet of which the fem. only is mentioned]. $afirapN and ↓ $afiyrapN signify A woman who experiences the gratification of her venereal lust ($ahowatahaA) in her $ufor; so that she emits (tunozilu) speedily: or [in the CK “ and ”] who is content with the least of coitus: (K, TA:) contr. of qaEirapN and qaEiyrapN. (TA.)

$aforapN *
A large knife; (S, A, K;) as also ↓ $iforapN, though this is mentioned only by the author of the Mgh; (MF; [but it is not in my copy of the Mgh; and Golius mentions ↓ $uforapN as having this signification, on the authority of Meyd;]) or a broad knife: (Mgh, Msb:) pl. $ifaArN (Msb, K) and $afaraAtN (Msb) and [coll. gen. n., of which $iforapN is the n. un., or it may be a quasi-pl. n. of $aforapN,] ↓ $iforN. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (Mgh, TA,) (tropical:) A servant; (S, Mgh, TA;) because of his utility. (TA.) It is said in a prov., A^aSogaru Alqawomi $aforatuhumo (tropical:) The least of the party is their servant. (S, Mgh.) ― -b3- Also A shoemaker's knife. (S, K.) ― -b4- And A piece of iron made broad, and edged, or pointed. (K.) ― -b5- A broad blade: so says the author of the Mgh. (TA. [But not in my copy of the Mgh.]) ― -b6- The edge, or cutting part, (Had~,) of a sword: (S, Mgh, K:) or the edge of the cutting part of a sword. (TA. [See *ubaAbN.]) The side of a blade: (K:) or each of the two sides thereof. (AHn, TA.) [Each of the two sharp sides or edges of a spear-head and of an arrow-head.] ― -b7- See also $uforN, second sentence.
$uforapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
$iforapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

[
$afuwrN *
i. q. zunobuwrN The hornet, or hornets. (Golius, on the authority of Meyd.)]
$afiyrN * : see $uforN, in three places. ― -b2- Also The edge of the lip of a camel. (K.) -A2- $afiyrapN: see $afirapN, voce $afirN.

yarobuwEN $ufaAriY~N *
A jerboa having hair upon its ears: (S:) or having large ears: or having long ears, and bare toes, [in the CK, for AlEaAriY AlbaraAvini, which is evidently the right reading, we find AlEAlY AlbrAvn,] not quickly overtaken: (K:) it is [of] a species of jerboa called DaA^onu AlyaraAbiyEi, the fattest and the best, with ears somewhat long: (TA:) or having long legs, and soft and fat flesh: (K:) it is said that it has a nail in the middle of its shank. (TA. [See tadomuriY~N.]) ― -b2- Dab~N $ufaAriY~N A long and bulky [lizard of the kind called] Db~. (Ham p. 242.) ― -b3- A^u*unN $ufaAriy~apN (as also $uraAfiy~apN [q. v.], TA) A large ear: (K:) or a bulky ear: (A'Obeyd, TA:) or a long ear: (AZ, TA:) or a broad ear, soft in the upper part: (TA:) or an ear having much hair and fur. (Ham p. 242.)
$af~aArN * The possessor of a $aforap [or large knife]. (A, * TA.)
$aAfirN * , and its dual: see $uforN, last sentence, in three places. -A2- Also One who destroys, or makes away with, his property: so in the Tekmileh. (TA.)
ma$ofarN * : see what next follows.

mi$ofarN * The lip of a camel; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also ↓ ma$ofarN: (K:) and (tropical:) of a horse: (S, TA:) and (tropical:) of a human being: (K, TA:) or (tropical:) of an Abyssinian, as being likened to that of a camel: (A'Obeyd, TA:) pl. ma$aAfiru. (S, K.) It is said in
a prov., A^araAka ba$arN maA A^aHaAra mi$ofarN [lit. External skin hath shown thee what a lip hath transmitted to the stomach;] meaning, the external appearance hath rendered thee in no need of inquiring respecting the internal state: (S, K:) originally said of a camel; (TA;) for when you see his external skin, whether he be fat or lean, you take it as an indication of the quality of his food. (K, TA.) ― -b2- Also The vulva, or external portion of the organs of generation, of a woman: (R, MF:) but this is strange. (TA.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) A piece of land: and of sand: (K, TA:) each by way of comparison [to the lip of a camel]. (TA.) -A2- Also A state of resistance; inaccessibleness, or unapproachableness: (K:) strength, or power; (K, * TA;) vehemence, or hardness, or firmness. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And A state of perdition or destruction: and thus it is expl. as used in the saying mentioned by Meyd [in his Proverbs, perhaps the origin of this explanation], tarakotuhu EalaY mivoli mi$ofari AlA^asadi [which may be rendered I left him at the like of the lip of the lion]; (TA;) applied to him who is exposed to destruction. (Meyd, TA. *)

Eayo$N mu$afirN *
Strait, scanty, subsistence. (O, K.)

$ufaArijN *
A tray (TabaqN) on which are small saucers, or cups, fayoxaAt and sukur~ajaAt: (O, K:) a Pers. word, (S, O,) arabicized; (S, O, K;) from biy$obaArajo or biy$obaArijo (K, TA) or biy$aArajo; (as in some copies of the K;) or what people call biy$obaAriajo: (Yaakoob, S:) [i. e. Piy$o PaAro or Piy$o PaAraho, “ pésh pár, ” and “ pésh párah, ” meaning “ sweetmeats presented to a guest: ”] accord. to ElJawáleekee, it signifies different kinds of flesh-meat in TbAyx: [but what this means I know not: I suppose it to be a corruption of some word signifying saucers or the like:] in the “ Kitáb el-Moheet, ” $afaAriyju is said to be pl. of $ufaArijN, signifying a kind of food. (TA.)

1 $afaEahu * , (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
$afaEa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. $afoEN, (S, Msb,) He made it to be a $afoE; (S, K, TA;) meaning (TA) he made it (a single thing) to be a zawoj [i. e. he made it to be one of a pair or couple; and sometimes, he made it to be a pair or couple together]: (Mgh, TA:) or he adjoined it to, or coupled it with, that which was a single thing: (Msb:) accord. to Er-Rághib, Al$~afoEu signifies the adjoining a thing to its like. (TA.) You say, kaAna witorFA fa$afaEotuhu, (S,) or kaAna witorFA fa$afaEotuhu biA=xara i. e. [It was a single thing, and] I made it to be one of a pair, or couple, with another. (Mgh. [In Har p. 194, I find the phrase bA=xr ↓ kAn wtrA f$f~Eh, expl. in like manner; but $f~Eh thus used I do not find in any lexicon: it may, however, be correctly thus used; for t$f~E, which has the form, app. has also the signification, of its quasi-pass.]) [And $ufiEa Almiloku bimilokK A=xara The possession (here meaning house, or piece of land,) was coupled by purchase with another possession: and $ufiEa bihi milokN It had a possession coupled with it by purchase: see $ufoEapN.] You say also, $afaEotu Alr~akoEapa I made the rkEp to be two. (Msb.) And a poet says,
maA kaAna A^aboSaraniY bigir~aAti AlS~ibaY
faA@loyawoma qado $ufiEato liYa A@loA^a$obaAHu
[How clear was my sight with the inadvertencies of youth! but to-day, objects have become doubled to me]: i. e., I see the object [as] two objects, by reason of the weakness and dispersedness of my sight. (O, K. *) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says of a she-camel, (S, O,) and of a ewe, or she-goat, (O,) $afaEato, (S, O,) inf. n. $afoEN, (S,) meaning She became such as is termed $aAfiEN [q. v.]: (S, O:) she is thus termed liA^an~a waladahaA $afaEahaA A^awo $afaEatohu [because her young one has made her to be one of a pair, or couple, with itself, or because she has made it to be one of a pair or couple, with another that is in her belly], (S, O, K,) inf. n. $afoEN, or the inf. n. in this case is $ifoEN, with kesr. (O, K.) ― -b3- One says also, A_in~ahu laya$ofaEu EalaY~a biAlEadaAwapi, (K,) or liY, (O,) i. e. (tropical:) Verily he aids [another, becoming to him one of a pair, by enmity] against me, and acts injuriously to me [conjointly with another]. (O, K, TA.) Accord. to Er-Rághib, ya$ofaEu means He joins himself to another, and aids him, becoming to him one of a pair, or a $afiyE [i. e. an intercessor], in doing good or evil, so that he aids him, or partakes with him, in [procuring] the benefit or the harm thereof; and thus it means in the saying in the Kur [iv. 87], mano ya$ofaEo $afaAEapF HasanapF [and in what follows the same]: (TA:) or these words mean Whoso adds a [good] deed to a [good] deed: (O, K:) or, as some say, the $fAEp here is a man's instituting, or prescribing, to another, a way of good or evil, so that he [the latter] imitates him, and thus becomes as though he were to him one of a pair. (TA.) [But accord. to the expositors in general, and accord. to the general usage of the inf. n. $afaAEapN as distinguished from $afoEN, what is here meant is Intercession.] ― -b4- [Hence also,] $afaEa lahu A_ilaY fulaAnK, (S, * K, * TA,) or AlY AlA^amiyri, (MA,) aor.
$afaEa , (K, TA,) inf. n. $afaAEapN; (MA, K, TA;) and lahu ↓ t$f~E, (MA,) or fiyhi ↓ t$f~E; (S, TA;) He made petition, or intercession, for him [to such a one, or to the prince or the like; thus adjoining himself to him as an aider]: (MA, TA:) and $afaEa bayona Aln~aAsi [He interceded between the people], inf. n. $afaAEapN: (Jel in iv. 87:) and $afaEotu fiY AlA^amori, (Msb,) inf. n. $afaAEapN (IKtt, Msb, TA) and $afoEN, (Msb, [but the latter is scarcely to be found elsewhere thus used,]) I pleaded, [or interceded,] in the affair, or case, [in favour of another,] for some means of access or ingratiation, or some right or due: (IKtt, * Msb, TA: *) $afaAEapN is mentioned, but not explained, in the K: (TA:) as distinguished from $afoEN meaning as expl. above, it signifies the joining oneself to another as an aider to him or a petitioner respecting him [or for him]; and in most instances the former person is one of higher station than the latter: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or the speaking of the $afiyE [or intercessor] to the king [or some other person] respecting some object of want which the speaker asks for another person: it is also expl. as signifying the passing over without punishment, or the forgiving, [or rather the asking, or requesting, the passing over &c., (for the word Talabu, probably accidentally omitted by the transcriber at the commencement of the explanation, should doubtless be supplied,)] of sins, crimes, or misdeeds. (TA.) Hence, in a trad., ↓ Ai$ofaEo tu$af~aEo [Intercede thou: thou shalt have thine intercession accepted]. (TA.) The saying in the Kur [ii. 117], walaA tanofaEuhaA $afaAEapN [Nor shall intercession profit it] means that it shall have no $aAfiE [or intercessor] for his $afaAEap [or intercession] to profit it; being a denial of the $aAfiE; (Ibn- 'Arafeh, O, K;) and the same is the case in the Kur lxxiv. 49, (Ibn-'Arafeh, O, TA,) and xx. 108. (TA.) $afaEa, inf. n. $afoEN and $afaAEapN, also signifies He prayed, or supplicated: and thus Mbr and Th explain the words of the Kur [ii. 256], mano *aA A@l~a*iY ya$ofaEu Einodahu A_il~aA biA_i*onihi [Who is he that shall pray, or supplicate, in his presence, except by his permission?]. (TA.) ― -b5- Accord. to El-Kutabee, (Mgh,) [i. e.] El-Kuteybee, (TA,) one says also, of a neighbour of one who desires to sell a dwelling [or land] $afaEa A_ilayohi fiY maA baAEa, meaning He made a demand to him, i. e. to the latter, respecting that which he sold [for the right of pre-emption]: and of the latter person, ↓ fa$af~aEahu [and he admitted his right of pre-emption, i. e.] and he pronounced him to have a better right, or title, or claim, [as a purchaser,] to that which was sold, that he whose connexion was more remote. (Mgh, TA. *) -A2- $afaEa, inf. n. $afoEN, signifies also He, or it, was, or became, tall, or high. (TA.) -A3- And $ufiEa, like EuniYa, He (a man) was smitten by the [evil] eye. (IKtt, TA. [But see $ufoEapN, last sentence.])

2 $af~aEa see 1, near the beginning. ― -b2- $af~aEotuhu fiyhi, inf. n. ta$ofiyEN, I accepted his intercession ($afaAEatahu) [for him]. (S, * O, K.) See, again, 1, in the last quarter of the paragraph. ― -b3- And see another signification of the verb in a later part of the same paragraph.

5 t$f~E * [signifies It was made a pair or couple, accord. to the K voce witorN; this word being there expl. as meaning maA lamo yata$af~aEo mina AlEadadi: but in the M and A, in the same place, instead of yata$af~aEo, we find yu$ofaEo]. ― -b2- t$f~E lahu, and fiyhi: see 1, near the middle of the paragraph. ― -b3- [It is said in the TA that ta$af~aEahu also is quasi-pass. of Aisota$ofaEa bihi: but ta$af~aEahu is evidently, here, a mistranscription, app. for ta$af~aEa, meaning He was granted intercession.] -A2- Also He became a $aAfiEiY~ [i. e. a follower of the Imám Esh-Sháfi'ee] in persuasion: but this is post-classical. (TA.)

10 Aisota$ofaEotuhu A_ilaY fulaAnK *
I asked him to make intercession for me (A^ano ya$ofaEa liY) to such a one. (S, O, K. *) And Aisota$ofaEotu bihi I sought, or demanded, intercession (Al$~afaAEapa) [by means of him]. (Msb.) A poet, cited by Aboo-Leylà, says,
zaEamato maEaA$iru A^an~aniY musota$ofiEN
lam~aA xarajotu A^azuwruhu A^aqolaAmahaA
i. e. Companies of men asserted me to be seeking intercession (zaEamuwA A^aniY A^asota$ofiEu) for the object of eulogy, [when I went forth repairing to visit him,] by means of their writing-reeds (biA^aqolaAmihimo), meaning by their letters (bikutubihimo). (O, TA.)

$afoEN *
contr. of witorN; (S, Mgh, O, K;) i. q. zawojN [i. e., like zawojN, it signifies One of a pair or couple; and sometimes, but rarely, a pair or couple together; and sometimes, (see for instance zakaA) an even number, a number that may be divided into two equal numbers]: (O, K:) also one with which another is made to be a pair or couple: (TA:) [and, as will be seen in what follows, one with which an odd number is made to be an even number:] pl. $ifaAEN, (TA,) and app. A^a$ofaAEN, whence AlS~alaApu bayona AlA^a$ofaAEi, meaning Alt~araAwiyH [q. v. voce tarowiyHapN]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Al$~afoEu also signifies The day of the sacrifice; (O, K;) thus in the words of the Kur [lxxxix. 2] waA@l$~afoEi waA@lowitori; by Alwtr being meant the day of 'Arafát: (O:) or in this instance it means the creatures of God, (O, K,) because of the saying in the Kur [li. 49], “ and of everything we have created two of a pair; ” (K;) Alwtr meaning God: (O, K:) or Adam's wife; Alwtr meaning Adam, who was made a pair with her: (I'Ab, O, TA:) or Adam's children: (TA:) or the two days after the sacrifice; Alwtr meaning the third day: (O, TA:) or God; [and Alwtr, those who compose an odd number;] because of the saying in the Kur [lviii. 8], “ there can be no secret discourse of three, but He is the maker of them, with Himself, to be four: ” (K:) or the meaning of Al$~afoEu waAlwitoru is the prayers; of which some are $afoE [i. e. an even number of rek'ahs], and some are witor [i. e. an odd number of rek'ahs]: (O, TA:) [for] it is said that all the numbers consist of $afoE [i. e. even] and witor [i. e. odd]. (TA.)
$afoEapN * : see the next paragraph, in two places, near the end.

$ufoEapN * is used in relation to a house and to land; (S, TA;) and ↓ $ufuEapN, with two dammehs, is a dial. var. thereof thus used. (TA.) It signifies A milok [here meaning house, or piece of land,] that is coupled (ma$ofuwE) [by purchase] with one's milok [i. e. house, or piece of land, previously possessed, and adjoining thereto]; (Mgh, Msb; *) from the phrase kaAna witorFA fa$afaEotuhu [expl. above, in the second sentence of this art.]; (Mgh; [and the like is said in the Msb;]) a noun of the same class as luqomapN; being of the measure fuEolapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (Mgh, Msb: *) this is the primary signification: then it was applied to denote a particular kind of obtaining possession; (Mgh;) [i. e.] it is also used as meaning the obtaining possession of that milok [or house, or piece of land, by purchasing it, and coupling it with that previously possessed, and adjoining thereto]; (Msb;) or one's making a demand respecting that which he seeks [to possess, for the right of the pre-emption thereof], and adjoining it to that which he [already] has: (O, K:) and with the lawyers it signifies the right of obtaining possession of a piece of land, [i. e. the right of pre-emption thereof, or of a house,] against one's co-sharer whose possession is recent, by compulsion, for a compensation: (K:) or the right of obtaining possession of a piece of land, by compulsion, for [the payment of] what it cost the [former] purchaser, by reason of partnership or of [immediate] neighbourship: (KT:) or the right of [immediate] neighbourship with respect to [pre-emption of] a house or land. (PS.) [See 1 in art. sqb.] El-Kutabee says, in explaining this word, in the Time of Ignorance, when a man desired to sell a house, his neighbour used to come to him and to make a demand to him ($afaEa A_ilayohi i. e. Talaba) respecting that which he sold [for the right of pre-emption], and he pronounced him to have a better right, or title, or claim, [as a purchaser,] to that which was sold, than he whose connexion was more remote: as though he took it from Al$~afaAEapu: but the [right] derivation is that first mentioned. (Mgh.) We have not heard, (Mgh,) or there is not known, (Msb,) any verb belonging to it [in the classical language]. (Mgh, Msb.) Esh-Shaabee uses it in the first and in the second of the senses expl. above, [or nearly so,] in his saying, mano biyEato $ufoEatuhu wahuwa HaADirN falamo yaTolubo *`lika falaA $ufoEapa lahu [i. e. He whose claimed possession to be coupled by purchase with one already belonging to him is sold when he is present without his demanding that possession, there shall be no obtaining possession for him by his purchasing it for that purpose]. (Mgh. [And the like is said in the Msb.]) Esh-Shaabee says [also], Al$~ufoEapu EalaY ruw^uwsi AlrijaAli [The possession that is coupled by purchase with another possession is apportioned according to the heads of the men entitled thereto]: i. e., when the house is shared by a company of men whose shares are different, and one of them sells his portion, what is sold to his co-sharers is to be apportioned among them equally, according to their heads, not according to their [former] shares: (O, K, TA:) so in the Nh. (TA.) ― -b2- $ufoEapu AlD~uHaY The two rek'ahs (rakoEataAni) of the [prayer that is performed in the period of the morning called the] DuHaY; as also AlDHY ↓ $afoEapu: (O, K:) occurring in a trad., thus accord. to two different relations. (O.) -A2- Also Diabolical, or demoniacal, possession; or madness, or insanity; (AA, O, K;) and so ↓ $afoEapN; the latter expl. in this sense by IAar; and as syn. with safoEapN and $unoEapN and rad~apN and naZorapN, [perceived] in the face: [see these words; the second and third of which generally mean an unseemliness or ugliness; and so, sometimes, does the last:] the pl. of $ufoEapN in the sense here expl. on the authority of AA is $ufaEN. (TA.) ― -b2- And IF states that it has been said to signify The [evil] eye, by which one is smitten: but he doubts its correctness; and thinks that it may be with the unpointed s. (O.) [See safoEapN, not sufoEapN.]
$ufuEapN * : see $ufoEapN, first sentence.
$afuwEN * A she-camel that fills two milking-vessels in one milking. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also $aAfiEN.

$afiyEN *
i. q. SaAHibu $afaAEapK; (S, K, TA;) i. e. (TA) An intercessor; as also ↓ $aAfiEN: pl. of the former $ufaEaA='u. (Msb, TA.) [See Als~uqafaA=', in art. sqf.] ― -b2- Also i. q.
