SaAHibu $ufoEapK; (S, K;) [meaning A possessor of the right termed $ufoEap; or] one who demands, and is granted, as a neighbour [or a partner], in preference to him whose connexion is more remote, the right of purchasing a house [or piece of land] that is to be sold. (TA.)

$afaAy^iEu *
Sorts of pasture, or herbage, that grow two and two: (Ibn-Abbád, O, K:) or twins (tuw^aAm [pl. of tawo'am]) of plants. (O, K.)

$aAfiEN * [act. part. n. of 1, q. v. ― -b2- Hence], applied to a she-camel, (tropical:) Having a young one in her belly and another following her: (Fr, Sh, S, Mgh, K, TA:) or applied in this sense to a ewe or she-goat: (K:) or, thus applied, having her young one with her: (A'Obeyd, S, Mgh:) thus called because her young one has made her to be one of a pair [with it], or because she has made it to be one of a pair [with her]: (A'Obeyd, S, K:) and ↓ $afuwEN, thus applied, signifies the same as $aAfiEN: and one says also, h`*ihi $aApu Al$~aAfiEi, like as one says SalaApu AlA^uwlaY and masojidu AljaAmiEi. (TA.) ― -b3- Also A he-goat, (O, K, TA,) himself: (O:) or a ram: or such as, when he impregnates, impregnates with twins. (O, K.) ― -b4- EayonN $aAfiEapN An eye [that makes a thing to appear a pair, i. e.,] that sees doubly. (O, K.) ― -b5- fulaAnN yuEaAdiyniY walahu $aAfiEN means (tropical:) Such a one treats me with enmity, and has one who aids him to do so. (A, TA.) ― -b6- See also $afiyEN and mu$af~aEN.

A^a$ofaEu *
Tall, or high. (L, TA.)

mu$ofiEN *
A ewe, or she-goat, that suckles any animal. (IAar, TA.)

mu$af~aEN * One whose intercession is accepted: hence the Kur-án is termed by Ibn-Mes'ood mu$af~aEN ↓ $aAfiEN, i. e. An intercessor of which the intercession will be accepted, for him who follows it and does according to what is in it, that his unpremeditated transgressions may be forgiven. (O, TA.)
mu$afiEN * One who accepts intercession. (L, TA.)

ma$ofuwEN * A possession (milokN [here meaning house, or piece of land,]) coupled [by purchase] with a man's possession [previously belonging to him,
upon certain conditions expl. voce $ufoEapN]. (Mgh, Msb.) -A2- Also Affected with diabolical, or demoniacal, possession; or with madness, or insanity; (O, K;) and masofuwEN, with the unpointed s, is a dial. var. thereof. (TA.) ― -b2- And ma$ofuwEapN is said to signify A woman smitten by the [evil] eye: (IF, O, L: [but see $ufoEapN, last sentence:]) the masc. is not used in this sense. (L, TA.)

1 $afiqa * and $afaqa : see 4, in five places. ― -b2- $afiqa Ealayohi signifies He was niggardly of it: (TA:) [thus] the saying [of a poet]
kamaA $afiqato EalaY Alz~aAdi AlEiyaAlu
means [Like as the household] are niggardly of the provision: (IDrd, M, O:) because he who is niggardly of a thing is Ealayohi ↓ mu$ofiqN [i. e. fearful, or cautious, on account of it]. (M.)

2 ta$ofiyqN * signifies (tropical:) The making [a gift or the like (see mu$af~aqN)] scanty, or little in amount or quantity; as also ↓ A_i$ofaAqN. (O, K, TA.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) The weaving badly. (K, TA.) You say, $f~q AlmiloHafapa (tropical:) He wove badly, (M,) or so as to make it scanty in the yarn, or unsubstantial, (TA,) the [kind of wrapper called] mlHfp. (M, TA.) -A2- See also 4, last sentence.

4 A$fq * signifies He feared, or was cautious; as also ↓ $afiqa [in the CK $afaqa]; or only the former: (K, TA:) [accord. to ISd,] ↓ $afiqa, inf. n. $afaqN, signifies he feared: (M:) IDrd says, ↓ $afiqotu [in one of my copies of the S $faqtu] and A^a$ofaqotu are syn., (S, O, TA,) as some assert, (O, TA,) but the lexicologists disallow this, (S, O,) saying that one should only say A^a$ofaqotu: (O:) accord. to Er-Rághib, AlA_i$ofaAqu signifies [the being affected with] care, or solicitude, mixed with fear; and when it is trans. by means of mino, the meaning of fear is most apparent in it; but when trans. by means of EalaY, the meaning of care, or solicitude, is most apparent in it: (TA: [and the like is said by Bd in xxi. 29:]) or it signifies [the being affected with] fright [or fear]; sometimes mixed with faithful or sincere or honest advice; and sometimes divested thereof: (Ham p. 179:) one says, A^a$ofaqotu minohu, (S,) or mino ka*aA, (Msb,) I feared, or was cautious of, (S, Msb,) him, or it, (S,) or such a thing: (Msb:) or A$fq minohu he feared him, or it: (MA:) and A^a$ofaqotu Ealayohi, (S, [in which it is implied that this differs from A^a$ofaqotu minohu,]) or EalaY AlS~agiyri, I was affectionate, kind, or compassionate, and favourably inclined, [towards him, or] towards the little one: (Msb: [and a similar explanation is given in the MA:]) and ↓ $afaqotu, aor.
$afiqa , is a dial. var. thereof [i. e. of A^a$ofaqotu when trans. by means of EalaY, and perhaps also when it is trans. by means of mino]: (Msb:) or A$fq Ealayohi signifies [he was solicitously affectionate, &c., towards him; agreeably with the explanation of Er-Rághib above, and with that here following;] he was affected with pity, or compassion, and tenderness, and fear, for him, at the same time giving him faithful or sincere or honest advice, A^ano yanaAlahu makoruwhN [lest some disliked or evil event should betide him]: (TA:) or he feared, or was cautious, for him: and A$fq minohu he was impatient of him, or it: and ↓ $afaqa is a dial. var. [of A$fq when trans. by means of mino, and app. also when trans. by means of EalaY]. (M.) -A2- See also 2. -A3- Also He entered upon [the time of] the $afaq [q. v.]. (M.) And He came in a [time of] $afaq: and so ↓ $f~q. (M.)

$afaqN *
Fear: (K:) [see also $afiqa, (of which it is the inf. n.) in the next preceding paragraph:] or fear [arising] from strictness ($id~ap) of faithful or sincere or honest advice; (M, TA;) as also ↓ $afaqapN: (M:) or ↓ the latter signifies the fear of him who gives faithful or sincere or honest advice, in consequence of his doing so, for him to whom such advice is given: (O:) or the former, (K, TA,) and ↓ the latter also, (TA,) the eagerness, or striving, of him who gives such advice, to rectify, or amend, the state of him to whom that advice is given: (K, TA: [said in the latter to be a tropical application of the words; but why, I see not:]) ↓ $afaqapN is subst. from AlA_i$ofaAqu, (S, Msb, TA,) and $afaqN is syn. therewith (S, O, K, TA) as being also a subst. from AlA_i$ofaAqu: (S, TA:) [it is said that] the primary signification of ↓ $afaqapN is weakness: (Ham p. 179:) and it is conjoined with xawofN [fear]; therefore it is not applied as an attribute to God: (Idem p. 722:) [generally] it signifies affection, kindness, benignity, compassion, or favourable inclination: (MA:) [or solicitous affection &c.:] or pity, or compassion, and tenderness, and fear of the betiding of some disliked or evil event, together with faithful or sincere or honest advice. (TA.) -A2- $afaqN also signifies The redness (Kh, S, Msb, K) in the horizon (K) from sunset until the time of the last Ei$aA=' [i. e. nightfall], (Kh, S, Msb, K,) when it disappears, (Kh, S, Msb,) and the white $afaq remains until the middle [or rather until a late period varying at different seasons] of the night: (Msb:) or until near that time: or until near the Eatamap [q. v., generally meaning the same, or nearly so]: (K:) or the redness that is seen in the sky at sunset: (IDrd, O:) or the remains of the light and redness of the sun in the first part of the night, until near the Eatamap: (S:) or the light and redness of the sun, seen at sunset, until the time of the prayer of nightfall: (M:) or the mixture of the light of day with the blackness of night at sunset: (Er-Rághib, TA:) accord. to Zj, the redness that is in the region of sunset after the setting of the sun: this is the meaning given as of common repute in the books of lexicology; and Mtr says [in the Mgh] that it means the redness accord. to a number of the Companions of the Prophet and of the people of the generation next succeeding them: but accord. to Aboo-Hureyreh, it means the whiteness [after sunset, which, to distinguish it from the $afaq commonly so called, is often termed the white $afaq, as in an instance above]: (Msb:) IAth says that this word has two contr. meanings; being applied to the redness that is seen after sunset; and to the whiteness remaining in the western horizon after the said redness. (TA.) Fr says, I heard one of the Arabs say, Ealayohi vawobN kaA^an~ahu Al$~afaqu [Upon him is, or was, a garment as though it were the $afaq]: and it was red. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) A garment, or piece of cloth, dyed red. (AA, TA.) ― -b3- And Day. (Zj, M, K.) -A3- Also i. q. naAHiyapN (assumed tropical:) [A side, &c.; or a remote side]: pl. A^a$ofaAqN. (O, K.) One says, A^anaA fiY A^a$ofaAqK mino h`*aA AlA^amori i. e. nawaAHK [meaning (assumed tropical:) I am apart, or aloof, from this affair; as though in, or on, remote sides thereof]: (O, TA:) and in like manner fiY EuruwDK minohu [app. a mistranscription for EaruwDK i. e. naAHiyapK] and fY A^aEoraADK mnh i. e. nawaAHK. (TA.) -A4- And (tropical:) A bad thing; syn. radiYo'N: (Lth, S, M, O, K, TA: [in the TA said to be written by J with kesr to the f; but not so in either of my copies of the S:]) applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, (Mgh, TA, and Ham p. 179,) [in this sense, or] as meaning bad and thin: (Mgh in art. xrv:) [said to be] from $afaqapN signifying “ weakness: ” (Ham ubi suprà:) seldom pluralized: (O:) and used alike as masc. and fem., being applied as an epithet to a miloHafap, (M, O,) meaning radiyy^apN. (M.)
$afiqN * : see $afiyqN, in two places.
$afaqapN * : see $afaqN, in five places.
$afuwqN * : see the next paragraph.

$afiyqN * is syn. with ↓ mu$ofiqN as part. n. of 4 [signifying Fearing, or fearful, or cautious; and also affectionate, kind, or compassionate, &c.]; (S, O, Msb, * K;) as also ↓ $afiqN (Msb) [and in an intensive sense ↓ $afuwqN; and , from what follows, it appears that $afiyqN also is used as an intensive epithet]: or ↓ $afiqN signifies fearing; and its pl. is $afiquwna: (M, TA:) and $afiyqN, one giving faithful or sincere or honest advice, eager, or striving, to rectify, or amend, the state of him to whom that advice is given. (M.)
A_in~a Al$~afiyqa bisuwo'i ZanK muwlaEN
[Verily the affectionate, &c., or the very affectionate &c., is addicted to evil opinion,] is a prov., applied in the case of the man who fears, for his friend, the accidents of fortune, by reason of his excessive $afaqap [or affection, &c.]. (TA.) And it is said in the Kur [xxi. 50], wahumo mina ↓ A@ls~aAEapi mu$ofiquwna [meaning And who are fearful of the time of the resurrection]; the signification of fear being most apparent when mu$ofiqN is thus trans. by means of mino. (TA.) See also an instance of ↓ mu$ofiqN [in a similar sense] in the first paragraph of this art.
mu$ofaqN * : see the last paragraph. -A2- [Accord. to Freytag, it signifies also Fear: but he names no authority for this.]
mu$ofiqN * : see $afiyqN, in three places.

EaTaA='N mu$af~aqN * (tropical:) A gift made scanty, or little in
amount or quantity; (S, TA;) as also ↓ mu$ofaqN. (TA.)

1 $afahahu * , aor.
$afaha , (K,) inf. n. $afohN, (TK,) He struck his $afap [i. e. lip]. (K.) ― -b2- $ufiha, [said of a water, (assumed tropical:) It had many lips of drinkers applied to it; i. e. it had many drinkers: (see its part. n.:) and] said of food, (tropical:) It had many eaters: (K, TA:) or [as a consequence thereof] it became little in quantity. (TA.) ― -b3- And [hence], said of property, (assumed tropical:) It had many seekers. (K.) ― -b4- And, said of a man, (assumed tropical:) He had many askers, or beggars, (K, TA,) so that they consumed what he had, or possessed. (TA.) [Or (assumed tropical:) He was importuned by begging, so that what he had, or possessed, was consumed: as pass. of what next follows.] ― -b5- $afahahu (assumed tropical:) He importuned him by begging, so that he consumed what he had, or possessed. (S, K.) And one says, kaAda AlEiyaAlu ya$ofahuwna maAliY (tropical:) The family, or household, almost consumed my property. (K, * TA.) ― -b6- Also, (S, K,) inf. n. $afohN, (S,) i. q. $agala. (S, K.) You say, $afahaniY Eano ka*aA (assumed tropical:) He, or it, occupied me so as to divert me from such a thing; syn. $agalaniY. (S.) And naHonu na$ofahu Ealayoka AlmarotaEa, and AlmaA='a, meaning (assumed tropical:) We occupy the place of pasturage so as to keep it from thee, and the water, (na$ogaluhu Eanoka,) i. e. it is sufficient for us without being more than sufficient. (S, TA.) And $ufiha Eanoka maA EinodanaA (assumed tropical:) What we had was employed so as to be kept from thee; syn. $ugila Eanoka. (JK.) -A2- IAar mentions the phrase $afahotu naSiybiY, with fet-h, without explaining it; but Th says that it is sfht, [i. e. safihotu, with s, and with kesr to the f,] meaning “ I forgot [my share, or portion]. ” (TA.)

3 $Afhhu * , (K,) inf. n. mu$aAfahapN, (TA,) He put his lip ($afatahu) near to his [another's] lip. (K, TA.) And kal~amahu mu$aAfahapF (Msb, TA) and mu$aAfaApF (Msb) He spoke to him putting his lip near to his lip: (TA:) [or mouth to mouth; for,] accord. to J, (TA,) mu$aAfahapN signifies the talking with another mouth to mouth: (S, TA:) but the usage of the inf. n. of a verb different from that which it is thus made to qualify is, as Sb says, restricted to instances that have been heard: the phrase kal~amahu mufaAwahapF [has not been heard, and therefore] is not allowable. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] $Afh Albalada, and AlA^amora, (tropical:) He was, or became, or drew, near to the town, or country, and the affair. (A, K, TA.)

$afapN * , (T, S, Msb, K, &c.,) also pronounced ↓ $ifapN, (K,) is a word of which the third, i. e. the final, radical letter is elided; (T, Msb;) and accord. to some, (Msb,) this letter is h, (T, Msb, K, TA,) so accord. to all of the Basrees, (TA,) the word being originally ↓ $fhp, (T, S, Msb, TA,) i. e. $afahapN, (so in copies of the S,) or $afohapN, like kalobahN and sajodapN, (Msb,) because it has the former of the dims. mentioned below, and the first of the pls. mentioned below, with h, (S, Msb, *) and it is sometimes pronounced $fhp; (T, TA;) or, as some assert, the deficient letter is w, (S, Msb,) the word being originally $afowapN, like $ahowapN, (Msb,) because it has the last of the pls. mentioned below, (S, [but omitted in one of my copies,] and Msb, *) and the latter of the two dims. mentioned below; (Msb;) both of which assertions are stated on the authority of Kh; (IF, Msb;) [The lip of a human being;] $afataA AlA_inosaAni meaning the two covers of the mouth of the human being: (K:) it is [properly] only of a human being: (Msb:) but it is sometimes, metaphorically, of the horse: and in like manner, of the dalow [or leathern bucket] as used by A'Obeyd; but ISd has expressed a doubt whether he had heard this from the Arabs: (TA:) the pl. is $ifaAhN (S, Msb, K, &c.) and $afahaAtN (Lth, Msb, TA) and $afawaAtN, (Lth, S, Msb, K,) the second of which is said by Lth to be more agreeable with analogy than the third, though the third is more common, as being likened to sanawaAtN [pl. of sanapN]: (Az, (Msb, TA:) and Ks mentions the phrase, A_in~ahu lagaliyZu Al$ifaAhi [as meaning Verily he is thick in the lip], as though the term $afapN applied to every portion of the $afap: (TA:) the dim. is ↓ $ufayohapu (S, Msb) and $ufay~apN. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] humo A^aholu Al$~afapi (assumed tropical:) They are those who have the right of drinking with their lips (bi$ifaAhihimo) and of watering their beasts. (Mgh.) ― -b3- And binotu $afapK (tropical:) A word; (S, Msb, K, TA;) as also *aAtu $afapK. (TA.) One says, maA kal~amotuhu bibinoti $afapK (assumed tropical:) I spoke not to him a word: (S:) or maA kal~amaniYbinota $afapK (assumed tropical:) He spoke not to me a word: (TA:) and maA samiEotu minohu binota $afapK (assumed tropical:) I heard not from him a word: (Msb:) and maA kal~amotu fulaAnFA *aAta $afapK (assumed tropical:) I spoke not to such a one a word. (AZ, T voce *uw.) ― -b4- And fulaAnN xafiyfu Al$~afapi (tropical:) Such a one is a person who asks, or begs, little of people: (ISk, S, K, * TA:) and also, (tropical:) importunate, (K, TA,) one who asks, or begs, much of people: (TA:) thus having two contr. meanings. (K.) ― -b5- And lahu fiY Aln~aAsi $afapN (assumed tropical:) He has praise, or commendation, among the people: (S:) and lahu fiynaA $afapN HasanapN (tropical:) He has a good report, or reputation, among us. (A, K, TA.) And A_in~a $afapa Aln~aAsi Ealayoka laHasanapN (tropical:) Verily the people's speaking of thee is good. (Lh, TA.) And maA A^aHosana $afapa Aln~aAsi Ealayoka (tropical:) How good is the people's speaking of thee! (K, TA.) ― -b6- See also $afFA, in art. $fw and $fY.
$ifapN * , and see the next preceding paragraph.
$afahapN * or $afohapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

$afahiY~N * and $afiY~N are both allowable as rel. ns. of $afapN [i. e. as meaning Labial: and so, accord. to some, is $afawiY~N]. (S.) AlHuruwfu Al$~afahiy~apu (Kh, T, S, Msb, K) and Al$~afawiy~apu, (Kh, T, Msb,) or the latter is not allowable, (S,) [i. e. The labial letters,] are b and f and m: (T, S, K:) [or, accord. to Lumsden (Ar. Gr. p. 28), b and m and w: and, it seems, accord. to some, (see De Sacy's Gr. Ar. sec. ed. i. 27,) j and $ and D, which is strange:] so called because their place of utterance is from the $afap, without any action of the tongue. (T, TA.)
$ufayohapN * : dim. of $afapN, q. v.
$ufaAhiY~N * A man (S, Mgh) large [in some copies of the S thick] in the $afataAni [or lips]; (S, Mgh, K;) as also ↓ A^a$ofahu. (Mgh. [But see this latter below.])

$aAfihN *
Thirsty, (K, TA,) not finding water enough to moisten his lip: like saAfihN, mentioned in art. sfh. (TA.)

A^a$ofahu * : see $ufaAhiY~N. ― -b2- [Accord. to some,] A^a$ofaY signifies A man whose lips do not close together: (S, K:) but there is no proof of its correctness: (S:) the fem. in this sense is $afoyaA='u. (TA in art. $fY.)

ma$ofuwhN * (tropical:) A water at which there are many lips ($ifaAh TA, and Har p. 669,) of those coming to drink, (Har,) so that it has become little in quantity; (TA;) or water at which are many people: (S, K: *) or water that is sought: or, as some say, forbidden to those who come to drink of it because of its being little in quantity. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (Har ubi suprà,) (tropical:) Food upon which are [put] many hands; (K, TA, Har;) having many eaters: or that has become little in quantity. (TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) Property sought by many: (TA:) [or little in quantity; for] one says, A^ataAnaA wa A^amowaAlunaA ma$ofuwhapN (tropical:) He came to us when our possessions were little in quantity. (K, TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) A man of whom people have asked, or begged, much, (S,) or importuned by begging, (K,) so that all that he had, or possessed, is consumed: (S, K:) like mavomuwdN, and maDofuwfN, and makovuwrN Ealayohi: (so in one of my copies of the S:) and sometimes it means (assumed tropical:) one whose household and guests have consumed his property. (IB, TA.)

div2.head: $fw and $fY
div2.entryFree:
1 $afati Al$~amosu * , aor.
1a2u3a , [inf. n. app. $afFA, but said in the TK to be $afowN,] The sun was, or became, near to setting: (K in art. $fw:) and $afat, (K in art. $fY,) [aor.
1a2i3a ,] inf. n. $afFA, (TA,) it (the sun) set; as also $afiyat: (K:) or, accord. to IKtt, set save a little; and the like is said in the T. (TA.) qubayola Al$~afaA means A little before the setting of the sun. (TA.) [See also $afFA below.] ― -b2- And $afaA said of the hilaAl [or moon a little after or before the change], It rose. (K.) And said of a $axoS [or bodily form or figure seen from a distance, or a person], It, or he, appeared, or became apparent. (K.) -A2- $afaAhu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
1a2i3a , (Msb, K,) inf. n. $ifaA='N, (S, Msb,) He (God, S, Msb) recovered him, or restored him to convalescence, syn. A^aboraA^ahu, so in the M, but in the K baraAhu, (TA,) namely a sick person, (Msb,) mino maraDihi [from his disease, or sickness]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, $afayotuhu, in art. bDE in the S, said by a person respecting one who asked him concerning a
question, as meaning (assumed tropical:) I relieved him from doubt: and $afaAhu Eani AlmasoA^alapi in the same art. in the K, as meaning (assumed tropical:) He relieved him from doubt respecting the question. See 8 as quasi-pass. of the verb thus used.] ― -b3- And ya$ofiyka A_ino qaAla (assumed tropical:) [He will please thee if he speak; i. e.] his speech will please thee. (Har p. 433.) ― -b4- $afaAhu also signifies He sought, or demanded, or desired, for him, recovery, or restoration to convalescence; and so ↓ A^a$ofaAhu: (K, TA:) thus in the M. (TA.)

2 $f~Ahu bikuli $aYo'K * , inf. n. ta$ofiyapN, He treated him medically, or curatively, with everything whereby he might attain recovery, or restoration to convalescence. (TA.) ― -b2- maA $af~aY fulaAnN A^afoDalu mim~aA $af~ayota i. e. maA A@zodaAda and rabiHa [meaning The gain of such a one (mA being here what is termed maSodariy~ap, as AizodaAda and rabiHa are intrans.,) is more excellent than thy gain] is said to be an instance of substitution, [originally $af~afa and $af~afota,] like [qaS~aY and taqaS~aY and] taqaD~aY [for qaS~aSa and taqaS~aSa and taqaD~aDa]. (TA.)
3 mu$aAfaApN * [an inf. n. of which the verb, if used, is $aAfaY]: see 3 in art. $fh.

4 A$fY Ealayohi *
He was, or became, on the brink of it; (S, Msb, K, TA;) namely, a thing; and death: (S, Msb:) mostly used in relation to evil, but also in relation to good: so says IKtt. (TA.) [See $afFA.] ― -b2- And A$fY [alone] (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, at the point of [giving or receiving] a charge or an injunction, or a trust or deposit. (TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, in the last part of the night; which is termed $afaA All~ayoli. (TA.) -A2- A^a$ofaY nafosahu EalaY hulokK (K and TA in art. xTr) and A$fY bihaA (TA in the same) i. e. EalaY $afaA hulokK [meaning (assumed tropical:) He caused himself to be on the brink of destruction]. (TA ibid.) -A3- A$fAhu He gave him a remedial medicine. (Az, TA.) And He prescribed for him a remedy in which should be his recovery, or restoration to convalescence. (TA.) And A^a$ofayotuka Al$~aYo'a (S, K *) I gave thee the thing in order that thou shouldst attain, or seek, recovery, or restoration to convalescence, thereby. (S: in two copies thereof, bihi ↓ ta$otafiY: in two other copies thereof, and in like manner in the K, bihi ↓ tasota$ofiY.) And A$fAhu A@ll~`hu EasalFA God made honey to be his remedy. (AO, S: and the like is said by IKtt as cited in the TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, last sentence. ― -b3- A$fY also signifies (assumed tropical:) He gave [a person] something. (TA.)

5 t$f~Y * : see 8 [with which it is syn.]. ― -b2- [Hence,] t$f~Y mino gayoZihi (S, MA, K) (assumed tropical:) He recovered from his anger, wrath, or rage. (MA.) And t$f~Y mino Eaduw~ihi, (T, TA,) or biAlEaduw~i, and bh ↓ A$tfY, (Msb,) (assumed tropical:) He inflicted injury upon his enemy [or the enemy] in a manner that rejoiced him [or relieved him from his anger]: (T, TA:) [or he attained what he desired from his enemy or the enemy, and so appeased his anger:] because latent anger is like a disease; and when it departs by reason of that which one seeks to obtain from his enemy, he is as though he became free, or recovered, from his disease. (Msb.)
6 ta$aAfayotu AlmaA='a * a phrase mentioned by IAar as meaning I exhausted the water: said by ISd to be originally ta$aAfafotu. (TA in art. $f.)

8 A$tfY bika*aA * (S, K, TA) He attained recovery, or restoration to convalescence, by means of such a thing: (TA;) and so ↓ t$f~Y: (TK:) and mino Eil~atihi ↓ Ast$fY [if not a mistranscription for A$tfY] he became free from his disease, sickness, or malady; recovered from it; or became convalescent. (TA.) See 4, latter part. ― -b2- And see also 5. ― -b3- [Also (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, content with such a thing; or relieved from doubt thereby: and] (assumed tropical:) he profited by such a thing. (MA.) One says, Ai$otafayotu bimaA A^axobaraniY fulaAnN (assumed tropical:) I was, or became, content with that which such a one told me, [or relieved from doubt thereby,] because it was true. (IB in art. Hk, from Az.) And A^axobarahu fulaAnN faA@$otafaY bihi (assumed tropical:) [Such a one gave him information] and he profited by his veracity. (TA.)

10 Ast$fY *
He sought, or demanded, a remedy, or cure. (TA.) See 4, latter part. ― -b2- And see also 8.

$afFA * The point or extremity, verge, brink, or edge, of anything; (S, Msb, K, &c.;) like ↓ $afapN; for $afaA AlHuforapi (Ksh in iii. 99) or $afaA Albiy^ori (Bd ibid.) and $afatuhaA both signify the same, (Ksh, Bd,) i. e. HarofuhaA (Ksh) or TarafuhaA; (Bd;) but the final w in the former is changed into A, and in the latter [accord. to those who hold $afapN to be originally $afowapN] it is elided; (Ksh, Bd;) $afFA being originally $afawN: (Bd:) [but $afFA generally signifies as expl. above; and $afapN almost always signifies the “ lip ” of a human being:] the dual is $afawaAni; this being known, as Akh says, by the fact that A_imaAlap in the word $afFA is not allowable: (S:) and the pl. is A^a$ofaA='N. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [iii. 99], wakunotumo EalaY $afaA HuforapN mina A@ln~aAri faA^anoqa*akumo minohaA [And ye were on the verge, or brink, of a pit of the fire of Hell, and He saved, or rescued, you from it]. (S.) And one says, huwa EalaY $afaA AlhalaAki (tropical:) [He is on the brink of destruction]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) A little; (S, A, K, TA;) a small part, or portion; somewhat; (A, TA;) somewhat remaining of the moon when near the change, (K, TA, [AlhalAk in the CK is erroneously put for AlhilaAl,]) and of the sight (AlbaSar), and of the day, and the like, as in the T. (TA.) One says of a man on the occasion of his dying, and of the moon at [the last period of the month called] its muHaAq, and of the sun at its setting, (S,) maA baqiYa minohu A_il~aA $afFA [and minohaA when said of the sun] (assumed tropical:) There has not remained of him, or it, save a little: (S, K: *) and [in like manner] mina AlEumuri [of life]. (S.) And one says, A^atayotuhu bi$afFA mino Dawo'i Al$~amosi (assumed tropical:) [I came to him in a time when there was little remaining of the light of the sun]. (TA.) El-'Ajjáj says,
A^a$orafotuhu bilaA $afFA A^awo bi$afaA
wamirobaA^K EaAlK limanN ta$ar~afaA
meaning [Many an elevated place of observation, high to him who ascends it, I have ascended] when the sun had set or when there was somewhat of it remaining. (S.) One says also, SaAra fiY $afaA Alqamari meaning (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, in the last part of the night. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., (in relation to [the temporary marriage termed] AlmutoEap,) falawo laA nahoyuhu EanohaA maA A@HotaAja A_ilaY Alz~inaA A_il~aA $afFA, accord. to the T meaning [Were it not for his (i. e. God's) forbidding it, none would need having recourse to fornication,] save a small number of men: (T, TA:) or, accord. to 'Atà, it means, but would be on the brink thereof, without falling into it; $afFA being thus used in the place of the inf. n. A_i$ofaA=': so says IAth, as from Az. (TA.)

$afapN * , in which the deficient letter is w, (K, TA,) for it has for pl. $afawaAtN, (TA,) or h, (K, TA,) for it has [also] for pl. $ifaAhN, (TA,) has been mentioned before, (K, TA,) in art. $fh [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also $afFA above, first sentence.

$ifaA='N * , (K, TA,) like kisaA='N, (TA,) [in the CK erroneously written $afA',] primarily signifies The becoming free from disease, sickness, or malady; recovering therefrom; or becoming convalescent: ― -b2- and then, Medical, or curative, treatment: (TA:) the giving of health; (KL:) inf. n. of $afaAhu [q. v.]: (S, Msb, TA:) ― -b3- and [then], (TA,) A medicine, or remedy: pl. A^a$ofiyapN, and pl. pl. A^a$aAfK. (K, TA.) [Hence, daAru Al$ifaA='i The hospital.] ― -b4- [And hence,] one says, $ifaA='u AlEiY~i Als~uw^aAlu (tropical:) [The remedy of inability is the asking information]. (TA.)
$afiY~N * : see art. $fh.
$ufay~apN * : see art. $fh.
$afawiY~N * : see art. $fh.
$aAfK * [Recovering, or restoring to convalescence; remedial;] health-giving. (KL.) ― -b2- [Hence, jawaAbN $aAfK (assumed tropical:) An answer that relieves from doubt.]

A^a$ofaY *
More [and most remedial or] healthgiving. (KL.) -A2- Also A man whose lips do not close together: fem. $afoyaA='u. (TA.) See A^a$ofahu, in art. $fh.

A_i$ofFY *
An instrument for perforating; (K;) a thing pertaining to the makers or sewers of boots or shoes or sandals &c.; (S;) [i. e.] the awl used by them: (MA, KL:) and the instrument with which leather, or skin, is sewed: (Mgh, K:) or, accord. to ISk, it is [an instrument used] for water-skins and water-bags and the like; and the mixoSaf is for sandals: (S:) [see also art. A$f:] masc. and fem.: (K, * TA:) pl. A^a$aAfK. (Mgh, TA.) ― -b2- Th mentions the saying, A_ino laATamotahu laATamota AlA_i$ofaY [if thou contend with him in slapping, thou wilt do so with the A$fY]; meaning that when one does so, it will be against himself. (TA.) ― -b3- And A_i$ofaY Almirofaqi, a phrase used by a poet, means (assumed tropical:) Sharp in the elbow. (TA.)

1 $aq~ahu * , (S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
$aqu3a , (M, Msb,)
inf. n. $aq~N, (S, M, Msb,) He cut it [or divided it] lengthwise; (TA in art. qd;) [i. e.] he clave it, split it, rived or rifted it, or slit it; so as to separate it; [i. e. he clave, split, rived or rifted, slit, rent, ripped, tore, broke, or burst, it asunder;] or without separating it; [i. e. he cracked, chapped, incided or incised, gashed, slashed, furrowed, or trenched, it; or clave, split, &c., or cut, it open;] syn. SadaEahu; (K;) or [more explicitly] Al$~aq~u signifies AlS~adoEu AlbaAy^inu [the cleaving &c. that separates]; or gayoru AlbaAy^ini [that which does not separate]; or AlS~adoEu [the cleaving, &c.,] in a general sense: (M:) and in like manner, [but with an intensive signification, or implying frequency or repetition of the action, or its application to several objects, generally meaning he clave it, &c., much, or in pieces, or in several places,] ↓ $q~qhu: (M, K:) you say, $q~q AlHaTaba (S, K) wagayorahu (S) i. e. $aq~ahu [but properly meaning He clave in pieces the firewood &c.]. (K. [In the CK, $aq~a AlHaTaba is erroneously put for $q~q AlHTb.]) ― -b2- [$aq~a raA^osahu generally means He clave his head, or his pericranium: and sometimes, as in an instance in the K voce $aqaA^a, he divided the hair of his head.] ― -b3- $aq~a AlEaSaA [lit. He split the staff] means (tropical:) he separated himself from the community; (S, K, TA;) and particularly, that of the Muslims: because the staff is not thus called but when it is whole, not when it is split: accord. to Lth, ya$uq~u EaSaA Almusolimiyna and ↓ yu$aAq~uhumo signify alike: but they differ in meaning, as will be shown hereafter. (TA.) $aq~a EaSaA Almusolimiyna, K, TA,) said of a xaArijiY~ [i. e. heretic or schismatic], also means (assumed tropical:) He effected disunion and dissension in the body of the Muslims. (TA.) And one says also, $aq~a EaSaA AlT~aAEapi (assumed tropical:) [He broke the compact of allegiance, or obedience; became a rebel]. (M.) ― -b4- laA waAl~a*iY $aq~a Alr~ijaAla liloxayoli waAljibaAla lils~ayoli [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) No, by Him who clave men for the riding upon horses, and the mountains for the flowing of the torrent,] is a saying mentioned by IAar, but not expl. by him. (M. [It is there added, waEinodiY A^an~ahu jaEala Alr~ijaAla waAljibaAla jumolapF waAHidapF vum~a xaraqahumaA fajaEala Alr~ijaAla lih`*ihi waAljibaAla lih`*aA: an expression of opinion which is, to me, by no means clear, though reconcilable with my rendering.]) ― -b5- AlmaAlu bayonanaA $aq~a AlA^abolamapi and AlA^ubolumapi [The property is divided between us as in the dividing of the Ablmp; or the cattle are divided &c.;] means we are equal in respect of the property, or cattle: for the Ablmp means the [kind of leaf called] xuwSap, which, when it is split lengthwise, splits in halves: (M:) or, accord. to Aboo-Ziyád, the Ablmp is a herb, or leguminous plant, (baqolapN,) to which there come forth pods, like [those of] the bean; and when you split them lengthwise, they split in halves, equally, from the first part to the last thereof: $aq~a is in the accus. case as an inf. n., ma$oquwqN being understood. (Har p. 639.) [See also $iq~N.] ― -b6- $aq~a, (S, M, K,) aor.
$aqu3a , inf. n. $uquwqN, (M,) said of the canine tooth of a camel, (tropical:) It [clave the gum and] came forth: (S, M, K, TA:) [said to be] a dial. var. of $aqaA^a: (S:) and said of the canine tooth of a child, (M, TA,) in like manner, (TA,) meaning it made its first appearance: (M:) and said also of a plant, [as meaning it came forth] on the ground's first cleaving open from it. (M, TA.) ― -b7- Also, aor.
$aqu3a , inf. n. $aq~N, said of the dawn, (tropical:) It rose; as though it clave the place of its rising and came forth therefrom. (TA.) ― -b8- Also, aor.
$aqu3a , (TA,) inf. n. $aq~N, said of lightning, (tropical:) It [clave the clouds, and] extended high, into the midst of the sky, without going to the right and left: (K, TA:) so says A'Obeyd: (TA: [see $aqiyqN:]) and ↓ An$q~ and ↓ t$q~q, said of lightning, signify AinoEaq~a [probably meaning the same; (see EaqiyqapN;) or, as expl. in the S and also in the O, in art. Eq, it was, or became, in a state of commotion, (taDar~aba,) in the clouds]: (M, TA:) or ↓ t$q~q said of lightning means it spread wide and long. (JK.) ― -b9- $aq~a Als~abiyla (K in art. Ebr) (assumed tropical:) He passed along the way; as though he cut it, or furrowed it. (TK in that art.) And $aq~a Aln~ahora (assumed tropical:) He crossed the river by swimming. (TA in art. qTE.) ― -b10- $aq~a AlmaA='a (assumed tropical:) He opened a way, passage, vent, or channel, for the water to flow forth; syn. bajasahu. (A and K in art. bjs.) ― -b11- $aq~a A^amorahu, aor.
$aqu3a , inf. n. $aq~N, (assumed tropical:) He, or it, discomposed, deranged, or disordered, so that it became incongruous, or inconsistent, his affair, or state of affairs. (M, TA.) [A phrase similar to $aq~a AlEaSaA, mentioned above. And so, app., what next follows.] ― -b12- $aq~a AlkalaAma, i. q. qad~ahu [also expl. as syn. with qaTaEahu, which generally means (assumed tropical:) He cut short, or broke off, the speech; or ceased from speaking; but sometimes, and perhaps in this case, he articulated speech, or the speech: compare a signification of 2.]. (M and L in art. qd.) ― -b13- See also 8. ― -b14- $aq~a baSaru Almay~iti i. q. $axaSa [i. e. (assumed tropical:) The eye, or eyes, of the dying man became fixedly open; or his eyelids became raised upwards, and he looked intently, and became disquieted, or disturbed]: (M, TA:) and (TA) the dying man looked at a thing, his sight not recoiling to him: (S, K, TA:) said of him to whom death is present: (S, TA:) or [simply] the eyes of the dying man became open: (TA:) one should not say $aq~a Almay~itu baSarahu: (S, M, K:) and $uq~a, with damm to the $, is not approved. (IAth, TA.) ― -b15- $aq~a Ealayohi, (M, K, in the S EalaY~a, and in the Msb EalayonaA,) aor.
$aqu3a , (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. $aq~N (S, M, K) and ma$aq~apN, (S, K,) [or the latter is a simple subst., as seems to be indicated in the M and Msb,] (assumed tropical:) It (a thing, S, or an affair, or event, M, Msb, K) affected him severely; had a severe effect upon him; distressed, afflicted, troubled, molested, inconvenienced, fatigued, or wearied, him: (M:) it was difficult, hard, distressing, grievous, or severe, to him; (K, TA;) and onerous, burdensome, oppressive, or troublesome, to him. (TA.) And $aq~a Ealayohi, [inf. n., app., $aq~N only,] (assumed tropical:) He caused him to fall into a difficult, hard, distressing, grievous, or severe, case: (K, TA:) imposed upon him that which was onerous, burdensome, oppressive, or troublesome. (TA.) And $aq~ati Als~aforapu (assumed tropical:) The journey was [difficult, hard, or] far-extending. (Msb.) -A2- $uq~a, said of the solid hoof, and of the pastern of a horse or the like, It was, or became, affected with the disease termed $uqaAq, occasioning cracks. (M, TA.)

2 $aq~a3a see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- $q~q AlkalaAma, (S, K, TA,) inf. n. ta$oqiyqN, (TA,) (tropical:) He uttered, or pronounced, speech, or the speech, in the best manner: (S, K, TA:) and he sought with repeated efforts, in speaking, to utter, or pronounce, the speech in the best manner. (TA.)

3 $Aq~hu * , (M, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. mu$aAq~apN (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and $iqaAqN, (S, M, Msb, K,) the latter inf. n. occurring in the Kur ii. 131 and iv. 39 [&c.], (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He acted with him contrariously, or adversely, (S, * M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and inimically; (K;) properly, each of them doing to the other that which was distressing, grievous, or troublesome, so that each of them was in a $iq~ [or side] other than that of his fellow; (Msb;) or as though he became in a $iq~, i. e. side, in respect of him: (Mgh:) accord. to Er-Rághib, the inf. n. signifies the being in a $iq~ [or side] other than that of one's fellow: or it is from $aq~u AlEaSaA bayonaka wabayona SaAHibika [meaning “ the effecting disunion and dissension between thee and thy fellow ”], so that it is tropical: (TA:) or the primary meaning of Al$~iqaAqu is the being [mutually] remote. (Ham p. 326.) See also 1, in the first quarter of the paragraph.

4 A$q~ Aln~axolu *
The palm-trees put forth their $awaAq~, pl. of $aAq~apN [q. v.]: mentioned by Th, on the authority of some one or more of the BenooSuwáäh. (M.)

5 t$q~q * quasi-pass. of 2: (S, M, K:) said of firewood (S, K) &c. (S) [as meaning It became cloven in pieces]. See 7, in two places. ― -b2- Said of lightning: see 1, in two places, in the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b3- Said of a horse, (tropical:) He was, or became, lean, or light of flesh; slender and lean; or lean, and lank in the belly. (A'Obeyd, TA.)

6 ta$aAq~aA * , said of two adversaries, or litigants, as also ↓ Ai$otaq~aA, They wrangled, quarrelled, or contended, each with the other, (M, TA,) and took to the right and left in contention; (TA;) fiY Al$~aYo'i [in respect of the thing]. (M.)

7 An$q~ * quasi-pass. of $aq~ahu as expl. in the first sentence of this art.: [i. e. it signifies It became divided lengthwise, cloven, split, riven or rifted, slit, rent, ripped, torn, broken, or burst, asunder; or it became cracked, chapped, incided or incised, gashed, slashed, furrowed, or trenched; or cloven, or split, &c., or cut, open: or it clave, split, &c.:] (S, M:) and in like manner, ↓ t$q~q is quasi-pass. of $aq~aqahu: [i. e. it signifies it became cloven or split &c., or it clave or split &c., much, or in pieces, or in several or many places:] (M:) or the former signifies [sometimes] it opened so as to have in it an interstice. (Msb.) waA@no$aq~a Alqamaru, in the Kur liv. I, means And the moon hath been cloven (Bd, Jel) in twain, (Jel,) as a sign to the
Prophet: (Bd, Jel:) or shall be cloven on the day of resurrection: but the former is confirmed by another reading, waqadi A^ono$aq~a Alqamaru: (Bd:) or, accord. to Er-Rághib, the meaning is, (assumed tropical:) the case hath become manifest. (TA.) One says, An$q~ Al$~aYo'u biniSofayoni [The thing became cloven, &c., in halves]. (S.) [And An$q~ minohu It became cloven, &c., from it: and it branched off from it; as a river from another river, and the like. And An$q~ Eanohu It clave asunder from over it, so as to disclose it: see also 8.] ― -b2- [Hence,] An$q~ flaAnN mina AlgaDabi (assumed tropical:) Such a one was as though his interior were filled with anger so that he split. (TA.) ― -b3- And Aino$aq~ati AlEaSaA (assumed tropical:) The affair, or state of affairs, became discomposed, deranged, or disordered: (S, K, TA:) and An$q~t AlEaSaA biAlbayoni, and ↓ t$q~qt, (Lth, M, TA,) (assumed tropical:) the affair, or state of affairs, became discomposed, deranged, or disorganized, by separation: (Lth, TA:) and An$q~ AlA^amoru (assumed tropical:) the affair, or state of affairs, became discomposed, deranged, or disorganized, being incongruous, or inconsistent. (M, TA.) And An$q~t EaSaA AlT~aAEapi (assumed tropical:) [The compact of allegiance, or obedience, became broken]. (M.) ― -b4- An$q~ said of lightning: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.

8 Ai$otiqaAqN * signifies The taking the $iq~ of a thing, (S, K,) i. e. the half thereof. (S.) One says, A$tq~ Al$~aYo'a He took the $iq~ [or half] of the thing. (TK.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) The taking [or deriving] a word from a word, (S, K,) with the condition of reciprocal relation in meaning and [radical] composition, and of reciprocal difference in form: [and it is of three kinds:] AlAi$otiqaAqu AlS~agiyru is that derivation in which there is a reciprocal relation between the two words in the letters and in the order [thereof]; as in Daraba from AlD~arobu: AlA$tqAq Alkabiyru is that in which there is a reciprocal relation between the two words as to the letter and the meaning, exclusively of the order; as in jaba*a from Alja*obu: AlA$tqAq AlA^akobaru is that in which there is a reciprocal relation between the two words in the place [or places] of utterance; as in naEaqa from Aln~ahoqu. (KT.) [You say, A$tq~ HarofFA or kalimapF or lafoZFA, and A@somFA, He derived a word, and a name, mino A=xara from another; and ↓ $aq~ahu sometimes signifies the same, as is shown by a citation voce raHimN.] ― -b3- [And, as syn. with AixotiraAEN, (see 8 in art. xrE,)] The constructing, or founding, (bunoyaAn,) of a thing of, or from, what is originated without premeditation. (M.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) The taking to the right and left, (S, K, TA,) not pursuing the right, or direct, course, (S, TA,) in speech, and in contention, or disputation, or litigation: (S, K, TA:) or Ai$otiqaAqu AlkalaAmi signifies the taking to the right and left in speech: (so in a copy of the M: [but I think that the right reading is AlAi$otiqaAqu fiY AlkalaAmi, agreeably with what here follows:]) you say, A$tq~ fiY AlkalaAmi, and fiY AlxuSuwmapi. (TK.) See also 6. And [in like manner] one says of a horse, A$tq~ fiY Eadowihi (assumed tropical:) He went to the right and left in his running. (M. [See also A^a$aq~u.]) ― -b5- A$tq~ AlT~ariyqu fiY AlfalaApi (tropical:) The road went [or branched off] into the desert. (TA. [See also 7.])

10 Ast$q~ biAljuwaAliqi *
He turned the sack upon one of his two sides (EalaY A^aHadi $iq~ayohi), in order to pass through a door. (TA.) ― -b2- [Ast$q~, as stated by Freytag, is expl. by Jac. Schultens, but on what authority is not said, as signifying “ Prodiit, manifestus evasit. ”]

R. Q. 1 $aqo$aqa * , (JK, S, K,) inf. n. $aqo$aqapN, (S,) said of a stallion [camel], He brayed [in his $iqo$iqap, or faucial bag]. (JK, S, K.) [It is said that] the primary meaning of $aqo$aqapN is Loudness of voice; or the being loud in voice. (JK.) ― -b2- And said of a sparrow, It uttered a cry: (K, TA:) or one says of a sparrow, yu$aqo$iqu fiY Sawotihi [app. meaning It makes a loud twittering in its cry]. (S.)

$aq~N * sing. of $uquwqN; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) originally an inf. n.; (S, Msb;) An opening forming an interstice in a thing: (Msb:) or a fissure, cleft, chink, split, slit, rent, crack, or the like, syn. SadoEN, in wood or a stick, or in a wall, or in a glass vessel [&c.]: (T, TA:) [or] a place that is ma$oquwq [i. e. cloven or cleft, split, &c.: (see 1, first sentence: and see also ma$aq~N:) and often signifying an incision, a gash, or a furrow, or trench]: (M, K:) as though an inf. n. used as a subst. in this sense: pl. as above, $uquwqN: (M:) it differs from $uqaAqN, (S, Mgh,) by having a general signification: (Mgh:) accord. to Yaakoob, one says, biyadi fulaAnK $uquwqN (S, Mgh) and birijolihi (S) [i. e. In the hand, or arm, of such a one are cracks, or the like, and in his foot, or leg]: but [it is asserted that in this case] one should not say $uqaAqN: (S, Mgh: [see, however, this word:]) and hence, $aq~u Alqabori The trench, or oblong excavation, in the middle of the grave: and accord. to As, $uquwqN signifies SuduwE [i. e. fissures, &c.,] in mountains, and in the earth, or ground. (Mgh.) ― -b2- The rima vulvæ of a woman; i. e. the gap [or chink] between the two edges, or borders, of the labia majora of her vulva: as also ↓ ma$aq~N. (M, K.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) The daybreak. (S, K, TA.) -A2- See also the next paragraph, first and fifth sentences. -A3- And see the last two sentences of the same paragraph.

$iq~N * The half (S, Mgh, Msb, K) of a thing (S, Msb, K) of any kind; as also ↓ $aq~N: (K:) or the half of a thing when it is cloven, or split, or divided lengthwise; (M;) as also ↓ $iq~apN. (AHn, S, * M, K.) One says, A^axa*otu $iq~a Al$~aApi and ↓ $iq~apa Al$~aApi I took the half of the sheep or goat: (S, TA:) the vulgar pronounce the $ with fet-h. (TA.) And xu*o h`*aA Al$~iq~a Take thou this ↓ $iq~ap [i. e. half] of the sheep or goat. (TA.) Hence the trad., taSad~aquwA walawo bi$iq~i tamorapK i. e. [Give ye alms though it be but] the half of a date; meaning deem not anything little that is given as alms. (TA.) And AlmaAlu bayoniY wabayonaka $iq~a Al$~aEarapi and Al$~aEarapi ↓ $aq~a, (O, K, * [in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K $q~u, but the former reading appears to be the right, $aq~a being an inf. n. as in a similar saying in the former half of the first paragraph of this art., and $iq~a being a subst. used as an inf. n. or for ka$iq~i,]) meaning [The property is between us] two halves, equal [in division]. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A certain kind of the jinn, or genii; (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K;) a species of diabolical beings having the form of the half of a human being. (Kzw in his Descr. of the Jinn.) ― -b3- The lateral half, or half and side; as when one says that a person paralyzed has a $iq~ inclining; and as when one speaks of the $iq~ of a maHomil [meaning either of the two dorsers, or panniers, or oblong chests, which are borne, one on either side, by a camel, and which, with a small tent over them, compose a maHomil: see this last word, and maHaArapN]. (Mgh.) ― -b4- The side of the body; as when one says of a person that his left $iq~ was grazed, or abraded. (Mgh.) [Hence,] one says of a horse, yamiylu EalaY A^aHadi $iq~ayohi [He inclines, or leans, upon one of his two sides]. (O.) [And ma$aY EalaY $iq~K and fiY $iq~K He went, or walked, inclining upon one side.] ― -b5- The side, or lateral part, (Lth, Msb, K, TA,) of a thing; the two sides of a thing being called $iq~aAhu: (Lth, TA:) or, as some say, (TA,) the side of a mountain. (S, TA.) [Hence,] one says, fulaAnN mino $iq~i AlEa$iyrapi laA mino SamiymihaA (assumed tropical:) [Such a one is of the collateral class of the kinsfolk, or tribe, not of the main stock thereof]. (Mgh in art. ErD.) ― -b6- I. q. ↓ $aqiyqN; (S, Msb, K;) [which primarily signifies The cloven-off half of a thing; i. e.,] when a thing is cloven in halves, each of the halves is called the $aqiyq of the other. (S, K.) ― -b7- [And hence, (assumed tropical:) The counterpart of a person or thing: and this appears to be meant by J, and accord. to SM in the K, where it is said that $iq~N is syn. with ↓ $aqiyqN; for they add immediately after:] one says huwa A^axiY wa$iq~u nafosiY (tropical:) [He is my brother, and the counterpart of myself]; (S, TA;) as though he were cloven from me, because of the resemblance of each of us to the other. (TA.) One says also, h*aA ↓ $aqiyquhu, meaning (assumed tropical:) This is the like of him, or it. (TA.) And [hence] it is said in a trad., Aln~isaA='u $aqaAy^iqu Alr~ijaAli, [in which $aqaAy^iqu is the pl. of ↓ $aqiyqN as fem., or of $aqiyqapN in the same sense,] meaning (assumed tropical:) Women are the likes of men in natural dispositions; as though they were cloven from them; or because Eve was created from Adam. (TA.) ― -b8- And (tropical:) A man's brother; (M;) and so ↓ $aqiyqN; (S, M, O, K, TA;) meaning a brother by the father and mother; (TA;) from $aqiyqN as meaning “ either half of a thing that is cloven in halves; ” (S, TA;) or as though the relationship of one were cloven from that of the other: (IDrd, O, K:) pl. of the latter A^a$iq~aA='u. (M, Msb.) ― -b9- And a name for A thing at which one looks: (Lth, O, K:) [but this is app. taken from the following
saying of Lth, in which I think Al$~iq~u is a mistranscription for Al$~aq~u, meaning “ the crack, ” &c.:] Al$~aq~u is the inf. n. of $aqaqotu, and Al$~iq~u is a name for that at which one looks [i. e. for the visible effect of the act signified by the verb], and the pl. is Al$~uquwqu [which is well known as the pl. of Al$~aq~u]. (JK.) -A2- Also i. q. ↓ ma$aq~apN (S, M, O, Msb, K) i. e. Difficulty, hardship, distress, affliction, trouble, inconvenience, fatigue, or weariness; (M, TA;) and languor, or lack of power, that overtakes the mind and the body; (Er-Rághib, TA;) and so ↓ $aq~N; (IJ, S, M, O, K;) thus it is sometimes pronounced with fet-h; mentioned by A'Obeyd; (S;) and by AZ; (M;) or this is an inf. n., and $iq~N is the subst.; (O, K;) and ↓ $uq~apN and ↓ $iq~apN also signify the same as ma$aq~apN, (K,) or such as overtakes a man in consequence of travel; (TA;) and the pls. of these two are $uqaqN, (K, TA,) mentioned by Fr, (TA,) and $iqaqN, (K, TA,) mentioned on the authority of some one or more of [the tribe of] Keys: (TA:) the pl. of ↓ ma$aq~apN is ma$aAq~u and ma$aq~aAtN. (TA.) Hence, in the Kur [xvi. 7], lamo takuwnuwA baAligiyhi A_il~aA bi$iqi A@loA^anofusi [Which ye would not reach save with difficulty, or distress, &c., of the souls]; where some read ↓ bi$aq~i. (S, * TA.)

$uq~apN * primarily signifies The half of a garment [consisting of two oblong pieces sewed together, side by side]: then it was applied to [such] a garment as it is [when complete: in both of these senses it is used in the present day]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or a piece (qiToEapN) of a garment: (Mgh:) or the $uq~ap of viyaAb [thus, and thus only, in the S, meaning of garments and of cloths, for it is of both,] is an oblong piece; syn. sabiybapN musotaTiylapN: (M, K:) [it is often applied to an oblong piece of cloth of those pieces of which a tent is composed:] pl. $uqaqN and $iqaAqN. (M, Mgh, TA.) One says, fulaAnN yabiyEu $iqaAqa Alkat~aAni [Such a one sells pieces, or oblong pieces, &c., of linen]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Also A piece of a mazaAdap [q. v.]. (B, TA in art. bSr.) ― -b3- And A piece, or portion, [or tract,] of Hell; likewise pronounced ↓ $iq~apN. (Ham p. 816.) ― -b4- And A far journey; as also ↓ $iq~apN, (S, M, K,) sometimes thus pronounced with kesr: (S:) a far, long journey: a far-extending space: (TA:) or a road difficult to him who travels it: (Mgh:) or [simply] a journey: and i. q. vnyA [so in my copy of the Msb, app. a mistranscription for vaniy~ap, i. e. a mountain-road, &c.]: pl. $uqaqN. (Msb.) ― -b5- And A part, region, quarter, or tract, (Ibn-'Arafeh, Er-Rághib, K, TA,) towards which one draws near, (Ibn-'Arafeh, TA,) or towards which the traveller directs himself, (K, TA,) [like $uk~apN,] or in the reaching of which one is overtaken by difficulty, or distress; (Er-Rághib, TA;) And ↓ $iq~apN signifies the same. (K.) ― -b6- And Distance; and so ↓ $iq~apN. (K.) ― -b7- See also $iq~N, last sentence but one.

$iq~apN *
A splinter (S, K) that splits off, (S,) or a piece (M, Mgh, TA) split off, (M, TA,) of a plank, (S, M, K, TA,) or of wood, (TA,) or of a piece of wood, (S, Mgh,) or other thing: (M, TA:) a piece split, or divided, lengthwise, of a staff, or stick, and of a garment, or piece of cloth, &c.: (IDrd, O, K:) and a piece split (K, TA) from anything; such as the half: (TA:) pl. $iqaqN. (O, TA.) One says of him who is angry, AiHotad~a faTaArato minohu $iq~apN fiY AlA^aroDi wa$iq~apN fiY Als~amaA='i (assumed tropical:) [He became excited by sharpness of temper, or angriness, and he was as though a bit flew from him upon the ground, and a bit into the sky]. (S, * M, TA: in the S, fY AlArD &c. is omitted.) See also $iq~N, first three sentences. ― -b2- See also $uq~apN, in four places. ― -b3- And see $iq~N, again, last sentence but one.
$aqaqN * The quality, in a horse, (M, K,) and in a man, (M,) denoted by the epithet A^a$aq~u [q. v.]. (M, K.)
$aqaqapN * [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned] Enemies. (TA.)

$uqaAqN *
A cracking in several places, (ta$aq~uqN, S, K,) or cracks, (Mgh,) or a certain disease occasioning cracks, (M,) in the pasterns of horses or the like, (S, M, Mgh, K,) and in their hoofs, (M, Mgh,) and sometimes rising to their shanks: so says Yaakoob: (S:) and, accord. to Lth, (Mgh,) and Az, (TA,) a cracking in several places (ta$aq~uqN) of the skin, from cold or some other cause, in the hands or arms, and the face: (Mgh, TA:) or it signifies also any crack, or slit, in the skin, from disease: (M, TA:) As says that it is in the hand or arm, and the foot or leg, of a human being, and in the fore leg and kind leg of an animal: (Mgh, TA:) but this is inconsistent with what is said by Yaakoob [as stated voce $aq~N, first sentence]. (Mgh.) See also A^asoEadu: and $arajN.

$aqiyqN * : see $iq~N, in five places. ― -b2- $aqiyqu Albaroqi [so in a copy of the M, but the right reading may be $aqiyqapu Albaroqi, which occurs in the next sentence of the M,] i. q. Eaqiyqatuhu [expl. in the S, in art. xfw, as meaning Lightning that cleaves the clouds, and extends high, into the midst of the sky, without going to the right and left: but see $aqiyqapN]. (M.) -A2- Also A calf that has become firm, or strong: (O, K:) and applied likewise to (assumed tropical:) a man [that has become so; by way of comparison]: (O:) or a bull such as is termed ja*aEN [i. e. in his second, or third, year]. (JK.)

$aquwqapN *
A certain bird; also called ↓ $aqiyqapN: (M, K:) and ↓ $uqay~iqapN is the dim. thereof: (K:) AHát says, the ↓ $aquwqap is a very little thing, grayish (zurayoqaA='u), of the colour of ashes; ten and fifteen of what are thus called congregate; and I think it to be the ↓ $uqay~iqap, which is a dux~alap of the dux~al [q. v.]; it is somewhat dusky; and its form is the form of these, but it is smaller than they: it is called ↓ $uqay~iqap becanse of its smallness: IDrd, in the class of fuEayoEil, mentions ↓ Al$~uqay~iqu as signifying a certain species of birds [app. as a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is with p]. (O, TA.)

$aqiyqapN * [accord. to Golius, A fissure; as from the KL; but not so expl. in my copy of that work. ― -b2- ] An intervening space or tract between two elongated, or extended, tracts of sand, (S, M, * O, K, * [in the last of which Aljabalayoni is erroneously put for Aljabolayoni,]) thus expl. to AHn by an Arab of the desert, (TA,) producing herbage: (S, M, O, K:) or a rugged tract between two elongated, or extended, tracts of sand, producing good herbage; (M, TA;) so in the T, as expl. to its author by an Arab of the desert: (TA:) pl. $aqaAy^iqu, (T, S, O, K, TA,) expl. by some as meaning sands themselves: (TA:) or a great piece of sand: or a piece of sand between two pieces thereof. (Ham p. 282.) ― -b3- [In the A and TA voce qiT~u, it is used as meaning A slice cut off of a melon &c.] -A2- A rain, (M,) or a violent rain, consisting of large drops, (K, TA,) wide in extent: so called because the clouds cleave asunder from it: (M, K, TA:) pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b2- The pl., $aqaAy^iqu, is expl. by Az as signifying Clouds that have cloven asunder with copious rains. (O, TA.) ― -b3- $aqiyqapu baroqKi, (O, K,) and Eaqiyqatuhu, both as expl. by Aboo-Sa'eed, (O,) A flash of lightning that has spread (O, K) in the horizon, (O,) or from the horizon: (K: [but see $aqiyqu Albaroqi:]) or $aqiyqapN signifies a flash of lightning that has spread in the breadth of the clouds, and filled the sky: pl. as above. (Ham p. 557.) -A3- A headache, (JK, T, TA,) or a pain, (S, O, K,) or a certain disease, (M,) in the half of the head, (JK, T, S, M, O, K,) [i. e. hemicrania,] and of the face: (JK, T, S, O, K:) or, accord. to IAth, a sort of headache in the fore part of the head and towards the sides thereof. (TA.) -A4- $aqaAy^iqu Aln~uEomaAni, used alike as sing. and pl., (S, O, K,) having no proper sing., (Msb,) or its sing. is $aqiyqapN; (M, O, Msb;) [The red, or blood-coloured, anemone;] a certain plant; (M;) a certain red flower; (Lth, O;) well known; (S, K;) the $aqir; (Msb;) or, as AHn says, on the authority of AA and Aboo-Nasr and others, it is the $aqirap [n. un. of $aqirN]; and the sing. of $qAy^q is $aqiyqapN: (O, TA:) it is called $qAy^q AlnEmAn because of its redness, as being likened to the $aqiyqap of lightning: (M, K:) or from Aln~uEomaAn as meaning “ blood, ” as resembling blood in colour; (Msb, TA;) so that it signifies “ pieces of blood: ” (TA:) or in relation to En-Noamán Ibn-El-Mundhir, because he prohibited to the public a piece of land in which it abounded: (S, K, TA:) or because he alighted upon $aqaAy^iq of sand that had produced red $aqir, and he deemed them beautiful, and commanded that they should be prohibited to the public; so the $aqir were called the $qAy^q of En-Noamán, by the name of the place of their growth. (TA.) -A5- See also $aquwqapN.
$uqay~iqN * , and with p: see $aquwqapN, in four places.
$aq~aAqN * , meaning One who glories, or boasts, vainly, and praises himself for that which is not in him, is not of the [classical] language of the Arabs. (L, TA.)

$aq~iY~N * A horse with which his rider ex-
periences difficulty in striving to master him. (JK.)

$iq~iy~apN *
A certain mode of jimaAE, (K, TA,) in which the woman lies upon her $iq~ [or side]. (TA.)

$iqo$iqapN * [The bursa faucium, or faucial bag, which is placed behind the palate of the he-camel, and which, when excited, he inflates, and blows out from the side of his mouth;] a thing resembling the lungs, or lights, which the he-camel protrudes from his mouth when he is excited by lust; (S, O, K;) a skin in the fauces of the Arabian camel, which he inflates with wind, and in which he brays; whereupon it appears from the side of his mouth; so says En-Nadr; and he adds that it does not pertain to any but the Arabian camel, [as is said in the M, and] as Hr says; but this requires consideration; (TA;) [also expl. as] the lahaAp [q. v.] of the he-camel, (M, and Har p. 16,) which he protrudes from his mouth when he brays: (Har ubi suprá:) pl. $aqaA$iqu. (TA.) ― -b2- To this is likened the tongue of the chaste, or eloquent, and able speaker; himself being likened to the braying stallion-camel: (O:) and hence they say of an orator, or a preacher, that he is *uw $iqo$iqapK: (S:) one says likewise of an orator, or a preacher, that is loud in voice and skilful in speech, huwa A^ahoratu Al$iqo$iqapi [lit. He is wide, or ample, in respect of the $q$qp]: (TA:) and one says, hadarato $iqo$iqatuhu (assumed tropical:) [meaning His utterance was sonorous and fluent]. (A and TA in art. hdr.) Orators, or preachers, are also termed $aqaA$iq [for *awuw $aqaA$iqa]: and one says, fulaAnN $iqo$iqapu qawomihi, meaning (assumed tropical:) Such a one is the noble, and the chaste in speech, or eloquent, of his people. (M.) And in a trad. of 'Omar, (M, O, TA,) accord. to A'Obeyd and others, or of 'Alee accord. to Hr, (TA,) $aqaA$iq are assigned to the Devil, in his saying, A_in~a kaviyrFA mina AlxuTabi mino $aqaA$iqi Al$~ayoTaAni [lit. Verily many of the orations, or harangues, are from the $qA$q of the Devil]; because of the lying introduced into them. (M, O, * TA. *)

AlxuTobapu Al$~iqo$iqiy~apu * an appellation applied to a certain xuTobap [i. e. oration, or harangue, or sermon,] of 'Alee, because of his saying to Ibn- 'Abbás, (O, K,) on his having cut short his speech, (O,) in reply to a remark of the latter person upon his not having continued his speech uninterruptedly, tiloka $iqo$iqapN hadarato vum~a qar~ato [That was a $q$qp that uttered a braying, then became still]. (O, K.)

$aAq~N *
Difficult, hard, distressing, grievous, afflicting, troubling, molesting, fatiguing, or wearying. (KL.) One says A^amorN $aAq~N [An affair, or event, that is difficult, &c.]; from $aq~a EalayonaA AlA^amoru. (Msb.) And $uq~apN $aAq~apN (S, Msb) A long journey [that is difficult, &c.]. (Msb.)
$Af~apN * The spadix of a palm-tree, that has become a span in length; so called because it cleaves the envelope: pl. $awaAq~u. (M.)

A^a$aq~u * , (S, M, O, K,) fem. $aq~aA='u, and pl. $uq~N, (K,) applied to a horse, Wide between the hind legs: (IAar, Th, T, O, * K, * TA:) and the fem. signifies wide in the A^arofaAg [or groins, or similar parts]; (TA;) and is applied to a mare: (IDrd, O, TA:) and wide in the vulva; (IAar, O, K;) applied in this sense to a woman. (IAar, O, TA.) And A^a$aq~u Almanoxirayoni, applied to a horse, Wide in the nostrils. (Lth, O, TA.) ― -b2- Also, (O, K,) Tall, or long; (T, S, M, O, K;) applied to a horse; (T, S, M, K;) thus expl. by As; (T, TA;) and so too applied to a man: (M, TA:) and the fem., as above, applied to a mare. (S.) ― -b3- And, applied to a horse, That goes to the right and left in his running, (JK, * O, K, TA, [in the CK, yasobiqu is erroneously put for ya$otaq~u, and in like manner in my MS. copy of the K, with the additional mistranscription of mn Eadowihi for fiY Eadowihi,]) as though (O, TA) leaning upon one of his sides: (JK, O, TA:) so says Lth; and he cites as an ex.,
watabaAzayotu kamaA yamo$iY AlA^a$aq~u
[as though meaning And I moved my posteriors in walking, like as goes the horse that inclines to the right and left in his running: but this may be rendered and I stepped wide, like as does the tall, or long-bodied, horse]. (O, TA.)
ma$aq~N * [properly A place of cleaving, splitting, &c.: and hence a fissure, cleft, &c., like $aq~N: pl. ma$aAq~u]: see $aq~N. ― -b2- ma$aq~u AlEayoni [The slit of the eye]. (TA in art. HwS.)
ma$aq~apN * [said in the S and K to be an inf. n. of $aq~a trans. by means of EalaY]: see $iq~N, in the last quarter of the paragraph, in two places.

1 $aqaA^a * , (S, K,) aor.
$aqaAa , (K,) inf. n. $aqo N and $uquwo'N, said of the naAb [or tush] (S, K) of a camel, (S,) It grew forth; (S, K;) it appeared; (TA;) as also $akaA^a. (K in art. $kA^.) [See also $aq~a.] $aAqiY, with the ' softened [or changed into Y], occurs in a verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh [for the part. n. $Aqy^]. (TA.) -A2- $aqaA^a raA^osahu He divided his head; syn. $aq~ahu: [meaning, his hair:] or he separated it (far~aqahu) [i. e. his hair] with the mi$oqaA=' [or comb]: (K:) or $aqaA^a $aEarahu biAlmu$oTi, inf. n. $aqo'N, he separated his hair with the comb. (AZ, S.) ― -b2- And $aqaA^ahu, (S, K,) inf. n. $aqo'N, (S,) He hit his ma$oqaA^, i. e. the place of the parting of the hair of his head, (S, K,) with a staff, or stick. (S.)

A_ibilN $uwayoqiy^apN *
Camels of the age when the naAb [or tush] grows forth: and so $uwayokiy^apN: (As, TA:) [or $uwayokiy~apN, q. v. in art. $wk.]
ma$oqaA^N * (S, K) and ↓ ma$oqiy^N, (Fr, O, TA,) like maforaqN and maforiqN, (O, TA,) The place of the parting of the hair of the head. (Fr, S, O, K.)

mi$oqaA^N *
A comb; (IAar, S, K;) as also ↓ mi$oqaA='N and ↓ m$oqaA^apN, and mi$oqFA [or mi$oqFY]. (K: the last also mentioned in the K in art. $qw.)
ma$oqiy^N * : see ma$oqaA^N.

mi$oqaA^apN * : see mi$oqaA^N. ― -b2- Also i. q. midoraApN; (K;) [i. e. A thing, or an iron instrument, with which the head is scratched; or a thing like a large needle, with which the female hair-dresser adjusts, or puts in order, the locks of a woman's hair;] or a piece of wood, or stick, [like a skewer,] which a woman inserts in her hair; or a horn prepared for that purpose (TA) [or for adjusting the locks of a woman's hair: see midoraApN].
mi$oqaA='N * : see mi$oqaA^N.

1 $aqaHa Aln~axolu * , and ↓ $q~H, The palm-trees were, or became, goodly with their fruit. (TA.) [See also 4.] -A2- $aqaHa A@ll~`hu fulaAnFA, [inf. n. $aqoHN,] accord. to AZ, is syn. with qabaHahu A@ll~`hu [i. e. God removed such a one far from good, or prosperity, &c.; or may God remove &c.]: (TA:) [or, as may be inferred from what follows, the former of these verbs is used by some as an imitative sequent to the latter of them:] and accord. to Sb, (TA,) $aquHa, (K, TA,) inf. n. [$uqoHN and] $aqaAHapN, (TA,) is syn. with qabuHa [i. e. He, or it, was, or became, bad or evil, foul or ugly, &c.]: (K, TA:) [but in this case also it seems that the former of these verbs may be used by some as an imitative sequent to the latter of them: for] one says, qaboHFA lahu wa$aqoHFA [May removal far from good, or prosperity, &c., betide him], (S, O, K,) in which $aqoHFA is an imitative sequent to qaboHFA, or syn. therewith; (S, K;) and [in like manner] quboHFA lahu wa$uqoHFA; (O, K;) and, of a man, qabuH wa$aquHa, inf. n. of the latter as above and in like manner of the former; (S;) and jaA='a biAlqabaAHapi waAl$~aqaAHapi [He did, or said, what was bad or evil, &c.]: (K:) and ↓ huwa qabiyHN $aqiyHN [He is bad or evil, foul or ugly, &c.]: (S, * O, K: *) and ↓ qaEada maqobuwHFA ma$oquwHFA [He sat, or remained, far removed from good, or prosperity, &c.]: in like manner: (K:) but Sb intimates that ↓ $aqyiHN is not an imitative sequent, by his stating that the Arabs say $aqiyHN wa*amiymN [Bad, or evil, &c., and blamed, &c.; or, more probably, $aqiyHN wadamiymN, meaning foul and ugly]: (L, TA:) and [it is said that] ↓ $aqiyHN signifies Recovering (naAqihN [for which Freytag appears to have read naAqap]) from disease; (O, K, TA;) and hence one says, fulaAnN qabiyHN $aqiyHN [as though meaning Such a one is unsightly, being just recovering from disease]: (TA:) and accord. to AZ, ↓ ma$oqawHN is [not an imitative sequent, but] syn. with maqobuwHN: (L, TA:) in the phrase abovementioned, ma$oquwHFA is said in the 'Ináyeh to mean broken: or far removed: (TA:) or it means reviled. (O.) -A3- [As indicated above,] $aHaqahu, aor.
$aqaHa , (Lh, O, K,) inf. n. $aqoHN, (Lh, O,) also
signifies He broke it. (Lh, O, K.) One says, laA^a$oqaHan~aka $aqoHa Aljawozapi biAljanodali, i. e. I will assuredly break [or crush] thee [as in the breaking of the walnut] with stones: (O, TA: *) or I will assuredly extract all that thou hast [as in the extracting of the contents of the walnut by means of stones]: for $aqaHa Aljawozapa, inf. n. as above, means He extracted what was in the walnut. (TA.)
2 $aq~aHa see 1, first sentence: and see also 4, in three places.

3 $AqHhu *
He reviled him; or contended with him in reviling; (K, TA;) and contended with him in annoyance. (O, TA.)

4 A$qH Aln~axolu * ; (S, A, Mgh, O, K;) as also ↓ $q~H, (S, * A, Mgh, O,) inf. n. ta$oqiyHN; (S;) i. q. A^azohaY [meaning The palm-trees showed redness, or yellowness, in their fruit]: (S, A, O, K:) or their dates became altered from greenness to yellowness: (Mgh:) the former is said by As to be of the dial. of El-Hijáz: and ↓ the latter verb is also said of the [kind of tree called] A^araAk, meaning it became coloured in its fruit. (TA.) And A$qH Alt~amoru, (O,) or Albusoru, (K,) inf. n. A_i$oqaAHN; (TA;) and ↓ $q~H, (O, K,) inf. n. as above; (TA;) The dates, or the unripe dates, became coloured, (O, K,) red, or yellow: (O, TA:) or, as some say, became sweet. (TA.) The Prophet forbade the selling of dates before their becoming in this state. (S, * A, * O, TA.) -A2- A$qHhu He removed him far away. (O, K. *) -A3- A^aqobiHo bihi waA^a$oqiHo [app. How foul, or ugly, or the like, is he! as seems to be shown by what here follows]: IDrd cites,
A^aqobiHo bihi mino waladK waA^a$oqiHo
mivolu juraY~i Alkalobi laA balo A^aqobaHo
[How foul is he, as offspring, and how ugly! like the little whelp of the dog; nay, rather, more foul!]. (O.)
$uqoHN * [and inf. n. of $aquHa, q. v. ― -b2- And,] accord. to AZ, i. q. $uH~N [i. e. Niggardliness, &c.; or the being niggardly, &c.: see 1 in art. $H]. (TA.)
$aqoHapN * : see what next follows.
$uqoHapN * and ↓ $aqoHapN An unripe date altering in redness, (K,) or altered to redness. (As, TA.) ― -b2- And the former signifies The [ruddy] colour termed $uqorap. (O, K.)

Hul~apN $uqaHiy~apN *
A red [dress, or garment, such as is termed] Hul~ap: (K:) the latter word being a rel. n. from $uqoHapN meaning “ an unripe date altering to redness. ” (TA.)
$aqiyHN * : see 1, in three places.

A^a$oqaHu *
Red; (TA;) or [of a ruddy colour;] i. q. A^a$oqaru: (O, K, TA:) so says AHát. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ragowapN $aqoHaA='u [Forth, app. of milk,] that is not of a pure white hue, (O, K, TA,) but coloured. (TA.)
ma$oquwHN * : see 1, in two places.

1 $aqi*a * , aor.
$aqa*a , (S, M, L, K,) inf. n. $aqa*N, (S, M, L,) He scarcely ever, or never, slept, and had a malignant eye, affecting, or hurting, others, therewith: (S, M, L, K: *) or he had a strong, or powerful, eye, quickly affecting or hurting [others therewith]. (M, L, K.) ― -b2- And $aqi*a, (S, M, L, K,) aor.
$aqa*a ; (K;) and $aqa*a, aor.
$aqi*a ; (L, K;) He went away, (S, M, L, K,) and went far off, (S, L,) being driven away. (S, L, K.)
3 $Aq*hu * , (S, L,) inf. n. mu$aAqa*apN, (K,) He regarded him, or treated him, with enmity, or hostility. (S L, K.)
4 A$q*hu * , (inf. n. A_i$oqaA*N, L,) He drove him away. (S, M, L, K.)
$aqo*N * : see $aqa*aAnN, in three places.
$ufo*N * : see $aqa*aAnN, in four places: ― -b2- and see also $aqa*N.
$iqo*N * : see $aqa*aAnN, in three places.

$aqa*N * : see $aqa*aAnN. ― -b2- maA bihi $aqa*N walaA naqa*N There is not in him any motion. (IAar, S, L.) ― -b3- And, (L, K, in the CK mA bh $aqo*N wlA naqo*N,) as also mA wlA nuqo*u ↓ bh $uqo*N, (K,) There is not in it (namely, a commodity, or household furniture, L) any fault, or defect: and there is not in it (namely, language, or speech, L) any defect, imperfection, or unsoundness. (L, K. *) ― -b4- And maA lahu $aqa*N walaA naqa*N He possesses not anything. (L, K.) ― -b5- And maA duwnahu $aqa*N walaA naqa*N There is not anything to be feared, nor anything to be disliked, in the way to the attainment thereof. (Meyd, TA.)
$aqi*N * : see $aqa*aAnN, in six places.
$uqa*N * : see $aqa*aAnN, in two places.
$iqa*N * : see $aqa*aAnN, in the latter half.
$iqo*apN * and $aqi*apN: see $aqa*aAnN, near the end; the latter, in two places.
$aqa*aY * : see what next follows.

EuqaAbN $aqo*aA='u *
An eagle vehemently hungry, (S, M, L, K,) and eager in seeking food; (M, L;) as also ↓ $aqa*aY. (K.) A poet likens a horse thereto. (M, L.)
$iqo*aAnN * , as a sing. n.: see $aqa*aAnN (of which it is also a pl.), in two places, near the end.

$aqa*aAnN * One who scarcely ever, or never, sleeps; (S, M, L, K;) as also ↓ $aqi*N; (S, M, K;) and who has a malignant eye, (S, M,) affecting, or hurting, others therewith; as also ↓ $aqi*N (S, M, K, in the TA $aqo*N,) and ↓ $aqiy*N: (M:) or who has a strong, or powerful, eye, quickly affecting or hurting [others therewith]; (M, L, K;) as also ↓ $aqi*N and ↓ $aqiy*N: (M:) and AlEayoni ↓ $aqi*u one who scarcely ever, or never, sleeps; whom drowsiness does not overcome. (T, L.) ― -b2- Also Driven away, and remote; and so ↓ $aqi*N. (L.) ― -b3- And $aqa*aAnapN A light-spirited woman: (Th, M, L:) foul, or obscene, in her speech; clamorous, and foul-tongued. (T, L.) -A2- Also The male chameleon; (M, L, K;) and so ↓ $aqi*N and ↓ $iqo*N and ↓ $uqo*N: or all these words signify a slender and compact male chameleon, with a small head, that cleaves to the trunk of the kind of tree called EiDaAh: (M, L:) pl. $iqo*aAnN (M, L, K) and $aqaA*aY: (M:) the former pl. like kirowaAnN, pl. of karawaAnN; (L;) and also used as a sing., meaning a male chameleon; (Th, M;) thus used by a poetess; (M:) also ↓ $iqo*N (S, M, L, K) and ↓ $uqo*N (M, L) and ↓ $uqa*N (M, L, K) and ↓ $aqo*N (K) the young one of a chameleon: (Lh, S, M, L, K:) pl. $iqo*aAnN (S, M, L, K) and $aqaA*aY: (M, L, K:) the former pl. like SinowaAnN, pl. of SinowN. (S.) A poet says, describing asses,
raA^ati Al$~aqaA*aY taSoTaliY
faraEato bihaA Hat~aY A_i*aA
And they pastured therein until the heat became vehement and they saw the male chameleons thirsty, desiring to go to water, and repairing to the sun: some say, that $qA*Y here signifies moths, (faraA$), but this is a mistake. (M, L.) $iqo*aAnN also signifies The animals called Dab~ and waral and TuHan and saAm~u A^aboraS and das~aAsap: and the sing. is ↓ $iqo*apN: (M, L:) or any small animals that creep or walk upon the earth, and venomous or noxious reptiles and the like: (M, L, K:) sing. ↓ $aqi*apN (M, L) and ↓ $iqa*N, (M,) or ↓ $aqi*N, (L,) and ↓ $uqa*N, (M,) or ↓ $aqa*N; (L;) but it does not appear how ↓ $aqi*apN can be a sing. of $iqo*aAnN unless the augmentative letter be regarded as elided. (M, L.) ― -b2- Also The wolf; (M, L, K;) and so ↓ $aqo*aAnN (Th, M, L, K) and ↓ $uqo*N, (M, L,) or ↓ $iqo*N, (K,) or ↓ $aqo*N. (TA.) ― -b3- Also The hawk; syn. SaqorN; (M, L;) and so ↓ $aqo*aAnN (Th, M, L) and ↓ $uqo*N, (M, L,) or ↓ $aqo*N. (TA.) ― -b4- And $iqo*aAnN [the pl.] also signifies The young ones of the kinds of birds called HbaAraY and qaTFA (M, L, K) and the like. (M, L.)
$aqiy*N * : see $aqa*aAnN, in two places.

TarodN mi$oqa*N *
A driving far away. (M, L.)

1 $aqira * , aor.
$aqara , inf. n. $aqarN (M, L, Msb, K [in the CK and TA $aqorN, which is evidently wrong,]) and $uqorapN, (Lth, K,) or the latter is a simple subst.; (M;) and $aqura; and ↓ Ai$oqar~a; (M, K;) He was, or became, of the colour termed $uqorapN. (M, L, Msb, K.)
9 A_i$oqar~a see 1.
$aqorN * : see $uquwrN.

$aqirN * [The red, or blood-coloured, anemone;] i. q. $aqaAy^iqu Aln~uEomaAni: (S, M, A, Msb, K:) it is not a sweet-scented flower: (Msb:) n. un. with p; (S, M, Msb, K;) pl. [of the n. un.] $aqiraAtN: (K:) as
also ↓ $uq~aArN and ↓ $aqiraAnN, (so in some copies of the K,) the latter so written by IDrd and Sgh, and thought by IDrd to be a place or a plant, (TA,) or ↓ $uqoraAnN, (so in some copies of the K and in the TA,) and ↓ $uq~aAraY and ↓ $uqaAraY: (K:) or $aqirN is the name of a certain other plant, not the $qAy^q, but red like it: (M, * K, * TA:) or it signifies cinnabar: (A:) or $aqirapN has this signification, (T, K,) as well as that first assigned to it above: (K:) and accord. to AHn, (M, TA,) ↓ $uq~aAraY is the name of a certain plant (S, M, TA) that grows is sands, having a pungent odour, which is tasted in the flavour of milk: and he adds that, accord. to some, it is the same as the $aqir; but that this opinion is not well founded: (M, TA:) it is also said that it is a certain plant having a flower of a dingy red colour, the seed, or grain, of which is called ximoximN: (TA:) and that ↓ $uq~aAraY (M, TA) and ↓ $uqaAraY, (M,) or ↓ $uq~aArN, (TA,) are names of a certain plant, having a flower of a colour somewhat of that termed $ukolapN, with slender, or delicate, dust-coloured leaves, which grows in the manner of qaDob [a kind of trefoil], is approved in pasturage, and grows only in fruitful years. (M, TA.)
jaA='a biAl$~uqari waAlbuqari * : see jA=' biAlS~uqari waAlbuqari, in art. Sqr.
$uqorapN * The colours described in the explanations of the epithet A^a$oqaru, below. (S, M, Msb, &c.)
$aqiraAnN * , or $uqoraAnN: see $aqirN.
$aqir~aAqN * and its vars.: see in art. $qrq.
$aquwrN * : see the next paragraph, in four places.

$uquwrN * (AHeyth, Fr, A'Obeyd, S, K) and ↓ $aquwrN (AHeyth, As, Abu-l-Jarráh, S, K) A want; or a needful, or requisite, thing, affair, or business: (S, K:) or the former signifies wants: (Ham p. 716:) A'Obeyd says that the former word is the more correct, because $uquwrN signifies things, or affairs, that cleave to the heart, disquieting it; and is pl. of ↓ $aqorN; and that ↓ $aquwrN, with fet-h, has the signification of an epithet [meaning cleaving to the heart and disquieting it]: (S:) or, accord. to some, this latter signifies grief, mourning, sorrow, or sadness; disquietude of mind: or disquietude of mind that causes one to be sleepless: the former is also expl. as signifying a man's case, and his secret: and ↓ both are also said to signify tidings: and a man's state, or condition. (TA.) One says, A^axobarotuhu bi$uquwriY I acquainted him with my want; like as one says A^afoDayotu A_ilayohi biEujariY wabujariY: (S:) or I acquainted him with my tidings. (TA.) And A^afoDayotu A_ilayohi bi$uquwriY I acquainted him with my case, and with what I kept secret from others; (TA;) and so nafaDotu lahu $uquwriY: (Ham p. 716:) or I revealed to him my secret, and acquainted him with all my affairs. (Mgh.) And ↓ bav~ahu $aquwrahu, and $uquwrahu, He complained to him of his state, or condition. (M, TA.)
$uqaAraY * : see $aqirN, in two places: -A2- and see also jaA='a biAlS~uqari waAlbuqari, in art. Sqr.
$uq~aArN * : see $aqirN, in two places.
$uq~aAraY * : see $aqirN, in three places.

A^a$oqaru * , applied to a man, [Of a ruddy complexion combined with fairness: or] of a clear ruddy complexion, with the outer skin inclining to white: (S:) or having a red, or ruddy, tinge, over a white, or fair, complexion: (M, Msb, K:) and applied to a horse, [of a sorrel colour;] of a clear red colour, (S, IF, Msb,) or of a red colour inclining to [the dull red hue called] mugorapN, (M, K,) with a red mane and tail: (S, M, K:) when the mane and tail are black, the epithet kumayotN [meaning bay, or dark bay, or brown,] is applied to the horse: (S:) the A$qr is said to be the best of horses: (IAar, M: [but it is said in Har p. 399 to be regarded by the Arabs as of evil omen:]) and applied to a camel, intensely red: (S:) or of a colour resembling that of a horse thus termed: (M:) fem. $aqoraA='u: and pl. $uqorN. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also, applied to blood, That has become thick, (maA SaAra EalaqFA, M, Msb, TA,) and not been overspread with dust. (Msb, TA.) ― -b3- And the fem., $aqoraA='u, is used as [a subst.] signifying Fire. (Ham p. 718.)

$aqir~aAqN * and $iqir~aAqN, (S, O, Msb, K,) the former accord. to IAar, (Th, TA,) the latter accord. to Fr, (TA,) but disallowed by IKt, and asserted by him to be a mispronunciation of the vulgar, (Msb,) and $iqoraAqN, (Msb, K,) and $aqoraAqN, (accord. to the CK,) and, (S, O, K,) as they sometimes said, (S, O,) $iriqoraAqN, (S, O, K,) and $araqoraAqN, and $araqoraqN, (K,) [the first and second now applied to The green wood-pecker, picus viridis: and to the common roller, coracias garrula:] a certain bird, (S, O, Msb, K,) well known, (K,) among the Arabs, (Fr, TA,) called A^axoyal, (Fr, S, O, Msb, TA,) [a name likewise now applied to the green wood-pecker,] and regarded by the Arabs as of evil omen; (S;) less than the pigeon, the colour of which is green, and the beak black, and having blackness in the extremities and exterior of its wings: (Msb:) accord. to IAar, the $aqir~aAq is with the Arabs the A^axoTab [q. v.]: (TA:) accord. to the K, or $qr~Aq and $rqrAq accord. to Lth, (TA,) a certain bird speckled, or spotted, with green and red and white (K, TA) and black, (TA,) and found, accord. to the copies of the K, in the land of the Haram, but correctly, as in the words of Lth, bArD Aljrm, thus, with j, [perhaps rightly biAlA^aroDi Aljaromi, in the land that is hot, or very hot,] in the places in which palm-trees grow; of the size of the hudohud [or hoopoe]: accord. to Lh, $qr~Aq is of the measure fEl~Al: $rqrAq is mentioned by J and Sgh [as well as in the K] in the present art.; but should, properly, be mentioned under the head of $rqrq, as it is in the L. (TA.)

2 $q~Shu * , (L, TA,) inf. n. ta$oqiySN, (L, Mgh, K,) He divided it into parts, or portions: (Mgh:) or he cut it up, and separated its members (A, L, K *) into just portions among the sharers; (L, K; *) namely, a slaughtered animal, (K,) or particularly a slaughtered sheep or goat, and a pig: (L, A, TA:) or he divided it (namely, a pig,) into parts or portions, and members, for eating and selling. (Mgh.) Hence the trad. mano baAEa Alxamora faloyu$aqiSi AlxanaAziyra (L, A) He who sells wine, let him cut up swine and divide their members, as is done to a sheep or goat when its flesh is sold: meaning, he who holds the selling of wine to be lawful, let him hold the selling of swine to be so; for they are equally forbidden. (L, TA.)

$iqoSN *
