A piece, or part, of a thing; (S, M, Mgh, Msb;) as also ↓ $aqiySN: (M, Mgh:) or a little, of much; (M, TA;) as also ↓ the latter: (IDrd, M, K:) and ↓ the latter, a little, or paltry, thing: (TA:) and the former, a piece of land: (S:) or a share; syn. sahomN, (A, K,) or HaZ~N, (M,) and naSiybN, (A, Mgh, K,) and $irokN, (A, K,) which signifies the same as naSiybN; (Sh, on the authority of Khálid;) as also ↓ $aqiySN; (Sh, M, Mgh, K;) like niSofN and naSiyfN: (M:) as, for instance, in property; (IDrd;) and of a slave: (TA:) or a certain share not divided: (EshSháfi'ee, TA:) or if divided it may also be thus called: (Az, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^a$oqaASN (M, Msb) and [of mult.] $iqaASN. (M, TA.)

$aqiySN * : see $iqoSN, throughout. -A2- Also A sharer, or partner. (S, A, K.) You say, huwa $aqiySY He is my sharer, or partner, (S, A,) in a piece of land. (S.) -A3- And A fleet, or swift, and excellent horse: (K:) but an epithet not known to Lth. (TA.)

mi$oqaSN *
A broad naSol [or iron head] (IDrd, Msb, K) of an arrow: (IDrd:) or an arrow having such a nSl, (Lth, IF, K,) with which wild animals are shot; (Lth;) but Az says that this explanation is at variance with what has been heard from the Arabs: (TA:) or it signifies, (M,) or signifies also, (K,) a long nSl; (M, K;) not a broad one: (M:) or an arrow having such a nSl; (M;) with which wild animals are shot: (K:) or a long and broad nSl: (S:) or it is of half the size of a nSl, and is worthless; children play with it, and it is the worst kind of arrow [-head], and is used for shooting at objects of the chase and any other thing: (TA:) pl. ma$aAqiSu. (S.)

mu$aqiSN *
A butcher. (A, K.)

1 $aqiYa * , (S, Msb, K,) originally $aqiwa, (S, TA,) aor.
$aqawa , (S, Msb,) dual thereof ya$oqayaAni, (S,) inf. n. $aqaAwapN and $iqaAwapN, (S, * K,) the latter accord. to a reading of the Kur xxiii. 108, (S,) and $aqaA='N and $iqowapN and $aqowapN (S, * K) and $aqFA, (K.) or the last of these is the inf. n., and $aqaAwapN and $iqowapN [and the rest, none of which is expressly specified as an inf. n. in the S,] are simple substs., (Msb,) He
was, or became, unprosperous, unfortunate, unhappy, or miserable; (S, Msb, TA;) $aqiYa being contr. of saEida; (Msb;) and $aqaAwapN &c. contr. of saEaAdapN: (S, TA:) or he was, or became, in a state of straitness, distress, adversity, or difficulty. (Az, K, TA.) [See also $aqaAwapN below.] ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) He suffered, or experienced, fatigue, (TA, and Ksh and Bd and Jel in xx. 1,) fiY ka*aA [in such a thing]. (TA.) -A2- $aqaAhu: see 3: ― -b2- and 4.

3 $AqAhu * , (K, TA,) inf. n. mu$aAqaApN (S, TA) and $iqaA='N, (TA,) He laboured, strove, or struggled, with him, to prevail, or overcome, (S, K, TA,) in war, or battle, and the like; (K, TA;) so in the T; (TA;) he struggled, or contended, with, or against, the difficulty, or trouble, or inconvenience, that he experienced from him; (S, * TA;) syn. EaAlajahu; (K, TA;) or maArasahu; and EaAnaAhu. (S, * TA.) ― -b2- And ↓ $AqAhu fa$aqaAhu, aor. of the latter verb
$aquwa , He endeavoured to surpass him in mutual labouring, or striving, or struggling, to prevail, or overcome, &c., (gaAlabahu fiY Al$~iqaA='i, [in the CK, fY Al$~aqA'i, but the former seems to be the right reading, and may be best rendered in the mutual striving against difficulty,]) and he surpassed him [therein]. (K. [In the S, $aAqaAniY fulaAnN fa$aqawotuhu, aor. A^a$oquwhu; and only the latter verb as thus used is there explained.]) ― -b3- mu$aAqaApN signifies also (assumed tropical:) The treating [one] with hardness, harshness, or illnature. (TA.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) The vying, one with another, in patience, or endurance: a rájiz says,
A_i*aA yu$aAqiY AlS~aAbiraAni lamo yarivo
yakaAdu mino DaEofi AlquwaY laA yanobaEivo
[When the two patient ones vie in endurance, he does not lag behind, almost, by reason of the weakness of powers, failing to hasten in pace]: he means a camel vying with the attendant thereof in endurance of going. (TA.)

4 A$qAhu A@ll~`hu *
God caused him to be unprosperous, unfortunate, unhappy, or miserable; contr. of A^asoEadahu: (S, * Msb, TA:) or God caused him to be in a state of straitness, distress, adversity, or difficulty: and so ↓ $aqaAhu. (K.) -A2- And A$qY He combed. (AZ, K. [See mi$oqFY.])
$iqowapN * an inf. n. of $aqiYa, as also $aqowapN: (S, * K:) or a simple subst. (Msb.)

$aqiY~N *
Unprosperous, unfortunate, unhappy, or miserable: (S, Msb, TA:) [or in a state of straitness, distress, adversity, or difficulty: (see its verb:)] pl. A^a$oqiyaA='u. (TA.) walamN A^akuno biduEaAy^ika rab~i $aqiy~FA, in the Kur [xix. 4, And I have not been, in supplicating Thee, my Lord, unprosperous], means I have been one whose prayer has been answered. (TA.)

$aqaAwapN * an inf. n. of $aqiYa; (S, * K;) or a simple subst.; (Msb;) signifying Unprosperousness, &c.; [see its verb;] contr. of saEaAdapN: (S, Er-Rághib, TA:) it is of two kinds; A^uxoraAwiy~apN [relating to the world to come] and dunoyaAwiy~apN [relating to the present world]: and the latter is of three kinds; nafosiy~apN [relating to the soul] and badaniy~apN [relating to the body] and xaArijiy~apN [relating to external circumstances]. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Fatigue; syn. taEabN; but the latter has a more general signification; every $qAwp being tEb, but every tEb is not $qAwp. (TA.)
A^a$oqaY * [More, and most, unprosperous, &c. ― -b2- And] (tropical:) More [and most] fatigued. (TA.)

mi$oqFY *
A comb: a dial. var. of mi$oqaA^N. (AZ, K.)

1 $aqaY * , inf. n. $aqoYN, said of the naAb [or tush] of a camel, It grew forth: a dial. var. of $aqaA^a. (K in art. $qw [but belonging to the present art.: mentioned in the TA, as not in the K, on the authority of ISd].) ― -b2- [Freytag states, as on the authority of Abu-l-'Alà, that $aqaY is used for $aq~a He clave, or split, &c.: ― -b3- and that Reiske has explained it as signifying He opened the mouth with a wide grinning (“ amplo rictu ” ).]

$aAqK *
A long prominence, or projecting portion, or ledge, (HayodN TaAliEN TawiylN,) of a mountain, (K, TA,) that cannot be ascended: (TA:) by rule it should be with ' [i. e. $aAqiy^N, as being derived from $aqaA^a]: (Sgh, TA:) pl. $awaAqiY (K [correctly $awaAqK]) and $uqoyaAnN. (TA. [Mentioned in the K in art. $qw, but belonging to the present art.])

1 $ak~a * is intrans. by itself, and trans. by means of the particle fY: ― -b2- one says $ak~a AlA^amoru, aor. ya$uk~u [contr. to analogy in the case of an intrans. verb of this class], inf. n. $ak~N, The thing, or case, or affair, was, or became, dubious, or confused: (Msb:) ― -b3- and $ak~a fiyhi, (MA, K,) first pers. $akakotu fyh, (S, Msb,) aor. as above, (JM, PS, &c.,) and so the inf. n., (MA, &c.,) He doubted, wavered or vacillated in opinion, or was uncertain, respecting it; (MA, Msb, and so accord. to explanations of $ak~N [q. v. infrà] in the S and Msb and K &c.;) syn. AirotaAba; (Msb;) and ↓ t$k~k signifies the same. (S, K.) ― -b4- $ak~a EalaY~a AlA^amoru means $aq~a [i. e. The case, or affair, was difficult, hard, distressing, &c., to me]: (O, TA:) or, as some say, [was such that] I doubted ($akakotu) respecting it. (TA.) -A2- $ak~a said of a camel, (IAar, S, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S,) He limped, or halted; or had a slight lameness, (IAar, S, TA,) of his hind leg: (IAar, TA:) or his arm stuck to his side, (K, TA,) and he had a slight lameness in consequence thereof: (TA:) and ↓ A$tk~, likewise said of a camel, he had a slight lameness; (Ibn-'Abbád, O, TA;) like $ak~a. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.) ― -b2- $ak~N also signifies The cleaving or sticking [of a thing to another thing]. (S, O, TA.) So in a verse of Aboo-Dahbal El-Jumahee cited voce yalabN. (S.) And one says, $ak~ati Alr~aHimu The relationship was, or became, closely united. (O, TA. [See raHimN $aAk~apN, voce $aAk~N.]) ― -b3- $ak~a fiY Als~ilaAHi, (K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He put on [or around him,] or attired himself with, the arms, or weapons, completely, not leaving any of them; (TA;) [as though] he entered amid them. (K, TA.) -A3- $akakotuhu biAlr~umoHi, (S, O, Msb, in the K $ak~ahu,) and biAls~ahomi, and the like, aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (Msb, TA,) I pierced, or transpierced, him, or it, (TaEanotuhu, Msb, or xazaqotuhu, O, and in like manner in the TA, but in my copies of the S xaraqotuhu [meaning I made a hole in him, or it], and thus in one place in the TA, and AinotaZamotuhu, S O, and in like manner in the K,) with the spear, (S, O, Msb, K,) and with the arrow, &c.: (TA:) but IDrd says that, accord. to some, $ak~N is only by the conjoining two things with an arrow or a spear: (O, TA:) [thus,] fa$ak~a rijolahu maEa rikaAbihi means And he clave and transpierced his leg, or foot, together with his stirrup. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [Hence,] $akakotu A_ilayohi AlbilaAda I traversed, or crossed, or cut through, the countries, or districts, to him. (O, TA.) ― -b3- And $uk~a Ealayih Alv~awobu The garment was put [or drawn] together upon him, and fastened with a thorn or a wooden pin: or was let down, or made to hang down, upon him. (TA.) ― -b4- $ak~uwA buyuwtahumo They placed their tents in one row, or series, (O, Msb, K,) in one regular order, (T, TA,) near together. (Msb.) ― -b5- Hence; $ak~uwA AlA^aroHaAma They made the relationships to be closely connected. (Msb.) And $uk~a He was made, or asserted, to be connected with the lineage of another. (IAar, O.) ― -b6- And $akakotuhu said of anything means I drew and joined, or adjoined, it [to another thing]. (Msb.) [And I infixed it in, or thrust it into, another thing.] ― -b7- maA $ak~a kafiY xaliyluhaA, [or, more probably, mA $uk~a,] a phrase in a verse of El-Farezdak,] in which it forms an apodosis,] means maA qaArana [i. e., app., Its friend (the sword, or the spear, both of which are meanings of Alxaliyl,) would not be conjoined (or grasped) with my hand]. (TA.) ― -b8- $ak~a Alv~awoba He (the sewer) made the stitch-holes far apart [in sewing the garment, or piece of cloth]. (O, TA.) [Thus the verb has two contr. meanings.] -A4- $akikotu A_ilayohi, with kesr, and $akikotuhu, (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, and so in the K accord. to the TA, as also in the TK, in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K $akakotuhu and Alyh,) I inclined to him, or it; or trusted to, or relied upon, him, or it, so as to be, or become, easy, or quiet, in mind; or leaned, rested, or relied, upon him, or it; syn. rakanotu. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

2 $k~knY fiyhi * , (S, O, K, *) inf. n. ta$okiykN, (O,) He made me to doubt, to waver or vacillate in opinion, or to be uncertain, respecting it; (S, K, TA;) he threw me, or made me to fall, into doubt, &c., respecting it. (O.)
5 ta$ak~a3a see the first paragraph.
8 A_i$otaka3a see the first paragraph.

$ak~N * [used as a subst.] signifies Doubt; (Msb; [see 1;]) or the contr. of yaqiynN; (S, O, Msb, K;) by which explanation is meant a wavering or
vacillation in opinion between two things, whether they be equal [in probability] or such that one of them outweighs [therein] the other; or, as the expositors explain its meaning in the Kur x. 94, uncertainty: (Msb:) or a wavering or vacillation in opinion, between two inconsistent things, without making either of them to outweigh the other in the estimation of him who conceives the $ak~: or, as some say, a pausing, or hesitation, between two extremes that are equal [in probability], without the mind's inclining to either of them: when one of them is made to outweigh, without the other's being rejected, it is Zan~N: (KT:) accord. to Er-Rághib, it is the alternation, or confusedness, of two inconsistent things, in the judgment of a man, and their being equal: this is sometimes because of there being two indications, equal in his judgment, of the two inconsistent things; or of there being no indication thereof: and sometimes it relates to the question whether a thing be, or be not; and sometimes, to the question of what kind it is; and sometimes, to some of its qualities; and sometimes, to the accident that is the cause of its being: it is a species of jahol; but is more special than this; for jhl is sometimes the utter nonexistence of knowledge of the two inconsistent things; so that every $k~ is jhl, but every jhl is not $k~: (TA:) accord. to some, the primary meaning is a state of commotion, or disturbance, of the heart and mind: (Msb:) pl. $ukuwkN. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence, yawomu Al$~aki The day of which one doubts whether it be the last of one month or the first of the next month: and generally, whether it be the last of Shaabán or the first of Ramadán; and to fast on this day is forbidden.] -A2- Also A small crack in a bone. (K.) ― -b2- And A seam, or line of sewing, of a garment. (L in art. SwH.) ― -b3- [And accord. to Freytag, A coat of mail composed of narrow rings: but he names no authority for this.] -A3- And [Arsenic;] a certain medicament, that destroys rats; brought from Khurásán, from the mines of silver; (K, TA;) of two kinds, (TA,) white and yellow; (K, TA;) now known by the name of sam~u AlfaA^ori [ratsbane]. (TA.)

$ik~N *
A covering (Hul~ap) that is put upon the backs of the two curved extremities of the bow: (K:) so says ISd. (TA.)
$ak~apN * [an inf. n. of un.] A single piercing through two men on a horse. (Ham p. 271.)

$uk~apN *
i. q. $uq~apN: (O, K:) so in the saying, A_in~ah labaEiydu Al$~uk~api [Verily he is one whose region to which he directs himself is far distant]. (O.)

$ik~apN *
Arms, or weapons, (S, K, TA,) that are worn. (TA.) ― -b2- And A broad piece of wood, (K,) or small broad piece of wood, (S, O,) that is put into the hole (xurot) [in which is inserted the end of the handle] of the axe, or adz, and the like, in order to narrow it. (IDrd, S, O, K.) -A2- rajulN muxotalifu Al$~ik~api means A man discordant in natural dispositions. (TA.)
$akikN * A camel having a slight lameness; that limps, or halts. (TA.)

$ukukN * , with two dammehs, [a pl. of which the sing., in the sense here indicated, is not mentioned,] i. q. A^adoEiyaA='u [Persons who make a claim in respect of relationship; or who claim to be sons of persons not their fathers; or who are claimed as sons by persons not their father; or adopted sons: pl. of daEiY~N]. (IAar, TA.) -A2- [Also said to be pl. of $akiykapN, q. v.]

$ikaAkN *
Tents arranged in a row: (O, K:) one says, DarabuwA buyuwtahumo $ikaAkFA They pitched their tents in one row: but accord. to Th, it is sikaAkFA, [q. v.], from Als~ik~apu. (TA.)

$akuwkN * (tropical:) A she-camel of which one doubts whether she be fat or not (S, K, TA) in her hump, (K, TA,) by reason of the abundance of her fur, wherefore her hump is felt: (S, TA:) pl. $uk~N. (K.)

$ukuwkN *
Sides; syn. jawaAnibu. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, TA.) [Perhaps pl. of $akaAkapN (q. v.), next after which it is mentioned in the O; like as SuliY~N (originally SuluwYN) is pl. of SalaAyapN.]

$akaAkapN *
A region, quarter, or tract, syn. naAHiyapN, of the earth. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

$akiykapN *
A party, sect, or distinct body or class, (AA, S, O, K,) of men: (AA, S, O:) pl. $akaAy^iku; (AA, S;) [and app. $ikakN also, for,] accord. to IAar, $ikakN signifies distinct bodies of soldiers. (TA.) -A2- A way, course, mode, or manner, of acting or conduct or the like: (IDrd, O, K:) thus in the saying, daEohu EalaY $akiykatihi [Leave thou him intent on pursuing his way, &c.]: (IDrd, O:) pl. $akaAy^iku (IDrd, O, K) and $ukukN, (so in copies of the K,) or $ikakN; if the latter of these two, extr. [with respect to analogy]. (TA.) ― -b2- And Natural disposition; syn. xuluqN. (TK, as from the K. [The only reading that I find in copies of the K is with H in the place of x, i. e. Haloq; and thus, but without any vowel-sign, in the TA: but I think that the right reading is evidently that in the TK.]) -A3- Also The [kind of basket called] sal~ap in which are [put] fruits. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K, *) -A4- And [the pl.] $akaAy^iku signifies The pieces of wood with which, they being joined together, are formed the tent-like tops of the vehicles called hawaAdij [pl. of hawodajN]. (AA, O, TA.)
$ukuk~apN * , applied to a woman, meaning Just in proportion, or beautiful, and slender; or light, or active, in her work; and clever; is vulgar. (TA.)

$ak~iY~N * , (so in the O, occurring there in three instances,) or $uk~iY~N, (thus in the K, [but if this were the right reading, the rule of the author would require him to add “ with damm, ” therefore I suppose it to have been mistranscribed in an early copy of the K,]) applied to a lijaAm [i. e. bit, or bridle], Difficult. (O, K.) [See also $ak~iY~N in art. $kw and $kY.]
$ak~aAkN * : see $aAk~N.

$ako$akapN *
Sharp arms or weapons: (IAar, O, K:) or the sharpness of arms or weapons: (K:) or the latter should be the meaning accord. to analogy. (O.)

$aAk~N * [act. part. n. of $ak~a]. ― -b2- rajulN $aAk~u Als~ilaAHi and $aAk~N fiY Als~ilaAHi [A man completely armed]: the former expl. as meaning a man wearing a complete set of arms, or weapons: [pl. $uk~aAkN, agreeably with analogy:] you say qawomN $uk~aAkN fiY AlHadiydi [a people, or party, completely clad in sets of iron arms or weapons]. (S, O. [In one of my copies of the S, biAlHadiydi.]) [Accord. to the TA, one says mino qawomK $uk~aAkK ↓ rajulN $ak~aAkN: but $ak~aAkN seems evidently to be a mistranscription for $aAk~N. See also $aAku Als~ilaAHi and $aAkiY Als~ilaAHi in arts. $wk and $kw.] ― -b3- raHimN $aAk~apN Near relationship. (O, TA. [See $ak~ati Alr~aHimu.]) -A2- See also what next follows.

$aAk~apN *
A tumour in the fauces; (O, K;) mostly in children: (O:) pl. $awaAk~u: or, accord. to Abu-lJarráh, the sing. of $awaAk~u is ↓ $aAk~N, meaning the tumour. (TA.)

mi$ak~N * The thong with which the coat of mail is [in certain parts thereof] conjoined (yu$ak~u bihi): 'Antarah says,
wami$ak~i saAbigapK hatakotu furuwjahaA
biAls~ayofi Eano HaAmiY AlHaqiyqapi muEolami
(O, TA:) [but in the EM it is masak~i, thus with s, and with fet-h to the m; a word which I do not find in any lexicon: it is said that] msk signifies a coat of mail narrow in the rings: and the poet means, And of many an ample coat of mail [narrow in the rings] have I rent open the middle parts with the sword, from over a man who was the defender of those who, or that which, it was his duty to defend, who was pointed to as being the cavalier of the army. (EM p. 243.)

A^amorN ma$okuwkN * [for ma$okuwkN fiyhi] An affair, or a case, in which there is doubt. (TA.) -A2- minobarN ma$okuwkN e. q. ma$oduwd [i. e. A pulpit made firm or strong &c.]. (TA. [See also masokuwk.])

1 $akadahu * , aor.
$akuda . (S, L) and
$akida , (L,) inf. n. $akodN; (S, L, K;) and ↓ A$kdhu, (M, L,) but this latter, which is erroneously said in the copies of the K to be syn. with $ak~ada, instead of $akada, is, accord. to ISd, not of high authority; (TA;) He gave him: (S, L, K:) or he gave him a thing as a free gift. (L.)

4 A$kdhu *
He gave him of dates on their being cut, and of wheat on its being reaped. (L.) He gave him of a heap of reaped corn on the occasion of measuring, and of the bundles (Huzam) [of corn] on the occasion of reaping: of the dial. of ElYemen. (L.) He gave him food to eat, or milk to drink, after it had been deposited in the house or tent. (L.) ― -b2- See also 1.

10 Ast$kd *
He sought, or demanded, what is termed $ukod [q. v.]. (L.) ― -b2- And jaA='a yasota$okiduniY He came seeking, or demanding, of me $ukod; meaning what is given of a heap of reaped corn on the occasion of measuring, and of the bundle (Huzam) [of corn] on the occasion of reaping: of the dial. of El-Yemen. (L.)

$ukodN *
A gift: (S, L, K:) or a free gift: pl. A^a$okaAdN. (L.) A recompense. (L.) [See $ukomN in two places.] What is given of dates when they are cut, and of wheat when it is reaped. (L.) What is given of a heap of reaped corn on the occasion of the measuring, and of the bundles (Huzam) [of corn] on the occasion of the reaping: of the dial. of El-Yemen. (L.) Travelling-provisions with which one is furnished, consisting of milk, or [the preparation of dried curd called] A^aqiT, or clarified butter, or dates, and with which one goes forth from the abodes of a people. (L.) And Meat and drink deposited in a house or tent. (L.)

1 $akara lahu * , and $akarahu, (S, Mgh, K,) but the former is the more chaste, (S,) and the latter is for $akara niEomatahu, (A,) aor.
$akura , (TA,) inf. n. $ukorN and $ukoraAnN (S, A, * Msb, K) and $ukuwrN, (S, K) which last, in the Kur lxxvi. 9, may be either an inf. n. or pl. of $ukorN [used as a simple subst.], (S,) He thanked him; or praised, eulogized, or commended, him, for a benefit or benefits: (S:) he was grateful, or thankful, to him; or he acknowledged his beneficence, and spoke of it largely: (S, * K: [but in the S, the verb in the former sense has $ukorN only for its inf. n., and it is implied that in the latter sense it has for its inf. n. only $ukoraAnN, as will be seen below:]) and $akara lil~`hi, and $akara A@ll~`ha, (Lh, Msb, K,) which latter is less common than the former, and even disallowed by As in prose, though allowed by him in verse, (Msb,) and $akara biA@ll~`hi and $akara niEomapa A@ll~`hi, and $akara biniEomapi A@ll~`hi, (Lh, K,) and $akara lil~`hi niEomatahu, (A,) inf. n. $ukorN and $ukoraAnN (Msb) [and $ukuwrN], He thanked, or praised, God for his beneficence: (A:) he was grateful, or thankful, to God; or acknowledged his beneficence, and spoke of it largely: (K:) he acknowledge the beneficence of God, and acted in the manner incumbent on him in rendering Him obedience and abstaining from disobedience; so that $ukor is in word and in deed: (Msb:) and lahu ↓ ta$ak~ara signifies the same as $akara lahu: (S, A, Msb, K:) you say, lahu maA SanaEa ↓ ta$ak~arotu [I thanked him, &c., for what he did]: (A:) and lahu balaA='ahu ↓ t$k~r [He was grateful to Him, &c., i. e. to God, for his probation]: (K:) and A^a$okuru A_ilayoka niEama A@ll~`hi [I praise to thee, or mention to thee with thanks, the favours of God]: (L in art. Hmd:) [but there are many explanations of $akara beside those given above: its meanings will be more fully shown by what here follows:] $ukorN is the thanking a benefactor; or praising, eulogizing, or commending, him, (S, A,) for a benefits: (S:) or the being grateful, or thankful; or acknowledging beneficence; and speaking of it largely; and [in the copies of the K, “ or, ” but this is evidently a mistake,] it is only on account of favour received; (K;) and $ukoraAnN is [the same, being] contr. of kuforaAnN: (S:) $ukorN [sometimes] differs from HamodN; (Msb in art. Hmd;) for $kr is only on account of favour received; whereas Hmd is sometimes because of favour received, (Th, Az, TA in art. Hmd, and Msb ubi suprà,) and sometimes form other causes; (Th ubi suprà;) [and thus] the latter is of more common application than the former; (S in art. Hmd;) therefore you do not say $akarotuhu EalaY $ajaAEatihi, but you say Hamidotuhu ElY $jAEth: (Msb ubi suprà:) or $ukorN is more common than HamodN with respect to its kinds and means, and more particular with respect to the objects to which it relates; and the latter is more common with respect to the objects to which it relates, and more particular with respect to the means; for the former is, with the heart, the being humble, or lowly, and submissive; and with the tongue, the act of praising, eulogizing, or commending; and acknowledging beneficence; and with the members, the act of obeying, and submitting one's self; and the object to which it relates is the benefactor, exclusively of his essential qualities; therefore one does not say $akaronaA A@ll~`ha EalaY HayaAtihi [we thanked God for his existence, or praised Him, &c.]; but He is maHomuwd on that account, like as He is for his beneficence; and $ukorN is also for beneficence: thus HamodN relates to every object to which, as an object, $ukorN relates; but the reverse is not the case: and everything whereby is Hmd, thereby is $kr; but the reverse is not the case; for the latter is by means of the members, or limbs, and the former is by means of the tongue: $ukorN is of three kinds; with the heart, or mind, which is the forming an [adequate] idea of the benefit; and with the tongue, which is the praising, eulogizing, or commending, the benefactor; and with the members, or limbs, which is the requiting the benefit according to its desert: it rests upon five foundations; humility of him who renders it towards him to whom it is rendered; his love of him; his acknowledgment of his benefit; the eulogizing him for it; and his not making use of the benefit in a manner which he [who has conferred it] dislikes: it is also explained as devotion of the heart to love of the benefactor, and of the members to obey him, and the employment of the tongue in mentioning him and eulogizing him: [and there are several other explanations of it which it is unnecessary to add:] some say that it is formed by transposition from ka$orN, the “ act of uncovering, or exposing to view: ” others, that it is from EayonN $akoraY “ a full fountain, or eye; ” accord. to which etymology it would signify the being full of the praise of the benefactor. (B, TA.) ― -b2- $ukorN on the part of God signifies (tropical:) The requiting and commending [a person]: (K:) or (assumed tropical:) the forgiving a man: or (tropical:) the regarding him with content, satisfaction, good will, or favour: and hence, necessarily, (tropical:) the recompensing, or rewarding, him: the saying $akara A@ll~`hu saEoyahu signifies (tropical:) May God recompense, or reward, his work, or labour. (TA.) -A2- $akirato, aor.
$akara , (S, K,) inf. n. $akarN, (S,) (tropical:) Her (a camel's) udder became full (S, K, TA) of milk: (S, TA:) or she (a camel) obtained a good share of leguminous herbage, or [other] pasturage, and in consequence abounded with milk after having had little milk: (T, TA:) and she (a beast;) became fat, (K, TA,) and her udder became full of milk. (TA.) ― -b2- And $akira (tropical:) He was, or became, liberal, or bountiful, (A, K,) after having been niggardly: (A:) or he gave largely after having been niggardly. (K.) -A3- $akirato said of a tree ($ajarapN), (Fr, S, A, K,) aor.
$akara , inf. n. $akarN, (S,) (assumed tropical:) It produced, or put forth, what are termed $akiyr, (Fr, S, K,) i. e. what grow around it, from its A^aSol [i. e. root, or base, or stem]; (S;) as also ↓ A$krt, (Fr, TA,) and ↓ A$tkrt: (Sgh, TA:) or its $akiyr, i. e. sappy twigs or shoots, from its stem, or small leaves beneath the large, became abundant. (A.) ― -b2- And $akira, aor.
$akara , (K,) inf. n. $akarN; (TA;) and $akara, aor.
$akura ; and ↓ A$kr; (K;) said of palm-trees (naxolN), (assumed tropical:) They had many $akiyr, i. e. offsets, or suckers. (AHn, K, * TA.) ― -b3- And $akara and ↓ A$kr and ↓ A$tkr are all verbs from $kiyrN. (K.) [It is said in the K that these verbs are from $kyr in all of certain significations there mentioned; app. meaning, all that are there mentioned after the next preceding verb: and hence they seem to have the significations here following: ― -b4- said of palmtrees (naxol), (assumed tropical:) They put forth leaves around their branches:: ― -b5- and, said of trees in general $ajara, (assumed tropical:) They put forth branches: ― -b6- and (assumed tropical:) They produced bark: ― -b7- and, said of a grape-vine, (assumed tropical:) it grew from a shoot planted: ― -b8- in the TA it seems to be implied that, said of a vine, they signify (assumed tropical:) It put forth long shoots, or upper shoots.]

3 $aAkarotuhu *
I showed him that I was thankful, or grateful, (A, O, K,) to him. (A.) -A2- And $aAkarotuhu AlHadiyva I commenced with him discourse. (O, K.)

4 A$kr Alqawomu * (assumed tropical:) The people's camels had their udders full of milk ($akirato A_ibiluhumo): (K:) or the people's camels became fat: (TA:) or the people milked a camel or sheep or goat having her udder full of milk, i. e., such as is termed $akirap: (S:) or the people milked camels or sheep or goats having their udders full of milk, one such after another: (O, TA: [but for AiHotalabuwA $akorapF $akorapF in the O, and $ukorapF $ukorapF in the TA, I read AHtlbwA $akirapF $akirapF, agreeably with what here next precedes:]) or the people, having alighted in a place where their camels found herbs, or leguminous plants, had abundance of milk from them. (T, TA.) ― -b2- A$kr said of an udder: see 8. ― -b3- A$krt AlA^aroDu (assumed tropical:) The land produced fresh herbage after other herbage that had become dried up and dusty. (TA.) ― -b4- See also 1, near the end of the paragraph, in three places.
5 t$k~r * : see 1, in three places. ― -b2- Also [He affected, or made a show of, thankfulness, or gratitude: (see taHam~ada:) or] he seemed, or appeared, thankful, or grateful. (KL.)

8 A$tkr * (tropical:) It (an udder) became full (S, K, TA) of milk; (S, TA;) as also ↓ A$kr. (K.) ― -b2- A$tkrt
Als~amaA='u (assumed tropical:) The rain fell vehemently: (S:) or the sky rained much. (K.) ― -b3- A$tkrt AlriyaAHu (assumed tropical:) The winds brought rain: (K:) or blew violently: or, as is said on the authority of A'Obeyd, were contrary; but ISd says that this is a mistake. (TA.) ― -b4- Also A$tkr (assumed tropical:) It (heat, and cold,) became intense. (K.) ― -b5- (tropical:) He (a man) strove, exerted himself, or did his utmost, in his running. (K, TA.) -A2- Also (assumed tropical:) It became what is termed $akiyr [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, near the end of the paragraph, in two places. ― -b3- [Hence, app.,] (tropical:) It (a fœtus) put forth downy hair. (A.)

$akorN * The vulva, or pudendum, of a woman: (S, M, Msb, K:) or the flesh thereof: (M, K, * MF:) as also ↓ $ikorN, in either of these senses: (K:) pl. $ikaArN: (Msb, TA:) laHomuhaA, in the K, as the second explanation, is a mistake for laHomuhu. (MF.) It is said in a trad., nahaY Eano $akori AlbagiYi, meaning He forbade the giving hire for prostitution; the word vamani being understood as prefixed to $kr. (TA.) ― -b2- Also i. q. nikaAHN [i. e. The act of compressing, or of contracting marriage with, a woman]. (TS, K.)
$ukorN * and inf. n. of $akara: (S, A, * Msb, K:) and it may [be used as a simple subst., and, as such,] have for its pl. $ukuwrN. (S. [See 1.])
$ikorN * : see $akorN.

$ukorapN * (assumed tropical:) [Fulness of the udder of a camel; and so ↓ $akariy~apN is expl. in the TK;] a subst. from A^a$okara Alqawomu [q. v.]. (K.) One says, h`*aA zamanu Al$~ukorapi, so in the L and other lexicons, (TA,) or ↓ Al$~akarapi, (so in my copies of the S,) or ↓ Al$~akariy~api, (so in the O and K,) (assumed tropical:) [This is the time of the fulness of the udder,] when the camels abound with milk, or have their udders full, (A_i*aA Hafalato, q. v.,) from the [herbage called] rabiyE. (S, O, L, K.)
$akarapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

$akirapN * (tropical:) A she-camel, (As, S, A, K,) and ewe or she-goat, (A,) having her udder full (As, S, A, K) of milk, (S,) whatever be the fodder, or herbage, she has eaten; (A;) as also ↓ mi$okaArN: (K:) or the former, that has obtained a good share of leguminous herbage, or of [other] pasture, and in consequence abounds with milk after having had little milk: (T, TA:) and ↓ the latter, that abounds with milk though having had but a small share of pasture: (TA:) or that abounds with milk in summer and ceases in winter: (IAar, TA:) pl. of the former $akaAraY, (S, K,) applied to camels and to sheep or goats, (S,) and $akoraY (K) and $akiraAtN: (S, K:) and $akaAraY is applied to camels, and sheep or goats, as meaning abounding with milk, or having their udders full, (A_i*aA Hafalato,) from the [herbage called] rabiyE. (S, TA.) [↓ $akoraY is also a sing. epithet, having a similar signification: as well as a pl.] One says ↓ Dar~apN $akoraY (tropical:) An udder abounding with milk: (A:) or having much milk. (S.) And ↓ EayonN $akoraY (assumed tropical:) A full source or eye. (B, TA.) And ↓ fidorapN $akoraY (assumed tropical:) A fat piece of flesh-meat: (K:) or (tropical:) [a piece of flesh-meat] flowing with grease, or gravy: (A: [but in my copy, qidorapN is erroneously put for fidorapN:]) pl. $akaAraY. (A.)
$akoraY * : see the next four preceding sentences.
$akariy~apN * : see $ukorapN, in two places.

$akuwrN * an intensive epithet, (TA,) signifying kaviyru Al$~ukori [i. e. One who thanks much; or who is very thankful or grateful: see 1]: (K, TA:) and one who is earnest, or does his utmost, in thanking his Lord, or in being thankful or grateful to Him, by obedience to Him, performing his appointed religious services: (TA:) or one who does his utmost in showing his thankfulness, or gratitude, with his heart and his tongue and his members, or limbs, with firm belief, and with acknowledgment [of benefits received]: or who sees his inability to be [sufficiently] thankful or grateful: or who renders thanks, or is thankful or grateful, for probation: or, for what is denied him: (KT:) pl. $ukurN. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A beast that is sufficed by little fodder or herbage, (S, A,) and that fattens upon it: (A:) or that fattens upon little fodder or herbage: (K:) as though thankful for that small benefit. (TA.) ― -b3- Al$~akuwru, applied to God, (tropical:) [He who approves, or rewards, or forgives, much, or largely:] He who gives large reward for small, or few, works: He in whose estimation small, or few, works performed by his servants increase, and who multiplies his rewards to them. (TA.)

$akiyrN * (tropical:) The shoots that grow around a tree, from its A^aSol [i. e. root, or base, or stem]: (S:) or sappy twigs or shoots, that grow from the stem of a tree: or small leaves beneath the large: (A:) or fresh and tender twigs or shoots, that grow among such as have become thick and tough: and what grow at, or upon, the A^uSuwl [i. e. roots, or bases, or stems,] of large trees: or small leaves that grow at, or upon, the root, or base, or stem, of a tree: (IAar, TA:) and offsets, or suckers, or sprouts, of palm-trees: (K:) and the leaves that are around the branches of the palm-tree: (Yaa- koob, K:) and plants, and hair, and feathers, and abundant ostrich-feathers (EifaA=', K, TA, in the CK EafA'), such as are small, growing among such as are large: or the first, of herbage, growing after other herbage that has become dried up and dusty: (K:) and downy hair, or down: and any soft, fine hair: (A:) or hair growing among the plaits: pl. $ukurN: and weak hair: (TA:) and hair at the roots of a horse's mane, (K, TA,) like down, and in the forelock: (TA:) and the hair that is next to the face and the back of the neck: (A, K:) and branches: (AHn, K: [in the CK, wAlguSuwni is erroneously put for wAlguSuwnu:]) and the bark (liHaA=') of trees: pl. $ukurN: (K:) and the pl. also signifies the long shoots of a grape-vine: or its higher, or highest, shoots: (AHn, TA:) and the sing., a grape-vine growing from a planted shoot. (AHn, K, TA.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Young men: (A:) or young offspring. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) The young ones of camels: (K, TA:) as being likened to the $akiyr of palm-trees. (TA.)
$akaAy^iru * (assumed tropical:) Forelocks: (K, TA:) as though pl. of $akiyrapN [which may be n. un. of $akiyrN]. (TA.)

[
$ikuwriyapN * a name applied in the present day to Cichorium, intybus and endivia; wild and garden-succory, and endive; as also hinodabaY, correctly hinodabFY.]

$aAkiriY~N *
A hired man, or hireling; one taken as a servant: an arabicized word, from [the Pers.] JaAkaro. (O, K.)
$awokaraAnN * : see the next paragraph.

$ayokuraAnN * (S, K) and $ayokaraAnN, (K,) [in the CK, erroneously, $akoraAn and with damm to the k,] or the correct form is $ayokuraAnN, with damm to the k as Ibn-Hishám El-Lakhmee and El-Fárábee have expressly affirmed; (TA;) or it is correctly with s, (K,) unpointed, and so it is mentioned by AHn; (TA;) [but see sayokuraAnN;] or correctly ↓ $awokaraAnN, (K,) as Sgh holds to be the case, (TA,) [and thus it is written in several medical books, from the Pers. $awokaraAno; accord. to Golius, Cicuta herba, and applied in the present day to conium, i. e. hemlock, or a species thereof; and this is probably what is meant by Golius, as the conium maculatum, or common hemlock, is called by some cicuta;] a certain plant, (S, K,) of the kind called HamoD, (so in a marginal note in a copy of the S,) the stem of which is like that of the raAziyaAnaj [or fennel], and the leaves of which are like those of the [species of cucumber called.] qiv~aA=', or, as some say, like those of the yaboruwH [q. v.], and smaller; having a white flower, and a slender stem, without any fruit; and its seed is like [that of] the naAnaxawaAp [or ammi], or [of] the A^aniysuwn [or anise], without taste or odour, and mucilaginous. (TA.)
A^a$okaru * [More, and most, thankful, or grateful, &c.: see an ex. voce barowaqN].

Eu$obN ma$okarapN * (O, K, TA, in the CK mu$okirapN,) (assumed tropical:) Herbage that causes milk to be copious. (O, K, TA. [In the CK, mugozarapu All~abani is erroneously put for magozarapN lil~abani.])
mi$okaArN * : see $akirapN, in two places.
riyHN mu$otakirapN * (assumed tropical:) A violent wind: (O, K:) or, as some say, a contrary wind; (O, TA;) but ISd, says that this is a mistake. (TA.)

1 $akisa * , (T, S, Msb, TA,) aor.
$akasa , inf. n. $akasN (T, Msb, TA) and $akaAsapN; (T, S, Msb, TA;) or $akusa, aor.
$akusa , (O, K, TA,) inf. n. $akaAsapN; (O;) He was, or became, refractory, untractable, perverse, stubborn, or obstinate, in disposition: (S, O, K:) or hard in disposition, or illnatured, in behaviour or dealing: (TA:)or evil in disposition, or illnatured, and very perverse or cross or repugnant and averse; syn. $arisa. (Msb, TA. *)

3 $Akshu *
He treated him, or behaved towards him, with hardness, harshness, or illnature. (O, K.)

6 t$AkswA *
They treated, or behaved towards, one another with hardness, harshness, or illnature; or disagreed, one with another; in buying or selling: (IDrd, O, TA:) or they treated, or behaved towards, one another with contrariety, or opposition. (K, * TA.) [Hence,] All~ayolu waAln~ahaAru yata$aAkasaAni (tropical:) The night and the day are opposed to each other: (TA:) or alternate. (Az, A, O, TA.)
$akosN * : see $akisN. ― -b2- maHal~apN $akosN (assumed tropical:) A strait place of alighting or abode. (TA.) -A2- Al$~akosu A day, or two days, before the new moon; i. q. AlmuHaAqu. (AA, O, K.)
$ikosN * : see the next following paragraph.
$akusN * : see the next following paragraph.

$akisN * , (Fr, S, Msb, K,) or ↓ $akosN, (S,) and ↓ $akusN, (K,) the first agreeable with analogy, (S,) A man (S) refractory, untractable, perverse, stubborn, or obstinate, in disposition: (S, K:) or hard in disposition, or illnatured: (TA:) or evil in disposition, or illnatured, and very perverse or cross or repugnant and averse; syn. $arisN: (Msb:) and ↓ $ikosN and ↓ mi$okasN are likewise epithets applied [in the same sense, but the latter having an intensive signification,] to a man: (IAar, TA:) pl. $ukosN; (S, K;) a pl. of the first or third; (K;) or of the second, like as SudoqN is pl. of SadoqN. (S.) ― -b2- Also the first, (tropical:) Niggardly; tenacious; avaricious. (K.)
mi$okasN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

muta$aAkisuwna * (Kur xxxix. 30) Disagreeing, one with another; (A, * K, * TA;) and behaving with hardness, harshness, or illnature: (A:) or disputing, or contending, together. (TA.) [See the verb, 6.]

1 $akala * , as an intrans. verb: see 4, in three places. ― -b2- And see 5. -A2- $akala Alfarasa biAl$~ikaAli, (S,) or $akala Ald~aAb~apa, (Msb, K,) aor.
$akula , inf. n. $akolN, (Msb,) He bound [the horse or] the beast, with the $ikaAl; (Msb;) [i. e.] he bound the legs of [the horse or] the beast with the rope called $ikaAl; as also ↓ $ak~alahaA, (K,) inf. n. ta$okiylN. (TA.) And $akalotu AlT~aAy^ira [app. I bound the legs of the bird in like manner]. (S.) And $akalotu Eani AlbaEiyri I bound the camel's $ikaAl between the fore girth and the hind girth; (S;) [i. e.] I put [or extended], between the hind girth and the fore girth of the camel, a cord, or string, called $ikaAl, and then bound it, in order that the hind girth might not become [too] near to the sheath of the penis. (TA in art. Hqb.) ― -b2- And [hence, i. e.] from the $ikaAl of the beast, (TA,) $akala AlkitaAba, (AHát, S, Msb, K, TA,) inf. n. as above, (Msb, TA,) (tropical:) He restricted [the meaning or pronunciation of] the writing, (qay~adahu, AHát, S, TA,) or he marked the writing, (A^aEolamahu, Msb,) with the signs of the desinential syntax (AHát, * S, * Msb, TA *) [and the other syllabical signs and the diacritical points]: or i. q. A^aEojamahu: (K:) but AHát says that $akala AlkitaAba has the former meaning; and A^aEojamahu signifies he dotted, or pointed, it [with the diacritical points]: (TA:) and AlkitaAba ↓ A$kl signifies the same as $akalahu; (S, Msb, K, TA;) as though [meaning] he removed from it dubiousness and confusion; (S, K, * TA;) so that the A^ in this case is to denote privation: (TA:) this [J says (TA)] I have transcribed from a book, without having heard it. (S.) ― -b3- And $akalato $aEorahaA, (O, TA,) aor.
$akula ; thus correctly, as pointed by IKtt; accord. to the K ↓ $k~lt; (TA;) (assumed tropical:) She (a woman) plaited two locks of her hair, of the fore part of her head, on the right and left, (O, K, TA,) and then bound with them her other *awaAy^ib [or pendent locks or plaits]. (TA.) ― -b4- And $kl [thus in the TA, so that it may be either $akala or ↓ $k~l,] (assumed tropical:) He (the lion) compressed the lioness: on the authority of IKtt. (TA.) -A3- $akilato, aor.
$akala ; (K, TA,) inf. n. $akalN, (TA,) She (a woman) used amorous gesture or behaviour; or such gesture, or behaviour, with coquettish boldness, and feigned coyness or opposition; displayed what is termed $ikol, i. e. gunoj and dal~ and gazal; (K, TA;) and ↓ t$k~lt [signifies the same], i. e. tadal~alato [and in like manner t$k~l is said of a man]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also $akalN below, in two places. ― -b3- And $akilotu A_ilaY ka*aA, with kesr [to the k], i. q. rakanotu [i. e. I inclined to such a thing; or trusted to, or relied upon, it, so as to be, or become, easy, or quiet, in mind]. (O.)

2 $k~l * , as an intrans. verb: see 4: ― -b2- and see also 5. -A2- $k~lhu, inf. n. ta$okiylN, He formed, fashioned, figured, shaped, sculptured, or pictured, it; syn. Saw~arahu; (K, TA;) namely, a thing. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, in three places.

3 mu$aAkalapN * signifies The being conformable, suitable, agreeable, similar, homogeneous, or congenial; syn. muwaAfaqapN; (S, K;) as also ↓ ta$aAkulN: (IDrd, S, K:) Er-Rághib [strangely] says that Almu$aAkalapu is from Al$~akolu signifying “ the binding, ” or “ shackling, ” a beast [with the $ikaAl]. (TA.) You say, huwa yu$aAkiluhu [He, or it, is conformable, &c., with him, or it; or resembles him, or it]. (Msb.) And h`*aA AlA^amoru laA yu$aAkiluka i. e. laA yuwaAfiquka [This affair will not be suitable to thee]. (TA.) And ↓ ta$aAkalaA They resembled each other. (MA.)

4 A$kl * [primarily] signifies SaAra *aA $akolK [meaning It, or he, was, or became, such as had a likeness or resemblance, or a like, or match, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence, app.,] said of a thing, or case, or an affair; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ $akala, (O, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, $akila, evidently not meant by the author of the K, as it is his rule, after mentioning a verb of this form, to add kafariHa or the like,]) inf. n. $akolN; (TA;) and ↓ $k~l, (K,) inf. n. ta$okiylN; (TA;) (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, dubious, or confused; syn. Ailotabasa, (S, O, Msb, K,) and AixotalaTa, (O, TA,) or Ai$otabaha: (Mgh:) [and ↓ A$tkl is mentioned in this sense by Golius as on the authority of J (whom I do not find to have mentioned it either in this art. or elsewhere), and by Freytag as on the authority of Abu-l-'Alà: accord. to Sh, A$kl in this sense is from $ukolapN signifying “ redness mixed with whiteness: ” (see mu$okilN:) but] accord. to Er-Rághib, A_i$okaAlN in a thing, or case, or an affair, is metaphorical, [and] like Ai$otibaAhN from Al$ibohu. (TA.) One says, A$kl AlA^amoru EalaY Alr~ajuli (assumed tropical:) [The thing, or case, or affair, was, or became, dubious, or confused, to the man]; and ↓ $akala means the same. (Zj, O.) And A^a$okalato EalaY~a AlA^axobaAru (assumed tropical:) [The tidings were dubious, or confused, to me], and A^aHokalato; both meaning the same. (TA.) And one says also, Ealayohi A_i$okaAlN and Elyh A_i$okaAlaAtN [meaning There is doubt, or uncertainty, and there are doubts, or uncertainties, respecting it: thus using the inf. n. as a simple subst., and therefore pluralizing it]. (Mz, 3rd nwE; &c.) ― -b3- It is also said of a disease; [app. as meaning (assumed tropical:) It became nearly cured; because still in a somewhat doubtful state;] like as you say tamaAvala; and so ↓ $akala. (TA.) ― -b4- A$kl Aln~axolu The palm-trees became in that state in which their dates were sweet (Ks, S, A, O, K) and ripe, (Ks, S, O, Msb,) or nearly ripe; (A, TA;) and ↓ t$k~l signifies the same. (O.) ― -b5- And A$klt AlEayonu The eye had in it what is termed $ukolapN [q. v.: see also $akalN]. (K.) -A2- A$kl AlkitaAba: see 1.

5 t$k~l *
It (a thing, TA) was, or became, formed, fashioned, figured, shaped, sculptured, or pictured; syn. taSaw~ara. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And He became goodly in shape, form, or aspect. (TK in art. Trz.) ― -b3- t$k~l AlEinabu, (S, K,) and ↓ $akala, and ↓ $k~l, (K,) The grapes became in that state in which some of them were ripe: (S, K:) or became black, and beginning to be ripe: (K:) thus in the M. (TA.) ― -b4- See also 4, near the end. ― -b5- And see 1, also near the end.
6 ta$aAokala see 3, in two places.
8 A_i$otakala see 4.
10 Ast$klhu * is often used by the learned in the present day as meaning He deemed it (i. e. a word or phrase or sentence) dubious, or confused.]

$akolN *
i. q. $abapN [as meaning A likeness, resemblance, or semblance; a well-known signification of the latter word, but one which I do not find unequivocally assigned to it in its proper art. in any of the lexicons]. (AA, K, TA. [In the CK, and in my MS. copy of the K, in the place of Al$~abahu as the first explanation of Al$~akolu in the K accord. to the TA, we find Al$~ibohu; but that the explanation which I have given is correct, is shown by what here follows.]) One says, fiY fulaAnK $akolN mino A^abiyhi, meaning $abahN [i. e. In such a one is a likeness, or resemblance, of his father]: (AA, TA:) and mino A^abiyhi ↓ fiyhi A^a$okalapN and ↓ $ukolapN (AA, O, K, TA)
and ↓ $aAkilN, (O, K, TA,) [likewise] meaning $abahN, (AA, O, K, TA,) and mu$aAbahapN: (TK:) and ↓ $aAkilapN also is syn. with $akolN [in the sense of $abahN]; (K, TA;) [for] one says, h`*aA EalaY $aAkilapi A^abiyhi as meaning $abahihi [i. e. This is accordant to the likeness of his father]. (TA.) ― -b2- And I. q. mivaAlN: you say, h`*aA EalaY $akoli h`*aA, meaning ElY mivaAlihi [i. e. This is according to the model, or pattern, or the mode, or manner, of this]. (TA.) ― -b3- And The shape, form, or figure, (Suwrap,) of a thing; such as is perceived by the senses; and such as is imagined: (K:) the form (hayoy^ap), of a body, caused by the entire contents' being included by one boundary, as in the case of a sphere; or by several boundaries, as in those bodies that have several angles or sides, such as have four and such as have six [&c.]: so says Ibn-El-Kemál: (TA:) pl. [of pauc., in this and in other senses,] A^a$okaAlN and [of mult.] $ukuwlN. (K.) ― -b4- [It often means A kind, sort, or variety, of animals, plants, food, &c.] ― -b5- [And The likeness, or the way or manner, of the actions of a person:] it is said in a trad. respecting the description of the Prophet, saA^alotu A^abiY Eano $akolihi, meaning [I asked my father respecting the likeness of his actions, or] respecting what was like his actions; accord. to IAmb: or, accord. to Az, respecting his particular way, course, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct: (O:) and ↓ $aAkilapN [likewise, and more commonly,] signifies a particular way, course, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct; (S, O, K, TA;) as in the saying, kul~N yaEomalu EalaY $aAkilatihi, (S, O, TA,) in the Kur [xvii. 86], (O, TA,) i. e. Every one does according to his particular way, &c., (Ibn-'Arafeh, S, O, Bd, Jel, TA,) that is suitable to his state in respect of right direction and of error, or to the essential nature of his soul, and to his circumstances that are consequent to the constitution, or temperament, of his body: (Bd:) and according to his nature, or natural disposition, (Ibn-'Arafeh, Er-Rághib, O, TA,) by which he is restricted [as with a $ikaAl]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and his direction towards which he would go: (Akh, S, O, K, * TA:) and his side [that he takes]: (Katádeh, O, K, * TA:) and his aim, intention, or purpose: (Katádeh, O, K, TA:) and $akolN [likewise] signifies aim, intention, or purpose; syn. qaSodN. (TA.) ― -b6- Also A thing that is suitable to one; or fit, or proper, for one: you say, h`*aA mino hawaAYa wamino $akoliY [This is of what is loved by me and of what is suitable to me]: (K, TA:) and layosa $akoluhu mino $akoliY [What is suitable to him is not of what is suitable to me]. (TA.) [And hence, app.,] one says, maA$akoliY wa$akoluhu, meaning What is my case and [what is] his, or its, case? because of his, or its, remoteness from me. (T and TA voce A^um~N.) ― -b7- And sing. of A^a$okaAlN (L, K, TA) signifying Discordant affairs and objects of want, concerning things on account of which one imposes upon himself difficulty and for which one is anxious: (Lth, TA:) and dubious, or confused, affairs: (TA:) or discordant, and dubious, or confused, affairs. (K. [In the CK, Almu$ak~alap is erroneously put for Almu$okilap.]) -A2- Also A like; syn. mivolN; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) and so ↓ $ikolN: (O, K:) or, as some say, the like of another in nature or constitution: (Msb: [and accord. to Er-Rághib, it seems that the attribute properly denoted by it is congruity between two persons in respect of the way or manner of acting or conduct: but in the passage in which this is expressed in the TA, I find erasures and alterations which render it doubtful:]) pl. A^a$okaAlN (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K *) and $ukuwlN [as above]. (S, O, Msb, K. *) One says, h`*aA $akolu h`*aA This is the like of this. (Msb.) And fulaAnN $akolu fulaAnK Such a one is the like of such a one in his several states or conditions [&c.]. (TA.) In the saying in the Kur [xxxviii. 58], waA=xaru mino $akolihi, (O, TA,) meaning And other punishment of the like thereof, (Zj, TA,) Mujáhid read ↓ mn $ikolihi. (O, TA.) -A3- Also sing. of A^a$okaAlN signifying, (O, K,) accord. to IAar, (O,) Certain ornaments (O, K) consisting of pearls or of silver, (K,) resembling one another, worn as ear-drops by women: (O, K:) or, as some say, the sing. signifies a certain thing which girls, or young women, used to append to their hair, of pearls or of silver. (O.) -A4- And A species of plant, (IAar, O, K,) diversified in colour, (K,) yellow and red. (IAar, O, K.) -A5- [And The various syllabical signs, or vowel-points &c., by which the pronunciation of words is indicated and restricted: originally an inf. n., and therefore thus used in a pl. sense.] -A6- See also the next paragraph.

$ikolN * : see the next preceding paragraph, latter part, in two places. -A2- Also, as an attribute of a woman, Amorous gesture or behaviour; or such gesture, or behaviour, combined with coquettish boldness, and feigned coyness or opposition; syn. dal~N, (S, O, Msb, K,) and gunojN, and gazalN; (K; [in the CK, gazol, which is a mistranscription;]) or her gunoj, and comely or pleasing dal~, whereby a woman renders herself comely or pleasing; (TA;) and ↓ $akolN signifies the same. (K.) One says AimoraA^apN *aAtu $ikolK [A woman having amorous gesture or behaviour; &c.]. (S, O, Msb.)

$akalN * , in a sheep or goat, The quality of being white in the $aAkilap. (S, O. [See A^a$okalu.]) [In this sense, accord. to the TK, an inf. n., of which the verb is ↓ $akila, said of a ram &c.]. ― -b2- And in an eye, The quality of having what is termed $ukolap [q. v.]. (S, O.) [Accord. to the TK, in this sense also an inf. n., of which the verb is ↓ $akila, said of a thing, as meaning It had a redness in its whiteness.]

$ukolapN * : see $akolN, first signification. ― -b2- One says also, fiyhi $ukolapN mino sumorapK [In him, or it, is an admixture of a tawny, or brownish, colour], and $ukolapN mino sawaAdK [an admixture of blackness]: (TA:) [or] $ukolapN signifies redness mixed with whiteness: (Sh, Msb, TA:) in camels, (K, TA,) and in sheep or goats, (TA,) blackness mixed with redness, (K, TA,) or with dust-colour: in the hyena, accord. to IAar, a colour in which are blackness and an ugly yellowness: (TA:) in the eye, a redness in the white: (Mgh:) or, in the eye, i. q. $uholapN [q. v.]: (K:) or, accord. to AO, (TA,) the like of a redness in the white of the eye; (S, O, TA;) and such was in the eyes of the Prophet; (O;) but if in the black of the eye, it is termed $uholapN: (S, O, TA:) and the like is in the eyes of the [hawks, or falcons, termed] Suquwr and buzaAp: accord. to some, it is yellowness mixing with the white of the eye, around the black, as in the eye of the hawk (AlS~aqor); but he [i. e. AO] says, I have not heard it used except in relation to redness, not in relation to yellowness. (TA.) fiyhi $ukolapN mino damK means In him, or it, is a little [or a small admixture] of blood. (TA.)
$akilapN * A woman using, or displaying, what is termed $ikol, i. e. gunoj and dal~ and gazal [meaning amorous gesture or behaviour, &c.], (K, TA,) in a comely, or pleasing, manner. (TA.)

$akolaA='u * fem. of A^a$okalu [q. v.]. (S, O.) -A2- Also A want; syn. HaAjapN; and so ↓ A^a$okalapN, (S, O, K, [both of these words twice mentioned in this sense in the K,]) and ↓ $awokalaA='u; this last and the second on the authority of IAar; (O;) accord. to Er-Rághib, such as binds, or shackles, (tuqay~id,) a man [as though with a $ikaAl]. (TA.) One says, ↓ lanaA qibalaka A^a$okalapN [&c.] i. e. HaAjapN [We have a want to be supplied to us on thy part; meaning we want a thing of thee]. (S, O.) -A3- Also i. q. mudaAhanapN. (So in the O and TA. [But whether by this explanation be meant the inf. n., or the fem. pass. part. n., of daAhana, is not indicated. Words of the measure faEolaA='u having the meaning of an inf. n., like bagoDaA='u, are rare.])

$ikaAlN * , of which the pl. is $ukulN, (S, O, Msb, K,) the latter also pronounced $ukolN, (TA,) i. q. EiqaAlN [A cord, or rope, with which a camel's fore shank and arm are bound together]: (S, O:) [or, accord. to the TA, by EqAl is here meant what next follows:] a rope with which the legs of a beast (daAb~ap) are bound: (K:) a bond that is attached upon the fore and hind foot [or feet] of a horse [or the like] and of a camel: (KL:) [hobbles for a horse or the like, having a rope extending from the shackles of the fore feet to those of the hind feet: so accord. to present usage; and so accord. to the TK, in Turkish kwstk: Fei says only,] the $ikaAl of the beast (dAb~p) is well known; and the pl. is as above. (Msb.) In relation to the [camel's saddle called] raHol, (K, TA,) accord. to As, (S, O, TA,) A string, or cord, that is put [or extended and tied] between the taSodiyr [or fore girth] and the Haqab [or hind girth], (S, O, K, TA,) in order that the latter may not become [too] near to the sheath of the penis; also called the ziwaAr, on the authority of AA: (S, O, TA:) and [in relation to the saddle called qatab,] a bond [in like manner extended and tied, for the same purpose,] between the Haqab [or hind girth] and the biTaAn [by which is meant the fore girth, answering to the taSodiyr of the raHol]: and a bond [probably meaning the rope men-
tioned in the explanation given from the K in the preceding sentence] between the fore leg and the hind leg. (K, TA.) ― -b2- Also, in a horse, (tropical:) The quality of having three legs distinguished by [the whiteness of the lower parts which is termed] taHojiyl, and one leg free therefrom; (S, O, K, TA;) [this whiteness] being likened to the EiqaAl termed $ikaAl: (S, O:) or having three legs free from taHojiyl, and one hind leg distinguished thereby: (S, O, K, * TA: *) accord. to A'Obeyd, it is only in the hind leg; not in the fore leg: (S, O:) or, accord. to AO, (TA,) having the whiteness of the taHojiyl in one hind leg and fore leg, on the opposite sides, (Mgh, * TA,) whether the whiteness be little or much: (TA:) [when this is the case, the horse is said to be *uw $ikaAlK mino xilaAfK: see 3 (last sentence) in art. xlf:] the Prophet disliked what is thus termed in horses. (O.)
$akiylN * (tropical:) Foam mixed with blood, appearing upon the bit-mouth, or mouth-piece of the bit. (Z, O, K, TA.)
$aAkilN * : see $akolN, first signification. ― -b2- Also A whiteness between the Ei*aAr [which see, for it has various meanings,] and the ear. (Ktr, S, O. [See also $aAkilapN.])
$awokalN * : see $awokalapN. ― -b2- One says, AijoEali AlA^amora $awokalFA waAHidFA, meaning Make thou the affair, or case, [uniform, or] one uniform thing. (Fr, TA in art. bA^j.)

$aAkilapN * : see $akolN, former half, in two places. -A2- Al$~aAkilapu, also, signifies The flank; syn. AlxaASirapu, i. e. AlT~afoTafapu: (S, O:) [or,] in a horse, the skin that is between the side (EuroD) of the xaASirap and the vafinap, (K, TA,) which latter means [the stifle-joint, i. e.] the joint of the faxi* and saAq: or as some say, the $aAkilataAni are the two exterior parts of the TafoTafataAni [or two flanks] from the place to which the last of the ribs reaches to the edge of [the hip-bone called] the Haroqafap on each side of the belly. (TA.) One says, A^aSaAba $aAkilapa Alr~amiy~api, meaning [He hit] the xaASirap [or flank] of the rmy~p [or animal shot at]. (TA.) [Hence,] one says, A^aSaAba $aAkilapa AlS~awaAbi (tropical:) [He hit the point that he aimed at, of the thing that was right]: and huwa yaromiY biraA^oyihi Al$~awaAkila (tropical:) [He hits, by his opinion, or judgment, the right points]. (TA.) Ibn-'Abbád says that [the pl.] $awaAkilu signifies [also] The hind legs; because they are shackled [with the $ikaAl]. (O.) ― -b2- Also The part between the ear and the temple. (IAar, K, TA.) ― -b3- And $awaAkilu (which is the pl. of $aAkilapN, TA) (assumed tropical:) Roads branching off from a main road. (K.) You say TariyqN *uw $awaAkila (assumed tropical:) A road having many roads branching off from it. (O.) ― -b4- And $aAkilataA AlT~ariyqi means (tropical:) The two sides of the road: you say TariyqN ZaAhiru Al$~awaAkili (tropical:) [A road of which the sides are apparent, or conspicuous]. (TA.)

$awokalapN * , (so in the O, as on the authority of IAar,) or ↓ $awokalN, (so in the K,) thus says EzZejjájee, but Fr says the former, [like IAar,] (TA,) i. q. raj~aAlapN [as meaning The footmen of an army or the like]: (Fr, IAar, Ez-Zejjájee, O, K, TA:) or mayomanapN [meaning the right wing of an army]: or mayosarapN [meaning the left wing thereof]. (Ez-Zejjájee, K, TA.) ― -b2- And i. q. naAHiyopN [probably as meaning The side, region, quarter, or direction, towards which one goes; like $aAkilapN, as expl. by Akh and others, in a saying mentioned voce $akolN]. (IAar, O, K.) -A2- Also i. q. EawosajapN [i. e. A tree of the species called Eawosaj, q. v.]. (IAar, O, K.)
$awokalaA='u * : see $akolaA='u, above.

A^a$okalu *
More, and most, like; syn. A^a$obapu: so in the saying, h`*aA A^a$okalu bika*aA [This is more, or most, like to such a thing]. (S, K. *) ― -b2- Also Of a colour in which whiteness and redness are intermixed; (S, Msb, K;) applied to blood; and, accord. to IDrd, a name for blood, because of the redness and whiteness intermixed therein; (S;) [and] applied to a man; (Msb;) or to anything: (TA:) or in which is whiteness inclining to redness and duskiness: (K:) or it signifies, with the Arabs, [of] two colours intermixed. (TA.) [Hence,] it is applied to water, (K, TA,) as meaning (tropical:) Mixed with blood: (TA: [see an ex. in a verse cited voce Hat~aY:]) pl. $ukolN. (K.) And the fem., $akolaA='u, is applied as an epithet to an eye, (S, K,) meaning Having in it what is termed $ukolapN, which is the like of a redness in the white thereof; like $uholapN in the black: (S:) pl. as above. (K.) A man is said to be A^a$okalu AlEayoni, meaning Having a redness, (Mgh,) or the like of a redness, (O,) in the white of the eye: (Mgh, O:) the Prophet is said to have been A^a$okalu AlEayoni: and it has been expl. as meaning long in the slit of the eye: (K:) but ISd says that this is extraordinary; and MF, that the leading authorities on the trads. consentaneously assert it to be a pure mistake, and inapplicable to the Prophet, even if lexicologically correct. (TA.) ― -b3- Applied to a camel, (K, TA,) and to a sheep or goat, (TA,) of which the blackness is mixed with redness, (K, TA,) or with dust-colour; as though its colour were dubious to thee: (TA:) pl. as above, applied to rams &c., (K, TA,) in this sense. (TA.) ― -b4- Applied to a sheep or goat, White in the $aAkilap [or flank]: (S, O:) fem. $akolaA='u; (S;) applied to a ewe, as meaning white in the $aAkilap, (K, TA,) the rest of her being black. (TA.) -A2- Also The mountain-species of sidor [or lote-tree]; (S, O, K;) described to AHn, by some one or more of the Arabs of the desert, as a sort of trees like the Eun~aAb [or jujube] in its thorns and the crookedness of its branches, but smaller in leaf, and having more branches; very hard, and having a small drupe, (nubayoqap, [dim. of nabiqapN, n. un. of nabiqN, which means the “ drupes of the sidor, ”]) which is very acid: the places of its growth are lofty mountains; and bows are made of it [as is shown by an ex. in the S and O]: (TA:) [app. with tenween, having a] n. un. with p: (S, K:) AHn says that the growth of the A$kl is like [that of] the trees called $iroyaAn [of which likewise bows are made]. (TA.)

A^a$okalapN * : see $akolN, first signification. ― -b2- Also i. q. lubosN [meaning (assumed tropical:) Dubiousness, or confusedness]. (K.) -A2- See also $akolaA='u, in two places. -A3- Also A single tree of the species called A^a$okal [q. v.]. (S, K.)

mu$okilN * , from A^a$okala in the first of the senses assigned to it above, signifies Entering among [meaning confused with] its likes. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence, app., or] accord. to Sh, from $ukolapN meaning “ redness mixed with whiteness, ” it signifies (assumed tropical:) Dubious, or confused. (TA.) [Used as a subst.,] it has for its pl. mu$okilaAtN [and ma$aAkilu also: for] one says, huwa yafuk~u Alma$aAkila, meaning (assumed tropical:) [He solves] the things, or affairs, that are dubious, or confused. (TA.) ― -b3- m$kl [app. mu$okilN], applied to a horse, means Having a whiteness in his flanks. (AA, TA in art. dEm.)

mu$ak~alN *
Endowed with a goodly aspect, or appearance, and form. (TA.)

ma$okuwlN * A horse bound, or shackled, with the $ikaAl [q. v.]. (O, TA.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) A horse distinguished by the whiteness in the lower parts of certain of the legs which is denoted by the term $ikaAlN [q. v.]: (S, Mgh, * O, TA:) such was disliked by the Prophet. (S.) [See also muHaj~alN.] ― -b3- And (tropical:) A writing restricted [in its meaning or pronunciation] with the signs of the desinential syntax [and the other syllabical signs and the diacritical points]. (AHát, TA.)

1 $akamahu * , aor.
$akuma , inf. n. $akomN, He bitted him; [namely, a horse or the like;] he put the bit ($akiymap) into his mouth. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence], $akama AlwaAliYa, (S, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He bribed the wAlY [i. e. prefect, or the like]; as though he stopped his mouth with the $akiymap, (S, K, TA,) i. e. the [bit, or] iron thing of the lijaAm. (TA.) And $akama faAhu biAlA_itaAwapi i. e. (assumed tropical:) [He stopped (lit. bitted) his mouth] with the bribe. (TA in art. Atw.) ― -b3- And faEala fulaAnN A^amorFA fa$akamotuhu (assumed tropical:) Such a one did a thing, or performed an affair, and I settled, or established, it. (Lth, TA.) ― -b4- And $akamahu, (S, K,) aor. as above, (S,) and so the inf. n.; (K;) and ↓ A$kmhN; (Th, K;) He repaid, requited, compensated, or recompensed, him; (S, K; *) or gave him what is termed $ukom [q. v.]: (K:) he gave him his hire, or pay. (S, from a trad.) ― -b5- And, as some say, (S,) $akamahu, inf. n. $akomN and $akiymN, He bit him. (S, K.) -A2- $akima, aor.
$akama , (K,) inf. n. $akamN, (TK,) He was, or became, hungry. (K.)
4 A^a$okama see the preceding paragraph.

$ukomN * (S, K, &c.) and ↓ $ukomaY; (K;) of the latter, ISd says, “ I think it to be a dial. var., but I am not certain of it; ” (TA;) A repayment, requital,
compensation, or recompense; (El-Umawee, A' Obeyd, S, K;) and $ukobN is a dial. var. thereof: (TA:) when the gift is initial, it is termed $ukodN: (S:) or a substitute; or thing given, received, put, or done, by way of replacement or exchange: (Ks, TA:) and (K) a gift; (As, K, TA;) as also $ukodN; (As, TA;) or the latter signifies a gift without compensation: (TA:) or $ukomN signifies a benefaction, bounty, or gratuity; syn. nuEomaY. (Lth, TA.)

$akimN *
A lion: (K:) expl. in this sense as occurring in a verse of Aboo-Sakhr El-Hudhalee: or, accord. to Skr, as there used, quickly, or soon, angry; or violently angry. (TA.)
$ukomaY * : see $ukomN.
$akiymN * : see $akiymapN, in three places. ― -b2- Also The loop-shaped handles of the cooking-pot. (S, K.)

[
$akaAmapN * expl. by Golius as meaning “ Malitia indolis, contumacia, ” as on the authority of the KL, is app. a mistake for $akaAsapN, which I find expl. in the KL as signifying the “ being evil in nature, or natural disposition, ” but not $kAmp. ― -b2- Freytag explains it as meaning also Likeness; a signification of $akiymapN, also mentioned by him; but for this he names no authority, and I know of none.]

$akiymapN * , in the lijaAm, [The bit-mouth, or mouthpiece of a pit; i. e.] the transverse piece of iron in the mouth of the horse, in which is the faA^os [q. v.]; (S, K;) as also ↓ $akiymN: (S:) [see also lijaAmN, and misoHalN:] or ↓ $akiymN is pl. of $akiymapN, as also $akaAy^imu and $ukumN, (K, TA,) this last with two dammehs, [but written in the CK $ukomN,] or [rather ↓ $akiymN is a coll. gen. n., and] $ukumN is said by some to be pl. of $akiymN, not of $akiymapN. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, [as used in phrases mentioned below,] (TA,) (tropical:) Resistance, or incompliance: (S, TA:) disdain, scorn, or disdainful and proud incompliance or refusal: and self-defence from wrong treatment: (K:) and self-magnification, pride, or haughtiness; syn. $amamN; Als~am~u in the copies of the K being a mistake for Al$~amamu: (TA:) firmness, strength, or vehemence, of spirit; (TA, and Ham p. 140;) and evilness of nature or disposition: (Ham ibid:) strength of heart: (IAar, TA:) hardiness; courage, or courage and energy; or determination; syn. EaAriDapN: vigorousness, strenuousness, or energy: (TA:) also [simply] nature, or natural disposition; syn. TaboEN. (K, TK: in the CK AlT~abaEu is [erroneously] put in the place of AlT~aboEu.) One says, fulaA=nN *uw $akiymapK (tropical:) Such a one is resistant, or incompliant: (S, TA:) or disdainful, or scornful; resistant, unyielding, or incompliant: one who defends himself from wrong treatment: proud: hardy: courageous: one possessing prudence or discretion, or firmness or soundness of judgment. (TA.) And fulaAnN $adiydu Al$~akiymapi, meaning [in like manner] (tropical:) Such a one is firm, strong, or vehement, of spirit; (S, TA, and Ham p. 140;) disdainful, or scornful; resistant, unyielding, or incompliant; (S, K, TA;) so says ISk: (TA:) or, as some say, one possessing strength, or vehemence, of tongue; and perspicuity, or eloquence, of speech or language; or perspicuity of speech with quickness, or sharpness, of intellect; and much hardiness, or courage, or courage and energy, or determination. (Ham p. 140.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) Likeness, or resemblance. (K.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) A compact, or covenant; syn. EahodN: (K, TA:) in some copies of the K, Alfahodu is erroneously put for AlEahodu. (TA.)

div2.head: $kw and $kY
div2.entryFree:
1 $akaA * , (K,) first pers. $akawotu, (S, Msb,) of which $akayotu is a dial. var., (K in art. $kY,) aor.
1a2u3a , (S, Msb,) [and of the latter
1a2i3a ,] inf. n. $akowN, (S, Msb,) or $akowaY, (K,) or this is a simple subst., (S, Msb,) also pronounced $akowFY, (K,) and $ikaAyapN, (S, K,) with kesr, (K,) in which the Y is [said to be] substituted for w because most inf. ns. of the measure fiEaAlapN of verbs ending with an infirm radical letter are of verbs of which that letter is Y, (TA,) or this also is a simple subst., (Msb,) and $akaApN, (S, K,) or this too is a simple subst., (Msb,) and $akaAwapN, (K,) and $akiy~apN, (S, K,) is a trans. verb; (S, Msb, K;) and ↓ A$tkY signifies the same; (S, K;) as also ↓ t$k~Y: (K:) one says, $akaA A^amorahu A_ilaY A@ll~`hi and ↓ A$tkY [i. e. A$tkY A^amorahu], and ↓ t$k~Y [i. e. t$k~Y A^amorahu], (K, TA,) meaning [He complained of his case to God; or] he told to God the weakness of his condition: (TA:) and $akawotu fulaAnFA and ↓ Ai$otakayotuhu [I complained to such a one of his conduct to me]; (S;) [or] $akaA fulaAnFA means he told such a one of his evil conduct to him: (TA:) and $akaA fulaAnFA A_ilaY fulaAnK He complained of such a one to such a one: (MA:) [and $akawotu A_ilayohi ka*aA I complained to him of such a thing:] see 4: and [in like manner] A_ilayohi ka*aA ↓ A$tkY He complained to him of such a thing: (MA:) and minohu ↓ Ai$otakayotu [I complained of him, or it; like $akawotuhu]: (Msb:) Er-Rághib says, Al$ikaAyapu is The showing, or revealing, of grief, or sorrow; whence the saying in the Kur [xii. 86], A_in~amaA A^a$okuw bav~iY waHuzoniY A_ilaY A@ll~`hi [I only show my grief and my lamentation to God]; and in the same [lviii. 1], A_ilaY A@ll~`hi ↓ wata$otakiY [And showeth her grief, or sorrow, to God]; the primary signification of Al$~akowu being the opening of the small skin for water or milk called $akowap, and showing what is in it; so that it is as though originally metaphorical [though what is termed HaqiyqapN Eurofiy~apN (expl. in art. Hq)]; like the phrases bavavotu lahu maA fiY wiEaAy^iY and nafaDotu lahu maA fiY jiraAbiY, meaning “ I showed him what was in my heart. ” (TA.) ― -b2- $akaA is also said of a camel as meaning He stretched out his neck, and made much moaning, or prolonged utterance of a complaining voice, being fatigued by journeying. (TA.) ― -b3- And $akaAhu, (MA, K, TA,) inf. n. $akowN and $akaApN and $akowaY, (MA, TA,) is said in relation to a disease, or sickness; (MA, K, TA;) meaning He (a diseased, or sick, person) complained of it, namely, his disease, or sickness; (MA; [accord. to the TK, followed in this case, as in many others, by Freytag, it means it (i. e. disease, or sickness,) afflicted him; which I think to be indubitably a mistake;]) and ↓ t$k~Y and ↓ A$tkY signify the same [as $akaA maraDahu he complained of his disease, or sickness]: (TA:) [or] these two verbs (t$k~Y and A$tkY) signify [or signify also] he was, or became, diseased, or sick. (TA in additions at the end of this art.) One says also, ↓ A$tkY EuDowFA mino A^aEoDaAy^ihi and ↓ t$k~Y, both meaning the same [i. e., originally, He complained of a pain, or disease, in some one of his members; but generally meaning he had a complaint of, or a pain or a disease in, some one of his members; and $akaA EuDowFA not unfrequently occurs used in the same sense]: (S:) [thus one often says of a brute; for ex.,] As says, in explaining AlqulaAbu as meaning “ a certain disease that attacks the camel, ” minohu qalobahu ↓ ya$otakiY [he has a pain in consequence thereof in his heart; in which qalobahu, though determinate, may be considered as an explicative, like baTonahu in the phrase A^alima baTonahu, q. v.]. (S in art. qlb.) ― -b4- One says also, huwa yu$okaY bika*aA, meaning He is accused, or suspected, of such a thing; syn. yut~ahamu bihi: (K: [there mentioned as though it were from A^u$okiYa, and held to be so by the author of the TK; but it is from $ukiYa; as though meaning he is complained of by reason of such a thing:]) mentioned by Yaakoob, in the “ Alfádh. ” (TA.) -A2- $kY fulaAnN [thus in my original, app. $akaA or $akaY,] is mentioned by Az as meaning The nails of such a one became split in several, or many, places. (TA.)

2 $ak~ati Aln~isaA='u * , inf. n. ta$okiyapN; and ↓ A$tkt; and ↓ t$k~t; (K;) or, accord. to Th, only this last; (TA;) The women took for themselves, or made, a $akowap [q. v.] for the churning of milk; (K, TA;) because it was little in quantity; the $kwp being small, so that only a small quantity can be churned in it: (TA:) or, as in the T, $k~Y and ↓ t$k~Y he took for himself, or made, a $akowap: (TA:) [or] so ↓ A$tkY: (S:) and so ↓ A$kY. (IKtt, TA.) -A2- $ak~aY $aAkiyahu, inf. n. ta$okiyapN, expl. in the K as meaning kaf~a Eanohu and Tay~aba nafosahu, is a foul mistranscription: correctly, sal~aY $aAkiyahu, meaning “ He comforted his complainer, and consoled him for that which had befallen him; ” as in the Tekmileh. (TA.)
3 $AkAhu * , inf. n. mu$aAkaApN, He complained of him, i. q. $akaAhu: or he told of his deceit, guile, or circumvention, and his vices, or faults. (TA.)

4 A$kAhu * [He made him, or caused him, to complain;] he did to him that which made him, or caused him, to have need to complain of him. (S, Msb.) He increased his annoyance and complaining. (Az, K, TA.) ― -b2- And He removed, or did away with, his complaint; or made his complaint to cease; (S, * Mgh, Msb, K;) he caused him to be pleased or contented [and so relieved him from his complaint]; syn. A^aEotabahu mino $akowaAhu; (S, and Har p. 337;) i. e. A^aroDaAhu; (Har ibid.;) and
he desisted from that of which he complained: (S, * Msb:) thus it has two contr. significations. (S, K.) Hence the saying, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) in a trad., (TA,) A_ilaY rasuwli A@ll~`hi Har~a Alr~amoDaA='i ↓ $akawonaA fiY SiyaAminaA falamo yu$okinaA [We complained, to the Apostle of God, of the heat of the burning ground, in our fasting,] and he did not remove, or cause to cease, our complaint. (Mgh, * Msb, TA.) And [hence] one says, A$kY fulaAnFA mino fulaAnK, meaning He took for such a one, from such a one, what pleased or contented him [and so relieved him from complaining of him]. (ISd, K, TA: omitted in the CK.) ― -b3- Also He told him his complaint, and the desire, or longing of the soul, that he endured. (TA.) ― -b4- And i. q. wajadahu $aAkiyFA [which may mean He found him to be complaining, or, as seems to be indicated by what immediately precedes it in the K, he found him to be complaining of a disease of the slightest sort]: (K:) or, as in the T, A$kY [app. meaning A$kY Habiybahu] signifies he found the object of his love, or his friend, to be complaining; expl. by SaAdafa Habiybahu ya$okuw. (TA.) -A2- See also 2.

5 t$k~Y *
He expressed complaint or lamentation, pain, grief, or sorrow; syn. tawaj~aEa; (Msb and K in art. wjE;) he made complaint or lamentation. (MA, KL.) See 1, in four places. ― -b2- [Hence] one says, t$k~Y $aA=y^iY A^aroDa ka*aA, meaning (assumed tropical:) [My sheep or goats] forsook such a land, [as though they complained of it,] and did not go near it. (TA. [But I have substituted $aAy^iY for what is there written $AkY, an evident mistranscription.]) -A2- See also 2, in two places.

6 ta$aAkawoA *
They complained, one to another. (K.)
8 A_i1ota2a3a see 1, in nine places: -A2- and see also 2, in two places.

$akowN * inf. n. of $akaA. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- It is also used in the sense of wajodN [meaning Grief, mourning, or sorrow]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, and ↓ $akowaY, and ↓ $akaApN, and ↓ $akaA='N, and ↓ $akowaA='u, (K,) this last mentioned by Az, (TA,) [but it is omitted in some copies of the K,] A complaint, meaning a disease, malady, or sickness. (K.) -A2- Also, the first, A small, or young, lamb: or a small, or young, camel: (K accord. to different copies: in some, Al$~akowu having for its explanation AlHamalu AlS~agiyru, and thus in the TA: in others, Aljamalu AlSgyr:) mentioned by ISd. (TA.)
$akaApN * an inf. n. of $akaA; (S, K;) or a simple subst., like $akowaY. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also $akowN. ― -b3- Also i. q. EayobN [A vice, fault, &c.]. (TA.) [See a verse cited voce rifaAqN.]

$akowapN * The skin of a sucking kid, (T, * S, M, *) for milk: that of the ja*aE and of such as is above that [in age] is termed waTobN; (S;) or that of the ja*aE is termed siqaA='N; and that of such as is weaned, badorapN: (T, TA:) or a receptacle of skin or leather, for water and for milk, (K, TA,) or, as some say, in which water is cooled and in which milk is kept close: (TA:) or a small skin for water or milk: or a small receptacle in which water is put: (Er-Rághib, TA:) the dim. is ↓ $ukay~apN: (TA:) and the pl. is $akawaAtN and $ikaA='N (K, TA) and $ukiY~N [like as buduwrN is a pl. of badorapN, being originally $ukuwwN, like as duliY~N (pl. of dalowN) is originally duluwwN]. (TA.)
$akowaY * an inf. n. of $akaA, as also $akowFY; (K;) or a simple subst. [signifying Complaint]: (S, Msb:) pl. $akaAwaY. (TA.) ― -b2- See also $akowN.
$akowaA='u * : see $akowN.
$akaA='N * : see $akowN.

$akiY~N *
i. q. ↓ $aAkK [i. e. Complaining]; (Msb;) [or a complainer; i. e.] Al$~akiY~u signifies Aal~a*iY ya$otakiY, (S,) or Al*Y ya$okuw. (JM.) ― -b2- And Pained; syn. muwjaEN; (K, TA;) in this sense an instance of faEiylN in the sense of mafoEuwlN: (TA:) or causing pain; syn. muwjiEN: [thus accord. to both of my copies of the S: and this appears to be correct; for it is there immediately added,] El-Tirimmáh says,
wasomiY $akiY~N walisaAniY EaArimu
[which is inconsiderately cited in the TA immediately after the former of these two explanations: I say “ inconsiderately ” because the meaning evidently is, not that thus indicated in the TA, but, My branding, or stigmatizing, by satire, (for one says wasamahu biAlhijaA='i,) is such as causes pain, and my tongue is vehement: or $akiY~N may here have the last but one of the meanings expl. in this paragraph]: wasomiY is from Als~imapu. (S.) ― -b3- Also Affected with a complaint, meaning disease, malady, or sickness, [app. in an absolute sense, (see $akowN,) and also] of the least, or lightest, or slightest, sort; and so ↓ $aAkK. (M, K.) ― -b4- And i. q. ↓ ma$okuw~N, (S, Msb, K,) which is a pass. part. n. of $akaA; [and therefore signifies Complained of; and also complained to; but mostly seems to be used in the former of these senses;] as also ↓ ma$okiY~N. (S, Msb.)
$ikaAyapN * an inf. n. of $akaA; (S, K:) or a simple subst., like $akowaY. (Msb.)

$akiy~apN * an inf. n. of $akaA. (S, K.) ― -b2- And also (TA) a subst. signifying A thing complained of (AisomN lima$okuw~K); like ramiy~apN a subst. signifying “ a thing cast at or shot at ” (AisomN limaromiy~K): (Msb, TA:) pl. $akaAyaA. (TA.) -A2- Also A remainder, or remaining portion, (K and TA in art. $kY,) of a thing: mentioned by Sgh. (TA.)
$ukay~apN * dim. of $akowapN, q. v. (TA.)
