$ak~iY~N * , (thus in copies of the K,) or $uk~iY~N, with damm to the $, (TA,) is mentioned in art. $k [q. v.], and J has committed a mistake (K, TA) in mentioning it here, as Sgh has observed: (TA:) [accord. to F, it seems to be a rel. n. applied to a bit, or bridle; for it is said to be so applied in the K, as well as in the O, in art. $k, in which both explain it as meaning Difficult; and also to a skin; for immediately after asserting that J has committed a mistake, F adds,] and $ak~aY, like Hat~aY, is a town in Armenia, whence [are brought] bits, or bridles, (lujum,) and skins, (K,) [and SM adds that they are termed $k~y~p: but what I find J to have stated is as follows:] Al$~akiY~u, [thus in one of my copies of the S,] or Al$ukiY, [thus in the other of those copies,] in relation to weapons, is an arabicized word, and is in Turkish la$ or la$o. (S. [But in the JM, this last word is written, as from the S, t$n: it may therefore be correctly la$on, or la$in, which, though used in Turkish, is a Pers. word, meaning smooth.])

$aAkK * : see $akiY~N, in two places. -A2- In the phrase rajulN $aAkiY Als~ilaAHi, (S,) which means A man whose weapon is sharp, or whose weapons are sharp, (S, K, *) Akh says that $AkY is formed by transposition from $aAy^ik [q. v. in art. $wk]: (S:) and accord. to AZ, one says also $aAkK fiY Als~ilAHi. (TA in art. $wk.) ― -b2- And Al$~aAkiY [is app. formed in like manner from Al$~aAy^iku, and] signifies The lion. (K.)

mi$okaApN *
A niche in a wall; i. e. a hole, or hollow, (kuw~apN,) in a wall, not extending through; (Fr, S, M, K, &c.;) in which a lamp, placed therein, gives more light than it does elsewhere: thus expl: by the generality of the expositors [of the Kur-án]; and this is said by Ibn-' Ateeyeh to be the most correct explanation: (TA:) said by Aboo-Moosà to mean the iron, or leaden, thing in which is the wick [of the lamp]: thought by Az to mean the tube which is the place of the wick in the glass lamp, as being likened to the kuw~ap which is thus called: (TA:) some expl. it as having this meaning in the Kur xxiv. 35, and say that the miSobaAH there mentioned is the lighted wick: (Bd:) accord. to Mujáhid, the pillar, or the like, (AlEamuwd,) upon the top, or head, of which the miSobaAH [meaning lamp] is put: or the iron things by means of which the qinodiyl [or lamp] is suspended: IJ says that its A is originally w, and hence it is [often] written mi$ok`wpN: and Zj says that it is an Abyssinian word, and used in the language of the Arabs: (TA:) [the pl. is ma$aAkK, like masaAHK pl. of misoHaApN:] Kaab says that, in the verse of the Kur [xxiv. 35], by the mi$okaAp is meant the breast of Mohammad; and by the miSobaAH, his tongue; and by the zujaAjap, his mouth. (TA.)
ma$okuw~N * and ma$okiY~N: see $akiY~N, last sentence.

1 $al~ato yamiynuhu * , (S, O,) or yaduhu, (Mgh, TA,) or Alyadu, (Msb, K,) originally $alilato, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) aor. ta$al~u, (S, O, &c.,) inf. n. $alalN (S, * O, * Mgh, Msb, K) and $al~N, (Msb, K,) or the latter
is not allowable; (Ham p. 69;) this is the chaste form of the verb; (Th, TA;) and ↓ A^u$il~ato; (Th, K;) and $ul~ato, (Th, O, K,) but this last is bad, (Th, O, TA,) and is disallowed by Fr; (TA;) His right hand or arm, or his hand or arm, or the hand or arm, was, or became, unsound, or vitiated: (S, O, TA:) or deprived of the power of motion by an unsound, or a vitiated, state of its Euruwq [meaning veins or nerves]: (Msb:) or dried up; or stiff: or it went [or wasted] away. (K, TA.) One says, in praying for a person, laA ta$olalo yaduka [May thy hand, or arm, not become unsound, &c.]: (S, Msb, * K: *) and laA $alalFA and ↓ laA $alaAli, which mean the same; the last word like qaTaAmi. (K.) And $al~a Ea$oruhu, and xamosuhu, [His ten fingers became unsound, &c., and his five fingers,] and some say $al~ato, but this is more rare; i. e., the suppression of the fem. t is more usual in a case of this kind. (Lh, TA.) To one who has shot or thrown, or who has pierced or thrust, well, one says, laA $alalFA walaA EamFY [Mayest thou not experience unsoundness, &c., nor blindness]; and laA $al~a Ea$oruka [May thy ten fingers not become unsound, &c.], meaning A^aSaAbiEuka. (S, O.) He who says $al~a AlmaArinu and $al~ati AlA^u*unu is a foreigner. (Mgh.) The lawyers [improperly] use Al$~alal in relation to the *akar. (Msb.) One says also, $alilota yaA rajulu [Thou hast become unsound, &c., in thy hand or thine arm, O man]. (S, O.) And laA $alala, meaning laA ta$olalo, because it occupies the place of an imperative. (Lth, TA.) In the saying of the rájiz, (S,) namely, Abu-l-Khudree El-Yarboo'ee, (O, TA,)
muhora A^abiY AljaboHaAbi laA ta$al~iY
[Colt of Abu-l-Habháb, mayest thou not become unsound, &c., in the fore leg], (S, TA, [in the O, AbY AlHarivi, for AbY AlH`rivi,]) the last word is thus [for lA ta$olalo] on account of the rhyme: (S, O, TA:) [for] the next hemistich is
baAraka fiyka A@ll~`hu mino *iY A^al~i
[God bless thee as one possessing fleetness, or swiftness]; (O, TA;) *Y Al~ in this instance meaning *Y suroEapK. (S in art. Al.) -A2- $al~ahu; (K;) and $alalotu AlA_ibila, (S, O,) and Alr~ajula; (Msb;) aor.
$alu3a , (S, Msb,) inf. n. $al~N (S, O, Msb, K *) and $alalN, (K, * and Ksh in xii. 3,) like as qaSaSN is inf. n. of qaS~a, (Ksh ibid.,) or $alalN is a simple subst.; (S, O;) He drove him away; (K;) and I drove away (S, O, Msb) the camels, (S, O,) and the man. (Msb.) And mar~a fulaAnN ya$ul~uhumo biAls~ayofi Such a one passed along urging them on, and driving them, with the sword. (S.) [See also 4. ― -b2- Hence,] AlS~uboHu ya$ul~u AlZ~alaAma (tropical:) The dawn drives away the darkness. (TA.) ― -b3- And $al~ati AlEayonu damoEahaA (assumed tropical:) The eye sent forth [or shed] its tears: (Lh, K:) like $an~atohu: (Lh, TA:) asserted by Yaa- koob to be formed by substitution [of l for n]. (TA.) ― -b4- And $al~a Ald~iroEa, (O, TA,) and $al~ahaA Ealayohi, aor.
$alu3a , inf. n. $al~N, (TA,) He put on himself the coat of mail; on the authority of ISh. (O, TA.) ― -b5- $alalotu Alv~awoba, (S, O, Msb, TA,) inf. n. $al~N, (O,) I sewed the garment, or piece of cloth, (S, O, Msb, TA,) slightly; (S, O, TA; [omitted, probably by inadvertence, in my copy of the Msb;]) [previously to the second sewing termed Alkaf~u;] strangely omitted in the K: ↓ $ilaAlapN is [app. a subst., not an inf. n., signifying The act, or art, of so sewing;] the contr. of kifaAfapN. (TA.)

4 A$l~ yamiynahu * , (S,) or yadahu, (Fr, K,) He (i. e. God, S) made his right hand or arm, (S,) or his hand, or arm, (K,) to become unsound, or vitiated: (S:) or to become dried up, or stiff: or to go [or waste] away: (K:) or A$l~ Alyada He (i. e. God) made the hand or arm to become deprived of the power of motion by an unsound, or a vitiated, state of its Euruwq [meaning veins or nerves]. (Msb.) And A$l~ A@ll~`h yadahu is said by way of imprecation [as meaning May God render his hand or arm unsound, &c.]. (O.) See also 1, first sentence. -A2- [It is said that] A_i$olaAlN signifies The driving away a camel, and a troop or company with the sword: [like $al~N: see 1, latter half:] ― -b2- and The making war. (KL.)

7 An$l~ *
He became driven away. (K, TA. [In some of the copies of the K, An$l~ bihi, meaning He became driven away by, or with, him, or it.]) And An$l~t AlA_ibilu The camels became driven away. (S.) And An$l~wA maToruwdiyna [They went driven away]; referring to a company of people. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] An$l~ Al*~iy^obu fiY Alganami (assumed tropical:) The wolf made an incursion among the sheep or goats; as also An$n~: mentioned by Az in art. n$g. (TA.) ― -b3- And An$l~ Als~ayolu (assumed tropical:) The torrent began to be impelled, before its becoming vehement: (Sh, O, K:) and so Ansl~. (Sh, O.) ― -b4- And An$l~ AlmaTaru (assumed tropical:) The rain descended. (K.)

R. Q. 1 $alo$alotu AlmaA='a *
I made the water to fall in drops; (S;) in consecutive drops. (TA.) And $alo$ala bawolahu, (K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, ta$alo$ala,]) and bibawolihi, (S, O, K, TA,) inf. n. $alo$alapN and $ilo$aAlN, [both incorrectly written by Freytag,] (K, TA,) He (a boy, S, O, TA) scattered his urine; emitted it dispersedly: (K, TA:) the subst. [signifying the act of doing so] is ↓ $alo$aAlN with fet-h. (K.) And $alo$ala Als~ayofu Ald~ama, [in the CK, erroneously, bAld~ami,] and bihi ↓ ta$alo$ala, The sword poured forth the blood. (K, TA.)

R. Q. 2 ta$alo$ala *
It (water) fell in consecutive drops. (TA.) And ta$alo$ala damFA It (a wound) dripped with blood in consecutive drops. (TA.) See also R. Q. 1, last sentence.
$al~apN * : see the next paragraph.

$ul~apN *
i. q. niy~apN [app. as meaning The thing, or place, that one proposes to himself as the object of his aim]: (S, O, K:) the place that a company of men have proposed to themselves as the object of their aim or journey: so in the M: (TA:) or the niy~ap [in the sense thus expl. in the M and TA] in journeying: (T, K:) and thus also ↓ $ul~aY, and likewise in fasting, and in warring: one says, ↓ A^ayona $ul~aAhumo [Where is the place that they propose to themselves as the object of their aim in journeying, &c.?]. (TA.) ― -b2- And A remote affair (S, O, K) that one seeks; (K;) as also ↓ $al~apN. (O, K.) -A2- See also $alalN. -A3- And see $aliylN.

$alalN *
An unsoundness in the hand or arm, or a vitiated state thereof. (S, O.) [See also 1, first sentence, where it is mentioned as an inf. n.] ― -b2- And (tropical:) A stain, (S, O,) or a blackness, (K,) or a dust-colour, (TA,) in a garment, or piece of cloth, that does not become removed by washing. (S, O, K, TA.) One says, maA h`*aA Al$~alalu fiY vawobika, (S, O,) or bivawobika, (TA,) (tropical:) [What is this stain, &c., in thy garment?] -A2- Also The act of driving away: (S, O, K:) a subst.: (S, O:) or an inf. n., (Ksh in xii. 3,) [see 1, latter half,] i. q. TarodN, like [the inf. n.] $al~N, (K,) as also ↓ $ul~apN. (TA.)
$ulalN * and $ululN: see $ulo$ulN.
laA $alaAli * : see 1, second sentence.

jaAw^uwA $ilaA lFA *
They came driving away the camels. (S, O.) ― -b2- And *ahaba Alqawomu $ilaAlFA The people went driven away (Aino$al~uwA maToruwdiyna). (TA.) ― -b3- And $ilaAlN signifies A company of men in a scattered, or dispersed, state. (S, O.)

$aluwlN * , of she-camels, and of women, (O, K, in the latter of which, in the place of waAln~isaA='i, is found wAl$~aA='i [i. e. and of sheep or. goats], TA,) is like naAbN [meaning Aged]. (O, K.) ― -b2- See also $ulo$ulN, in two places.

$aliylN * , (S, O, K,) accord. to AO, (S,) or A 'Obeyd, (O, TA,) An innermost covering for the body, worn beneath the coat of mail, (S, O, K,) whether it be a vawob or some other thing: (S, O:) and, (S, O, K,) sometimes, (S, O,) a short coat of mail, (S, O, K,) worn beneath the upper one, (S, O,) or worn beneath the large one: or in a general sense: (K:) [i. e.] a coat of mail itself is called $aliylN; (ISh, TA;) and also ↓ $ul~apN: (TA:) pl. A^a$il~apN; (S, O, TA;) in the K, erroneously, $il~apN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (S, O, K) A [cloth such as is termed] Hilos, (S, O,) or misoH, of wool or of [goats'] hair, (K,) that is put upon the rump, or croup, of the camel, (S, O, K,) behind the [saddle called] raHol. (K.) [See also saniyfN.] -A2- And The part, of a valley, in which the water flows: (K:) or the middle of a valley, (S, O, K,) where flows the main body of water: (S, O:) so says A 'Obeyd, on the authority of AO; but the word commonly known [in this sense] is saliylN, with the unpointed s. (O.) -A3- And The nuxaAE [or spinal cord]; (K, TA;) [also called the saliyl;] i. e. the white Eiroq [or nerve] that is in the vertebræ of the back: mentioned by Kr. (TA.) ― -b2- And Long streaks, or strips, of flesh, extending with the back: (K, TA:) n. un. with p also mentioned by Kr: but the more approved word
is with [the unpointed] s. (TA.) -A4- And Clouds in which is no water; syn. jahaAmN. (AA, O.)
$ilaAlapN * : see 1, last sentence.
$ul~aY * : see $ul~apN, in two places.

$alo$alN * Water, and blood, falling in consecutive drops; as also ↓ muta$alo$ilN. (K, TA.) ― -b2- A ziq~ [or skin for wine &c.] flowing [or leaking]. (TA.) And Roasted flesh-meat ($iwaA='N) of which the grease, or gravy, drips; like $aro$arN and ra$oraA$N. (TA in art. $r.) ― -b3- maA='N *uw $alo$alK (S, O) and ↓ $alo$aAlK (S, O *) Water having a dripping. (S, O.) -A2- See also the next paragraph.

$ulo$ulN * A man light, active, or agile; (S;) [and] so ↓ mi$al~N, (O,) and ↓ $aluwlN: (O, TA:) or the first, a boy, or young man, sharp-headed; light, or active, in spirit; brisk, lively, or sprightly, in his work; and so $uEo$uEN, and julojulN: (IAar, TA:) or a man clever, ingenious, acute, or sharp; light, active, or agile: (O:) or light, active, or agile, in accomplishing that which is wanted; quick; a good companion; cheerful in mind; as also ↓ $alo$alN, and ↓ mi$al~N [in the CK (erroneously) mu$il~N], and ↓ $aluwlN, and ↓ $ululN, and ↓ $ulalN, (K, TA,) of which last the pl. is $ulaluwna, it having no broken pl. because of the rareness of fuEalN as the measure of an epithet: (Sb, TA:) and having little flesh; light, active, or agile, in that which he commences, (K, TA,) of work &c.; (TA;) as also ↓ muta$alo$ilN: (K, TA:) or this latter [simply] lean, or having little flesh. (S, O.)
$alo$alapN * The falling of water in drops, (K, TA,) consecutively. (TA.) [If an inf. n. in this sense, its verb is most probably $ulo$ila.]
$alo$aAlN * : see R. Q. 1: ― -b2- and see also $alo$alN.
$ulaA$ilN * , applied to a plant, or herbage, Fresh, juicy, or sappy. (TA.)

A^a$al~u * A man whose hand, or arm, has become unsound, or vitiated: (S, TA:) or deprived of the power of motion by an unsound, or a vitiated, state of its Euruwq [meaning veins or nerves]: (Msb:) or dried up, or stiff: or whose hand, or arm, has gone [or wasted] away: (K, TA:) fem. $al~aA='u. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- And yadN $al~aA='u (Mgh, TA) A hand, or an arm, that will not comply with that which its possessor desires of it, by reason of disease therein. (TA.) ― -b3- And EayonN $al~aA='u An eye of which the sight has gone. (O, Msb, K.)

mi$al~N *
A [spear of the kind called] miTorad [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- And A he-ass that drives away [his she-asses] much. (K. [In the CK, in this sense, erroneously written mi$olN. See mu$alilN.]) ― -b3- See also $ulo$ulN, in two places. ― -b4- One says also A_in~ahu lami$al~N EawonN [thus app., but written in my original without any syll. signs,] meaning Verily he is a writer soundly, or thoroughly, learned; or skilled, intelligent, and experienced; and sufficing. (TA.) -A2- Also A garment with which the neck is covered: mentioned by the sheykh Zádeh in his Commentary on El-Beydáwee. (TA.)
mu$al~ilN * A he-ass much busied by the care of his she-asses. (IAar, O, L, K. [See also mi$al~N.])
muta$alo$ilN * : see $alo$alN: ― -b2- and see also $ulo$ulN.

$alojamN *
A well-known plant; (S;) [colza: see salojamN:] mentioned by the author of the L, and other leading lexicologists, following J. (TA.)

$il~amN *
Sparks of anger: so in the saying yataTaAyaru $il~amuhu [His sparks of anger fly about]: (K:) and so $in~amuhu. (TA.)
$aAlamN * : see what follows.
$awolamN * : see what follows.

$ayolamN * The ruw^aAn [now applied to darnel-grass (but see this latter word zw^An)] that is [often found] in wheat; also called ↓ $aAlamN (Msb, K) and ↓ $awolamN; (K;) of Pers., or foreign, origin; (A^aSoluhu A^aEojamiY~N;) and it is said that one of its two extremities is sharp and the other thick: (Msb:) of the dial. of the Sawád: accord. to IAar, i. q. ziywaAn [sic.] and saEiyE: AHn says that it is a small, oblong, red, erect grain, resembling in form the suws [or grub] of wheat; and it does not intoxicate, but renders the wheat very bitter: and in one place he says, the plant of the $ylm spreads upon the ground, and its leaves are like those of the xilaAf [or salix Aegyptia] that is termed baloxiY~, very green, and juicy, or tender; people eat its leaves when they are fresh, and they are pleasant [to the taste], without bitterness; but its grain is more intensely, or nauseously, bitter (A^aEoqaY) than aloes. (TA.) [Forskål, in his Flora Aegypt. Arab. p. 199, after describing the zw^An, says, “ $ylm etiam agri vitium; a priore tamen diversa species: decocto plantæ obtunduntur sensus hominis qui operationem chirurgicam subire debet; Avicenna sic referente. ” See also sakarapN.] -A2- [Golius says, on the authority of a gloss in a copy of the KL, that it signifies also A short, or little, avaricious, man; “ vir curtus, avarus: ” a meaning, if correct, app. tropical.]

1 $alaA * , aor.
$aluwa , He went, or journeyed. (K.) -A2- And He raised, uplifted, or took up, a thing; syn. rafaEa. (IAar, Az, K.)

4 A$lY * , (S, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. A_i$olaA='N, (Msb,) He called a dog, (AZ, S, Msb,) &c.: (Msb:) and he called a she-camel, (ISk, S, K,) and a ewe or she-goat, by her name, (ISk, S,) to milk her. (ISk, S, K.) And A$lY daAb~atahu He showed the mixolaAp [or nose-bag (in the CK erroneously AlmixolATa)] to his beast in order that it should come to him. (K.) [See also 10.] Accord. to IAar and several others, one says, A^a$olayotu Alkaloba EalaY AlS~ayodi, meaning I incited, or urged, the dog [against the object, or objects, of the chase]; like A^agorayotuhu in measure and in signification: (Mgh, ast; Msb, TA:) but this is disallowed by ISk, (S, Msb, TA,) and by Th; (S, Mgh, TA;) and in like manner, A$lythu biAlS~ayodi in the same sense; though they are allowed by others: one says, however, [by common consent,] A^a$olayotu Alkaloba lilS~ayodi, meaning I called the dog to the chase. (Mgh.)
8 A_i$otalawa see the next paragraph, in two places.

10 Ast$lAhu * , (S, K,) and ↓ A$tlAhu, (S, * K, [accord. to my copies of the former, A^a$olaAhu, but a verse immediately following as an ex. shows the right reading,]) He called him in order to save him, or rescue him, (S, K,) or to make him come forth, (S,) from straitness, or perdition, (K,) or from a place: (S:) this is the primary signification. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence] the former, (S, K, TA,) and ↓ the latter also, (S, TA, i. e. A$tlAhu, [thus in this instance in the copies of the S,]) (tropical:) He saved him, or rescued him. (S, K, TA.) -A2- And Ast$lY He (a man, TA) was, or became, angry. (K, TA.)
$alFA * : see the next paragraph.

$ilowN *
A limb, or member; (Msb, K;) as also ↓ $ilowapN: (TA:) or a limb, or member, of flesh-meat: whence, in a trad., AytiniY bi$ilowihaA AlA^ayomani [Bring thou to me its right limb]: (S:) pl. A^a$olaA='N (S, Msb, TA) and A^a$olK, [originally A^a$oluwN,] like A^adolK pl. of dalowN. (TA.) ― -b2- And The body of anything [i. e. of any animal]: as also ↓ $alFA; (K;) which latter is expl. by ISd as signifying the skin and body of anything; and is applied in a trad. to the inner side of a haunch as meaning having no flesh upon it: (TA:) [or,] accord. to IDrd, $ilowu AlA_inosaAni signifies the body of the man after its wasting, or decaying: (Msb, TA:) [or] A^a$olaA='u AlA_inosaAni means the members, or limbs, of the man after wasting, or decaying, and becoming dissundered: (S, TA:) and (hence, Msb) one says, banuw fulaAnK A^a$olaA='N fiY baniY fulaAnK, meaning (assumed tropical:) The sons of such a one are remains among the sons of such a one: (S, Msb:) and huwa mino A^a$olaA='i Alqawomi (assumed tropical:) He is of the remains of the people: [for] $ilowN signifies (assumed tropical:) a remain, or remaining portion: and $lY~ [app. $uliY~N, said to be like gnY~, but this is, I doubt not, a mistranscription for EuniY~N, i. e. originally of the measure fuEuwlN, is another pl. of $ilowN, and ] signifies (assumed tropical:) remains of any thing. (TA.) [See also $aliy~apN.] ― -b3- Also Any skinned animal of which somewhat has been eaten and a portion remains: (K:) or a portion remaining, whether much or little, of a sheep or goat of which part has been eaten: (L voce saliyxN:) pl. A^a$olaA='N. (K.) ― -b4- And A^a$olaA='u All~ijaAmi (assumed tropical:) The straps, or thongs, of the bit or bridle: (A, K:) or such as have become old, and of which the iron appertenance has become slender, (K,
TA,) or, as in the M, [of which] the iron appertenances [have become slender], without straps, or thongs: app. likened to limbs, or members, of flesh-meat. (TA.)
$ilowapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

$aliy~apN *
A piece, or portion, of flesh-meat &c. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A remnant, or remaining portion; (K, TA;) only of property: (S, K, * TA:) pl. $alaAyaA. (S, TA.) One says, *ahabato maA$iyapu fulaAnK wabaqiyato lahu $aliy~apN (assumed tropical:) [The cattle of such a one went away, but a remnant remained to him]. (AZ, S.) [See also $ilowN.]

mu$al~FY *
Lean, or light of flesh: (K, TA:) an epithet applied to a man. (TA.)
ma$aAlK * , in the dial. of El-Hijáz, The Things, or instruments, with which scarification is performed upon the cheeks: app. pl. of mi$olaApN. (TA.)

Al$~aloyaAqu *
A certain northern constellation, [namely, Lyra,] consisting of ten stars, the bright star [alpha] of which is called Aln~asoru AlwaAqiEu: the Arabs liken it to a vulture (nasor) which has contracted its wings to itself, as though it had alighted upon a thing: the vulgar call [the three chief stars in] it AlA^avaAfiY: and before the bright star is a dim star which the Arabs call AlA^aZofaAr [i. e. the talons]. (Kzw. [Not in any of my Lexicons.])

1 $amimotu * , aor. A^a$am~u; and $amamotu, aor. A^a$um~u; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) the latter mentioned by AO; (S, TA;) third pers. of each $am~a; (Mgh;) inf. n. $am~u (S, Msb, K) and $amiymN, (S, K,) which are of both verbs, (TA,) and $im~iymaY, mentioned by Z (K, TA) alone; (TA;) I smelt, i. e. perceived by the nose, (K,) a thing, (S, Msb, K, *) or an odour; (Mgh;) and ↓ Ai$otamamotu signifies the same; (S, Msb, K, TA; [Aa$omamotuhu in the CK is a mistranscription for Ai$otamamotuhu;]) and ↓ ta$am~amotu also, (K,) and ↓ $am~ayotu, thus in the copies of the K, but correctly ↓ $am~amotu: (TA: [both, however, are mentioned in the CK: the former like qaS~ayotu for qaS~aSotu:]) or Al$~aYo'a ↓ ta$am~amotu signifies $amimotuhu fiY muholapK [I smelt the thing leisurely, or gently]: (S, TA:) or Al$~aYo'a ↓ t$m~m and ↓ A$tm~hu both signify he put the thing near to his nose in order that he might draw in its odour. (AHn, TA.) ― -b2- See an ex. in a prov. mentioned voce ximaArN. ― -b3- [Hence,] $um~a (assumed tropical:) He was tried, or proved by trial or experiment or experience; syn. Auxotubira. (IAar, K.) -A2- $am~a, see. pers. $amimota, aor. ya$am~u, (Msb,) inf. n. $amamN, (S, * Msb, K, *) He (a man) was high, or elevated, in the nose. (S, * Msb, K. *) ― -b2- [And hence,] $am~a, (K,) [sec. pers. $amimota,] inf. n. $amamN, (TA,) (tropical:) He (a man, TA) magnified himself; or behaved proudly, or haughtily. (K, TA. [And A$m~ has a similar meaning.]) ― -b3- [This verb is also probably used in other senses, said of a mountain, &c.: see $amamN below.] ― -b4- See also 4, near the end.
2 $am~amotu * and $am~ayotu : see above, in two places.

3 $aAm~aA * , (K,) inf. n. mu$aAm~apN, (S, TA,) They smelt each other; (S, * K;) as also ↓ t$Am~A, (K,) inf. n. ta$aAm~N. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] $aAmimohu (tropical:) Look thou to see what is with him, or in his mind, (maA Einodahu, S, K, TA,) and draw near to him, (K, TA,) and seek after the knowledge of what is with him, or in his mind, (mA Endh,) by means of informations and disclosure; as though each smelt what was with the other in order to act according thereto. (TA.) And hence the saying, $aAmamonaAhumo vum~a naAwa$onaAhumo (tropical:) [We endeavoured, or looked, to ascertain their condition; then we engaged them in near, though not close, conflict]. (TA.) You say also, $aAmamotu Alr~ajula meaning [simply] (assumed tropical:) I drew near to the man. (S.) mu$aAm~apN [used tropically] signifies (assumed tropical:) The looking into a thing. (KL.) And (assumed tropical:) The approaching the enemy so that the two parties see each other. (S.)

4 A$m~hu A_iy~aAhu *
He made him to smell it, or perceive it by the nose. (K.) You say, A^a$omamotuhu AlTiyba [I made him to smell the perfume]. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- And [hence] one says to the prefect, or governor, or prince, or commander, A^a$omimoniY yadaka A^uqab~ilohaA (assumed tropical:) [Suffer me to approach thy hand that I may kiss it]; (S, * TA;) a phrase like naAwiloniY yadaka, (TA,) but better than the latter phrase: so says Kh. (S.) ― -b3- And A$m~ AlxitaAna, and A$m~t AlbaZora, (tropical:) He, and she, i. e. the operator, took, (K, TA,) or cut off, (TA,) a small portion of the prepuce, and of the baZor [q. v.]: (K, TA:) or the latter signifies she cut off a portion of the nawaAp [q. v.], not extirpating it. (TA.) ― -b4- And A$m~ AlHarofa, (S, * K,) inf. n. A_i$omaAmN, (S,) (assumed tropical:) He made the consonant to have a smack of the dammeh or the kesreh, (lit., made it to smell, S, or to taste, K, the dammeh or the kesreh,) in such a manner (S, K) that the A_i$omaAm, (S,) or that the dammeh or kesreh, (K,) was not heard, (S, K,) what is termed A_i$omaAmu AlHarofi being less than what is termed rawomu AlHarakapi, the former being apparent only by the motion of the lip, (S,) or of the upper lip, (so in one of my copies of the S,) no account being taken of it, (S, K,) i. e. of the dammeh or kesreh, (K,) it not being reckoned as a Harakap because of its feebleness, the consonant in this case being quiescent or like that which is quiescent, (S,) and the prosodical measure not being broken thereby: (K:) for ex., in the following verse,
mataY A^anaAmu laA yuw^ar~iqoniY AlkariY
layolFA walaA A^asomaEu A^ajoraAsa AlmaTiY
[meaning AlkariY~ and AlmaTiY~, (as is said in one of my copies of the S,) i. e. When I sleep, he who lets beasts on hire will not render me wakeful by night, nor do I hear the bells of the camels on which people ride], the Arabs [or, as is said in the TA, some of the Arabs] make the q [in yw^r~qnY] to have a smack of the dammeh; but if you took account of the Harakap of the A_i$omaAm [in this case,] the measure of the verse would be broken, [the foot] rqnY AlkrY becoming, in the scanning, mutafaAEiluno, which may be only in the kaAmil; whereas this verse is of the rajaz: (Sb, S:) another case of A_i$omaAm is that of the Y in duwayob~apN, [in which that letter is quiescent, but made to have a smack of kesreh,] as is the same letter in every similar case, in a dim. noun, when followed by a doubled letter. (Zj, T in art. db.) Also He pronounced the consonant with a Harakap [or vowel-sound] between damm and kesr, apparent only in utterance, not in writing; as in qiyla and giyDa in the Kur xi. 46. (I 'Ak pp. 130 and 131.) [See also rawomu AlHarakapi, voce raAma.] ― -b5- [Golius explains A$m~ as signifying also “ Reduxit, fecit ut converteret se ab aliqua re; ” as on the authority of the KL; in my copy of which, however, I do not find this meaning.] -A2- A$m~, (S, K,) inf. n. A_i$omaAmN, [as an intrans. verb,] said of a man, (S,) also signifies He passed by, or along, raising his head; (S, K, TA;) and magnified, or exalted, himself; behaved proudly, or disdainfully; or elevated his nose, from pride. (TA. [See also 1, near the end.]) ― -b2- And He turned away from a thing. (K.) One says bayonaA humo fiY wajohK A_i*o A^a$am~uwA, i. e. [While they were in a certain direction, lo,] they turned away; (S, TA, as from AA;) or ↓ $am~uwA. (Thus in one of my copies of the S [but I think it to be a mistranscription].) And A$m~ Alqawomu The people, or party, deviated in their directions to the right and left: a phrase heard in this sense by AA. (S.)
5 ta$am~a3a see 1, in three places.
6 ta$aAoma3a see 3, first sentence.
8 A_i$otama3a see 1, in two places.

10 Ast$m~ *
He desired to smell. (KL.) ― -b2- And He perceived a smell, or an odour, from a thing. (KL.) ― -b3- daxala AlmuxaATu A^anofahu faA^osota$am~ahu faA^adoxalahu fiY Haloqihi, said of a man, means Aisotano$aqahu [i. e. (tropical:) The mucus entered his nose, and he snuffed it up, and made it to pass into his fauces]; the verb being metaphorically thus used, like as AlAisotino$aAqu is metaphorically used for Al$~am~u. (Mgh.)

$amamN * inf. n. of the intrans. verb $am~a [q. v.]. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- [Used as a simple subst.,] Highness of the nose: (Msb:) or highness of the bone of the nose, (S, K,) and beauty thereof, (K,) with evenness, or straightness, of its upper part, (S, K, when there is in it a gibbousness it is termed qanFA, S,) and uprightness of the end, or lowest part: (K:) or, as some say, this last quality [alone]: (TA:) or length of the end, or lower part, of the nose, so that it extends over the middle of the mustache, (wuruwdu AlA^aronabapi,) with beautiful evenness, or straightness, of the bone, and highness thereof greater than the highness that is termed *alafN: or length and slenderness of the nose, and a downward extending of its rawovap [i. e. end or tip, or part where the blood that flows from the nostrils drops or drips]: (K:) or [simply] length.
in the nose. (Ham p. 789.) ― -b3- And, in a man, The quality of having what is termed $amamN of the nose. (S.) ― -b4- [And hence, (tropical:) Self-magnification, or pride, or haughtiness: see 1, near the end.] ― -b5- And (tropical:) Generosity. (Ham p. 728.) ― -b6- Also Highness, (K,) or tallness of the head, (S,) of a mountain. (S, K.) ― -b7- And (tropical:) Nearness: and (tropical:) remoteness: thus having two contr. meanings. (K, TA.) It has both of such meanings in the phrase daAruhu $amamN (tropical:) [His house, or abode, is near: and, remote]: (K, TA:) and in the phrase raA^ayotuhu mino $amamK (tropical:) [I saw him, or it, from within a short distance: and, from afar]. (TA.)
$amuwmN * A thing [odorous, fragrant, or] fit to be smelt. (KL.)

$amiymN *
High, or elevated: (S, K:) applied in this sense to a [camel's saddle such as is called] qatab. (S.)

$am~aAmN *
A sort of melon resembling a small colocynth, [or rather a small melon resembling a colocynth,] streaked with redness and greenness and yellowness: called in Pers. dasotanobuwyah [i. e. “ perfume ”]; (K;) originally dasoto buwY [or dasoto buwyaho]: (TA:) its odour is cool, pleasant, lenitive, and narcotic; and the eating of it is laxative to the bowels: (K:) [The cucumis dudaïm of Linn.; called by Forskål cucumis schemmam: the latter thus describes it (Flora Aegypt. Arab. p. 169): “ Caules 5-sulcati, setis rigidis, scandentes, cirrhosi: folia cordato-oblonga, acuta, subsinuata, dentato-repanda, hispida: calyces villosi, molles: flores flavi, conferti in alis: fructus globosoovatus, glaberrimus, magnitudine citri, flavus, maculis inæqualibus, fulvo-ferrugineis, versus polos in lineas confluentibus; pulpa aquosa, seminibus tota plena: fructus juvenis villosus; maturus glaber: odor, fortis nec ingratus; eamque ob caussam cultus; non edulis: ” in the present day, the same appellation is applied in Egypt to several species of melon, of pleasant odour and taste; but this application I believe to be of very late origin: see also luf~aAHN: and see De Sacy's “ Rel. de l'Égypte par Abd-allatif, ” pp. 126-7.]

$am~aAmaAtN *
Sweet odours that one smells. (K.)

$amaA$imu *
Ripe dates remaining upon the raceme. (AZ, K.)

[
$aAm~N *
Smelling, or perceiving by the nose.] ― -b2- yaA A@bona $aAm~api Alwa*orapi [O son of her who smells the wa*orap] is an expression of reproach. (S.)

A^a$am~u * , applied to a man, (Msb,) Having that quality of the nose which is termed $amamN; (Msb, K;) or so A^a$am~u AlA^anofi, thus applied: (S:) fem. $am~aA='u: (Msb, TA:) and pl. $um~N. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence, (tropical:) Self-magnifying, or proud, or haughty: or] a chief characterized by disdainfulness, scornfulness, or disdainful and proud incompliance, (K, TA,) and high-minded. (TA.) ― -b3- Also A mountain tall, (S, TA,) or high, (TA,) in the head. (S, TA.) [And High, as applied to a place of ascent in a mountain: see an ex. of the pl. in a verse cited voce taSad~afa.] ― -b4- And A shoulder high in the head of its bone. (K.) ― -b5- [Freytag mentions two other meanings: ― -b6- “ Ventus ex alto veniens, qui penetrantioris est odoratus: ― -b7- [and] fem. $am~aA' Jugum extensum in monte: ” from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.]
mu$im~N * [Turning away, or averse]. One says, EaraDotu Ealayohi ka*aA faA_i*aA huwa mu$im~N laA yuriyduhu [I offered to him such a thing, and lo, he was averse, not desiring it]. (S.)

[
mi$am~N *
An instrument of smelling; like as misomaEN signifies “ an instrument of hearing. ” ― -b2- Hence, its pl.] ma$aAm~u signifies Noses. (KL.) ― -b3- [This pl. is expl. by Jac. Schultens, as meaning Perfumes (odoramenta): so says Freytag.]

ma$omuwmN *
A thing that is smelt; such as any sweet-smelling plant: like as maA^okuwlN signifies “ a thing that is eaten: ” (Msb:) [and] musk: (S, K:) [pl. ma$omuwmaAtN.]

1 $amita * , aor.
$amata , (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. $amaAtapN (S, K) and $amaAtN, (K,) or the former is a simple subst., (Msb, [in which no inf. n. is mentioned,]) He (an enemy) rejoiced: (TA:) or he (a man, TA) rejoiced at the affliction of the enemy: (K, TA:) you say, $amita bihi He rejoiced at his [an enemy's] affliction. (S, A, Msb.)

2 $am~ata see 4. ― -b2- ta$omiytN is syn. with tasomiytN: [i. e.] ta$omiytu AlEaATisi signifies The uttering a prayer for the sneezer; (S;) when he has, in obedience to an injunction of the Prophet, said AlHamodu lil~`hi [Praise be to God]: (Har p. 250:) you say, $am~ata AlEaATisa, (ISd, A, TA,) and $m~t Ealayohi, meaning [as expl. in art. smt: or] He prayed for the sneezer that he might not be in a state in which his enemy might rejoice at his affliction: (ISd, TA:) $m~t is better and more common than sm~t: (A 'Obeyd, TA in art. sm~t and in the present art.:) but the latter is said by Th to be the original word: or the meaning is, he said to the sneezer, May God put away, or avert, from thee that on account of which one would rejoice at thy affliction: or it is from Al$~awaAmitu as signifying “ the legs ” of a quadruped, as though meaning he prayed for the sneezer that he might be firm, or steadfast, in his obedience to God. (L and TA from the Fáïk &c.) And $m~t lahu and Ealayohi, inf. n. as above, He prayed for what was good for him; prayed for a blessing upon him; as also sm~t, but the former is the better and the more common. (L and TA from the T and Fáïk &c.) ― -b3- Also i. q. taxoyiytN: (K:) you say, $m~thu fulaAnN, meaning xay~abahu [Such a one disappointed him; or caused him to be disappointed of attaining what he desired or sought: or denied him, refused him, prohibited him from attaining, or debarred him from, that which he desired or sought]. (TA.) ― -b4- And i. q. jamoEN [The act of collecting, &c.]. (K. [But SM says that he had searched to the utmost for this meaning without finding it in any other lexicon.])

4 A$mthu A@ll~`hu bihi *
God made him (i. e. the enemy, A, Msb) to rejoice at his affliction. (A, * Msb, K, TA.) For falaA tu$omito biYa A@loA^aEadaA='a [Therefore make not thou the enemies to rejoice at my affliction], in the Kur [vii. 149], Mujáhid is related to have read ↓ flA tu$am~ito: but the correctness of this is doubted. (TA.)
5 ta$am~utN * signifies A people's returning disappointed of attaining their desire, without spoil. (K.)
8 Ai$otimaAtN * [A camel's] beginning to be fat. (K. [See the part. n., below.])

$imaAtN *
Disappointment; frustration of one's endeavour or hope: (IB, TA:) a subst. from ta$omiytN as signifying taxoyiybN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, thus written in copies of the K, [and in the S,] with kesr, (TA,) [but in the CK $amAt,] and ↓ $amaAtaY, (K,) Persons suffering disappointment; or failing of attaining their desire; (K, TA;) without spoil: (TA:) [pls.] without any sing.; (K:) or the latter has no sing. known to ISd: (TA:) [but] ↓ $aAmitN has this meaning as a sing. part, n., and $mAt [app. $imaAtN] is its pl. (IB, TA.) One says, ↓ rajaEuwA $amaAtaY, (IAar, TA,) or $imaAtFA, (S,) They returned suffering disappointment; or failing of attaining their desire; (IAar, S, TA;) without spoil; and so ↓ mu$am~atiyna and ↓ muta$am~itiyna. (TA.)

[
$amiytN *
Reproach (“ convicium ”): so Golius, as from the KL; but I do not find it in my copy of that work.]
$amaAtaY * : see $imaAtN, in two places.

$aAmitN * One rejoicing at the affliction of an enemy: [fem. with p: pl. masc. $um~aAtN and fem. $awaAmitu; or the latter may be anomalously masc., like fawaArisu &c.; and as such it is evidently used in the L, in one place; but in another place, where it cites an explanation by AO, as fem.: both are mentioned in the M and L and TA, and the latter in the S and A also.] One says, Aall~`hum~a laA tuTiyEan~a liY $aAmitFA [O God, comply not with the desire of one who is to me a rejoicer at my affliction]; meaning, do not with me that which one who rejoices at my affliction likes, or approves; for in that case, Thou wouldst be as though Thou obeyedst him. (ISk, L, TA.) And baAta fulaAnN balayolapi Al$~awaAmiti Such a one passed a night such as would make to rejoice those, or those females, that would rejoice at the affliction of an enemy; (S, A, L, TA;) i. e., a distressing night. (A.) [And a verse cited in the next paragraph presents, as some read it, a similar ex. of Al$~awaAmit.] -A2- See also $imaAtN.

$aAmitapN * [fem. of $aAmitN, q. v. -A2- Also], as a subst., sing. of $awaAmitu (S, TA) which signifies The legs of a beast. (S, A, K, TA.) One says, laA taraka A@ll~`hu lahu $aAmitapF, i. e. [May God not leave to him] a leg
of a beast. (AA, S, A, TA.) And En-Nábighah [Edh-Dhubyánee] says,
faA@rotaAEa mino Sawoti kal~aAbK fabaAta lahu
TawoEa Al$~awaAmiti mino xawofK wamino Saradi
[And that has been frightened at the voice of a huntsman with his dogs,] and passed the night in consequence thereof standing, (lit. obeying the legs,) by reason of fear and [also] of cold; the poet describing a [wild] bull: (AO, L, TA:) but some read TawoEu (instead of TawoEa); and accord. to this reading, the meaning is, and passed the night having, of fear and of cold, what was agreeable with the desire of such as would rejoice at his affliction; the phrase being like the saying Aall~`hum~a laA tuTiyEan~a liY $aAmitFA meaning as expl. in the next preceding paragraph: (ISk, L, TA:) or he passed the night having [of fear and of cold] what would rejoice the $awaAmit that heard thereof: (AO, L, TA:) [and in like manner, Z says,] baAta TawoEa Al$~awaAmiti [without lahu, and with TwE in the accus. case, lit. he passed the night obeying those, or those females, that rejoiced at his affliction,] means, as those that rejoiced at his affliction liked, or approved. (A.)
mu$am~atN * A king prayed for (K, TA) with the prayers that are offered for kings. (TA.) -A2- See also $imaAtN, last sentence.
mu$am~itN * Any one praying, or who prays, for what is good; as also musam~itN. (S.)

A_ibilN mu$otamitapN *
Camels beginning to be fat. (TA.)
muta$am~itN * : see its pl. voce $imaAtN, last sentence.

1 $amaxa * , (S, L, K,) aor.
$amuxa , inf. n. $umuwxN, (L,) It (a mountain) was high, or lofty. (S, L, K.) ― -b2- Hence, (Har p. 442,) $amaxa biA^anofihi, (S, A, L, K,) and $amaxa A^anofuhu, aor. and inf. n. as above, (L,) He (a man) magnified, or exalted, himself; was proud; (S, A, L, K;) behaved proudly, or disdainfully; elevated his nose, from pride. (L.) [See also zamaxa.]
niy~apN $amaxN * (L, K) and ↓ $amuwxN (L) A distant, far-reaching, or far-aiming, intention, purpose, or design; [in an action or a journey &c.;] (L, K;) as also ny~apN zamaxN and zamuwxN. (L.)

mafaAzapN $amuwxN *
A desert, or waterless desert, farextending; (K;) as also zmuwxN. (TA.) ― -b2- See also $amaxN.
$am~aAxN * : see what follows, in two places.

jabalN $aAmixN *
A high, or lofty, mountain; (S, A, L;) as also ↓ $am~aAxN [but in an intensive sense, i. e. a very high or lofty mountain]: (L:) pl. jibaAlN $awaAmixu (S, A) and $um~axN. (A.) ― -b2- Hence, $aAmixN signifies also Proud; (L, TA;) elevating the nose, from pride, or disdain: [like zaAmixN:] pl. $um~axN: (L, K:) and ↓ $am~aAxN a man who magnifies, or exalts, himself much; or elevates his nose much, from pride. (L.) ― -b3- And A^unuwfN $um~axN [Noses elevated, from pride]; like zum~axN. (S.) ― -b4- And nasabN $aAmixN (tropical:) [A proud, or high, lineage]. (TA.)

1 $amara * , aor.
$amura , inf. n. $amorN: see the next paragraph, in five places.

2 $m~r * , (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. ta$omiyrN, (S, K,) He raised, (S, Msb, K,) or tucked up, or contracted, (A,) his garment, (Msb, K,) or his waist-wrapper, (S,) [or his sleeve,] or his skirts. (A.) One says, $m~r Eano saAqihi [He raised, or tucked up, his garment, or waist-wrapper, or skirts, from his shank]. (S.) [And in like manner, ↓ t$m~r signifies He raised, or tucked up, his garment, &c.: for] one says also, t$m~r Eano saAEidayohi [He tucked up his sleeves from his fore arms]. (TA.) It is said in a prov., $am~ara *ayolFA waA@d~araEa layolFA i. e. [lit.] He contracted, or drew up, his [or a] skirt [and clad himself with night as with a tunic]: (TA:) or $amiro *ayolFA waA@d~ariEo layolFA, meaning (tropical:) Use thou prudence, or precaution, or good judgment, and journey all the night. (S and K in art. drE.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) He strove, or laboured, exerted himself or his power or ability, employed himself vigorously or laboriously or with energy, or took extraordinary pains, (AA, Msb, TA,) and was quick, (AA, TA,) fiY AlA^amori [in the affair]; as also ↓ $amara, inf. n. $amorN: (TA:) and fiY AlEibaAdapi [in religious service]: (Msb:) and fiY sayorihi [in his pace, or journeying]; like tajar~ada and Ainojarada. (L and TA in art. jrd.) Also, (K,) inf. n. as above; (TA;) and ↓ $amara, (K,) aor.
$amura , inf. n. $amorN; (TA;) and ↓ An$mr, and ↓ t$m~r; (K;) (assumed tropical:) He passed along striving, or exerting himself, or vigorously: or he passed along with a proud and self-conceited gait; (K;) [and] ↓ mar~a ya$omuru, inf. n. as above, has the latter meaning. (S.) And $m~r fiY AlA^amori (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, light, or active, (S, Msb, K,) and quick, (Msb,) in, or for, the affair: (S, Msb, K:) and $m~r liloA^amori, and $m~r liloA^amori A^a*oyaAlahu, (A, TA,) and $m~r Eano saAqihi, (TA,) (tropical:) He was, or became, light, or active, and he rose, or hastened, to do the thing, or affair. (A, TA.) And $m~rt AlHarobu and $m~rt Eano saAqihaA (tropical:) [The war, or battle, became vehement; like ka$afato Eano saAqK]. (A.) ― -b3- Also He contracted a thing; syn. qal~aSa; (TA;) [and so, perhaps, ↓ $amara; for] Al$~amoru signifies taqoliySu Al$~aYo'i, like Alt~a$omiyru: (K:) [or the author of the TA may have misunderstood this explanation in the K, and the meaning may be it (a thing) contracted, or became contracted; for qal~aSa is trans. and also (like qalaSa) intrans.: that $m~r has this latter meaning, whether it have also, or have not, the former, is shown by the statement that] one says, $am~arati Al$~afapu meaning qalaSat [i. e. The lip became contracted, or became contracted upwards]: (M in art. qlS:) and ↓ t$m~r [in like manner] signifies it (a thing) contracted, or became contracted; syn. taqal~aSa. (TA.) ― -b4- Also, (inf. n. as above, As, S,) (tropical:) He launched forth a ship, or boat; let it go; let it take its course; (As, IAar, S, A, K;) and in like manner, a hawk; (A;) and he discharged, or shot, an arrow: (As, IAar, S, A, Msb:) and hence, (As, S,) (tropical:) he sent, sent forth, or sent away, (As, S, M, A, K,) a thing. (M, A.) [See also sam~ara.] And $m~r AlA_ibila, inf. n. as above; (TA;) and ↓ A$mrhA; (K;) (assumed tropical:) He hastened the camels; made them to hasten; syn. A^akoma$ahaA, [which seems to be either syn. with, or a mistranscription for, kam~a$ahaA, (see sam~ara,)] and A^aEojalahaA. (O, K, TA.) ― -b5- And $am~arotu Aln~axola (tropical:) I cut off the fruit of the palm-trees; syn. Saramotuhu; (A, TA;) or so ↓ $amarotuhu, (Ibn-'Abbád, O,) [for] Al$~amoru signifies SiraAmu Aln~axoli. (K.)

4 A$mr AlA_ibila * : see 2, last sentence but one. ― -b2- A$mr Aljamalu Taruwqatahu The he-camel impregnated the she-camel covered by him. (O, K.) ― -b3- A$mrhu biAls~ayofi He destroyed him with the sword; syn. A^adorajahu. (O, K.)

5 t$m~r * : see 2, third sentence. ― -b2- [Hence,] t$m~r liloA^amori, (S, K,) or liloEamali (A,) and ↓ An$mr lalAmr, (S,) (assumed tropical:) He prepared himself (S, A, K) for the affair, (S, K,) or for the work. (A.) [Freytag mentions A$mr llAmr in a similar sense, “ Paratus fuit ad rem peragendam, ” as on the authority of J; but I do not find it in the S,] ― -b3- See also 2 as syn. with 1 and 7. -A2- [Also, app., as quasipass. of 2, It (a garment, &c., was, or became, raised, or tucked up, or contracted; and so signifies ↓ An$mr.] ― -b2- See 2 again, in the latter part of the paragraph.

7 An$mr * : see 5, in two places. ― -b2- See also 2 as syn. with 1 and 5. ― -b3- Also He (a horse) hastened, or went quickly. (S, O. [Accord. to Freytag, the verb in this sense in the S is A$tmr; but this is a mistake.]) ― -b4- And i. q. maDaY and nafa*a [app. as meaning (assumed tropical:) It, or he, acted with a penetrative force or energy (see $imorN and $am~ariY~N)]; and so ↓ A$tmr. (TA.) ― -b5- And It (the water of a wall) went away. (A, TA.)
8 A_i$otamara see the next preceding paragraph.

$imorN * , applied to a man, (assumed tropical:) Light, agile, or active; acute, or sharp, or quick, in intellect; clever, knowing, or intelligent; syn. zawolN; and baSiyrN; (ElMuärrij, O, K;) and naAqidN; (O, K;) thus accord. to the copies of the K [probably from the O]; but in the Tekmileh &c., naAfi*, [which I regard as the right reading, meaning one who acts with a penetrative energy, or who is sharp, vigorous, or effective,] (TA,) in everything. (O, TA.) See also $am~ariY~N. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous; (O, K;) and courageous. (TA.)
$amarN * : see $amaArN.

$imorapN * The gait, or manner of walking, of a
vitious, or depraved, man; (O, K;) or, accord. to IAar, of a man who goes to and fro, and round about. (TA.) [See also $anorapN.]

$ar~N $imir~N *
Severe evil. (S, O, K.) It is said in a prov., A^alojaA^ahu Alxawofu A_ilaY $ar~K $imir~K, (TA,) or A^ajaA='ahu, (so in a copy of the A,) [Fear compelled him to betake himself to that which was a severe evil:] i. e. he feared an evil, and fear reduced him to a greater evil. (A.)

$amaArN *
i. q. raAziyaAnajN, in the dial. of Egypt, (O, K, TA,) also [and more commonly] called ↓ $amarN [applied to the Anethum graveolens, or common garden-dill, and to its seed; and also to the anethum fœniculum, or fennel: see also san~uwtN]. (TA.)

$am~ariY~N * [in the CK $amariY~N, without teshdeed to the m,] (tropical:) A man, (S,) penetrating, or acting with a penetrative energy, or sharp, vigorous, and effective, in the performing of affairs, and expert, or experienced; (S, * K, TA;) mostly with respect to travel; (TA;) as though it were a rel. n. from $am~ara; (S;) as also $im~ariY~N (S, K) and $im~iriY~N [in the CK $imiriY~N] and $um~uriY~N [in the CK $umuriY~N] and ↓ $imorN and ↓ $im~iyrN, (K,) the last an intensive form, (TA,) and ↓ mu$am~irN: (K:) or clever in the performing of affairs, and quick: (Fr, TA:) or one who strives, labours, or exerts himself, and is clever and skilful: (Aboo-Bekr, TA:) or quick in evil, and in what is vain, or false; who strives, labours, or exerts himself, therein; from $am~ara meaning “ he strove, laboured, or exerted himself, and was quick: ” (AA, Aboo-Bekr, TA:) or one who goes his own way, or pursues a headlong, or rash, course, and will not refrain. (Aboo-Bekr, TA.) ― -b2- naAqapN $am~ariy~apN, (S, K,) and $im~ariy~apN, and $im~iriy~apN, and $um~uriy~apN, (K, TA,) [all in the CK without teshdeed to the m,] and ↓ $im~iyrN, (S, K,) (assumed tropical:) A she-camel that is quick (S, K) in pace. (TA.)

$am~uwrN * , occurring in a trad. respecting 'Ooj Ibn- 'Unuk, [or Ibn-'Ook,] as meaning something with which a mass of rock was hollowed out according to the size of his head, (TA,) Diamond: (K:) thought by El-Khattábee to have this meaning; but he says, “ I have not heard respecting it anything upon which I place reliance. ” (IAth, TA.)

$im~iyrN * (assumed tropical:) One who strives, labours, or exerts himself; who employs himself vigorously, laboriously, or with energy; (K, TA;) in the performance of affairs. (TA.) See also $am~ariY~N, in two places.

$aApN $aAmirN * , and $aAmirapN, A ewe or she-goat, having her udder drawn up to her belly: (S, K:) an epithet having no verb. (TA.) ― -b2- $afapN $aAmirapN, and ↓ muta$am~irapN, A contracted lip. (TA.) ― -b3- livapN $aAmirapN, (A, K,) and ↓ muta$am~irapN, (K,) or ↓ mu$am~irapN, (so in a copy of the A,) A gum cleaving to the roots of the teeth. (A, K.)
mu$am~irN * : see $am~ariY~N: ― -b2- and see also $aAmirN.
muta$am~irN * : see its fem. voce $AmirN, in two places.

Q. 1 $amoraxa Aln~axolapa *
He stripped off the unripe dates of the palm-tree. (L.) And $amorixi AlEi*oqa Strip thou the $amaAriyx [or fruit-stalks] of the raceme of the palm-tree with the mixolab, cutting off [the dates]. (L, * K. [In the former, in the place of qaToEFA, the last word in the explanation in the K, is put qaEoTFA, app. by a mistake of the copyist.])

$imoraAxN * (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and ↓ $umoruwxN (S, Msb, K) A [fruit-] stalk of the raceme of a palm-tree; (Mgh;) the EivokaAl, (S, L,) or thing, (Msb,) upon which are the dates; (L, Msb;) [i. e. any one of the stalks that branch off from the main stem of the raceme, and on which hang the dates; each of these stalks comprising a number of dates, one below another:] pl. of both $amaAriyxu: (Msb:) the Ei*oq, or kibaAsap, [q. v.,] comprises the $amaAriyx: (Msb voce Ei*oqN:) or an EivokaAl upon which are unripe dates, or grapes: (K:) originally relating to a raceme of dates; but sometimes, to grapes: (L:) and the former word [or each] signifies a small bunch of grapes, growing apart, but attached to the lower portion of the stalk of a larger bunch. (T, TA.) ― -b2- Also, $imoraAxN, The head of a mountain: (S, K:) or a round, tall, slender head, or peak, of a mountain: (L:) accord. to As, [the pl.] $amaAriyxu signifies the heads of mountains: (TA:) or it signifies the upper, or uppermost, part [or parts] of a mountain; and in like manner, of trees. (Ham p. 786.) And (assumed tropical:) The upper, or uppermost, parts of clouds: (K:) or [the pl.] $amaAriyxu is metaphorically applied to the upper, or uppermost, parts of clouds. (Ham ubi suprà.) ― -b3- And A blaze upon the face of a horse, when it is narrow, (S, K, TA,) and long, (TA,) and extending so as to cover the [part of the nose called] xayo$uwm, but not reaching to the lip: (S, K, TA:) or a blaze, upon the face of a horse, extending downwards on the nose. (Lth, TA.) [See gur~apN saAy^ilapN, in art. syl.] Accord. to J, The horse itself [that has such a blaze] is also thus called; but this is a mistake: (K:) it seems that he meant to have said *uw $imoraAxK; but this, in a verse which he cites, is the name of a horse of Málik Ibn-'Owf En-Nadree, as is said in the K. (MF.) ― -b4- [The pl.] Al$~amaAriyxu is also a name applied by the Arabs to (assumed tropical:) The stars of Centaurus (qanoTuwrus) and Lepus (Als~abuEu) collectively. (Kzw.)
$umoruwxN * : see the next preceding paragraph, first sentence. ― -b2- Also A slender, and soft or tender, branch, that has grown forth, within a year, upon the upper part of a thick branch. (L.)

Al$~imoraAxiy~apu *
A sect of the heretics, or schismatics, (AlxawaArij,) the companions [or followers] of 'AbdAllah Ibn-Shimrákh. (S, K.)

$amarodalN *
A youth, strong and hardy; and in the like sense applied to a camel: (Lth, TA:) or tall; as also ↓ $amarodaliY~N: (Ham pp. 728 and 789:) or a bulky camel: (IAar, TA:) or, of camels &c., (S, O, K,) the swift; (S, O;) or youthful, swift, and goodly in make: (K:) and with p, a she-camel goodly, beautiful in make. (A 'Obeyd, S, O, K.)
$amarodaliY~N * : see the preceding paragraph.
$amaro*alN * a dial. var. of $amarodalN [q. v.]. (Lth, O, K.)

1 $amazato nafosiY minohu * , aor.
$amuza , (TK,) inf. n. $amozN, (IAar, K,) My soul shrank from it in dislike or hatred. (IAar, K, TK.) [See also 5, and Q. Q. 4.]

5 t$m~z wajohuhu *
His face became changed, or altered, (T, S, K,) by anger, (K,) and contracted. (T, S, K.) See also what next follows.

Q. Q. 4 Ai$omaA^az~a * , (S, K,) inf. n. Ai$omiy^ozaAzN, (S,) He (a man, S) shrank, or became contracted; (S, K, TA;) as also ↓ t$m~z: (TA:) he quaked, or shuddered: (IAar, K:) or he was frightened (AZ, S, K) at a thing. (AZ, S.) It is said in the Kur xxxix. 46, waA_i*aA *ukira A@ll~`hu waHodahu A@$omaA^az~ato quluwbu A@l~a*iyna laA yuw^ominuwna biA@loA=xirapi And when God is mentioned alone, the hearts of those who will not believe in the world to come become contracted, and shrink with aversion: (Bd, Jel:) or quake, or shudder. (Zj, TA.) And you say, qulotu lahu ka*aA faA@$omaA^az~a minohu [I said to him such a thing, and he shrank from it; or quaked, or shuddered, at it; or was frightened at it]. (A.) And A$mA^z~ Al$~aYo'a, (K,) without a prep., accord. to Kr, (TA,) He disliked, or hated, the thing. (K.) [See also 1, and 5.]

$umaA^oziyzapN * [a subst.] from Q. Q. 4, [A shrinking, or contraction: a quaking, or shuddering: or fright: and dislike, or hatred.] (S, K, * TA.) You say, rajulN fiyhi $umaA^oziyzapN [A man in whom is a shrinking, &c.] (TA.)

mu$omay^iz~N *
Shrinking with aversion; syn. naAfirN: (K:) disliking, or hating, (K,) a thing: (TA:) frightened, or afraid. (K.)

1 $amasa * , aor.
$amusa and
$amisa , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. $umuwsN; (TA;) and $amisa, aor
$amasa (K) and
$amusa also, like faDila, aor. yafoDulu, accord. to the lexicologists, as ISd says, but he holds the aor. of $amisa to be
$amasa [only]; (TA;) and ↓ A$ms; (S, K;) It (a day) was, or became, sunny, or sunshiny; it had sun, or sunshine: (S, Msb, K:) or it had sun, or sunshine, all the daytime: or it was, or became, clear, or unobscured: (TA:) or its sun was, or became, vehement. (IF, Msb.) -A2- $amasa, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
$amusa (Msb, TA) and
$amisa , (Msb,) inf. n. $umuwsN
and $imaAsN, (S, Msb, K,) He (a horse) refused to be ridden or mounted: (S, K:) or took fright and broke loose and ran away, refusing to be ridden, by reason of the vehemence of his force of resistance, [for li$id~api mtEbh in the TA, I read l$d~p manaEatihi,] and his sharpness of temper, so that he would not remain still: (TA:) or became rebellious against his rider. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] $amasati AlmaroA^apu (assumed tropical:) The woman abstained from looking at men, and from exciting their desire. (TA.) ― -b3- And $amasa liY fulaAnN (tropical:) Such a one showed enmity to me: (K: *) or showed his enmity to me, (T, S, A,) and almost made it to take effect, (A,) or as though he purposed to act: (T, TA:) or $amasa fiY fulaAnK signifies, [unless fY be a mistake for liY, and fulaAnK for fulaAnN,] he showed his enmity [towards such a one], and could not conceal it. (M in TA.) [See also 3.] ― -b4- And Alxamoru ta$omusu biSaAHibihaA (assumed tropical:) Wine overcomes, and runs away with, its drinker. (TA.)
2 $m~s * , (TK,) inf. n. ta$omiysN, (K,) He worshipped the sun. (K, TK.) -A2- And He spread a thing in the sun, or sunshine, (K, TK,) in order that it might dry. (TA.)
3 $Amshu * , inf. n. mu$aAmasapN and $imaAsN, He opposed him, and treated him with enmity or hostility. (Th, TA.) [See also 1.]
4 A^a$omasa see 1, first signification. ― -b2- [Also He ascended a mountain towards the sun. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)]

5 t$m~s *
He (a man) sat in the sun, or sunshine: (TA:) he set himself up [or exposed himself standing] to the sun. (S, TA.) -A2- t$m~s Ealayohi He was niggardly, tenacious, or avaricious, to him. (TA.) [See also the part. n., below.]

Al$~amosu * [The sun;] the body of the solar light, that runs its course in the firmament: (Lth, * TA:) it is fem.: (S, * Msb, K:) and has neither dual nor pl.: (Msb:) or it has a pl., [though this is not used in a pl. sense,] namely, $umuwsN, (S, K,) as though they called every part of it a $ms, like as they said mafaAriqu for maforiqN. (S.) When it is made determinate without the article Al, [as] in the name Eabodu $amosa, meaning The Servant of the Sun, (Msb, K,) i. e., of this luminous object, (Msb,) the $ms of heaven, because they used to worship it, (K,) it is imperfectly decl., (Aboo- 'Alee, Msb, K,) because it is determinate and of the fem. gender, (Aboo-'Alee, K,) or because it is a proper name and of the fem. gender and altered from Al$~amos: (Msb:) and a poet says,
kal~aA wa$amosa lanaxoDiban~ahumu damFA
[Nay verily, by the sun, we will assuredly dye them with blood], making $ms imperfectly decl. because he means the art. Al to be understood: (IAar, TA:) but some say that in the former instance, (Msb, TA,) and in the latter, (TA,) the word in question has a different signification, which will be shown below: (Msb, TA:) and Sb says that none of the Arabs made $ms determinate without the art. Al, except in the proper name mentioned above, in which all of them made it so. (TA.) The dim. is ↓ $umayosapN. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [Also The sun, or sunshine.] You say, qaEada fiY Al$~amosi [He sat in the sun, or sunshine]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, (K, TA,) or $amosN, (Msb,) A certain ancient idol. (Msb, K.) Accord. to Ibn-El-Kelbee, it is this that is meant by the proper name mentioned above; and if so, it is perfectly decl.: (Msb:) and some say that it is this also that is meant in the words of the poet cited above, and that he makes the word imperfectly decl. because he uses it as a proper name of the image (AlS~uwrap). (TA.) -A2- $amosN also signifies A kind of necklace or collar: (S, K:) or a pendant, or suspended ornament, (miEolaAq,) of the necklace or collar upon the neck: or the collar of a dog: (TA:) or a kind of women's ornament: of the masc. gender: (Lh, TA:) pl. $umuwsN. (TA.) ― -b2- And A kind of comb, (K,) with which women in the first age used to comb themselves; (TA;) as also ↓ $amosapN. (IDrd, TA.) -A3- yawomN $amosN: see $aAmisN.
yawomN $amisN * : see $aAmisN.
$amosapN * : see $amosN, last sentence but one.

$amosiY~N * [Of, or relating to, the sun; solar]. Als~anapu Al$~amosiy~apu The solar year. (Mgh.) ― -b2- It is also a term applied by some of the Arabs to The first [annual] increase [of sheep and goats]. (Aboo-Nasr, TA voce SafariY~N, q. v.)

$amaAsN * The disposition, in a horse, of refusing to be ridden, or mounted. (S.) ― -b2- [And hence,] (assumed tropical:) The disposition, in a woman, of abstaining from looking at men, and from exciting their desire: a subst. from $amasatN. (TA.)

$amuwsN * A horse that refuses to be ridden or mounted; (S, K;) as also ↓ $aAmisN: (K:) or that takes fright and breaks loose and runs away, refusing to be ridden, by reason of the vehemence of his force of resistance and his sharpness of temper, so that he will not remain still: (TA: [see 1:]) or that will hardly remain still: (A:) or that rebels against his rider: (Msb:) or that refuses to be ridden or mounted, and will hardly remain still: (Mgh:) also applied to a she-camel: (TA:) $amuwSN, with S, applied to a horse is not allowable: (Msb:) pl. $umusN (A, Mgh, Msb, K) and $umosN. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A woman who abstains from looking at men, and from exciting their desire; as also ↓ $aAmisapN: pl. of the former, $umusN; and of the latter, [$awaAmisu and] $umuwsN. (TA.) ― -b3- Hence also, (Msb,) (tropical:) A man refractory, untractable, perverse, stubborn, or obstinate, in disposition: (S, Msb, TA:) and a man hard, harsh, or illnatured, in his enmity, vehement in contrariousness to him who opposes him: (TA:) $amuwSN [with S] is not allowable. (S.) ― -b4- [Hence too,] Al$~amuwsu (assumed tropical:) Wine: (AHn, K:) because it overcomes, and runs away with, its drinker, like the horse to which this epithet is applied. (AHn.)
$umayosapN * dir of $amosN, q. v.

$am~aAsN *
One of the heads of the Christians, who shaves the middle of his head, and keeps to the church: (Lth, A, Mgh, K:) [in the present day, a deacon: see jaAvaliyqu:] not pure Arabic, (IDrd,) or not sound Arabic: (M:) [probably, as Golius says, from the Chaldee 165:] pl. $amaAmisapN. (Mgh, K: [in the TA, $mAsp; and in a copy of the A, $am~aAsap; but the right reading is that in the Mgh.])

$aAmisN * A sunny, or sunshiny, day; a day having sun, or sunshine: or having sun, or sunshine, all the daytime: or clear; unobscured: and in like manner, ↓ $amosN and ↓ $amisN, a clear, cloudless, day: and $aAmisN also signifies intensely hot: (TA:) and ↓ mu$omisN, applied to a day, signifies the same as $aAmisN; (A;) and so ↓ ma$omuwsN. (Th, TA.) -A2- A neck having [ornaments of the kind called] $umuws [pl. of $amosN, q. v.]: a possessive epithet. (TA.) -A3- See also $amuwsN, in two places.

A^a$omasu *
More, and most, incompliant or resisting. (Ham p. 324.)
mu$omisN * : see $aAmisN.

mu$am~asN *
Made [or spread to dry (see 2)] in the sun, or sunshine. (S.)

mu$am~isN *
A worshipper of the sun. (O, TA.)
ma$omuwsN * : see $aAmisN.

muta$am~isN * [Sitting in or] setting himself up to [or exposing himself standing to] the sun. (K.) -A2- A man who defends what is behind his back: (ISh, TA:) a man strong (ISh, K, TA) in that which sustains or supports him; syn. qawiY~N $adydu Alquwmiy~api: (ISh, TA:) Sgh says $adydu Alquw~api; but the former is the right reading: (TA:) and niggardly, tenacious, or avaricious, to the utmost degree. (K.)

1 $amiTa * , aor.
$amaTa , inf. n. $amaTN, He (a man, S, TA) was, or became, grizzled in the hair of his head; he had whiteness in the hair of his head, mixed with its blackness: (S, Mgh, * K:) as also ↓ A^a$omaTa, (K, but wanting in one copy,) and ↓ Ai$omaT~a, and ↓ Ai$omaAT~a, and ↓ Ai$omaA^aT~a: (K:) [or he had hair of two different colours, black and white: or he had whiteness of the hair, or hoariness, mixed with the blackness of youth: or he had whiteness, or hoariness, in his beard: but $amiTato, said of a woman, she had whiteness, or hoariness, in the head: see $amaTN, below.] -A2- $amaTa, aor.
$amiTa , (S, K,) inf. n. $amoTN, (S,) He mixed a thing; (S, K;) he mixed together any two things: (S, Mgh:) and ↓ A^a$omaTa signifies the same. (AZ, K.) You say, $ayaTa bayona AlmaA='i waAll~abani He mixed together the water and the milk. (TA.) And Eamalaka biSadaqapK ↓ A^a$omiTo (assumed tropical:) Mix thou thy work with alms. (AZ.) And Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà used to say to his companions, A$omiTuwA, [i. e. either
Ai$omiTuwA or ↓ A^a$omiTuwA,] meaning (assumed tropical:) Betake yourselves at one time to reading, or reciting, somewhat of the Kur-án, and another time to some tradition, and another time to something strange [that is to be elucidated], and another time to poetry, and another time to lexicology; i. e., mix ye these [subjects of study]: (TA:) or, accord. to one relation, ↓ $am~iTuwA. (Har p. 177; where it is expl. in a similar manner).
2 $am~aTa see above, last sentence.
4 A^a$omaTa see 1, in four places.
9 A_i$omaT~a see 1, first sentence.
11 A_i$omaAoT~a see 1, first sentence.

Q. Q. 4
see 1, first sentence.

$amaTN *
Whiteness of the hair of the head mixed with its blackness: (S, Mgh, K:) or difference in the hair by being of two colours, black and white: (M, TA:) or mixture of whiteness of the hair, or hoariness, with the blackness of youth: (Mgh:) or in a man, whiteness, or hoariness, of the beard: (Lth, Mgh, TA:) but in a woman, whiteness, or hoariness, of the head. (Lth, TA.) [See 1.] ― -b2- Also $amaTaAtN, which is its pl., White hairs that are in the head. (TA.)

$amiyTN *
Mixed; as also ↓ ma$omuwTN: (K:) mixed together; (S, TA;) applied to any two things; (S;) or any two colours. (TA.) ― -b2- *anabN $amiyTN; in the K, *iy^obN, which is a mistake; (TA;) A tail (TA) in which are blackness and whiteness. (K, TA.) And farasN $amiyTu Al*~anabi A horse in whose tail are two colours. (TA.) And TaAy^irN $amiyTu Al*~unaAbaY A bird having a whiteness (Lth, K) and blackness (Lth) in the tail. (Lth, K.) ― -b3- nabotN $amiyTN A plant of which part is dried up, or dried up and yellow, (Lth, S, K,) and part green. (Lth, K.) ― -b4- Al$~amiyTu, [in a copy of the Mgh, ↓ $umayoTN, which is probably a mistranscription,] (tropical:) The dawn: (S, K:) because of the mixture of its whiteness with the remains of the darkness of night: (S, Mgh:) or because its colour is a mixture of darkness and whiteness. (TA.) ― -b5- labanN $amiyTN (tropical:) Milk which is such that one knows not whether it be sour or what has been collected in a skin, and had fresh milk poured upon it, by reason of its pleasantness. (K, TA.) ― -b6- waladN $amiyTN (tropical:) Children of whom half are males and half are females. (L, K.)
$umayoTN * : see $amiyTN. -A2- See also SuradN.

A^a$omaTu * A man (S) having the hair of his head grizzled; having whiteness in the hair of his head, mixed with its blackness: (S, K:) [or whose hair is of two different colours, black and white: or having whiteness of the hair, or hoariness, mixed with the blackness of youth: or having whiteness, or hoariness, in his beard: see $amaTN, above:] or whose hair of his head is white in one place, the rest being black: (Mgh:) fem. $amoTaA='u: (Lth, S, Mgh:) one should not apply to a woman the epithet $ayobaA='u: (Lth, Mgh:) pl. $umoTaAnN (S, K) and $umoTN. (K.) ― -b2- naAqapN $amoTaA='u A she-camel having white lips. (TA.) ― -b3- laHumN A^a$omaTu [Flesh-meat marbled with fat]. (Az, TA in art. kr$.)
ma$omuwTN * : see $amiyTN.

1 $amaEa * , aor.
$amaEa , inf. n. $amoEN and $umuwEN and ma$omaEapN, He played, sported, gamed, jested, or joked: (S, O, K:) or he was mirthful, and laughed: and $amaEatN, aor. as above, inf. n. $amoEN and $umuwEN, She cheered by her discourse. (TA.) It is said in a trad., mano yat~abiEi Alma$omaEapa ya$omaEi A@ll~`hu bihi (S, * O) He who follows the practice of play, or sport, or unprofitable play or sport, with men, (S, O,) and derision and laughter and enjoyment with them, God will requite him for that, (O,) or God will cause him to be in a state in which the like shall be done with him. (S, O.) ― -b2- And $amaEa, inf. n. $umuwEN, It was, or became, scattered, or dispersed. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

2 $m~Ehu * , (K,) inf. n. ta$omiyEN, (O, K,) He, or it, made him to play, sport, game, jest, or joke. (O, * K.) -A2- $m~E Alv~awoba He dipped the garment, or piece of cloth, in liquified $amoaE [i. e. wax]. (O, K.)

4 A$mE Als~iraAju *
The lamp, or lighted wick, diffused its light. (S, K.)

$amoEN * and $amaEN, both chaste accord. to ISd: (TA:) accord. to Fr, (S, O, Msb, TA,) the former is post-classical; (S, O, Msb, K, TA;) but ISd says that this is a mistake: (TA:) accord. to ISk one should say the latter, and not the former: (TA:) or accord. to him, the word is with fet-h to the m, and some of the Arabs make the m quiescent: accord. to Th, it is with fet-h to the m; and if you will, you may make it quiescent: accord. to IF, the m is sometimes with fet-h; so that he gives one to understand that it is more frequently made quiescent: (Msb:) A kind of thing with which one lights himself: (S, O, Msb, K:) or i. q. muwmN [which, or rather muwmo, in Pers., signifies both wax and the wax-candle; both of which or rather the former and wax-candles, are meant by $amoEN and $amaEN]: (ISk, TA:) or the muwm of honey [i. e. bees' wax]: (Lth, K:) the n. un., (CK,) or what denotes a piece, or portion, thereof, (so in copies of the K and in the TA,) is with p, (K, TA,) $amoEapN and $amaEapN, (TA,) [i. e.] $mEp has a more particular signification. (S, O.)

$amoEiY~N * or $amaEiY~N (K [as there mentioned app. meaning A dealer in wax or wax-candles, like ↓ $am~aAEN in the present day,]) a rel. n. from $amoEN or $amaEN. (TA. [The latter said in the K to be the correct form.])

$imaAEN *
Mirth and laughter and jesting or joking; as also ↓ $imaAEapN. (TA. [Not mentioned there as inf. ns.])

$amuwEN * , applied to a woman, (S, K,) That jests, or jokes, much; (K, TA;) pleasant in discourse; that kisses one, and will not comply with one's desire otherwise than by doing thus: (TA:) [or] playful, sportful, or gamesome, and wont to laugh; (S, K, TA;) and in this sense applied also to a man: or, applied to a woman, that cheers by her discourse. (TA.)
$imaAEapN * : see $imaAEN.

$am~aAEN *
A manufacturer of $mE [meaning waxcandles]: (TA:) or a melter of $mE [meaning wax]. (KL.) See also $amoEiY~N.

mi$omaEapN *
A candlestick: pl. ma$aAmiEu. (MA.)
mu$am~aEN * A garment, or cloth, dipped in liquified $amoaE [i. e. wax]. (TA.)

misokN ma$omuwEN *
Musk mixed with ambergris. (O, K.)

Q. 1 $amoEala * , (O, K, TA, [in the CK ta$amoEala,]) inf. n. $amoEalapN, (TA,) It became scattered or dispersed. (O, K, TA.) -A2- And $amoEalapN signifies The reading, or reciting, of the Jews, (S, O, K, TA,) when they assemble fY mhrhm: (TA: [but I know not what this means:]) one says of them $amoEalat [i. e. $amoEalati Alyahuwdu]. (TA.)

Q. 4 Ai$omaEal~a *
He hastened, made haste, or went quickly; syn. A^asoraEa: this is the primary signification. (Ham p. 282.) One says of a she-camel A$mEl~t meaning She hastened, &c. (S.) ― -b2- And A$mEl~t AlA_ibilu The camels went, or went away, and scattered or dispersed themselves, by reason of briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness: (Kh, S, O, K:) or spread themselves, or became scattered or dispersed; as also A$mET~t: (Aboo-Turáb, TA:) or became scattered or dispersed, going [away] quickly. (TA.) And in like manner, (Kh, S, O,) A$mEl~t AlgaArapu fiY AlEaduw~i, (Kh, S, O, K,) meaning The horsemen making a sudden attack upon the enemy scattered, or dispersed, themselves; (Aboo-Turáb, K, * TA;) and so A$mET~t. (Aboo-Turáb, TA.) And A$mEl~ Alqawomu fiY AlT~alabi The people, or company of men, hastened, and scattered or dispersed themselves, in seeking; (Aboo-Turáb, S, O, K;) as also A$mET~. (Aboo-Turáb, TA.) -A2- And i. q. A^a$orafa [q. v.]. (O, K.)
$amoEalN * , and with p: see the following paragraph.

mu$omaEil~N * A swift she-camel; (Az, S;) or so mu$omaEil~apN: (O:) and ↓ $amoEalN and ↓ $amoEalapN (O, K) and mu$omaEil~N (K) a she-camel brisk, lively, or sprightly, (O, K,) and swift, (K,) and light, active, or agile. (TA.) mu$omaEil~apN in the first of these senses is [said to be] from the phrase qirobapN mu$omaEil~apN A water-skin of which the water flows out. (Har p. 111.) ― -b2- Also A man quick and penetrating or having a penetrative energy: and with p, a very active woman. (TA.) A man light, active, or agile; excellent, or elegant, in mind, manners, &c., or clever, ingenious, or acute in mind: or tall. (K.) A man vigorous, strenuous, or energetic, and light, active,
or agile. (Ham p. 384.) ― -b3- Also applied to milk, meaning Sour, (K, TA,) overcoming by its sourness. (TA.)

1 $amilahumu AlA^amoru * , aor.
$amala ; and $amalahum, aor.
$amula ; (S, Msb, K;) but the latter verb was unknown to As, (S, TA,) and is said by Lh to be rare; (TA;) inf. n. $amalN, (Msb, K,) which is of the former, (Msb,) and $umuwlN, (Msb, K,) and $amolN; (K;) i. q. Eam~ahumo [i. e. The event, or case, included them in common, in general, or universally, within the compass of its effect or effects, its operation or operations, its influence, or the like]: (S, Msb, K:) or $amilahumo xayorFA or $ar~FA, or xayorFA and $ar~FA, (accord. to different copies of the K,) like fariHa, (in the CK, or like fariHa,) [app. means he, or it, caused that] good or evil, or good and evil, betided them [in common, in general, or universally]: and $ar~FA ↓ A^a$omalahumo [means] Eam~ahumo bihi [i. e. he, or it, included them in common, in general, or universally, with, or by, evil]: (K:) but one should not say, A$mlhm xayorFA. (TA.) [Whether what precedes, or what next follows, should be regarded as giving the primary signification of $amila, is uncertain.] ― -b2- $amilahu, aor.
$amala , inf. n. $amolN and $umuwlN, He covered [or enveloped] him with the $amolap, (K, TA,) or, with the mi$omalap: such is thought by ISd to be meant by the explanation given by Lh, which is, gaT~aY Ealayohi Almi$omalapa. (TA.) ― -b3- h`*ihi $amolapN ta$omaluka means tasaEuka [i. e. This is a $mlp sufficient in its dimensions, or sufficiently large, for thee]. (TA.) You say, Ai$otarayotu $amolapF va$omaluniY [I bought a $mlp sufficient in its dimensions, &c., for me]. (ISk, S, O.) ― -b4- $amilato liqaAHFA, aor.
$amala , (S, O, K,) inf. n. $amalN, (S, O,) said of a she-camel, (S, O, K,) She admitted impregnating seed, (K,) or she conceived, mino faHoli fulaAnK, [from the stallion of such a one]. (S, O.) ― -b5- $amilato A_ibilukumo baEiyrFA lanaA Your camels concealed among them a he-camel belonging to us, by his entering amid their dense multitude: (K, TA:) so in the M and the Moheet. (TA.) -A2- $amala Al$~aApa, aor.
$amula (S, K) and
$amila , (K,) inf. n. $amolN, (S,) He suspended upon the ewe, or she-goat, the kind of bag called $imaAl, and bound it upon her udder: (S, * K, TA:) and some say, $amala Aln~aAqapa, he suspended a $imaAl upon the she-camel. (T, TA.) Also, and ↓ A$mlhA, He put to the ewe, or she-goat, (K, TA,) or he made for her, (TA,) a $imaAl. (K, TA.) -A3- $amala bihi, (K, TA,) inf. n. $amolN, (TA,) He took [in it, i. e. in travelling it, (see the pass. part. n.,)] the direction of the left hand; syn. A^axa*a *aAta Al$~imaAli: (K, TA:) so expl. by IAar. (TA.) ― -b2- $amalati Alr~iyHu, aor.
$amula , inf. n. $umuwlN (S, O, TA) and $amaAlN, (O,) or $amolN, (TA,) The wind shifted to a northerly direction ($amaAlFA); (S, TA;) so expl. by Lh: (TA:) or the wind blew northerly; syn. hab~ato $amaAlFA; as also ↓ A^a$omalat. (O. [In the TA, I find A^a$omalat AlryH *hbt $mAlyl mvl $am~alt: but this, I doubt not, is a mistranscription of the passage in the O, which I have here followed; i. e. A^a$omalati AlriyHu hab~at $amAlFA mivl $amalat; or of a similar passage in which A_i*aA hab~ato is put instead of hab~ato alone.]) One says of two persons when they are separated, $amalato riyHuhumaA (assumed tropical:) [Their wind has become north, or northerly]. (TA voce januwbN, q. v. [See also ma$omuwlN.]) ― -b3- $amala Alxamora, (K,) aor.
$amula , inf. n. $amolN, (TA,) He exposed the wine to the $amaAl [i. e. north, or northerly, wind], so that it became cold, or cool. (K.) ― -b4- And $umiluwA, (S, and in like manner in the Ham p. 595,) or $amiluwA, [expressly said to be] like fariHuwA, (K, [but this I think to be a mistake, the weight of authority, and the form of the part. n., which is ma$omuwlN, being against it,]) They were smitten, or blown upon, by the wind called the $amaAl. (S, K.) -A4- $amala Aln~axolapa, (K,) aor.
$amula , inf. n. $amolN, (TA,) He picked the ripe dates that were upon the palm-tree; as also ↓ A$mlhA, and ↓ $amolalahaA: (K:) or this last (which is mentioned on the authority of Seer), accord. to some, signifies he took of the $amaAliyl of the palmtree; i. e., of the few dates remaining upon it. (TA.)

2 ta$omiylN * [properly inf. n. of $am~ala]: see 5, of which it is an anomalous inf. n. (TA.) ― -b2- And for its proper verb see 7. -A2- Also The taking by the $imaAl [or left hand]. (TA.) -A3- And $m~l Aln~axolapa He bound pieces of [the garments called] A^akosiyap [pl. of kisaA='N] beneath the racemes of the palm-tree, because of its shaking off its fruit. (TA.)

4 A^a$omalahumN $ar~FA * : see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- A$ml AlfaHolu $awolahu, (AZ, S, O,) inf. n. A_i$omaAlN; (S;) or A$ml $awolahu liqaAHFA; (K;) The stallion-camel got with young from half to two thirds of the number of his $awol [or she-camels that had passed seven or eight months since the period of their bringing forth]: (AZ, S, O, K:) when he has got them all with young, one says, A^aqam~ahaA; (AZ, S, O, TA;) and of the $wl one says, qam~ato, inf. n. qumuwmN. (TA.) ― -b3- A$ml fulaAnN xaraAy^ifahu Such a one picked the ripe dates that were upon his xrAy^f [or palm-trees of which he gathered the fruit for himself and his household], except a few. (S, O.) ― -b4- See also 1, last sentence. -A2- A$mlhu He gave him a $amolap [q. v.]. (K, TA.) ― -b2- A$ml Al$~aApa: see 1. -A3- A$ml He became possessor of a mi$omalap, (Lh, TA,) or, of a mi$omal. (K.) -A4- A$mlwA They entered upon [a time in which blew] the [north, or northerly,] wind termed Al$~amaAl: (S, O, K:) like as they say, AjnbwA in the case of the januwb. (TA.) ― -b2- A^a$omalati Alr~iyHu: see 1, latter half. ― -b3- See also 7.

5 t$m~l biAl$~amolapi * , [and t$m~l Al$~amolapa, (see 5 in art. drs,)] inf. n. ta$am~ulN and ↓ ta$omiylN; (K;) the former reg.; the latter, which is mentioned by Lh, irreg., an instance like that in the saying [in the Kur lxxiii. 8], watabat~alo A_ilayohi tabotiylFA; (TA;) He covered himself with the $amolap [q. v.]. (K.) [See also 8.]

7 An$ml *
i. q. $am~ara, (K, TA,) or Aino$amara, (O, TA,) [both of which signify He passed along striving, or exerting himself; and the latter signifies also he acted with a penetrative force or energy; and he hastened, or went quickly;] fiY HaAjatihi [in his needful affair]. (O, TA.) And i. q. A^asoraEa [He hastened; went quickly; or was quick, swift, or fleet]: (K:) or so ↓ A^a$omala: (thus in the O, as on the authority of IDrd:) or so ↓ A$tml, inf. n. A$tmAl: (thus accord. to my copy of the Msb:) and likewise (O, K) ↓ $amolala, (S, O, K,) inf. n. $amolalapN: (S:) and so ↓ $m~l, (K,) inf. n. ta$omiylN. (TA.) And i. q. Aino$amara (O, TA) and AinoDam~a, (TA,) [both meaning It became contracted,] as used by a poet in relation to a she-camel's udder. (O, TA.)

8 A$tml bivawobihi *
He wrapped, or inwrapped, himself with his garment; syn. talaf~afa: (S, O:) or A$tml biAlv~awobi signifies he wrapped the garment around the whole of his body so that his arm, or hand, did not come forth from it: (K:) or, as some say, he wrapped himself with the garment, and threw [a part of] it upon his left side. (TA.) [See also 5.] Ai$otimaAlu AlS~am~aA='i, which is forbidden by the Prophet, is, accord. to As, The wrapping oneself with the garment so as to cover with it his body, not raising a side thereof in such a manner that there is in it an opening from which he may put forth his hand, or arm: (O:) this is also termed Alt~alaf~uEu: and sometimes one reclines in the state thus described: (TA:) but A 'Obeyd says, accord. to the explanation of the lawyers, it is the wrapping oneself with one garment, not having upon him another, then raising it on one side and putting it upon his shoulders: [so says Sgh; and he adds,] he who explains it thus has regard to the dislike of one's uncovering himself and exposing to view the pudenda; and he who explains it as do the lexicologists dislikes one's covering his whole body for fear of his becoming in a state in which his respiration would become obstructed so that he would perish: (O:) or it is one's covering his whole body with the kisaA=' or with the A_izaAr; (S, Msb;) to which some add, not raising aught of the sides thereof. (Msb.) [See also art. Sm.] One says also, ya$otamilu EalaY Als~ayfi [He wraps his garment over the sword; or] he covers the sword with his garment. (S, O.) ― -b2- [Hence, A$tml EalaY ka*aA It comprehended, or comprised, such a thing.] One says, Alr~aHimu ta$otamilu EalaY Alwaladi (assumed tropical:) The womb comprises [or encloses] the young. (TA.) [And in like manner one says of a woman, A$tmlt minohu EalaY waladK (assumed tropical:) She became with child by him. And AlkitaAbu ya$otamilu EalaY ka*aA waka*aA (assumed tropical:) The book, or writing, comprises such and such things.
