And hence the phrase in grammar, badalu A@$otimaAlK (assumed tropical:) A substitute for an antecedent to indicate an implication therein.] ― -b3- One says also, A$tml Ealayohi AlA^amoru, meaning (tropical:) The event [such as a misfortune or an evil of any kind beset him, or beset him on every side, or] encompassed him; (K, TA;) like as the kisaA=' encompasses the body.
(TA.) ― -b4- One says of wine, ta$otamilu EalaY AlEaqoli fatamolikuhu wata*ohabu bihi (assumed tropical:) [It compasses the intellect, and so takes possession of it, and makes away with it]: (Ham p. 555:) or ta$otamilu EalaY Eaqoli AlA_inosaAni fatugay~ibuhu (assumed tropical:) [It compasses the intellect of the man, and conceals it]; and thus one says of the present world or its enjoyments (Ald~unoyaA). (TA.) [A$tml EalaY $aYo'K often means (assumed tropical:) He took, or got, possession of a thing; got it, or held it, within his grasp, or in his possession.] ― -b5- [Hence,] one says, A$tml EalaY naAqapK fa*ahaba bihaA (assumed tropical:) He mounted a she-camel and went away with her. (AZ, O.) ― -b6- And A$tml Ealayohi (assumed tropical:) He shrouded, covered, or protected, him with himself, or his own person. (TA.) ― -b7- See also 7
R. Q. 1 $amolala * : see 1, last sentence: -A2- and see also 7.

$amolN *
A state of union or composedness: and a state of disunion or discomposedness: thus having two contr. significations: (MF, TA:) or a united, or composed, state of the affairs, (S, Msb, TA,) and of the number, (TA,) of a people, or company of men: (S, Msb, TA:) and a disunited, or discomposed, state of the affairs [&c.] thereof. (S, Mgh, Msb.) In imprecating evil upon enemies, (O, TA,) [or upon an enemy,] one says, $at~ata A@ll~`hu $amolahumo, (O, TA,) or far~aqa A@ll~`hu $amolahumo, (Msb,) or fr~q All~`h $amolahu, (S,) i. e. [May God dissolve, break up, discompose, derange, disorganize, disorder, or unsettle,] their, (Msb,) or his, (S,) united, or composed, state of affairs; (S, Msb;) and $at~a $amoluhumo i. e. [May their united, or composed, state of affairs &c.] become dissolved, broken up, discomposed, &c.: (O, TA:) and [in the contr. case] one says, jamaEa A@ll~`hu $amolahumo, (S, O, Msb, TA,) or $amolahu, (Mgh,) i. e. [May God unite, or compose,] their, (S, Msb,) or his, (Mgh,) disunited, or discomposed, state of affairs [&c.]. (S, Mgh, Msb.) And ↓ $amalN signifies the same: El-Ba'eeth says,
qado yanoEa$u A@ll~`hu AlfataY baEoda EavorapK
waqado yajomaEu A@ll~`hu Al$~atiyta mina Al$~amalo
[Sometimes, or often, God raises the young man after a stumble: and sometimes, or often, God unites, or composes, what is dissolved, or broken up, of the state of affairs previously united, or composed]: (S, O:) AZ cites this ex. in his “ Nawádir: ” (S:) but Aboo-'Omar El-Jarmee says that he had not heard the word thus except in this verse: (S, O:) Ibn-Buzurj, however, cites another verse as presenting an ex. of the same. (TA.) ― -b2- daxala fiY $amolihaA and ↓ $amalihaA, said of a he-camel that has become concealed among a herd of [she-] camels, means He entered amid their dense multitude: (K, TA:) so in the M and the Moheet. (TA.) -A2- Also, (AHn, O, K,) and so ↓ $imolN, and ↓ $imil~N, (K,) A raceme of a palm-tree: (AHn, O, K:) Et-Tirimmáh likens thereto a camel's tail: (TA:) or such as has little fruit: (K:) or of which some of the fruit has been plucked: but AO used to say that it is the produce [or spadix] of the male palm-tree, while not abundant and large. (TA.) -A3- See also $amaAlN. -A4- And $amolN mino junuwnK signifies Fear, or fright, like insanity: and so ↓ $amalN [used alone, and thus written]. (TA.)
$imolN * : see the next preceding paragraph, near the end.

$amalN * : see $amolN, in two places. -A2- Also i. q. kanafN [as meaning Quarter, or shelter or protection]: Alkatifu in the copies of the K being a mistake for Alkanafu: one says, naHonu fiY $amalikumo i. e. fiY kanafikumo [We are in your quarter, &c.]. (TA.) -A3- And A small quantity (S, K) of dates upon a palm-tree (S) or of ripe dates: (K:) and of rain: (S, K:) and a small number (S, K) of men and of camels (S) or of men &c.: pl. A^a$omaAlN: and in like manner ↓ $umoluwlN [app. in all of these applications]; (K;) [or] as meaning a light quantity of fruit of the palm-tree; (TA;) and the pl. of the latter is $amaAliylu: (K:) one says, maA EalaY Aln~axolapi A_il~aA $amalN and ↓ $amalapN and ↓ $amaAliylu There is not upon the palm-tree save a small quantity remaining of its fruit: (S, TA:) or ↓ maAbaqiYa fiY Aln~axolapi A_il~aA $amalapN and ↓ $amaAliylu There remained not upon the palm-tree save somewhat in a sparse state [of its fruit]: (TA:) and A^aSaAbanaA $amalN mino maTarK A small quantity of rain fell upon us: and raA^ayotu $amalFA mina Aln~aAsi waAlA_ibili I saw a small number of men and of camels. (S.) -A4- See also $amaAlN, in two places: -A5- And see $amolN, last sentence.

$amilN *
Wrapping, or inwrapping, himself (↓ mu$otamilN) with a $amolap [q. v.]. (TA.) -A2- And Thin; syn. raqiyqN: thus expl. by Sh, as applied in this sense by Ibn-Mukbil to a she-camel's tail, which he terms liyf. (TA.)

$amolapN *
A [garment of the kind called] kisaA=', with which one wraps, or inwraps, himself (yu$otamalu bihi), (S, Mgh, K,) smaller than the qaTiyfap; as also ↓ mi$omalN (K) and ↓ mi$omalapN; (S, K;) the last two expl. by Lth as a kisaA=' having a sparse villous substance, with which one wraps himself, smaller than the qaTiyfap: (TA:) or the first signifies a small kisaA=' which one wears in the manner of the A_izaAr [or waist-wrapper]: (Msb:) or with the Arabs it is a miy^ozar [or waist-wrapper] of wool or of [goats'] hair, which one wraps round him: and ↓ mi$omalapN, such as is made of two pieces sewed together, with which a man wraps himself when he sleeps by night: (Az, TA:) and this last, accord. to Meyd, signifies a kisaA=' comprising the steel with which one strikes fire, with the apparatus of this latter: (Har p. 628:) the pl. of the first is $imaAlN (Msb, TA) and $amalaAtN. (Msb.) [See also mi$omaAlN.] ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] Dam~a Ealayohi All~ayolu $amolatahu (tropical:) [The night contracted upon him its covering of darkness]. (TA.) ― -b3- And A^um~u $amolapa (tropical:) The present world, or its enjoyments; syn. Ald~unoyaA: (IAar, K, TA:) so called because compassing the intellect of a man (ta$otamilu EalaY Eaqolihi), and concealing it. (TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) Wine: (AA, K, TA:) so called for the same reason. (TA.) ― -b5- And The sun. (Z, TA; and T in art. Am).

$imolapN *
A mode, or manner, of Ai$otimaAl [or wrapping oneself with a garment as expl. above: see 8]. (K, TA.) Al$imolapu AlS~am~aA='u is That [mode of wrapping oneself] which is without a shirt and without drawers beneath; in the case of which, prayer is disliked. (TA. [See 8, and see also art. Sm.])
$amalapN * : see $amalN, in two places.
$amal~N * : see $amaAlN.

$imil~N * : see $amolN, near the end of the paragraph. -A2- Also, (TA,) and $imil~apN; (S, O, K, TA;) the former applied to a he-camel; (TA;) and the latter to a she-camel, as also ↓ $imolaAlN and ↓ $imoliylN, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) which are likewise applied to a he-camel, (TA,) and ↓ $imaAlN; (K;) Light, active, or agile; (S, O, Msb, K;) or swift. (Msb, K, TA.) Hence the phrase ↓ TaA^oTaA^otu $imolaAliY [I hastened my light one, or my swift one]: or, accord. to AA, he means his hand, or arm, called the $imaAl; [i. e. I lowered my left hand or arm;] $imolaAlN and $imaAlN meaning the same. (S, O.)

$amaAlN * , (S, O, Msb, K, &c.,) the most common form of the word, (Msb,) and ↓ $imaAlN, [a form which I think objectionable as likely to cause confusion, though it is probably the original form,] (K,) and ↓ $amoA^alN, (S, O, Msb, K,) and ↓ $amoA^al~N, (S, O, K, [in one place in the O erroneously written $aA^mal~,]) and ↓ $aA^omalN, (S, O, Msb, K,) which last is formed by transposition, (S, O, Msb,) and ↓ $aAmalN, without ', (MF, TA,) and ↓ $awomalN, and ↓ $ayomalN and ↓ $amuwlN, (O, K,) and ↓ $amiylN, (K,) and ↓ $amalN, (S, O, Msb, K,) and ↓ $amolN, (S, Msb, K,) the last said by ISd not to have been heard except in the poetry of El-Ba'eeth, (TA,) and ↓ $amal~N, (MF, TA,) [every one of these] used as a subst. and as an epithet, (K,) [so that one says riyHu Al$~amaAli &c. as well as riyHN $amaAlN &c. and $amaAlN &c. alone; The north wind: or a northerly wind:] the wind that is the opposite to the januwb: (Msb:) the wind that blows from the direction of the quTob [or pole-star]: (S:) or the wind that blows from the direction of the Hijor [which is on what is called the north, but what is rather to be called the north-west, side of the Kaabeh]: (M, K:) or the wind that blows from the direction of the right hand of a person facing the Kibleh [by which is meant the angle of the Black Stone; i. e., correctly speaking, from the north]: (Th, M, K:) or, correctly, the wind that blows from between the place of sunrise and the constellation of the Bear (banaAt naEo$): or from between the place of sunrise and the place of setting of the constellation of the Eagle (Aln~asor
AlT~aAy^ir): (IAar, K:) [i. e. the wind that blows from some point of the north-east quarter, or nearly so: but it was probably thus named as being the wind that blows from the direction of the $imaAl (or left side) of a person facing the rising sun; and therefore the north wind or a northerly wind:] it seldom, or never, blows in the night: (K:) when it blows for seven days upon the people of Egypt, they prepare the graveclothes, for its nature is deadly: it is cold and dry: (TA:) [see also nakobaA='u:] the pl. of $amaAlN is $amaAlaAtN (S, O, K) and $amaAy^ilu, which is anomalous, as though pl. of $amaAlapN: (S, O:) AlA^a$aAmil also occurs, coupled with AlA^ajaAnib, in a verse of Et- Tirimmáh; and [as A^ajaAnibu is a reg. pl. of A^ajonubN, which is a pl. of januwbN,] ISd thinks that they formed from $amolN the pl. A^a$omalN; and then from this last, the pl. A^a$aAmilu. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, ↓ A^aSabotu mino fulaAnK $amalFA i. e. riyHFA [(assumed tropical:) I perceived from such a one an odour, app. meaning a foul odour]. (TA.)

$imaAlN * , (S, O, Msb, K, &c.,) applied to one of the hands or arms, (S, Msb,) The left; contr. of yamiynN; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also ↓ $iymaAlN, (K, TA, [in the CK, Al$~amAl and Al$~mAl are erroneously put for Al$~imaAl and Al$~iymaAl,]) the latter thought by ISd to be used only by poetic license, for $imaAlN, (TA,) and ↓ $imolaAlN, (AA, S, O, K,) this last not known to Ks nor to As: (TA:) of the fem. gender: (S, O, Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] A^a$omulN, (S, O, Msb, K,) because it is fem., (S, O,) and [of mult.] $amaAy^ilu, (S, O, Msb, K,) which is anomalous, (S, O,) and $umulN, and $imaAlN like the sing. (K.) ― -b2- And The direction [or side] of the hand so called: you say, Ailotafata yamiynFA wa$imaAlFA i. e. [He looked, or turned his face,] in the direction of the ymyn and in the direction of the $mAl: and the pl. in this sense also is A^u$omulN and $amaAy^ilu: (Msb:) you say, *ahaba A_ilaY A^ayomuni AlA_ibili waA^a$omulihaA He went to the right sides of the camels and the left sides thereof. (TA in art. ymn.) ― -b3- [Hence,] (tropical:) Ill luck, unluckiness, or evil fortune. (K, TA.) Tayoru Al$~imaAli means (tropical:) Birds of ill luck: (A, TA:) every bird from which one augurs evil. (O, TA.) One says, jaraY lahu guraAbu $imaAlK, meaning (assumed tropical:) What was disliked, or hated, happened to him: as though the bird [to which this is likened] came to him from the $imaAl [or direction of the left hand]. (TA.) And when the place that a person occupies is rendered evil, one says, fulaAnN EinodiY biAl$~imaAli (assumed tropical:) [Such a one is with me, or in my estimation, in an evil plight]. (TA.) ― -b4- See also $amaAlN. ― -b5- Also Every handful of corn, or seedproduce, which the reaper grasps [app. because grasped with his left hand]. (K.) -A2- And A sort of bag that is put upon the udder of the ewe or goat (S, O, K) when it (i. e. the udder, TA) is heavy [with milk]: (K, * TA:) or it is peculiar to the she-goat: (K:) pl. $umulN. (K voce EaraAbapN.) ― -b2- And A similar thing that is put to the raceme of a palm-tree, made with pieces of [the garments called] A^akosiyap [pl. of kisaA='N], in order that the fruit may not be shaken off. (S, O.) [In this sense it may perhaps be from the same word as pl. of $amolapN.] -A3- And A mark made with a hot iron (simapN) upon the udder of a ewe or goat. (K.) -A4- Also A nature; or a natural disposition or temper or the like: (O, Msb, K:) accord. to Er-Rághib, so called because [it is as though it were a thing] inwrapping the man [and restricting his freedom of action], like as the [garments called] $imaAl [pl. of $amolapN] inwrap the body: (TA:) the pl. is $amaAy^ilu, (O, K, TA,) and $imaAlN, also, [which seems to be rarely used as a sing. in this sense,] may be a pl., like dilaASN. (TA; and Ham p. 489, q. v.) 'Abd-Yaghooth El-Hárithee says,
A^alamo taEolamaA A^an~a AlmalaAmapa nafoEuhaA
qaliylN wamaA lawomiY A^axiYmino $imaAliyaA
[Know not ye two that the utility of censure is little, and my censuring my brother is not of my nature, or of my natural dispositions?]: (O, TA:) here it may be a pl., of the class of hijaAnN and dilaASN: or it may be [$amaAliyaA,] an instance of transposition, for $amaAy^iliY. (TA.) -A5- See also $imil~N.
$amoA^alN * and $amoA^al~N: see $amaAlN.

$amuwlN * : see $amaAlN. ― -b2- Also Wine: (S, K:) or wine that is cool (K, TA) to the taste; but this is not of valid authority; (TA;) as also ↓ ma$omuwlapN: [wine is said to be] thus called because it envelops (ta$omalu) men with its odour: or because it has a strong puff (EaSofap), [when opened,] like that of the [wind called] $amaAl [in the CK $mAl]. (K, TA.)
$amiylN * : see $amaAlN.
$mAlp * [thus in my original, without any syll. signs, probably $imaAlapN, like sitaArapN &c.,] The lurkingplace (qutorap) of a hunter or sportsman: pl. $amaAy^ilu. (TA.)

$amaAliY~N *
Of, or relating to, the quarter of the $amaAl [or north, or northerly, wind]. (KL.) ― -b2- And A cold day. (KL.)
$imolaAlN * : see $imil~N, in two places: -A2- and see $imaAlN.

$umoluwlN * ; and its pl. $amaAliylu: see $amalN, in three places. ― -b2- $amaAliylu also signifies The shoots that divaricate at the heads of branches, like the fruitstalks of the raceme of the palm-tree. (S, O.) ― -b3- [Hence,] *ahabuwA $amaAliyla They went away in distinct parties: (K:) or they dispersed themselves. (S, O.) ― -b4- And vawobN $amaAliylu A garment, or piece of cloth, rent, or slit, in several places; (O, TA;) like $amaATiyTu. (S, O.) ― -b5- $amaAliylu AlnwY means baqaAyaAhu [i. e. The remains of AlnwY: but I doubt whether this word be correctly transcribed]. (TA.)
$imoliylN * : see $imil~N.
$aAmalN * and $aA^omalN: see $amaAlN.

A^amorN $aAmilN *
i. q. EaAm~N [i. e. An event, or a case, that includes persons or things in common, in general, or universally, within the compass of its effect or effects, its operation or operations, its influence, or the like; or that is common, general, or universal, in its effect &c.]. (S, * O, * Msb, TA.) ― -b2- lawonN $aAmilN A black colour overspread with another colour. (O, TA.)
$awomalN * : see $amaAlN.
$ayomalN * : see $amaAlN.
$iymaAlN * : see $imaAlN.
mi$omalN * : see $amolapN. ― -b2- Also A short sword, (S, O, K,) or a short and slender sword, like the migowal, (TA,) over which a man covers himself with his garment. (S, O, K.)
ma$omalapN * The place [or quarter] whence blows the [north, or northerly, wind called] $amaAl. (Ham p. 628.)
mi$omalapN * : see $amolapN, in two places.

mi$omaAlN *
A [garment of the kind called] miloHafap, (K, TA,) with which one wraps, or inwraps, himself (yu$otamalu bihi). (TA.) [See also $amolapN.]

ma$omuwlN * A man smitten, or blown upon, by the [north, or northerly,] wind called $amaAl: (S, O:) and in like manner, a meadow, and a pool of water left by a torrent; (O;) or, applied to this last, smitten by the wind thus called so as to become cool: (S:) and hence, with p, wine (tropical:) cool to the taste; (S, O, TA; *) or wine exposed to the $amaAl and so rendered cool and pleasant: (TA: see also $amuwlN:) and fire upon which the wind called the $amaAl has blown: (S, O:) and a night cold, with [wind that is called] $amaAl. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) One whose natural dispositions are liked, approved, or found pleasant: (K:) from [the same epithet applied to] water upon which the $amaAl has blown, and which it has cooled: or, as ISd thinks, from $amuwlN [q. v.]: (TA:) or ma$omuwlu AlxalaAy^iqi a man whose natural dispositions are commended; as being likened to wine that is commended: and also whose natural dispositions are discommended; as though from Al$~amaAlu, because they do not commend it when it disperses the clouds: (Har p. 285:) [for] A^axolaAqN ma$omuwlapN [sometimes] means discommended, evil, natural dispositions. (IAar, ISk, TA.) The saying of Aboo-Wejzeh,
ma$omuwlapu AlA^unosi majonuwbN mawaAEiduhaA
is expl. by IAar as meaning (assumed tropical:) Her familiarity passes away with the $amaAl, and her promises pass away with the januwb [which is the opposite of the $amaAl]: or, as some relate it,
majonuwbapu AlA^unosi ma$omuwlN mawaAEiduhaA
[meaning in like manner, as is said in the TA, on the authority of IAar, in art. jnb: or,] accord. to ISk, meaning her familiarity is commended,
because the jnwb, with rain, is desired for abundance of herbage; and her promises are not commended. (TA.) ― -b3- nawFY ma$omuwlapN, a phrase used by Zuheyr, is expl. as meaning (assumed tropical:) [A tract, or place, towards which one journeys,] that separates friends; because the [wind called] $amaAl disperses the clouds: (TA:) or it means quickly [or soon] becoming exposed to view; (ISk, O, TA;) from the fact that when the wind called the $amaAl blows the clouds, they delay not to become cleared away, and to depart: (O:) or, accord. to IAar, it means maA^oxuw*N bihaA *aAtu Al$~imaAli [in which the direction of the left hand is taken]. (TA.) ― -b4- In the saying,
Hamalato bihi fiY layolapK ma$omuwlapN
the meaning is, fariEapN [i. e. One in a state of fright became pregnant with him in a certain night]. (TA, referring to the phrase $amolN mino junuwnK.)

mu$otamilN * : see $amilN ― -b2- One says, jaA='a mu$otamilFA bisayofihi like as one says murotadiyFA [i. e. He came having his sword hung upon him]. (TA.) ― -b3- And jaA='a fulaAnN mu$otamilFA EalaY daAhiyapK (tropical:) [Such a one came conceiving a calamity]. (TA.)

1 $an~a AlmaA='a * , (S, Mgh, K,) aor.
$anu3a , inf. n. $an~N, (Mgh, TA,) He scattered the water; (S, K;) or poured it scatteringly; (Mgh;) or poured it and scattered it; or, as some say, poured it in a manner like that which is termed naDoHN [i. e. sprinkling]; (TA;) EalaY Al$~araAbi [upon the wine, or beverage]: (S, K:) san~ahu signifies “ he poured it gently. ” (TA.) And $an~ati AlEayonu damoEahaA The eye poured forth its tears; (TA;) or sent forth [or shed] its tears; like $al~at, (Lh, TA in art. $l,) which is asserted by Yaakoob to be formed by substitution [of l for n]. (TA in that art.) ― -b2- And, from the former, $an~a AlgaArapa, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Msb,) (tropical:) He scattered, (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) or poured, (K, TA,) the horsemen making a raid, or sudden attack, and engaging in conflict, or the horsemen urging their horses, AlgaArapa meaning Alxayola Almugiyrapa, (Mgh, Msb,) from every direction, Ealayohimo [upon them]; (S, K;) as also ↓ A$n~hA; (S, Msb, K;) the latter mentioned in the Mj, (Msb,) by IF, but disapproved by the people of chaste speech. (TA.) ― -b3- And $an~a bisaloHihi (AA, S, * TA) He cast forth his excrement, or dung, in a thin [and scattered] state: and one says of the HubaAraY [or bustard] ta$un~u bi*aroqihaA [It casts forth its dung in a thin and scattered state]. (AA, TA.) ― -b4- And $an~a Ealayoihi diroEahu He put (lit. poured) on him his coat of mail. (TA.) -A2- $an~a Aljamalu mina AlEaTa$i, [aor. accord. to general rule
$ani3a ,] The camel became dried up [like a $an~, q. v.,] from thirst. (TA.) And $an~ati Alxiroqapu The rag became dried up. (TA.)
2 ta$oniynN * and ta$onaAnN [inf. ns. of $n~n] The dripping, or dropping by degrees, of water from the $an~ap [or old and worn-out water-skin or the like]. (TA. [See also $aniynN.])
4 A^a$ona3a see 1: ― -b2- and see also what next follows.

5 ta$an~anati Alqirobapu * , and ↓ t$An~t, (S, K,) and ↓ A$n~t and ↓ Ast$n~t, (K,) The water-skin became old, and worn out: (S, K:) or ↓ t$An~, said of skin, or a skin, does not signify thus, but signifies, (AA, S,) or signifies also, (K,) and so t$n~n, (S, K, TA,) said of the skin of a man, in extreme old age, (S,) it contracted, shrank, shrivelled, or wrinkled; or became contracted or shrunk &c.; (S, K, TA;) and dried up: (S, TA:) and ↓ Ast$n~ is likewise said of the skin of a man, meaning it became old, and worn out, like the old, and worn-out, $an~. (Har p. 675.) It is said in a trad., ↓ AlquroA=nu laA yatofahu walaA yata$aAn~u [expl. in art. tfh]. (TA.) See also a tropical usage of ↓ Ast$n~ in a trad. cited in the first paragraph of art. bl. ― -b2- t$n~n is also said of the skin of a man as meaning It became altered [for the worse] in odour, in extreme old age. (TA.)
6 ta$aAn~a * : see 5, in three places. ― -b2- Also It was or became, mixed. (K.)

7 A_ino$ana3a [An$n~ It became poured out, or forth; it flowed. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.) ― -b2- Hence,] An$n~ Al*~iy^obu fiY Alganami (assumed tropical:) The wolf made an incursion among the sheep or goats; as also An$l~: mentioned by Az in art. n$g. (TA.)

10 Ast$n~ * : see 5, in three places. ― -b2- Also, (Kh, S, K,) said of a man, (Kh, S, TA,) and of a camel, (TA,) (tropical:) He became lean, or emaciated, (Kh, S, K, TA,) like the water-skin that has become old, and worn out: so says Aboo-Kheyreh: (TA:) or, said of an animal, he became dried up, and lean, or emaciated. (Har p. 530.) ― -b3- And Ast$n~ A_ilaY All~abani i. q. EaAma, (K,) i. e. He betook himself to milk, or the milk, and desired it eagerly, or longed for it. (TA.)

R. Q. 1 $ano$anapN * [an inf. n., of which the verb, if it be used, is $ano$ana,] The motion of paper, and of a new garment: [or rather the making a kind of crackling sound by the motion thereof:] mentioned by Az in art. fqE: (TA:) and na$ona$apN signifies the same: both thus expl. by IAar. (TA in art. qE.)

$an~N *
A skin, (Msb,) or a water-skin, (S, Mgh,) or a small water skin, (K,) or, as some say, any vessel made of skin, (TA,) applied by a poet to a dalow [or leathern bucket], (Ham p. 602,) that is old, and worn out; (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA;) and so ↓ $an~apN; (S, K;) but app. one that is small: (S: [in which this addition to the explanation seems to relate peculiarly to the latter word: see an ex. of this latter word in some verses cited in the first paragraph of art. sqY:]) or both signify an old water-skin; as also ↓ mi$an~N: (MA:) and ↓ $ananN, also, signifies an old, worn-out, water-skin: (TA:) pl. (of the first, Mgh, Msb) $inaAnN: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) and Lh mentions the phrase qirobapN A^a$onaAnN, as though they applied the term $an~N to every portion of the qrbp and then pluralized it thus; but he says that he had not heard A^a$onaAnN as a pl. of $an~N except in this case: (TA:) the water in a $an~ is cooler [than that in a skin not so old]. (Mgh.) It is said in a prov., laA yuqaEoqaEu liY biAl$~inaAni [A confused and clattering noise will not be made to me with the old and worn-out water-skins to frighten me]: (S in the present art.: [in the S and K in art. qE, with maA in the place of lA; and in the K in that art., with lahu in the place of lY:]) maA yuqaEoqaEu lahu biAl$~inaAni is applied to him who will not be abased by misfortunes, nor frightened by that which has no reality: (Sgh and K in art. qE:) or it means, he will not be deceived nor frightened: $inaAn being pl. of $an~N, a dried up skin, which is shaken to a camel to frighten him. (L and TA in art. qE.) An old man is likened to the skin thus termed. (Har p. 675.) And ↓ $an~apN signifies also (tropical:) A worn-out old woman; as being likened to the skin thus termed. (IAar, TA.) And one says, rafaEa fulaAnN Al$~an~a, meaning (assumed tropical:) Such a man raised himself bearing upon the palm of his hand. (IKh, TA.) ― -b2- Also i. q. grD [app. garaDN, i. e. A butt, at which one shoots or casts: probably because an old water-skin was sometimes used as a butt]: pl. as above. (Msb.) ― -b3- [And, as Freytag states, on the authority of Meyd, (assumed tropical:) Dry herbage.] -A2- Also Weakness. (TA.)
$an~apN * : see $an~N, in two places.
$ananN * : see $an~N, first sentence.
$anaAnN * a dial. var. of $anoA=nN [inf. n. of $aniy^a], (S, K,) signifying Hatred; [or the hating of another;] (S;) mentioned by AO. (S in art. $nA^.)

$unaAnN *
Water in a scattered state, or being scattered. (S, K.) ― -b2- And (K) Cold water: (As, Skr, ISd, K:) this explanation is preferred by Aboo-Nasr. (TA.) ― -b3- And Clouds (saHaAb) pouring (ya$un~u i. e. yaSub~u) water. (Skr, TA.)

$anuwnN * A camel in a state between that of the lean, or emaciated, and that of the fat; (S;) so called because some of his fatness has gone: (Aboo-Kheyreh, TA:) one says mahozuwlN; then munoqK, when he has become a little fat; then $anuwnN; then saAH~N; and then muvaroTimN, when fat in the utmost degree: (Lh, TA:) so says Aboo-Ma'add El-Kilá- bee. (TA in art. sH.) [But it is said that] it signifies also Lean, or emaciated; (K;) applied to a beast: (TA:) and fat: thus having two contr. meanings. (K.) ― -b2- Also Hungry: (S, K:) applied in this sense by Et-Tirimmáh to a wolf, because this animal is not described as fat or lean. (S.)

$aniynN *
Poured forth: applied in this sense by the Hudhalee poet 'Abd-Menáf to thick blood (Ealaq). (TA.) ― -b2- And Pure milk upon which cold water has been poured: (IAar, TA:) or any milk, whether fresh or collected in a skin at different times, upon which water is poured. (K, TA.) -A2- And The dropping (S, K, TA) by degrees, (TA,) of water (S, K, TA) from a skin, (TA,) and of tears. (S, TA. [See also 2, and see $ino$inapN.])

$unaAnapN *
Water that drops (S, K) from a skin, or from a tree. (S.)

$aAn~apN * The [channel called] madofaE [q. v.] of a small valley: or a small madofaE of a valley: (TA: [the want of a vowel-sign in my original renders it doubtful which of these meanings is the right one:]) or $awaAn~u, its pl., signifies the channels of water, of mountains, that pour forth into valleys from a rugged place. (AA, TA.)

$ino$inapN *
A nature; or a natural, a native, or an innate, disposition or temper or the like; syn. TabiyEapN, (S, Mgh, K,) and xuluqN, (S,) and sajiy~apN: (TA:) and a custom, habit, or wont: (Mgh, K:) [pl. $anaA$inu.] One says fiyhi mino A^abiyhi $anaA$inu In him are habits [or natural dispositions inherited] from his father. (TA.) Hence,
$ino$inapN A^aEorifuhaA mino A^axozamo
[A natural disposition, or a habit, which I know, as inherited from Akhzam]: (S, Meyd, Mgh:) or, accord. to one relation, ni$oni$apN, which is app. formed by transposition from $ino$inapN: (Meyd:) a prov.: (Meyd, Mgh:) [of its origin there are different explanations: see Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 658, and Har pp. 591 and 596:] A^axozamu is the proper name of a man: (Meyd, Mgh, &c.:) or accord. to Lth, it is an epithet applied to a penis; one says kamarapN xazomaA='u “ a glans of a penis having a short frænum, ” and *akarN A^axozamu; and $n$np means the dropping of water [i. e., in this case, of the seminal fluid]: (Meyd:) the prov. is applied in relation to nearness of resemblance. (Meyd, Mgh.) -A2- Also A bit of flesh-meat, as much as is chewed at once; syn. muDogapN: or a piece of flesh-meat; (K, TA;) and so ni$oni$apN: on the authority of AA. (TA.) ― -b2- And [the pl.] $anaA$inu signifies Bones; like sanaAsinu. (IAar, L in art. sn.)
mi$an~N * : see $an~N, first sentence.

mi$an~apN *
A thing like the mikotal: [in the present day, a round shallow basket is thus called: pl. ma$aAn~u.] (TA.)

1 $aniy^ahu * , (Th, S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) and $anaA^ahu, (K,) but this is said by AHeyth to be a bad dial. var. of the former, (TA,) aor.
$anaAa , (Msb, K,) inf. n. $ano'N (AO, S, Msb, K) and $ino'N and $uno'N (Aboo- 'Amr Esh-Sheybánee, S, K) and $anoA^apN (K, TA, in the CK $anA'ap [i. e. $anaA='apN, which is afterwards added in the TA, not as in the K, and mentioned in the S but not there said to be an inf. n.,]) and $anaA^N (TA from Es-Safákusee) and $anaA='N (TA [as from J, but perhaps from Az, for I do not find it in the S,]) and ma$onaA^N (S, CK, and TA as from Es-Safá- kusee, not as from the K,) and ma$onaA^apN and ma$onuw^apN (K, TA, the last in the CK ma$onuw'ap [i. e. ma$onuwo'apN],) and ma$oniy^apN (TA from Es-Safákusee) and $anaA=nN, (S, K,) which is anomalous as being of a measure regularly employed [only] for the inf. n. of a verb signifying motion and agitation, as DarabaAnN and xafaqaAnN, (S, TA,) for though it has been said that [hatred (which it signifies) is attended by anger and] anger is accompanied by agitation of the heart, there is no necessary connection between hatred and anger, and it is anomalous also as being of a measure not proper to [the inf. n. of] a trans. verb, (TA,) and $anoA=nN, (S, Msb, K,) which is also anomalous, and [said to be] the only instance of its kind (S, TA) except lay~aAnN, though some few others have been mentioned, as zayodaAnN, but this is not well known, [and xa$oyaAnN, of which the same may be said,] and wa$okaAnN [perhaps a simple subst.], and jawolaAnN which is said to occur in a verse [perhaps contracted from jawalaAn by poetic license], (TA,) and AO mentions $anaAnN, without ', as being like $anoA=nN; (S;) these inf. ns. being fourteen, which is said by IKtt to be the greatest number of inf. ns. to any one verb, only seven other verbs, he says, having this number, namely, qadara, laqiYa, warada, halaka, tam~a, makava and galaba; but Es-Safákusee makes the inf. ns. of $aniy^a to be fifteen, [though the fifteenth form (which is perhaps ma$onuwo'apN) I do not find mentioned,] and this is the greatest number known; (TA;) He hated him: (IKoot, IF, S, ISd, IKtt, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.:) or, as some say, he hated him vehemently. (TA.) y$nY, [app. yu$onaY, for yu$onaA^u,] with the hemzeh changed into Y, occurs in a trad. (TA.) And $uniy^a signifies He (a man, S) was hated, (S, and so accord. to some copies of the K,) or was rendered hateful, or an object of hatred, (so accord. to other copies of the K,) even if beautiful or comely. (S, K.) -A2- $aniy^a lahu Haq~ahu, (K,) so says A'Obeyd, or, accord. to Th, $anaA^a A_ilayohi, like manaEa [in form], and this is the more correct, aor. of each
$anaAa , (TA,) He gave him his right, or due. (A'Obeyd, Th, K, TA.) And $aniy^a bihi He acknowledged it: (S, Msb, K:) or he gave him (K) his right, or due, (TA,) [or the meaning in the K may be he gave it,] and declared himself clear, or quit, of him or it; as also $anaA^a: (K:) [but accord. to SM, this is wrong, for he says that] the author of the K should have said, or $aniy^a A_ilayohi, like $anaA^a, aor.
$anaAa , he gave him, and declared himself clear, or quit, of him or it. (TA.) And $aniy^a Al$~aYo'a He produced the thing: (K, TA:) or, as A'Obeyd says, $aniy^a Haq~ahu he acknowledged his right, or due, and produced it from his possession. (TA.)

6 ta$aAnaw^uwA *
They hated one another. (S, O, K.)

$ano'N * and $ino'N and $uno'N [all mentioned above as inf. ns., when used as simple substs. signify Hatred; and thus ↓ $anaA='apN, likewise mentioned above as an inf. n., signifies accord. to the S; and so ↓ $aniyoy^apN accord. to Freytag, as on the authority of Meyd; and app. also $anuwo'apN, q. v.; or all signify] vehement hatred; in which sense the first is expl. by AO: (TA:) or ↓ $anaA='apN signifies hatred mixed with enmity and evilness of disposition. (Ham p. 108)
$anuw^apN * : see $anuwo'apN, in three places.

$anaA='apN * : see $ano'N, in two places. -A2- Also, and ↓ $anaAy^iyapN, epithets applied to a man, Rendered hateful, or an object of hatred, evil in disposition. (Lth, O, TA.) [See also the latter word voce $anoA=n; and see ma$onuwo'N, and mi$onaA='N.]

$anuwo'apN * The removing oneself far, or keeping aloof, from unclean things; (S, K, TA;) and the continual doing so, or the continual purification of oneself; as also ↓ $anuw^apN; and accord. to the K, $unuwo'apN, but this is not found elsewhere. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (S,) A^azodu $anuwo'apa, the appellation of a tribe of El-Yemen; (S, K; *) sometimes called A^azodu $anuw~apa: (ISk, S, K:) [or] this tribe was so called because of $anoA=n among them; (K, TA;) i. e. because of mutual hatred that occurred among them: (TA:) [whence it seems that $anuwo'apN signifies also Hatred:] or because of their removing far from their [original] district: or, accord. to El-Khafájee, because of their high lineage, and good deeds; from the phrase rajulu $anuwodapK, meaning A man of pure lineage and of manly virtue; and AO says the like. (TA.) ― -b3- [And accord. to Reiske, as stated by Freytag, (who has written it ↓ $anuw^apN in all its senses,) it is expl. by Meyd as meaning What is esteemed sordid, of words and of actions.] -A2- Also One who removes himself far, or keeps aloof, from unclean things; (K, TA;) and so ↓ $anuw^apN. (TA.) Thus both of these words are epithets, as well as substs. (TA.)
$aniyoy^apN * : see $ano'N.

$anoA=n * , of which the fem. is $anoA=napN and $anoA^aY, [so that one may say either $anoA=nN or $anoA=nu,] is an epithet applied to a man; (K;) [signifying either Hating or (like ma$onuwo'N) hated; the former meaning seeming to be indicated by what immediately precedes it in the K; but the latter appears from what here follows to be the right meaning, and perhaps it may be that which is meant in the K;] as also ↓ $anaAniy^apN or ↓ $anaAy^iyapN [q. v. voce $anaA='apN]: so accord. to different copies of the K. (TA.) ― -b2- In the Kur v. 3 and 11, it is accord. to some an inf. n., and some read there $anaA=n: [see 1, first sentence:] accord. to others, it is an epithet, signifying mubogaDN or bagiyDN [i. e. Hated or odious]. (TA.) ― -b3- $anoA=nu Al$~itaA='i, in a trad. of Kaab, is said to be a metaphorical expression for barodu Al$~itaA='i (tropical:) [The cold of winter]; because it is hated: or, as some say, by the barod thereof is meant ease and repose: and the meaning intended is either mutual hatred or ease and repose. (TA.)
$anaAy^iyapN * : see $anaA='apN, and $anoA=n.
$anaAniy^apN * : see $anoA=n.

$aAniy^N *
Hating, or a hater, (Fr, S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) and an enemy: (Fr, TA:) fem. with p. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- laA A^abaA li$aAniy^ika, as also laA A^aba li$aAniy^ika, (S, O, [but in my two copies of the S li$aAniyka, which perhaps expresses the general pronunciation, and in the TA lA AbA l$Any^k and lA AbA l$Anyk,]) means limubogiDika [i. e., lit., May there be no father
to thy hater]; and is said by ISk to be a metonymical expression for laA A^abaA laka [q. v., lit. an imprecation, but generally meant as an expression of praise]. (S, O, TA.)

$awaAniy^u AlmaAli * means [Camels, or the like,] not avariciously retained; as though hated, and therefore liberally given away: (IAar, K, TA:) $wAny^ being app. an act. part. n. [in the pl.] used in the sense of a pass. part. n., like the instances in maA='N daAfiqN and Eiy$apN raADiyapN. (MF, TA.)

ma$onaA^N * , applied to a man, (A'Obeyd, S, O,) like ma$onaEN [in form, and perhaps in meaning], (A'Obeyd, TA,) Foul, or ugly, in aspect; as also ↓ mi$onaA='N: (S, O:) or foul, or ugly, (K, TA,) in face, (TA,) even if made an object of love [by good qualities]: (K, TA:) [originally an inf. n., and therefore] used alike as sing. (S, O, K) and dual (S, O) and pl. (S, O, K) and masc. and fem.: (K:) so says Lth: (TA:) or one who hates men; (K;) and so ↓ mi$onaA='N, accord. to 'Alee Ibn- Hamzeh El-Isbahánee: (TA:) or ↓ this last signifies one whom men hate: or it may be well rendered one who does much for which he is to be hated; for it is one of the measures of the act. part. n. [used in an intensive sense]. (A'Obeyd, K.)
mi$onaA='N * : see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

ma$onuwo'N * , applied to a man, (S,) Hated, (S, and so in some copies of the K, [see also $anoA=n,]) or rendered hateful, or an object of hatred, (so accord. to other copies of the K,) even if beautiful, or comely; (S, K;) and ma$onuw~N and ma$oniY~N signify the same. (K in art. $nw.)

ma$oniyoy^apN * , occurring in a trad. of 'Áïsheh, [A kind of food that is supped, or sipped;] i. q. HasaA='N and talobiynapN: [see these two words:] said by IAth to be irregularly formed from ma$onuwo'apN, by changing the ' into Y [so that the word becomes ma$onuwyapN, and then, by rule, ma$oniy~apN, which is mentioned in the TA, in art. $nw, as occurring thus in a trad.,] and then by restoring the ' [in the place of the second Y], the meaning being hated. (TA.)

1 $aniba * , aor.
$anaba , (K,) inf. n. $anabN, (TA,) He had the quality termed $anabN meaning as expl. below. (K.) ― -b2- And It (a day) was, or became, cool, or cold. (A, K.)

$anabN *
Lustre, and fineness, or delicacy, or thinness, and coolness, and sweetness, in the teeth: (A, K:) or lustre, and fineness, or delicacy, or thinness, in the fore teeth: (TA:) or these two qualities, together with coolness and sweetness, in the mouth, accord. to As, or in the teeth: (TA:) or coolness and sweetness in the teeth: or sharpness of the teeth: (S:) or sharpness of the canine teeth, like garobN, so that they appear like a saw: (K:) or white specks in the teeth: (A, K:) or the state of the teeth when they appear somewhat tinged with blackness, like the appearance of blackness in hail; guruwbN signifying the “ lustre ” of the teeth; and ZalomN, their “ whiteness that is as though there were over it a blackness: ” (ISh, TA:) Abu-l-'Abbás says, It is variously expl., as a serrated state of the teeth: and their clearness and cleanness: and their being separate, or apart, one from another: and the sweetness of their odour: (TA:) El-Jarmee says, I heard As say that this word signifies coolness of the mouth and teeth; and I said, Our companions say that it is their sharpness when they come forth; by which is meant their new, or recent, and fresh state; for when they have undergone the lapse of years, they become abraded, or worn: but he said, It is nothing but their coolness: and the saying of Dhu-r-Rummeh,
wafiY All~ivaAti wafiY A^anoyaAbihaA $anabu
[which should be rendered And in the gums, and in her canine teeth, is coolness], corroborates the assertion of As; for there is no sharpness in the gum: (S, L, TA:) it is also related of As that he said, I asked Ru-beh respecting the meaning of $anabN, and he took a grain of pomegranate, and pointed to its lustre: (Mz, TA:) [and ↓ $unobapN signifies the same:] a poet says,
munaS~abuhaA Hamo$N A^aHam~u yaziynuhu
EawaAriDu fiyhaA $unobapN waguruwbu
[Her even set of front teeth are slender and white, side teeth in which are coolness and lustre adorning them]. (O, TA.) ― -b2- [In the present day, it signifies The mustache.]
$anibN * and ↓ $aAnibN, (A, K,) the former regular, the latter on the authority of usage, (TA,) A cool, or cold, day. (A, K.)

$unobapN *
Coolness, or coldness, of a day. (O, K.) ― -b2- See also $anabN, near the end.
$aniybN * : see A^a$onabu.
$aAnibN * : see $anibN: ― -b2- and what here follows.

A^a$onabu *
Having the quality termed $anabN meaning as expl. above; (A, O, K;) as also ↓ $aAnibN, (K,) which is irregular, (TA,) and ↓ $aniybN, (K,) [which is likewise irregular;] but the first of these three is the most common: (TA:) applied to a man, (O,) and to the vagor [or front teeth], (A,) [and to the mouth, as in a verse cited voce zaronabN:] fem. $anobaA='u, (S, O, K,) applied to a woman, (S, O,) and also written $amobaA='u, (K,) the n being changed into m because of the following b, and in like manner [the pl. $unobN is also written] $umobN. (TA.) ― -b2- $anobaA='u also signifies A pomegranate (rum~aAnapN) such as is termed A_imoliysiy~apN, having no grains, but only juice within the rind, (A, K, TA,) in the form of grains without stones. (TA.)

mi$onabN *
A young boy whose teeth are sharp and serrated by reason of his youthfulness. (IAar, O.)

ma$aAnibu *
Sweet mouths. (O, K.)
Q. 1 $anobava AlhawaY qalobahu * , (S and L in art. $bv, as Q. Q., and K in the present art.,) inf. n. $anobavapN, (S, L,) Love clave to his heart. (S, L, K.)

Al$~anobavu *
The lion; as also ↓ Al$~unaAbivu. (K.)

$unaAbivN *
Thick, gross, big, bulky, coarse, or rough; syn. galiyZN. (K.) ― -b2- See also Al$~anobavu.
xiyaAru $anobara * : see the former word in art. xyr.

1 $anija * , aor.
$anaja , inf. n. $anajN; and ↓ t$n~j, (S, A, Mgh, K,) and ↓ An$nj, (S, K,) and ↓ A$nj; (TA;) said of the skin (S, Mgh, K) in consequence of the touch [or proximity] of fire [&c.], (Mgh,) and of the face, and of a member or limb, (A,) of a finger, &c., (TA,) It contracted, shrank, shrivelled, or wrinkled; or became contracted or shrunk &c. (S, A, Mgh, K, TA.) [↓ ta$an~ujN is often used as meaning Spasmodic contraction of a muscle &c.] And one says, ↓ fiY A^aEoDaAy^ihi ta$an~ujN and ↓ ta$oniyjN [In his limbs, or members, is a contraction]. (A.)

2 $n~jhu * , inf. n. ta$oniyjN, He [or it] contracted, shrunk, shrivelled, or wrinkled, it; namely, the skin [&c.]. (S, K.) See 1, last sentence. One says also, $n~j Alxay~aATu AlqabaA='a [The tailor puckered the tunic]. (A. [In the Mgh, the wrinkling around the anus is said to be like the ta$oniyj of the qabaA='.])
4 A^a$onaja see 1.
5 ta$an~aja see 1, in three places; and see mu$an~ajN.
7 A_ino$anaja see 1.

$anajN * inf. n. of 1. (S &c.) -A2- Also A camel: (Lth, IDrd, K:) or a heavy camel. (L in art. gnj.) ganajN EalaY$anajK is a phrase of the tribe of Hudheyl, meaning A man upon a camel: (Lth, IDrd, O:) or a man, or an old man, upon a heavy camel. (L in art. gnj.) ― -b2- It is also said, in the L, that it signifies An old man, in the dial. of Hudheyl. (TA.)

$anijN * , applied to the skin &c., Contracted, shrunk, shrivelled, or wrinkled. (TA.) And, applied to a man, Contracted, &c., in the skin, and in the arm, or hand; as also ↓ A^a$onaju. (M, TA.) And yadN $anijapN means Day~aqapu Alkaf~i [i. e. An arm contracted, or narrow, in the hand; or a hand contracted, &c., in the palm, or in the palm and fingers]. (TA.) $aniju Aln~asaA means Contracted in the Eiroq called AlnsA [app., in this instance, the sciatic nerve]: (TA:) it is an epithet of commendation applied to a horse; because, when he is contracted therein, his hind legs are not relaxed: (S, K:) or it is an epithet of com-
mendation applied to a horse of good breed; but not so when applied to a hackney: it is also applied to some other animals, that do not walk with freedom; to a gazelle, and to a wolf: (T, TA:) and sometimes to the raven, or crow, (T, S,) which hops as though it were shackled. (T, TA.)

A^a$onaju * : see $anijN. ― -b2- $anijN A^a$onaju and ↓ $anijN mu$an~ajN are expressions sometimes used; [A^a$onaju being syn. with $anijN, as shown above, and in this case a corroborative; and] ↓ mu$an~ajN [when thus used] meaning Intensely contracted or shrunk &c. (Lth, TA.) -A2- Also Having one of his testicles smaller than the other; like A^a$oraju, which is more approved. (TA.)

mu$an~ajN * : see A^a$onaju, in two places. ― -b2- qabaA='N mu$an~ajN [A puckered tunic: see 2]. (A, Mgh.) saraAwiylu mu$an~ajapN, mentioned in a trad., in which they are forbidden, are said to be Such [drawers, or trousers,] as are so ample that they fall down upon the boot so as to cover half of the foot; as though meaning that, being ample and long, they cease not to rise, and become puckered (↓ fatata$an~aju). (TA.)

2 $n~r Ealayohi * , inf. n. ta$oniyrN, He blamed him; found fault with him; attributed or imputed to him, or accused him of, a vice, or fault: (K:) or the same, (K,) or $n~r bihi, (O,) or $n~rhu, (TA,) he rendered him infamous; exposed his vices, faults, or evil qualities or actions; disgraced him; or put him to shame. (O, K, TA.)
$anorapN * The gait, or manner of walking, of a righteous man. (O, K.) [See also $imorapN.]

$anaArN *
A vice, or fault: (S, O:) or the foulest vice or fault: (K:) and a disgrace, or shame, or thing that occasions one's being reviled: (S, O, K:) or a disgraceful vice or fault: seldom used unless conjointly with EaArN: (TA:) accord. to Sh, (O,) a thing, or an affair, notorious for badness or foulness: (O, K:) pl. $anaAy^iru. (TA.)
$unaAraY * one of the names of The cat. (O, K. *)

$un~aArN *
A certain white bird, found in water: of the dial. of Syria. (TA.)
$in~iyrN * and ↓ $in~iyrapN, (O, K,) [the latter having an intensive meaning,] applied to a man, (O,) Abounding in evil or mischief, and in vices, or faults; bad in disposition. (O, K.)
$in~iyrapN * : see what next precedes.
ma$onuwrapN * A liberal, bountiful, or generous, woman: as also mano$uwrapN. (IAar, T in art. n$r, TA.)

$uwniyzN * , (Mgh, K,) so called by the Persians, (TA,) [and generally by the Arabs in the present day,] and $awoniyzN, as in the “ Towsheeh ” of ElJelál Es-Suyootee, (TA,) and $iynyzN, (AHn, L, and so in some copies of the K,) without hemz, (AHn, L,) the proper form, for so the Arabs called it, (IAar, TA in art. swd,) or $iy^oniyzN, (as in some copies of the K, and in the TA,) with hemz, (TA,) and $uwnuwzN, or $uw^onuwzN, (as in different copies of the K,) and $ihoniyzN, (ADk, K,) A kind of seed, (L,) or grain; (Mgh;) the same as AlHab~apu Als~awodaA='u [the black aromatic seed of a species of nigella; a sort of all-spice]; (K;) or said to be so: (Mgh:) or it is of Persian origin: (K:) so it is accord. to Ed-Deenäwaree [AHn]: (TA:) but some say that AlHb~p AlswdA' is the same as AlHab~apu AlxaDoraA='u. (TA in art. swd.)

1 $anuEa * , aor.
$anuEa , inf. n. $anaAEapN (S, O, Msb, K) and $anaEN and $anaAEN, but this last, occurring in a verse, may be used by poetic license for $anaAEapN, (TA,) It (a thing, S) was, or became, bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly; (S, * O, * Msb, K;) syn. qabuHa. (Msb. [In the S and O and K, it is said that $anaAEapN signifies the same as faZaAEapN; but the latter seems to import more than the former.]) -A2- $anaEa fulaAnFA He regarded such a one as bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly, (AisotaqobaHahu, S, O, K, TA, in the CK Asotaxaf~ahu,) and reviled, or vilified, him, ($atamahu, O, K, TA, and so accord. to one of my copies of the S,) or loathed him, (say^imahu,) thus in some of the lexicons, [and accord. to one of my copies of the S,] but [SM says that] $atamahu is shown to be the right reading by the saying of IAar that $anaEahu, inf. n. $anoEN, means sab~ahu. (TA.) [See also 10.] ― -b2- Also, (O, K,) inf. n. $anoEN, (TA,) He disgraced such a one; put him to shame; or exposed his vices, faults, or evil qualities or actions. (O, K, TA.) ― -b3- And $anaEa Alxiroqapa He frayed the torn-off piece of cloth so that it became shaggy ($aE~avahaA Hat~aY tanaf~a$a): (O, K: [in the CK, in the place of the last word of the explanation, which is for tatanaf~a$a, is put tanofa$~a:]) and in like manner one says of a thing similar to a xiroqap. (O.) -A3- $aniEa bihi: see 10.

2 Alt~a$oniyEu * signifies takoviyru Al$~anaAEapi [app. meaning The uttering, or saying, much, or often, what is bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly: and the doing what is bad &c. much or often]: (K:) or the uttering, or saying, what is bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly, (KL, PS,) against any one: (PS:) and the representing, or regarding, as bad, &c.: (KL, PS: *) and the committing [an action that is bad, &c., or] a fault, or vitious action. (KL.) You say, $an~aEotu Ealayohi, inf. n. ta$oniyEN, (S, O,) I uttered, or said, what was bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly, against him: (PS:) from Al$~anaAEapu. (O.) And $n~E Ealayohi AlA^amora, inf. n. as above, He showed, or declared, to him that the affair was bad, evil, &c.: (TA: [see also 5:]) or characterized the affair to him as bad, evil, &c. (Msb.) -A2- And The striving, labouring, or exerting oneself, and being quick, and vigorous, or energetic, syn. Alt~a$omiyru, (S, O, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, Alt~a$ohiyru,]) and AlAinokimaA$u, and Aljid~u, (O, K,) in pace, or going; (O, * K;) as also ↓ Alt~a$an~uEu (K) [and ↓ AlA_i$onaAEu]: thus $n~E is said of a man, meaning He strove, laboured, or exerted himself, and was quick: (TA:) and in like manner $an~aEato is said of a she-camel, (As, A'Obeyd, S, O,) and of camels, (O,) as also ↓ t$n~Et, (S, * O, expl. in the former by jad~ato only,) and ↓ A$nEt; (O;) in pace, or going: (S, O:) or ↓ A$nEt said of a she-camel means she was quick, or swift. (K.)
4 A^a$onaEa see the next preceding sentence, in three places.

5 t$n~E Alqawoma *
He showed, or declared, the case of the people, or party, to be bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly, by reason of their disagreement, and the unsound, or unsettled, state of their opinion. (TA.) -A2- And t$n~E He (a man) purposed to do a bad, an evil, an abominable, a foul, or an unseemly, thing or affair. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 2, last sentence, in two places. ― -b3- Hence, (IAar, TA,) He prepared himself for fight: (IAar, K, TA:) or, said of a party of men, they prepared themselves for fight: (O:) and accord. to AA, t$n~E lil$~ar~i He prepared himself for evil, or mischief. (O, TA.) ― -b4- And It ( a garment, or piece of cloth,) became rent, or slit. (O, K.) -A3- t$n~E AlgaArapa He spread, or dispersed, the horsemen making a raid, or sudden attack, upon an enemy. (AA, S, O, K, TA.) ― -b2- And t$n~E Alfarasa He mounted the horse. (S, O, K.) ― -b3- And t$n~E Als~ilaAHa He put on the weapon, or weapons. (S, O, K.)

10 Ast$nEhu *
He reckoned it bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly. (O, TA.) And accord. to Lth, (O, TA,) one says, bihi ↓ raA^aY A^amorFA $aniEa, meaning Ast$nEhu, (O, K, TA,) i. e. [He saw a thing] which he regarded as bad, evil, &c. (TA.) ― -b2- And accord. to him, one says also, qadi A@sota$onaEa bifulaAnK jaholuhu, (O, TA,) meaning His ignorance has rendered such a one light, inconstant, or unsteady. (TA.)
$aniEN * : see $aniyEN.

$unoEapN * the subst. from $anuEa; (S, O, K;) [i. e.] Badness, evilness, abominableness, foulness, or unseemliness; syn. quboHN; (Har p. 196;) as also ↓ $unuwEN: (O, K:) thus in the saying, fiY fulaAnK ↓ $unuwEN [In such a one is unseemliness, or ugliness]; as also naZorapN and rad~N [or rather rad~apN]: (TA:) and one says also, fiY wajohihi $unoEapN and rad~apN and naZorapN [app. meaning In his face is unseemliness, or ugliness]. (IAar TA voce $ufoEapN.) ― -b2- Also Diabolical, or demoniacal possession; or madness, or insanity. (IAar, TA.)
$unuwEN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

$anaEonaEN *
Incongruous, unsound, weak, or faulty, [and therefore unseemly,] in make; (IDrd, O, K, TA;) as also Alxaloqi ↓ A^a$onaEu; applied to a man: the former is from Al$~unuwEu: and some say that it signifies tall. (TA.)
A^a$onaEu * ; and its fem. $anoEaA='u: see $aniyEN, in four places: and see also $anaEonaEN.
ma$onaEN * : see ma$onaA^N, in art. $nA^.
mu$an~aEN * ; and its fem., with p: see $aniyEN, in two places.

ma$onuwEN *
i. q. ma$ohuwrN [Well, or commonly, known; notorious; &c.]. (O, L, K.)

1 $anafotu A_ilaY Al$~aYo'i * , (S,) aor.
$anifa , (O, Msb,) inf. n. $anofN, (S, O, K,) I looked in a state of opposition, or resistance, (fiY A@EotiraADK,) at the thing; like $afanotu: (S, O: *) or Al$~anofu signifies the looking at a thing, (O,) or the looking at a thing like him who is opposing it, or resisting it, (kaAlmuEotariDi Ealayohi, K, TA,) and the raising of the eyes in looking at a thing, (TA,) like him who wonders at it, or like him who dislikes it, or hates it; (O, K, TA;) and so Al$~afonu, as AZ says. (TA.) [See also 2.] -A2- $anifa lahu, (S, O, K,) and bihi also, or, correctly, accord. to ISd, this verb is trans. in the sense here next following without any particle, (TA,) [but two exs. are cited in the O from trads. in which it is trans. by means of l,] aor.
$anafa , (S, K,) inf. n. $anafN, (S, O,) He hated him, (A^abogaDahu,) and met him in a morose manner: (S, O, K: [in the K, the latter meaning is expressed by tanak~arahu, for tanak~ara lahu: in the S and O, the former meaning is expressed as above, on the authority of ISk; and it is also said that Al$~anofu is syn. with AlbugoDu and Alt~anak~uru:] in the former of these two senses it is like $ay^ifahu, with ': (S, O:) or Al$nf [i. e. Al$~anafu] is a subst. signifying vehemence of enmity. (Ham p. 108.) ― -b2- And $anifa lahu, (IAar, ISd, O, * K, TA,) and bihi, (ISd, TA,) i. q. faTina [i. e. He knew it; knew, had knowledge, or was cognizant, of it; or knew it instinctively; &c.]. (IAar, ISd, O, K, TA.) -A3- And $anifa, (K, TA, [in the former of which it is erroneously implied that the verb is followed by lahu,]) His upper lip turned upwards; (K, TA;) inf. n. $anafN; (TA;) or this is a subst., signifying a turning upwards of the upper lip: so says AZ. (O.)

2 $an~afahaA * , inf. n. ta$oniyfN, He adorned her (i. e. a woman, S, or a girl, or young woman, O, K) with the [ornament called] $anof; (S, O, K;) like as one says, qar~aTahaA; (S, TA;) as also ↓ A^a$onafahaA. (Zj, O, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] $an~afa kalaAmahu waqar~aTahu (tropical:) [He adorned and embellished his language]. (TA.) -A2- $n~f A_ilayohi, inf. n. as above, He looked at him, or it, from the outer corner of the eye. (Yaakoob, TA.) [See also 1.]
4 A^a$onafa see the next preceding paragraph.

5 t$n~ft *
She adorned herself with the [ornament called] $anof; (S, O, K;) like as one says, tqr~Tt. (S.)

$anofN * (incorrectly pronounced with damm, IDrd, O, K, i. e. $unofN, O, TA) The upper quroT [i. e. ear-ring or ear-drop]: (S, O, K:) or a pendant (miEolaAqN) in [or suspended from] the quwf [app. meaning the upper part, or perhaps, the helix, in the CK erroneously written fawoq,] of the ear; (Lth, O, K;) and likewise such as is attached to necklaces: (Lth, O:) or such as is suspended from the upper part of the ear; what is suspended from the lower part [or lobe] thereof being termed quroTN; (IDrd, O, K;) or this latter is termed ruEovapN: (IAar, TA:) or, as some say, i. q. quroTN: (TA:) pl. [of mult.] $unuwfN (IDrd, S, O, K) and [of pauc.] A^a$onaAfN. (TA.)

$anifN *
Hating, (S, O, K,) and meeting in a morose manner. (K.) IB cites, as an ex.,
walano tudaAwiY Eil~apa Alqalobi Al$~anifo
[And thou will not cure the hating heart]. (TA.)
$afapN $anofaA='u * [A lip, meaning an upper lip] turning upwards: (O:) or $aApN $anofaA='u [A sheep or goat] having the upper lip turning upwards. (TA.)

$aAnifN *
Turning away, or averse. (O, K.) One says, maA liY A^araAka $aAnifFA Ean~iY What ails me that I see thee turning away, or averse, from me? (O.) ― -b2- And A_in~ahu la$aAnifN Ean~aA biA^anofihi (tropical:) Verily he is raising his nose [in aversion] from us. (O, * K.)
ma$onuwfapN * (assumed tropical:) A she-camel having a zimaAm [or noserein] attached to her. (AA, O, K.)

1 $anaqa AlbaEiyra * , aor.
$anuqa (S, M, Msb, K) and
$aniqa , (M, K,) inf. n. $anoqN, (S, M, Msb,) He curbed the camel by means of his zimaAm [or nose-rein], (S, K,) or pulled the xiTaAm [or halter, or leadingrope,] of the camel, (M,) while riding him, (S, M,) in the direction of his [own] head, (M,) so as to make the prominences behind his [the camel's] ears cleave to the upright piece of wood rising from the fore part of the saddle: (M, K:) or he raised the camel's head (M, Msb, K) by pulling his zimaAm, (M, Msb,) while riding him, (Msb, K,) like as the rider of the horse does with his horse: (Msb:) and ↓ A$nqhu signifies the same: (S, M, Msb, K:) or ↓ A$nq is intrans.; you say, $anaqa AlbaEiyra and huwa ↓ A$nq, the reverse of the usual rule; (IJ, M;) or the latter is intrans. also; (S, Msb, K;) signifying he (the camel) raised his head. (S, M, Msb, K. *) ― -b2- Hence, $anaqotuhaA, occurring in a trad., referring to a female hare, inf. n. as above, means, as implying restraint, I cast, or shot, at her, or I struck her, so as to render her incapable of motion. (O.) ― -b3- And $anaqa AlbaEiyra, or Aln~aAqapa, (M, K,) inf. n. as above, (M,) He bound the he-camel, or the she-camel, with the $inaAq [q. v.]. (M, K.) ― -b4- And $anaqa raA^osa Ald~aAb~api, (M,) or raA^osa Alfarasi, (K,) (tropical:) He bound (M, K) the head of the beast, (M,) or the head of the horse, (K,) to the upper part of a tree, (M,) or to the head of a tree, or to a tree, (accord. to different copies of the K,) or to a peg, (M,) or to an elevated peg, (K,) so that his neck became extended and erect. (M, TA.) ― -b5- And $anaqa Alqirobapa, (IDrd, O, K,) aor.
$anuqa , (IDrd, O,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He bound the mouth of the water-skin with the bond called wikaA=', and then bound the extremity of its wikaA=' to its fore legs: (IDrd, O, K, TA: [in the CK, A^awokaA^ahA is erroneously put for A^awokaAhaA, or, as in some copies of the K, wakaAhaA:]) or he suspended it: and [in like manner] Alqirobapa ↓ A$nq, inf. n. as above, he suspended the water-skin to a peg: (TA:) or the latter signifies he put a $inaAq to the water-skin: (M:) or he bound the water-skin with a $inaAq, (S, K, TA,) i. e. a cord with which its mouth is bound. (S.) ― -b6- [Hence $anaqahu, as used in the present day, and in post-classical works, meaning (assumed tropical:) He hanged him by the neck, till he died: (see the pass. part. n., below:) whence ↓ mi$onaqapN, meaning A gallows; pl. ma$aAniqu.] ― -b7- $anaqa Alxaliy~apa, (M, K,) aor.
$anuqa , inf. n. $anoqN; (M;) and ↓ $n~qhA, (M, K,) inf. n. ta$oniyqN; (TA;) He put a piece of wood, which is called ↓ $aniyqN, (M, K,) pared for the purpose, (M,) into the hive, and with it raised a portion of the honey-comb in the width of the hive, (M, K, *) having fixed the $ynq beneath it; and sometimes two portions of the honey-comb, and three: (M: [accord. to which one says also, $anaqa fiY Alxaliy~api AlquroSayoni waAlv~alaAvapa:]) this is done only when the bees are rearing their young ones. (M, K. *) ― -b8- Accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, Al$~aYo'a ↓ A^a$onaqotu and $anaqotuhu signify the same: (TA: [in which the meaning is not expl.; but it is immediately added, app. to indicate the meaning here intended;]) El-Mutanakhkhil El-Hudhalee says, describing a bow and arrows,
$anaqotu bihaA maEaAbila murohafaAtK
i. e. I put its string into [the notches of] arrows [broad and long in the heads, made sharp or
pointed]. (O, * TA.) -A2- $aniqa, (M, K,) aor.
$anaqa ; (K;) and $anaqa, (M, K,) aor.
$aniqa ; (K;) He loved a thing, and became attached to it; (M, K, TA;) said of a man: (TA:) and $aniqa, inf. n. $anaqN, is said of a man's heart, (O, TA,) meaning as above: (O:) or $anaqN signifies the heart's yearning towards, or longing for, or desiring, a thing. (Msb.) -A3- $anaqN also signifies The being long: (M:) or the being long in the head, (JK, S, TA,) as though it were stretched upwards: (TA:) one says of a horse, $aniqa inf. n. $anaqN, meaning He was long in the head. (JK.) ― -b2- $anaqu AlmaroA^api, signifies AisotinaAnuhaA mina Al$~aHomi [app. meaning The woman's becoming sleek, like masaAn~ (or whetstones) by reason of fat: see Aisotan~ati AlfiSaAlu, in art. sn]: and the epithet applied to her is ↓ $aniqapN, pl. $aniqaAtN. (JK, Ibn-' Abbád, O, TA.)

2 $n~q Alxaliy~apa * , inf. n. ta$oniyqN: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b2- ta$oniyqN also signifies The cutting [a thing] in pieces. (O, K. [See the pass. part. n.]) ― -b3- And The adorning [a person or thing]. (K. [See 5.]) ― -b4- See also the next paragraph, near the end.

3 $Anqhu * , inf. n. mu$aAnaqapN and $inaAqN, He mixed his cattle with his [i. e. another's] cattle: (K, TA:) this is when [contributions to the poor-rate such as are termed] A^a$onaAq [pl. of $anaqN] are incumbent on a man, or two men, or three, when their cattle are separate, and one says to another, $aAniqoniY, i. e. Mix thou my cattle and thy cattle; for if they are separate, a $anaq will be obligatory, or incumbent, on each of us; and if they are mixed, the case will be light to us: so the $inaAq signifies the sharing in the $anaq or in the $anaqaAni. (L, TA.) [See also what follows in this paragraph: and see $anaqN.] One says also ↓ laA ta$aAnaquwA [for laA tata$aAnaquwA] Ye shall not put together what are separate [of cattle]; Alt~a$aAnuqu being syn. with Almu$aAnaqapu. (TA.) ― -b2- $inaAqN signifies also The taking somewhat from the $anaq: and hence the trad., laA $inaAqa: (K, TA:) this means There shall not be taken from the $anaq [any contribution to the poorrate] unless it is complete [in number]: (A' Obeyd, S, TA:) the $anaq being, of camels, such as exceed five, up to ten; and what exceed ten, up to fifteen: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) Aboo-Sa'eed Ed-Dareer says, up to nine; and up to fourteen: but this is pronounced in the L to be wrong: (TA:) [Mtr also says,] it means there shall not be taken aught of what exceed five, up to nine, for example: or, accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed Ed-Dareer, it is like the mixing; but this requires consideration: (Mgh:) Aboo-Sa'eed says that laA $inaAqa means a man shall not adjoin (↓ laA yu$oniqu [thus written here and thus expl. in the TA]) his sheep or goats, and his camels, to the sheep or goats [and the camels] of another person, in order to annul what is obligatory, or incumbent, on him, of the poor-rate: this is [for instance] in the case in which each of them has forty sheep or goats; so that it is incumbent on them to give two sheep or goats; but when one of them adjoins (A^aHaduhumaA ↓ faA_i*aA $an~aqa [thus in this instance in the TA, perhaps a mistranscription for A^a$onaqa,]) his sheep or goats to those of another, and the collector of the poorrate finds them in his [the latter's] possession, he takes from them one sheep or goat. (TA.)

4 A$nq * : see 1, in five places. ― -b2- A_i$onaAqN [as inf. n. of A^u$oniqa, from A^a$onaqa Alqirobapa expl. in the first paragraph,] also signifies The having the hand attached to the neck by means of a gul~ [q. v.]. (AA, TA.) ― -b3- See also 3, in the latter half. -A2- Accord. to IAar, (O, TA,) A$nq also signifies He took (O, K, TA) the $anaq, i. e., (O, TA,) the [fine termed] A^aro$: (O, K, TA:) or it was, or became, obligatory, or incumbent, on him to give the A^aro$; thus having two contr. meanings [assigned to it]: (K:) or it signifies also, accord. to IAar, it was, or became, obligatory on him to give what is termed a $anaq; and this is the case until his camels amount to five and twenty, when what is due of them is [a she-camed such as is termed] Aibonap maxaAD. (O.) A man of the Arabs said, min~aA mano yu$oniqu, which may mean Of us is he who gives the $unuq, i. e. cords, pl. of $inaAqN: or it may mean, who gives the $anaq, i. e. A^aro$. (O.) ― -b2- A$nq Ealayohi He exalted himself above him; domineered over him; or oppressed him. (O, K.)

5 t$n~q *
He adorned himself; or was, or became, adorned: (JK, O:) and he clad himself with garments. (JK.)
6 ta$aAonaqa see 3.

$anaqN *
What is between one fariyDap and the next fariyDap, (A'Obeyd, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) [meaning a number that is between two other numbers whereof each imposes the obligation of giving a due termed fariyDap,] of camels, and of sheep or goats, (M, TA,) in relation to the poorrate: (S, Mgh, K, TA:) so called because nothing is taken therefrom; so that it is adjoined (A^u$oniqa i. e. A^aDiyfa) to that [number] which is next to it [of the numbers below it]: (JK:) accord. to some, it is syn. with waqaSN; (Mgh, Msb;) but some say that it relates peculiarly to camels; (M, Mgh, Msb;) and waqaSN, to bulls and cows: (Mgh, Msb:) used in relation to sheep or goats, it is what is between forty and a hundred and twenty; and in like manner as to other numbers [that impose the obligation of giving a fryDp]: K, TA:) Ahmad Ibn-Hambal is related to have said that the $anaq is what is above the fryDp, absolutely; as, for instance, what is above forty sheep or goats: (TA: [I here render the word duwna “ above, ” though it also means “ below, ” because nothing is due from sheep or goats fewer than forty:]) as A'Obeyd says, it is, of camels, such as exceed five, up to ten; and what exceed ten, up to fifteen: (O, * TA: [see also 3:]) Ks states, on the authority of some one or more of the Arabs, that it is up to twenty-five; and says that it is what does pot impose the obligation of the fryDp; meaning what is between five and twenty-five: (Fr, TA:) [but it is also expl. as applied to the due itself that is to be contributed to the poorrates for certain numbers of camels: thus] Aboo- 'Amr Esh-Sheybánee says, the $anaq for five camels is a sheep or goat; for ten, two sheep or goats; for fifteen three sheep or goats; and for twenty, four sheep or goats; the term $anaqN being applied alike to the sheep or goat, and to the two sheep or goats, and to the three sheep or goats, and to the four sheep or goats; what exceeds this last being termed fariyDapN: (TA:) or, in the case of the poor-rate, the lowest $anaq (Al$~anaqu AlA^asofalu) is a sheep or goat for five camels; and the highest $anaq (Al$~anaqu AlA^aEolaY) is a binot maxaAD for five and twenty: (O, K:) the pl. of $anaqN is A^a$onaAqN (M, Msb, TA) and $inaAqN. (M.) ― -b2- Also What is above the bloodwit (maA duwna Ald~iyapi): (As, S, O, Msb, K:) the term A^a$onaAq, (S, M, Msb,) pl. of $anaqN, (M,) being applied to the fines, for wounds, that are sent with the complete bloodwit (S, M, * O, Msb) by him upon whom rests the obligation to send such; (S, O, Msb;) as though they were attached to the main, or greatest, fine: (S, M, * O:) and an addition, in the bloodwit, (M, Msb,) of five, (M,) or of six, (M, Msb,) or of seven, (Msb,) to the hundred camels [which constitute the complete bloodwit], (M, Msb, *) in order that it may be described as ample: (Msb:) [for,] as IAar and As and El-Athram say, the man of rank or quality, when he gave [the bloodwit], used to add to it five [or more] camels, to show thereby his excellence and his generosity: (TA:) a redundancy [in the case of the bloodwit]; (O, K;) one of the explanations of the term given by As: (O:) or in the case of bloodwits (diyaAt), the lowest $anaq (Al$~anaqu AlA^asofalu) is twenty camels whereof every one is a binot maxaAD; and the highest $anaq (Al$~anaqu AlA^aEolaY) is twenty camels whereof every one is a ja*aEap: (O, K:) and some say that A^a$onaAqu Ald~iyaAti means the sorts of bloodwits; the bloodwit for purely-unintentional homicide being a hundred camels, which those who are responsible for it undertake to give in fifths, consisting of twenty whereof every one is an Aibonap maxaAD, and twenty whereof every one is an Aibonap labuwn, and twenty whereof every one is an Aibon labuwn, and twenty whereof every one is a Hiq~ap, and twenty whereof every one is a ja*aEap; these also being termed A^a$onaAq. (TA.) ― -b3- It signifies also A fine, or mulct, for a wound or the like; (O, Msb, K;) as, for instance, for a burn, (O, TA,) or such as a wound on the head that lays bare the bone, (Msb, TA,) and other wounds, (Msb,) and for a tooth [knocked out], and for an eye blinded, and for an arm or a hand vitiated, or rendered unsound and motionless, or stiff; and for anything short of what requires the complete bloowit: (TA:) or, as some say, a fine for that which does not render obnoxious to retaliation; as a scratch, or laceration of the skin, and the like: (M:) pl. A^a$onaAqN. (M, Msb.) -A2- Also A burden borne on one side of a beast, equiponderant to another borne on the other side; syn. EidolN: (K, TA: [in the CK and my MS. copy of the K, AlEadolu is
erroneously put for AlEidol:]) Al$~anaqaAni signifies AlEidolaAn. (JK, Ibn-' Abbád, O, TA. *) ― -b2- And A rope, or cord. (Ibn-' Abbád, O, K.) ― -b3- And A bow-string; (O, TA;) as also ↓ $inaAqN; (O, K, * TA;) so called because it is bound to the head of the bow: (O, TA:) or, accord. to Sh, a good bow-string, i. e. strong and long. (TA.) [See what follows.] -A3- Al$~anaqu also signifies AlEamalu [The making a thing]: (K:) thus accord. to some in the saying of Ru-beh, describing a sportsman [and his bow],
saw~aY lahaA kabodaA='a tanozuw fiY Al$~anaqo
[as though meaning He prepared for it, or them, a bow such that the part whereby it was held filled the hand, springing in the making by reason of its elasticity and strength: but the word which I have written tanozuw, and which is thus in one place in the TA, and in another place in the same, where the verse is repeated, tanozuwA, is illegible in the copy of the O, and may be a mistranscription]: accord. to others, however, the last word, Al$~anaqo, here means the bow-string. (O, TA.)

$aniqN * , applied to a heart, Loving intensely, or very passionately or fondly; syn. hayomaAnu. (M, TA.) Accord. to Lth, ↓ qalobN $aniqN mi$onaAqN signifies TaAmiHN A_ilaY kul~i $aYo'K [app. meaning A heart aspiring to everything]: (O, L, TA:) in the K, qalobN $aniqN kakatifK mu$otaAqN TaAmiHN A_ilaY kul~i $aYo'K; but the right reading is qalobN $aniqN mi$onaAqN kakatifK wamiHoraAbK, and the signification as above; primarily relating to the eye. (TA.) ― -b2- Applied to a man, Cautious; or fearful. (TA.) ― -b3- $aniqapN, applied to a woman: see 1, last sentence.

$inaAqN *
A rope, or cord, with which the head of a he-camel and of a she-camel is pulled: [see 1, first sentence:] pl. [of pauc.] A^a$oniqapN and [of mult.] $unuqN. (M, TA.) ― -b2- A cord, (A' Obeyd, S, K,) or thong, (A' Obeyd, K,) with which the mouth-of a water-skin is bound, (A' Obeyd, S, Mgh, K,) and that of a leathern water-bag, and which is untied in order that the water may pour forth: (A' Obeyd, TA:) or the suspensory cord of a water-skin: and any cord by which a thing is suspended. (M.) ― -b3- See also $anaqN, in the last quarter of the paragraph. -A2- As an epithet, Tall: (ISh, S, K:) used alike as masc. and fem. (ISh, K) and dual (ISh) and pl., (ISh, K,) not dualized nor pluralized: (ISh:) applied to a man, (S, TA,) and to a woman, and to a he-camel, and to a she-camel: applied to a she-camel as meaning tall, and longnecked; as also ↓ $anoqaA='u: and to a he-camel as meaning tall and slender: (ISh, TA:) also, and ↓ ma$onuwqN, applied to a horse as meaning tall. (T, TA.) See also A^a$onaqu.

$aniyqN * One whose origin is suspected; syn. daEiY~N: a poet says,
A^anaA Ald~aAxilu AlbaAba Al~a*iY laA yaruwmuhu
daniYo'N walaA yudoEaY A_ilayohi $aniyqu
[I am he who enters the door that the ignoble seeks not, and to which one whose origin is suspected is not invited]. (S.) -A2- See also 1, latter half.

$an~iyqN * A man evil in disposition: (M, L:) or a self-conceited young man. (JK, Ibn-' Abbád, O, K.) And $an~iyqapN, like sik~iynapN, [in some copies of the K $aniyqapN, like sakiynapN,] A woman talking, or conversing, or who talks, or converses, in an amorous and enticing manner. (JK, Ibn-' Abbád, O, K.)

$iniqonaAqN * a name for A calamity or misfortune (daAhiyap): (Ibn-' Abbád, O, K: *) or, as some say, a name of The chiefs of the Jinn, or Genii: (Ibn- 'Abbád, O:) or also a certain chief of the Jinn. (K.)

A^a$onaqu *
Long; applied to a neck. (M.) And, as also ↓ ma$onuwqN, Long in the head; applied to a horse and to a camel; and so $anoqaA='u [the fem. of the former] and ↓ $inaAqN applied to the female. (M.) For the fem., see also $inaAqN. -A2- [The fem.] $anoqaA='u signifies [also] A female bird that feeds her young ones with her bill, ejecting the food into their mouths. (O, K.)
mi$onaqapN * : see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.

mu$an~aqN * Flesh-meat (Ks, S) cut in pieces: (Ks, S, K:) applied to flesh-meat, (M,) it is from the A^a$onaAq [pl. of $anaqN] of the diyap [or bloodwit]. (Ks, S, M.) ― -b2- And Dough cut into pieces, and prepared with oil of olives: (El-Umawee, S, M, K:) or dough cut into lumps, or pieces, upon the table, before it is spread out; also called farazodaqN and EajaAjiyru. (IAar, TA.)
mi$onaAqN * : see $aniqN.

ma$onuwqN * [as pass. part. n. of $anaqa means Curbed by means of his nose-rein, &c. ― -b2- And] (assumed tropical:) Hanged: one says, qutila ma$onuwqFA (assumed tropical:) He was put to death [by being] hanged. (TA.) -A2- See also $inaAqN: and A^a$onaqu.
ma$onuw~N * and ma$oniY~N: see ma$onuwo'N, in art. $nA^.
ma$oniy~apN * : see ma$oniyoy^apN, in art. $nA^.

1 $ahiba * , (S, Msb, K,) aor.
$ahaba , (Msb, K,) inf. n. $ahabN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, *) It (a thing, S) was, or became, of the colour termed $uhobap, (S, Msb, K,) i. e. of a [gray] colour in which whiteness predominated over blackness, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or in which whiteness was interrupted by blackness; (K, * TA;) as also $ahuba, aor.
$ahuba ; and ↓ A$hb~; (K;) the last, inf. n. Ai$ohibaAbN, said in the former sense of a horse; as also ↓ A$hAb~, inf. n. Ai$ohiybaAbN; (S;) and this last verb, said of the head, its whiteness predominated over its blackness; (TA;) as also ↓ A$thb. (S, TA.) -A2- $ahabahu, aor.
$ahaba , (K,) inf. n. $ahobN, (TK,) said of heat and of cold, It altered his colour; as also ↓ $h~bhu: (K:) or, accord. to A' Obeyd, (TA,) Al$~ajara ↓ $h~b, (O, TA,) inf. n. ta$ohiybN, (O,) said of cold, It altered the colour of the trees: and Aln~aAsa ↓ $h~b is likewise said of cold [as meaning It altered the colour of the men or people]. (O, TA.) ― -b2- And $ahabati Als~anapu Alqawoma The year of drought destroyed the cattle (A^amowaAl) of the people or party: (so accord. to the CK and my MS. copy of the K:) or the verb in this sense is ↓ A^a$ohabat. (So accord. to the text of the K as given in the TA.) ― -b3- [Freytag erroneously assigns to this verb, as from the K, another meaning, belonging to 4.]
2 $ah~aba see the preceding paragraph, in three places.

4 A$hb * , said of a stallion, He had offspring of the colour termed $uhobap born to him: so accord. to the K: but accord. to IM and the other lexicologists, it is said of a man, meaning the offspring of his horses were of the colour termed $uhobap: IAar says that there are not, among horses, such as are termed $uhobN [pl. of A^a$ohabu]: A' Obeyd, however, [as will be seen below,] explains $uhobap as meaning a colour of horses. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, last sentence but one.
8 A_i$otahaba and 9: see 1, first sentence.

11 A_i$ohaAob~a see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Also, said of seedproduce, (tropical:) It dried up, or became yellow, (S, A,) but with somewhat green remaining in its interstices: (S:) or was near to yielding, and became white, and dried up, but with a little greenness remaining in its interstices. (TA.) ― -b3- Accord. to the L, one says also A$hAb~t ma$aAfiruhu [app. meaning His lips became of an ashy hue]. (TA.)

$ahobN *
A mountain overspread with snow. (O, K.) -A2- And a boy, or young man, light, or active, in body, and sharp-headed. (IAar, TA voce EaDobN. [See also $ihaAbN.])
$ahabN * : see what next follows.

$uhobapN *
A [gray] colour in which whiteness predominates over blackness, (S, Msb,) or in which whiteness is interrupted by blackness; as also ↓ $ahabN; (A, K;) which latter is [properly] an inf. n., of $ahiba: (S, Msb:) or whiteness mixed with blackness: (Har p. 150:) not pure whiteness, as some have imagined it to be. (TA.) And in horses, A colour in which the main hue is interrupted by a hoariness, or by some white hairs, whether the horse be [in his general colour] kumayot or A^a$oqar or A^adoham. (A' Obeyd, TA.)

$ahabaAnN *
A kind of plant ($ajarN), resembling the vumaAm [or panic grass]; (K;) like $abahaAnN. (TA. [But see this last word.])

$ahaAbN * (AHát, S, K) and ↓ $uhaAbapN (AHát, Kr, K) Milk mixed with much water: (AHát, S:) or a mixture of which one third is milk and the rest water: (K, TA:) Az heard several of the Arabs apply the former term to milk mixed with water: so called on account of the alteration of its colour. (TA.)

$ihaAbN * , in its primary acceptation, A $uEolap [i. e. either brand or flame (app. the former, agreeably
with what follows,)] of fire: (TA:) or a $uEolap of fire gleaming or radiating: (S, K:) accord. to ISk, a firebrand; i. e. a stick in which is fire: or, accord. to AHeyth, originally, a piece of wood, or stick, in which is fire gleaming or radiating: (Az, TA:) pl. $uhubN, (S, K,) and some allow $uhobN, (TA,) and $uhobaAnN (Akh, S, K) and $ihobaAnN, (K,) which is strange, (TA,) and A^a$ohubN, (K,) which last is [a pl. of pauc., but] thought by IM to be a quasi-pl. n. (TA.) The reading bi$ihaAbi qabasK, instead of bi$ihaAbK qabasK, in the Kur [xxvii. 7], is an instance of a word prefixed to another identical therewith. (Fr. L.) ― -b2- Hence, [A shooting, or falling, star;] a star, or the like of a star, that darts down [or is hurled] by night; and particularly after a devil; as occurring in the Kur [xv. 18 and] xxxvii. 10; and in a trad.; respecting the attempt of a devil to hear, by stealth, words uttered in heaven. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] Al$~uhubu signifies The shining, or brightly-shining, stars: (K:) or the seven stars [or planets; meaning, not the Pleiades (which are called Aln~ajomu), but the Moon, Mercury, Venus, the Sun, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn: the first three of which are said by Freytag to be called SigaAru Al$~uhubi]. (TA.) ― -b4- For another meaning assigned in the K to Al$~uhubu, see Al$~uhobu, voce A^a$ohabu. ― -b5- $ihaAbN also signifies (tropical:) One who is penetrating, sharp, or energetic, in an affair; (K, TA;) as being likened to the [shooting] star. (TA.) One says, A_in~a fulaAnFA la$ihaAbu HarobK (tropical:) Verily such a man is one who is penetrating, sharp, or energetic, in war. (S, A. *) And h`w^ulaA='i $uhobaAnu Aljayo$i (tropical:) [These are the braves, or heroes, of the army]. (A.) ― -b6- Also the name of A certain devil: occurring in a trad.: hence the Prophet changed the name of a certain man [originally] thus named. (TA.)
$uhaAbapN * : see $ahaAbN.
katiybapN $ah~aAbapN * : see A^a$ohabu.
$aAhibN * : see A^a$ohabu, first sentence.
$awohabN * The hedge-hog; syn. qunofu*N. (S, K.)

A^a$ohabu *
Of the colour termed $uhobapN; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓ $aAhibN, (K,) occurring in the poetry of Hudheyl: (TA:) fem. of the former $ahobaA='u: (S, Msb, K: *) and pl. $uhobN: (O:) the former epithet is applied to a horse, (S,) [contr. to an assertion of IAar, (see 4,)] and to a he-mule, (Msb,) and $ahobaA='u to a she-mule. (Mgh, Msb.) [Golius, on the authority of Meyd, explains A^a$ohabu A^adohamu, applied to a horse, as meaning Subniger, spadiceus: and A^a$ohabu A^axoDaru as meaning lucide leviterve viridis: the correct meaning of the former seems to be of a blackish, or brownish, gray: and that of the latter, of a dark dustcoloured gray: see A^adohamu and A^axoDaru.] Al$~ahobaA='u was the name of a mare belonging to El-Kattál ElBejelee. (O, K; in the CK El-Bejlee.) Applied to a she-goat, $ahobaA='u signifies Of a white colour intermixed with black: thus applied, it is like maloHaA='u applied to a ewe. (K.) Applied to a gur~ap [or blaze on a horse's forehead], it means In which are hairs differing from the whiteness [of the blaze]. (S.) And AlA^a$aAhibu is [a pl. formed from AlA^a$ohabu as though this were a subst.] applied to the Benu-l-Mundhir, (K,) or one of the troops of En-Noamán Ibn-El-Mundhir, consisting of the sons of his paternal uncle and his maternal uncles, and their brethren; (TA;) so called because of their comeliness, (K,) or because of the whiteness of their faces. (TA.) ― -b2- Applied to ambergris, (K, TA,) (assumed tropical:) Of an excellent colour, i. e., (TA,) inclining to whiteness. (K, TA.) And applied to an iron head or blade of an arrow or of a spear &c., (tropical:) That has been filed so that its blackness has gone: (S, A, TA:) or that has been filed lightly, so that all its blackness has not gone. (AHn, TA.)
