[Hence,] katiybapN $ahobaA='u (assumed tropical:) A great troop having numerous weapons; (K;) so called because of the iron; (S;) or because of the whiteness of the weapons and iron, intermixed with blackness: or a troop of which the iron [of the weapons and armour] is white and bright: (TA:) or, as also ↓ katiybapN $ah~aAbapN, a troop upon which is [seen] the whiteness of the iron [weapons &c.]. (T, TA. [See also katiybapN maloHaA='u, voce A^amolaHu.]) And jayo$N A^a$ohabu A strong army [app. because of its numerous weapons]. (TA.) ― -b3- A^aroDN $ahobaA='u (assumed tropical:) A land in which is no verdure, by reason of the paucity of rain. (TA.) And [hence,] sanapN $ahobaA='u (tropical:) A year of drought, or sterility, white in consequence thereof, (TA,) in which is no verdure, or in which is no rain: (K, TA:) next in degree is the bayoDaA='; then, the HamoraA=', which is more severe than the bayoDaA='; (TA;) and then, the sawodaA=': (TA in art. Hmr:) or a year that is white by reason of the abundance of snow and the want of herbage: (IB, TA:) or a year of drought, or sterility; because the seedproduce dries up therein, and becomes yellow: and EaAmN A^a$ohabu signifies the same. (Har p. 150.) And A^a$ohabaAni (assumed tropical:) Two white years (EaAmaAni A^aboyaDaAni) between which is no verdure (K, TA) of herbage. (TA.) And yawomN A^a$ohabu (tropical:) A cold day: (A, K:) or a day of cold wind; thought to be so called on account of the snow and hoar frost and hail therein: (L, TA:) or a day of hoar-frost: (Az, TA:) a day of cold wind and hoar frost; and [in like manner] the night (All~ayolapu) is termed $ahobaA='u. (S.) In the following verse, cited by Sb,
fidFY libaniY *uholi boni $ayobaAna naAqatiY
A_i*aA kaAna yawomN *uw kawaAkiba A^a$ohabu
[May my she-camel be a ransom for the sons of Dhuhl Ibn-Sheybán when there is a day of difficulties, or distresses, . . .] the meaning may be A$hb [or whitish] by reason of the whiteness of the weapons, or by reason of the dust. (TA.) And Al$~uhobu [pl. of A^a$ohabu], (O,) or ↓ Al$~uhubu [pl. of $ihaAbN], (K,) [but the former, I think, is evidently the right,] (assumed tropical:) The white nights; (All~ayaAliY AlbiyDu;) [i. e. the thirteenth and fourteenth and fifteenth nights of the lunar month; so called because lighted by the moon throughout, (see art. byD;)] (O;) three nights of the month; (K, TA;) because of the alteration of their colour. (TA.) ― -b4- A^a$ohabu [or A^amorN A^a$ohabu] also signifies (assumed tropical:) A hard, or difficult, affair or case, (K, TA,) such as is disliked, or hated. (TA.) And A^a$ohabu baAzilN (assumed tropical:) A hard, or difficult, affair or case, that is beyond one's power [of accomplishment or endurance]: termed bAzl because the camel thus termed is one that has attained its utmost strength. (O, TA. [See also art. bzl.]) ― -b5- And AlA^a$ohabu signifies The lion. (O, K.) [And in the Deewán of Jereer, it is applied to The swine. (Freytag.)]

1 $ahida * , (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) aor.
$ahada ; (K;) and $ahuda, aor.
$ahuda ; (K;) also pronounced and written $ahoda, (Akh, S, K,) and $ihoda, and $ihida, accord. to a rule applying to all verbs of the measure faEila of which the medial radical letter is a faucial; (MF;) inf. n. $ahaAdapN (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb, K) and $hd; (TA;) [there written without any syll. sign, and not found by me in any other Lex.;]) He told, or gave information of, what he had witnessed, or seen or beheld with his eye: (Mgh, L, Msb:) this is the primary signification: (L:) he declared what he knew: he gave testimony, attestation, or evidence; he bore witness: (L:) he gave decisive information. (S, A, L, K.) [See also $ahaAdapN below.] You say, $ahida bika*aA, inf. n. as above, (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) He told, or gave information of, such a thing, as having witnessed it, or seen or beheld it with his eye; (Mgh, Msb;) or declared such a thing as knowing it; (L;) or gave his testimony, attestation, or evidence, respecting it; or bore witness of it, or to it; (S, A, L, K;) Einoda AlHaAkimi [in the presence of the judge]; lifulaAnK [for, or in favour of, such a one], (S, Mgh, L, K,) and EalaY fulaAnK [against, or in opposition to, such a one]. (Mgh.) And $ahida EalaY ka*aA He gave decisive information [respecting such a thing (as in the Kur xlvi. 9, and in many other instances); he testified respecting it]. (S, L. [See also another meaning of this phrase in what follows.]) [Hence,] $ahida A@ll~`hu A^an~ahu laA A_ilaAha A_il~aA huwa, in the Kur [iii. 16], means God hath given evidence that there is no deity but He: (Abu-l- 'Abbás, IAmb, Jel:) or God knoweth &c.; (Ah- mad Ibn-Yahyà, K;) and so $ahida A@ll~`hu throughout the Kur-án: (Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà:) or God saith &c.: or God hath written &c. (K.) And A^a$ohadu A^ano laA A_ilaAha A_il~aAA@ll~`hu I know, (Msb, K,) [or acknowledge,] and I declare, [or testify, that there is no deity but God:] (K:) [Fei says,] the verb is trans. in this phrase by itself [i. e. without the intervention of a prep.] because it is used in the sense of A^aEolamu. (Msb.) [And hence, kalimapu Al$~ahaAdapi means The sentence declaring that there is no deity but God and that Mohammad is God's apostle.] ― -b2- $ahida biA@ll~`hi, (Mgh, * Msb,) aor.
$ahada , inf. n. $ahaAdapN, (Mgh,) means He swore by God: (Mgh, Msb:) and A^a$ohadu bika*aA I swear by such a thing. (S, K.) A^a$ohadu biA@ll~`hi laqado kaAna ka*aA I swear by God that such a thing happened, or took place, combines the meaning of witnessing with that of swearing and that of informing at the time of
uttering these words; as though the speaker said, I swear by God that I witnessed such a thing, and now I inform of it. (Msb.) Accord. to some, when one says only A^a$ohadu, not adding biA@ll~`hi, it is an oath. (TA.) ― -b3- $ahida EalaY ka*aA, a phrase of which one meaning has been expl. above, means also He became a witness ($aAhid) of, or to, such a thing; (S, K;) he had knowledge of such a thing, and witnessed it, or saw it or beheld it with his eye: (Msb:) and $ahidahu, (Mgh, L,) inf. n. $ahaAdapN, (L,) [likewise] signifies he witnessed it; or saw, or beheld, it, or him, with his eye; (Mgh, L;) and (Mgh, L, Msb) so ↓ $Ahdhu, (A, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) inf. n. mu$aAhadapN. (S, A, L, Msb.) [Hence,] one says, minohu HaAlN jamiylapN ↓ $uwhidato [A comely, or pleasing, state, or condition, of him was witnessed]. (A.) ― -b4- And $ahidahu, (aor.
$ahada , K,) inf. n. $uhuwdN, He was, or became, present at it, or in it; (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb, * K;) namely, a place, (Mgh,) or an assembly. (Msb.) Hence the saying, (Msb,) famano $ahida minokumu A@l$~ahora faloyaSumohu, in the Kur [ii. 181], Therefore whosoever of you shall be present in the month, and stationary, not journeying, he shall fast therein (Mgh, Msb) as long as he shall remain present and stationary: (Msb:) Al$hr being here in the accus. case as an adv. n. of time. (Mgh, Msb.) [And hence,] $ahida AljumoEapa He attained to [the being present at] the jumoEap [here meaning, as in many other instances, the prayer of Friday]: (Mgh:) and $ahida AlEiyda he attained to [the being present at] the Eiyd [or festival, or the prayer thereof]. (Msb.) [Hence also,] it is said in a trad., ya$ohadu bayoEakumu AlHalifu waAll~agowu [Swearing, and unprofitable speech, attend your selling]. (TA in art. $wb: see 1 in that art.)
2 $ah~ada see 4.
3 $aAohada see 1, latter half, in two places.

4 A^a$ohadotuhu EalaY ka*aA *
I made him to be a witness ($aAhid) of, or to such a thing: (S, Mgh, L:) [and in like manner,] A^a$ohadotuhu Al$~aYo'a I made him to have knowledge of the thing, and to witness it, or see it or behold it with his eye. (Msb.) See also 10. A_i$ohaAdN in relation to criminal matters means [The causing one to take notice of a thing that threatens to occasion some injury, with a view to the prevention of such injury; as, for instance,] the saying to the owner of a house, “ This thy wall is leaning, therefore demolish it, ” or “ feared, therefore repair it. ” (Mgh.) ― -b2- A$hdhu also signifies He caused him to be present. (K.) You say, A^a$ohadaniY A_imolaAkahu He caused me to be present [at, or on the occasion of, his being put in possession]. (S.) ― -b3- A^u$ohida: see 10. -A2- A$hd [as intrans.] (assumed tropical:) Humorem tenuem e pene emisit vir propter lusum amatorium vel osculum; (S, K;) as also ↓ $h~d, (K,) inf. n. ta$ohiydN: (TA:) [from $ahodN signifying “ honey; ” for] EusayolapN is a term for ma*oYN. (S.) (assumed tropical:) He rendered his miy^ozar [or waist-wrapper] of a reddish hue and of a dark dust-colour (A^axoDar) [by the act above-mentioned]. (L.) (assumed tropical:) He (a boy) attained to puberty. (Th, TA.) And A$hdt She (a girl) menstruated: and attained to puberty. (K.)

5 Alt~a$ah~udu * in prayer is well known; (S, K;) The reciting of the form of words commencing with Alt~aHiy~aAtu lil~`hi: [see art. HY:] from the occurrence therein of the words A^a$ohadu A^ano laA A_ilaAha A_il~aA A@ll~`hu waA^a$ohadu A^an~a muHam~adFA Eaboduhu warasuwluhu. (Mgh, * TA. [See also Har p. 611.]) ― -b2- And ta$ah~ada also signifies He sought, or desired to obtain, martyrdom. (L.)

10 Ast$hdhu *
He asked him, or required him, to tell what he had witnessed, or seen or beheld with his eye; to declare what he knew; to give testimony, or evidence; to bear witness; or to give decisive information. (S, Mgh, L, Msb, K.) You say, Aisota$ohadotu fulaAnFA EalaY fulaAnK I asked, or required, [or cited, or summoned,] such a one to give his testimony, or evidence, or to bear witness, against such a one. (L.) And Aisota$ohadotu Alr~ajula EalaY A_iqoraAri Algariymi and ↓ A^a$ohadotuhu I asked, or required, [&c., and made,] the man to bear witness to, or to be witness of or to, the confession, or acknowledgment, of the debtor. (L.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Ast$hd bibayotK EalaY maEonaY kalimapK [He adduced, or urged, or cited, a verse as an evidential example of the meaning of a word]. (A phrase of frequent occurrence in the larger lexicons.) ― -b3- Ausotu$ohida (S, K) and ↓ A^u$ohida (K) He was slain a martyr in the cause of God's religion. (S, K. [See $ahiydN.])

$ahodN * : see $aAhidN, first sentence. -A2- Also, and ↓ $uhodN, (S, Msb, K,) the former of the dial. of Temeem, and the latter of the people of El-'Áliyeh, (Msb, TA,) Honey: (K:) or honey in its wax [i. e. its comb]; (S, Msb;) honey not expressed from its wax [or comb]: (TA:) pl. $ihaAdN: (S, Msb, K:) $ahodapN is a more particular term, (S, K,) the n. un., [signifying a portion thereof; and a honey-comb, or a portion of a honey-comb;] as also $uhodapN. (TA.)
$uhodN * : see the next preceding paragraph.
$uhuwdN * : see $aAhidN, in two places.

$ahiydN * is also written and pronounced $ihiydN, with kesr to the $: (K, TA:) and in like manner is every word of the measure faEiylN having a faucial letter for its, medial radical, whether an epithet, like this, or a subst., like ragiyfN and baEiyrN: ElHemdánee says, in the “ Iaráb el-Kur-án, ” that the people of El-Hijáz, and Benoo-Asad, say raHiymN and ragiyfN and baEiyrN, with fet-h to the first letter; and Keys and Rabee'ah and Temeem say raHiymN and rigiyfN and biEiyrN, with kesr to the first letter: Sub says, in the R, that Temeem pronounce every faEiyl of which the medial radical letter is hemzeh or any other faucial with kesr to the first letter: and En-Nawawee states, on the authority of Lth, that some of the Arabs do the same when the medial radical letter is not a faucial; as in kbyr and krym and jlyl and the like thereof. (TA.) [This last pronunciation obtains extensively in the present day: and so, in similar cases, does the intermediate pronunciation termed A_imaAlapu AlfatoHi, (i. e. the pronouncing fet-h like “ e ” in the English word “ bed, ”) which may be justly regarded as the best to be followed because intermediate and because sanctioned by the usage of the classical times, except in cases that are pointed out by the grammarians as presenting obstacles to the pronunciation thus termed.] ― -b2- $ahiydN is syn. with $aAhidN [in several senses, as shown below]: and its pl. is $uhadaA='u. (S, K.) See $aAhidN, in six places. ― -b3- Also Possessing much knowledge with respect to external things: xabiyrN is used in the like sense with respect to internal things; and EaliymN, in the like sense absolutely. (L.) [Hence, perhaps,] waA@doEuwA $uhadA='akumo, in the Kur ii. 21, [as though meaning And call ye to your aid those of you who possess much knowledge: or] the meaning here is, your helpers: (Bd:) or your gods whom ye worship. (Jel.) Al$~ahiydu as a name of God means The Faithful, or Trusty, in his testimony (Zj, L,) or in testimony: (K:) and (Zj, K) as some say, (Zj,) He from whose knowledge nothing is hidden; the Omniscient. (Zj, L, K.) ― -b4- Also, derived from Al$~ahaAdapu, or from Almu$aAhadapu, or from Al$~uhuwdu, [all inf. ns.,] accord. to different opinions; (TA;) and of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; (Msb, TA;) or in the sense of the measure faAEilN; (TA;) A martyr who is slain in the cause of God's religion; (S, K;) [i. e.] one who is slain by unbelievers on a field of battle; (Msb;) one who is slain fighting in the cause of God's religion: (IAth:) so called because the angels of mercy are present with him; (K;) because the angels are present at the washing of his corpse, or at the removal of his soul to Paradise: (Msb:) or because God and his angels are witnesses for him of his title to a place in Paradise: (IAmb, Mgh, * K:) or because he is one of those who shall be required to bear witness on the day of resurrection, (K, TA,) with the Prophet, (TA,) against the people of past times, (K, TA,) who charged their prophets with falsehood: (TA:) or because of his falling upon the ↓ $aAhidap, or ground: (K:) or because he is still living, and present with his Lord: (ISh, Mgh, K:) or because he witnesses. or beholds, God's world of spirits and his world of corporeal beings: (K, * TA:) [and several other reasons are assigned for this appellation:] the primary application is that expl. above: but it is also applied by the Prophet to one who dies of colic: one who is drowned: one who is burned to death: one who is killed by a building falling to ruin upon him: one who dies of pleurisy: (IAth, L:) one who dies of plague, or pestilence: a woman who dies in a state of pregnancy: (L:) and to some others: (IAth:) the pl. is $uhadaA='u. (A, Msb, K, &c.)

$ahaAdapN * [see 1:] Information of what one has witnessed, or seen or beheld with his eye: (IF, Mgh, L, Msb:) this is the primary signification: (L:) said to be a subst. from Almu$aAhadapu: (Msb:) declaration of what one knows: testimony, attestation, evidence, or witness: (L:) decisive information. (S, A, L, K.) ― -b2- An oath: pl. $ahaAdaAtN: so in the Kur xxiv. 6 [and 8]. (TA.) ― -b3- Martyrdom in the cause of God's religion.
(S, K. [See $ahiydN.]) ― -b4- Also i. q. ma$ohadN as expl. below: see the latter word. ― -b5- [And it is used in the sense of mu$aAhadN: thus,] EaAlimu Algayobi waAl$~ahaAdapi, in the Kur vi. 73 &c., means The Knower of what is unseen and of what is seen. (Jel.)

$ahiydapN *
A roasted lamb: or [the kind of food called] hariysap [q. v.]: pl. $ihaAdN. (Har. p. 609.)

[
$ah~aAdN *
Always present. (Freytag from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)]

$aAhidN * (S, Mgh, L, K) and ↓ $ahiydN (S, * Mgh, L) One who tells, or gives information of, what he has witnessed, or seen or beheld with his eye: (Mgh, L:) one who declares what he knows: (L:) one who knows, and declares what he knows: (ISd, TA:) a witness, as meaning one who gives testimony, or evidence; who bears witness: (S, * L, K: *) [one who gives decisive information: (see 1, first sentence:)] pl. of the former ↓ $ahodN, (Akh, S, K,) or [rather] this is a quasi-pl. n., (Sb, TA,) like as SaHobN is of SaAHibN, and saforN of saAfirN, (S,) but some disallow this; (TA;) and ↓ $uhuwdN [but see what is said of this in the latter half of the paragraph] and A^a$ohaAdN are also pls. of $aAhidN, (Mgh, L,) or of $ahodN: (S, K:) the pl. of ↓ $ahiydN is $uhadaA='u. (S, Mgh.) [Hence,] ↓ maEahaA saAy^iqN wa$ahiydN, in the Kur 1. 20: see art. swq. ― -b2- [Hence also] Al$~aAhidu a name of the Prophet; (K;) meaning The witness against those to whom he has been sent. (Jel in xxxiii. 44.) ― -b3- And $aAhidN An angel: (S, L, K:) or a guardian angel: (Mujáhid:) pl. A^a$ohaAdN: or this means the prophets. (TA.) ― -b4- And The tongue: (S, L, K:) from the saying, lifulaAnK $aAhidN HasanN Such a one has an elegant diction. (L.) One says also, maA lifulaAnK ruwaA='N walaA $aAhidN Such a one has neither goodliness of aspect nor tongue. (Aboo-Bekr, L.) ― -b5- [As a conventional term used in lexicology &c.,] An evidential example, generally poetical, of the form or meaning of a word or phrase: pl. $awaAhidu: the sciences that require $awaAhid being those of All~ugap and AlS~arof and Aln~aHow and AlmaEaAniY and AlbayaAn and AlbadiyE and AlEaruwD and AlqawaAfiY. (MF on the xuTobap of the K.) [One says, h`*aA $aAhidN lika*aA and EalaY ka*aA This is an evidential example of such a thing.] With respect to the classical language, absolutely, $wAhd are taken, by universal consent, from the Kur-án, and from the language [both verse and prose (Kull p. 348)] of those Arabs who lived before the period of the corruption [in any considerable degree] of the Arabic tongue: [see muwal~adN:] also, accord. to the general decision of the learned, from the Traditions of Mohammad; [which last source is excluded by some because traditions may be corrupted in language by their transmitters, and interpolated, and even forged;] and electively from the language of those Arabs who lived after the first corruption of the Arabic tongue, but before the corruption had become extensive. (Mz, 1st nwE; and MF ubi suprà. [See, again, muwal~adN.]) The classes of the poets from whose poetry $wAhd are taken are the Pagan Arabs, the Mukhadrams, the Islámees, and the Muwelleds: [see jaAhiliY~N and muxaDoramN and A_isolaAmiY~N and muwal~adN:] with respect to all the sciences above mentioned, they are taken from the poetry of the first, second, and third, classes; from that of the first and second by universal consent, and from that of the third electively: (MF ubi suprá:) but they are taken from the poetry of the fourth class with respect only to the sciences of AlmaEaAniY and AlbayaAn and AlbadiyE. (Idem, and Kull p. 348.) [The age of the earliest existing classical poems (though some older fragments and couplets and single verses have been preserved) is only about a century before the birth of Mohammad: that of the latest, about a century after his death. (See the Preface to this work.)] ― -b6- Knowing, (Msb,) and witnessing, or seeing or beholding with his eye; a witness, as meaning an eyewitness; (L, Msb;) as also ↓ $ahiydN: pl. of the former [or, as is said in the L in art. mjd, of the former or of the latter,] A^a$ohaAdN and $uhuwdN; [but see what is said of these pls. in the first sentence of this paragraph;] and of the latter $uhadaA='u. (Msb.) [See an ex. of ↓ $ahiydN in this sense in a verse cited voce rab~N.] ― -b7- [Hence, in the present day, applied to A notary, who hears and writes and attests cases to be submitted for judgment in the court of a kádee.] ― -b8- Present; a witness as meaning one personally present; (S, L, Msb, K;) as also ↓ $ahiydN: (Msb:) pl. of the former $uh~adN (S, L, K) [and A^a$ohaAdN, as above,] and ↓ $uhuwdN, (K,) or this last is used as a pl. but is originally an inf. n. (S, L.) One says, Al$~aAhidu yaraY maA laA yaraY AlgaAy^ibu, meaning The present knows what the absent knows not. (Msb.) And qawomN $uhuwdN People, or persons, present. (S, A.) And kal~amotuhu EalaY ruw^uwsi AlA^a$ohaAdi [I spoke to him before witnesses, or persons present]. (A.) ― -b9- [Hence, app., being opposed to gaAy^ibN,] A running in which a horse exerts his force unsparingly; (A, L;) as in the saying, lilofarasi gaAy^ibN wa$aAhidN The horse has a run which he reserves [for the time of need], and a run which he performs unsparingly; like the saying, lahu SawonN waba*olN: (A: [see 1 in art. b*l:]) or $aAhidN means a running that testifies the excellence of a horse, (IAar, K,) and his quality of outstripping others. (IAar, TA.) ― -b10- A star [app. when visible]; (Aboo-Eiyoob, K;) as being present and apparent in the night. (TA.) ― -b11- [Hence, accord. to some,] SalaApu Al$~aAhidi The prayer of sunset; (A, L, Msb, K;) because it is the prayer that is performed when the star becomes visible; (Sh, L;) also called SalaApu AlbaSari, because the stars are seen at the time thereof: or, accord. to some, the prayer of daybreak; (L;) [and so, accord. to some, SalaApu AlbaSari; (see art. bSr;)] as also ↓ Alma$ohuwdu; (TA;) and it is said to be so called because he who is travelling must perform it without abridging it, like him who is present at his home: Aboo-Sa'eed Ed-Dareer says that the former prayer is so called for this reason [as is also said in the A and Msb]: AM asserts that the first reason assigned above is the right one, because the prayer of daybreak, in like manner, may not be abridged, and is not thus called; but it is thus called by a poet. (L.) ― -b12- And Al$~aAhidu is a name of Friday; (Fr, K;) as also ↓ Alma$ohuwdu: or the latter is the day of resurrection: (K:) or the day of 'Arafeh: (Fr, K: [see Earafapu:]) because of the presence and congregation of people on each of those days. (TA.) ― -b13- $aAhidN also signifies Matter resembling mucus, that comes forth with the fœtus: (S, K:) pl. $uhuwdN: which latter, accord. to ISd, means the A^agoraAs [pl. of girosN, q. v.,] upon the head of a young camel at the time of its birth. (TA.) And $uhuwdN Aln~aAqapi means The marks left by the blood, or by the membrane that enclosed the fœtus, of the she-camel, in the place where she has brought forth. (S, K.) ― -b14- Also A quick, or an expeditious, thing or affair. (K.)

Al$~aAhidapu *
The earth, or ground. (K.) See $ahiydN, last sentence.

ma$ohadN *
A place where people are present or assembled; a place of assembling; an assembly; (S, L, K;) as also ↓ ma$ohadapN and ↓ ma$ohudapN (K) and ↓ $ahaAdapN: (L:) pl. ma$aAhidu. (A.) [Hence,] ma$aAhidu mak~apa The places of religious visitation, where the ceremonies of the pilgrimage &c. are performed, at Mekkeh. (L.) ― -b2- [A funeral assembly or procession. ― -b3- A place where a martyr has died or is buried. ― -b4- And The aspect, or outward appearance, of a person; like maroA^FY: see an instance voce EawodN.]

mu$ohadN *
Slain a martyr in the cause of God's religion. (K. [See also $ahiydN.])
AimoraA^apN mu$ohidN * , (S, A, K,) without p, (S,) and mu$ohidapN, (A,) A woman whose husband is present with her: (S, A, K:) opposed to AimoraA^apN mugiybapN; (S, A;) this last with p. (S.)
ma$ohadapN * and ma$ohudapN: see ma$ohadN.

majolisN ma$ohuwdN * [A place of assembling at which numerous persons are present]. (A.) And yawomN ma$ohuwdN [A day on which numerous persons are present: and particularly] a day on which the inhabitants of heaven and earth will be present. (TA.) And SalaApN ma$ohuwdapN makotuwbapN A prayer at the performance of which the angels are present, and the recompense of which, for the performer, is written, or registered. (L.) See also $aAhidN, in two places, in the last quarter of the paragraph. ― -b2- maEohuwdN wama$ohuwdN wamawoEuwdN Past and present and future; the tenses of a verb. (Kh, L in art. Ehd.)

$ahodaAnijN * , (K accord. to the TA,) with fet-h to the $ and kesr to the n, (TA,) and $aAhodaAnijN, (K accord. to the TA,) or $ahodaAnajN, (Mgh, Msb, and so in the CK, except that it is there written as though imperfectly decl.,) with fet-h to the n, (Msb,) and $aAhodaAnaj, (CK,) arabicized from [the Pers.] $aAho daAnaho, which means “ king of grains, ”
(Ibn-El-Kutbee, TA,) The seed of the qin~ab [or hemp]: (Mgh, Msb, K:) it is useful as a remedy for the quartan fever, (K,) prepared as a beverage, (TA,) and for the [kinds of leprosy called] bahaq and baraS, (K,) applied as a liniment, (TA,) and it kills what are called Hab~u AlqaroEi, (K,) which are worms in the belly, [tape-worms,] (TA,) when eaten, and also when applied to the belly externally. (K.)

1 $aharahu * , (S, A, K,) aor.
$ahara , (S, K,) inf. n. $ahorN and $uhorapN; (S;) and ↓ $h~rhu, (S, A, O, K,) inf. n. ta$ohiyrN; (S;) and ↓ A$thrhu; (S, K;) He made it apparent, conspicuous, manifest, notorious, notable, commonly known, or public: (S, O, MF:) or [it generally means] he made it apparent, &c., as bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly; he exposed it as such; or rendered it notorious in a bad sense, or infamous. (A, K.) You say, $aharotu AlHadiyva, inf. n. as above, I divulged the story, or discourse. (Msb.) And ↓ lifulaAnK faDiylapN A@$otaharahaA Aln~aAsu [Such a one has an excellent quality which the people have made commonly known]. (S.) And $aharotuhu bayona Aln~aAsi I rendered him conspicuous [or notorious or celebrated or renowned] among the people. (Msb.) And $aharotu zayodFA bika*aA and ↓ $h~rth [I rendered Zeyd conspicuous, notorious, celebrated, or renowned, for such a thing]; (Mgh, * Msb;) [but] the latter has an intensive signification: ↓ A^a$oharotuhu, with A, in the sense of $aharotuhu, has not been transmitted: (Msb:) or is not of established authority. (Mgh.) One says also, $uhira bika*aA, and ↓ Ai$otahara, [generally, but not always, in a bad sense, meaning] He was rendered, or became, notorious, or infamous, for such a thing: (A:) the latter verb being intrans. as well as trans. (TA.) And [hence one says,] ↓ Ai$otaharotu fulaAnFA meaning (tropical:) I held such a one in light, or little, estimation, or in contempt, and exposed his vices, faults, or evil qualities or actions. (A.) ― -b2- And $ahara sayofahu, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
$ahara , (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. $ahorN, (S, Msb,) He drew his sword (S, Msb, TA) from its scabbard: (TA:) or he drew his sword and raised it over the people; (A, K;) as also ↓ $h~rhu. (K.)

2 $ah~ara see above, in three places. [In modern Arabic, $h~r often signifies He paraded an offender as a public example; and it occurs in this sense in the S and TA in art. bls, &c.: the offender, in this case, is generally mounted upon an ass or a camel, and often with his face towards the animal's tail.]

3 $Ahrhu * , (K,) inf. n. mu$aAharapN (S, K) and $ihaArN, (K,) He hired him, or took him as a hired man or hireling, for [or by] the month: (Lh, K:) or he made an engagement, or a contract, with him for work or the like, by the month, or month by month: (TA:) Almu$aAharapu from Al$~ahoru is like AlmuEaAwamapu from AlEaAmu. (S, TA.)

4 A^a$ohara see 1. -A2- A^a$oharonaA, (S, Msb, * K,) inf. n. A_i$ohaArN, (Msb,) A month passed (lit. came) over us. (S, Msb, * K.) And A$hr AlS~abiY~u [The child became a month old; or] a month passed (lit. came) over the child: similar to A^aHowala, (A,) or to A^aHaAla. (Msb.) And A$hrt Ald~aAru The house became altered, or changed, and months passed over it. (TA in art. Hwl.) ― -b2- Also We remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, a month in a place. (ISk, S.) ― -b3- And We entered upon the month, i. e., the lunar month. (Th, S.) ― -b4- And A$hrt She (a woman) entered upon the month of her bringing forth. (Msb, K.)

8 A$thr *
It was, or became, apparent, conspicuous, manifest, notorious, notable, commonly known, or public: (S:) or [it generally means] it was, or became, apparent, &c., as bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly; it was, or became, exposed as such, or rendered notorious in a bad sense or infamous. (A, K.) It (a story, or discourse,) became divulged, or public. (Msb.) A$thr bika*aA: see 1. -A2- As a trans. verb: see 1 in three places.

$ahorN * The new moon, when it appears: (IF, A, Mgh, O, Msb, K:) so called because of its conspicuousness. (Mgh, Msb.) This is the original signification. (Mgh.) [See the last sentence of this paragraph.] You say, raA^ayotu Al$~ahora, meaning I saw the new moon of the month. (Mgh.) Hence it is said in a trad., SuwmuwA Al$~ahora, meaning Fast ye the first day of the lunar month. (Lh, TA.) And hence the trad., A_in~amaA Al$~ahoru tisoEN waEi$oruwna, meaning The utility of watching for the new moon is on the nine and twentieth night. (L, TA.) [Or the meaning is, that the lunar month is a period of nine and twenty nights.] ― -b2- Also The moon: or the moon when conspicuous, and near to being full. (K.) ― -b3- And [A lunar month;] a certain well-known number of days: so called because made manifest by the moon: (ISd, K:) an arabicized word; or, as some say, Arabic; (Msb;) and so called because of its being manifest: (Msb, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] A^a$ohurN (Msb, K) and [of mult.] $uhuwrN. (S, Msb, K.) The following are the modern names of the months: 1. AlmuHar~amu [to which the epithet AlHaraAmu is often added]: 2. SafarN [to which the epithet Alxayoru is often added]: 3. rabiyEN AlA^aw~alu: 4. rabiyEN AlA=xiru [or Alv~aAniY]: 5. jumaAdaY AlA^uwlaY: 6. jumaAdaY AlA=xirapu [or Alv~aAniyapu]: 7. rajabN [to which is often added the epithet AlA^aSam~u, and that of Alfarodu]: 8. $aEobaAnu [to which we often find the epithet AlmuEaZ~amu added, and sometimes that of Al$~ariyfu]: 9. ramaDaAnu [to which the epithet AlmubaAraku is appropriated]: 10. $aw~aAlN [to which the epithet Almukar~amu is frequently added]: 11. *uw AlqaEodapi: and 12. *uw AlHij~api: [see the second of the two tables in p. 1254:] and the following are the names by which they were called by the tribe of 'Ád, agreeably with the foregoing numeration: 1. muw^otamirN: 2. naAjirN: 3. xaw~aAnN: 4. buS~aAnN [q. v.]: 5. rub~aY: 6. HaniynN: 7. AlA^aSam~u: 8. EaA*ilN: 9. naAtiqN: 10. waEolN: 11. waronapu: and 12. burakN [or buraku?]. (Ibn-El-Kelbee, in TA, voce muw^otamirN. [But authors differ respecting some of these names, as will be seen in other articles.]) A^a$ohurN maEoluwmaAtN, said, in the Kur [ii. 193], to be the period of the pilgrimage, for by AlHaj~u, which immediately precedes, is meant waqotu AlHaj~i, (Mgh, Msb,) or zamaAnu AlHaj~i, (Msb,) applies to Showwál and Dhul-Kaadeh and ten days of Dhu-l-Hijjeh, (Mgh, Msb,) accord. to Aboo-Haneefeh (Mgh) and most of the learned, part of Dhu-l-Hijjeh being called a month tropically, as is often done by the Arabs in similar cases, relating to time; for ex. when they say, maA raA^ayotuhu mu*o yawomaAni, the period of separation having been a day and a part of a day: (Msb:) or [and] nine days of Dhu-l-Hijjeh with the night preceding the day of the sacrifice, accord. to Esh-Sháfi'ee: (Mgh:) or [and] all Dhu-l-Hijjeh, accord. to Málik: (Mgh, Msb:) [in these two explanations the two months next preceding being meant to be included:] or Showwál and Dhu-l- Kaadeh and Dhu-l-Hijjeh and Moharram, accord. to Aboo-'Amr Esh-Shaabee. (Msb.) ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) A learned man: (O, K:) [because of his celebrity:] pl. $uhuwrN. (O, TA.) ― -b5- [And accord. to the K, it signifies also The like of a nail-paring: but this is app. a mistake, perhaps originating from a mutilated transcript of what here follows:] a poet says, describing camels,
A^abodaA^ona mino najodK EalaY viqapK
waAl$~ahoru mivolu qulaAmapi AlZ~ufori
[They went forth from Nejd in a state of confidence, the new moon being like the nail-paring]. (O.)

$uhorapN * a subst. from AlAi$otihaAru, (Mgh,) signifying The appearance, conspicuousness, manifestness, notoriousness, notableness, or publicity, of a thing: (S, O, Msb:) or [generally] its appearance, &c., as bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly; its notoriousness in a bad sense, or infamousness. (A, K.) ― -b2- Any evil thing that exposes its author to disgrace; any disgraceful, or shameful, thing; a vice, or fault, or the like. (IAar, O, TA.) ― -b3- A dress of the most excellent or superb kind; and one of the vilest or meanest kind: both of which are forbidden. (Mgh.) ― -b4- [It is also used in the sense of ma$ohuwrN.] One says, jaEalahu $uhorapF (tropical:) [He rendered him notorious, either in a bad or in a good sense]. (A.) And SaAra $uhorapF, (K in art. dwl,) i. e. ma$ohuwrFA (assumed tropical:) [He became notorious, &c.]; said of a man. (TK in that art.)

biro*awonN $ihoriY~N *
A br*wn [or hackney] between the ramakap [or mare of mean breed] and the horse of generous breed: one says, lamo yarokabi Al$~ihoriy~apa and Al$~ahaAriYa [He did not ride hackneys of the sort above mentioned]: (A:) or $ihoriy~apN signifies baraA*iyn [or hackneys]; and its pl. is $ahaArK: (Mgh:) or a sort of baraA*iyn [or hackneys]; (Lth, O, K;) a horse of which the dam is Arabian but not the sire. (Lth, O.)
$ahiyrN * : see ma$ohuwrN. ― -b2- $ahiyrapN A woman, and a she-ass, broad (O, K) and bulky. (O.)

[
A^a$oharu *
More, and most, apparent, conspicuous, manifest, notorious, &c.; better, and best, known. ― -b2- Hence, AlA^a$oharaAni The drum and the banner. (Gol., from Meyd.)]
A^a$aAhiru * [in the CK Aa$Ahiyru] The whiteness of the narcissus. (K, TA.)
mu$ohirN * A child a month old. (O, TA.)
mu$ah~arN * : see the following paragraph.

ma$ohuwrN *
Of known place or station; (K;) well known; well spoken of; celebrated; held in repute; reputable; notable; eminent; (O, K, TA;) applied to a man; (O, TA;) as also ↓ $ahiyrN, (O, K, TA,) and [in an intensive sense] ↓ mu$ah~arN. (TA.) [And Anything apparent, conspicuous, manifest, notorious, notable, commonly known, or public: lit. rendered apparent &c. Applied to a word or phrase or meaning, Commonly known or obtaining or received; well known; or held in repute. Hence EalaY Alma$ohuwri According to common, or well-known, usage; or according to common repute.]

1 $ahaqa * , aor.
$ahaqa , (S, Msb,) inf. n. $uhuwqN, (Msb,) [said of a mountain, and of a building, &c., (see $aAhiqN,)] It rose high; or became high, or elevated, or lofty. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- $ahaqa, aor.
$ahaqa and
$ahiqa , inf. n. $ahiyqN [and ta$ohaAqN], said of an ass, [He uttered the ending of his braying, or the final sounds thereof;] (S;) [for] $ahiyqN signifies the ending, or final part, of the crying, or braying, of the ass; (S, O;) and to this the cries of the punished in Hell are likened in the Kur xi. 108; (O;) and zafiyrN signifies the “ beginning, or commencing part, thereof: ” (S:) or $hyq signifies the drawing back of the breath; and zfyr the “ emitting thereof: ” (Lth, S: [but the reverse is said by Lth and in the S in art. zfr:]) and ta$ohaAqN signifies the same as $ahiyqN: (S:) or both of these words signify [absolutely] the crying, or braying, of the ass: (O, K:) Zj says that $ahiyqN as denoting one of the cries of the afflicted [in Hell] means a very high-sounding moaning: and that, accord. to some, zafiyrN [as used in the Kur ubi suprà] is similar to the beginning of the cry of the ass, termed $ahiyq; and that $ahiyqN is in the chest. (TA.) [Said of a man,] $ahaqa, aor.
$ahaqa and
$ahiqa ; and $ahiqa, aor.
$ahaqa ; inf. n. $ahiyqN and $uhaAqN (O, K) and $uhuwqN (O) and ta$ohaAqN; signify The [sound of] weeping became reiterated in his chest: (O, K:) or, as in the L, he reiterated the [sound of] weeping in his chest. (TA.) [Or] $ahaqa, aor.
$ahaqa and
$ahiqa , inf. n. $ahiyqN, signifies [or signifies also] He reiterated his breath, making his voice audible, naturally. (Msb.) One says also, $ahaqa fulaAnN $ahoqapF famaAta Such a one uttered a single cry and died. (S, TA.) ― -b3- And $ahaqato Eayonu Aln~aAZiri Ealayohi (tropical:) The eye of the looker smote him with evil influence: (O, K, TA:) or, was pleased with him, and therefore continued looking at him. (A, TA.)

$ahoqapN *
A single cry. (S, TA.) [See 1, last sentence but one.]

$uhoqapN *
Height, elevation, or loftiness. (TA.)

$aAhiqN *
High, or lofty; applied to a mountain, (S, O, Msb, K,) and to a building, &c.: (O, K:) or, applied to a mountain, high and inaccessible: (JK, TA:) pl. $awaAhiqu: (JK, Msb, TA:) you say jibaAlN $aAhiqapN and $aAhiqaAtN and $awaAhiqu. (Msb.) ― -b2- Applied to a vein [or an artery], (tropical:) Pulsing upwards: (O, K, TA:) a term of the physicians. (O, TA.) ― -b3- *uw $aAhiqK (tropical:) A man whose anger is vehement: (JK, S, A, O, L, TA:) wrongly expl. in the K by the words laA ya$otad~u gaDabuhu: (TA:) and so *uw SaAhilK. (A, TA.) And (tropical:) A stallion [camel] Excited by lust, assaulting [the she-camels], and causing a sound to be heard from his inside; as also *uw SaAhilK. (TA.)
ta$ohaAqN * an inf. n. (S, * O, K. [See 1.]) ― -b2- [And also an epithet.] One says DaHikN ta$ohaAqN [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) A loud laughing, likened to the ta$ohaAq of the ass]. (S, O.)

1 $ahila * , aor.
$ahala , (K,) inf. n. $ahalN, (S, * O, * TA,) He (a man, S, O) had that quality of the eye which is termed $uholapN [expl. below]; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ A$hl~, inf. n. Ai$ohilaAlN. (K.) [And in like manner each of these verbs is probably used as said of the eye.]
2 ta$ohiylN * is a vulgar dial. var. of tasohiylN [inf. n. of sah~ala, q. v.]. (TA.)

3 $Ahlhu * , (K,) inf. n. mu$aAhalapN, (S, O, TA,) He acted with him in an evil manner; or contended, or disputed, with him; syn. $aAr~ahu; (S, * O, * K, TA;) and laAHaAhu [which has the latter of these significations]: and opposed him, being opposed by him; syn. EaAraDahu: (TA:) he reviled him; or reviled him, being reviled by him: (K:) he exchanged bad names with him; syn. qaAraSahu: (S, * TA: [in the O, AlmuqaAraDap is put for AlmuqaAraSap:]) he bandied words with him. (S, O, TA.)
5 t$h~l * , said of the freshness, or brightness, and beauty, of the face, (maA=' Alwajoh,) It went away, or departed, (O, K, TA,) by reason of emaciation. (TA.)
9 A_i$ohal~a see 1.

$aholN *
A mixture of two colours. (ISk, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (ISk, TA,) one says, fiY fulaAnK waloEN and $aholN, (ISk, O, K, *) or fY flAn $aholN, (JK,) (assumed tropical:) In such a one is lying. (ISk, JK, O, K.) -A2- See also $aholapN.
$ahalN * [properly inf. n. of $ahila]: see $uholapN.

$aholapN * A middle-aged, intelligent woman: an epithet peculiarly applied to a woman: (S, O, K:) one says AimoraA^apN $aholapN kaholapN, but not ↓ rajulN $aholN kaholN; though IDrd mentions $aholN kaholN. (TA.) ― -b2- And An old woman. (K.)

$uholapN *
A tinge, or mixture, of zuroqap [i. e. blueness, or grayness, or a greenish hue,] in the black of the eye: (S, O:) or, as also ↓ $ahalN, [this latter mentioned above as inf. n. of $ahila, a tint] less than zaraqN, [in the CK Alz~uroq is erroneously put for Alz~araq, which is here used in the sense of Alz~uroqap,] and more beautiful than this, in the black of the eye: (K, TA:) thus in the M: (TA:) or a tinge of redness in the black of the eye, not in lines, like $ukolapN, but [consisting in] a paucity of blackness of the black of the eye, so that it is as though it inclined to redness: (K:) or a hue of the black of the eye between redness and blackness: or a lack of purity of the blackness thereof: or a redness in the black of the eye; $ukolapN being the like of a redness in the white thereof; thus expl. by A 'Obeyd; and in like manner by Es-Semmák. (TA.)
$aholaA='u * fem. of A^a$ohalu [q. v.]. (S, O, K.) -A2- Also A want; syn. HaAjapN: (S, O, K:) said by IF to be originally $akolaA='u. (O.)
$iholiyliY~N * A diroham [app. meaning a silver coin] of the measure of the breadth of the hand. (Mgh.)

A^a$ohalu * , applied to a man, (S, O,) Having that quality of the eye which is termed $uholapN: (S, O, K:) accord. to AZ, syn. with A^a$okalu: (TA: [but see this latter epithet:]) fem. $aholaA='u; (K;) which is applied as an epithet to an eye. (S, O.) ― -b2- Also A mountain, and a wolf, dust-coloured inclining to whiteness. (En-Nadr, TA.) ― -b3- And AlA^a$ohalu is the name of A certain idol. (Ibn-El-Kelbee, O, K.)

1 $ahuma * , aor.
$ahuma , (S, K,) inf. n. $ahaAmapN (S, TA) and $uhuwmapN, (TA,) He (a man) was, or became, hardy, strong, sturdy, enduring, or patient; (S;) [or] acute of mind or intellect; (S, K;) clever, ingenious, sharp, or penetrating. (K.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) He (a horse) was, or became, swift; brisk, lively, sprightly, or agile; and strong. (K, TA.) ― -b3- [And app. It was, or became, rough, harsh, or coarse: for] $ahaAmapN signifies xu$uwnapN. (Ham p. 699.) -A2- $ahamahu, (S, K,) aor.
$ahama and
$ahuma , inf. n. $ahomN and $uhuwmN, (K,) He frightened him, or made him afraid; (S, K;) namely, a man. (K.) ― -b2- And $ahama Alfarasa, aor.
$ahama , (K,) inf. n. $ahomN, (TA,) He chid the horse; (K;) or incited him to quickness. (JK, K, and Ham p. 699.)

$ahomN * , applied to a man, Hardy, strong, sturdy, enduring, or patient; (S;) acute of mind or intellect; (S, K;) clever, ingenious, sharp, or penetrating; and ↓ ma$ohuwmN signifies the same: pl. of the former $ihaAmN (K) [and app. $uhumN also: see suhumN, and see what here follows]. ― -b2- A chief whose judgment, or judicial decision, or exercise of authority, is effectual in affairs; (K, * TA;) courageous; or sharp, or vigorous and effective, in affairs which others are unable to accomplish: or, accord. to Fr, forbearing, or clement; who performs well that which is imposed upon him; whom one finds not otherwise than forbearing, or clement, and pleased, or content, with that which
is imposed upon him: and in like manner applied to other than a man: (TA:) pl. $uhuwmN (K) [and app. $uhumN]: see suhumN, with which $uhumN is syn. (TA in art. shm.) ― -b3- And, applied to a horse, (tropical:) Swift; brisk, lively, sprightly, or agile; and strong. (K, TA.) -A2- Also A stone which is placed at the entrance of a trap (maSoyadap or maSiydap in different copies of the K) for a lion, and which falls upon it when he enters: as also sahomN: (K, * TA:) the latter is the word [better] known to the leading lexicologists. (TA.)

$ahaAmN *
i. q. siEolaApN [app. meaning The kind of goblin, or demon, thus called]. (As, S, K.)

$ayohamN * The dulodul [q. v., i. e. hedge-hog; or a certain species of hedge-hog; &c.]: (K:) [see also the last sentence of this paragraph:] and, (K,) or accord. to AZ, (TA,) the male hedge-hog: (S, K, TA:) or such as has large prickles or spines, of male hedge-hogs, (K, TA,) and the like. (TA.) EalaY Zahori $ayohamK, occurring in a verse of El-Aashà, is said by AO to mean (assumed tropical:) In a state of fright, or fear. (TA.) ― -b2- $ayohamapN An old woman: (K:) or, accord. to IAar, a hedge-hog. (TA.)
ma$ohuwmN * : see $ahomN. -A2- Also Frightened, or made afraid. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And, applied to a horse, Chidden; or incited to quickness. (TA.)

$ihoniyzN *
i. q. $iyniyzN, (ADk, K,) and $uwniyzN, i. e. AlHab~apu Als~awodaA='u. (ADk, TA.)

1 $ahiyahu * and $ahaAhu : see 8. -A2- $ahaA, aor.
$ahuwa ; and $ahiYa, aor.
$ahawa ; inf. n. $ahowapN; It [food &c.] was good, sweet, pleasant, or the like. (MA. [But this, the only meaning there assigned to these two verbs, I do not find elsewhere.])

2 $ah~ayotuhu * [I made him, or caused him, to desire, to long, or to desire eagerly]. (Msb.) ― -b2- [And $h~Y It excited desire, longing, eager desire, or appetence. For ex., in art. smq in the K, yu$ah~iY is said of the sum~aAq, or berry of the sumach, meaning It excites appetence.] ― -b3- And $h~Y Al$~aYo'a He, or it, caused the thing to be desired, longed for, or desired eagerly: made it to be good, sweet, pleasant, or the like. (MA.) One says, h`*aA $aYo'N yu$ah~iY AlT~aEaAma i. e. [This is a thing that causes the food to be desired, &c.; that makes it sweet, &c.; or] that incites to desire, or eager desire, of the food. (S, TA.) ― -b4- [And accord. to an explanation of the inf. n., ta$ohiyapN, in the KL, $h~Ahu seems to signify also He said to him, I will give to thee what thou desirest, longest for, or eagerly desirest; agreeably with a rendering of the verb alone, as on the authority of that work, by Golius.]

3 $AhAhu * , (K, TA,) inf. n. mu$aAhaApN, (TA,) He was, or became, like him; he resembled him. (K, TA.) -A2- Also He jested, or joked, with him: (IAar, TA:) [and] so haA$aAhu. (K in art. h$w.) ― -b2- And accord. to IAar, it is also used in relation to the smiting action of the [evil] eye [perhaps meaning He vied with him in smiting with the evil eye: see also 4]. (TA.)

4 A$hAhu *
He gave him what he desired or eagerly desired. (K.) ― -b2- And He smote him with an [evil] eye: (K:) in this sense [said to be] formed by transposition from A^a$aAhahu. (TA.) -A2- maA A^a$ohaAhaA A_ilaY~a means that she is desired, or eagerly desired, [i. e. How great an object of desire is she to me!] as though it were from $uhiYa, though this was not said: and maA A^a$ohaAniY lahaA means that thou art desiring, or eagerly desiring, [i. e. How desirous, or eagerly desirous, am I of her!] so says Sb. (TA.)

5 t$h~Y *
He demanded with repeated desire. (K, TA.) So in the saying, (TA,) t$h~Y EalaY fulaAnK ka*aA (S, TA) [He demanded with repeated desire, of such a one, such a thing]. ― -b2- See also what next follows.

8 A$thAhu * (S, &c.) He desired it, or longed for it: (Msb:) he loved it; and desired it, or wished for it: (K:) or he desired it eagerly, or intensely: (M in art. frs: [see an ex. in a poetical citation voce far~asa:]) and ↓ $ahiyahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
$ahawa ; (Msb, K;) as also ↓ $ahaAhu, aor.
$ahuwa ; (AZ, Msb, K;) inf. n. $ahowapN (S, TA) and $aAhiyapN, which last is an inf. n. [of a rare class] like EaAqibapN; (TA;) signifies the same: (S, Msb, K:) and so does ↓ t$h~Ahu. (K.) [See what next follows.]

$ahowapN * [mentioned above as an inf. n.] is a word of well-known meaning; (S;) Desire, or longing, or yearning, of the soul for a thing; (Er-Rághib, Msb, TA;) [meaning for a thing gratifying to sense: or eager, or intense, desire; particularly for such a thing; for] it has a more intensive signification than A_iraAdapN; and the intelligent agree in opinion that it is not commendable: (M in art. frs:) [being either lawful or unlawful, it may be rendered as above: or appetite: or appetence: or lust: or carnal lust:] in the present state of existence, it is of two sorts, SaAdiqapN [i. e. true], and kaA*ibapN [i. e. false]; the former being that without which the body becomes in an unsound state, as the $ahowap [or desire &c.] for food on the occasion of hunger; and the latter being that without which the body does not become in an unsound state: and sometimes it is applied to the object of desire &c., or thing desired &c.: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and agreeably with this last explanation the first of the following pls. is used in the Kur iii. 12: (Ksh, Bd, Jel:) sometimes also it is applied to the faculty to which a thing is made an object of desire &c.: (Er-Rághib, TA:) [also, to the gratification of venereal lust; thus in the K in art. $fr; see $afirato and $afirapN:] the pl. is $ahawaAtN (Msb, TA) and A^a$ohiyapN and $uhFY; the last mentioned by AHei, and a rare instance of a pl. of the measure fuEalN from a sing. of the measure faEolapN having an infirm letter for its last radical, like juhFY pl. of jahowapN [and like qurFY pl. of qaroyapN]. (TA.) [Al$~ahowataAni means The two appetites, that of the stomach and that of the generative organ.] Al$~ahowapu Alxafiy~apu [The latent desire &c.] mentioned in a trad. is said to be any act of disobedience which one conceives in his mind, and upon which he resolves: or one's seeing a beautiful young woman, and lowering his eyes, then looking with his heart, and imaging her to his mind, and so tempting himself. (JM.) [$ahowapu AlT~iyni, lit. The longing for clay, is app. used as a general term for malacia: see Hum~aADN.]

$ahowaAnu * (S, Msb, K, TA) and ↓ $ahowaAniY~N and ↓ $ahiY~N, (K, TA,) applied to a man, Desirous, or longing; (S, * Msb, * K, * TA;) or very desirous or longing; greedy; or voracious: (TA:) fem. (of the first, Msb) $ahowaY: (Msb, K, TA:) pl. [of the first] $ahaAwaY, (K, TA,) like sakaAraY [pl. of sakoraAnu]. (TA.) [See an ex. of the pl. in a verse cited voce jarodabaAnN.] One says, rajulN $ahowaAnu lil$~aYo'i [A man desirous &c. of the thing]. (S.)
$ahowaAniY~N * : see the next preceding paragraph.

$ahiY~N *
i. q. ↓ mu$otahFY (S, Msb) [i. e. Desired, longed for, or eagerly desired:] or pleasant, delicious, or sweet: (Msb, TA:) applied to food, (S,) and to water. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A^abuw Al$~ahiY~i (assumed tropical:) The barobaT [or Persian lute]. (KL.) ― -b3- [And Golius adds, as on the authority of a gloss in a copy of the KL, (assumed tropical:) The water-melon (anguria).] -A2- See also $ahowaAnu.
$ah~aA='N * A man having much, or frequent, desire or longing or eager desire. (TA.) [See also $ahowaAnu.]
$aAhK * [act. part. n. of 1; Desiring, or longing; &c.]. (Sb, TA.) -A2- $aAhiY AlbaSari A man sharp of sight: (S, K:) formed by transposition from $aAy^ihu AlbaSari. (S.)

A^a$ohaY * [More, and most, desirable, or pleasant or delicious or sweet]. One says, huwa A^a$ohaY A_ilaY~a mino ka*aA [It is more desirable, or pleasant &c., to me, or in my estimation, than such a thing]. (Msb voce A_ilaY.) See also another ex. in a verse cited voce A_ilaY, in art. Alw.
mu$otahFY * : see $ahiY~N. ― -b2- [Used as a subst., its pl. is mu$otahayaAtN.]

1 $aA='aniY * , formed by transposition from $aA=niY, aor. ya$uwo'u and ya$iYo'u, [but the latter form of the aor. is disallowed by MF,] He preceded me, or outwent me. (K.) -A2- And He grieved me. (K.) ― -b2- And He pleased me. (K.) Thus it bears two contr. significations. (TA.) And $uw^otuhu, aor. A^a$uwow^uhu, I pleased him. (Lth, O.) ― -b3- And $uw^otu bihi I was pleased with, and rejoiced in, him, or it. (Lth, O, K.) [See also art. $A^w.]
$aA='N * , n. un. $aApN: see art. $wh.

$ay~iA=nN * , (K, TA, and L in art. tyH,) in form like the dual of say~idN [except as to the final vowel], (TA,) [erroneously written in the CK $ayoy^A`n,]
and $ay~aA=nN, like tay~iHaAnN and tay~aHaAnN [q. v.], (L in art. tyH,) [applied to a man,] Far-sighted; (K;) either in the proper sense, or metonymically applied to a man characterized by deliberation, and reflection, and looking to the results of affairs. (TA.) Each is also applied as an epithet to a horse. (L in art. tyH.) [The radical letters of this epithet are either $wA^ or $yA^; therefore it is mentioned again in art. $yA^; and another form thereof, without ', ($ay~aAn,) is mentioned in art. $wY.]

1 $aAbahu * , aor. ya$uwbuhu, (S, A, Msb,) inf. n. $awobN (S, A, Msb, K) and $iyaAbN, (K,) He mixed it; (S, A, Msb, K;) such as milk with water; (Msb;) or honey with water. (A.) [And It mingled with it: for] one says also, kaA^an~a riyqatahaA xamorN ya$uwbuhaA EasalN [As though her saliva were wine with which honey mingled]. (A.) ― -b2- [It is sometimes used in a good sense, but more frequently in a bad sense; and often means He adulterated, vitiated, or sophisticated, it.] It is said in a trad., ya$ohadu bayoEakumu AlHalifu waAll~agowu fa$uwbuwhu biAlS~adaqapi (assumed tropical:) [Swearing, and unprofitable speech, attend your selling; therefore mix ye it with alms]. (TA.) And it is said in a prov., huwa ya$uwbu wayaruwbu (assumed tropical:) He mixes, or confounds, or makes a confusion or disorder, in speech and in actions: (S, TA:) or he says right one time and wrong another time: (As, TA:) or he defends without energy: (TA:) or he is sometimes incited to motion, or action, and defends himself, but without energy, and sometimes he is motionless, and does not become excited to motion, or action; and it is not from [the words $awobN and rawobN applied to] milk: so says Aboo-Sa'eed [i. e. As]: and he says also that $aAba Eanohu waraAba means he defended him at one time, and was sluggish, or indolent, at another time: and that Enh ↓ $w~b, inf. n. ta$owiybN, means he defended him without energy: and thus this latter is expl. in the K, as is likewise $Ab Enh: also that the Arabs say, laqiytu fulaAnFA Alyawoma ya$uwbu Eano A^aSoHaAbihi, meaning I found such a one to-day defending his companions in some measure. (TA.) [See also art. rwb.] ― -b3- $Ab also signifies He acted treacherously, perfidiously, or unfaithfully: (Fr, TA:) he lied: he deceived in selling or buying: and he acted dishonestly, insincerely, or with dissimulation. (IAar, TA.) ― -b4- [See also Har p. 448; where it is implied that it signifies also He spoke truth, or was veracious.]
2 $aw~aba see the preceding paragraph.
7 A_ino$awaba see what next follows.

8 A_i$otawaba
A$tAb It was, or became, mixed; (O, K;) as also ↓ An$Ab. (K.)

$awobN * inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, A, &c.) ― -b2- [Hence,] laA $awoba walaA rawoba, occurring in a trad., means There is, or shall be, no dishonesty, insincerity, or dissimulation, nor mixing, in the selling, or buying: so says IAar: or I am irresponsible with respect to this commodity: or, as he is related to have said, thou art irresponsible for its being faulty, or defective. (TA. [See also $awobapN.]) ― -b3- And $awobN (TA) and ↓ $iyaAbN, (S, TA,) [each an inf. n. used as a subst. properly so termed,] or ↓ $iyaAbapN, (so in one copy of the S,) signify A mixture; an admixture; or a thing mixed with another thing. (S, TA.) Thus $awobFA signifies in the Kur xxxvii. 65: (TA:) or, accord. to one reading, the word there is ↓ $uwbFA, meaning a thing with which another thing is mixed. (Bd.) Al$~awobu also signifies [particularly] What is mixed [with something else], of water or of milk: (K:) one says, saqaAhu Al*~awoba biAl$~awobi He gave him to drink honey with water, or milk, mixed [therewith]: (TA:) or saqaAhu Al$~awoba biAl*~awobi He gave him to drink milk [mixed] with honey. (IDrd, TA.) And Mixed honey; as in the saying, maA EinodiY $awobN walaA rawobN I have not mixed honey nor milk such as is termed raAy^ib [q. v.]: (IAar, TA:) or [simply] honey &c.; (A, Msb, TA;) so called because they mix it with beverages; (Msb;) as in the saying, saqaAhu Al$~awoba biAlr~awobi He gave him to drink honey with clarified butter, or with milk. (A.) And Broth; as in the saying, maA Einodahu $awobN walaA rawobN He has not broth nor milk. (S, K: but in the latter, maA lahu.) And $awobN signifies also A piece of dough. (K.) ― -b4- And [the pl.] A^a$owaAbN signifies (assumed tropical:) A medley, or mixed multitude, of sundry sorts: a less particular term than A^awobaA$N, which signifies a medley, or mixed multitude, of the low, or lower, or lowest, sort: (TA, from a trad.:) accord. to El-Jawáleekee, it is an arabicized word, from the Pers. A=$uwbN. (TA in art. w$b.)
$uwbN * : see $uwbFA in the next preceding paragraph.

$awobapN *
Deceit, delusion, guile, or circumvention: (K: [see also $awobN:]) [or, app., somewhat thereof:] one says, fiY fulaAnK $awobapN [In such a one is deceit, &c.]. (TA.)

$ayobaA='u *
A virgin in the night of her devirgination: (Ibn-Abi-l-Hadeed, MF:) [either from $aAba having for its aor. ya$uwbu, signifying “ he mixed, ” or from $aAba having for its aor. ya$iybu, signifying “ he became white-headed, or hoary; ” as shown by what follows:] one says, baAtato bilayolapi $ayobaA='a, (S and A in art. $yb, and K in the present art.,) and bilayolapi Al$~ayobaA='i, (K,) She passed the night of a virgin then devirginated, (S, A, K,) and of the virgin then devirginated: (K, TA:) said of a virgin-bride when she is devirginated by the bridegroom in the night in which she has been first brought to him: (A, K, TA:) in the contr. case, when she is not devirginated, one says, baAtato bilayolapi Hur~apK: (S, TA:) and one says also, bilayolapK $ayobaA='a and bilayolapK Hur~apK: (TA in art. Hr:) Z, in the A, mentions the first phrase in art. $yb, and makes it to be tropical, as though the bride were in that night afflicted by an event so severe as to cause the locks of her hair to become white: in the L it is said that the Y in $ybA' is substituted for w, because of [the allusion of the phrase to] the mixing of the sperma genitale of the man with that of the woman; but that `$awobaA=' has not been heard instead of $ybA': ISd, in the M, mentions it in arts. $wb and $yb; observing that the Y is said to take the place of w: J, as well as Z and others, mentions it in art. $yb [q. v.]. (TA.)
$iyaAbN * and $iyaAbapN: see $awobN.

$aAy^ibapN * sing. of $awaAy^ibu meaning The whiteness [mixing] with the darkness of night. (Har p. 58.) ― -b2- The saying layosa fiyhi $aAy^ibapu mulokK may be from $aAbahu “ he mixed it; ” meaning There is not in it anything [of ownership, or right of possession,] mixed therewith, though small, or however small; like as one says, layosa fiyhi EuloqapN walaA $ubohapN; it being an instance of the measure faAEilapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN, as in Eiy$apN raADiyapN: thus the lawyers use it. (Msb.) ― -b3- $aAy^ibapN is also sing. of $awaAy^ibu meaning Uncleannesses, filths, or pollutions; or unclean, filthy, or foul, things. (S, Msb, K. *)

ma$uwbN * (S, Msb) and ma$iybN, the latter from $iyb [“ it was mixed ”], Mixed. (S, Msb.) A poet says, (namely, Suleyk Ibn-Es-Sulakeh EsSaadee, TA,)
wamaA='u quduwrK fiY AlqiSaAEi ma$iybu
i. e. [And the water of cooking-pots, in the wooden bowls,] mixed with seeds for seasoning and with sauces. (S.) ― -b2- AlfatoHapu Alma$uwbapu biAlkasorapi means [The fet-hah that is mingled with kesreh; which is] the fethah that precedes the A of A_imaAlap; as in EaAbidN and EaArifN [when they are pronounced “ 'ébidun ” and “ 'érifun ”]; for AmAlp consists in inclining [the sound of] fet-hah towards [that of] kesreh; whereby [the sound of] the A that follows it is inclined, and is not a pure A; for like as [the sound of] the fet-hah is mingled [with that of kesreh], so is [the sound of] the A [mingled with that of Y]. (L, TA.)

mu$aAwabN * , with damm [to the m], and fet-h to the w, [not with both of these vowels to the w as supposed by Freytag,] The case (gilaAf) of a flash or bottle; (K;) because it is mixed with redness and yellowness and greenness; mentioned by AHát on the authority of As: (TA:) pl. ma$aAwibu: (AHát, K:) or the pl. signifies [receptacles of the sorts called] A^asofaAT [pl. of safaTN] and Huqaq [pl. of Huq~apN] made of palm-leaves. (A.)
5 t$w~* * and ↓ A$tA* (assumed tropical:) He turbaned himself; attired himself with a turban. (AZ, T, S, L, K.) [See above.]
8 A_i$otawa*a see what next precedes.
fulaAnN Hasanu Al$~iy*api * (assumed tropical:) Such a one is goodly in his manner of turbaning. (K.)
xayoru AlA^a$aAwi*i * (assumed tropical:) The best of the creation, or of mankind, or people; syn. xayoru Alxaloqi. (K.)

mi$owa*N * (assumed tropical:) A turban; (IAar, S, Mgh, L, Msb, K;) as also ↓ mi$owaA*N: (K:) pl. of the former ma$aAwi*u; (S, Mgh, L, Msb, K;) and of the latter ma$aAwiy*u. (K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A king: (K:) a crowned king. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A lord, or chief, (K,) to whom obedience is paid. (TA.)
mi$owaA*N * : see the next preceding paragraph.

1 $aAra * , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor. ya$uwru, (Msb,) inf. n. $aworN (Msb, K) and $iyaArN and $iyaArapN and ma$aArN and ma$aArapN; (K;) and ↓ A$tAr, and ↓ A$Ar, (S, K,) and ↓ Ast$Ar; (A, K;) He gathered honey; (S, Msb;) extracted it from the small hollow [in the rock in which it had been deposited by the wild bees]; (A, K;) gathered it from its hives and from other places. (TA.) -A2- $Ar, inf. n. $aworN, He exhibited, showed, or displayed, a thing. (IAth, TA.) ― -b2- $Ar Ald~aAb~apa, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. $aworN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and $iwaArN, (K, TA,) or $awaArN; (CK;) and ↓ $w~rhA, (A, K,) inf. n. ta$owiyrN; (TA;) and ↓ A$ArhA, (Th, K,) but this last is rare; (Th, TA;) He exhibited, or displayed, the beast, for sale, (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) going to and fro with it, (S, Mgh,) or making it to run, and the like: (Msb:) he tried the beast, to know its pace, or manner of going: (A, Mgh:) he made the beast to run, that he might know its power: (TA:) he broke, or trained, the beast: or he rode it on the occasion of exhibiting, or displaying, it to its purchaser: or tried it, to see its powers: or he examined it, as though he turned it over; and in like manner, AlA^amapa the female slave. (K, TA.) [Hence] $Ar nafosahu He displayed his agility, to show his power. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b3- And $urotuhu I ornamented, or decorated, it. (TA.) -A3- $Ar He (a man) became goodly in countenance. (Fr, TA.) ― -b2- He (a horse) became fat and goodly: (S:) and so $Art said of a she-camel: (TA:) [and ↓ t$w~rt said of a woman: (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees:)] or $Art said of a she-camel, she became fat; (K;) and in like manner ↓ A$tAr and ↓ Ast$Ar said of a he-camel: (S:) and ↓ A$tArt AlA_ibilu the camels became somewhat fat: (S:) and ↓ Ast$Art they became fat and goodly: (K:) or this last signifies (tropical:) they became fat; because their owner points to such with his fingers; as though they desired to be pointed to. (A.)

2 $w~r Ald~aAb~apa * , inf. n. ta$owiyrN: see 1. ― -b2- $w~r bihi He did to him a deed of which one should be ashamed: (Yaakoob, Th, A, K:) or he made bare his pudenda: (O:) or as though he made bare his pudenda. (S.) ― -b3- And $w~rhu, (Lh, S,) and $w~r bihi, (Lh, TA,) He made him to be confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, by reason of shame; or ashamed, and confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, in consequence of a deed that he had done. (Lh, S.) ― -b4- $w~r AlquTona He turned over [or separated and loosened] the cotton by means of the mi$owaAr [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b5- See also 4, in two places.

3 $Awrhu * , (inf. n. mu$aAwarapN and $iwaArN, TA,) and ↓ Ast$Arh, both signify the same, (S, Msb,) He consulted him, or consulted with him; he debated with him in order that he might see his opinion; (Msb;) fiY AlA^amori respecting the thing or affair: (S, Mgh, * Msb: *) or ↓ the latter, (A, K,) or both, (TA,) he sought, desired, or asked, of him counsel, or advice. (A, K.) See also 6.

4 A^a$owara see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- A^a$ironiY EasalFA, (K,) or EalaY AlEasali, (Sh, Sgh, L,) Help thou me to collect honey, or the honey. (Sh, Sgh, L, K.) -A2- A$Ar Ald~aAb~apa: see 1. ― -b2- A$Ar Aln~aAra, and A$Ar bihaA, (K,) and A^a$owarahaA, or A^a$owara bihaA, (accord. to different copies of the K, the former accord. to the text of the K in the TA,) and bihaA ↓ $w~r, (K, TA,) He stirred up the fire, or made it to burn up; syn. rafaEahaA. (K.) -A3- A$Ar A_ilayohi, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_i$aArapN, (Msb,) He made a sign to him, with the hand, (S, Msb, K,) or with the head, (Msb,) or with the eye, or with the eyebrow, (K,) or with a thing serving to convey intelligence of what he would say; as when one asks another's permission to do a thing, and the latter makes a sign with his hand or with his head, meaning that he should do it or not do it; (Msb;) as also Alyh ↓ $w~r, (ISk, S, Msb, K,) inf. n. ta$owiyrN. (Msb.) ― -b2- [And He, or it, pointed to it or at it, pointed it out, or indicated it. Hence, in grammar, Aisomu A_i$aArapK A noun of indication; as *aA &c. And] A$Ar A_ilaY AlHarakapi biSawotK xafiY~K [He indicated the vowel by a somewhat obscure sound;] meaning he pronounced the vowel in the manner termed Alr~awomu. (I'Ak p. 351.) And A$Ar A_ilaY AlA_iEoraAbi fiY Alwaqofi [He indicated the caseending by the pronunciation termed Alr~awomu in pausing; as when you say A^aY~u with a slurring of the final vowel-sound to one who says to you mar~a biY rajulN]. (S voce A^aY~N.) ― -b3- A$Ar bihi He made it known. (Har p. 357.) ― -b4- A$Ar Ealayohi He made known, or notified, to him the manner of accomplishing the affair that was conducive to good, and guided him to that which was right. (Har ibid.) ― -b5- A$Ar Ealayohi bika*aA [in the CK Alyh] He counselled him, or advised him, to do such a thing; (S, * Msb;) showed him that he held it right for him to do such a thing: (Msb:) or he commanded, ordered, or enjoined, him to do such a thing. (K.)

5 t$w~r *
He had a deed done to him of which one should be ashamed. (Yaakoob, Th, A, K.) [It occurs in a saying of Yaakoob, respecting an indecent action of an Arab of the desert, app. as meaning His pudenda became exposed; (see 2;) but some disapprove it, and say that it is not genuine Arabic; as is stated in the TA.] ― -b2- He was, or became, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, by reason of shame; or ashamed, and confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, in consequence of a deed that he had done. (Lh, S.) -A2- See also 1, last sentence.

6 t$AwrwA * and ↓ Ai$otawaruwA (A, Mgh, Msb) They consulted one another, or consulted together; they debated together in order that they might see one another's opinion: (Msb:) ta$aAwurN signifies the extracting, or drawing forth, opinion; as also ↓ mu$aAwarapN and ↓ ma$owarapN and ↓ ma$uwrapN, from $aAra “ he extracted honey; ” (Bd in ii. 233;) and ↓ $uwraY signifies the same as ta$aAwurN. (Bd in xlii. 36, and Mgh.) -A2- ta$aAyarahu Aln~aAsu occurs in a trad. as meaning Ai$otaharuwhu biA_iboSaArihimo [app. The people rendered him conspicuous, or notorious, by their looking at him]. (TA. [There mentioned in the present art.; as though the Y were a substitute for w.])

8 A$tAr * : see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- And see 10. -A2- See also 1, last sentence, in two places. -A3- A$tAr *anabahu i. q. AikotaAra [He (a horse) raised his tail in running]. (Sgh, TA.) -A4- Ai$otawaruwA: see 6.

10 Ast$Ar * : see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- See also 3, in two places. ― -b3- Ast$Ar Aln~aAqapa He (a stallioncamel) smelt the she-camel and examined her, to know if she had conceived or not; (K;) as also ↓ A$tArhA. (A'Obeyd, TA.) -A2- It (a man's case or affair) became manifest. (AZ, K.) ― -b2- He put on, or clad himself with, goodly apparel. (K.) ― -b3- See also 1, last sentence, in two places.
$aArN * : see $ay~irN, in two places.

$aworN *
Honey gathered, or extracted, from its place: (K, TA:) originally an inf. n. (TA.) ― -b2- See also $uwrapN, with which it is syn. in several senses accord. to the O and some copies of the K.
$uwrN * : see $uwrapN, with which it is syn. in several senses accord. to the L and some copies of the K.
$aArapN * : see $uwrapN, in three places.
$aworapN * : see $uwrapN, in three places: -A2- and see mi$owaArapN. -A3- Also i. q. xajolapN [i. e. Confusion, or perplexity, and inability to see one's right course, by reason of shame: &c.]. (K.)

$uwrapN * , (S, IAth, O, L, K,) with damm, (IAth, L,) and ↓ $aworapN, (TA, and so in some copies of the K,) and ↓ $aArapN, (S, O, L, K,) in which the | is changed from w, (TA,) and ↓ $uwrN, (so in the L and in some copies of the K,) or ↓ $aworN, (so in other copies of the K and in the O,) and ↓ $awaArN, (S, O, K,) and ↓ $iyaArN, (O, K,) Form, or appearance; figure, person, mien, feature, or lineament; external state or condition; state with respect to apparel and the like, or garb. (S, IAth, O, L, K.) One says, ↓ fulaAnN Hasanu Al$~aArapi and Al$~uwrapi Such a one is goodly in form or appearance, &c. (TA.) And huwa rajulN Hasanu AlS~uwrapi waAl$~uwrapi He is a man goodly in respect of form and of appear-
ance, &c. (Fr. S. [See also below.]) ― -b2- Goodliness, or beauty: (IAth, L, K:) so $uwrapN is expl. by IAar: (O:) and ↓ $aworapN, with fet-h, is expl. as signifying pleasing beauty: (TA:) app. from $aworN, the “ act of exhibiting, or showing, ” a thing. (IAth, TA.) ― -b3- Clothing, or apparel: (S, O, L, K:) ↓ $aworapN, with fet-h, is said to have this signification by Th: and ↓ $aArapN is also expl. as signifying goodly, or beautiful, apparel. (TA.) ― -b4- Ornament, ornature, or finery. (K.) ― -b5- Fatness. (K.) ― -b6- And $uwrapN, with damm, and ↓ mi$owaArN, Aspect, or pleasing aspect; syn. manoZarN: and Internal, or intrinsic, state or quality; syn. maxobarN. (K, * TA.) One says, ↓ layosa lifulaAnK mi$owaArN i. e. manoZarN [Such a one has not a pleasing aspect]. (TA.) And fulaAnN Hasanu AlS~uwrapi waAl$~uwrapi Such a one is good in respect of form, and of internal state or qualities, when tried. (TA.) And ↓ fulaAnN Hasanu Almi$owaAri Such a one is good when one tries him. (As, TA.) -A2- For the first word ($uwrapN), see also mi$owaArapN. -A3- And see musota$iyrN.

$aworaY *
A certain marine plant; (K;) a sort of trees, of the trees of the shores of the sea: (Sgh, TA:) [it is, as supposed by Freytag, the plant called by Forskål (Flora Aegypt. Arab, p. 37,) sceura marina; of the class tetrandria, order monogynia; foliis lanceolatis, integris; floribus fulvis: &c.: said by him to be called in Arabic “ schura ” $wrh; and by the people of Maskat, “ germ ” qrm:] a sort of trees growing in inlets of the sea, in the midst of the water of the sea, resembling the dulob in the thickness of its stem and the whiteness of its bark, and also called quromN. (O.)
$uwraY * : see ma$owarapN, in four places; and 6.
$aworaAn * [whether with or without tenween is not shown] i. q. EuSofurN [i. e. Safflower, or bastard saffron]. (K.)

$awaArN * : see $uwrapN. -A2- Also, (ISk, S, Msb, K,) and ↓ $iwaArN, and ↓ $uwaArN, (Msb, K,) The furniture and utensils of a house or tent; (ISk, S, Msb, K;) such as are deemed goodly: (Ham p. 305, in explanation of the first:) and of a camel's saddle. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- And the first, (S, Msb, K,) and ↓ second, (Msb, K,) and ↓ third, (K,) The pudendum, or pundenda, (faroj, S, Msb,) of a woman and of a man: (S:) or a man's penis, [see also mi$owaArN,] and his testicles, and his posteriors or anus (Aisot). (K.) A^abodaY A@ll~`hu $awaArahu is a form of imprecation, (TA,) meaning May God make bare his pudenda. (S, A, TA.) -A3- riyHN $awaArN A soft, or gentle, wind: (Sgh, K:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (Sgh, TA.)
$uwaArN * : see $awaArN; each in two places.
$iwaArN * : see $awaArN; each in two places.

$iyaArN * : see $uwrapN. -A2- Also a name given by the Arabs to Saturday, (S in this art., and K in art. $yr,) in the Time of Ignorance: (TA in art. $yr:) pl. [of pauc.] A^a$oyurN and [of mult.] $uyurN and $iyrN: (Zj, K:) accord. to Zj, you may say valaAvapu $iyrK [Three Saturdays, using $iyr as a pl. of pauc.]: so in the Tekmileh. (TA.)

$ay~irN * One's consulter, or counseller with whom he consults: and one's waziyr [q. v.]: (K:) one qualified for consultation: (S, TA:) pl. $uwaraA='u. (K.) One says, fulaAnN xay~irN $ay~irN Such a one is [good,] qualified for consultation. (S, TA.) ― -b2- A man goodly in respect of $aArap [i. e. appearance, or apparel, &c.]: (Fr, S, A:) or beautiful, or good: in this or in the former sense, the fem., with p, is applied to a woman. (TA.) One says, A_in~ahu laSay~irN $ay~irN Verily he is goodly in form and in appearance or apparel &c. (Fr, S, A.) ― -b3- A man goodly in his internal, or intrinsic, states or qualities, when tried; as also ↓ $aArN: one says rajulN $ay~irN Say~irN and SaArN ↓ $aArN A man goodly in his internal, or intrinsic, states or qualities, and equally so in his outward appearance. (TA.) ― -b4- Fat: (TA:) or fat and goodly: (S, K, TA:) pl. $iyaArN, applied to horses, (S, K,) and to camels. (S.) ― -b5- qaSiydapN $ay~irapN A beautiful ode; (K;) an excellent ode. (TA.)

A^a$owaru * [More, and most, distinguished by $uwrap or $aArap, i. e., form, or appearance; &c.]. A^a$owaru EaruwsK turaY [The comeliest bride that was to be seen] is a phrase occurring in a trad. relating to Ez-Zebbà [a queen of El-Heereh, celebrated for her beauty]. (A, TA.)

ma$aArN *
A xaliy~ap [or habitation of bees, generally a hollow in a rock,] (S, K,) from which one gathers, or extracts, honey; (S;) a bee-hive; as also ↓ mu$otaArN. (KL.) See the next paragraph. [And see also mi$owaArapN.]

maA*iY~N mu$aArN *
White honey (TA) gathered, (S, TA,) or which one has been assisted to gather. (K, TA.) AA cites the following verse, (S,) of El-Kutámee, (accord. to a copy of the S,) or of 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd, (O, TA.)
wasamaAEK yaA^o*anu Al$~ayoxu lahu
waHadiyvK mivoli maA*iY~K mu$aArN
[And a singing, or a musical performance, (or, instead of And, the meaning may be Many,) to which the old man would lend ear, and a discourse like gathered white honey]: but As disapproves of this, and says that the right reading is maA*iY~i ↓ ma$aArN [white honey of a habitation of bees from which it has been extracted], the former of these words being prefixed to the latter, governing it in the gen. case, and the latter being with fet-h to the m. (S, TA.)
ma$uwrN * A thing ornamented, or decorated. (K.)
mi$owarN * , (S,) or ↓ mi$owaArN, (K,) or both, (TA,) The wooden implement with which honey is gathered: (S, K, * TA:) pl. of the former ma$aAwiru. (S.)

ma$aArapN * : see mi$owaArN. -A2- Also A rivulet, or streamlet, for irrigation; syn. saAqiyapN: (TA voce rakiybN:) or a channel of water: (TA voce dabor:) or a daborap [i. e. either a small channel of water for irrigation or a portion of ground] in land sown or for sowing: (S, K:) or a daborap [app. here meaning a portion of ground] cut off, or separated, from the adjacent parts, (muqoTaEapN,) for sowing and for planting: it may be of this art., or from Alma$orapu: (ISd, TA:) or what is surrounded by dams [or by ridges of earth] which confine, or retain, the water [for irrigation]; as also daborapN and HibosN: (R, TA:) pl. ma$aAwiru and ma$aAy^iru. (K.)
ma$uwrapN * : see the next paragraph, in four places.

ma$owarapN * and ↓ ma$uwrapN and ↓ $uwraY signify the same: (S:) the first and second are substs. from $aAwarahu, and the third is a subst. from ta$aAwaruwA: (Msb:) or the first (Lth) and second [which is written in the CK ma$owarapN] (Lth, K) and third (K) are from AlA_i$aArapu (Lth) or A^a$aAra Ealayohi: (K:) [they signify Consultation; or mutual debate in order that one may see another's opinion; or counsel, or advice: or a command, an order, or an injunction: or] the extracting, or drawing forth, opinion: (Bd, as mentioned above: see 6:) ↓ ma$uwrapN [in the CK ma$owarapN] is of the measure mafoEulapN, [originally ma$owurapN, in the CK mafoEalapN,] not mafoEuwlapN, (K, TA,) because it is an inf. n., [or rather a quasi-inf. n.,] and such a noun has not this last measure: (TA:) it is like maEuwnapN; (Msb;) and is a contraction of ma$owurapN: (Fr, TA:) and it is said also to be from $aAra Ald~aAb~apa; or, accord. to some, from $aAra AlEasala; good counsel or advice being likened to honey. (Msb.) One says, Ealayoka biA@loma$owarapi fiY A^umuwrika and ↓ biA@loma$uwrapi [Keep thou to consultation, or take counsel, in thine affairs]. (A.) And ↓ fulaAnN jay~idu Alma$uwrapi and Alma$owarapi [Such a one is good, or excellent, in consultation, or counsel]. (TA.) And ↓ A^amoruhumo $uwraY bayonahumo, like Amrhm fawoDaY bynhm, [Their affair, or case, is a thing to be determined by consultation among themselves,] i. e., none of them is to appropriate a thing to himself exclusively of others. (Msb.) It is said of 'Omar, ↓ taraka AlxilaAfapa $uwraY (A, Mgh) He left the office of Khaleefeh as a thing to be determined by consultation: for he assigned it to one of six; not particularizing for it any one of them; namely, 'Othmán and 'Alee and Talhah and Ez-Zubeyr and 'Abd-Er-Rahmán Ibn-'Owf and Saad Ibn-Abee-Wakkás. (Mgh.) And one says also, ↓ Aln~aAsu fiyhi $uwraY [The people are to determine by consultation respecting it]. (A.)

Almu$iyrapu *
The forefinger, or pointing finger. (A, K.)

vawobN mu$aw~arN *
A garment, or piece of cloth, dyed with $aworaAn, meaning EuSofur [i. e. safflower]. (K, TA.)

mi$waArN * : see mi$owarN. ― -b2- Also The string of the minodaf [q. v.]: (K, TA:) because the cotton is turned over [or separated and loosened] (yu$aw~aru i. e. yuqal~abu) by means of it. (TA.) -A2- Also A place in which beasts are exhibited, or displayed,
(S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) for sale, and in which they run. (Mgh, Msb.) Hence the saying, A_iy~aAka waAlxuTaba faA_in~ahaA mi$owaArN kaviyru AlEivaAri (tropical:) [Avoid thou orations, for they are means of display in which one often stumbles]. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- And The pace, or manner of going, of a horse: one says farasN Hasanu Almi$owaAri [A horse good in respect of pace, or manner of going]. (A.) -A3- See also $uwrapN, latter part, in three places. ― -b2- One says of camels, (K,) or of a beast, (daAb~ap, TA,) A^axa*ato mi$owaArahaA and ↓ ma$aAratahaA They, or it, became fat and goodly (K, TA) in appearance. (TA.) -A4- [It occurs in the O and K, in art. xwq, as signifying The penis of a horse: perhaps a mistranscription for $iwaAr, q. v.: I find it expl. in this sense in Johnson's Pers., Arab., and Engl. Dict.; but he may have taken it from the K.] -A5- [It is said to signify] also A portion that a beast has left remaining of its fodder: (O, K, TA:) but Kh says, “ I asked ADk, Is it ni$owaArN or mi$owaArN? and he said ni$owaArN, and asserted it to be Pers.: ” (O, TA:) it is an arabicized word, (K,) originally ni$oxuwaAr: (O, K: or, as in the CK, nu$oxwAr: [correctly ni$oxowaAro or nu$oxowaAro:]) one says, na$owarati Ald~aAb~apu ni$owaArFA. (TA.)

mi$owaArapN *
A place in which bees deposit their honey; as also ↓ $uwrapN; (K;) or, as written by Sgh, the latter word is [↓ $aworapN,] with fet-h. (TA.) [See also ma$aArN.]

mu$otaArN *
A gatherer of honey. (S, TA.) ― -b2- See also ma$aArN.

musota$iyrN *
Fat; (AA, S;) as also ↓ $uwrapN, with damm, applied to a she-camel: (K:) or the latter signifies of generous race; or excellent. (TA.) [See also $ay~irN.] ― -b2- And A stallion-camel (ElUmawee, T, S) that knows the female which has not conceived, and distinguishes her from others. (El-Umawee, T, S, K.)

1 $awisa * , (K,) aor. ya$owasu, (TA,) inf. n. $awa$N; (S, A, K, TA;) and $aAsa, aor. ya$aAsu, (Lth, K, TA,) or ya$uwsu; (Ham p. 68;) He looked from the outer angle of his eye, by reason of pride, or of anger, or rage: (S, A, K:) or, as in the M, he looked with one of his eyes, inclining his face towards the side of that eye; doing so naturally, or by reason of pride and self-conceit and anger: or he raised his head in pride: (TA:) or he made the eye small, contracting the lids, to look: and ↓ t$Aws has the first of the meanings above mentioned; (A, K;) or the last: (A:) or one says, t$Aws fiY naZarihi, meaning he looked with the look of the haughty, or proud: (TA:) or t$Aws A_ilayohi he looked at him from the outer angle of his eye, inclining his face towards the side of the eye with which he looked: (AA, S, TA: [see also 3:]) or t$Aws signifies he looked towards the sky with one of his eyes: or it means he showed, or manifested, pride and self-conceit, and haughtiness; agreeably with the general analogy of verbs of this measure: and $awasN is in the natural disposition. (TA.) ― -b2- Also He was such as is termed A^a$owas meaning bold, or daring, to engage in fight, and strong. (TA.) -A2- $awosN [inf. n. of $aAsa] in relation to the siwaAk [or toothstick] is a dial. var. of $awoSN: (IAar, K, TA:) one says, $aAsa faAhu biAls~iwaAki, like $aASahu [q. v.]. (Fr, TA.)
3 $aAwasahu * [He looked at him in the manner of him who is termed A^a$owas; like t$Aws A_ilayohi: see mu$aAwisN].
6 ta$aAowasa see the first paragraph.

A^a$owasu * , applied to a man, (S, A,) Who looks in the manner expl. above, in the first sentence of this art.: (S, A, K:) or in whose look is known anger; or rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite; and pride: (TA:) or raising his head by reason of pride: (AA, TA:) fem. $awosaA='u: (A, TA:) and pl. $uwsN. (S, A, K.) [Hence the saying,] buliYa fulaAnN bi$uwsi AlxuTuwbi (tropical:) [Such a one was tried with terrifying, or severe, calamities or afflictions]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Also Bold, or daring, to engage in fight, and strong. (TA. [See also $uw$N: and see A^a$orasu.])

mu$aAwisN * (tropical:) Water hardly to be seen, by reason of its paucity, and the depth to which it has sunk; (A, * K;) as though it looked at him who came to it in the manner of him who is termed A^a$owas (kaA^an~ahu yu$aAwisu AlwaArida). (A, TA.)
