2 $w~$ Ealayohi AlA^amora * , inf. n. ta$owiy$N, He rendered the affair, or state, or case, confused, disordered, or perplexed, to him: (El-Fárábee, S, * Msb: the inf. n., and that only, mentioned in the S in art. $y$:) or, accord. to certain of those skilled in the abstrusities and niceties of science, $w~$ is a post-classical word, and the chaste word is haw~a$a: accord. to IAmb, the leading lexicologists hold that one should only say hw~$; and Az and others say the same: (Msb:) [F also says,] ta$owiy$N is a mistake for tahowiy$N. (K.) See also $awaA$K.

5 t$w~$ Ealayohi AlA^amoru *
The affair, or state, or case, became confused, or perplexed, to him: (ElFárábee, S, Msb: mentioned in the S in art. $y$:) or this is post-classical: (Msb:) or ta$aw~u$N is a mistake for tahaw~u$N. (K.)

6 t$Aw$ Alqawomu *
The people, or company of men, became mixed, or confounded, together; syn. tahaAwa$a. (Sgh, K. *)
$aw$N * in the phrase A^aboTaAlN $uw$N i. q. $uwsN [pl. of A^a$owasu, q. v.]. (O, K.)

$awo$aA='u * and $awo$aApN, (Lth, O, K,) or the former is a mistake, (TA,) the latter said by Az to be that which he heard from the Arabs, (O, TA,) applied to a she-camel, Light, or agile: (Lth, O, K:) or, so applied, swift: (A'Obeyd, O:) and applied to a woman as an epithet of discommendation. (O.) A poet, cited by AA, applies the epithet ↓ $awaA$iy^, with hemz, by poetic license, to a naADiH [properly meaning a camel upon which water is drawn from a well]; originally from $awo$aA='u, (O,) or $awo$aApN, (TA,) meaning “ Light, ” or “ agile, ” applied to a she-camel: so says AA. (O, TA.)

bayonahumo $awaA$K * , (O, and so in the TA as from the K,) or $awaA$N, (so in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K,) Between them is disagreement, dissension, discord, or difference: (O, K:) the vulgar say ↓ ta$owiy$N. (O, TA.)
$awaA$iy^ * : see $awo$aA='u.
ma$uw$N * , (so accord. to my copy of the KL,) or mi$owa$N, (so accord. to Golius from the KL,) A small turban (dasotaAroJaho). (KL. [Comp. mi$owa*N.])
mu$aAwi$N * Water not to be seen, (K,) or hardly to be seen, (TA,) by reason of its remoteness [from the surface of the ground] or its paucity: (K:) a dial. var. of mu$aAwisN [q. v.]. (TA.)

1 $aASa * , aor. ya$uwSu (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and ya$aASu, in all its senses, (O, K,) inf. n. $awoSN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) He set up a thing with his hand: (Msb, K:) or he put it into a state of commotion: (Msb:) or it signifies also he moved it violently from its place. (IDrd, K.) ― -b2- He rubbed a thing with his hand. (IAar, K.) ― -b3- He washed (A'Obeyd, S, Mgh, Msb, K) a thing, (Msb,) or anything: (A'Obeyd:) he cleansed (AO, S, K) a thing: (AO:) as, for instance, his mouth, with the siwaAk [or toot-stick]: (S:) he rubbed and cleansed the teeth and the side of the mouth. (IAar.) You say $aASa faAhu He cleansed and washed his teeth, (Mgh,) biAls~iwaAki [with the tooth-stick]. (Msb.) And $aASa A^asonaAnahu, (A,) or faAhu, (TA,) [or app., $aASa alone, accord. to the K,] He cleansed his teeth with the siwaAk: (AA, K, TA:) or he did so by passing it across his teeth: (A, TA:) or from below upwards: (K, TA:) or by thrusting it into them, or between them: (TA:) and in like manner you say, faAhu ↓ A$AS, (TA,) inf. n. A_i$aASapN; (Fr, K, TA;) and fAh ↓ $w~S, (TA,) inf. n. ta$owiySN. (K, TA.) ― -b4- Also He chewed a siwaAk [app. to separate the fibres at the end and so make it like a brush, to prepare it for cleaning his teeth with it]. (K, * TA.)
2 $aw~aSa see 1, near the end of the paragraph.
4 A^a$owaSa see 1, near the end of the paragraph.

$awoSu Als~iwaAki *
The washings (gusaAlap) of the toothstick: or what remains from the tooth-stick when one cleans his teeth with it: each of these meanings is assigned to it in explanations of a trad.: AisotagonuwA Eani Aln~aAsi walawo bi$awoSi Als~iwaAki [Be ye independent of other men, if it be only by means of possessing the washings, &c., of the tooth-stick: i. e., as long ye possess anything]. (TA.)

1 $aATa * , aor. ya$uwTu, inf. n. $awoTN, He ran a heat,
or single run, or a run at once, to a goal, or limit. (TA.)

2 $w~T * , inf. n. ta$owiyTN, He (a man, IAar) made a long journey; his journey was, or became, long. (IAar, K.) -A2- $w~T Alfarasa: see 5. ― -b2- $w~T safiynatahu He voyaged with his ship. (TA.) -A3- Also $w~T He made a cooking-pot to boil. (El-Kilábee.) ― -b2- He cooked thoroughly flesh-meat; (Ibn- 'Abbád, Sgh, K;) as also $y~T: (Ibn-'Abbád, Sgh:) or both signify he smoked it, or made it smoky, and did not thoroughly cook it. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) It (hoar-frost, or rime,) burned (A^aHoraqa, q. v.) a plant, or herbage: (K:) and in like manner one says of medicine which is sprinkled upon a wound. (TA.) See also 4 in art. $yT, in two places.

5 t$w~T Alfarasa * , [in the CK, ↓ $aw~aTa, but as this, in the manner in which it is there mentioned, is a needless repetition, being implied, if correct, it is doubtless a mistranscription,] He continued to drive, or urge on, the horse, until he was tired, or fatigued. (K, * TA.)

$awoTN *
A heat; a single run, or a run at once, to a goal, or limit; (Mgh, Msb, K;) syn. TalaqN: (S, Msb:) pl. A^a$owaATN. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) You say, EadaA $awoTFA He ran a heat. (S.) And TaAfa baAlbayoti saboEapa A^a$owaATK He performed seven circuits round the House [of God, i. e. the Kaabeh]: (S, TA:) from the [Black] Stone to the [Black] Stone [again] is one $awoT: (S, Msb, TA:) but some of the lawyers disapprove of this application of the term A$wAT. (IF, K, TA.) ― -b2- [It is also, app., an inf. n. used as an epithet: for one says, jaA='a $awoTN mina Alxayoli: see sananN, in the latter part of the paragraph.] It is sometimes used in relation to the wind: so says Lth: and he cites the following as an instance in which the wind is meant:
wanaAziHK muEotakiri AlA^a$owaATi
[app. meaning And a wind, or many a wind, exhausting, or drying up, the waters, the blasts thereof bringing dust]. (TA.) ― -b3- And it is also [used as meaning A bout] of shooting arrows. (T and M in art. r$q.) ― -b4- Also The space of ground over which a horse runs; such as a mayodaAn, and the like; which is [said by some to be] the primary signification; [but the primary signification is said by others to be the first given above; (see Har p. 574;)] and so ↓ ta$owiyTapN. (TA.) ― -b5- Also (assumed tropical:) A scope; an object to be reached, or accomplished; syn. gaAyapN: whence the saying, Al$~awoTu baTiynN (assumed tropical:) The scope is remote: (Har p. 574:) a prov., relating to the long extent of hope. (TA.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) A place between two elevated tracts of ground, through which water and men pass, as though it were a road, extending as far as the voice of a caller can be heard, then ending, (ISh, O, K,) of such depth that it will conceal the camel and his rider, found only in plain, or soft, ground, and producing good herbage: (ISh, O:) pl. $iyaATN; (ISh, O, K;) originally $iwaATN. (ISh, O.) Z writes it with s. (TA. See sawoTN.) -A2- $awoTu baraAHK i. q. Aibonu A=waY [The jackal]: (IDrd, S, Z, O, L, K:) or some other beast. (L.) -A3- $awoTu baATilK: see sawoTu baATilK, in art. swT: accord. to IDrd, it is not of established authority. (O.)
ta$owiyTapN * : see $awoTN. ― -b2- It is also, metonymically, applied to (tropical:) The plague, or pestilence; and other destructive diseases. (TA.)

$uwaAZN * and $iwaAZN, (S, K, &c., [but in one copy of the S, I find only the former, which is the more common,]) occurring in the Kur [lv. 35], where Ibn-Ketheer read $iwaAZN, (TA,) Flame (S, Bd, Jel, K) without smoke: (S, Jel, K:) or smoke of fire: and heat of fire: (ISh, K:) and heat of the sun: (K, TA:) or a piece of fire in which is no smoke: or flame of fire: or only of fire and something mixed therewith. (L.) ― -b2- [And hence,] (tropical:) Vehemence of thirst: (K, TA:) or simply, thirst. (A, TA.) You say, jamalN bihi $wAZN (tropical:) A thirsting camel. (A, TA.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) Clamour. (K, TA.)

1 $ufotuhu * , (S, O, K,) aor. A^a$uwfuhu, (O,) inf. n. $awofN, (O, K,) I polished it; (S, O, K;) namely, a thing, (S, O,) or an ornament of gold or silver. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [Hence,] $iyfati AljaAriyapu, (S, O, K,) also written $uyofat, (thus in one of my copies of the S, in the other written $uy^ifat, and thus only,) aor. tu$aAfu, (S, O, K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) The girl, or young woman, was adorned. (S, O, K.) ― -b3- And [hence likewise,] $awofN also signifies The smearing of a camel with tar. (K.) One says, $ufo baEiyraka Smear thy camel with tar. (O.) -A2- [The inf. n.] $awafaAnN as syn. with ta$aw~ufN [but in what sense is not said] is vulgar. (TA.) ― -b2- So too is [the inf. n.] $awofN as meaning The act of seeing [and of looking]. (TA.) [$Af is much used in the present day as meaning He saw, and he looked at, a thing.]

2 $w~f AljaAriyapa * , inf. n. ta$owiyfN, He adorned the girl, or young woman. (TA.) -A2- $y~f Ald~awaA='a He made the medicament to be what is termed $iyaAf [q. v.]. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) [The Y in this verb is substituted for w.]

4 A$Af Ealayohi *
i. q. A^a$orafa [meaning He was, or became, on the brink, or verge, or at the point, of it], (S, O, K,) namely, a thing; like A^a$ofaY; (S, O;) from which it is formed by transposition. (S.) ― -b2- And A$Af He feared. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) You say, A$Af minohu He feared him, or it. (K.) -A2- See also 5, last sentence.

5 t$w~f *
He adorned himself: (K:) or t$w~ft she (a woman, IDrd, O, or a girl, or young woman, S) adorned herself. (IDrd, S, O.) One says of a woman divorced by a sentence that admits of her returning, tuta$aw~afu lizawojihaA i. e. She adorns herself for her husband, by making her face clear, and polishing her cheeks; from 1 in the first of the senses assigned to it above. (Mgh.) -A2- t$w~ft AlA^awoEaAlu The mountain-goats ascended upon the tops of the mountains, (Lth, O, Msb,) and looked down, (Lth, O,) to see the plain country and its freedom from those whom they feared, in order that they might repair to the water and the pasturage. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, t$w~f lika*aA He (a man) raised, or stretched and raised, his eyes, or sight, towards such a thing: and hence the verb became used to denote hope, or expectation, and desire, or seeking. (Msb.) And t$w~f mina Als~aToHi He stretched himself up, and looked, and overlooked, or looked down, from the house-top. (K.) One says, Aln~isaA='u yata$aw~afona mina Als~uTowHi The women look, [or look down,] stretching themselves up, from the house-tops. (S, O.) [See also 8.] And one says also, t$w~f A_ilaY Al$Yo'i, (S,) or AlY Alxayori, (O, K,) or AlY Alxabari, (CK,) He looked for [the thing, or good, or the news or tidings], (S, O, K,) &c. (TA.) ― -b3- And t$w~f Al$~aYo'u The thing rose, or became high or elevated; as also ↓ A$Af. (TA.)

8 A$tAf *
He (a man, S, O) stretched himself up, and looked: (S, O, K:) and in like manner one says of horses. (TA.) [See also 5.] ― -b2- And A$tAf Albaroqa He looked at the lightning, or at the cloud thereof, to see whither it was tending, and where it would rain; syn. $aAmahu. (S, O, K.) -A2- Also, said of a wound, It became rough, or thick; (AZ, O, K;) and so ↓ Ast$Af, thus without hemz. (TA.)
10 A_isota$owafa see what next precedes.
$awofN * The mijar~, (O, K,) i. e. a wooden implement, (O,) [meaning a harrow,] by means of which the ploughed land is made even. (O.)
$aAfapN * : see $aA^ofapN, in art. $A^f. (TA.)

$iyaAfN *
Medicaments for the eye and the like: (O, K:) from 1 in the first of the senses assigned to it above: originally $iwaAfN. (O.)
$aw~aAfN * A sharp-sighted man. (TA.)

$ay~ifapN *
A scout, or scouts, (TaliyEapN,) employed to look out for a party; (IAar, S, O, K;) as also ↓ $ay~ifaAnN. (IAar, O, K.)
$ay~ifaAnN * : see what next precedes.

ma$uwfN *
Polished: applied to a diynaAr [&c.]. (S, O, K.) 'Antarah says,
walaqado $aribotu mina AlmudaAmapi baEoda maA
rakada AlhawaAjiru baAlma$uwfi AlmuEolami
[And verily I have drunk wine, after that the vehement noon-day-heats of summer had remitted, purchased with the polished, charactered deenár]: (S, O, and EM p. 237:) he means the deenár polished by the minter thereof: (TA:) or, as some say, he means the bright, charactered, or figured, bowl. (O, TA. *) ― -b2- Also A camel smeared with tar; (O, K;) because it polishes him. (TA.) ― -b3- And (K) accord. to AA (O, TA) and A'Obeyd, (TA,) as used by Lebeed, (O, TA,) A camel in a state of excitement by lust: (O, K: *) but as some relate the verse in which it occurs, the word is with s, and means “ smelt ”
by the [other] camels because smeared with tar. (O, TA.) ― -b4- And, (K,) as some say, (O, TA,) it means [A camel] decorated with wools of various colours, and with other things. (O, K. [In the CK, Almuzay~inu is erroneously put for Almuzay~anu.])
mu$aw~afapN * like muEaZ~amapN [in measure], A woman who exposes herself to view in order that men may see her. (Aboo-'Alee, TA.)

1 $aAqaniY * , (S, Msb, K,) aor. ya$uwquniY, (S, Msb,) inf. n. $awoqN; (Msb, TA;) and ↓ $aw~aqaniY, (S, Msb, * K,) inf. n. ta$owiyqN; (TA;) It (a thing, S and Msb in relation to the former verb, or the love of a female, K, and the mention of her, and her beauty, TA, or the latter verb is said of a man, Msb,) excited my desire, or the yearning or longing of my soul. (S, Msb, * K * TA.) [Hence,] one says, $uqo $uqo fulaAnFA, meaning Render thou desirous, render thou desirous, such a one (↓ $aw~iqohu) for the ultimate abode or ultimate state of existence in the world to come (A_ilaY AlA=xirapi). (IAar, K, TA. [See also 2.]) ― -b2- And $Aq AlT~unuba A_ilaY Alwatidi, (K,) aor. ya$uwquhu, inf. n. $awoqN, (TA,) (tropical:) He tied, and made fast, the tent-rope to the tent-peg; (K, TA;) as also $Aqh having for its inf. n. $ayoqN; (TA in art. $yq;) like naATahu bihi, inf. n. nawoTN: mentioned also by Z. (TA.) ― -b3- And $Aq Alqirobapa, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He set up the water-skin, leaning it against the wall: (K, TA:) mentioned by Ibn-Buzurj. (TA.)

2 $aw~aqa see above, in two places. A poet says, (O,) a man of the tribe of Kelb, (Ham pp. 145 et seq.,)
waHan~ato naAqatiY TarabFA wa$awoqFA
A_ilaY mano biAlHaniyni tu$aw~iqiyniY
[And my she-camel uttered a yearning cry, by reason of lively emotion, and desire; whereupon I said, For whom, by the yearning cry, dost thou render me desirous?]: tu$aw~iqiyniY being for tu$aw~iqiynaniY. (O, and Ham p. 146, q. v.) Lth says that Alt~a$owiyqu in relation to reading or recitation [of the Kur-án], and [sacred] narratives, is as when one says, $aw~iqonaA yaA fulaAnu [lit. Do thou render us desirous, O such a one], meaning do thou mention [to us] Paradise and what is therein, by narratives, or reading or recitation; may-be we shall become desirous of it, and therefore work for it. (O, TA.)

4 A$Aqhu * signifies wajadahu $aAy^iqFA [app. meaning, EaA$iqFA, i. e. He found him to be an excessive, or attached, or admiring, lover]. (IAar, * TA.) ― -b2- One says also, maA A^a$owaqaniY A_ilayoka [How great is my desire, or the yearning or longing of my soul, for thee!]. (TA.)

5 t$w~q *
He was, or became, excited by desire, or yearning or longing of the soul; quasi-pass. of $aw~aqahu (S, TA) and $aAqahu. (TA.) See also 8. ― -b2- And (TA) He showed, or made a show of, (O, K, TA,) and affected, (O,) or affecting, (K, TA,) desire, or a yearning or longing of the soul. (O, K, TA.)

8 A$tAq A_ilayohi * , (MA, O, Msb, K,) and A$tAqhu, both signifying the same, (MA, O, K,) as also A_ilyh ↓ t$w~q, i. e. He was, or became, desirous of it; or affected with desire for it; (MA;) [or he yearned or longed for it in his soul; for] Ai$otiyaAqN is syn. with $awoqN, (q. v.) as expl. below. (S.)

$awoqN *
Desire, or yearning or longing of the soul, (S, O, Msb, K,) A_ilaY $aYo'K for a thing; (S, Msb;) as also ↓ Ai$otiyaAqN: (S:) [or] the motion of love: (IAar, O, K:) pl. A^a$owaAqN. (K.) One says, bar~aHa biY Al$~awoqu [Desire, &c., distressed me]: and balagato min~iY AlA^a$owaAqu [meaning in like manner Desires, &c., distressed me]. (TA.) banaAtu Al$~awoqi means (assumed tropical:) The effects of Al$wq [or desire, &c.]. (Ham p. 539.) -A2- Also inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (Msb, TA.)
$iyqN * : see what next follows.

$iyaAqN * (assumed tropical:) The thing with which a thing is extended in order to its being tied to a thing; (O, K;) like niyaATN; (S in art. $yq, O, TA;) originally. $iwaAqN: and ↓ $iyqN, originally $iwoqN, signifies the same. (TA.)

$aAy^iqN *
Exciting one's desire, or the yearning or longing of the soul of a person. (S, TA.) ― -b2- Also [a possessive epithet, meaning *uw $awoqK. And hence,] An excessive, or attached, or admiring, lover; syn. EaA$iqN; and so ↓ ma$uwqN: (Har, p. 142:) or ↓ the latter signifies one whose desire, or yearning or longing of the soul, is excited: (S, TA:) the former is sing. of $uwqN, (TA,) which is syn. with Eu$~aAqN [pl. of EaA$qNi] (IAar, O, K, TA) as well as pl. of A^a$owaqu. (K.)

$ay~iqN *
i. q. ↓ mu$otaAqN [i. e. Desirous, or yearning or longing in the soul]: (O, Msb, K:) or i. q. ma$uwqN [q. v. voce $aAy^iqN, in two places]: (JK:) originally $ayowiqN, of the measure fayoEilN. (O, TA.)
$aw~aAqN * [Very desirous; or desiring, or yearning or longing, in the soul, much]. (JK and Msb voce taw~aAqN.)

A^a$owaqu *
Tall; (IDrd, O, K;) applied to a man; but not of established authority: (IDrd, O:) pl. $uwqN. (K.)
ma$uwqN * : see $aAy^iqN, in two places. ― -b2- qirobapN ma$uwqapN (tropical:) A water-skin set up, leaned against a wall. (Ibn-Buzurj, O, K, TA.)

mu$otaAqN * : see $ay~iqN. Almu$otaA^aq (so in the S,) or Almu$otay^iq, because mu$otaAqN is originally mu$otawiqN, of the measure mufotaEilN, (O,) is used by poetic license for mu$otaAq, (S, O,) as Sb says; (S;) for the poet, requiring to make the last letter but one movent, makes it so by the original vowel. (O.)

1 $aAkatoniY Al$~awokapu * , (As, S, O, K, *) aor. ta$uwkuniY, (As, S, O,) inf. n. $awokN, (TA,) The thorn entered into [or pierced me, or] my body or person. (As, S, O, K. *) And $Akt A_iSobaEahu It (a thorn) entered into [or pierced] his finger. (TA.) And $aAkatoniY Al$~awokapu, (K,) aor. as above, (TA,) The thorn hurt me, or wounded me; syn. A^aSaAbatoniY. (K, TA.) And $aAkaniY Al$~awoku, aor. ya$uwkuniY, The thorns hurt, or wounded, (A^aSaAba,) my skin. (Msb.) [Hence,] ↓ laA ya$uwkuka min~iY $awokapN (tropical:) No harm, or hurt, shall ensue to thee from me. (TA.) ― -b2- $ukotuhu, aor. A^a$uwkuhu, [I pierced him with a thorn;] I made a thorn to enter into his body or person; (S, O, K;) as also ↓ A^a$akotuhu, (K,) inf. n. A_i$aAkapN: (TA:) the former verb from Ks; (T, S, O;) as though he made it to be doubly trans. [meaning that $awokapF is to be understood]. (Az, TA.) And $awokapF ↓ maA A^a$aAkahu [and maA $aAkahu bi$awokapK as is meant by its being added] walaA $aAkahu bihaA He did not hurt him with a thorn; (K, * TA;) as expl. by IF: (TA:) and ↓ A^a$akotuhu I hurt him with thorns: (TA:) or biAl$~awoki ↓ $aw~akotuhu and bihi ↓ A^a$akotuhu I hurt him, or wounded him, with thorns, or the thorns. (Msb.) ― -b3- Accord. to IAar, (TA,) $Ak Al$~awokapa, (K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, Al$~awokapu,]) aor. ya$aAkuhaA, (TA,) signifies xaAlaTahaA [app. meaning He pierced (lit. mixed or blended) himself with the thorn: unless $awokap be improperly used in this instance, by poetic license, as a coll. gen. n., as seems to be implied in the S and O by an explanation of a verse cited-voce naqa$a, q. v., in which case the meaning is, he entered among the thorns]. (K, TA.) ― -b4- [It is also said that] $Ak Al$~awokapa, aor. ya$aAkuhaA, inf. n. $awokN, signifies He (a man) extracted the thorn from his foot. (MA.) ― -b5- $iyka, aor. yu$aAku, inf. n. $awokN, He (a man) was, or became, pierced by a thorn. (S, O.) ― -b6- $aAka, (K,) or [first pers.] $ikotu, (S, O,) aor. ya$aAku, (K, and the like in the S and O,) inf. n. $aAkapN and $iykapN, (S, O, K,) He, (K,) or I, (S, O,) fell, or lighted, among thorns: (S, O, K: [whence, accord. to the S and O, the verse above referred to, voce naqa$a:]) and $ikotu Al$~awoka, aor. A^a$aAkuhu, I fell, or lighted, among the thorns: (K:) accord. to IB, $ikotu, aor. A^a$aAku, is originally $awikotu. (TA.) ― -b7- $Akt Al$~ajarapu, aor. ta$aAku, inf. n. $awokN; and ↓ A$Akt; (Msb;) or ↓ $aw~akat, (K, TA,) inf. n. ta$owiykN; in some of the copies of the K $awikat; (TA; [in the CK, $awakat;]) and ↓ A^a$owakat; (K;) The tree was thorny, or prickly; abounded with thorns, or prickles: (Msb, K, TA:) [and] ↓ A^a$owakat said of a palm-tree has the like signification. (S, O.) ― -b8- [Hence,] $Ak laHoyaA AlbaEiyri (assumed tropical:) The two jaws of the camel put forth his canine teeth; (S O;) as also ↓ $w~k, (S, O,) inf. n. ta$owiykN: (S:) or the phrase with the latter verb means The camel's canine teeth became long. (K.) ― -b9- And $Ak vadoYu AljaAriyapi (assumed tropical:) The breast of the girl was ready to swell, or become protuberant or prominent; as also ↓ $w~k, inf. n. ta$owiykN; (S;) and, accord. to Z, $awika, like
fariHa: (TA:) or vadoyuhaA ↓ $w~k signifies (tropical:) her breast became pointed in its extremity, (IDrd, O, K, TA,) and its protrusion appeared. (IDrd, O, TA.) ― -b10- $Ak Alr~ajulu, aor. ya$aAk, inf. n. $awokN, (tropical:) The man exhibited his $awokap [i. e. vehemence of might or strength, or of valour or prowess, &c.], and his sharpness. (S, O, Msb, K, TA.) [And The man was completely armed; (as though meaning he bristled with arms;) for] the inf. n. $awokN signifies a man's being completely armed. (KL.) ― -b11- And $iyka (tropical:) He was, or became, affected with the disease termed $awokap [q. v.]. (K, TA.)

2 $aw~akotuhu biAl$~awoki * : see 1, former half. ― -b2- $w~k AlHaAy^iTa, (S, K,) inf. n. ta$owiykN, (TA,) He put thorns upon the wall. (S, K.) ― -b3- See also 1, latter half, in four places. ― -b4- $w~k Alz~aroEu (tropical:) The seed-produce, or corn, became white, before its spreading: (K:) or came forth [pointed,] without forking, or shooting forth into separate stalks, (Had~ada,) and became white, before its spreading; as also ↓ A^a$owaka: (TA:) [or began to come forth: see mu$aw~ikN.] ― -b5- $w~k naAbu AlbaEiyri (assumed tropical:) [The canine tooth of the camel grew forth]. (TA.) ― -b6- $w~k riy$u Alfaroxi, (IDrd, O,) and $aAribu AlgulaAmi, (IDrd, O, K,) (tropical:) The feathers of the young bird, (IDrd, O,) and the mustache of the young man, became rough to the feel. (IDrd, O, K, TA.) And $w~k Alfaroxu (assumed tropical:) The young bird put forth the heads of its feathers: (S, * K, TA:) in [some of the copies of] the S and A, $w~k Alfaroju, thus with j, expl. by A^anobata. (TA.) And $w~k Alr~aA^osu baEoda AlHaloqi (tropical:) The head put forth its hair after the shaving. (S, K, TA.)
4 A^a$owaka as a trans. verb: see 1, former half, in four places: ― -b2- as intrans.: see 1, latter half, in three places: and see also 2.
5 ta$aw~ukN * The having thorns; expl. by baA xaArN $udano. (KL.)
$aAkN * ; and its fem., with p: see $aAy^ikN, in four places.

$awokN * , (S, Msb, K, &c.,) of a tree, (Msb,) or of a plant, (TA,) Thorns, prickles, or spines; (PS, TK;) the kind of thing that is slender [or pointed] and hard in the head; (TA;) well known: (Msb, K:) n. un. with p. (S, O, Msb, K, TA.) [Hence the saying,] laA ya$uwkuka min~iY $awokapN: see 1, near the beginning. [The $awok of the palm-tree are commonly called sul~aA='N.] $awoku Als~unobuli [The sharp prickles that compose the awn, or beard, of the ear of corn]. (AHn, TA in art. bhm.) ― -b2- [For other significations of $awokapN, see this word below.]
$awikN * ; and its fem., with p: see $aAy^ikN, in three places.

$awokapN * n. un. of $awokN [q. v.]. (S &c.) [Hence various meanings here following; all of which seem to be tropical.] ― -b2- A^aSaAbatohumo $awokapu AlqanaA [app. (assumed tropical:) The point of the spear hit, hurt, or wounded, them]. (TA. [There expl. only by the words whY $bh AlAsnp, i. e. wahiYa $ibohu AlA^asin~api; as though relating to a pl. number.]) ― -b3- jaAw^uwA biAl$~awokapi waAl$~ajarapi (tropical:) They came with multitude [app. meaning of armed men]. (TA.) ― -b4- $awokapu AlEaqorabi (assumed tropical:) The sting of the scorpion. (S, O, K.) ― -b5- $awokapu AlHaAy^iki (tropical:) The weaver's implement with which he makes the warp and the woof even: (S, O, TA:) i. e., (TA,) Al$~awokapu signifies AlS~iySiyapu, (O, K, in the CK AlS~iySapu,) as having this meaning: ― -b6- and also as meaning (tropical:) The spur of the cock. (O, TA.) ― -b7- And Al$~awokapu, (Lth, O,) or $awokapu Alkat~aAni, (K, TA,) (assumed tropical:) A piece of clay, (Lth, O, K, TA,) in a moist state, (K, TA,) made into a round form, and having its upper part pressed so that it becomes expanded, then (Lth, O, TA) prickles of the palm-tree are stuck into it, (Lth, O, K, TA,) and it dries; (K, TA;) used for clearing [or combing] flax therewith: (Lth, O, K, TA:) mentioned by Az: and also called Alkat~aAni ↓ $uwaAkapu. (TA.) ― -b8- $awokapN also signifies (tropical:) A weapon, or weapons; syn. silaAHN; (K, TA, and Ham p. 526;) as in the phrase fulaAnN *uw $uwokapK (tropical:) [Such a one is a possessor of a weapon or weapons; though this admits of another rendering, as will be shown by what follows]: (TA:) or (tropical:) sharpness thereof: (K, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) the point, or edge, in a weapon. (S, O.) ― -b9- And (assumed tropical:) Vehemence of might or strength, or of valour or prowess, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) in respect of fighting: (K, TA:) and (assumed tropical:) vehemence of encounter: and (assumed tropical:) sharpness: (TA:) and (assumed tropical:) the infliction of havock, or vehement slaughter or wounding, syn. nikaAyapN, [app. meaning effectiveness therein,] among the enemy: (K, TA:) and (assumed tropical:) strength in weapons [app. meaning in the use thereof]: (Msb:) and [simply] (assumed tropical:) strength, or might. (Ham p. 526.) One says, lahumo $awokapN fiY AlHarobi (assumed tropical:) [They have vehemence of might or strength, or of valour or prowess, in war]: and huwa *uw $awokapK fiY AlEaduw~i (assumed tropical:) [He has effectiveness in the infliction of havock among the enemy]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., halum~a A_ilaY jihaAdK laA $awokapa fiyhi (assumed tropical:) [Come to a war in the cause of religion wherein is no vehemence of might or strength, &c.]; meaning the pilgrimage. (TA.) ― -b10- Also (tropical:) A certain disease, (IDrd, O, K, TA,) well known; (K;) namely, plague, or pestilence; syn. TaAEuwn. (IDrd, O.) And (assumed tropical:) A redness that arises (A, * O, K) upon the body (K) or upon the face, and part of the body, and is [said to be] allayed by means of charms, or spells: (O:) because the sting of the scorpion, which is thus called, when it strikes a man, mostly produces redness. (A, TA.) ― -b11- [In one instance, in the CK, $awokapN is erroneously put for $awikapN, as an epithet applied to a tree.]

$awokaA='u * , applied to a [garment such as is called] burodap, (S, O,) or to a [garment or dress such as is called] Hul~ap, (A, O, K,) (tropical:) Rough to the feel, because new: (AO, S, O, K, TA:) but As said, “ I know not what it is. ” (O, L, TA.)
$aAkiY Als~ilaAHi * and $aAkK fiY AlslAHi: see $aAy^ikN, in three places.
$uwaAkapu Alkat~aAni * : see $awokapN.
$uwayokapN * , like juhayonap [in measure], accord. to the K, A certain species of camels; and thus in the Moheet and the Mohkam: but the correct word is that which here follows. (TA.)

A_ibilN $uwayokiy~apN * , (S, O, TA,) thus [says Sgh] I have seen the latter word in a verse in the Deewán of Dhu-r-Rummeh in the handwriting of Skr, with a distinct sheddeh to the [latter] Y, but in the handwriting of El-Bujeyrimee without a sheddeh; (O, TA;) (assumed tropical:) Camels whose canine teeth have grown forth: (S, * O, TA:) some say that it is $uwayokiy^ap, with ', and is for $uwayoqiy^ap [q. v.], the q being changed into k. (O, TA.)

$ajarN $aAy^ikN * (S, O) and ↓ $awikN and ↓ $aAkN (O) Trees having thorns; (S, O; *) and ↓ $ajarapN mu$iykapN a tree having thorns: (TA:) [or thorny; having many thorns; for] ↓ $ajarapN $aAkapN signifies a thorny tree, or a tree having many thorns, (S, O, K,) accord. to ISk; (S, O;) as also ↓ $jrp $awikapN [in the CK (erroneously) $awokapN] and $aAy^ikapN (K, TA) and ↓ mu$owikapN. (S, O, K, * TA.) And ↓ A^aroDN $aAkapN A thorny land, or a land in which are many thorns: (K, TA:) and [in like manner] A^aroDN ↓ mu$owikapN (S, O, K) a thorny land, or a land abounding with thorns; (O;) a land in which are the [thorny trees called] siHaA=' and qataAd and haraAs. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- $aAy^iku Als~ilaAHi (S, O, Msb, K) and AlslAHi ↓ $aAku, (Fr, K, TA,) with refa to the k, (TA,) [in the CK, erroneously, $Aki,] and ↓ $awiku AlslAHi, (K,) which is of the dial. of El-Yemen, (TA,) and AlslAHi ↓ $aAkiY, (Fr, S, O, Msb, K,) this last formed by transposition from the first, (S, O, Msb, TA,) or, as Fr says, $aAkiY AlslAHi and $aAku AlslAHi are like jurufo haArK and haArN, (TA,) (tropical:) A man who exhibits his $awokap [i. e. vehemence of might or strength, or of valour or prowess, &c.], and his sharpness: (S, O, Msb:) or a man whose weapon is sharp, or whose weapons are sharp: (K, TA:) or AlslAHi ↓ $aAkiY, as some explain it, a man whose spear-head and arrow-head and the like are sharp: (TA:) [or all may be rendered bristling with arms:] and accord. to AZ, one says fiY Als~ilaAHi ↓ $aAkK and $aAy^ikN. (TA.)

ma$uwkN *
Affected with the disease, (K, * TA,) or redness, (O, K, *) termed $awokapN; (O, K, TA;) applied to a man. (O.)
mu$owikN * : see its fem. voce $aAy^ikN, in two places.
mu$iykN * : see its fem. voce $aAy^ikN.

zaroEN mu$aw~ikN *
Seed-produce of which the first portion has come forth. (A, TA. [See also 2.])

1 $aAla * , [aor. ya$uwlu,] (S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. $uwolN, (TK,) It rose; or became raised, or elevated; (S, O, Msb, K;) said, in this sense, of a she-camel's tail; (S, O, K;) [and in like manner of a star; (see Ham p. 239;)] and ↓ An$Al signifies the
same, (O, K,) said of a stone, (K,) and so An$Alt said of a jar (jar~ap); (S, O;) and likewise ↓ A$tAl. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] $Al AlmiyozaAnu The balance had one of its two scales higher than the other, (S, O, Msb, TA,) by reason of its lightness. (Msb.) Whence the saying, $Al miyzaAnu fulaAnK, aor. ya$uwlu, inf. n. $awalaAnN, meaning (tropical:) Such a one was overcome in contending with another for superiority in glory or the like. (TA.) ― -b3- And $Alt Alqirobapu, and $Al Alz~iq~u, The legs of the water-skin, and of the skin for wine &c., became raised, or elevated, on the occasion of its being filled, or inflated. (TA.) ― -b4- And $aAla labanuhaA [meaning Her milk became drawn up, or withdrawn,] is said of a camel. (TA.) ― -b5- One says also, $Alt naEaAmatuhu, meaning (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, flurried, agitated, or excited, (xaf~a,) and angry, and then became calm. (K.) And $Alt naEaAmatuhumo (assumed tropical:) Their might (Eiz~uhumo) departed: (O, K:) or their abodes became clear of them, as though lightened of them, (xaf~ato manaAziluhumo minohumo, K, TA,) and they went away: (TA:) or their expression of opinion was, or became, discordant: (tafar~aqato kalimatuhumo: K:) or they died: and they became scattered, or dispersed; as though there remained not of them save a remnant; [see $awolN;] Aln~aEaAmapu signifying AljamaAEapu: (TA:) or they became irresolute, by reason of fear, and fled: (Msb:) or they were frightened, and fled. (M in art. rA^l.) [See also naEaAmapN: and see a verse cited voce A_im~aA.] -A2- $ulotu bihi, and $ulotuhu; (Msb;) and ↓ A^a$alotuhu; (O, Msb;) or $ulotu biAljar~api, for which one should not say $ilotu [which the vulgar say in the present day, making it trans. by itself]; (S, O;) and ↓ A^a$alotuhaA; (S;) or $Al biAlHajari; and ↓ A$Alhu, (K,) inf. n. A_i$aAlapN; (TA;) and ↓ $Awlhu; (K;) aor. of the first as above, inf. n. $awolN; (S, O, Msb;) I raised, (S, O, Msb,) or he raised, (K,) it, (O, Msb,) namely, a thing, (O,) or the jar, (S, O,) or the stone. (K.) And $Alt bi*anabihaA, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (S, O, K,) inf. n. $awolN (O, Msb, K) and $awalaAnN; (O, K;) and ↓ A$Althu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_i$aAlapN; and ↓ Ast$Althu; (TA;) She (a camel) raised her tail, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) having become pregnant. (Msb. [See $aAy^ilN: and see also 2.]) And $Alt bi*anabihaA It (a scorpion) raised its tail. (TA.) And $Al yadahu He raised his arm or hand; like $Al bihaA. (Msb.) And biDaboEihi ↓ A$Al He raised his DaboE [generally expl. as meaning the upper half of the arm, from the elbow to the shoulder-blade]. (TA.)

2 $aw~ala
$w~lt, said of a she-camel, (S, O, K,) She became such as is termed $aAy^ilap: (S, O, TA: [in one of my copies of the S, SaAra $awolFA is erroneously put for SaArato $aAy^ilapF:]) or her supplies of milk dried up; (jaf~ato A^alobaAnuhaA; K, TA; [but perhaps the right reading is xaf~ato, meaning became scanty; for SM adds,]) and became little in quantity. (TA.) And $w~lt AlA_ibilu The camels became in such a state that their bellies [were drawn up as though they] reached their backs: (K, TA:) or became such as to have [only] a $awol [or small quantity remaining] of milk: like as one says, (O, TA,) $w~lt AlmazaAdapu The mzAdp [or leathern water-bag] had little water remaining in it: (O, K, TA:) one should not say $aAlat. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] ta$owiylN of the *akar signifies Its being in a relaxed state on the occasion of mujaAmaEap. (O, K.) And $w~l said of a horse means, like raf~aDa, He put forth his veretrum without being vigorously lustful. (TA in art. rfD.) ― -b3- $w~l said of a garob [or large bucket], Its water became little in quantity. (O, K.) Said of a she-camel's milk, It became deficient: (K, TA:) and it became withdrawn. (TA.) And said of water, It became little in quantity. (K.) ― -b4- In the following saying, (S, TA,) of Abu-n-Nejm, (TA,)
Hat~aY A_i*aA maA AlEi$oru EanohaA $aw~alaA
the poet means, *ahaba and taSar~ama [i. e. Until, when the coming to water on the tenth day after the next preceding period of abstinence ceased from her or them... referring to a camel or to camels]. (S, TA.) ― -b5- $w~l fiY AlmazaAdapi He left somewhat remaining (A^aboqaY $awolFA) of water in the mzAdp [or leathern water-bag]. (K, * TA.)

3 $Awlhu * : see 1, latter half. ― -b2- Also, and $Awl bihi, and $Awl bihi fiY AlT~iEaAni, [inf. n. mu$aAwalapN,] He contended with him in thrusting [with the spear]. (TA.) See also 6. ― -b3- And $Awl AlfaHolu AlfaHola The stallion [camel] fought with, or combated, the stallion [camel]. (Ham p. 660.)
4 A^a$owala see 1, latter half, in five places.

6 t$AwlwA *
They reached, or smote, one another, (tanaAwala baEoDuhumo baEoDFA,) in fight, with the spears: and ↓ mu$aAwalapN has a similar signification [to ta$aAwulN, as shown above by an explanation of its verb, 3]. (AZ, S, O.)
7 A_ino$awala see 1, first sentence.
8 A_i$otawala see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- A$tAl lahu (tropical:) He opposed himself to him, and reviled him. (O, K, TA.)
10 A_isota$owala see 1, near the end of the paragraph.

$aAlN *
A certain fish of the sea, or of great rivers (samakapN baHoriy~apN): (TA:) [in Egypt this name is applied to a fish of the genus silurus, found in the Nile: it is well described by Sonnini, in p. 407 of the 4to Engl. ed. of his Travels in Upper and Lower Egypt.] -A2- Also A certain kind of ridaA=' [here meaning shawl], made in Cashmere and Lahore, and brought for sale to other countries; [erroneously] said to be made of camels' fur; and so called because raised to the shoulders, if it be an Arabic word [which is not the case, for it is from the Pers. $aAlN, whence our word “ shawl ”]: pl. $iylaAnN and $aAlaAtN. (TA.)

$awolN * : see $aAy^ilapN, voce $aAy^ilN: -A2- and $awolapN. -A3- Also Somewhat remaining of water in the skin and in the bucket, (K,) and of milk in the udder: (TA:) and a small quantity of water (S, O, K, TA) in the bottom of the water-skin (S, O, TA) and of the leathern water-bag: (TA:) [in the CK, AlmAlu Alqaliylu is erroneously put for AlmaA='u Alqaliylu:] pl. A^a$owaAlN. (S, O, K.) It is said in a prov.,
maA Dar~a naAbFA $awoluhaA AlmuEal~aqu
(Meyd, TA,) i. e. Her small quantity of water [that is hung upon her does not harm an aged she-camel]: or naAbiY [my aged she-camel]: applied to the case of carrying that which will not harm thee if it be with thee, and will be useful to thee if thou be in want of it: (Meyd:) or applied to him who is enjoined to take the prudent course and to supply himself with travelling-provision though he be going to such provision. (TA.) -A4- And Light, active, or agile; syn. xafiyfN: (K:) so in the M. (TA.) [See also the next paragraph.]

$awilN * One that raises a thing. (TA. [See also $aAy^ilN.]) ― -b2- And A man light, active, or agile, (xafiyfN,) in work, and in service, (S, O, K,) and in respect of what is wanted; and quick: (K:) thus in a verse of El-Aashà: (O, TA:) [but accord. to the reading of AO of that verse, it is ↓ $uwulN, which has a similar, but intensive, meaning. (De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., 2nd ed., ii. 484-5.) See also what next follows.]
$uwalN * , like SuradN [in measure], One who aids, or assists, much or well; syn. naSuwrN. (O, TA.) [See also what next precedes.]
$uwulN * : see $awilN.

$awolapN * The part that it raises of the tail of the scorpion; (S, O, K;) and so ↓ $awolN: (Ham p. 649:) or, accord. to Sh, its sting, with which it strikes. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Al$~awolapu (assumed tropical:) Two bright stars, near together, [ λ and ν,] (S, O,) in the end of the tail of Scorpio, (Kzw,) which are one of the Mansions of the Moon, (S, O, Kzw,) namely, the Nineteenth Mansion; (Kzw;) also called Humapu AlEaqorabi. (S, O.) [See manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl.] ― -b3- And $awolapu is a proper name for The scorpion; (O, TA;) [and] so ↓ $aw~aAlapu. (K, TA.) -A2- Also A foolish, or stupid, woman. (IAar, O, K.) $awolapu was the name of A certain foolish female slave, belonging to [the tribe of] 'Adwán, and she used to give advice to her masters, and it resulted in evil to them; whence the saying, A^anota $awolapu Aln~aASiHapu [Thou art Showleh the giver of advice]. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- Also the name of The mare of Zeyd-el-Fawáris Ed-Dabbee. (O, K.)

$uwayolaA='u *
A certain plant, (AHn, O, K,) mentioned, but not described, by As; of the kind termed Eu$ob, growing in plain, or soft, land, (AHn, O,) used as a medicament, (AHn, O, K,) and well known: (AHn, O:) [Sgh says,] I have seen it: it is dust-coloured, spreads upon the ground, has no thorns, and the cattle eagerly desire it: (O:) it is called (O, K) sometimes, (K,) by some of the people of El-'Irák, (O,) ↓ $uw~ayolN, like fub~ayoTN [in measure]. (O, K.)

$aw~aAlN * The tail of the scorpion. (TA. [So called
because often raised.]) ― -b2- Also, (S, O, Msb, K,) and sometimes it is called Al$~aw~aAlu, (Msb,) The month of the festival of the breaking of the fast; (Msb, K; *) the month next after ramaDaAn; (TA;) the first of the months of the pilgrimage; (S, O;) [the tenth month of the lunar year:] as some assert, (IDrd, O,) so called because [when first thus named] it coincided with the season when the she-camels [being seven or eight months gone with young] raised their tails: (IDrd, O, Msb, TA:) [for the camels generally couple in winter:] or because of their milk becoming then withdrawn; such being the case with the camels in the time of vehement heat and of the coming to an end of the juicy fresh herbage: [see a table of the months voce zamanN:] the Arabs used to regard the making of marriage-contracts in this month as of evil omen; and to say that the woman [then] married would resist him who married her, like as the she-camel resists the stallion and raises her tail; but the Prophet abolished their thus auguring, and he married 'Áïsheh in this month: (TA:) the pl. is $aw~aAlaAtN and $awaAwiylu (S, Msb, K) and $awaAwilu, this last formed by rejecting the augmentative letter [in the second]. (TA.)
$uw~ayolN * : see $uwayolaA='u.

$aw~aAlapN * [not (as is implied in the K) $aw~aAlapu] A certain bird, (AHát, O, K,) a dux~alap [n. un. of dux~alN q. v.], of a dusky colour, which, when it alights upon a stone or a tree, moves up and down its tail like as does the camel; so called because it raises its tail; and in its belly and its hinder part is somewhat of redness. (AHát, O, TA.) ― -b2- See also $awolapN. ― -b3- [Hence, as being likened to the scorpion, whence also the phrase A_in~ahu latadib~u EaqaAribuhu,] AimoraA^apN $aw~aAlapN (assumed tropical:) A woman wont to calumniate. (K.)

$aAy^ilN * A she-camel raising her tail, (S, O, Msb, K,) having conceived, (Msb,) or by reason of having conceived, and having no milk whatever: (S, O, K:) or a she-camel that has conceived, and raises her tail to the stallion as a sign of her having conceived, raising her head therewith, and elevating her nose: (Az, TA:) the word is without p because it is an epithet of peculiar application [to a female]: (Msb:) or it is without p anomalously; for the male also raises his tail: (ISd, TA:) the pl. is $uw~alN (Az, S, O, Msb, K) and $uy~alN and $iy~alN and $uw~aAlN. (K.) Also, with p, applied to a mare, as meaning Raising the tail. (TA.) ― -b2- And $aAy^ilapN, which is anomalously with p because it is an epithet denoting an attribute not shared with the female by the male, (ISd, TA,) A she-camel that has passed seven months, (S, O, K,) or eight, (S, O,) since the period of her bringing forth, (S, O, K,) or of her becoming pregnant, (K,) and whose milk has dried up, (jaf~a labanuhaA, K, and so in a copy of the S,) or whose milk has become scanty, (xaf~a labanuhaA, O, and so in another copy of the S,) and her udder drawn up, (S, O,) there remaining in her udder no more than a $awol, a third of the quantity of the contents thereof when her bringing forth was recent: (TA:) she-camels in this case are termed ↓ $awolN, (S, O, K,) an anomalous pl., (K,) [or rather a quasi-pl. n.,] expl. by some as applied to she-camels whose milk has become deficient, which is the case when their young are weaned at the period of the [auroral] rising of suhayol [or Canopus, a period which commenced, in Central Arabia, about the beginning of the era of the Flight, on the 4th of August, O. S.], and they cease not to be thus termed until the stallion is sent among them; (TA;) the pl. pl. [or pl. of $awolN] is A^a$owaAlN; (K;) and $awaAy^ilu is a pl. of $aAy^ilapN meaning [as expl. above, or] a she-camel whose milk has become withdrawn. (TA.) ― -b3- $aAy^ilN is also applied to Anything that is raised, or drawn up, or withdrawn. (TA.)

$awo$alaA='u *
Initus; syn. nayokN: said to be an Abyssinian word. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

mi$owalN *
A small minojal [or reaping-hook: in the CK, erroneously, munoxul]. (S, O, K, TA.)
mu$iylN * act. part. n. of 4. See an ex. in a verse cited voce xaAfiD; cited also in the present art. in the S and O.
mi$owalapN * is said by Yz to signify A certain thing with which one plays. (O, TA.)

mi$owaAlN *
A stone that is raised. (Lh, K.)

1 $aAha wajohuhu * , aor. ya$uwhu; (K;) and $aAhati Alwujuwhu, aor. ta$uwhu; (S, Msb;) inf. n. $awohN (S, K) and $awohapN, (K,) or the latter is a simple subst.; (TA;) and $awiha wajohuhu, (K,) inf. n. $awahN; (TA;) His face was, (K,) and the faces were, (S, Msb,) foul, unseemly, or ugly. (S, Msb, K.) And $awiha, (Msb,) and $awihato, (Mgh,) inf. n. $awahN, (Mgh, Msb,) He, (a man, Msb,) and she, (a woman, Mgh,) was, or became, foul, unseemly, or ugly, (Mgh, Msb,) in face, (Mgh,) or in make. (Msb.) ― -b2- $awahN is also syn. with HusonN [app. as an inf. n., of which the verb is $awiha signifying He was, or became, beautiful: thus having two contr. meanings]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, (K,) as an inf. n., (TK,) The neck's being long, (K, TA,) and high, and the head's overtopping; whence ↓ A^a$owahu applied to a horse: (TA:) and the neck's being short: thus [again] having two contr. meanings: (K:) one says, [app. of a horse,] $awihato Eunuquhu His neck was long [&c.]: and his neck was short: (TK:) or $awahN said of the neck [of a horse] signifies the being extended: and said of the $idoq [or side of the mouth], the being wide, (JK. [It probably signifies any of the attributes denoted by the epithet A^a$owahu, q. v.]) ― -b4- Also, [and app. in this sense likewise an inf. n. of which the verb is $awiha,] The being quick to smite with the [evil] eye. (S.) ― -b5- And one says, $aAha fulaAnFA, (K,) inf. n. $awohN, (TA,) He smote such a one with the [evil] eye; (K, TA;) as also ↓ A$Ahhu: (TA in art. $hw:) and in like manner, maAlahu [his cattle, or property]: (Lh, TA:) or $awohN signifies the smiting vehemently therewith. (TA.) And EalaY~a ↓ laA tu$aw~iho Smite not thou me with an [evil] eye: (K:) or, accord. to Abu-l-Mekárim this means say not, How eloquent art thou! (Az, TA,) or say not, How beautiful art thou! (ISk, S,) and so doing smite me with the [evil] eye, or with an [evil] eye. (ISk, Az, S, TA.) ↓ t$w~h signifies He practised artifice to smite people with the evil eye. (JK.) And one says, A^amowaAla Aln~aAsi liyuSiybahaA biAlEayoni ↓ huwa yata$aw~ahu i. e. He raises his look towards the cattle, or possessions, of the people to smite them with the [evil] eye. (TA.) [See also 1 in art. $yh.] ― -b6- Also, He frightened, or terrified, such a one. (Lh, K.) ― -b7- And He envied such a one. (K.) ― -b8- And $aAhato nafosuhu A_ilaY ka*aA His desire became raised towards such a thing. (AA, K.)

2 $w~hhu * , (S, K,) inf. n. ta$owiyhN, (TA,) He (God) rendered foul, unseemly, or ugly, his face: (S, K, TA:) and it, i. e. the conformation of the face. (TA, from a verse of El-Hotei-ah.) And $aw~ahotu Alwujuwha I rendered foul, unseemly, or ugly, the faces. (Msb.) ― -b2- And $aw~aha A@ll~`hu Huluwqakumo God rendered, or may God render, wide your throats, or fauces. (TA.) ― -b3- laA tu$aw~iho EalaY~a: see 1, latter half. ― -b4- $w~h biyadihi He (a man) made a sign with his arm, or hand. (JK.)
4 A$Ahhu * : see 1.

5 t$w~h lahu *
He became altered in countenance to him, so as to be not known by him, (syn. tanak~ara, S, K,) and assumed various appearances. (S.) ― -b2- See also 1, in two places, near the end. -A2- t$w~h $aApF He hunted a $Ap [app. here meaning a wild bull, as seems to be indicated by the context in the S]. (S, K.)
$aA='N * : see the next paragraph.

$aApN * , (S, Msb, K, &c.,) originally $aAhapN, (S, Msb, TA,) A sheep, or goat; [each and either, but more commonly the former; see an instance voce SuwfN;] i. e. one of what are termed ganam; (S, * Msb, * K;) applied to the male and to the female; (S, Msb, K;) so that one says of the male, h`*aA $aApN, (Msb,) which is said by Kh to be like the phrase h`*aA raHomapN mino rab~iY; (Sb, TA;) and of the female, h`*ihi $aApN; and $aApN *akarN and $aApN A^unovaY: (Msb:) or it may be [one] of sheep, and of goats, and of gazelles or antelopes, and of the bovine kind [app. of the wild bovine kind i. e. of bovine antelopes], and of ostriches, and of wild asses; (K;) it is applied to a wild bull by Tarafeh, in his saying,
kasaAmiEataYo $aApK biHawomala muforadi
(S) i. e. Like the two ears of a wild bull, in Howmal, solitary; the poet likening thereto the ears of a she-camel in respect of sharpness and erectness; (EM p. 76;) and likewise by Lebeed, and by El-Farezdak: (IB, TA:) and it is also applied to [a wild cow; (though said in the K in art. $wY to signify the wild bull, specially the male;) and hence, as being likened thereto,] (tropical:) a woman; (K, TA;) thus by El-Aashà; and thus also by Antarah, in his saying,
yaA $aApa maA qanaSK limano Hal~ato lahu
Harumato EalaY~a walayotahaA lamo taHorumi
(TA) O $Ap [i. e. wild cow] of the chase (mA being redundant) for him to whom she is lawful: she has become forbidden to me, and would that she were not forbidden: (EM p. 246:) pl. ↓ $aA='N, (S, Msb, K,) originally $aAhN, (K,) used when they are many in number, (S,) [but this is properly termed a coll. gen. n.,] and $iyaAhN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) with h, which is used of a number from three to ten [inclusive], for more than which it is with t [meaning p, i. e. $aApN, agreeably with a general rule], (S,) and $iwaAhN, [the original of $iyaAhN,] (K,) and ↓ $awiY~N, (S, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, $awFY,]) which is pl. of $aA='N, (S, TA,) or rather a quasi-pl. n., originally $awiyhN, the h being changed into Y like as it is in *iY for *iho, (TA,) and A^a$aAwihu, (K,) and ↓ $ayohN, (so in copies of the K, [in the TA said to be like EinabN, which is a mistake, (perhaps for EayonN,) for it is there said to be a quasi-pl. n., which could not be said if it were $iyahN,]) and ↓ $iyhN, (CK, [but this, which is another quasi-pl. n., is not in my MS. copy of the K nor in the TA,]) and ↓ $ay~ihN, (K,) originally $ayowihN, but this, also, is a quasi-pl. n., (TA,) and ↓ $iyapN also is syn. with $aA='N: (IAar, K in art. $wY:) it has not a pl. formed with A and t, [i. e. it has not for a pl. $aAA=tN,] whether it be used as a gen. n. or as a proper name: (TA:) the dim. is ↓ $uwayohapN. (S, Msb.) The sing. is also used in the sense of the pl., in the saying fulaAnN kaviyru Al$~aApi waAlbaEiyri [Such a one is possessor of a large number of sheep or goats, and of camels], because the article Al denotes the genus. (S.) And it is said in a trad. faA^amara lahaA bi$iyaAhi ganamK [And he ordered that sheep or goats should be given to her]: $yAh being prefixed to gnm, governing it in the gen. case, for the sake of distinction; because the Arabs [sometimes] call an animal of the wild bovine kind $Ap. (IAth, TA.) ― -b2- Al$~aApu is also the name of (assumed tropical:) Certain small stars (K in art. $wY) between AlqrHh [or Alfrjp, thus in the work of Kzw, in his descr. of Cepheus, and there said to be the star in the breast of Cepheus,] and AljadoYu [i. e. the pole-star]; (TA in that art.;) [the same that are described by Kzw as certain small stars, called by the Arabs AlA^agonaAmu, between the legs of Cepheus and the star AljadoYu.]
$aAhu AlbaSari * , and $aAhiY AlbaSari: see $aAy^ihN.
$awahN * an inf. n., of $awiha. (Mgh, Msb, TA. [See 1, in several places.]) -A2- Also a subst. meaning Unluckiness, or inauspiciousness, of a woman. (TA.)
$ayohN * and $iyhN and $iyapN: see $aApN.

$uwhapN *
Remoteness: (K, TA:) and so buwhapN: one says, in dispraise, $uwhapF lahu wabuwhapF [i. e. buEodFA lahu, lit. Remoteness to him! meaning may God alienate him or estrange him, from good, or prosperity! or, curse him!]. (TA.)
$awiY~N * , originally $awiyhN: see $aApN.
$uwayohapN * dim. of $aApN, q. v. (S, Msb.)

$aAy^ihN *
Envying: pl. $uw~ahN: (As, Lh, TA:) or the latter signifies persons practising artifice to smite men with the [evil] eye. (JK.) ― -b2- And $aAy^ihu AlbaSari, (JK, S, K,) and AlbaSari ↓ $aAhu, (JK, K,) and $aAhiY AlbaSari, (JK, TA, and S and K in art. $hw,) the last formed by transposition from the first, (S in art. $hw,) A man sharp of sight. (JK, S, K.)
$aAy^iY~N * : see the next paragraph.
$aAhiY~N * : see the next paragraph.

$aAwiY~N * and ↓ $aAhiY~N A man possessing $aA=' [meaning sheep or goats or both]: (K:) the former is the rel. n. of $aA='N; and the latter, that of $aApN: but used as a proper name of a man, it is ↓ $aAy^iY~N, and, if you will, $aAwiY~N. (S, TA. *)
$ay~ihN * : see the next paragraph: -A2- and see $aApN.

A^a$owahu * , applied to a man, (Msb,) Foul, unseemly, or ugly, (JK, Msb, K,) in face, (JK, K,) or in aspect, (Msb,) and, as also ↓ $ay~ihN, of which the pl. is $ay~ihuwna, in make: (JK:) fem. $awohaA='u: (JK, Mgh, Msb:) and pl. $uwhN. (Msb.) Any created thing incongruous in its several parts; as also ↓ mu$aw~ahN. (TA.) And the fem., A woman frowning, or morose, in face; (K, * TA;) foul, unseemly, or ugly, in make: (TA:) and also beautiful, goodly, or comely; (K, * TA;) that excites admiration and approval by her beauty: (TA:) thus having two contr. meanings. (K, TA.) Also, the fem., Unlucky, or inauspicious. (K.) ― -b2- And the masc. applied to a man, (Lth, S, TA,) and the fem. applied to a woman, (Lth, TA,) That smites quickly with the [evil] eye: (Lth, S, TA:) or that smites people effectually with his, and her, [evil] eye. (TA.) And A^a$owahu AlEayon Having an evil eye. (Fr, TA in art. $zr.) ― -b3- The fem. is also applied to a mare, (JK, T, S, K,) as an epithet of commendation, but not the masc. to a horse, meaning, it is said, Wide in the $idoqaAni [or two sides of the mouth]: (S:) or long in the head, and wide in the nostrils: (JK:) or tall, and such as excites admiration and approval by her beauty or excellence: (K, * TA:) or exceedingly wide in the $idoqaAni [or two sides of the mouth] and the nostrils: (K, TA:) or, as some say, wide in the mouth: (TA:) and small in the mouth: thus having two contr. meanings: (K, TA:) or sharpsighted: (T, TA:) or sharp in spirit: (TA:) see also 1. ― -b4- Also, the masc., Proud, and self-conceited. (K.) ― -b5- And xuTobapN $awohaA='u [An oration from the pulpit] in which a blessing is not invoked on the Prophet. (TA.)

A^aroDN ma$aAhapN *
A land in which are $aA='; (A'Obeyd, S, K;) like as one says A^aroDN maA^obalapN: (A'Obeyd, S:) or in which are many thereof. (K.)

mu$aw~ahN *
Rendered foul, unseemly, or ugly, in face, by God: (TA:) or foul, &c., in shape. (K.) See also A^a$owahu, second sentence. ― -b2- And Bad in intellect. (TA.)

1 $awaY All~aHoma * , (aor.
$awiYa , TA,) inf. n. $aY~N, (S, MA, Msb, K,) He roasted, broiled, or fried, the flesh-meat; (MA, KL, * PS;) and ↓ A$wAhu signifies the same; as also ↓ A$twAhu; (Msb, TA;) or this last, (TA,) or A$twY [alone], (S, MA,) signifies he prepared, or prepared for himself, (S, MA, * TA,) $iwaA=', (S, TA, *) or roasted, broiled, or fried, flesh-meat. (MA.) ― -b2- And $awaY AlmaA='a, (IAar, K,) aor. as above, (TA,) He heated the water. (IAar, K.) ― -b3- [And accord. to Freytag, $awaY signifies also He cut off from (mn) roasted flesh-meat: but for this he has named no authority.] -A2- See also 4.
2 $aw~aYa see 4. ― -b2- Also $w~Ahu laHomFA He gave him flesh-meat [app. in an unrestricted sense]. (TA.)
3 yu$aAwiY * , for yu$aAy^iY: see 3 in art. $A^w.

4 A$wY All~aHoma * : see 1. ― -b2- A^a$owaAhumo; (S, Msb, K;) and ↓ $aw~aAhumo, inf. n. ta$owiyapN; (K;) He fed them with $iwaA=' [i. e. roasted, or broiled, or fried, flesh-meat]. (S, Msb, K.) And (both verbs with their complements) He gave them flesh-meat that they might roast, or broil, or fry, thereof. (AZ, K.) -A2- And A$wY (tropical:) He left a portion remaining of his supper: (S, K, TA:) or he left some roasted, or broiled, or fried, flesh-meat of his supper. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And A$wY AlqamoHu The wheat became fit to be rubbed with the hands and to be roasted. (ISd, K.) ― -b3- And A$wY Als~aEafu (assumed tropical:) The palmbranches became yellow on the occasion of their drying up; (K, TA;) as though a roasting affected them. (TA.) -A3- Also He got, or acquired, the worse, or viler, sort of cattle. (K.) -A4- A$wAhu said of a shooter or caster, He hit (S, * Msb, * K) his $awaY, (K,) i. e. [one or more of his] extremities, (TA,) not a [vital] place where a wound would occasion death; (S, Msb, K;) and so ↓ $awaAhu, as in the Tekmileh: in the K, erroneously, $w~Ahu. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, He missed it, i. e. the object of his aim. See mu$owFY: and see also Ham p. 91.] ― -b3- [Hence, also, app.,] Hr says that A$wY is allowable in the sense of A^asoqaTa (assumed tropical:) [He dropped, left out, omitted, &c., anything]; like A^asowaY [q. v.]. (TA in art. swY.) -A5- In the saying maA A^aEoyaAhu waA^a$oyaAhu (S, K, [in some copies of the K wamaA A^a$oyaAhu,]) and so in mA AEyAh waA^a$owaAhu, (S, * K, * TA,) the latter verb is an imitative sequent to the former [added only for the purpose of corroboration]. (S, K, TA.)

7 An$wY All~aHomu *
The flesh-meat became roasted, broiled, or fried; (MA;) quasi-pass. of $awaY All~aHoma; (S, * M, Msb, K;) as also * A$twY; (M, K;) [or] the latter in this sense is not allowable. (S, Msb.)

8 A_i$otawaYa see 1. ― -b2- [Hence,] Ai$otawayotuhaA, referring to a she-camel, (assumed tropical:) I journeyed upon her until the heat of the middays of summer emaciated her and she became as though she were burnt. (Ham p. 783.) -A2- See also 7.
$aApN * : see what next follows: and see more in art. $wh.

$iyapN *
i. q. $aA='N [q. v. in art. $wh]; as also ↓ $awiY~N; (IAar, K;) the latter is like ganiY~N, [Al$~aw`Y in the CK as syn. with Al$~A'u being a mistranscription,] and is said by IAth to be a quasi-pl. n., or [what lexicographers term] a pl., of ↓ $aApN [n. un. of $aA='N]. (TA.)

$iY~N * is originally $iwoYN. (ISd, TA.) One says, jaA='a biAlEiY~i waAl$~iY~i, (S, K,) using the latter noun as an imitative sequent to the former [for the purpose of corroboration: see art. EY]. (TA.)

$awFY * is pl. of $awaApN: [or rather the former is a coll. gen. n. of which the latter is the n. un.:] the latter signifies The skin of the head: (S, TA:) so [accord. to some] in the Kur lxx. 16: (TA:) or the exterior of the skin of the head, in which grows the hair: (Aboo-Safwán, TA in art. b$r:) and some say, the exterior of all, or of any part, of the skin: (TA in the present art.:) and the former signifies the arms or hands and the legs or feet, or the fore and hind legs, (S, K,) and (K) the extremities (Msb, K) collectively, (K,) and the head of a human being, (S,) or the qiHof of the head [i. e. the bone above the brain, or a separate portion of the skull, or a distinct bone of the skull], (K,) but of a horse the legs, not the head, because one says Eabolu Al$~awaY [i. e. thick in the legs], for this cannot relate to the head of the horse, (S,) and any part that is not a [vital] place [i. e.] where a wound causes death (S, Msb, K) such [for instance] as the legs. (Msb.) vaAlibapu Al$~awaY means A woman having cracked, or chapped, feet. (S and K in art. vlb.) ― -b2- It is also a subst. [app. meaning a quasi-inf. n.] from A^a$owaAhu [q. v.] as said of a shooter or caster: (TA:) [and hence] the saying (S, TA) of the Hudhalee, (S, [accord. to the TA, Khálid Ibn-Zuheyr,])
faA_in~a mina Alqawoli Al~atiY laA $awaY lahaA
A_i*aA zal~a Zahori All~isaAni A@nofilaAtuhu
means (assumed tropical:) [And, or for] verily of speech is that sentence (kalimap, a word understood,) which does not hit a place where a wound will not occasion death, [i. e. which does not miss its object, when its escaping from the upper surface of the tongue is quick,] but which kills. (S, TA.) And $awFY is used [app. in like manner, as a quasi-inf. n.,] in the case of anything that has missed an object of aim, though there be to it [really] no place where a wound would occasion death nor anything that is [properly] termed $awFY [as meaning a place where a wound will not occasion death]. (TA.) And [hence] it signifies (assumed tropical:) A mistake; syn. xaTaA^N. (TA.) ― -b3- Also (tropical:) A thing, (S,) or an affair, (K,) that is paltry, mean, despicable, or of no account or weight or worth: (S, K, * TA:) in this sense, from the same word as signifying the “ extremities ” [of an animal]. (IAth, TA.) Hence, in a trad. of Mujáhid, kul~u maA A^aSaAba AlS~aAy^ima $awFY A_il~aA Algayobapa (tropical:) [Everything that befalls the faster is a matter of no account, except absence of mind]; i. e. nothing that befalls the faster annuls his fast except Algybp, for this does annul it. (TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) The worse, or viler, sort of cattle, (S, K, TA,) of camels, and of sheep or goats; and the small, or young, thereof. (TA.) [See also $uwaAyapN.] ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) A remainder, or remaining portion. (TA.) [See, again, $uwaAyapN.] ― -b6- Also i. q. A_iboqaA='N (assumed tropical:) [The making, or causing, or suffering, to remain; or, perhaps, to continue in life, and if it mean thus, it may be from the same word in a sense expl. above, for the animal that one hits in a part that is not vital is suffered to continue in life]. (TA.)
$uwaA='N * : see what next follows.

$iwaA='N *
Roasted, broiled, or fried, flesh-meat; (S, * MA, Msb, K, * KL;) as also ↓ $uwaA='N; (Ks, Sgh, K;) but the former is more usual and more chaste: (TA:) a subst. from $awaY All~aHoma: and ↓ $iwaA='apN [as its n. un.] signifies a piece thereof. (S.)

$awiY~N * (K) and ↓ ma$owiY~N (Msb) [Roasted, broiled, or fried], the latter originally ma$owuwYN. (Msb.) [In the K the former is said to be like $iwaA='N; but it has the signification of the latter, i. e., of a pass. part. n.] -A2- See also $iyapN. -A3- Ks says, (S,) in the phrase EayiY~N $ayiY~N, and so in EayiY~N $awiY~N, (S, K,) some say (S) the latter word is an imitative sequent to the former [i. e. a corroborative: see art. EY]. (S, K.)
$iwaA='apN * : see $iwaA='N.
$awiy~apN * : see the next paragraph.
$awaAyapN * : see the next paragraph.

$uwaAyapN *
What is cut off from, or of, flesh-meat: (K, TA:) or what the slaughterer cuts off from, or of, the extremities of a sheep or goat. (TA.) ― -b2- A small thing [or portion] of that which is large; as a piece, or detached portion, of a sheep, or goat: one says, maA baqiYa mina Al$~aApi A_il~aA $uwaAyapN [There remained not of the sheep, or goat, save a piece]. (S.) ― -b3- Also, (S, K,) and ↓ $iwaAyapN and ↓ $awaAyapN, (K,) A quroS [or round cake, or small round cake,] of bread. (S, K.) ― -b4- And, all the three, A remaining portion of people, or of cattle, that have perished; as also ↓ $awiy~apN; (K;) or this last, a remaining portion of people that have perished: (S:) pl. (of the last, S) $awaAyaA. (S, K.) [See also $awFY.] ― -b5- And (tropical:) The bad, or vile, sort, (K, TA,) or worse, or viler, sort, (TA,) of camels, and of sheep, or goats: (K, TA:) in this sense written by ISd with kesr and with fet-h. (TA.) [See, again, $awFY.] ― -b6- [And accord. to Freytag, $wAyp AlrDf (i. e. $wAypu Alr~aDofi) is expl. by Meyd as meaning Cooked milk cast upon a hot stone, so that only a small portion remains.]
$iwaAyapN * : see the next preceding paragraph.

$aw~aA='N *
A seller of roasted, broiled, or fried, flesh-meat. (KL.)

$ay~aAnu * [mentioned in this art. as though originally $awoyaAnu] i. q. damu AlA^axawayoni [The red, resinous, inspissated juice called dragon's blood: see art. dmw]. (S. K.) -A2- And Far-seeing. (S, K.)

$aAwiY~N *
A possessor of $aA=' [meaning sheep or goats or both]. (S, K. [In the CK without teshdeed. Mentioned also in art. $wh, q. v.]) -A2- saEafapN $aAwiy~apN (with teshdeed to the Y, TA, [but in the CK without teshdeed,]) (assumed tropical:) A palm-branch that has become yellow in drying up. (K. [See 4.])
$awo$aApN * , (S, K, [in some copies of the K $awo$aA='N, but]) like mawomaApN, (S,) A swift she-camel. (S, K.)
A^a$aAwaY * a pl. pl. of $aYo'N, q. v.

mu$owFY * , like muhodFY, (K, TA, [in the CK, ma$owiY~, like mahodiY~, erroneously, as is proved by a verse cited as an ex. in the TA, pass. part. n. of 4,]) applied to a portion of a living serpent, (TA,) That has been missed by the stone [cast at it]. (K, TA.)
mi$owFY * (K in art. Swl) A frying-pan. (TK in that art.)
ma$owiY~N * : see $awiY~N.
mu$otawFY * [A place of roasting, broiling, or frying, flesh-meat]. (S in art. Tbx.)
4 A^a$oyaAhu * an imitative sequent to A^aEoyaAhu in the phrase maA A^aEoyaAhu waA^a$oyaAhu: see 4 in art. $wY.
$iyapN * , syn. with $aA='N: see art. $wY.
$aY~N * : and yaA $aY~a maA liY: see $aYo'N, in art. $yA^.
$iY~N * an imitative sequent to EiY~N: see art. $wY.
$ayiY~N * an imitative sequent to EayiY~N: see $awiY~N.
$ay~aAnu * : see art. $wY.

1 $aA='ahu * , (Msb,) [originally $ayiy^ahu,] like xaAfahu, [which is originally xawifahu,] (MF,) first. pers. $iy^otuhu, (S, K,) aor. ya$aAw^uhu, (Msb,) [and by poetic license ya$aAhu, without ',] first pers. A^a$aAw^uhu, (S. K,) inf. n. $aYo'N (Msb, K) and ma$iyoy^apN, (S, * K,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) and ma$aA='apN and ma$aAy^iyapN, (K,) [or these two also are simple substs.,] He, and I, willed, wished, or desired, it; syn. A^araAdahu (Msb) and A^aradotuhu: (S, * K:) most of the scholastic theologians make no difference between Alma$iyoy^apu and AlA_iraAdapu, though they are [said to be] originally different; for the former, in the proper language, signifies the causing to be or exist, syn. AlA_iyjaAdu; and the latter, the willing, wishing, or desiring; syn. AlT~alabu. (TA.) A Jew objected, to the Prophet, his people's saying maA $aA='a A@ll~`hu wa$iy^otu [What God hath willed and I have willed], as implying the association of another being with God: therefore the Prophet ordered them to say maA $aA='a A@ll~`hu vum~a $iy^otu [What God hath willed, then I have willed]. (TA.) [maA $aA='a A@ll~`hu as signifying What hath God willed! is used to express admiration. And as signifying What God willed it is a phrase often used to denote a vague, generally a great or considerable, but sometimes
a small, number or quantity or time: See De Sacy's Relation de l'Égypte par Abdallatif, pp. 246 and 394 &c.] -A2- See also 1 in art. $wA^

2 $ay~aA^otuhu EalaY AlA^amori * [in some copies of the K (erroneously) $iy^otuhu] I incited him, or made him, to do the thing, or affair. (As, S, L, K, TA.) -A2- And $ay~aA^a A@ll~`hu wajohahu, (K, TA,) and xaloqahu, (TA,) God rendered, or may God render, foul, unseemly, or ugly, his face, (K, TA,) and his make. (TA.)

4 A^a$aA='ahu A_ilayohi *
He, or it, compelled him, constrained him, or necessitated him, to have recourse, or betake himself, to it; syn. A^alojaA^ahu; (S, K;) a dial. var. of A^ajaA='ahu; (S;) of the dial. of Temeem. (TA.) Temeem say, $ar~N maA yu$iyw^uka A_ilaY mux~api EuroquwbK, meaning yujiyw^uka [q. v., i. e. It is an evil thing that compels thee to have recourse to the marrow of a hock]. (S.)

5 t$y~A^ *
His anger became appeased: (K:) said of a man. (TA.)

$aYo'N * [A thing; anything; something; somewhat;] a word of well-known meaning: (K:) [sometimes, in poetry, written and pronounced $aY~N: see an ex. in a verse cited voce Suw^aAbapN: see also the last sentence but one of this paragraph:] Al$~aYo'u properly signifies what may be known, and that whereof a thing may be predicated: (Mgh, KT:) accord. to Sb, it denotes existence, and is a name for anything that has been made to have being, whether an accident, or attribute, or a substance, and such that it may be known, and that a thing may be predicated thereof: (KT:) MF says that it is app. an inf. n. used in the sense of a pass. part. n., meaning what is willed, and meant, or intended, [in which sense ↓ ma$iyoy^apN (pl. ma$iyoA=tN) is often used,] without restriction to its actuality or possibility of being, so that it applies to that which necessarily is, and that which may be, and that which cannot be; accord. to the opinion adopted by the author of the Ksh: [or, as an inf. n. in the sense of a pass. part. n., it may be expl., agreeably with what is said to be the proper meaning of the verb, as signifying what is caused to be or exist; accordingly,] Er-Rághib says that it denotes whatever is caused to be or exist, whether sensibly, as material substances, or ideally, as sayings; and Bd and others expressly assert that it signifies peculiarly what is caused to be or exist; but Sb says that it is the most general of general terms; and some of the scholastic theologians apply it to what is non-existent; such, however, are overcome in their argument by its not being found to have been thus used by the Arabs, and by such passages as kul~u $aYo'K haAlikN A_il~aA wajohahu [Everything is subject to perish except Himself (Kur xxviii. last verse)] and waA_ino mino $aYo'K A_il~aA yusab~iHu biHamodihi [And there is not anything but it glorifies Him with praising (Kur xvii. 46)], for what is nonexistent cannot be described as perishing nor imagined to glorify God: (TA:) the pl. is A^a$oyaA='u, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) imperfectly decl., (Msb, TA,) or rather this is a quasi-pl. n., (Sb, TA,) respecting the formation of which there is much difference of opinion [as will be shown hereafter], (Msb, TA,) and A^a$oyaAwaAtN, (S, K,) a pl. pl. [i. e. pl. of A^a$oyaA='N], (MF, TA,) and A^a$aAwaAtN, [a contraction of that next preceding,] (K,) and A^a$aAwaY, (S, K,) with fet-h to the w, (MF, TA,) and it is also mentioned as with kesr, (TA,) [and is written in both of my copies of the S A^a$aAwaY, though if with kesr it should be either A^a$aAwK or A^a$aAwiY~u, but A^a$aAwaY only is meant by J, as is shown by what here follows,] originally A^a$aAyiY~u, with three Y s, not A^a$aAy^iY~u as J says, [or rather as the word is written in copies of the S, for J may have held it to be A^a$aAy^iY~u or A^a$aAyiYo'u, as he says that the ' was changed into Y thus occasioning the combination of three Ys, so that he held its secondary form to be A^a$aAyiY~u, as will presently be shown,] because the first Y is radical, not augmentative, (IB, K,) the medial Y of the three being suppressed, and the final one changed into A [though written Y], and the initial one changed into w, (S,) and another form of pl. is A^a$aAyaA, (S, Msb, K,) with the Y preserved, not changed into w [as it is in A^a$aAwaY], (TA,) [likewise] a pl. of A^a$oyaA='u, (Msb,) and A^a$ayaAyaA also is mentioned, (K,) as formed [from A^a$oyaA='u] by the change of ' into Y and adding A, (TA,) and A^a$aAwihu, which is strange, (Lh, K,) as there is no h in A^a$ayaA='u, (Lh,) or in $aYo'N: (K:) with respect to the first of these forms, [the quasi-pl. n.] A^a$ayaA='u, the most probable opinion is that of Kh: (Msb, TA:) accord. to him, (S, Msb, K,) it is originally of the measure faEolaA='u, (S, K, *) in lieu of A^afoEaAlN, (K,) and therefore imperfectly decl., (S,) [i. e.] it is originally $ayoy^aA='u, (Msb,) and the two hemzehs combined in the latter portion being found difficult of pronunciation, the former of them is transposed to the beginning of the word, so that it becomes of the measure lafoEaA='u, (S, Msb,) as is shown by its having for its pls. A^a$aAwaY and A^a$aAyaA and A^a$oyaAwaAtN: (S:) accord. to Akh, it is [originally] of the measure A^afoEilaA='u; (S, K;) but if it were thus a broken pl., [not a quasi-pl. n.,] its dim. would not be ↓ A^u$oy~aA='u, as it is, but $uyayoA=tN: (S:) accord. to Ks, it is of the measure A^afoEaAlN, and made imperfectly decl. because of frequency of usage, being likened to faEolaA='u; but were it so, A^abonaA=' and A^asomaA=' would be imperfectly decl.: (S, K:) accord. to Fr, $aYo'N is originally $ay~iy^N, and therefore has a pl. of the measure A^afoEilaA='u, afterwards contracted to faEolaA='u; but were it so, it would not have for its pl. A^a$aAwaY. (S. [Much more respecting this pl. is added in the TA, but it is comparatively unprofitable.]) The dim. of $aYo'N is ↓ $uyaYo'N and ↓ $iyaYo'N; (S, K, TA, but only the former in some copies of the K, the word being written in other copies $uiyaYo'N;) not ↓ $uwaY~N, or ↓ $uwaYo'N; (the former accord. to my two copies of the S and accord. to the copies of the K followed in the TA, in which it is said to be with teshdeed to the Y, and the latter accord. to the CK and my MS. copy of the K;) or this is a dial. var. of weak authority, (K,) used by post-classical poets in their verses. (MF, TA.) ― -b2- When a man says to thee, “ What dost thou desire? ” thou answerest, laA $ayoy^FA [Nothing]: and when he says, “ Why didst thou that? ” thou answerest, lilaA $aYo'K [For nothing]: and when he says, “ What is thine affair? ” thou answerest, laA $aYo'N [Nothing]: it is with tenween in every one of these cases. (As, AHát, TA.) [When one says laA $aYo'a, he means thereby There is nothing.] ― -b3- layosa bi$aYo'K means [It is nought, of no account or weight; it is not worthy of notice, or not worth anything;] it is not a good thing; or it is not a thing to be regarded. (W p. 27.) ― -b4- [layosa mina AlA^amori fiY $aYo'K is a phrase of frequent occurrence, meaning He has no concern with the affair; see two exs. in the first paragraph of art. HwS. ― -b5- fiyhi $aYo'Ki mina AlT~uwli occurs in the TA voce HusobaAnapN, meaning In it is somewhat, or some degree, of length; i. e. it is somewhat long; and is used in the present day in this sense.] ― -b6- In the phrase huwa A^aHosanu minoka $ayoy^FA, the last word is for bi$aYo'K [i. e. He is better than thou in something; meaning he is somewhat better than thou]. (IJ, L.) ― -b7- maA A^agofalahu Eanoka $ayoy^FA is a phrase of the Arabs [app. lit. signifying How unmindful of thee is he as to anything!] mentioned by Sb as meaning daEi Al$~ak~a Eanoka [Dismiss doubt from thee (respecting him as to anything)]: IJ says that $yy^A is here put in the accus. case as an inf. n., as though the saying were maA A^agofalahu Eanoka gufuwlFA, because the verb of wonder does not require to be corroborated by the inf. n. [proper to it]: (L, TA:) [or it is a specificative:] IF says that it is a phrase of dubious meaning; and that the most probable explanation of it is this; that mA is here lit. interrogative, but in meaning denotative of wonder; and that $yy^A is governed in the accus. case by some other word, or phrase, as though the saying were dismiss a thing by which he is not occupied in mind, and dismiss doubt as to his being occupied in mind by it. (TA in art. mA.) ― -b8- [$ayoy^FA fa$ayoy^FA means Thing by thing, part by part, bit by bit, piecemeal, inch by inch, drop by drop, little and little in succession, by little and little, by degrees or gradually.] ― -b9- A^aY~u $aYo'K [meaning What thing?] is, by the alleviation of the Y [in AY~] and the suppression of the ' [in $Y'], made into one word, A^ayo$aYo: so says El-Fárábee: (Msb:) or, [as is commonly the case in the present day,] by reason of frequency of usage, it is contracted into A^ayo$a. (TA in art. jrm, as on the authority of Ks.) ― -b10- $aYo'N in the Kur lx. 11 may mean Any one (Bd, Jel) or more. (Jel.) ― -b11- [It is also applied to (assumed tropical:) The penis of a man; as in the explanation of a phrase mentioned voce *anabN; like as its syn. hanN is to the same and (more commonly) to the “ vulva ” of a woman.] ― -b12- In algebra, it signifies [A square root;] a number that is multiplied into itself; which in arithmetic [and in algebra also] is called j*r [i. e. ja*orN]; and in geometry, DlE [i. e. DiloEN or DilaEN]; (“ Dict. of the Techn. Terms used in the Sciences of the Musalmans, ” p. 202;) an unknown number that is multiplied into itself.
(Idem, p. 730.) -A2- It is also said, on the authority of Lth, to signify Water: and he cites as an ex.,
taraY rakobahu biAl$~aYo'i fiY wasoTi qaforapK
[Thou seest, or wilt see, his company of riders at the water in the midst of a desert]: but AM says, I know not Al$Y' in the sense of “ water, ” nor know I what it is. (TA.) -A3- yaA $aYo'a is an expression of regret, (El-Ahmar, Ks, TA,) or of wonder, (K, TA,) [or of both,] meaning [Oh! or] O my wonder! (Ks, Lh, TA.) One says, yaA $aYo'a maA liY, (El-Ahmar, Ks, Lh, K,) and yaA $aY~a maA liY, i. e. with and without ', (Ks, TA,) and yaA haYo'a maA liY, (Lh, K,) yA haY~a mA lY, and yaA faY~a mA lY, (El-Ahmar, Ks, TA,) neither of these two with ', (Ks, TA,) [meaning Oh! or O my wonder! What has happened to me?] in all of these, (Ks, TA,) mA being in the place of a noun in the nom. case. (Ks, Lh, TA.) ― -b2- Some also say, yaA $aYo'a and yaA haY~a and yaA faY~a, and some add maA, saying, yaA $aYo'a maA and yaA haY~a maA and yaA faY~a maA, meaning How good, or beautiful, is this! (Ks, TA.)

$iyoy^apN * [Will, wish, or desire,] a subst. from $aA='ahu, (Lh, K,) [and] so is ↓ ma$iyoy^apN [which is mentioned in the K as an inf. n.]. (Msb.) One says, kul~u $aYo'K bi$iyoy^api A@ll~`hi, (S, K,) i. e. ↓ bami$iyoy^atihi [Everything is by the will of God]. (S.)
$uyaYo'N * and $iyaYo'N and $uwaY~N or $uwaYo'N: see $aYo'N in the middle of the paragraph.
$ay~iA=nN * and $ay~aA=nN: see art. $wA^.
A^u$ay~aA='u * dim. of A^a$oyaA='u: see $aYo'N, in the latter part of the former half of the paragraph.
ma$iyoy^apN * : see $iyoy^apN, in two places: ― -b2- and see also $aYo'N, near the beginning of the paragraph.

mu$ay~aA^N *
Incongruous, unsound, (K, TA,) foul, or ugly, (TA,) in make, or formation. (K, TA. [See Ham p. 192.]) ― -b2- And accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, A child born preposterously, the legs coming forth before the arms. (TA.)

1 $aAba * , aor. ya$iybu, inf. n. $ayobN and $ayobapN (Msb, TA) and ma$iybN, (TA,) He became whitehaired, or hoary. (Msb, TA.) And $Ab raA^osuhu (S,) and raA^osuhaA, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. $ayobN and $ayobapN, (S,) His head, and her head, became white, or hoary. (S, Msb, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] $aAbato ruw^uwsu AlA=kaAmi (tropical:) [The heads, or summits, of the hills became white, or hoary]. (A.) -A2- And $Ab Alr~aA^osa It whitened the head: so expl. by ISk as used in the following saying, (S,) ascribed by J to 'Adee, but it is of 'Abeed Ibn-El-Abras: (IB, TA:)
taSobuw waA^an~aY laka Alt~aSaAbiY
↓ waAlr~aA^osu qado $aAbahu Alma$iybu
[Thou inclinest to silly and youthful conduct: but whence cometh to thee the inclining to such conduct when hoariness, or the entering upon the period of hoariness, hath whitened the head?]. (S, * IB, TA.) [See also 2.]

2 $y~bhu AlHuzonu * , (Ks, S, A,) and $y~b AlHuzonu raA^osahu, and biraA^osihi, (Ks, S, Msb, K,) which last is a strange phrase, as it exhibits together two means by which a verb is rendered trans., [namely, the doubling of the medial radical letter of the verb and the introduction of the prep. bi,] (TA,) Grief rendered him white-headed, or hoary-headed; (Ks, S, A, Msb, K;) as also ↓ A$Abhu, (A,) and ↓ A$Ab raA^osahu and biraA^osihi. (Ks, S, Msb, K. *)
4 A$Ab * , said of a man, He had children that had become white-headed, or hoary. (S, TA.) -A2- See also the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

$ayobN * The hair (K, TA) itself: sometimes it is thus called: (TA:) [but app. only when white, or hoary; in which sense it is often used; as in the TA in arts. xDb and Sbg &c.:] or (K, TA, in the CK “ and ”) whiteness of the hair, or hoariness; (A, K, TA;) as also ↓ ma$iybN: (K, TA:) both signify the same [and are thus used as simple substs. and are also inf. ns.]: (S:) or the former has the latter of the two significations given above; (As, S, Mgh, Msb;) and is little and much [whiteness of the hair]: one says, EalaAhu Al$~ayobu [Whiteness of the hair, or hoariness, came upon him]: (TA:) but ↓ ma$iybN signifies a man's entering upon the period of whiteness of the hair, or hoariness: (As, S, Msb:) see an ex. of this latter in the first paragraph. In the phrase in the Kur [xix. 3], waA@$otaEala Alr~aA^osu $ayobFA, (S,) meaning And whiteness of the hair of the head hath spread therein like as the radiance of fire spreads in firewood, (Jel,) [or the head has become glistening with whiteness of the hair, or hoariness,] $ybA is in the accus. case as a specificative: or, accord. to Akh, as an inf. n., as though it were said wa$aAba Alr~aA^osu $ayobFA. (S, TA. *)

$iybN * , of a whip, a genuine Arabic word of wellknown meaning; (S;) The thong (K, TA) at the upper extremity (TA) of a whip: (K, TA:) there are two of such thongs, called $iybaAni. (TA.) -A2- Also A word imitative of the sounds made by the lips of camels (S, K) in drinking. (S.) -A3- And pl. of A^a$oyabu [q. v.]. (S, K, &c.)
$uyubN * a pl. of which the sing. is doubted: see A^a$oyabu.

$ayobapN * an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- And accord. to El-Khafájee, A white, or hoary, beard: but MF says that this is a conventional postclassical meaning. (TA.) -A2- [Also, in the present day, applied to A species of artemisia; (Forskål's Flor. Aegypt. Arab., p. lxxiii., no. 439;) the artemisia arborescens of Linn.: (Delile's Flor. Aegypt. Illustr., no. 799:) ― -b2- and Lichen; (Forskål ubi suprà;) the lichen prunastri of Linn. (Delile, ib., no. 976 (assumed tropical:) .) And $ayobapu Aljabali Lichen scyphifer. (Forskål, p. lxxviii., no. 559.)]
$ayobaAnu * : see A^a$oyabu; near the end of the paragraph: ― -b2- and see also the paragraph here following.
