$iybaAnu * and miloHaAnu, (S, A,) thus in a verse of El-Kumeyt, as related by Ibn-Selemeh, with kesr to the $ and m, (S,) or the former word is written ↓ $ayobaAnu, and sometimes $iybaAnu, and the latter is as above, (K,) and sometimes maloHaAnu, (TA,) (tropical:) The two months of winter; (A, TA;) [as though meaning the second of the Six Seasons, commencing two months after the autumnal equinox; (see the former of the two tables in p. 1254;)] i. q. $ahoraA qimaAHK, (S, A, K, TA,) which are the two coldest months; (S, K, TA;) so called because of the earth's being then white with snow and hoar frost; (S, TA;) falling at the period of the [auroral] rising of the Scorpion and the Vulture, (AlEaqorab and Aln~asor, [by which latter is meant Aln~asoru AlwaAqiEu, i. e. the star a of Lyra,]) said by him who knows not to be the two Kánoons [i. e. kaAnuwnu AlA^aw~alu and kaAnuwnu Alv~aAniY, corresponding to December and January O.S.]: (TA:) [it appears that they nearly agree with the two Kánoons; for El-Kazweenee and others say that Alqalobu (i. e. the heart of the Scorpion, which is the 18th of the Mansions of the Moon,) and Aln~asoru AlwaAqiEu rise together, and their auroral rising in Central Arabia, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, accord. to my calculation, (see manaAzilu Alqamari in art. nzl,) was on the 25th of November O. S.: see also miloHaAnu, and qimaAHN: it is also said that] $iybaAnu [used alone] is a name of [the month] kAnwn AlAw~l, because of the whiteness of the earth by reason of the hoar-frost and snow. (Mgh.)
$iyaAbN * and $iyaAbapN [the former erroneously written by Golius $ay~aAbN]: see $awobN, in art. $wb.
$ayuwbN * : see A^a$oyabu.

$aAy^ibN * [Being, or becoming, white-haired, or hoary]: see A^a$oyabu. ― -b2- $ayobN $aAy^ibN is a phrase like layolN laAy^ilN, (S,) or like $iEorN $aAEirN: it means Intense whiteness of the hair. (TA.)

A^a$oyabu *
White-haired, white-headed, or horary: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) [it is said to be] anomalous in form; (S, Mgh, Msb;) for an epithet of this measure is only formed [by rule] from a verb of the measure faEila, aor. yafoEalu; (S, TA;) and it is a condition of the formation of such an epithet that it must denote a defect or the like, or a colour: but A^a$oyabu signifies white-headed, or hoaryheaded; [so that it does denote a colour;] and ElKhafájee says that it is reckoned among epithets denoting defects, or blemishes, like A^aEomaY and A^aEoraju: (MF, TA:) it is said in the K that it has no faEolaA=', i. e., (TA,) the epithet $ayobaA='u is not applied to a woman; (Msb, TA;) $amoTaA='u being used in its stead; (TA;) though one says $aAba raA^osuhaA: (Msb, TA:) [but see Har p. 418, where $ayobaA='u is mentioned, applied to a woman, as meaning aged, and white, or hoary, in the head: and see $ayobaA='u in art. $wb:] the pl. is $iybN; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) with which is syn. $uy~abN; (TA, as from the K; [but not found by me in the copies of the K to
which I have had access;]) and ↓ $uyubN: (K, TA:) this last is said by IM to be allowable in poetry, EalaY Alt~amaAmi [here meaning as though it were a word composed of sound letters]; and this is the assertion of the lexicologists [in general]: ISd thinks it to be pl. of ↓ $aAy^ibN [q. v.], like as buzulN is of baAzilN; or pl. of ↓ $ayuwbN [which app. means very white or hoary in the head], accord. to the dial. of the people of El-Hijáz, who say dajaAjapN bayuwDN and dajaAjN buyuDN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, raA^ayotu AljibaAla $iybFA (tropical:) I saw the mountains white with snow and hoar frost. (A, TA.) And $iybN [used alone] signifies (assumed tropical:) Mountains upon which snow falls, and which are white, or hoary, therewith: (S, L:) or mountains white with snow or with dust: and, some say, white clouds: sing. A^a$oyabu. (L, TA.) And, applied to truffles (kamoA^ap), (assumed tropical:) White and large: (TA:) or simply white. (Id. voce taEaA$iybu.) ― -b3- yawomN A^a$oyabu (assumed tropical:) A day in which are cold and clouds and SuraAd [correctly Sur~aAd, meaning thin clouds, or cold and humid clouds, in which is no water]; as also ↓ yawomN $ayobaAnu. (K.) ― -b4- layolapu Al$~ayobaA='i, (K,) or layolapu $ayobaA='a, (TA,) and layolapN $ayobaA='u, (TA voce Hur~N,) (assumed tropical:) The last night of the [lunar] month: (K, TA:) its first night is called layolapu Hur~apK and layolapN Hur~apN. (K voce Hur~N.) baAtato bilayolapi $ayobaA='a, and bilayolapi Al$~ayobaA='i: see in art. $wb.
ma$iybN * : see $ayobN, in two places.

1 $aAHa * : see 4. ― -b2- [Also, accord. to Freytag, on the authority of the “ Kitáb el-Addád, ” He was brave, or bold: thus having two contr. significations. ― -b3- Another meaning assigned to it by him, in common with $aAyaHa and A^a$aAHa, as on the authority of the K, i. e. “ Diligens fuit, ” is a mistake.]

2 $y~Hhu * , (O,) inf. n. ta$oyiyHN, (K,) He cautioned him; or made him to fear, or be in fear. (O, K. *) ― -b2- And He removed him, or it, far away. (O.) -A2- And $y~H, (O, TA,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He looked at his adversary, or antagonist, and straitened him, or treated him with hardness or harshness: (O, K, * TA:) from IAar. (TA.)
3 $aAoyaHa see the next paragraph, in two places. ― -b2- Also He fought. (T, K.)

4 A$AH * , (S, A, K,) inf. n. A_i$aAHapN, (IAar, TA,) He was cautious, or in fear, (S, A, K,) minohu [of it], (A, TA,) i. e. a thing, or an affair, (TA,) and EalaY HaAjatihi [for the thing that he wanted]; (K;) as also ↓ $AyH, (S, A, K,) inf. mu$aAyaHapN and $iyaAHN; and ↓ $aAHa: (K:) or he was cautious and in fear, endeavouring to repel death. (L.) ― -b2- But in the dial. of Hudheyl, (S,) He strove, laboured, toiled, or exerted himself, fiY A^amorK [in an affair]; and so ↓ $AyH. (S, A.) ― -b3- And He continued journeying, or going on. (O.) ― -b4- A$AH biwajohihi He turned away his face, (S, A, TA,) from a [person or] thing, or from the heat of fire, or a hot odour, and from something hurtful: (TA:) or he exerted himself in aversion or turning away. (IAar, TA.) One says, kal~amotuhu faA^a$aAHa biwajohihi I spoke to him, and he turned away his face. (A.) ― -b5- A$AH also signifies He advanced, or came forward; syn. A^aqobala. (Fr, O, TA.) [Thus it has two contr. meanings. See also the part. n., mu$iyHN.] ― -b6- And He defended what was behind his back. (IAth, TA.) [See, again, the part. n.] ― -b7- A$AH bi*anabihi, said of a horse, He let his tail hang down loosely. (Lth, S.) F, in the K, following Az and Sgh, says that this is a mistranscription of the verb, for AsAH; but his assertion requires proof. (MF.) [See the latter verb, in art. syH.] -A2- A$AHt AlA^aroDu The land produced the plant called $iyH. (AHn, O, K.)

$iyHN *
Cautious, or fearing; (A, K;) as also ↓ $aAy^iHN, (A, TA,) and ↓ mu$iyHN: (As, O:) or this last, cautious, or fearing, and at the same time striving, labouring, toiling, or exerting himself: (Az, TA:) or all signify prudent; discreet; or having, or using, precaution, or good judgment; (Ham p. 281;) and so ↓ $ayoHaAnu. (Id. p. 43.) ― -b2- In the dial. of Hudheyl, (S, O,) Striving, labouring, toiling, or exerting himself, (S, A, O, K,) in affairs; (S, O, K;) and so ↓ $aAy^iHN, (A, K,) and ↓ mu$iyHN: (As, O, K:) pl. of the first [and app. of the second also] $iyaAHN: (S, O.) -A2- Also [The artemisia Judaïca; and absinthium Ponticum; species of wormwood;] a certain plant, (AHn, S, A, O, K,) well known, (AHn, O, K,) of several species, (AHn, O,) of some [species] whereof brooms are made, (L,) [and which is also used for fumigation,] the leaves of which are [of the kind called] hadab; (AHn, O, L;) it has a sweet odour, but its taste is bitter; is pasture for horses and camels; and the places of its growth are the plains and the meadows: (AHn, O, L:) pl. $iyHaAnN. (Fr, O, L.) -A3- Accord. to the K, [probably on the authority of Lth,] it signifies also A [garment of the kind called] burod, of El-Yemen: but Az says that there is no kind of garment so called: the correct word is sayoHN, with [the unpointed] s [and with fet-h]. (TA.)

$ayoHaAnu * [and probably with tenween also]: see $iyHN. ― -b2- Also Very jealous; (S, O, K;) because such is cautious for his wives, or women under covert, or household or family; (S, O;) and so ↓ $aAy^iHN. (K.) ― -b3- Also, (O, K,) and ↓ $iyHaAnN, (As, O, K,) Tall: (O, K:) or goodly in tallness. (L.) ― -b4- And the former, That makes, or utters, a low sound in running; [so I render yataham~asu EadowFA in the K and TA; in the O and in my MS. copy of the K, yataham~a$u; but the former I think the right reading; app. by reason of quickness, or swiftness; for it is added,] quickness, or swiftness, is meant thereby: (O, TA: *) mentioned by Az, on the authority of Khálid Ibn-Jembeh. (TA.) [In this sense it seems to be with tenween: for] $ayoHaAnapN [is its fem. and] means A quick, or swift, she-camel. (S, O.) ― -b5- Also A horse strong in spirit; syn. $adiydu Aln~afosi; (O, K, TA; in the CK, Aln~afasi [i. e. in breath];) and so ↓ $iyHaAnN: thus expl. by Skr. (O.)
$iyHaAnN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

$iyaAHN *
Mutual caution or fear. (And The act of striving, labouring, toiling, or exerting oneself, in anything. (K.) [But in both of these senses it seems to be an inf. n. of 3, q. v.] -A2- Also (K) Drought, dearth, scarcity. (O, K.)
$aAy^iHN * : see $iyHN, in two places: ― -b2- and see also $ayoHaAnu.

mu$iyHN * : see $iyHN, in two places. It is also expl. as meaning Striving, labouring, toiling, or exerting himself, and persevering in his work: (A:) and striving &c., and hastening, or going quickly. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Advancing, or coming forward, to one. (Fr, O, K.) ― -b3- And Defending what is behind one's back. (Fr, O, K.)
mu$ay~aHN * is expl. as meaning Striped; applied to a garment: but Az says that there is no such word, so applied: the correct word is musay~aHN, with [the unpointed] s. (TA.)
ma$iyHaY * : see the following paragraph.
ma$iyHaA=' * : see the following paragraph.
ma$oyuwHaY * : see the following paragraph.

ma$oyuwHaA='u * (S, O, K) and ↓ ma$iyHaY (O, K) A state of haste: (S, O, K:) or a state of confusion: (K:) the latter meaning mentioned in the L: (TA:) you say, humo fiY ma$oyuwHaA='a mino A^amorihimo (S, O, K) and fY ma$iyHaY mn Amrhm (O, K) They are in a state of haste in respect of their affair: (S, O, K:) or in a state of confusion in their affair: (L, K:) as having the latter meaning, Ibn-Málik says that it is ma$iyjaA=', with j and medd, of the measure faEiylaA=', not mafoEilaA='; but this requires consideration: Ibn-Umm-Málik and others, following AHei, say that ↓ Alqawomu fiY ma$iyHaA='a mino A^amorihimo means the people, or party, are in a state of striving, labour, toil, or exertion, and determination, or resolution, in respect of their affair. (TA.) -A2- ma$oyuwHaA='u also signifies A land that produces the plant called $iyH; (S, O, K;) and so ↓ ma$oyuwHaY: (O, K:) or it signifies many plants of the kind so called: thus in the T, on the authority of As and A 'Obeyd, and so says AHn, as is stated [in the O and] in the R; (TA;) AHn saying further that it is like ma$oyuwxaA=' meaning a company of $uyuwx [or elderly men], and maEoyuwraA=' meaning a herd of Euyuwr [or asses], &c.; (O;) [so that it is a quasi-pl. n.;] but this is disallowed by El-Mufaddal Ibn-Selemeh. (TA.)

1 $aAxa * , (S, A, Msb, K,) aor. ya$iyxu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. $ayaxN, with fet-h to the Y, (S, K,) and
$uyuwxapN (K) and $iyuwxapN (TA) and $uyuwxiy~apN (K) and $iyuwxiy~apN (Zbd, TA) and $ayoxuwxapN [the most common form, respecting which see what follows,] (S, A, Msb, K) and $ayoxuwxiy~apN; (K;) and ↓ $y~x, inf. n. ta$oyiyxN; (S, A, K;) and ↓ t$y~x; (K;) He became a $ayox [i. e. an old, or elderly, man; &c.]: (S, A, Msb, K:) in $ayoxuwxapN, the Y is originally movent [with fet-h], and afterwards made quiescent, for there is not in the language a word of the measure faEoluwlN [except SaEofuwqN, as is said in the S in art. Hyd]: as to the similar words whose medial radical letter is w, as kayonuwnapN and qayoduwdapN and dayomuwmapN and hayoEuwEapN, these are originally kay~anuwnapN [for kayowanuwnapN, of the measure fayoEaluwlapN,] and the like, and are contracted; for were it not so, they would be kawonuwnapN and the like. (S, L.)

2 $y~x * : see the preceding paragraph. -A2- $y~xhu, (S, K,) inf. n. ta$oyiyxN, (TA,) He called him by the appellation of $ayox, to pay him honour, or respect. (S, K, TA.) -A3- And $y~x Ealayohi He attributed or imputed to him, or charged him with, a vice, or fault; blamed, or reproached, him; (K, TA;) cast a bad, an evil, a foul, or an excessively bad or evil or foul, imputation upon him. (TA.) And $y~x bihi [and so $y~xhu accord. to an explanation of $ay~axotu Alrjl, as on the authority of AZ, in the TA, but this may be a mistranscription for $y~xt biAlr~ajuli,] He exposed his vices, faults, or evil actions; disgraced him; or put him to shame. (K, TA.)
5 t$y~x * : see 1. ― -b2- [It signifies also] He feigned, or made a show of, old age. (KL.)

$ayoxN * (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb, K, &c.) and ↓ $ayoxuwnN, (K,) but the latter is a strange word, mentioned by some of the expositors of the Fs, as expressing more than the former word, (MF,) [An old, or elderly, man; an elder, as meaning a man whose age gives him a claim to reverence or respect; a senior;] one advanced in age, (Mgh,) such as is beyond him who is termed kaholN, (Mgh, Msb,) which means him whose $abaAb [i. e. youthfulness, or prime of manhood,] is ended: (Mgh:) one in whom age has become apparent, (L, K,) and hoariness: (L:) or a man from the age of fifty, or fifty-one, to the end of his life, or to the age of eighty: (L, K:) also expl. as meaning a man advanced in age but having strength, or vigour, to fight: and an old and weak, or a decrepit, man, who is of no service: (Mgh:) [in the present day, $ayoxN is used in the senses above mentioned; and is also especially applied, as an appellation of honour, to a doctor of religion and law; a head, or chief, of a religious confraternity; a chief of a tribe or the like, and of a village; and to a reputed saint:] fem. ↓ $ayoxapN, (S, A, Msb, K,) an old, or aged, woman; syn. EajuwzN: (A:) [and applied in the present day particularly to a learned woman; an instructress; and the like:] the pl. [of pauc.] of $ayoxN is A^a$oyaAxN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and $iyxapN (Kr, ISd, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and [of mult.] $uyuwxN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and $iyuwxN (K, with kesr, to agree with the Y, TA) and $iyxaAnN (S, A, Msb, K) and $iyaxapN (S, Mgh, K) and $ayaxapN (A [there said to be like EabadapN]) and ↓ ma$oyaxapN, (K, and so in one of my copies of the S,) or this last is a quasi-pl. n., (Mgh, Msb,) and [so are] ↓ mi$oyaxapN and ↓ ma$oyuxapN and ↓ mi$oyuxapN (TA) and ↓ ma$iyxapN (K, and so in one of my copies of the S,) and ↓ ma$oyuwxaA='u, (S, K,) the last like ma$oyuwHaA='u and maEoluwjaA='u and masoluwmaA='u and maEobuwdaA='u and maEoyuwraA='u, which are said to be the only other instances of this form, (TA,) [but to these should be added maHomuwraA='u and makobuwraA='u and matoyuwsaA='u and perhaps some other instances,] and ↓ ma$oyuxaA='u, (K,) and another pl. is ↓ ma$aAyixu, (S, A, K,) or this last is pl. of ma$oyaxapN, (Mgh, Msb,) and is disallowed by IDrd and Kz (TA) [though very commonly used in the present day, especially as applied to doctors of religion and law]; and the pl. of A^a$oyaAxN is A^a$aAyiyxu, like A^anaAyiybu pl. of A^anoyaAbN: (Z, TA:) the dim. of $ayoxN is ↓ $uyayoxN (S, A, K) and ↓ $iyayoxN, (S, K,) with kesr to the $: (S:) ↓ $uwayoxN is not allowable, (S, A,) or is rare. (K.) ― -b2- [Al$~ayoxaAni, The two Sheykhs, is a title peculiarly applied to the first two Khaleefehs, Aboo-Bekr and 'Omar.] ― -b3- $ayoxN also signifies (assumed tropical:) A woman's husband, (K,) though young: and in like manner, a man's wife, whether old or young, is called his Eajuwz. (Az, TA in art. Ejz.) ― -b4- [And (tropical:) An ancestor. Accord. to a copy of the A that seems to have been used by the author of the TA, one says, wariva mino ma$iyxapi Alkaram and mn A^a$oyaAxihi, which is tropical, meaning mino A=baAy^ihi: but the right reading is evidently ↓ mn ma$iyxatihi, and Alkarama; and the meaning, (tropical:) He inherited, from his ancestors, generosity.] ― -b5- $ayoxu Aln~aAri means (tropical:) Iblees: because he was created of fire, or because his ultimate place will be the fire of Hell. (Har p. 130.) ― -b6- And Al$~ayoxu (assumed tropical:) The mountain-goat that is advanced in age, or fullgrown. (TA.) ― -b7- And (assumed tropical:) The milk-skin. (TA.) ― -b8- A^a$oyaAxu Aln~ujuwmi i. q. A^uSuwluhaA, (K,) i. e. (assumed tropical:) The seven [or five] planets; (TK;) or the daraAriYo' [also applied by some to the five planets, Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn]; accord. to IAar, A$yAx Alnjwm, (TA in this art.,) or A^asonaAxu Aln~ujuwmi as is related by Th, (TA in art. snx,) means the stars that do not make their [temporary] abode in the Mansions of the Moon, which [latter] are called nujuwmu AlA^axo*i: ISd says, I think that he means, by the njwm, the fixed stars: Th says that they are called only A^asonaAxu Aln~ujuwmi, i. e. the A^uSuwl thereof, around which the [other] stars revolve, and pursue their courses. (TA. [See also sinoxN, last sentence.]) -A2- $ayoxN signifies also A certain tree; (AZ, K, TA;) also called $ajarapu Al$~uyuwxi, the fruit of which is a jirow [q. v.] like that of the xir~iyE, which is the bastard saffron ($ajarapu AlEuSofuri); it grows in the meadows, and the quroyaAn [or places where water runs to, or in, or into, meadows, &c.]. (AZ, TA.)
$ayoxapN * fem. of $ayoxN, q. v. (S, A, Msb, K.)
$ayoxuwnN * : see $ayoxN.
$uyayoxN * and $iyayoxN and $uwayoxN: dims. of $ayoxN, q. v.
ma$oyaxapN * and mi$oyaxapN &c.; and the pl. ma$aAyixu: see $ayoxN, in seven places.
ma$oyuxaA='u * : see $ayoxN.
ma$oyuwxaA='u * : see $ayoxN.

1 $aAdahu * , aor. ya$iydu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. $ayodN, (S,) He plastered it (a wall) with $iyd, (S, K,) i. e. gypsum, or the like: (K:) he built it (a structure) with $iyd, meaning gypsum. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 2. ― -b3- $aAduwA Ald~iyna (assumed tropical:) They strengthened and exalted the religion: from $aAda in the first of the senses expl. above: (Har p. 5:) [or rather from this verb as syn. with $ay~ada and A^a$aAda.] ― -b4- See also 4. ― -b5- As inf. n. of $aAda in the phrase $aAda biAlA_ibili, aor. as above, (TK,) $iyaAdN signifies (assumed tropical:) The calling camels, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K, TA,) as also ↓ A_i$aAdapN, (Ibn-'Abbád, O,) raising the voice in doing so. (TA.) ― -b6- Also, (K,) as inf. n. of the same verb, (TK,) (assumed tropical:) The rubbing perfume with the skin; (K;) as also ↓ ta$ay~udN; in some copies of the K, ↓ ta$oyiydN: (TA:) [the former of these two seems to be the right; and the meaning seems to be, the rubbing the skin with perfume; for,] accord. to AA, one says bih`*aA AlT~iybi ↓ ta$ay~ado, meaning Rub thy skin with this perfume. (O.) -A2- $aAda, (said of a man, TA,) aor. as above, (K,) inf. n. $ayodN, (TA,) also signifies He perished, or died. (K.)

2 $y~dhu * , (A, L, Msb, TA,) inf. n. ta$oyiydN, (L, Msb, TA,) He raised it high; (A, Msb, TA;) namely, a palace, (A,) or a building; (Msb, TA;) as also ↓ A$Adhu, (A, L, TA,) and ↓ $aAdahu: (A: [this last is app. included with the two other verbs, in the A, as having this meaning, which is confirmed, as pertaining to it, by an explanation of its pass. part. n., ma$iydN, q. v.:]) or $y~dhu [implies a repetition of the act of building: (see ma$iydN:) or] signifies he built it firmly, or strongly, and raised it high. (L.) ― -b2- See also 1.

4 A$Adhu * : see 2. ― -b2- Hence, (L,) A_i$aAdapN signifies (tropical:) The raising the voice in saying a thing (Lth, S, L, K) [of any kind, or] such as one's companion dislikes; like tanodiydN. (Lth, L.) See also 1. You say, A$Ad Sawotahu and biSawotihi (tropical:) He raised his voice. (A.) And A$Ad bihi (tropical:) He proclaimed it, or cried it, raising his voice; namely, a stray, or any other thing: (As, L:) (tropical:) he made it known; (AA, S, A,
K; *) namely, a stray. (S, K.) And A$Ad bi*ikorihi (tropical:) He raised his good fame, by praising him; raised a good report of him: (S, * A, L:) and he raised his ill fame, by dispraising him; raised an evil report of him: and A$Adhu and ↓ $aAdahu he raised his notoriety or fame. (L.) And A$Ad Ealayohi (tropical:) He published against him something disliked, disapproved, or odious: one says, A$Ad Ealayohi qabiyHFA and biqabiyHK (tropical:) [He published against him something bad, evil, abominable, or foul]. (A.) ― -b3- And A_i$aAdapN also signifies (tropical:) The act of destroying: (K, TA:) from the same word as syn. with tanodiydN. (TA.)
5 ta$ay~ada see 1, in two places.
$ayodN * , a Pers. word, [or rather of Pers. origin, from $ayodaA,] Possessed; or mad, or insane: or intoxicated. (TA.)

$iydN *
Anything with which a wall is plastered, (S, A, K,) consisting of gypsum and the like; (A, K;) J says, of gypsum or balaAT; but this last word is a mistake, [probably originated by an early transcriber of the S,] for milaAT, i. e. mud, or clay: (K:) or [peculiarly] gypsum. (Msb.) ― -b2- Az says that some of the Arabs sometimes call thus A HiSon [i. e. fortress, fort, or fortified place]. (TA.)

ma$iydN *
Plastered with $iyd; and so, as some say, ↓ mu$ay~adN: (T:) or built with gypsum: (Msb:) or made with $yd, (S, A, K,) i. e. gypsum; and so, some say, ↓ mu$ay~adN: (A:) or the latter signifies raised high, or made lofty; (A 'Obeyd, S, A, K;) and so the former, applied to a place, (A,) or building: (TA:) the former has this meaning in the Kur xxii. 44: (Jel:) J says in the S, Ks says, ma$iydN is applied to a sing., from the saying in the Kur, [ubi suprà,] waqaSorK ma$iydK; and ↓ mu$ay~adN, to a pl., from the saying in the same, [iv. 80,] fiY buruwjK mu$ay~adapK: but this is a mistake: what Ks says is that mu$ay~adapN, with p and teshdeed, is a pl. [i. e. a lexicological, not a grammatical, pl.] of mu$ay~adN: (IB, K: *) or the saying of Ks [if as quoted in the S] may be expl. accord. to the opinion of those who hold that ma$iydN and mu$ay~adN both signify plastered with $iyd, on the supposition that the Arabs did not use ma$iydapN as applied to a pl., but only to a sing.: (Az, L:) [for] Fr says that the pass. part. n. of the unaugmented verb only is used when applied to a sing. and not denoting repetition, or muchness; but either this or the pass. part. n. of the verb of the measure faE~ala may be used when applied to a sing. and denoting repetition, or muchness, and when applied to a pl.: thus you say kabo$N ma*obuwHN [“ a slaughtered ram ”]; but not mu*ab~aHN; but you may say vawobN muxar~aqN [as meaning “ a garment in which holes have been repeatedly made, ” or “ in which many holes have been made, ” or “ much pierced with holes, ” as well as vawobN maxoruwqN meaning “ a garment in which a hole has been made, ” or “ in which holes have been made, ”] and kibaA$N mu*ab~aHapN [“ slaughtered rams ”]: and hence you may say ↓ qaSorN mu$ay~adN; because ta$oyiydN denotes building, and the act of building is repeated, and a building becomes high by degrees. (L.)
mu$ay~adN * : see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.
6 t$Ayr * : see 6 in art. $wr.
$iyarN * : n. un. with p: pl. of the latter $iyaraAtN: and dim. $uyayorapN and $iyayorapN: see $ajarN.
$iyaArN * : see art. $wr.
$ay~irN * : see art. $wr.

$iyzN * and ↓ $iyzaY A kind of black wood, of which bowls (qiSaAE) are made: (S, K:) or the latter is a certain black wood of which combs and bowls (jifaAn) are made: (Mgh:) or ebony: or saAsam [a certain wood of which bows or arrows are made]: (AA, K:) or walnut-wood: (As, EdDeenäwaree [AHn], Mgh, K:) As says of the $yzY, by the name of which the Arabs call bowls (jfAn and qSAE) and the sheaves of pulleys, that it is walnut-wood, but it becomes blackened by grease, and therefore is thus called, and it is not $yz: so says AHn: and he adds, the case is as he has described it; for the $yz does not become thick so as that bowls may be carved from it: (Sgh, TA:) of this latter, only combs and the like are made; and it is black: it is also said, in the T, that bowls made from the walnut-tree are called $iyzaY. (TA.)
$iyzaY * : see the preceding paragraph.

4 A$A$t Aln~axolapu *
The palm-tree produced dates such as are termed $iy$. (O, K.)

$iy$N * and ↓ $iy$aA='N A sort of dates which do not organize and compact stones; (Fr, O, K;) or, if they do so, they do not become hard; and when they dry, they become such as are termed Ha$af, not sweet: (O, K:) dial. vars. of $iySN and $iySaA='N: (S:) accord. to AHn, (TA,) of Persian origin. (O, TA.)
$iy$aA='N * : see the next preceding paragraph.
2 $ay~aSa see the next paragraph.

4 A$ASt Aln~axolapu *
The palm-tree was not fecundated by the flowers, or pollen, of the male tree: (A, K:) or its dates dried up: and it bore dates such as are termed $iyS: (Msb:) or it became bad, and its dates became such as are termed $yS; (TA;) as also ↓ $y~St. (Kr, TA.)

5 t$y~S Alt~amoru *
The dates became such as are termed $iyS. (S.)

$iySN *
Dates of which the stones do not become hard; as also ↓ $iySaA='N; (S, A, K;) which is only the case when the palm-tree has not been fecundated by the flowers, or pollen, of the male tree: (S:) and sometimes, having no stones: (Fr, TA:) or bad dates: (A:) or the worst of dates; (IF, Msb, K;) as also ↓ the latter word: (Msb:) or the worst of dates when full-grown but unripe: (Lth, TA:) called in the dial. of Belhárith Ibn-Kaab, SiySN; and by the people of El-Medeeneh, sux~alN: (El-Umawee, TA:) and said by some to be a Persian word, arabicized: (TA:) n. un. with p; (A, Msb, K;) i. e., $iySapN and $iySaA='apN. (A, Msb.)
$iySaA='N * : n. un. with p: see $iySN, in two places.

1 $aATa * , (S, Msb, K,) aor. ya$iyTu, (Msb, K,) inf. n. $ayoTN and $iyaATapN (K) and $ayoTuwTapN, (Lth, K,) It (a thing, Msb, TA, or, as some say, particularly, olive-oil, and rob, TA) burned, or became burnt; (Msb, K, TA;) as also ↓ t$y~T, (K,) said of flesh-meat: (TA:) or both, said of flesh-meat, signify its upper part became burnt by the contact of fire: (Lth, TA:) the latter is also said of wool; and the former likewise, of wool, and of hair: (TA:) the former also signifies it was near to becoming burnt: (TA:) and, said of clarified butter, and of olive-oil, (S, K,) it became cooked so much that it burned; (S;) because, in that case, it perishes; (O;) [which implies that a signification hereafter to be mentioned is held to be the primary one;] or became thick; or became cooked so much that it almost perished. (K.) You say also, $aATati Alqidoru The cooking-pot burned, and had something sticking in it: (S:) or had something burnt sticking in the bottom of it. (O, K.) ― -b2- $aATa, (S, K,) aor. as above, (S,) also signifies He (a man) perished, or died. (S, K.) [The art. in the S commences with this signification, which, as remarked above, seems to be regarded by some as the primary one.] ― -b3- Also He burned with anger. (TA in art. $Tn.) ― -b4- And It was, or became, null, void, of no account, or of no force. (Msb, TA.) ― -b5- His (a man's) blood, (S,) or it, (his blood,) (Mgh, Msb, K,) went (S, Mgh, Msb, K) for nothing, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct; it was, or became, of no account. (S, Mgh, * Msb.) ― -b6- And It (any- thing) went away; ― -b7- $aATati Aljazuwru (tropical:) The slaughtered camel became dispensed; syn. tanaf~aqat; (S, K, TA;) there remained not of it any portion that was not divided and given: (As, S:) and $aATa laHomu Aljazuwri The flesh of the slaughtered camel went away divided and distributed, nothing thereof remaining. (A, TA.) ― -b8- $aATa also signifies (tropical:) He hastened (S, K, TA) in an affair. (K, TA.) -A2- [$aATahu seems to be dial. var. of saATahu, as signifying He mixed it. ― -b2- And hence,] $aATa Ald~imaA='a (tropical:) He mixed the bloods; as though he shed, or poured forth, the blood of the slayer upon that of the slain. (S, K, TA.) A poet, (S,) namely, El-Mutalemmis, (TA,) uses the expression lawo tu$aATu dimaAw^unaA [If our bloods were
mixed]; (S, TA;) accord. to one relation; but accord. to another, the verb is with s. (TA.) ― -b3- $aATa bidamihi: see 4.
2 $ay~aTa see the next paragraph, in five places.

4 A$AThu * , (Msb, K,) inf. n. A_i$aATapN, (Msb,) He burned it, or made it to burn; (Msb, K;) namely, a thing, (Msb,) as, for instance, olive-oil; (TA;) as also ↓ $y~Thu, (K,) inf. n. ta$oyiyTN. (TA.) ↓ The latter also signifies He burned its wool, namely, that of a sheep, in order to cleanse it; and so $w~Thu: (S, TA:) and each of these, he (a cook) set it on fire, namely the foot of a bull or cow, or of a sheep or goat, and the head, so that what was upon it, of hair, or wool, became burnt. (TA.) You say also, $AT Alqidora He made the cooking-pot to burn, and to have something sticking in it. (S.) And Alqidora ↓ $y~T He made the cooking-pot to boil; as also $w~ThA. (ElKilábee.) And All~aHoma ↓ $y~T He cooked thoroughly the flesh-meat; as also $w~Thu: (Ibn-'Abbád:) or he smoked it, or made it smoky, and did not thoroughly cook it; (S;) and so the latter. (TA in art. $wT.) And AlD~abuEu Aln~abota ↓ $y~T; and Ald~awaA='u AljuroHa; (tropical:) The year of drought burned the herbage; and the medicine, the wound. (A, TA:) [See also $aw~aTa.] ― -b2- Also, (K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) He destroyed him, or it. (S, K.) ― -b3- A$AT damahu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and bidamihi, (S, K,) He (the Sultán, Mgh, Msb) made his blood to go for nothing, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct; made it to be of no account: (Mgh, Msb, K, * TA:) or the latter, (TA,) or both, (K,) he laboured to destroy him, or to kill him: (K, TA:) or both, he exposed him to slaughter: (S, K:) or, accord. to IAmb, you say, bidamihi ↓ $aATa, meaning he exposed him to destruction. (TA.) You say also, A$AT dama Aljazuwri He shed the blood of the camel that was to be slaughtered. (As, K.) ― -b4- A$AT All~aHoma (tropical:) He distributed the flesh, (K, TA,) i. e. the flesh of a slaughtered camel: (TA:) or A$AT Aljazuwra he dispensed the last remaining portion of the slaughtered camel, after all beside had been distributed. (S, TA.) Also (assumed tropical:) He cut up, or cut in pieces, the flesh of the slaughtered camel before the distribution. (ISh.)
5 ta$ay~aTa see 1, first sentence.

10 Ast$AT * (tropical:) He became inflamed by anger; Ealayohi against him: (K, TA:) or he became as though he were inflamed in his anger; accord. to As, from mi$oyaATN as applied to a she-camel: (S, TA:) [or] he burned, and became inflamed, by vehement anger. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He (a man, TA) became brisk, or sharp; (K, * TA;) he burned; (TA;) mina AlA^amori by reason of the thing, or affair. (K, TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) It (a pigeon) flew briskly. (K, TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) He sought to be slain in war or fight. (TA.) ― -b5- (tropical:) He became at the point of destruction. (TA.) ― -b6- (tropical:) He (a camel) became fat: (S, TA:) [as though he desired, or demanded, that he should be slaughtered, and that his flesh should be distributed:] or fatness spread in him. (TA.)

$ayoTaAn * [i. e. $ayoTaAnN or $ayoTaAnu, accord. to different authorities, as shown below, A devil; and with the article Al, the devil, Satan;] is, accord. to some, from $aATa, (Msb, K, TA,) as signifying “ it was, or became, null, void, of no account; ” and the like: (Msb, TA:) or “ he perished: ” (K, TA:) or “ he went away: ” or “ it burned, ” or “ became burnt: ” two reasons given for this derivation are, that among the names of the devil are Almu*ohabu and AlbaATilu: and another is this; that several read, in the Kur xxvi. 210, Al$~ayaATuwna [instead of Al$~ayaATiynu]: but some say that it is from $aTana, signifying “ he became distant, ” or “ remote: ” Sb gives both of these derivations: respecting the former of which, it should be observed that if from $AT as signifying “ it burned, ” or “ became burnt, ” it is proper; but if from the same in any of the other senses mentioned above, it is tropical: and if belonging to this art., it is imperfectly decl., being of the measure faEolaAn: (S in art. $Tn, in which see it:) [but in the Kur-án it is always perfectly decl.: and SM says that] it is perfectly decl., unless used as a proper name; in the latter case being imperfectly decl. (TA.)
$iyaATN * The smell of a piece of cotton burning, or burnt. (S, K.) -A2- See also mi$oyaATN.

$aAy^iTN * and $aATK, like haAy^irN and haArK, [the latter being formed by transposition from the former, $aATK and haArK being for $aATiYN and haAriYN,] Flesh-meat [&c.] burning, or being burnt. (TA.)

ta$oyiyTN *
Flesh-meat roasted, (K,) or made good, and roasted, (TA,) for a company of men: (K:) a subst., like tamotiynN. (K, TA.) [In the CK, for AisomN kaAlt~amotiyni, we find wAsmN kAlt~amotiyni.]

mi$oyaATN * (tropical:) A she-camel that quickly becomes fat: (As, S, A, K:) applied also to a he-camel: (TA:) pl. ma$aAyiyTu; (S, K;) in some of the copies of the S, ma$aAyiTu: and you say also ↓ A_ibilN $yAT [app. a mistake for mi$oyaATN, which is fem., like A_ibilN, as well as masc.]: AA says that m$AyT, [or ma$aAyiyTu,] applied to camels, signifies assigned for slaughter; from $aATa said of a person's blood. (TA.)
musota$iyTN * (tropical:) A fat camel. (K.) [See 10.] ― -b2- (tropical:) Laughing exceedingly; (K;) laughing vehemently, like one exerting himself in his laughing. (ISh.)

1 $aAEa * , aor. ya$iyEu, (S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. $uyuwEN (O, Msb, K) and $ayoEuwEapN (S, O, K) and $ayoEN (K) and $ayaEaAnN and ma$aAEN, (O, K, the last, in the CK, ma$aAEap,) said of information, an announcement, a piece of news, or a narrative, or story, (TA,) or of a thing, (O, Msb,) It became spread, published, divulged, revealed, made known, or disclosed; (S, O, K, TA;) or it became apparent, or manifest; (Msb, TA;) fiY Aln~aAsi [among the people]; so as to reach every one, becoming equally known by the people, not known by some exclusively of others. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] $AE, aor. as above, said of a thing, signifies also (assumed tropical:) It became scattered, or dispersed; like $aE~a. (TA in art. $E.) You say, $AE All~abanu fiY AlmaA='i, (Msb,) or $AEt qaTorapN mina All~abani fiY AlmaA='i, and ↓ t$y~Et, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The milk, (Msb,) or the drop of milk, (TA,) became dispersed in the water, (Msb, TA,) and mixed: (Msb:) and fiyhi ↓ $ay~aEa likewise signifies it became dispersed in it. (TA.) And $AE Al$~ayobu, inf. n. $ayoEN and $iyaAEN and $ayaEaAnN and $uyuwEN and $uyuwEapN and ma$iyEN, (tropical:) Whiteness of the hair, or hoariness, appeared, and became scattered: and $AE fiyhi Al$~ayobu, inf. n. as above, (tropical:) Whiteness of the hair, or hoariness, spread upon him; as also ↓ t$y~Ehu [or t$y~E fiyhi, agreeably with what has been said above]. (TA.) And $AE AlS~adoEu fiY Alz~ujaAjapi (assumed tropical:) The crack spread, and became dispersed, in the glass, or glass vessel. (Th, TA.) And AlA_ibilu ↓ t$AyEt (assumed tropical:) The camels became scattered, or dispersed; or they scattered, or dispersed, themselves. (TA.) -A2- As trans. by means of bi: see 4, in two places. -A3- [It is also trans. by itself.] $aAEakumu Als~alaAmu is like the saying Ealayokumu Als~alaAmu [Safety, or peace, &c., be, or light and abide, on you]; (S, O, K;) but is only said by a man to his companions when he desires to quit them: (S, O:) or it means [may safety, &c.,] follow you: (O, K:) or, not quit you: (K:) whence, (TA,) one says also $aAEaka Alxayoru may prosperity not quit thee; and in like manner Lebeed says of praise (HamodN): (O, TA:) [and J says that] $AEhu, inf. n. $iyaAEN, signifies he, or it, followed him: (S:) or $AEkm AlslAm, (Yoo, O, K,) aor. ya$aAEukum, inf. n. $ayoEN, (Yoo, O,) means [may safety, &c.,] fill you: (Yoo, O, K:) [app. from what next follows.] ― -b2- One says also $iEotu AlA_inaA='a, (K, TA,) aor. A^a$iyEuhu, inf. n. $ayoEN, (TA,) I filled the vessel. (K, TA.)

2 $y~E fiyhi * : see 1. -A2- $y~E said of a pastor, He blew in the reed-pipe [called $iyaAE, by means of which the camels are called together]. (Lth, K, TA.) ― -b2- $y~E biAlA_ibili He (a pastor) called to the camels, whereupon they followed one another; (Msb;) in [some of] the copies of the K, i. q. A$A' bhA, [in the CK Aa$AbahA,] but correctly bihaA ↓ A^a$aAEa, (TA,) which means he called to the camels, (K in another part of the art., and TA,) when some of them remained, or lagged, behind: (TA:) and [in like manner] biA_ibilihi ↓ $AyE, (S, K,) inf. n. mu$aAyaEapN and $iyaAEN, (S,) he (a pastor, S) shouted and called to his camels, (S, K,) when some of them remained, or lagged, behind: (S:) or $y~E A_ibilahu he (a pastor) called out among his camels, whereupon they went along, following one another: (Mgh:) and $y~E Alganama he urged on the sheep, or goats, (K, * TA,) because of their lagging behind, (TA,) in order that they might follow the others. (K, TA.) [The last two phrases are app. from the second of the explanations here following.] ― -b3- $y~Ehu, inf. n. ta$oyiyEN,
also signifies He sent, or sent on, him, or it. (TA.) ― -b4- And He made him, or it, to follow. (TA.) ― -b5- [And He made it to be followed by another thing.] One says, $ay~aEotu ramaDaAna bisit~K mino $aw~aAlK [or rather bisit~apK] (assumed tropical:) I made [the fasting of] Ramadán to be followed by [the fasting of] six [days] of Showwál expl. by A^atobaEotuhu bihaA [a well-known phrase, of frequent occurrence, but one which I have not found in any of the lexicons, except in explanations; the approved phrase used in its stead being A^atobaEotuhu A_iy~aAhaA, lit. meaning “ I made them to follow it; ” this being virtually the same as “ I made it to be followed by them ”]: (Msb:) [and in like manner, the elliptical phrase] $y~E ramaDaAna, (K,) or $y~E $ahora ramaDaAna, (O, TA,) means He fasted after Rama- dán, or the month of Ramadán, six days; (O, K, TA;) i. e. A^atobaEahu bihaA. (TA.) ― -b6- $ay~aEotuhu Einoda raHiylihi (Lth, * S, O, Msb, K *) I went forth with him (Lth, O, Msb, K) on the occasion of his departure, (O, Msb,) namely, a guest, (Msb,) in order to bid him farewell, and to conduct him to his place of alighting, [app. meaning, to his first place of alighting,] (Lth, O, K,) or to show honour, or courtesy, to him; and I bade him farewell: (Msb:) or $y~E AlD~ayofa signifies he followed the guest [app. on the occasion of his departure, in order to bid him farewell, &c.]: (Mgh:) or $y~Ehu Einoda raHiylihi he went forth with him on the occasion of his departure, desiring to cheer him by his company to some place: and ↓ $AyEhu signifies the same. (TA.) ― -b7- [$y~Ehu sometimes signifies He followed him, not coming up with him, but always going behind him]. See Almu$ay~iEapu, voce mu$ay~aEN. ― -b8- [And He followed, or imitated, him; conformed, agreed, or complied, with him; like $aAyaEahu]. See 3, in three places. ― -b9- $y~E fulaAnFA (tropical:) He encouraged such a one, and emboldened him, (O, K, TA,) and strengthened him. (TA.) One says, fulaAnN yu$ay~iEuhu EalaY *`lika (tropical:) Such a one strengthens him to do that. (TA.) And $ay~aEa h`*aA bih`*aA (assumed tropical:) He strengthened this with this. (TA.) ― -b10- $y~Ehu Aln~aAra (tropical:) He threw, or put, firewood upon the fire to make it blaze or flame, burn up, or burn brightly or fiercely. (ISk, S, K, TA.) ― -b11- And $y~Ehu biAln~aAri (assumed tropical:) He burned him, or it, with fire. (S, K, TA.) Of anything that has been burned, one says, $uy~iEa. (TA.)

3 mu$aAyaEapN * primarily signifies The following another, or conforming with him, in, or as to, an affair, and an opinion; as also $iyaAEN; [an inf. n. of $AyEhu, like the former;] and so too signifies ↓ ta$ay~uEN [if not a mistranscription for ↓ ta$oyiyEN, which I rather think it to be, agreeably with what follows]: and the agreeing, or complying, with him, or obeying him. (TA.) You say, $AyEhu EalaY A^amorK, (Lth, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. mu$aAyaEapN (Msb) [and $iyaAEN], He followed him, or conformed with him, [&c.,] in, or as to, an affair: (Lth, O, Msb:) or he did so, and strengthened him; and likewise ElY raA^oYK in, or as to, an opinion; as also Ealayohi ↓ $y~Ehu, referring to an opinion [and an affair]. (TA.) And maA tu$aAyiEuniY rijoliY walaA saAqiY My leg does not conform with [my wish] nor aid me to walk, nor does my shank. (TA.) And $aAyaEatohu nafosuhu EalaY *`lika His soul conformed [or complied] with him, [i. e. with his wish,] and encouraged him, to do that; as also ↓ $ay~aEatohu. (L, TA.) ― -b2- Also (O, K) He befriended him, or was friendly to him; syn. waAlaAhu, (S, O, K,) from AlwaliY~u. (S.) ― -b3- $AyEhu Einoda raHiylihi: see 2, in the latter part of the paragraph. ― -b4- $AyE biA_ibilihi: see 2, near the beginning. [Hence, app.,] one says also, $aAyaEa bihimu Ald~aliylu faA^aboSaruwA AlhudaY The guide called to them [and they saw the right direction]. (TA.) -A2- Al$~iyaAEu occurs in a trad., as some relate it, and is expl. as there meaning AlmufaAxarapu bikavorapi AljimaAEi: but AA says that it is a mistranscription for Als~ibaAEu, with s and b; or that it may be from $aAEapN signifying “ a wife. ” (IAth, TA.)

4 A$AE Alxabara * , (S, O,) or Al$~aYo'a, (Msb, K,) or rather Als~ir~a, as in the L; (TA;) and A$AE bihi; (O, * K;) as also bihi ↓ $AE, first pers. $iEotu bh; (Msb, K;) He spread, published, divulged, revealed, made known, or disclosed, (S, O, K,) and (K) made apparent or manifest, (Msb, K,) the information, announcement, news, narrative, or story, (S, O,) or the thing, (Msb, K,) or the secret. (L, TA.) And A$AE *ikora Al$~aYo'i He made the mention, or fame, of the thing to fly [abroad, or to spread]. (TA.) ― -b2- A^a$aEotu AlmaAla bayona Alqawomi (assumed tropical:) I dispersed, or distributed, the property among the people, or party; and Alqidora fiY AlHaY~i the [contents of] the cooking-pot among the tribe. (A 'Obeyd, TA.) [See also its pass. part. n.] ― -b3- A$AEt bibawolihaA (assumed tropical:) She (a camel) ejected her urine, (S, K,) scattering it, (K,) and stopped it; (S, K; expl. in the K in two places;) but this is only when the stallion has leaped her, and is only said in relation to camels; and bbwlhA ↓ A$tAEt signifies the same: and in like manner A$AE is said of a he-camel. (TA.) ― -b4- A^a$aAEakumu A@ll~`hu Als~alaAma, (S, O,) or biAls~alaAmi, (K,) or both, (TA,) as also A@ll~`hu biAls~alaAmi ↓ $aAEakumu, (K,) May God make safety, or peace, &c., [to light and abide upon you, or] to accompany and follow you. (S, O, K. [See also 1, latter half.]) ― -b5- A$AE biAlA_ibili: see 2. ― -b6- [A$AEt is also expl. in the TA as meaning xrjt: but I suspect a mistranscription or an omission in this case.]

5 ta$ay~aEa see 1, in two places. ― -b2- t$y~E said of a man, (S, O,) He asserted himself to hold the tenets of the $iyEap [q. v.]: (S, O, K, KL, TA:) or he became a $iyaEiY~: a verb similar to taHan~afa and ta$af~aEa. (TA.) -A2- [Accord. to Golius, it is expl. in the KL as meaning He left a portion of a thing undistributed: but this explanation is not in my copy of that work.] ― -b2- t$y~E fiY Al$~aYo'i He strove, or laboured, or he distressed himself, or he courted death, (Aisotaholaka,) in his love of the thing. (TA.) -A3- t$y~Ehu AlgaDabu Anger excited him to lightness, levity, or unsteadiness; or flurried, or disquieted, him. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 3, first sentence.

6 t$AyEt AlA_ibilu * : see 1. ― -b2- t$AyEwA is from Al$~iyEapu, (S, O,) and signifies They became $iyaE [i. e. separate parties, &c., pl. of $iyEapN, q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b3- And They went, or went along, together. (KL.) ― -b4- [See also the part. n., voce $ay~iEN.]
8 A$tAEt bibawolihaA * , said of a she-camel: see 4. ― -b2- [See also the part. n., voce $ay~iEN.]

$aAEN * , originally $aAy^iEN: see the latter word. ― -b2- Also The urine of the she-camel, that becomes scattered when the stallion leaps her. (As, O, K.) And, (As, O, [accord. to the K “ or, ”] The urine of the he-camel when he is excited by lust. (As, O, K.)

$ayoEN *
A space [of time]. (S, O, K.) One says, A^aqaAma fulaAnN $ahorFA A^awo $ayoEahu (S, O) i. e. Such a one remained, or stayed, a month or the space thereof: or nearly the space thereof. (TA.) ― -b2- One says also, A=tiyka gadFA A^awo $ayoEahu I will come to thee to-morrow or after it: (S, O, K:) or to-morrow or the day after it. (L, TA.) ― -b3- And h`*aA $ayoEu h`*aA This is he that was born next after this; like $awoEuhu: (S, O, K, all in art. $wE:) or this is the like of this. (A 'Obeyd, O and K in the present art.) ― -b4- $ayoEN signifies also A follower: and a friend, or a comrade, or an assistant. (KL.) ― -b5- And A lion's whelp: (Lth, IDrd, S, O, K:) or when he has attained to taking prey; so in the L: and some say the lion [himself]. (TA.) -A2- See also $aAy^iEN.

$iyEu nisaA='K *
One who follows after women, and mixes, associates, or converses, with them. (K, * TA.)

$aAEapN *
A wife: because she follows, or conforms with, [the wishes of] her husband. (Sh, O, K, TA.) -A2- See also $aAy^iEN.

$ayoEapN *
A certain tree, (O, K,) below the stature of a man, having knotted, or jointed, rods, and small, dark-red blossoms, smaller than the jasmine: (O:) the bees feed upon it; (O, K;) and men eat its tender extremities, being rendered healthy, or sound, thereby; (yataSaH~aHuwna bihi;) and it has a hot quality in the mouth; and is sweet in odour: (O:) clothes become sweet-scented by adhering to it, (O, K, * TA,) i. e. to its blossom, agreeably with what is said in the “ Book of Plants, ” not to the tree, to which the pronoun refers in the O and K; (TA;) and its honey is clear, (O, K,) very clear, and is well known: it is a pasture; and grows in the plains, and near to seed-produce. (O.)

$iyEapN *
A separate, or distinct, party, or sect, (O, K, TA,) of men: this is the primary signification: so called from their agreeing together, and following one another: or, accord. to some, the Y is originally w, and it is from $uw~aEa qawomahu, which means “ he collected his people or party: ”
(TA:) the followers and assistants (S, O, Msb, K) of a man: (S, O, K:) any people that have combined in, or for, an affair: (Msb, TA:) accord. to Az, persons who follow, or conform with, one another, [though] not all of them agreeing together: (TA:) and any assistant and partisan of a man: (O, TA:) [for] the word is applied to one and to two and to a pl. number and to the male and to the female, (K, TA,) without variation: (TA:) the pl. is $iyaEN and A^a$oyaAEN, (S, * O, Msb, K,) the latter a pl. pl.; (Msb;) and the former is applied to any people, or party, whose affair, or case, is one, who follow one another's opinion. (S.) The saying, in the Kur [xxxiv. last verse], kamaA fuEila biA^a$oyaAEihimo mino qabolu means As was done with the likes of them, of the same persuasion as they, of the peoples that have gone before: (S, * TA:) and similar to this is the saying in the Kur liv. 51. (TA.) ― -b2- Afterwards, Al$~iyEapu became a name of A particular party [or sect]; (Msb, K;) being predominantly applied to all who took as their friends, or lords, 'Alee and the people of his house: (K:) those who followed 'Alee, saying that he was the [rightful] Imám after the Apostle of God, and believing that the office of Imám should not depart from him and his descendants: (KT:) they are an innumerable people, who are innovators; the extravagant zealots among them are the Imámeeyek, who revile the Two Sheykhs [Aboo-Bekr and 'Omar]; and the most extravagant of them call the Two Sheykhs disbelievers: some of them rise to the pitch of [that misbelief which is termed] Alz~anodaqap [q. v.]. (TA.) [It is also applied to A single person of this party, or sect; agreeably with what has been said above; and such a person is likewise called ↓ $iyaEiY~N: see 5.]
$iyaEiY~N * : see the next preceding sentence.

[
$iyaEiy~apN * and $iyoEiy~apN The way of doctrine and practice, or the system of tenets, of the sect called Al$~iyEapu.]
$ayaAEN * : see the next paragraph.

$iyaAEN * The reed-pipe of the pastor; (IAar, O, K;) the instrument with which the pastor blows; so named because he calls together the camels with it: (A, TA:) or the sound of the pastor's reed-pipe. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- And Callers, or summoners; syn. duEaApN, (O, K,) pl. of daAEK: (K:) in the Tekmileh, duEaA=' [a call, or calling, &c.]. (TA.) -A2- Also, (S, O, K,) and ↓ $ayaAEN, (O, K,) but the former is the more chaste, (O, [and the same is implied in the K,]) (tropical:) Slender firewood, with which a fire is made to blaze or flame, burn up, or burn brightly or fiercely: (S, O, K, TA:) and ↓ $ayuwEN signifies [the same, i. e.] slender firewood (AHn, O, K) that is quickly kindled by a weak fire, so that it prevails over the thick, or large, firewood. (AHn, O.)
$ayuwEN * : see next preceding sentence.

$ay~iEN *
A sharer, or partner: (TA:) pl. $uyaEaA='u. (O, K, TA.) One says, humo $uyaEaA='u fiyhaA [They are sharers, or partners, in it, i. e. a house (daAr) or land;] i. e. every one of them is a $ay~iE to his fellow [or fellows]. (O, K.) And ↓ humaA muta$aAyiEaAni fiY daArK, (O, K,) or A^aroDK; (O;) and ↓ mu$otaAEaAni, (O, TA,) in the copies of the K, erroneously, muta$aAEaAni; (TA;) They two are sharers, or partners, in a house, (O, K,) or land. (O.) ― -b2- And Ald~aAru $ay~iEapN bayonahumo The house is undivided [i. e. shared] among them; syn. ↓ mu$aAEapN. (O, K. [See also $aAy^iEN.])

$aAy^iEN * Information, an announcement, a piece of news, a narrative, or a story, spreading; or becoming spread, published, divulged, revealed, made known, disclosed, apparent, or manifest; fiY Aln~aAsi [among the people]; so as to reach every one, becoming equally known by the people, not known by some exclusively of others: (TA:) and ↓ $aAEapN [is app. a pl. thereof, like as baAEapN is of baAy^iEN, signifying, or so A^axobaArN $aAEapN,] news, or tidings, &c., spreading, or becoming spread. (IAar, O, K.) ― -b2- [(assumed tropical:) A thing scattered, or dispersed, or in a state of dispersion: fem. with p: pl. of the latter $awaAy^iEu; which may also be pl. of the former applied to a rational being, like fawaArisu pl. of faArisN.] One says, jaA='ati Alxayolu $awaAy^iEa (assumed tropical:) The horsemen came scattered, or dispersed, or in a state of dispersion; as also $awaAEiYa, formed by transposition. (TA. [But the latter is also mentioned as belonging to art. $Ew.]) ― -b3- Also A lot, share, or portion, (sahomN, S O, Msb, K, and naSiybN, TA,) undivided; and so ↓ $aAEN, (S, O, K, TA,) like as one says saAy^iru Al$~aYo'i and saAruhu; (S, O;) and ↓ mu$aAEN; (S, K;) [i. e. shared in common; as though] spread; (TA;) so called because mixed, not being separated: (Msb:) [and it seems, from the usage of a phrase in art. xlT of the K, (Almu$aAriku fiY Al$uyuwEi,) that ↓ $ayoEN, as sing. of $uyuwEN, signifies an undivided portion.] ― -b4- Also Anything that is a supplement to a thing: or an addition, or augment, thereto. (TA.)
mu$aAEN * ; and its fem., with p: see $aAy^iEN and $ay~iEN.

ma$iyEN *
Filled; (O, K;) applied to a vessel. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) Very rancorous, malevolent, malicious, or spiteful; filled with baseness, meanness, or sordidness. (K, TA. [In the CK, erroneously said to be, in this sense, mi$oyaE, like makoyal; instead of ma$iyE, like makiyl.]) Hence also, huwa Dab~N ma$iyEN (assumed tropical:) He is [like a lizard of the kind called Db~ that is] very rancorous, &c. (TA.) IAar says, I heard Abu-l-Mekárim revile a man, saying, huwa xab~N ma$iyEN, [perhaps correctly Dab~N, but see this word, which is used as a syn. sequent to xab~N,] meaning He is like a Dab~ that is very rancorous, &c., and unprofitable; (O, TA;) ma$iyEN, here, being with fet-h to the m; (O;) from $iEotuhu “ I filled it. ” (O, TA.)

mi$oyaEapN *
A quf~ap [or kind of basket, of palmleaves,] in which a woman puts her cotton and other things: (IDrd, O, L, K:) so called because it accompanies and follows her. (TA.)

mi$oyaAEN *
One who will not keep, or conceal, a secret; or one who is unable to conceal his information, news, or tidings; [a babbler of secrets &c.;] syn. mi*oyaAEN. (S, O, K.)

mu$ay~aEN * (tropical:) Courageous: (S, O, K, TA:) as though he were encouraged and emboldened and strengthened by another, or encouraged and emboldened by the strength of his heart: (O, K:) or whose heart is encouraged and emboldened by every formidable affair in which he has embarked. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) Very quick or speedy or hasty. (Ibn-'Abbád, Z, O, K.) ― -b3- Almu$ay~aEapu, in a trad. relating to sheep or goats to be slaughtered as victims on the day of sacrifice, in which trad. such are forbidden, (O, Msb, K,) means the sheep or goat (Mgh) that requires one to urge it on after the [other] sheep or goats, (Mgh, O, Msb, K,) because of its weakness (Mgh, K) and leanness, (Mgh,) or because of its lack of strength to follow them: (O:) or, as some relate it, the word is ↓ Almu$ay~iEapu, (Mgh, O, Msb, K,) meaning that ceases not to follow the [other] sheep or goats, (Alganama ↓ laA tazaAlu tu$ay~iEu, O, K, * i. e. tatobaEuhaA, Mgh, O, K,) or that ceases not to lag behind the [other] sheep or goats, (Msb,) not coming up with them, (Mgh, TA,) but always going behind them, (TA,) because of its leanness; (Mgh, Msb, K;) from $ay~aEa AlD~ayofa [expl. above (see 2)]; (Mgh;) or as though urging on the [other] sheep or goats. (Msb.)
Almu$ay~iEapu * : see what next precedes.

mu$aAyiEN *
Overtaking, or coming up with another or others; or one that overtakes, &c.: (S, K, TA:) as in the saying of Lebeed,
kamaA Dam~a A^uxoraY Alt~aAliyaAti Almu$aAyiEu
[Like as he that overtakes collects together the last of those cattle that go behind the others]. (TA.)
mu$otaAEN * : see the dual of each, voce $ay~iEN.
muta$aAyiEN * : see the dual of each, voce $ay~iEN.
2 $y~f Ald~awaA='a * [from $iyaAfN]: see 2 in art. $wf.

$iyfN * The prickles ($awok) that are at the back of the Easiyb [or leafless portion, next above the lowest and thickest part, of the branch] of the palm-tree: (O, K:) so says AHát: (O:) but Lth says that the word is [siyfN, q. v.,] with the unpointed s. (TA.)
$iyaAfN * , originally $iwaAfN: see art. $wf.
$iy~ifapN * and $iy~ifaAnN: see art. $wf.
1 $iqotu AlT~unuba A_ilaY Alwatidi * , (S,) inf. n. $ayoqN, (TA,) is like nuTotuhu. (S.) [See 1 (last sentence but one) in art. $wq.]

$iyqN *
A mountain: (IAar, S:) or the highest part of a mountain: (Skr, O, K:) or a part that is even, (Lth, O, K,) and small in breadth, in the face of a mountain, resembling a wall, (fiY lihobi jabalK,) (Lth, O,) that cannot be ascended: (Lth, O, K: *) or the most difficult place in a mountain. (S, O, K.) A poet says, cited as using it in the last sense,
$agowaA='u tawTinu bayona Al$~iyqi waAln~iyqi
[An eagle dwelling between the most difficult place in a mountain and the highest part thereof]. (S, O.) See also a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb cited voce xaAfapN, in art. xwf. ― -b2- A long, or tall, mountain; (jabalN TawiylN;) (K;) thus accord. to some in the verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb. (TA.) ― -b3- And accord. to some, it signifies in that verse (TA) A narrow cleft in a mountain: or in the head thereof: or a cleft between two rocks. (K, TA.) ― -b4- A side; syn. jaAnibN. (Skr, O, K.) One says, AimotalA^a mina Al$~iyqi A_ilaY Al$~iyqi It became filled from side to side. (TA.) -A2- The head [or glans] of the penis. (IAar, O, K.) -A3- The hair of a horse's tail: n. un. with p. (IAar, O, K.) -A4- A species of fish. (IAar, O, K.) ― -b2- The aquatic bird [or rather birds] called burak [pl. of burokapN, q. v.]: (K:) n. un. with p. (TA. [In the K, $iyqapN is mentioned in another place as meaning a certain aquatic bird: and in the O as meaning a species of aquatic birds.]) -A5- And accord. to Ibn- 'Abbád, i. q. kitaAbN [A writing, or book, &c.]. (O.) -A6- See also art. $wq.
$iyaAqN * : see art. $wq.
$ay~iqN * : see art. $wq.

1 $ayolN * is a bad [or vulgar] dial. var. of $awolN: one says, $ilotu bihi, [and now, more commonly, $ilotuhu, like $ulotuhu, meaning I raised it; and, as now used, I lifted it; and hence, I removed it, or took it away; and I carried it; and I loaded it, namely, luggage upon a beast &c.;] aor. A^a$iylu, inf. n. $ayolN and ma$oyalN, the latter [in measure] like maqoEadN. (TA.)
$iyaAlapN * The occupation of the $ay~aAl, i. e. porter, or carrier of burdens. (TA.)
$uy~alN * and $iy~alN pls. of $aAy^ilN. (K in art. $wl, in which see the singular.)
$ay~aAlN * , from $ilotu bihi [expl. above], A porter, or carrier of burdens. (TA.)

farasN mi$oyaAlu Alxaloqi *
A horse incongruous, unsound, faulty, or weak, in make: (AO, O and TA in the present art.:) mentioned in the L in art. $wl. (TA.)

1 $aAma Al$~aYo'a fiY Al$~aYo'i * , (K,) [aor. ya$iymu,] inf. n. $ayomN, (TA,) He hid, or concealed, the thing in the thing: (K, TA:) and he inserted the thing in the thing. (TA.) [Hence,] $Am sayofahu, (K,) first pers. $imotuhu, (S,) aor. as above, (K,) inf. n. $ayomN, (TA,) He sheathed his sword; (S, K;) and [in like manner] $Am nabolahu [He put his arrows into the quiver]: (TA:) and the former signifies also He drew his sword: thus having two contr. meanings: (S, K:) A 'Obeyd doubted of the latter meaning; and Sh knew it not; but the verb is said to have this meaning in a verse of ElFarezdak. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Aboo-Bekr that a complaint was made to him against Khálid Ibn-El-Weleed, and he said, laA A^a$iymu sayofFA sal~ahu A@ll~`hu EalaY Almu$orikiyna i. e. I will not sheath a sword [which God has drawn against the believers in a plurality of gods]. (TA.) [Hence also,] one says, $Am A^abaA EumayorK (K, TA) i. e. [He sheathed] the *akar; (TA;) meaning (assumed tropical:) he attained his desire of the virgin. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And $Am fiY Alfarasi saAqahu He struck the mare with his shank to make her run: (K:) or he impressed (lit. inserted) his leg [or shank] in the belly of the mare, striking her [with it]. (Aboo-Málik; TA.) -A2- $imotu maxaAyila Al$~aYo'i I directed my look towards the indications, or symptoms, of the thing, waiting, or watching, for it. (S.) ― -b2- And [hence, or the reverse may be the case,] $imotu Albaroqa, (S, Msb, K, *) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Msb, TA,) I looked at, (S, K, *) or watched, or observed, (Msb,) the lightning, (Msb, K,) or the cloud thereof, to see where it would rain, (S,) or to see where it would pour, or bring rain, (Msb,) or to see whither it tended and where it would rain: (K:) this is done only when it flickers and disappears without delay: and [it is said, but, in my opinion, fancifully, and with little reason, that] the drawing and sheathing of a sword are likened to lightning flickering and disappearing. (TA.) [Hence the phrase, $imotu baroqa fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) I looked hoping for the benefits of such a one: mentioned by Freytag on the authority of Meyd: and the like is said in Har p. 319.] And $Am Als~aHaAba He looked at the clouds from afar: and [in like manner,] Aln~aAra the fire. (TA.) It is said in a prov.,
laA ta$imi Algayova faqado A^awodaY Aln~aqado
i. e. [Look not thou hoping for rain, for] the lambs have perished: addressed to him who mourns for that which has past. (Meyd.) And one says, fulaAnN muwsirN walaA A^a$iymuhu mino faqorK (assumed tropical:) [Such a one is wealthy, and I do not look at him in hope by reason of poverty]; meaning that he is independent of him. (Z, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] $imo maA bayonahumaA (tropical:) Compute thou, or estimate, or consider, (K, TA,) and look, or see, (TA,) what [relation, or difference,] is between them two. (K, TA. [In the CK, $ay~ama is erroneously put for $imo; and qad~arahu, in the explanation, for qad~irohu.]) -A3- $aAma also signifies It (a thing, TA) entered, fiY $aYo'K into a thing; (K, TA;) quasi-pass. of the same verb in the latter of the two senses expl. in the first sentence of this art.; (TA;) and so ↓ An$Am, (S, K, TA,) and ↓ A$Am, and ↓ A$tAm, and ↓ t$y~m, and ↓ $y~m. (K, TA.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. $ayomN and $uyuwmN, He made a valid charge, or assault, or attack, in war, or battle. (K.) -A4- Also, (K,) aor. as above, (TA,) He (a man) had a black raqomap [app. meaning spot, or mole, i. e. $aAmap,] apparent in his skin. (K.) And $iyma, inf. n. $ayomN, [perhaps a mistranscription for $ayamN,] He was marked with a $aAmap [or mole]: or, as some say, [the pass. part. n.] ma$oyuwmN [signifying “ marked with a $Amp ”] has no verb: and AZ says that ↓ $ayamN, signifying the having upon him a $Amp, has no known verb: (TA:) or $ayamN is an inf. n. signifying the having upon him $aAm [i. e. moles]. (Ham p. 361.) -A5- $aAma fulaAnFA, (K,) aor. as above, (TA,) He soiled the legs, or feet, of such a one with dust, or earth: (K, TA:) in [some of] the copies of the K, gay~ara rijolayohi biAl$~iyaAmi; but correctly, [as in the CK and in my MS copy of the K,] gab~ara; and accord. to the M, from Al$~iyaAm, [meaning that the verb is derived from this word,] i. e. Alt~uraAb. (TA.)
2 $ay~ama see 1, in the latter half. -A2- $y~m yadayohi fiY raA^osihi, or vawobihi, He seized his head, or his garment, fighting him. (K.)
4 A^a$oyama see 1, in the latter half.

5 ta$ay~ama see 1, in the latter half. ― -b2- t$y~mhu AlD~iraAmu The kindling of fire entered it; namely, a wood; as used in a verse of Sá'ideh: or, as some relate it, tasan~amahu [q. v.]. (S, TA.) And t$y~m AlHariyqu AlqaSaba The fire entered, and mixed with, the reeds, or canes. (TA.) ― -b3- And t$y~mhu Al$~ayobu (tropical:) Hoariness came upon him, (K, TA,) and became intermixed upon him: or, accord. to IAar, became abundant upon him, and spread; (TA;) as also tasan~amahu. (IAar, M and TA in art. snm.) -A2- t$y~m A^abaAhu He resembled his father in $iymp i. e. nature, or natural disposition. (IAar, K, TA.)
7 An$Am * : see 1, in the latter half. -A2- Also He (a man) became one who was looked at. (S, K.)
8 A_i$otayama see 1, in the latter half.
$aAmN * : see $aAmapN, in three places. -A2- The country of Al$~aAm [i. e. Syria] has been mentioned in art. $A^m [as originally Al$~aA^om].

$iymN *
A certain species of fish. (S, K. *) -A2- Also pl. of A^a$oyamu [q. v.]. (S, TA.) -A3- And pl., in one sense, of $iyaAmN [q. v.]. (K.)

$ayamN * : see 1, near the end. -A2- Also Any land, or ground, in which one has not yet dug, remaining in its [original] hard state, (Aboo-Sa'eed, K, TA,) so that the digging therein is more difficult [than elsewhere] to the digger. (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA.)

$aAmapN *
A mole, syn. xaAlN, (S, Msb, TA,) upon the person; (Msb;) [i. e.] a pimple inclining to blackness, upon the person; (Mgh;) or a [natural] mark differing from the colour of the person upon which it is: (K, * TA:) its medial radical letter is originally Y: (S, TA:) and it is
also with ', i. e. $aA^omapN: (IAth, TA:) pl. ↓ $aAmN, (S, Msb, K,) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] and [the pl. properly so termed is] $aAmaAtN. (Msb, K.) Hat~aY takuwnuwA kaA^an~akumo $aAmapN fiY Aln~aAsi [So that ye may be as though ye were a mole amid the people], occurring in a trad., means [that ye may] be in the goodliest garb or guise, appearing like the $Amp, at which one looks exclusively of the rest of the person. (IAth, TA.) And one says, ↓ SaAruwA $aAmFA fiY AlbilaAdi, meaning (assumed tropical:) They became scattered [in the countries] like the $Am [or moles] upon the person. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A black mark upon the person, [an explanation which seems to apply, like the former in the K, to a mole, though given as differing therefrom,] and upon the ground: pl. [or coll. gen. n.] ↓ $aAmN. (K.) ― -b3- It is also [A mark, or spot,] upon a mare, upon a place that is disapproved, and sometimes upon her dawaAy^ir [which means what are termed feathers, pl. of daAy^irapN, q. v.]. (ISh, TA.) ― -b4- And A spot (nukotap) [upon the face] of the moon. (K.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) A black she-camel: (IAar, S, K, TA:) accord. to Niftaweyh, $aA^omapN, with; but ISd says, I know not the reason of this, unless it be extr., like AlxaA^otamu and AlEaA^olimu. (TA.) One says, maA lahu $aAmapN walaA zahoraA='u, meaning, (tropical:) He has not a black she-camel nor a white one. (S, K, TA.)

$iymapN *
Nature; natural, native, or innate, disposition, temper, or other quality or property; (S, Msb, K;) as also $iy^omapN, (K,) which is an extr. dial. var.: (TA:) pl. $iyamN. (Msb.) -A2- Also Dust, or earth, dug from the ground; (As, S, K;) and so ↓ $iyaAmN. (S, as on the authority of As; but only in one of my two copies of the S.)

$ayaAmN *
Soft, or plain, land; (AA, K, TA;) of which the earth is soft, or uncompact. (TA.) ― -b2- See also the paragraph here following, in two places.

$iyaAmN *
Dust, or earth, (K, TA,) in a general sense; (TA;) as also ↓ $ayaAmN: (K:) see also $iymapN: [or,] accord. to Kh, a hollow dug in the ground: or, as some say, land of which the earth is soft, or uncompact. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And A [covert such as is termed] kinaAs: so called because of the wild animal's entering (lAino$iyaAmi AlwaHo$i i. e. duxuwlihi) into it. (As, S, TA.) -A2- Also The rat, or mouse; syn. faA^orN: (IAar, K, TA:) but written by Aboo-'Amr Ez-Záhid ↓ $ayaAmN, and said by him to be the jura* [generally meaning a large field-rat]: (TA:) pl. $iymN. (K.)

qawomN $uyuwmN *
A people, or party, in a state of security: occurring in a trad.: and it is said that $ywm is an Abyssinian word: but, as some relate the trad., it is suyuwmN [q. v., voce saAy^imN, of which it is said to be pl.]. (TA.)

A^a$oyamu * A man (S, Msb) having a $aAmap [or mole] upon his person; (AZ, S, Mgh, Msb, K; *) and ↓ ma$iymN (S, K) and ↓ ma$uwmN (K) and ↓ ma$oyuwmN (S, K) signify the same [or rather marked with a mole]: (S, * K:) or A^a$oyamu signifies having upon him $aAm [or moles]: (Ham p. 361:) fem. $ayomaA='u: (TA:) and pl. $iymN. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And A beast, (Lth, AO, TA,) and anything, (Lth, TA,) having upon him, or it, a [mark such as is termed] $aAmap, (Lth, AO, TA,) or [marks such as are termed] $aAm. (AO, TA.) ― -b3- And $iymu AlA_ibili (assumed tropical:) Such as are black, of camels: sing., masc. and fem., as above: (TA:) occurring in this sense in a verse of Aboo-Dhueyb, as related by AA: but as heard by As, in this verse, $uwmuhaA, and thought by him to be a pl. [originally $uyom] of A^a$oyamu. (S.) See also A^a$oA^amu (in art. $A^m), last sentence.
ma$uwmN * : see the next preceding paragraph. -A2- And see ma$ow^uwmN, in art. $A^m.
ma$iymN * : see A^a$oyamu: -A2- and see also the paragraph here next following.

ma$iymapN * The giros; (S, TA;) i. e. (TA) the place of, (K, TA,) or [membrane that encloses, or forms the] covering of, (Msb,) the fœtus (Msb, K, TA) of a human being: (Msb: [see girosN:]) originally ma$oyimapN: (S, Msb:) pl. ma$aAyimu (S, K) and [coll. gen. n.] ↓ ma$iymN. (IB, K.) [See also salFY.]
ma$oyuwmN * : see A^a$oyamu.

1 $aAnahu * , aor. ya$iynuhu, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. $ayonN, (S, * Msb, TA,) He, or it, disgraced him, or dishonoured him; rendered him ugly or unseemly, disfigured him, or blemished him; (MA, PS;) i. q. EaAbahu; (Msb, TA;) contr. of zaAnahu; (S, * K;) [and ↓ $y~nhu, inf. n. ta$oyiynN, signifies the same, (the verb alone rendered by Freytag, on the authority of Meyd, “ dehonestavit, ”) like as the contr. zy~nhu signifies the same as zaAnahu.] ― -b2- The saying of Lebeed,
ya$iynu SaHaAHa Albiydi kul~a Ea$iy~apK
biEuwji Als~araA='i Einoda baAbK muHaj~abi
[They deface what is unmarred of the deserts, every evening, with the crooked things (i. e. the bows) of the wood of the tree called saraA=', at a veiled door, (referring to a company of men, and therefore the verb is sing.,)] means that they vie, one with another, in glorying, or boasting, and make marks, or lines, with their bows, upon the ground, as though they disfigured it ($aAnuwhaA) with those marks, or lines. (S.)
2 $ay~ana see 1. -A2- $y~n $iynFA HasanFA (T, TA) or HasanapF (K) He made, (Th, TA,) or wrote, (K,) a beautiful $. (Th, K, TA.)

$ayonN * is the contr. of zayonN: (S, Msb;) and ↓ ma$aAyinu [in the CK ma$Ay^in] is an anomalous pl. thereof: (TA:) the latter signifies Disgraces or dishonours, i. e. things, or qualities, that cause to be disgraced or dishonoured; things that render ugly or unseemly, that disfigure, or that blemish; syn. maEaAyibu, (S, K, TA,) and maqaAbiHu; (S, TA;) on the authority of Fr.: (TA:) [↓ $aAy^inapN, also, signifies the same; and its pl. is $awaAy^inu;] one says h`*ihi $aAy^inapN mina Al$~awaAy^ini [This is one of the things that disgrace or dishonour, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- [It is also used as epithet, like as is its contr. zayonN:] one says, wajohuhu $ayonN, i. e. His face is ugly, or unseemly; for *uw $ayonK; mentioned by Az. (TA.)

$iynN *
One of the letters of the alphabet, (S, K,) [i. e. the name of that letter; (see art. $,)] of the letters termed mahomuwsap [expl. in art. $], with somewhat of Alt~anogiym and Alt~ago$iyap [app. meaning that kind of utterance which is undertoned, and muffled, exactly like our “ sh ”], its place of utterance being the $ajor, i. e. the place of the opening of the mouth, (K, TA,) near the place of utterance of j: masc. [as meaning a Harof, or letter], and fem. [as meaning a kalimap, or word]: pl. A^a$oyaAnN and $yAnAt [a mistranscription for $iynaAtN]. (TA.) -A2- Also, thus with kesr, A man having many riqaAE [i. e. patches in his garment, pl. of ruqoEapN]. (Kh, TA.) -A3- And A long marokab [app. meaning ship or boat]. (TA.)
fiEolN $aAy^inN * [An action that disgraces or dishonours, &c.]. (TA.)
$aAy^inapN * [a subst. from $aAy^inN]: see $ayonN.

ma$iynN *
Disgraced, or dishonoured; rendered ugly or unseemly, disfigured, or blemished; pass. part. n. of 1. (Msb.)
ma$aAyinu * an anomalous pl. of $ayonN, q. v. (TA.)
1 $aAhahu * , aor. ya$iyhuhu, (K,) inf. n. $ayohN, (TA,) i. q. EaAnahu, (Ibn-Buzurj, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously EAbahu,]) i. e. He smote him with the [evil] eye. (TA.) [See also 1 in art. $wh.]
$ayohN * and $iyhN: see $aApN (of which they are quasipl. ns.) in art. $wh.
$iyaAhN * : see $aApN (of which it is a pl.) in art. $wh.

$ayuwhN *
That smites vehemently with the [evil] eye. (Ibn-Buzurj, K, TA. [In the CK, EayuwbN is erroneously put for EayuwnN.])
$ay~ihN * : see $aApN (of which it is a quasi-pl. n.) in art. $wh.

A^a$oyahu * [More, and most, wont to smite with the evil eye]. One says, huwa mino A^a$oyahi Aln~aAsi [He is of the most wont, of men, to smite with the evil eye: this meaning being indicated by the context]. (Ibn-Buzurj, K, TA.)
